child_mcqs.description: Hearing is one of the first senses to be called upon in the blind, and becomes highly developed, but/and...
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 4 is correct. The author specifically quotes others as making a note between the natural capacity, and the increased ability to use that capacity as two distinct things. In the blind, it is the increased ability to use that natural capacity, rather than an increase in the natural capacity, that results in highly developed hearing

answers.description: The reason it becomes highly developed is still unknown
The reason it becomes highly developed is because the hearing apparatus acquires increased sensory capacity due to frequent use
The reason it becomes highly developed is because the hearing apparatus hypertrophies in response to increased use
The reason it becomes highly developed is because the blind acquires an increased ability to use the natural capacity of the hearing apparatus

child_mcqs.description: The author finds the use of touch to sense the environment, especially by those who’ve been blind from a young age, to be:
child_mcqs.explanation: The fourth paragraph evinces the author's sense of wonder at children's use of the sense of touch to describe their environment. That the author is able to go into great depth about these matters casts doubts on option A. Similarly, although the author 'wonders how' deaf-blind children can navigate with neither sense, it is through a sense of awe rather than genuine puzzlement, as the article has provided the reasoning why they are so effective at doing so.

child_mcqs.description: From the author’s viewpoint, the sense of smell:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the final paragraph, the author goes into great detail about the impact of smell in forming connections with the human and natural world. Answer 2 best accommodates this information. The author does not limit the usess of smell, precluding Answer 1, nor does she give any recommendations or regrets, precluding Answers 3 and 4.

answers.description: Is a sense that is only useful for navigation purposes in daily life
Is a sense that provides a powerful emotive connection to the world
Is a sense that is extremely powerful in identifying places and people but should not be abused for pleasure or for boastfulness
Is a sense that is exceedingly helpful and provides a powerful connection to the world, but laments not having refined it herself

child_mcqs.description: Overall, the purpose of the passage is:
child_mcqs.explanation: In total, the text is a deep reflection of the author on the impact of the loss of one sense, and the development of those that remain. In so doing, it does more than attempting to convince the reader that blind people are 'normal', it provides an honest explanation of life without sight, and decreases the need for amazement at what can be achieved by the other senses. Answer 1 is the best option.

answers.description: To paint picture in the reader’s mind of what a blind person perceives, and correct common misconceptions and misunderstood amazement
To explore the psychology behind what a blind person perceives and the emotive reactions induced
To explore how blind people interact socially
To convince the reader that blind people are normal human beings

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
The following is an excerpt from Making Modern Migraine Medieval: Men of Science, Hildegard of Bingen, and the Life of a Retrospective Diagnosis which was published in Medical History.

The issue of retrospective diagnosis has long exercised historians of medicine. Do histories that mine the past for symptoms or traces corresponding to current medical knowledge tell us anything about medical history? Or should we write histories that respect and contextualise historical knowledge on its own terms? This approach accepts, in Andrew Cunningham’s words, that ‘you die of what your doctor says you die of’, however outdated these contemporary pronouncements might now seem to our modern gaze. While practitioners of retrospective diagnosis consider the employment of modern biomedical categories as a perfectly valid way to talk about disease in the past, others have criticised the practice’s tendency to reduce the lives of individuals to ‘the mere expression of disease’. Roger Cooter, for example, has dismissed retrospective diagnosis as ‘inherently condescending’. The discussion about how to approach histories of disease and illness has re-emerged with renewed vigour in recent years with the publication of a slew of disease ‘biographies’.

We might usefully think of retrospective diagnosis practice as a broad spectrum, whose ends bear little similarity to each other. At one end of the scale well-funded paleopathology research groups utilise expensive scientific technology to identify pathogens in archaeological remains. High-profile examples of this include the 1976 examination of the mummy of Ramses II by French scientists who wished to prove that the Egyptian pharaoh died from tuberculosis. The question of whether or not the pathogenYersinia pestis was responsible for the ravages of the Black Death in the medieval and early-modern period almost constitutes a sub-discipline. Recently, Monica Green has emphasised the value of cross-disciplinary collaborations that take the biological materiality of disease seriously on both global and deep chronological scales. Combining scientific disciplines including paleopathology and genetics with professional history offers a very different kind of disease work than the ‘parlour game’ that imposes various illnesses on historical figures through the interpretation of texts, artefacts, images and commentary. Was King George III’s madness actually porphyria? Did Nietzsche have syphilis? These kinds of diagnoses have widely been criticised; Caroline Walker Bynum’s discussion in Holy Feast and Holy Fast (1987) regarding whether medieval women can be said to have had ‘anorexia’ remains one of the most convincing explorations of the problems and implications of making such a diagnosis if our aim is to understand a period historically. In particular, Bynum criticised a tendency to assume that we can identify either a ‘secularisation’ or ‘medicalisation’ of behaviour previously regarded as religious, noting that a number of medieval paradigms existed for ‘not eating’. She also noted that the validity of a diagnosis depends on which modern definition of an illness is chosen. If we take examples of retrospective diagnoses as historical artefacts in themselves, however, they can be very revealing. In a recent survey of theories about Jonathan Swift’s ailments over three centuries, for example, Marjorie Lorch notes that while the evidence regarding Swift is inadequate to determine the accuracy of any individual retrospective diagnosis of his ailments, analysing how these diagnoses have changed reveals something of how ‘different signs and symptoms were given status and significance by different writers at different historical periods’.

child_mcqs.description: The approach considered by Cunningham is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Cunningham considers the contextualised approach (you die of what your doctor says you die of); that is, your 'cause' of death is dependent upon medical knowledge at the time. In other words, someone's death is contingent on the state of science. That there is this time-'cause' relationship means the cause is determinate, yet not absolute (the cause of death can change if science develops).

answers.description: Fatalistic
Indeterminate
Contingent
Absolute

child_mcqs.description: Why would retrospective diagnosis be considered "inherently condescending"?
child_mcqs.explanation: Condescension is the attitude of patronising superiority. While the other responses have a basis in the text, they do not directly answer the question. Only A agrees with the definition of condescension, and provides an accurate assessment of Cooter's opinion.

answers.description: Modernity self-attributes superiority.
It surrenders historical enquiry to pathology.
Only a contextual approach can be respectful to the dead.
The publication of new literature has undermined historical diagnoses.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following best describes the spectrum referred to in the second paragraph?
child_mcqs.explanation: On one side, the author describes "research groups [who] utilise expensive scientific technology to identify pathogens in archaeological remain". On the other: " the ‘parlour game’ that imposes various illnesses on historical figures through the interpretation of texts, artefacts, images and commentary". The wording suggests that the author is not particularly attached to either view, thus precluding answers A or B (the preceeding sentence suggests that a synthesis of both is preferable). C's stipulation that the "non-science" side is "intuitive" is troubling, given that it involves the use of historical texts and artefacts (ie evidence, not intuition). Rather, the process of using these sources to form a judgement is 'evaluation'.

child_mcqs.description: According to the author, what criticism does CW Bynum make of some modern approaches to retrospective diagnosis?
child_mcqs.explanation: Bynum is concerned to understand a period historically. To view behaviour (for example, fasting) in solely medical terms is to fail to account for the behaviour in an historical sense. This 'secularisation' only provides part of the picture. A is incorrect as this would require the mixing of both scientific and religious approaches. While C may be a view held by Bynum, that option doesn't really help answer the issue of why a technology-based approach is not desirable. The argument made by D is circular and is not what Bynum suggests. Secularisation is the transformation towards non-religious institutions, thereby acknowledging that people were previously religious. For D to be valid it must provide a reason why this secularisation is inappropriate. Bynum does this through the example of fasting, but this is not the argument presented by option D

answers.description: It conflates scientific and religious accounts of uncommon behaviour.
It fails to provide a comprehensive historical account of uncommon behaviour.
It is too focussed on technology-based investigations.
The secularisation of medical problems is unfounded as most people were highly religious during the period of Bynum's study.

child_mcqs.description: The tone of the text is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The text considers the views of several authors within the field of retrospective diagnosis without explicitly committing to any of them: this can only be accommodated by answer A.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is NOT supported by the text?
child_mcqs.explanation:
By process of elimation:

A: This is the recurring theme of the text, in which the varying theories about the relationship between history and science are considered.

B: This is evidenced by the work of Bynum and Lorch

D: As in the final sentence, ‘different signs and symptoms were given status and significance by different writers at different historical periods’.

This only leaves C. This statement is NOT supported by the text since it would imply that technology has not given any results in this field. That is in disagreement with statements made in the passage that demonstrate there have been some results.

answers.description: Retrospective diagnosis raises important questions about the role of modern medical science in history.
There is a body of scholarship that rejects the pre-emienence of scientific findings in history.
The application of high-end technology in investigations of historical deaths has proven to be fruitless.
Retrospective diagnoses of the same death have changed over time.

sections.title: Section III: Reasoning in Biological	and Physical Sciences

stem_mcq.title: Isotopes
stem_mcq.description: Isotopes are different types of atoms of the same chemical element (ie. same number of protons/atomic number), each having a different number of neutrons. The atomic weight of an element is calculated by aggregating the product of the representative isotopic composition and atomic mass (the top number of the nuclide symbol) of all isotopes of that element.

child_mcqs.description: Magnesium has an atomic number of 12. 25Mg has:
child_mcqs.explanation: The atomic number is determined by the number of protons and the mass number is the number of protons plus neutrons. Since the mass of the magnesium isotope is 25 and its atomic number is 12, it must have 12 protons and 13 neutrons.

child_mcqs.description:
Given the following information,

Isotope

Representative isotopic composition

24Mg

80 %

25Mg

10 %

26Mg

10 %

 

The atomic weight of magnesium is:
child_mcqs.explanation:
The atomic weight of magnesium is = (0.8 x 24) + (0.1 x 25) + (0.1 x 26) = 24.3

The maths in this questions may seem difficult, but is relatively easy if separated down into components. Many students find a calculation like 0.8 x 24 intimidating due to the fraction. Instead, calculate 8 x 24, and then divide by 10. This will give you 192/10 = 19.2. The second two components are 2.5 and 2.6. So then you simply add 19.2 + 2.5 + 2.6 to get the answer.

stem_mcq.title: Valence Electrons
stem_mcq.description: The valence electrons of pure metals are not strongly associated with particular atoms. This is a function of their low ionization energy. Electrons in metals are said to be delocalized (not found in one specific region, such as between two particular atoms). Since they are not confined to a specific area, electrons act like a flowing “sea”, moving about the positively charged cores of the metal atoms.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the given text, which of the following answers is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the delocalized electrons of metals, the bonds between metal atoms are not forced into specific configurations. This allows them to slide passed each other without being subjected to strong repulsive forces.

answers.description: De-localised electrons explain the malleability of metals.
Electrons must be evenly distributed in the metal.

stem_mcq.title: HPLC
stem_mcq.description:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is an analytical technique that can be used to separate, identify and quantify the components in a mixed solution. HPLC relies on pumps to push a pressurized liquid through a column filled with a solid adsorbent material. It is a form of chromatography where the liquid moving through the column is the mobile phase, and the material in the column is the stationary phase. Each component in the sample contained in the mobile phase interacts slightly differently with the adsorbent material of the stationary phase, causing different flow rates for the different components of the mixed sample, which leads each component to elute from the column at a different time. The time to elution is consistent for a given compound in a given set of conditions, and thus the use of standards can be used to identify unknown compounds based on elution time alone.

On elution, a variety of techniques can be used to analysed the compounds leaving the column. arguably the simplest of these is light spectroscopy, which can measure the amount of light absorbed at a given wavelength by a particular compound in the mixture. This can give an absorbance spectrum that will be specific to that compound, and can also be used to quantify the amount of the compound using a standard curve created with known concentrations of that substance.

The picture below represents a typical HPLC chromatogram showing elution time on the x-axis and absorbance units of the y-axis.

child_mcqs.description: Which peak (if any) represents the compound present in the highest quantity in the sample undergoing separation?
child_mcqs.explanation: The correct option is Answer 1, insufficient data. The stem states that light spectroscopy "can give an absorbance spectrum that will be specific to that compound, and can also be used to quantify the amount of the compound using a standard curve created with known concentrations of that substance." Thus, each different compound will absorb light at different levels, and the amount of components in a complex mixture such as this cannot be determined just from the chromatogram.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the labelled compounds is likely to have the highest affinity for the stationary phase, relative to its affinity for the mobile phase?
child_mcqs.explanation: A compound with a high affinity for the stationary phase relative to the mobile phase will interact very strongly with the column through which the liquid is passing, causing it to have a very long elution time. Thus, peak 4 is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: The Haber process
stem_mcq.description:
The Haber process describes the reaction of hydrogen gas and nitrogen gas to form ammonia:

N2    +    3H2     -->       2NH3         ΔH = -92 kJ/mol

child_mcqs.description: 5 grams of nitrogen gas and 1 gram of hydrogen gas are utilised to produce ammonia via the Haber process. How much ammonia is produced (N = 14 amu, H = 1 amu)?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The initial obvious answer here may appear to be 6 grams. However, the molar amounts of 5 grams N2 and 1 gram H2 are not equal, so one will be limiting. The molar mass of N is 14, so the molar mass of N2 is 28, and there are therefore 5/28 moles of N2 available for the reaction. The molar mass of H is 1, so the molar mass of H2 is 2, and there is 1/2 (i.e. 14/28) moles of H2 available for the reaction.

Because of the stoichiometry, we know that 3 moles of H2 are required for each mole of N2 used, which would mean 15/28 moles of H2 would be needed. However, there is only 14/28 moles of H2. This means that N2 is in excess and will not all be utilized. Instead all of the H2 (1/2 mol) will react with 1/6 mol N2. 

Looking at the reaction stoichiometry, if we use 1/6 moles of nitrogen we make 2/6, or 1/3 moles of ammonia. This weighs 1/3*17 = 5.67 g

child_mcqs.description: In a perfectly closed system, it is measured that 462 kJ of energy is generated during the process of creating ammonia via the Haber process. How much hydrogen gas was reacted?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The ΔH of the reaction -92 kJ/mol, so if 462 kJ was produced then the answer is 5 times the molar amounts given in the equation, or 15 moles of H2.  So the amount of H2 used was 30 grams (15 moles x 2 g/mol). 

When given an enthalpy change in kJ/mol, we consider in terms of the reagent with the lowest coefficient - in this case N2, which has a coefficient of 1 (whereas H2 has a coefficient of 3). This means that for every mole of N2 we react with 3 moles of H2, we get 92 kJ produced. This is the way to think about molar enthalpies in these sort of reactions

child_mcqs.description: One joule provides the heat required to raise the temperature of 1 g of water by 0.24 K. In a closed system, using the Haber process, approximately how many grams of N2 would be required to heat 18 litres of water by 24 degrees.
child_mcqs.explanation: 18 litres of water is 18 000 grams. Therefore 18 kJ of energy is required to heat this volume by 0.24K, and 1800 kJ is require to heat it by 24K. 1800 kJ is roughly 20x the enthalphy of the reaction (ΔH = -92 kJ/mol). 20 moles of N2 has a mass of 560 grams (20 moles x 28 g/mol).

stem_mcq.title: Combustion of methane
stem_mcq.description:
When methane burns, it reacts with oxygen to form carbon dioxide and water. This combustion reaction can be show as follows:

CH4     +     2O2       -->      CO2     +     2H2O 

C = 12 amu, O = 16 amu, H = 1 amu.

child_mcqs.description: Which of these statements is correct concerning the burning of methane in oxygen?
child_mcqs.explanation: It should be obvious that the burning of methane gives off heat, making it an exothermic reaction. Exothermic reactions have negative enthalpies because the products have less energy that the reactants (with the difference transferred to the surrounding environment, thus causing the heating effect).

answers.description: The enthalpy of combustion is negative and the reaction is endothermic.
The enthalpy of combustion is negative and the reaction is exothermic.
The enthalpy of combustion is positive and the reaction is exothermic.
The enthalpy of combustion is positive and the reaction is endothermic.

child_mcqs.description: How much water is produced when 8 grams of methane is burned?
child_mcqs.explanation: Students should be able to calculate the molecular mass of methane as 16 g/mol, and thus calculate that 8 grams of methane is 0.5 mol. From the equation we know that 1 mole of water is produced from 0.5 mole of methane. Water has a molecular mass of 18 g/mol, so 1 mol of water has a mass of 18 grams (18 ml).

child_mcqs.description: 32 grams of methane combusts in a closed container containing 64 grams of oxygen. How much carbone dioxide is produced?
child_mcqs.explanation: 32 grams of methane is 2 moles (it has a molecular mass of 16 g/mol). 64 grams of oxygen is also 2 moles (it has a molecular mass of 32 g/mol). Given the stoicheometry of the reaction, it is apparent that only 1 mole of the methane will be able to combust before all the oxygen has been used up, therefore 1 mole of carbon dioxide will be produced. Carbon dioxide has a molecular mass of 44 g/mol, so 44 grams will be produced.

stem_mcq.title: Chemical Structures
stem_mcq.description:
The crystal field theory provides an insight into the reason for the colour of metal-ligands such as [Cr(CN)6]4- (Cr2+ is a transitional metal ion with normally 4 electrons in its outermost d orbitals). Taking an octahedral metal-ligand structure (see below) as an example,

We can demonstrate that the five d orbitals of the central metallic ion exhibit different degrees of repulsion from surrounding ligands. The orbital energies also split, with two d orbitalS higher in energy than the other three (see below). The degree of split (crystal field splitting energy Δ0) depends directly on the strength of the ligand. Electrons will fill the orbitals as per the usual orbital filling rules.

child_mcqs.description: Given that cyanide is a strong ligand, how many electrons occupy the top level of d orbitals in [Cr(CN)6]4-?
child_mcqs.explanation: We are told that the crystal field splitting relates directly to the strength of the ligand, hence, we know that a strong ligand (as we are told cyanide is) will result in a high crystal field splitting energy. This means that it is more energetically favourable to have all the electrons in the lower energy orbitals, even though we must pair the spins. Thus, the answer is A.

child_mcqs.description: A torchlight is shone through a solution containing [Ti(H2O6)]3+ (Ti3+ is a d1 ion). Why does the solution appear purple to an observer in the direct path of the light beam?
child_mcqs.explanation: The colours between yellow and green are absorbed by the solution due the crystal field effect and the remaining colours appear purple.

answers.description: The crystal field splitting energy corresponds to the energy of purple photons.
The crystal field splitting energy corresponds to the energy of photons which correspond to the complementary colour of purple.

The single electron in an lower energy orbital is excited by the high energy photons of incoming light, so that it absorbs some of the energy of these photons to reach the top level and emits the rest as lower energy photons (purple).

stem_mcq.title: Crystal Field Splitting
stem_mcq.description:
The following table and formula is provided for the next question

Colour

λ - Wavelength (nm)

Green-yellow

560

Yellow

600

Red

620

Purple

410

Dark blue

430

Blue

450

Green

520

child_mcqs.description: The crystal field splitting energy of a solution of unknown metal-ligand [(XY6)2+] – with incomplete d-orbitals – corresponds to an absorption band of 490 nm, what colour is observed?
child_mcqs.explanation:
According to the colour wheel, 490 nm is blue-green in colour. Note however, that wavelength corresponding to these colours are absorbed. Thus, the resulting colour will be Option A, red.

EDIT: There seems to be some confusion over how to tell Red vs Yellow apart. The answer is that it is sometimes difficult to do so in the face of little information. However, it is generally the case that we consider red to be the compliment to blue-green, whereas yellow is typically the compliment of blue-violet (wavelength of between 400nm to 430nm). 490nm is clearly outside of this range and is without a doubt red.

child_mcqs.description: When compared to [Ti(H2O6)]3+, the crystal field splitting energy of [(XY6)2+] would be:
child_mcqs.explanation: (XY6)2+ has one more outer shell electron compared to [Ti(H2O)6]3+, which increases the field splitting due to electron repulsion

stem_mcq.title: Law of Mass Action
stem_mcq.description:
The law of mass action states that, at a constant temperature and pressure, the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the product of the molar concentration of the reactants each raised to a power equal to the corresponding stoichiometric coefficient.

Given that the rate limiting step in the production of NO2 (g) is

NO2Cl2 (g) → NO2 (g) + Cl2 (g)

child_mcqs.description: What is the rate of the process?
child_mcqs.explanation: Based on the information given in the stem, the rate of this reaction is directly proportional to the molar concentration of the reactant (i.e. NO2Cl2) raised to the power of it's stoichimoetric coefficient (i.e. 1). The fact that the rate of reaction is directly proportional, rather than equal to, this value, means that a coefficient (i.e. k) is required. Thus, Answer A is correct.

child_mcqs.description: What is the shape of the graph when [NO2] is plotted against time?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Note the product is plotted against time – the concentration of the reactant increases over time.

Because the rate is directly proportional to the concentration of the reactant, as the reaction progresses and [reactant] becomes less and less the rate will slow as a result. This means that the rate will eventually plateau, so the graph is not linear but rather the answer is C.

stem_mcq.title: Effusion
stem_mcq.description:
Effusion is the movement of gas through tiny holes into an evacuated space. Assuming equal pressure, effusion is governed by Graham’s Law.

M is the molar mass.

Graham's Law: Rate1 / Rate2 = sqrt (M2 / M1)

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is true?
child_mcqs.explanation:
For a gas at standard pressure, density is directly proportional to molar mass. This is a basic chemical conclusion which students should be able to draw. 

It then follows from Graham's Law that low density (i.e. mass) gasses will effuse at faster rates. Without the need to perform any calculations, this can be seen because 'rate 1' is the numerator on one side of the equation, while 'M1' is the demoninator on the other. Thus if 'M1' is smaller, 'rate 1' is larger.

answers.description: Gases with lower gas densities effuse faster
Gases with higher gas densities effuse faster

child_mcqs.description: When gas laws are applied to real gases, a discrepancy between theoretical and observed behaviour appears. This was because two factors were omitted from the ideal gas laws in order to simplify the mathematics involved, what were they?
child_mcqs.explanation: In order to simplify the ideal gas laws, it is assumed that gas particles have no intermolecular forces, and do not take up any volume.

answers.description: Kinetic energy of individual gas molecules and the total potential energy of the medium containing the gas.
Thermal energy of individual gas molecules and the overall entropy of the enclosed system.
Intramolecular forces and mass of gas molecules.
Intermolecular forces and the volume occupied by gas molecules.

child_mcqs.description: At an atmospheric pressure of 100kPa, water boils at 100°C, but water puddles on the ground will evaporate away even at normal atmospheric temperatures. Why does this happen?
child_mcqs.explanation: Water molecules have varying kinetic energies, which have a bell curve frequency distribution. Molecules at the edge of water puddles with high kinetic energy may escape as vapor, or evaporate, at temperatures below water’s boiling point.

answers.description: Radiation from the Sun heats up the ground, so that the temperature of the ground (and thus the water it is in contact with) approaches and sometimes, even exceeds 100°C.
Water starts evaporating at 20°C and at 100°C, it undergoes a process where it rigorously evaporates (boils).
Surface tension confers potential energy to water particles which allows them to evaporate.
The kinetic energy of water at a certain temperature is distributed in a bell curve, with some particles possessing enough energy to escape the liquid state.

stem_mcq.title: Soluble Equilibrium
stem_mcq.description: Soluble equilibrium occurs when the rate of deposition of salt equals the rate of dissolution, ie. when the solution is saturated. Its solubility product constant (Ksp) is the product of the molar concentration of the soluble ions each raised to a power equal to the corresponding stoichiometric coefficient, which appears in the balanced chemical equation.
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: What is the correct equation to describe a saturated solution of Na2SO4?
child_mcqs.explanation: The solubility product constant is equal to the product of the molar concentrations of the two ions, to the power of their stoichiometric coefficient. That is, [Na+]2 x [SO42-].

child_mcqs.description: Given that the solubility of Na2SO4 increases with increasing temperature, would the Ksp increase or decrease when a saturated solution of Na2SO4 at 10°C is heated to 25°C?
child_mcqs.explanation: If the solubility of Na2SO4 increases with increasing temperature, more salt is dissociated into ions, increasing concentration of ions. Thus the Ksp­ would increase because it is directly proportional to the concentration of ions.

answers.description: Increase; because more salt is readily dissociated into ions
Decrease; because the dissolved ions collides more often with higher thermal energy, thus drives the equilibrium towards recrystallization.
No change; Ksp is a thermodynamic constant independent of temperature.

child_mcqs.description: Even though the solubility of Na2SO4 increases with increasing temperature, it was found that the maximum solubility of Na2SO4 was at 32.4°C. If a small amount of NaCl was added prior to Na2SO4, and the solution was then heated to 32.4°C, what will happen to the Ksp compared to a pure solution of Na2SO4?
child_mcqs.explanation: If there is already some Na+ present due to the addition of NaCl, then that means that less Na+ will be contributed by the dissolution of Na2SO4. This means that the solubility will decrease. However, Ksp is by definition a constant - it will not be effected without changing a condition such as temperature or pressure. In fact, it is because Ksp stays the same that less Na2SO4 dissolves.

stem_mcq.title: Carbon Phases
stem_mcq.description: This is a phase diagram of carbon, indicating the most stable state of carbon at given temperature and pressure conditions.

child_mcqs.description: At 2000 K and 0.01 GPa, what is the most stable state of carbon?
child_mcqs.explanation: Reading the point 2000K and 0.01GPa on the graph, this lies in the graphite area

child_mcqs.description: The triple point (TP) is where solid, liquid and gaseous states of carbon exist simultaneously. What state will carbon be in if both the temperature and pressure increases slightly from the triple point?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer depends on the relative degree of increase of temperature and pressure. Given the line between vapour and liquid roughly follows an increase in both temperature and pressure, one of these states will be favoured; however, which one is unclear.

answers.description: It is not clear from the figure

child_mcqs.description: A diamond stone was found at standard conditions (i.e. atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature). Which of the following statements is true?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Graphite is more stable under these conditions, however the change will occur over aeons.

The position of this on the graph would be way down in the bottom left corner, near to the origin, where graphite is most stable, hence, we know that diamond will eventually become graphite. 

Please note that this reaction of diamond to graphite is the classic example of the independence of chemical kinetics and rate from thermodynamics. The reaction is spontaneous, but will occur so slowly that it isn't noticeable on a human timescale.

answers.description: It will quickly change to the more stable graphite.
It will change to graphite, but at a negligible rate.
It will not change to graphite without any external forces.
Diamond stones are not found at standard conditions.

stem_mcq.title: NMR Spectroscopy
stem_mcq.description: Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy is a technique used to study the composition of substances. It is applicable to any nucleus which exhibits non-zero spin, ie. it possesses either (or both) odd numbers of neutrons or odd numbers of electrons.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following isotope nuclei does not exhibit spin?
child_mcqs.explanation: Anything with an odd number of electrons exhibts spin as per the question stem. Hence the only possible answer is C as the rest all have odd atomic numbers.

child_mcqs.description: X is an isotope of selenium (atomic number 34) that exhibits nuclear magnetic resonance. What is the likely mass number of selenium?
child_mcqs.explanation: Because the number of protons is even, the number of neutrons must be odd, so therefore the overall mass number must also be odd.

stem_mcq.title: Bacteria
stem_mcq.description:
Gram-positive bacteria have a thick mesh-like cell wall made of peptidoglycan (50-90% of cell wall), which stains purple while Gram-negative bacteria have a thinner layer (10% of cell wall), which stains pink. Gram-negative bacteria also have an additional outer lipopolysaccharide membrane separated from the cell wall by the periplasmic space (in addition to the inner membrane present in all bacteria). There are four basic steps of the Gram stain, which include applying a primary stain (crystal-violet) to a heat-fixed (death by heat) smear of a bacterial culture, followed by the addition of a trapping agent (Gram's iodine), rapid decolorization with alcohol or acetone, and counterstaining with safranin (which gives Gram-negative bacteria their pink colour).

 

When a decolorizer such as alcohol or acetone is added, it interacts with the lipids of the cell membrane. A gram-negative cell will lose its outer lipopolysaccharide membrane and the inner peptidoglycan layer is left exposed. The crystal-violet complexes are washed from the gram-negative cell along with the outer membrane. In contrast, a gram-positive cell becomes dehydrated from an ethanol treatment. The large crystal-violet complexes become trapped within the gram-positive cell due to the multilayered nature of its peptidoglycan. The decolorization step is critical and must be timed correctly; the crystal violet stain will be removed from both gram-positive and negative cells if the decolorizing agent is left on too long (a matter of seconds).

child_mcqs.description: Staphylcoccus auerus is a type of bacterium with a thick cell wall of peptidoglycan.  What colour will S. aureus appear if it stained using the Gram stain?
child_mcqs.explanation: Bacteria with thick cell walls of peptidoglycan are ‘gram positive’ according to the passage.  This means that they would stain purple

child_mcqs.description: Propionibacterium have cell walls particularly sensitive to breakage (especially during cell division).  A gram stain is performed on a particular sample of Propionibacterium containing a high number of cells with broken cell walls.  What colour will these cells stain with the Gram stain?
child_mcqs.explanation: Propionibacterium  is actually a gram positive organism. However, the question stem states that this sample contains mainly cells with broken walls.  According to the passage, thick walls of peptidoglycan are responsible for trapping the crystal-violet complexes in the gram stain.  If this wall’s integrity is compromised, then the cells would stain pink (gram negatively).  This is similar to decolorizing for too long – the crystal-violet is washed out from the peptidoglycan, giving falsely gram negative results for gram positive organisms (as stated in the passage).

answers.description: Impossible to tell from the information provided

child_mcqs.description: A particular sample of organisms have their outer lipopolysaccharide membrane stripped away before staining using the Gram process.  What color will this sample appear?
child_mcqs.explanation: If these organisms have an outer lipopolysaccharide membrane then they are gram negative.  According to the passage, the outer membrane has little effect on the final staining colour – it is the peptidoglycan wall that has the main effect.  Therefore, these organisms would continue to stain gram negatively pink.

answers.description: Impossible to tell from the information provided

child_mcqs.description: The beta-lactam class of antibiotics works by inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis.  Based on this information alone, the beta-lactams would work against:
child_mcqs.explanation: According to the information given, both gram positive and gram negative organisms contain peptidoglycan.  Theoretically, the beta-lactams, by inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis, should work against both.  Note that the question is not asking whether the beta-lactams are more effective or not against gram positive or negative organisms.

answers.description: Both gram positive and gram negative organisms
Impossible to tell from the information provided

child_mcqs.description: The aminoglycoside class of antibiotics works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.  They also interfere with the integrity of lipopolysaccharide membranes.  Based on this information, aminoglycoside antibiotics would be most effective against:
child_mcqs.explanation: Since gram negative organisms have an outer membrane of lipopolysaccharide (whereas gram positive organisms don’t) and since aminoglycosides interfere with lipopolysaccharide membrane integrity, aminoglycosides are presumably more effective against gram negative organisms.  The thick peptidoglycan walls of gram positive bacteria tend to prevent aminoglycoside penetration.  Extra information: when aminoglycosides are used in combination with beta-lactams, they together are effective against gram positive organisms because the beta-lactams weaken the peptidoglycan walls, allowing easier penetration by aminoglycosides.

answers.description: Both gram positive and gram negative organisms
Impossible to tell from the information provided

child_mcqs.description: Some bacteria are able to resist the action of the beta-lactam class of antibiotics by producing ‘beta-lactamases’ (enzymes that destroy the antibiotics).  Vancomycin belongs to another class of antibiotics that also inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis.  Vancomycin is often effective against organisms resistant to the beta-lactams via the beta-lactamases.  Which of the following statements best explains why?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is wrong because this is not supported by the passage.  Options B and C do not directly explain why vancomycin would work against beta-lactam resistant organisms.  Option D is therefore the best option.

answers.description: Bacteria do not have the capability of developing resistance against vancomycin
Vancomycin inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis via an alternative mechanism to beta-lactams

stem_mcq.title: The chloride shift
stem_mcq.description:
The chloride shift refers to the exchange of bicarbonate (HCO3-) and chloride (Cl-) across the membrane of red blood cells (RBC).

In one direction, it involves the movement of CO2 from the extracellular space into RBCs, which is combined with water to form carbonic acid (H2CO3) by the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. Carbonic anhydrase is not generally present outside of red blood cells. Carbonic acid is a weak acid that spontaneously dissociates to a H+ and HCO3-,  the latter of which is transported across the RBC membrane in exchange for Cl-.

The chloride shift is part of a process that enables CO2 to be transported in blood in the form of more readily dissolved bicarbonate. This whole process can be visualized as shown below.

child_mcqs.description: Bicarbonate ions are moved across the RBC membrane by a:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the question, it states, "HCO3-... is transported across the RBC membrane in exchange for Cl-". When two ions are transported across a membrane in opposite directions (i.e. in exchanged) by a single trasport protein, this is referred to as an antiporter. Thus the correct answer is bicarbonate/Cl- antiporter. Channels are passive and can therefore not exchange different ions, while symporters transport molecules in the same direction. Bicarbonate and Cl- are anions, so answer 4 is incorrect. Note that although double ended arrows are shown throughout to indicate that each step is reversible, the text is clear that bicarbonate and Cl- are exchanged across the membrane.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is "almost" right, except that it states that RBCs directly carry bicarbonate. As can be seen from the figure and text, while CO2 is converted to bicarbonate in RBCs, it is then transported back into the plasma. Thus answer 1 is incorrect. Answer 2 is incorrect because it refers to CO2 from the lungs being converted. In fact, CO2 is always transported to the lungs, where it is removed from the body. The text makes no reference to Cl- concentrations, and indeed if Cl- was higher in RBCs, there would be less conversion of CO2 into HCO3- due to equilibrium effects, thus answer 3 is incorrect. Answer 4 is a simple summary of the information provided in the initial text, and is therefore correct.

answers.description: Red blood cells assist in the removal of CO2 from the body by directly carrying HCO3- to the lungs, where it can be removed.
CO2 from the lungs can be rapidly converted to carbonic acid in red blood cells, which spontaneously dissociates to H+ and HCO3-.
Red blood cells are able to convert high amounts of CO2 to HCO3- due to the presence of high levels of Cl- within the cells.
Red blood cells assist in the removal of CO2 from the body by converting it to a readily soluble compound in a reversible process.

child_mcqs.description: Haemoglobin, the major component of red blood cells, is a protein that readily binds O2, thereby increasing the O2 carrying capacity of the blood. Under acidic conditions, the affinity of haemoglobin for O2 is decreased. This results in:
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is correct because when high levels of CO2 are present, the equilibrium shifts towards the right (based on the figure), resulting in higher H+ concentrations, and thus low pH. The question states that haemoglobin has a lower affinity for O2 at lower pH. Therefore, more O2 will be released from the haemoglobin and will increase oxygen delivery to tissues. Answer 2 is incorrect since the removal of CO2 will change the equilibrium in such as way as to increase pH, therefore increasing the binding of O2 to haemoglobin. Answer 4 is incorrect for the same reason. Answer 3 relates O2 binding to bicarbonate, which is not a relevant factor.

answers.description: Greater oxygen delivery to active tissues in which high levels of CO2 are produced.
Greater oxygen delivery at the lungs, where CO2 is removed from the circulation.
Increased binding of O2 to haemoglobin in red blood cells in the presence of bicarbonate ions.
Decreased binding of O2 to haemoglobin in red blood cells in low CO2 conditions.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements concerning red blood cells in venous blood is most likely to be true?
child_mcqs.explanation: In venous blood, there will be a much higher level of CO2 compared to arterial blood. According to the figure, this will result in a higher H+concentration (i.e. lower pH). Also, as more HCO3- will be produced and exchanged across the membrane for Cl-, this will result in a higher internal Cl- concentration.

answers.description: They have a lower Cl- concentration and lower pH than RBCs in arterial blood.
They have a higher Cl- concentration and higher pH than RBCs in arterial blood.
They have a lower Cl- concentration and higher pH than RBCs in arterial blood.
They have a higher Cl- concentration and lower pH than RBCs in arterial blood.

child_mcqs.description: Which two molecules are likely to passively diffuse across the RBC membrane?
child_mcqs.explanation: Cell membranes are highly hydrophobic, and generally only small uncharged molecules will easily passively diffuse across them. Thus answer 1 and 4 are incorrect. While theoretically, carbonic acid might seem to be a molecule that could passively diffuse across a membrane, the question states that it spontaneously dissociates, thus diffuse would not occur. Answer 3 is correct since both CO2 and H2O can cross cell membranes without the need for active transport or channels.

stem_mcq.title: Starling Forces
stem_mcq.description: The following diagram demonstrates how fluid is distributed between the capillaries and tissues.  Fluid is distributed according to “Starling Forces” (hydrostatic and oncotic pressures).  Hydrostatic pressure is the force exerted by a fluid, whereas oncotic pressure is the retention of fluid due to proteins.  The net movement of fluid at the arterial end of the capillaries is outwards from the vasculature, whereas the net movement of fluid at the venous end of the capillaries is into the vasculature.  This difference is mainly due to the difference in capillary hydrostatic pressure.  Capillary hydrostatic pressure is much less at the venous end.

child_mcqs.description: According to the diagram above
child_mcqs.explanation: Blood is flowing from left to right.  Furthermore, the passage says that net fluid flow is outwards at the arterial end of capillaries, and inwards at the venous end.  Therefore, the arterial end is on the left and the venous end is on the right.

answers.description: The venous end of the capillaries is on the right and the arterial end on the left
The venous end of the capillaries is on the left and the arterial end on the right
The venous end of the capillaries could be on the right or left
Whether the venous end is on the right or left of the diagram is irrelevant

child_mcqs.description: The tissue oncotic pressure (TOP) is not marked on the diagram.  Using the numbers provided, calculate what it should be.
child_mcqs.explanation:
On the arterial (left) end, the sum of the pressures give is +37-1-25 = +11 … this is equivalent to the net 11 mmHg outwards (which is shown at the top of the diagram), so the TOP must be 0.  

This can also be represented by the equation:

Net driving force = (capillary hydrostatic pressure - tissue hydrostatic pressure) - (capillary oncotic pressure - tissue oncotic pressure). So on the arterial side of the equation: 

11 = [(37 - 1) - (25 - TOP) 

11 = 36 - 25 - TOP

11 = 11 - TOP

TOP = 0

child_mcqs.description: If the concentration of proteins within the capillary is decreased, what would happen to the net movement of fluid?
child_mcqs.explanation: A decrease in protein concentration in the capillaries would decrease the capillary oncotic pressure.  This increases the tendency of fluid to be lost from the capillaries (at both the arterial and venous ends).  Therefore, there is increased OUTWARD flow at the arterial end (left side), and decreased INWARD flow at the venous end (right side).

answers.description: Increased outward flow on the left of the diagram, decreased inward flow on the right
Decreased outward flow on the left of the diagram, increased inward flow on the right
Increased outward flow on the left of the diagram, increased inward flow on the right
Decreased outward flow on the left of the diagram, decreased inward flow on the right

stem_mcq.title: Renal Biology
stem_mcq.description:
The nephron is the smallest functional unit of the kidney, and is composed of a glomerulus, the proximal tubule, the loop of Henle, the distal convoluted tubule and the collecting duct. Blood is filtered at the glomerulus (a tuft of  capillaries), where small molecules are able to pass into the Bowman’s capsule. This filtrate passes through the proximal tubule and subsequently through the loop of Henle, which passes deep into the medulla of the kidney.  Finally the filtrate enters the collecting ducts, forming urine.  Throughout these tubules, certain substances are secreted into the filtrate, while others are reabsorbed back into the bloodstream. This is depicted in the diagram below.

Note: AA = Amino acid

child_mcqs.description: According to the diagram, which of the following substances is not reabsorbed and will be lost in urine?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A is the correct answer. Penicillin is an antibiotic, and there is no reabsorptive mechanism for antibiotics shown in the diagram above. In fact, antibiotics are secreted into the tubule of the nephron.

Note: This method of handling antibiotics is useful for treating urinary tract infections because it results in high concentrations of antibiotic at the site of infection!

Sodium, water and glucose are very important molecules in homeostasis. They are all reabsorbed by the nephron back into the bloodstream.

child_mcqs.description: All of the following statements are correct according to the diagram, except:
child_mcqs.explanation: Glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, not the proximal part of the distal convoluted tubule.

answers.description: Magnesium is reabsorbed in the ascending limb of the Loop of Henle
Water is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule
Glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal part of the distal convoluted tubule
Potassium is reabsorbed in the Loop of Henle

child_mcqs.description: Aldosterone is a hormone released in response to low blood pressure. This hormone increases the reabsorption of a particular ion in the distal part of the distal convoluted tubule in order.  According to the diagram, which of the following ions is this most likely to be?
child_mcqs.explanation: When blood pressure is low, aldosterone causes an increase in sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. This reabsorption of sodium chloride is represented in the diagram above. Along with sodium, water is also reabsorbed. This raises blood volume, and increases blood pressure.

child_mcqs.description: During surgery, an incision is made in the outermost part of the kidney. Which of the following components of the nephron is least likely to be severed?
child_mcqs.explanation: The Loop of Henle is in the medulla of the kidney, which is lower/deeper within the kidney than the other structures in the other options.

answers.description: Proximal part of the distal convoluted tubule
Distal part of the distal convoluted tubule

child_mcqs.description: Parathyroid hormone affects calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.  At which of the following structures could it possible target?
child_mcqs.explanation: Calcium is reabsorbed in the proximal part of the distal convoluted tubules.  The Loop of Henle is also involved but this is not an option.  Therefore, parathyroid hormone must act at the distal convoluted tubule.

answers.description: Proximal part of the distal convoluted tubule
Distal part of the distal convoluted tubule

child_mcqs.description: According to the diagram, the greatest variety of substances are reabsorbed in the:
child_mcqs.explanation: The greatest variety of substances, including glucose and bicarbonate, are reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

stem_mcq.title: Alcohol
stem_mcq.description:
Ethanol (alcohol) is metabolized to acetaldehyde in the body by alcohol dehydrogenase.  Acetaldehyde is then metabolized to acetic acid by acetaldehyde dehydrogenase.  

 

Acetaldehyde is more toxic than alcohol and is responsible for many hangover symptoms.  Acetaldehyde accumulates after drinking alcohol, leading to symptoms of acetaldehyde poisoning, including the characteristic flushing of the skin and increased heart and respiration rates.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: Many people of far-Eastern descent experience flushing and unpleasant effect after consuming a relatively small amount of alcohol.  These people most likely:
child_mcqs.explanation: The toxic effects are due to accumulation of acetaldehyde.  Therefore, the acetaldehyde is not being metabolised fast enough to acetic acid – this implies an acetaldehyde dehydrogenase deficiency.

answers.description: Have less body fat to absorb the effects of alcohol

stem_mcq.title: Flowers
stem_mcq.description: Flowering plants (angiosperms) can be divided into monocotyledons and dicotyledons.  Monocotyledon embryos begin with a single cotyledon (the first leaf of an embryonic plant).  Dicotyledon embryos begin with two cotyledons.  Monocotyledon leaves usually have parallel leaf veination, whereas dicotyledon leaves usually have reticulated veination.

child_mcqs.description: The picture above is of a young castor oil plant.  This is an example of a:
child_mcqs.explanation: This young plant obviously sprouted its leaves in pairs.  Furthermore, its leaves have reticulated veination.  Therefore, it is a dicotyledon.  It is an angiosperm (flowering plant) because the question states that this is a castor oil plant.  Oils come from seeds and seeds come from flowers.

stem_mcq.title: Arthropods
stem_mcq.description:
Arthropods are insects with joints in their legs and can be classified as chelicerates, myriapods, hexapods, or crustaceans:

Chelicerates  are characterised by the presence of chelicerae which are appendages just above / in front of the mouth. Chelicerae appear in scorpions as tiny claws that they use in feeding, but those of spiders have developed as fangs that inject venom.

Myriapods  have many body segments, each bearing one or two pairs of legs.

Hexapods comprise insects with six thoracic legs.

Crustaceans are primarily aquatic (a notable exception being woodlice) and are characterised by having appendages that branch into two.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO14 Experimental design and data analysis

child_mcqs.description: A new type of arthropod is discovered in the forest. Scientists note that it has one body segment, eight thoracic legs and lives in the water. Close examination reveals small appendages near the mouth. Which of the following is the most appropriate category for this arthropod?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is the correct answer, and it directly follows from the available descriptors.

stem_mcq.title: Mitosis
stem_mcq.description: Mitosis (division of eukaryotic cells) can be divided into four phases: prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase.  The first step, prophase, is when the chromatin (DNA) in the cell nucleus has condensed and the centrioles started to move to opposite ends of a cell.  Metaphase is the second step – the chromosomes of the cell are now lined up in the centre and the centrioles are at opposite sides.  Anaphase is when the chromosomes split into chromatids and move to opposite ends of the cell, guided by the centrioles.  Telophase is the final step – the cell begins dividing into two daughter cells.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following correctly identifies the correct order of sequence (the above images are out of sequence)?
child_mcqs.explanation: IV = Prophase, II = Metaphase, I = Anaphase, III = Telophase

child_mcqs.description: Errors may occur at various steps of mitosis.  In non-disjunction, one daughter cell will receive both chromatids of a chromosome, and the other will receive none.  At what stage does this error occur?
child_mcqs.explanation: For a daughter cell to receive both chromatids of a chromosome, the chromatids must not have separated.  Separation normally occurs during anaphase.

stem_mcq.title: Meiosis
stem_mcq.description: Meiosis is the process by which gametes (e.g. sperm and ova) are produced.  It is a unique process because sperm and ova must contain half the number of chromosomes of a normal/somatic cell – this is because two gametes will eventually unite to begin a new organism.  Since they have half the number of chromosomes, gametes are termed haploid cells (n), whereas normal cells are diploid (2n). C refers to the number of total copies of the genome present in the cells.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: The products of meiosis are:
child_mcqs.explanation: This is the whole aim of meiosis.  The diagram may deceive some students with the word ‘zygote’ at the end.  However, it can be seen that TWO arrows lead to zygote (one arrow being the end-product of meiosis).  A zygote is the first cell of a new organism i.e. unification of two gametes (a sperm and ovum).

child_mcqs.description: What is the first stage that the products of meiosis are ‘haploid’?
child_mcqs.explanation: The diagram illustrates pairs of chromosomes separating in anaphase I, so by telophase I, the cells could be considered ‘haploid’. This can also be seen by the information beneath the cells in parenthesis, where each cell is n (haploid) rather than 2n (diploid) at this stage.

child_mcqs.description: Female humans do not start producing ova (eggs) until puberty.  However, the precursors exist before puberty.  These precursors (oocytes) are arrested at a particular stage of meiosis, and will become ova once they complete meiosis.  Arrested oocytes are considered diploid, and their chromosomes are visibly paired up.  At what stage are oocytes arrested?
child_mcqs.explanation: The oocytes are still diploid, and so they are still within meiosis I.  Since the chromosomes are still paired up, they are within Prophase I.

child_mcqs.description: Male humans do not begin sperm production until puberty.  The precursors to sperm (spermatogonia) divide twice to produce four sperm each.  Spermatogonia are:
child_mcqs.explanation: The two divisions that spermatogonia undergo must be the two divisions of meiosis (as shown in the diagram).  Therefore, the precursors are diploid.  It has been stated that sperm are haploid.

stem_mcq.title: Symbiosis
stem_mcq.description: Symbiosis is close and often long-term interactions/relationships between different biological species living together. The symbiotic relationship may be categorized as mutualistic, commensal, or parasitic in nature.  Mutualism is any relationship between individuals of different species where both individuals derive a benefit. Commensalism describes a relationship between two living organisms where one benefits and the other is not significantly harmed or helped. A parasitic relationship is one in which one member of the association benefits while the other is harmed.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: Spiders build their webs in trees to catch food.  This is an example of:
child_mcqs.explanation: Trees provide spiders with the benefit of a habitat for web construction.  The spiders do not negatively affect the tree.  This is commensalism by definition.

child_mcqs.description: Herbivores have large numbers of bacteria living in their gut.  These bacteria breakdown plant fibres that the herbivores cannot digest into simpler sugars.  This is an example of:
child_mcqs.explanation: The bacteria benefit from both a habitat and plants that the herbivores consume.  The herbivores benefit from the simpler sugars that the bacteria produce. This is mutualism by definition.

child_mcqs.description: Algae produce oxygen via photosynthesis.  Rabbits, like all animals, require oxygen to breathe.  This is an example of:
child_mcqs.explanation: The definition of symbiosis given is species living in CLOSE relationship and/or living together.  Algae, being aquatic, and rabbits, being land-based animals, have no direct effect upon each other.  Therefore, this is not an example of symbiosis.

stem_mcq.title: Hepatitis B
stem_mcq.description:
Hepatitis B is a blood-borne virus that infects the liver and causes liver damage. It is diagnosed through testing an individual for the different types of Hepatitis B antigens or antibodies produced in response, or the virus DNA. The virus has the following antigens to which antibody responses are mounted:

·         Surface antigen (HBsAg): On the surface of the virus. This is used in the Hepatitis B vaccination to trigger an immune response. If a person has been infected with hepatitis B, antibodies produced against surface antigen indicate that the virus has been cleared.

·         Core antigen: Within the virus, released when the virus breaks down to replicate

·         Pre-core antigens: Used by the virus to initiate replication.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the statements is incorrect:
child_mcqs.explanation:
Answer: C. An individual who had been infected would have antibodies to the surface, core and pre-core antigens, while an individual immunised with only the surface antigen of hepatitis B would only have this type of antibody. 

Note that answer B is a correct statement because a person actively infected with hepatitis B will test positive for the surface antigen, while a vaccinated person will test positive for the antibody to the Hepatitis B surface antigen.

answers.description: An individual who is actively infected with hepatitis B would test positive for the HBsAg but not the antibody against it.
Only those who are actively infected with Hep B will test positive for the HBsAg.
The same antibodies would be seen in the serum of those who were immune due to natural infection and those who were immune due to vaccination.
An individual who was started on viral replication-inhibiting drugs may show a change in the antigens in their serum with treatment.

child_mcqs.description: Many viruses are able to reinfect a host who has previously mounted an immune response against it, by mutating its antigens. If Hepatitis B began to mutate, which of the following would be the most devastating to a previously immunised, and immune population?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer B: The vaccine against Hep B uses the surface antigen to produce specific antibodies which prevent the virus infecting cells. Immunisation does not involve the core proteins so a is incorrect. The virus is not able to replicate anyway with successful immunisation as it cannot enter cells, so c is incorrect.

answers.description: Mutation to the core proteins so they were no longer recognised.
A change in the nature of its surface antigen
Gain of additional virulence factors allowing it to replicate at double its original rate
None of the above, as long as the entire virus does not change, an immunised individual will still be immune

stem_mcq.title: Ecological Pyramid
stem_mcq.description: Grass gets eaten by grasshoppers.  Shrews eat the grasshoppers.  Shrews get eaten by hawks.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO14 Experimental design and data analysis

child_mcqs.description: According to the ecological pyramid above, which of the following statements is correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Grass = primary producer; grasshopper = primary consumer; shrew = secondary consumer; hawk = tertiary consumer

stem_mcq.title: Hepatobiliary System
stem_mcq.description: The liver produces bile (which is required for fat digestion).  The gallbladder stores excess bile produced by the liver.  Bile is produced and flows down the left and right hepatic bile duct, which unite to form the common hepatic duct.  The common hepatic duct unites with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.  The common bile duct and pancreatic duct unite to form the Ampulla of Vater, which empties into the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine).  The following diagram illustrates the LOWER part of this ‘biliary tree’ (the structures transmitting the flow of bile).

child_mcqs.description: If the common hepatic duct is completely blocked, bile would most likely:
child_mcqs.explanation: The gall bladder and pancreas are further down the biliary tree than the common hepatic duct.  Backflow would be to the liver.

child_mcqs.description: If the pancreatic duct is plugged with debris, bile would most likely:
child_mcqs.explanation: If the pancreatic duct only is blocked off with debris, bile still flows down the common bile duct and into the Ampulla of Vater unimpeded (unless the Ampulla of Vater gets blocked too).

child_mcqs.description: The Sphincter of Oddi controls the release of biliary juices from the Ampulla of Vater.  If the spincter is open, bile is allowed out into the duodenum.  Note that bile is continuously produced by the liver.  If the Sphincter of Oddi is closed, bile would MOST LIKELY:
child_mcqs.explanation: The gall bladder is lower down than the liver.  Therefore, bile is more likely to flow up to the gall bladder than into the liver.  Furthermore, it is stated that the gallbladder stores excess bile.  It would make sense for the bile to therefore flow backwards to the gallbladder rather than the liver.

stem_mcq.title: Muscle Contraction
stem_mcq.description: The following diagram demonstrates how the power and force of a muscle contraction changes depending on how fast it contracts (shortening velocity). This graph is from Journal of Experimental Biology 2012 215: 4345-4357 and reproduced under CC-BY 3.0

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is most appropriate?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is the correct answer to this question. It is clear that peak power (the local maximum of the power curve) shifts to the right with increasing temperatures. A is incorrect because the power is higher at higher temperatures. B is incorrect because the force v. power curve is parabolic in shape and so more force does not necessarily result in more power.  The force of contraction continuously decreases with increasing contraction velocity, which is why option D is wrong.

answers.description: Muscles contract with less power at higher temperatures
The more forceful a contraction, the higher the power.
The optimal contractile force for a muscle is temperature specific
The faster a muscle contracts, the more forceful the contraction

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following best describes the relationship between force of muscle contraction and shortening velocity?
child_mcqs.explanation: The force of contraction continuously decreases with increasing contraction velocity.  Therefore, they are inversely proportional i.e. one increases when the other decreases.  Power is not requested by the question.

answers.description: The force of a muscle contraction is inversely proportional to the shortening velocity
The force of a muscle contraction is directly proportional to the shortening velocity
The force of a muscle contraction is not related to the shortening velocity
The force of a muscle contraction has a complex relationship with the power of the contraction

stem_mcq.title: Urine production
stem_mcq.description:
Urine production by the kidney allows direct regulation of plasma fluid volume. Blood passes via the renal arteries to the glomeruli of the kidney which filter approximately 180 L of fluid day. Filtration pressure is governed by 3 factors:

1.    Hydrostatic pressure (PGC):  the pressure of blood flow forces fluid through the leaky endothelium into the Bowman’s space;

2.    Colloid osmotic pressure (πGC): protein is present in the plasma but not in Bowman’s space, this creates a gradient for water flow into the glomerular capillaries;

3.    Fluid pressure(PBC): the enclosed space of Bowman’s capsule creates a hydrostatic pressure favouring the movement of water into the glomerular capillaries.

Following filtration, fluid in Bowman’s space passes through the renal tubule where its composition is refined. Fluid that remain in the tubule following this process is excreted.

child_mcqs.description: With the above information in mind, which of the following is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Osmotic and fluid pressure are exerting pressure from the Bowman's capsule back into the capillaries. Therefore, for any net filtration to take place, the hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries must be great enough to overcome these combined pressures.

answers.description: Hydrostatic pressure must be greater than cumulative colloid osmotic and fluid pressure in order for net filtration to occur
Net filtration occurs always occurs when hydrostatic pressure is greater than colloid osmotic pressure
Hydrostatic pressure, colloid osmotic pressure and fluid pressure must be balanced to allow net filtration into Bowman’s capsule

child_mcqs.description: If the ureter (a distal continuation of the Bowman’s capsule) becomes obstructed, which of the following is most likely to occur?
child_mcqs.explanation: If a ureter becomes obstructed (e.g. due to kidney stones!), this leads to a blockage in the flow of urine downstream of the Bowman's capsule. Therefore, this will cause fluid to accumulate in the Bowman's capsule and increase the fluid pressure. The ultimate effect of this will be a decrease in the filtration and the production of urine decrease.

answers.description: Raised pressure in the Bowman’s capsule prevents urine formation
Raised colloid osmotic pressure acts to reduce urine output

child_mcqs.description: Due to a pathological process, the quantity of albumin (protein) in the blood is significantly lower than normal. Which of the following will occur most rapidly?
child_mcqs.explanation: If the quantity of blood albumin is lower, this reduces the osmotic force, which normally acts against the hydrostatic pressure that leads to filtration. The consequence of this is that more fluid will enter the Bowman's capsule.

answers.description: More fluid will enter the Bowman’s capsule
More protein will be produced by the body

child_mcqs.description: Following a bacterial infection, the glomerular capillaries become injured and scarred. This scarring disrupts the glomerular filtration barrier and obstructs fluid movement into Bowman’s capsule. To promote glomerular filtration, the afferent arterioles which channel blood to the glomerular capillaries dilate. Which of the following physiological consequences would result?
child_mcqs.explanation: When the afferent arteriole dilates, this increases blood flow into the glomerulus, and therefore raises the hydrostatic pressure. Note also that when kidneys become scarred, their production of urine drops, which activates the renin-angiotensin system to increase blood pressure. So people with scarred glomeruli will have high blood pressure. This is a challenging question.

stem_mcq.title: The TCA cycle
stem_mcq.description: The diagram below shows a simplified schematic of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, which is a series of chemical reactions utilised by all aerobic cells to produce energy through the oxidation of acetate (C2H3O2-) in the form of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA can be derived from a number of sources, including glucose, lipids and amino acids.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the chemical intermediates of the TCA cycles is the most reduced?
child_mcqs.explanation: The question states that the reaction derives energy via the oxidation of acetyl-CoA. Thus the final chemical intermediate of the cycle (immediately prior to the the combination of oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA) are the most oxidised, and the initial intermediate formed by oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA is the most reduced. Neither Acetyl-CoA nor NADH can be said to be intermediates of the TCA cycle.

child_mcqs.description: It is apparent from the TCA cycle reactions shown that the two carbon atoms comprising acetyl-CoA:
child_mcqs.explanation: The two carbon atoms from acetyl-CoA ultimately end up as carbon dioxide, which is a gas. Thus, they are a different state of matter. It's not correct to say carbon atoms can provide a reducing potential, so answer 1 is incorrect . Also, three NADH molecules (not two) appear to be generated per acetyl-CoA so answer 3 is incorrect, and the NAD+ to NADH reactions do not include and carbon atom transfer, so answer 4 is incorrect.

answers.description: Provide the reducing potential for the production of NADH from NAD+.
Are ultimately converted to a different state of matter.
Result in the production of two NADH molecules and one FADH2 molecule.
End up as part of the NADH molecule.

child_mcqs.description: Assuming that the TCA cycle is occuring at a perfect equlibrium, changing the concentrations of which two substances would both increase rate of the overall TCA cycle?
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the effect on several of the chemical equilibriums in the TCA cycle, increasing NADH would slow the reactions (because increasing the concentration of the reaction product would push the equilibrium towards the reactants). Similarly, decreasing NAD+ concentrations would slow the reactions because they are reactants of several steps of the TCA cycle. Thus, answers 2 and 4 are incorrect. Answer 1 is not correct because, in the absence of more acetyl-CoA, and increase in oxaloacetate on it's own would not produce more citrate because each oxaloacetate molecule requires the addition of acetyl-CoA in order for citrate to be formed. Answer 3 is correct becase decreasing NADH would push the equilibrium of the NAD+ to NADH steps towards the products, and increaseing citrate increases the amount of initial reactants for the whole cycle.

answers.description: Increased oxaloacetate and increased NAD+
Increased citrate and increased NADH
Increased citrate and decreased NADH
Increased acetyl-CoA and decrease NAD+

child_mcqs.description: Following the combination of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate to form citrate, the consumption of citrate to produce iso-citrate and alpha-ketoglutaric acid, respectfully, are examples of:
child_mcqs.explanation: The second reaction step, forming alpha-ketoglutaric acide from iso-citrate, produces NADH from NAD+ as well as CO2, so it is clearly oxidative decarboxylation. The first step where citrate is converted into iso-citrate has no secondary reactants or products, which can fit only with an isomerization reaction where the reactant and product have the same atoms. The name iso-citrate also provides a hint that it is a different isomer of citrate.

answers.description: Hydration and isomerization
Isomerization and oxidative decarboxylation
Oxidative decoarboxylation and hydration
Isomerization and decarboxylation

stem_mcq.title: Electrical Field
stem_mcq.description: The electric field for two point charges A and B is shown below. Which of the following is true?

child_mcqs.explanation:
There are 2 rules about electric field lines.

Field lines point away from positive charges and towards negative charges.

Field lines cannot cross.

Since both charges have field lines point away from them, it is clear that they are both positive.

Additonal note on the physical meaning of field lines

The field lines indicate the direction a positive charge would move in if placed in the field. It makes sense that the positive charges have field lines pointing away from them; another positive charge placed near them would be pushed away from them.

stem_mcq.title: Resistors
stem_mcq.description: Each resistor in the circuit below has a resistance of 2 Ω. The battery is a 12 V battery. What is the current across resistor B?

child_mcqs.explanation:
First off, we calculate the total resistance of the circuit, RT. This can be considered to be the sum of the parallel portion of the circuit, RP, and the other 2 ohm resistor (line 1). Line 2 is the formula used to calculate the resistance of a parallel circuit. Once you've calculated RP, you can simply add 2 ohms (representing the resistor in series with the parallel circuit) to calculate the total resistance of the circuit.

The total current flowing, the voltage is 12/3 = 4 amps as determined by Ohm's Law V=IR.

Since the battery is a 12 V battery, the total voltage drop must be 12 V. We can calculate the voltage drop across C as below

Which means that the voltage drop across the parallel circuit must be 12 - 8 = 4 V

As voltage is not split across elements in parallel (current is split across parallel circuits), 4 volts must pass across both resistors A and B, since their resistances are the same.  This means that the current flowing through resistor B will be

This is also the current that would flow through resistor A, as you'd expect in a parallel circuit with equal resistances in each branch.

stem_mcq.title: Pendulum in Electric Field
stem_mcq.description:
A positive point charge of unknown mass, `m`, is suspended on a massless sting in a uniform horizontal magnetic field as shown below. The magnitude of the charge is `q = 3  "coulombs"`. It is found experimentally that in order for the string to make a `45^circ` angle with the vertical that the electric field `E` must be adjusted to exactly `0.5  "N/C"`. 

 

Take the acceleration due to gravity to be `g = 10  "m/s"^2`.

The following exact values may be of use:

`sin(45)=cos(45)=1/sqrt(2)~~0.7`

child_mcqs.description: What is the mass of the charge?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Firstly recall that a charged particle in an electric field experiences a force given by `F=qE`. Since the charge is positive this force will act in the direction of the magnetic field (to the right).

Next, we can take the components of the tension in the string, `Tcos(45)` and `Tsin(45)`. Drawing all the forces acting on the charge:

We know that `Tcos(45)=Tsin(45)=T \times 1/sqrt(2)`.

The charge is stationary, so the horizontal forces must balance:

`qE=1/sqrt(2) T`

Similarly, the vertical forces must also balance:

`mg=1/sqrt(2) T`

Combining the two equations and making m (the mass) the subject yields:

`qE=mg`

`m=(qE)/g`

Substituting in q = 3, E = 0.5 N/C, g = 10 m.s-2

`m=(3xx0.5)/10`

`m=0.15  "kg"`

stem_mcq.title: Ice cube
stem_mcq.description:
An ice block of mass `28  "grams"` is held stationary against a vertical surface by a force `F`, applied at an angle of `60 ^circ` to the vertical. Assume friction between the ice and the surface is negligible. Take acceleration due to gravity to be `g = 10  "m/s"^2`.

The following exact values may be of use:

`cos(30)=sin(30)=sqrt(3)/2~~7/8`

`sin(30)=cos(60)=1/2`

child_mcqs.description: What is the magnitude of `F`?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Since the ice cube is held stationary we know that `F_"net"=0`. This means that the horizontal forces must balance and the vertical forces must balance. 

Taking the components of `F`, we see that the vertical component is given by `Fcos(60)=1/2 F` (cosine = adjacent/hypotenuse --> adjacent side to angle represents vertical component)

This upwards component `1/2 F` must exactly balance with the weight of the ice cube `mg`:

`1/2 F = mg`

`F = 2mg`

Substituting in,

`F = 2 xx 0.028 xx 10`

`F = 0.56  "N"`

stem_mcq.title: Forgetting Formulae
