stem_mcq.description:
A physics student is sitting an exam and working on a problem involving air resistance. Unfortunately, she has forgotten the equation for calculating air resistance, but is able to recall that it has the following form:

`F_"air resistance" = N A^a rho^b v^c`

`a`, `b`, and `c` are unknown whole numbers that the student can’t remember.

`N` is simply a number which depends on the shape of the object (no units).

`A` is the cross sectional area of the object given in units of `"m"^2`.

`rho` is the air density given in units of `"kg"/("m"^3)`.

`v` is the velocity of the object given in units of `"m"/"s"`
stem_mcq.tag: PHY03 Newton's Laws and Types of Forces

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is a unit of force equivalent to newtons?
child_mcqs.explanation:
From `F=ma`, we can determine that the units equivalent to a newton:

`[F]=[m][a]`

`"N"="kg" "m"/("s"^2)`

`"N"=("kg m")/("s"^2)`

child_mcqs.description: By checking that the units are consistent across each side of the equation, determine the values of `a`, `b`, and `c`, and thus the correct form of the formula for air resistance.
child_mcqs.explanation:
We know the units on both sides of the equals sign must be equivalent, so lets start by substituting in all the units we know:

`[F_"air resistance"] = [N] [A]^a [rho]^b [v]^c`

`("N") = (1) ("m"^2)^a ("kg"/("m"^3))^b ("m"/"s")^c`

Notice that since `N` has no units we have substituted in `1` to the equation, i.e. multiplying `N` with the other variables does not change the units.

From here, since all the units on the right hand side are in terms of `"m"`, `"kg"`, and `"s"`, it would help if we could represent force in terms of these units as well. From the previous question we determined that a newton is equivalent to a `"kg m"/("s"^2)`.

Thus,

`("kg m"/("s"^2))= ("m"^2)^a ("kg"/("m"^3))^b ("m"/"s")^c`

To ensure there is a `"kg"` on the numerator of each side we should choose `b=1`:

`"kg m"/("s"^2)= ("m"^2)^a ("kg"/("m"^3)) ("m"/"s")^c`

To ensure there is a `"s"^2` on the denominator of each side we should choose `c=2`:

`"kg m"/("s"^2)= ("m"^2)^a ("kg"/("m"^3)) ("m"/"s")^2`

`"kg m"/("s"^2)= ("m"^2)^a "kg"/("m s"^2)`

Finally, to ensure there is a `"m"` on the numerator of each side we should choose `a=1`:

`"kg m"/("s"^2)= ("m"^2) "kg"/("m s"^2)`

`"kg m"/("s"^2)= "kg m"/("s"^2)`

stem_mcq.title: Projectile Motion
stem_mcq.description:
Students conduct an experiment to study projectile motion. A projectile is launched from a spring-loaded gun. The gun launches the projectile from a hill and with the same speed each time. The gun is aimed so that the initial velocity of the projectile has an angle `theta` from the horizontal. The angle theta is increased by `15^o` each time the projectile is launched. The horizontal displacement d traveled by the projectile as well as the time `t` spent in flight is measured and recorded. The results are shown in the table below

Angle

Horizontal Displacement

Time

0°

14.0 m

1.4 s

15°

16.4 m

1.7 s

30°

17.3 m

2.0 s

45°

16.2 m

2.3 s

60°

12.6 m

2.5 s

75°

6.9 m

2.7 s

child_mcqs.description: Each time the projectile is launched, it leaves the spring-loaded gun with an initial speed of
child_mcqs.explanation:
The easiest case to deal with is when the gun is being fired at an angle of 0 degrees. This means all of the velocity will be in the horizontal direction. We know that the projectile takes 1.4 seconds to travel 14 m. Since the acceleration in the horizontal direction is zero, we can use the equation below and sub in `s = 14` m, `t = 1.4` s and `a_("horizontal") = 0 "ms"^-2`.

`v = s/t = 14/1.4 = 10"ms"^-1`

Alternatively, you could use the formula `s = ut + 1/2at^2  `, and set `a = 0 "ms"^-2`. Note that doing so gives `s = ut   ->    u = s/t`    where it doesn't matter whether `u` or `v` is being used to represent velocity, as in the horizontal direction, the velocity is constant.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is true concerning the projectile in the experiment?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A – cannot be correct by just reading the table.
B – the height the projectile travels should correspond to the angle it was fired at – with higher angles meaning the projectile moves higher in the air.  As we can see in the table, the smallest horizontal displacement corresponded to the highest angle, so this cannot be true.
C – The easiest way to think of this question is in terms of energy. The projectile started off at a height above the ground – so it must have some potential energy - and with an initial velocity – so it has some kinetic energy. If the height the ball is at lowers, from start to end, it must loose some potential energy, which will get transferred to kinetic energy. From this, it's clear the the kinetic energy must be higher after firing than                before, so the projectile must be moving fastest at the point at which it hits the ground.    So C cannot be correct.
D – by the logic of C, it’s clear that D must be correct.

answers.description: The longer the projectile remained in the air, the greater was its horizontal displacement
The higher the projectile went, the greater was its horizontal displacement
The speed of the projectile was greatest just after it left the spring-loaded gun
The speed of the projectile was greatest just before hitting the ground.

child_mcqs.description:
At what time is the projectile at it's highest point, when fired at an angle of `30^o`? The following may be useful:

`sin(60) = sqrt(3)/2`

`cos(60) = 1/2`

`sin(30) = 1/2`

`cos(30) = sqrt(3)/2`
child_mcqs.explanation:
Using `v = u + at`   in the vertical direction, and setting `v = 0 "ms"^-1`  :

`0 = 10sin(30) - 10t`

`t = 10sin(30)/10 = sin(30) = 1/2` s

child_mcqs.description: Approximately how high above the ground is the spring-loaded gun held when it releases the projectile?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Once again, use the case where the projectile is fired at zero degrees. In this case, it has no vertical velocity intially.

Using the equation, `s = ut + 1/2at^2` in regards to the vertical direction, where `u = 0 "ms"^-1`, `a = -10 "ms"^-2` and `t = 1.4` s

`s = 0 + 1/2 \times 10 \times 1.4^2`

`s = 5 \times 1.96 \approx 10  "m"`

Using other angles (not recommended!) with working below (using the `30^o` example)

Now we know the initial velocity, we can work out the height the projectile is fired from. If we take the 30 degree case, the vetical component of the velocity is 

`sin(30)xxu = 0.5xx10 = 5 "ms"^-1`

From here, we can work out the amount of time it takes for the projectile to reach its maximum height – which happens when the vertical velocity goes to zero.

`v = u + at`

`0 = 0.5xx10 - 10t`

`t = 0.5 "s"`

Going back to the table in the question, we know that the projectile takes 2 seconds from being fired to hitting the ground, so it must only take 1.5 seconds from its maximum height. Now we can set up two different equations. The first solves for the height the projectile travels above its starting point before stopping moving vertically – `s_h`. At this point, the projectile will be `H` meters above the ground, so we can solve a second equation to solve for how far it drops, to work out the height above where it lands that it was fired (which will be `H - s_h`)

`s_h = ut + 1/2at^2`

`s_h = 5xx0.5 - 0.5xx10xx0.5^2`

`s_h = 1.25m`

Now, we know the projectile is 1.25m above where it was fired. It is now `H` m above where it lands, and is at a vertical velocity of `0 "ms"^-1`.

`H = ut + 1/2at^2`

`H = 1/2xx(10)xx(1.5)^2`

`H = 5xx2.25 = 11.25 "m"`   note here that H should come out negative because the projectile will be dropping down from this height. However, as long as you understand what H represents, it isn't so important.

Therefore, it must have started

`H - s_h = 11.25 - 1.25 = 10 "m"` above ground.

stem_mcq.title: Vomit Comet
stem_mcq.description:
To train its astronauts NASA simulates weightlessness by taking advantage of the physics behind projectile motion. Reduced gravity aircraft are designed to be able to manoeuvre through a flight path that exactly replicates a parabolic trajectory. Thus, the passengers inside the plane follow a path of projectile motion with zero air resistance. 

Such a plane can only maintain an exact parabolic path for a time period of `24  "seconds"`. This time period is depicted below and starts at an altitude of `9000  "m"`. 

`u = "initial velocity of the plane"`

`g = 10  "m/s"^2`

 

The following equations of motion may be of use:

`v = u + at`

`s = ut + 1/2at^2`

`v^2 = u^2 + 2as`

child_mcqs.description: What is the vertical component of the planes initial velocity (`u_y`)?
child_mcqs.explanation:
To solve this question we must choose the correct constant acceleration equation.

We want to determine: `u_y`

We know: `a=-g`, and half way through the flight `v_y=0`,   `t=12  "s"`

So the equation we should use is: `v = u + at`

Substituting in,

`0 = u_y + (-10)xx12`

`u_y = 120  "m/s"`

child_mcqs.description: What is the maximum altitude reached by the plane?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Again, as the maximum altitude occurs half way through the flight, so we will use `v_y=0` and `t=12  "s"`. We also know `a=-g` and we want to determine `s_y`.

So the equation we should use is: `v^2 = u^2 + 2as`

Substituting in,

`0 = 120^2 + 2xx(-10)xxs_y`

`s_y = 120^2/20`

`s_y = 14400/20 = 1440/2`

`s_y = 720  "m"`

Adding this on to the initial altitude of `9000  "m"` gives a total of `9720  "m"`.

stem_mcq.title: Board of Physics
stem_mcq.description:
A student, with a mass of `80  "kg"`, is sitting at the end of a massless board, as shown below. The board does not bend, vibrate, or move in any way. The board is firmly attached to two supports at points `P_1` and `P_2`.

Take acceleration due to gravity to be `g = 10  "m/s"^2`.

child_mcqs.description: What is the magnitude of the torque about point `P_1` due to the student alone?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Torque is determined by `tau = F.d`, where `d` is the distance to the pivot under consideration. 

Here we are considering the torque about `P_1` due to the student's weight `mg`, so the distance we will use is `5  "m"`.

`tau = F.d = mg.d`

`tau = 80xx10xx5`

`tau = 4000  "Nm"`

Additonal notes

Students in the past have asked why `P_2` is ignored. While the normal force at `P_2` does contribute torque around `P_1`, this question did not ask what the net torque around `P_1`. (the net torque would be zero, because we're at equilibrium).

This would be akin to being asked what is the force due to gravity alone on an object sitting on the ground. The force due to gravity is mg, and is independent of the normal force also acting on the object.

child_mcqs.description: If the student stands up and walks left slowly towards point `P_2`, the normal force applied to the board due to the support at point `P_2` will be:
child_mcqs.explanation:
The torques about point `P_1` must add to zero for the system to be in equilibrium. As the student's weigh is initially causing a torque of `4000  "Nm"` clockwise, the support at `P_2` must initially be causing an equal torque of `4000  "Nm"` back in the other direction, anti-clockwise. So the support at `P_2` must be pushing upwards on the board. This eliminates answers C and D.

As the student walks to the left, they are decreasing their distance `d` to the pivot `P_1`. Thus, they are also decreasing the torque their weight is causing about `P_1`, from `4000  "Nm"` to something less. Since this torque is decreasing, so must the torque applied by support `P_2` to balance it. Since the distance between `P_1` and `P_2` remains constant, this means the upwards force at `P_2` must be decreasing.

stem_mcq.title: Half-life
stem_mcq.description:
is a radioactive isotope of phosphorous with a half-life of 14.3 days.

 

Note:

child_mcqs.description: How long will it take for 1.3×108atoms of to be depleted to 8 x 107 ?
child_mcqs.explanation:
This question involves using your understanding of what half life is.  If we were to directly calculate it, you would have to do the unpleasant calculation below.

However, as calculating log(8/13) without a calculator is beyond what you would be expected to do, we can reach this same answer through the definition of what the half life actually means – the amount of time it takes for half the particles to decay.

In this case, the system began with 1.3 x 108 atoms and was depleted to 8 x 107 atoms – a loss of slightly less than half the particles.

It takes 14.3 days for half the atoms to decay.

Therefore, the amount of time taken for this depletion should be slightly less than the half life of 14.3 days, suggesting answer B.

stem_mcq.title: Non-Uniform Field Strength
stem_mcq.description: The diagram below shows magnetic field (`B`) lines in some region of space.

child_mcqs.description: Choose the most accurate ranking for the relative magnitudes of the field strength at points A, B, C, and D, as indicated on the diagram above.
child_mcqs.explanation:
The density of the field lines is proportional to magnetic field strength. So in areas where the lines drawn as closer together, the field strength is greater. Whether the specific point lies on or off a field line doesn't matter, as these lines are simply representitive of a field that is present throughout the space.

The lines are closest together, and of equal spacing at points A and B. So the field is strongest at those points. Next, as the field lines spread out is point C. Lastly, point D is where the field is weakest and the lines are drawn furthest apart.

stem_mcq.title: Friction Forces
stem_mcq.description:
The world famous Altona Racing Track is a huge circular track of radius 160m. Circular tracks are dangerous because, if a driver loses control, the car will carry on in a direction tangential to the curve of the track and straight into the wall that surrounds it. Two safety features of the track help prevent this: 1) when the highway is dry, the frictional force between the tires and the road surface may be enough to prevent sliding; and 2) the track is banked, so that even when the track is wet and the frictional force is negligible, there is enough force to keep the cars from sliding.

Note: FNx is pointing towards the centre of the track.

The dotted vectors `F_{Nx}` and `F_{Ny}` are the horizontal and vertical components of `F_N`; they have been added to show that the bank angle of the track is equal to the angle between the vector `F_N` and `F_{Nx}`. They would not typically appear on a free body diagram.

Centripetal force is given by the equation `F_c = \frac{mv^2}{r}`
stem_mcq.tag: PHY03 Newton's Laws and Types of Forces

child_mcqs.description: On a wet day, when frictional force is negligible, what bank angle is required to keep a car travelling at 22m/s on the track?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The centripetal force required to turn the car is given by the formula

`F_c = \frac{mv^2}{r}`

as stated by the question.

The only force acting in the horizontal direction that could provide this centripetal force is `F_{Nx}`. Therefore

`F_{Nx} = \frac{mv^2}{r}`

To work out the angle, we need to either calculate `F_N` or `F_{Ny}` and use the appropriate trigometric ratio. I will use `F_{Ny}` since it is much quicker.

To work out `F_{Ny}`, use the fact that vertical equillibrium is in effect. `F_{Ny}` balances out `mg` in this case, such that

`F_{Ny} = mg`

`F_N{x}` can be expressed in terms of `F_{Ny}` using the tangent trigometric ratio `tan\theta = \frac{"Opposite"}{"Adjacent"}`

`tan\theta = \frac{F_{Nx}}{F_{Ny}}`  where `\theta` is the angle represented by the question mark, and equal to the bank angle.

We know that `F_{Ny} = mg` (vertical equillibrium). In addition, `F_{Nx} = \frac{mv^2}{r}` (provides centripetal force). Therefore

`tan\theta = \frac{mv^2}{r} \div mg`

`tan\theta =\frac{mv^2}{r} \times 1/{mg}`

`tan\theta = \frac{v^2}{rg}`

`\theta = tan^-1(\frac{v^2}{rg})`

child_mcqs.description: An extra safety feature is the addition of spoilers to the cars, which adds an extra downward force FL to aid gravity. How will FNx change as a result of this addition?
child_mcqs.explanation: Adding a spoiler will add a vertical force acting downwards on the car. However, the car must stay in vertical equilibrium. As a result, the normal force `F_N` must increase. If `F_N` increases, so will `F_{Nx}`

child_mcqs.description: The track is now dry and an 800kg car has come to a complete stop on the banked surface, what is the coefficient of static friction (μs) required for this to occur. Pick the best solution: (note: `F_f = muxxF_N`)
child_mcqs.explanation:
Because the car is stationary, the way the forces cancel changes. See the diagram below.

Now, the normal force is equal to the perpendicular component of the weight force.

`mgcos(theta) = N`

Equating the friction force `mumgcos(theta)` and the parallel component of the weight force (down the incline) `mgsin(theta)`

`mumgcos(theta) = mgsin(theta)`

`mu = sin(theta)/cos(theta)`

stem_mcq.title: Obesity Bed
stem_mcq.description:
With an increasingly obese population, the designers of hospital trolley beds have had to redesign them to accommodate larger patients. The designers for a company are required to design a bed able to support a 150kg person.

The following is one of their designs:

Gravitational constant is taken to be 10 ms-2

child_mcqs.description: Initially designers assume the centre of mass is in the centre of the bed, and a safety factor of 3 times intended load is required. Supports A and B need to withstand:
child_mcqs.explanation:
A safety factor of 3 means that the designers would want a bed that could support 3 times more weight than what it would be rated for. So if the bed was meant to carry a 150kg person, then by taking into account the safety factor, the design should support a 450kg person, or 4500N of force, located at the centre of the bed, so the sum of the forces on the two supports should be 4500N, eliminating solutions A and B.

Intuitively, the closer a support is to the centre of mass, then more weight it must support. Support B is closer to the centre of mass compared to support A, so it must support more weight. This implies answer C.

child_mcqs.description: A motor is added to raise the trolley bed. The bed must be raised at a rate of 5 cm/s for a 150kg person. What is the power output of the motor required to achieve this?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Power is the change in energy over the change in time.  If the bed moves up 5cm every second, it gains potential energy every second.

We can work out how much potential energy it gains every second, remembering to use SI units (5 cm = 0.05 m)

So the bed moves up 5 cm a second, gaining 75 J of potential energy per second. This energy must come from the motor, which is providing the power requirement of 75 J/s (or 75 W) to achieve this.

child_mcqs.description: The bed should also have the ability to be inclined at certain angles. Given the coefficient of friction µ is 0.2 and maximum friction is F=µN (where N is the normal reaction force), roughly at what inclination will a patient of unknown weight begin to slip (choose the best solution)?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The component of the weight force going down the slope will be:

The normal force, and the frictional force will be:

For the patient to not slide down the slope, the frictional force must balance out the component of the force going down the slope, so:

As sin divided by cos equals tan, we can rearrange this to give:

Power, measured in watts, and can be calculated by:

child_mcqs.description: What is the chirality of the front carbon?
child_mcqs.explanation: Both carbon atoms are not chiral, hence no optical activity.

child_mcqs.description:
Given that electron clouds of atoms bonded to neighbouring carbons repel each other, what is the most stable conformation of butane?

            I                                                         II                                                        III                                                      IV

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is the IUPAC name for this non-polar alkane?
child_mcqs.explanation: Nomenclature dictates the longest carbon chain as the primary backbone, hence the hydrocarbon must be a nonane.

child_mcqs.description: Benzoyl chloride reacts with ammonia to form benzamide. Which of the following molecules is the correct structure for benzamide?
child_mcqs.explanation: An amide is when a carbonyl group is connected to the same carbon as an amine group, hence Answer 3 is correct.

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following statements about halogenation in alkanes is true?

I. It can involve addition of F, Br, Cl or N
III. It typically leads to oxidation of an organic molecule
child_mcqs.explanation:
Statement I is false because addition of N is not halogenation (addition of F/Cl/Br/I)

Statement II is true - formation of a C-X bond is an oxidation reaction as the halogens have higher electronegativities than carbon.

stem_mcq.title: Ideal gas equations
stem_mcq.description:
Although it does not model reality perfectly, the best known gas law is the Ideal Gas Law, which is frequently used to model the behaviour of gases. It states that the pressure and volume for a gas with temperature T, number of moles n and molar gas constant R is

PV = nRT

An important consequence of the law is that in the absence of energy input into a gas, PV is a constant.

child_mcqs.description: Consider a box containing two gases at equilibrium as below. The gases are separated by a non-permeable partition that can move freely and frictionlessly from side to side. The partition and the box itself are perfectly insulating, so that they cannot transfer or conduct heat. The gas in the left side of the box is heated to 150 K and the box is left to reach a new equilibrium. What is the volume of each side of the box once a new equilibrium is reached?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The question states that the box and partition are perfectly insulating, so that there is no transfer of heat outside of the gas on the left and it stays at 150 K, where the gas on the right stays at 100 K. Initially, the product PV on both sides is 5. After heating, the temperature on the left increases by a factor of 1.5, so that the product PV must also increase by a  factor of 1.5, so that it is now 7.5. As there is no energy input into the gas on the right, the product PV on the right is still 5.

Now consider what happens to the partition. If it didn’t move i.e. no change in volume occurred, then the pressure on the left would have to increase to 1.5 atm to compensate for the increase in temperature. However, if the pressure is larger on the left than the right, then the partition will move to decrease the pressure on the left and increase the pressure on the right until a new equilibrium is reached i.e. one where the pressures on either side are equal and the net force is equal.

The problem is thus finding a set of pressure and volume values such that total volume is still 10 L, the pressure in both sides is equal, and the products of pressure and volume are 7.5 on the left and 5 on the right. This gives a set of simultaneous equations.

PleftVleft = 7.5
PrightVright = 5
Pleft = Pright
Vleft = 10 - Vright

Substituting the last two equations into the first two gives

Pright(10-Vright) = 7.5
PrightVright = 5

Solving these gives Pleft = Pright = 1.25 atm, Vright = 4 L and Vleft = 6 L

answers.description: 4 L on the left, 6 L on the right
5 L on the left, 5 L on the right
6 L on the left, 4 L on the right
7.5 L on the left, 2.5 L on the right

child_mcqs.description: Consider a box containing two gases at equilibrium as below. The gases are separated by a non-permeable partition that can move freely and frictionlessly from side to side. The box is sitting in a room at standard temperature and pressure. A whole is cut in the box on the right that allows gas to escape or enter freely and the box is left to re-equilibrate. What is the volume of each side of the box once a new equilibrium is reached?
child_mcqs.explanation: This is similar to the last question. The product PV on both sides must stay constant, and at equilibrium the pressures on both sides of the partition must be equal. Once the box is opened, the right hand side essentially becomes the atmosphere, with gas escaping until this side is in equilibrium  with the atmosphere (1 atm). If the right hand side is continuous with the atmosphere, then it will always have 1 atm pressure, and so the left hand side will expand until the gas in the left is also at 1 atm pressure. The initial PV product on the left is 7.5, which it must be after it expands. If PV = 7.5 and P = 1, then the new volume on the left is 7.5 L

answers.description: 5 L on the left, 5 L on the right
6 L on the left, 4 L on the right
7.5 L on the left, 2.5 L on the right
10 L on the left, 0 L on the right

child_mcqs.description:
When a pressure difference exists across a membrane, the force on the membrane from the side at higher pressure can be calculated as

F = ΔP. A

where F is the force, ΔP the pressure difference across the partition(in Pa) and A the surface area of the partition (in m2). A box with a moveable partition of surface area 2 m2 is initially resting at room temperature and pressure in equilibrium with the atmosphere as below. A weight is then placed on the partition, compressing the gas such that the pressure is now 1.1 atm. What is the mass of the weight?

(1 atm = 1x105 Pa, assume g = 10 ms-2)
child_mcqs.explanation:
Once the gas is compressed, there is a force on the membrane pushing it up from the compressed gas. This has to be countered exactly by the weight force of the weight pushing down. The force from the compressed gas can be calculated from the equation in the preamble; A = 2, and ΔP = 10000 Pa (note the conversion from atm to Pa), so F = 20000 N. This is equal to the weight of the object, mg.

mg = 20000
10m = 20000
m = 2000 kg

child_mcqs.description: Consider the box in the question above, after the addition of the weight. The box has a volume of 100 L after compression and is insulated so that no heat can be transferred into or out of the box. The compressed gas is then heated to a temperature of 546 K and allowed to expand or contract to a new equilibrium. What is the volume of the box?
child_mcqs.explanation: Initially the PV product in the box is 110, so when temperature doubles, the product must also double to 220. We thus know that the final P and V must multiply to 220. The box will expand until the pressure drops to 1.1 atm, as this is the point where the pressure difference across the partition is balanced by the weight of the weight. If the pressure is 1.1 atm, and PV = 220, then the V = 200 L

title: Exam 2
instruction:
This GradReady Practice Exam is meant to test your ability to take the GAMSAT. The idea behind this exam is to help you assess what you have learned and where you may still be struggling. You will get the best results from this exam if you treat it as if it were the actual GAMSAT.

Upon completion of the exam you will be able to see your score. Your essay will be graded by a tutor, and feedback will be given.

Today’s Exam consists of 3 Sections:

Section 1: Reasoning in Humanities and Social Sciences (10 min reading time + 1 hr 40 min)

Section 2: Written Communication - Essay (5 min reading time + 1 hr)

Lunch Break (1 hr)

Section 3: Reasoning in Biological & Physical Sciences (10 minute reading time + 2 hr 50 min)

Good luck!

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is found in the memoir “The Neon Bible”.

 

This is the first time I've been on a train. I've sat in this seat here for about

two or three hours now. I can't see what's passing by. It's dark now, but when the

train left, the sun was just beginning to set, and I could see the red and brown

leaves and the tanning grass all along the hillside.

I feel a little better the further the train gets from the house. The tingling

that has been running up and down the inside of my legs is stopping, and my feet

feel like they're really there now, and not like two cold things that don't really

belong to the rest of my body. I'm not as scared anymore.

There's a colored fellow coming through between the seats. He's snapped

off every one of the lights over the seats. There's just a tiny red one glowing at the

end of the coach, and I'm sorry it isn't bright here anymore by my seat, because I

start to think too much in the dark about what's back in the house. They must

have turned the heat off too. It's cold in here. I wish I had a blanket to throw over

my knees and something to put over this seat so the plush wouldn't scratch the

back of my neck.

If it was day outside, I could see where I was. I've never been this far from

home in my life. We must be almost two hundred miles away now. With nothing

to see, you have to listen to the click-click-click of the train. Sometimes I hear the

whistle sounding far ahead. I've heard it plenty times, but I never thought I'd be

riding with it. And I don't mind the clicking. It sounds like the rain on a tin roof at

night when it's quiet and still and the only thing you can hear is the rain and the

thunder. But I had a train of my own. It was a toy one I got for Christmas when I

was three. That was when Poppa was working at the factory and we lived in the

little white house in town that had a real roof you could sleep under when it

rained, and not a tin one like the place on the hill had that leaked through the nail

holes too.

People came to see us that Christmas. We always had some people in the

house, coming in blowing and rubbing their hands together and shaking out their

coats like it was snowing outside. But there was no snow. Not that year. But they

were nice, and brought me things. I remember the preacher gave me a book of

Bible stories. But that was most likely because my mother and father were paying

church members then, with their names on the rolls and both of them in the Adult

Study Class that met every Sunday at nine and Wednesday night at seven for a

social. I was in the Pre-School Play section, but we never played like the name

said. We had to listen to stories some old woman read to us out of a grownup

book that we didn't understand.

Mother was very hospitable that year I got the train. Everybody got some

of her fruitcake that she was proud of. She said it was from an old family recipe,

but I found out later she got the cake through a mail order from some company in

Wisconsin called the Olde English Baking Company, Limited. I found that out

when I learned to read and saw it in the mail a few Christmases later when we

didn't have any people over and we had to eat it ourselves. No one ever knew,

though, that she didn't make it, except me and Mother and maybe the man at the

post office, but he was a deaf mute and couldn't tell anybody.

I don't remember any children my age coming around that Christmas. As a

matter of fact, there weren't any children my age living around us at all. After

Christmas was over, I stayed in the house and played with my train. It was too

cold outside, and about January it began to snow. Heavy snows that year,

although everyone thought they'd never come.

It was that spring that Mother's Aunt Mae came to live with us. She was

heavy but not fat, and about sixty, and came from out of state somewhere where

they had nightclubs. I asked Mother why her hair wasn't shiny and yellow like

Aunt Mae's, and she said some people were just lucky, and I felt sorry for her.

child_mcqs.description: The essential style of this passage would be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: To claim the passage is inessential (an absolute necessity) is a judgment which cannot be made given the lack of context for the passage.  Therefore Option C is not correct.  The passage engages with the past, but also the present, and ideas whose scope exceeds the author.  Therefore Option D is not correct.  The style of the passage is thoughtful, so option A is a possibility.  However Option B best describes the scope of the passage and is therefore the answer.

child_mcqs.description: More than an object the train is used by the author as a
child_mcqs.explanation: The use of the train is not metaphorical because it only represents itself, so Option A is incorrect.  A leitmotif is a musical term, thus Option C is incorrect.  As a meta-commentary references to the train would not work as they are an essential part of the actual narrative.  B is the best option as the train is a dominant theme in the passage.

child_mcqs.description: The point of view in the passage is that of
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage is split between contemporary observations and nostalgia.  The memories presented in the passage are those of a child, referring to parents, gifts and discovering aspects of the world, suggesting that Options A or D are correct. However there is not clear indication of the authors current age, suggesting that Option D is the best answer.

answers.description: An adult remembering crucial details of their childhood
An adult remembering his life from a childlike perspective
A figure of indeterminate age remembering periods of his life
A figure of indeterminate age remembering his childhood

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
The following is a passage from the novel “1984”

 

Winston thought. “By making a man suffer,” he said.

“Exactly. By making him suffer. Obedience is not enough. Unless he is suffering, how can you

be sure that he is obeying your will and not his own? Power is in inflicting pain and humiliation.

Power is in tearing human minds to pieces and putting them together again in new shapes of your

own choosing. Do you begin to see, then, what kind of world we are creating? It is the exact

opposite of the stupid hedonistic Utopias that the old reformers imagined. A world of fear and

treachery is torment, a world of trampling and being trampled upon, a world which will grow not

less but MORE merciless as it refines itself. Progress in our world will be progress towards more

pain. The old civilizations claimed that they were founded on love or justice. Ours is founded upon

hatred. In our world there will be no emotions except fear, rage, triumph, and self-abasement.

Everything else we shall destroy -- everything. Already we are breaking down the habits of thought

which have survived from before the Revolution. We have cut the links between child and parent,

and between man and man, and between man and woman. No one dares trust a wife or a child or a

friend any longer. But in the future there will be no wives and no friends. Children will be taken from

their mothers at birth, as one takes eggs from a hen. The sex instinct will be eradicated. Procreation

will be an annual formality like the renewal of a ration card. We shall abolish the orgasm. Our

neurologists are at work upon it now. There will be no loyalty, except loyalty towards the Party.

There will be no love, except the love of Big Brother. There will be no laughter, except the laugh of

triumph over a defeated enemy. There will be no art, no literature, no science. When we are

omnipotent we shall have no more need of science. There will be no distinction between beauty and

ugliness. There will be no curiosity, no enjoyment of the process of life. All competing pleasures will

be destroyed. But always -- do not forget this, Winston -- always there will be the intoxication of

power, constantly increasing and constantly growing subtler. Always, at every moment, there will be

the thrill of victory, the sensation of trampling on an enemy who is helpless. If you want a picture of

the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face -- for ever.”

child_mcqs.description: The political ideology being described is likely
child_mcqs.explanation: While A. and C. could be applicable there is not specific evidence to suggest either.  B. is not supported by the passage.  D. is the most broadly applicable to the kind of control described in the passage.

child_mcqs.description: The effectiveness of O’Brien's over-arching message is mainly communicated by:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is correct. Logic does not need to be ethical to be accepted. The passage is strong in logical foundation, best seen here; "Already we are breaking down the habits of thought which have survived from before the Revolution. We have cut the links between child and parent, and between man and man, and between man and woman. No one dares trust a wife or a child or a friend any longer. But in the future there will be no wives and no friends. Children will be taken from their mothers at birth, as one takes eggs from a hen. The sex instinct will be eradicated.” The sentences bounce logically between ideas, that is, there are no radically jumps between the ideologies of the phrases. The details of the passage do not support B, C, or D.

child_mcqs.description:
He paused as though he expected Winston to speak. Winston had tried to shrink back into the surface of the bed again. He could not say anything. His heart seemed to be frozen. O’Brien went on: 

“And remember that it is forever. The face will always be there to be stamped upon. The heretic, the enemy of society, will always be there, so that he can be defeated and humiliated over again. Everything that you have undergone since you have been in our hands -- all that will continue, and worse. The espionage, the betrayals, the arrests, the tortures, the executions, the disappearances will never cease. It will be a world of terror as much as a world of triumph. The more the Party is powerful, the less it will be tolerant: the weaker the opposition, the tighter the despotism. Goldstein and his heresies will live for ever. Every day, at every moment, they will be defeated, discredited, ridiculed, spat upon and yet they will always survive. This drama that I have played out with you during seven years will be played out over and over again generation after generation, always in subtler forms." 

Which literary technique is prominent in this passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: "The party" is described as 'powerful' and 'less tolerant'; both attributes of a person. Similarly, the sentence, "Goldstein and his heresies will live for ever... will be defeated, discredited, ridiculed, spat upon and yet they will always survive" is personifying Goldstein's heresies as if they (the ideas) are people that can be spat upon. Thus, Option D, 'personification', is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: What would best describe what O’Brien is exposing Winston to?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is correct. A good student would narrow these options down to A and C. In C, the nature of propaganda is that one imposes biased or unfair views on another, which O’Brien is indeed doing. This is an objective action though, in which O’Brien merely states ‘facts' to Winston. The nature of O’Brien's prose would thus need to be convincing Winston, ie. An appeal for Winston to change, for option A to be correct. We indeed see this through phrases such as: "putting them together again in new shapes of your own choosing. Do you begin to see, then, what kind of world we are creating?” O’Brien does not want to lose Winston and thus the passage is basically a persuasive political monologue to Winston. This would support A.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon is a satire of
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D is correct. The two individuals pictured are tip-to-toe in symbols of the modern era; short skirt, make-up, earrings on her, earring, goatee (modern facial hair style) and an opulently lavish haircut on him. Yes, there’s no flying ship or anything that harshly obvious, but the subtle clues definitely indicate the 21st century. The fact that the man in the cartoon is kneeling in the traditional method of proposing marriage, and yet is actually asking "will you add me to your health plan" is a satire of the modern trend (i.e. 21st century) towards marriage being less about a committed relationship, and more about the effect it has on the bureaucracies of everyday like; including things such as effecting health insurance premiums. Everything leads to option D being correct.

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon’s subtext is
child_mcqs.explanation: While Answers C and D may be true, they do not form part of the subtext, or deeper meaning, of the cartoon, and are thus incorrect. The subtext of this cartoon is that the man wants to marry the woman because of the benefit it will give to him personally, e.g. access to her health care plan. However, although he his specifically referring to the healthcare plan, Answer B is does not completely encompass this aspect, and thus Answer A, that he is planning on relying on the woman, is the best option.

answers.description: That the man plans to rely on the woman
That the man needs access to a health plan
That the woman is keen to get married
That marriage will not change the relationship

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon’s prime audience is
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage is addressing the global phenomenon of social networking and the opinions of the general public on social networking.  As such all options but D are too narrow.  D is correct.

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon addresses
child_mcqs.explanation: The cartoon examines the impact of various social media platforms on how we communicate and even experience primal events.  As such it represents nothing short of a basic change in how we see and experience the world.  Option C is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8

child_mcqs.description: For the cartoon’s humour to work the reader requires most
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is not correct sinice it is assumed for any kind of humour, and it thus not specific for the cartoon. The readers don't need to have a watched King Kong, since the humour is not based on the specific plot points of the film but rather the Ape’s response.  D. is not supported by the cartoon.  Option C is correct since the humour is found in the absurdity of the ape's response.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is from “The Uses of Enchantment”.

 

“Little Red Riding Hood was my first love. I felt that if I could have married Little Red Riding

Hood, I should have known perfect bliss.” This statement by Charles Dickens indicates that he,

like untold millions of children all over the world throughout the ages, was enchanted by fairy

tales. Even when world-famous, Dickens acknowledged the deep formative impact that the

wondrous figures and events of fairy tales had had on him and his creative genius. He

repeatedly expressed scorn for those who, motivated by an uninformed and petty rationality,

insisted on rationalizing, bowdlerizing, or outlawing these stories, and thus robbed children of

the important contributions fairy tales could make to their lives. Dickens understood that the

imagery of fairy tales helps children better than anything else in their most difficult and yet

most important and satisfying task: achieving a more mature consciousness to civilize the

chaotic pressures of their unconscious.

Today, as in the past, the minds of both creative and average children can be opened to an

appreciation of all the higher things in life by fairy tales, from which they can move easily to

enjoying the greatest works of literature and art. The poet Louis MacNeice, for example, tells

that “Real fairy stories always meant much to me as a person, even when I was at a public

school where to admit this meant losing face. Contrary to what many people say even now, a

fairy story, at least of the classical folk variety, is a much more solid affair than the average

naturalistic novel, whose hooks go little deeper than a gossip column. From folk tales and

sophisticated fairy tales such as Hans Andersen’s or Norse mythology and stories like the Alice

books and Water Babies I graduated, at about the age of twelve, to the FaerieQueene.”

Literary critics such as G. K. Chesterton and C. S. Lewis felt that fairy stories are “spiritual

explorations” and hence “the most life-like” since they reveal “human life as seen, or felt, or

divined from the inside.”

Fairy tales, unlike any other form of literature, direct the child to discover his identity and

calling, and they also suggest what experiences are needed to develop his character further.

Fairy tales intimate that a rewarding, good life is within one’s reach despite adversity—but only

if one does not shy away from the hazardous struggles without which one can never achieve

true identity. These stories promise that if a child dares to engage in this fearsome and taxing

search, benevolent powers will come to his aid, and he will succeed. The stories also warn that

those who are too timorous and narrow-minded to risk themselves in finding themselves must

settle down to a humdrum existence—if an even worse fate does not befall them.

Past generations of children who loved and felt the importance of fairy tales were subjected to

the scorn only of pedants, as happened to MacNeice. Today many of our children are far more

grievously bereaved—because they are deprived of the chance to know fairy stories at all. Most

children now meet fairy tales only in prettified and simplified versions which subdue their

meaning and rob them of all deeper significance—versions such as those on films and TV

shows, where fairy tales are turned into empty-minded entertainment.

child_mcqs.description: Fairy tales would be typified best as
child_mcqs.explanation: While A. and B. both might be appropriate answers for this question, the emphasis on the child learning about functioning successfully within the adult world would suggest B. as more appropriate.  C. is definitely never mentioned and while D. might be appropriate, it only accounts for a small part of the appeal of such tales.

child_mcqs.description: Children, as described, are gendered
child_mcqs.explanation: References to “his” would indicate the answer as A.  To refer to the child being described as “masculine” would fail to be specific enough to describe such a use of language.

child_mcqs.description: The text was most likely written in the
child_mcqs.explanation: References to television would rule out A and D, as would reference to C. S. Lewis. Additionally typically, in recent modern English there would be a references to “his or her” when referring to gender non-specific character (e.g "benevolent powers will come to his aid") as it more politically correct, thus making Option B more likely than Option C.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage explores the composition style of Howard Shore for the soundtrack of The Hobbit.

As Gandalf marks Bag End with a rune, the Shire theme is stretched over minor harmonies better suited to a Wizard than a Hobbit (B minor–G minor). It is the first time this variation has appeared in the Shire, but it will not be the last, for it becomes synonymous with Bilbo’s “odd” behavior. But how could he behave otherwise? Alerted by the Wizard’s mark — and accompanied by a touch of uilleann pipes — a throng of hungry Dwarves soon comes trundling into Bag End to blunt the knives and crack the plates. The Dwarves, however, intend to assault more than Bilbo’s cutlery. Led by Thorin Oakenshield, the company has assembled to plot their return to the lost kingdom of Erebor. Gandalf has decreed that Bilbo is to join the Dwarves’ quest as their resident burglar — despite his complete lack of burgling experience. Bilbo protests that he is a Baggins, and thus better suited to plush chairs and musty books. But Gandalf knows that the son of Belladonna Took is tempted by the opportunity to see the world beyond his windows. Bilbo will always be a citizen of the Shire, and its theme will always define him. The pull-and-push inherent in Bilbo’s dual natures creates a unique two-part variation of the Shire theme that stretches its pentatonic-flavored harmonies into something more expressive and thoughtful. For better or worse, Bilbo is no ordinary Hobbit. The first half of his theme wraps itself tightly in safe, warm harmonies and cozy melodic contours. However, after a subtle harmonic turn, the theme moves into a new key and exposes Bilbo’s emerging thirst for excitement with leaping intervals and a stout, confident tone.

The Dwarves, too, are defined by their homeland. Long ago, under the leadership of Thrór, King Under the Mountain and grandfather to Thorin Oakenshield, Erebor was a place of great wealth and power depicted by a proud, compact figure rising in three horn-calls, but remaining stubbornly affixed to its root (A–C; A–D; A–E). Most cherished among Thrór’s treasures was the Arkenstone, a luminous white gem matched to a glowing choral cluster and a stately string line in B minor. Word of Thrór’s riches soon reached Smaug the Dragon, who attacked Erebor, ousted the Dwarves, and claimed their golden hoard as his own. Countless Dwarves were left to wander the wilderness; their once-mighty race brought low.

Thorin has taken it upon himself to right this wrong. His theme directly recalls Erebor’s, though it moves by bitter steps, not proud leaps. As a lonely French horn melody passes above A minor and G major harmonies, Thorin’s resolve is painted with a sense of longing and melancholy. His theme expresses grim determination and the soul of a Dwarf who cannot forgive and cannot forget. Yet nestled in the noble remorse of Thorin’s theme there is hope: the stepwise motion that opens his theme is the same that begins the Shire theme. Perhaps there is more to the Dwarves’ new burglar than meets the eye — perhaps the quest for Erebor is not in vain.

Still, if Erebor is to be retaken, Smaug must be defeated. Shore’s theme for Smaug heaves like the bellows of a great furnace. Low brass and divisi celli and basses deliberately alternate between major and minor iterations of the same pulsing chord (F major–F minor–F major– F minor). Bass drum and Tibetan gongs rumble and clatter while low harp quivers with improvised patterns. Above this, winds and strings play a line that worms through chromatic intervals with an exotic gleam (E–E–F–A ; E–F–A –A –A –C ). The Dragon still lies far to the east, however, and before the Dwarves can reach him, a long journey awaits. With their burglar Hobbit in tow, Thorin’s company sets out from Bag End accompanied by Shore’s bold setting of the “Misty Mountains” song (composed by Plan 9 and David Long) — and by a comic triple-beat clarinet figure in D minor that represents Bilbo’s fussy inflexibility.

child_mcqs.description: The fundamental message that the text exudes is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. B and C are the best two options. Option B presents a case in which the nature of the character is augmented/increased/bolstered by the music played; which is true, but not the main message in the text. The main message in the text is that musical techniques are used to assign/give/endow (not necessarily enhance) the characteristics of a given character. We can do a little experiment with this. Consider the phrase: "Erebor was a place of great wealth and power depicted by a proud, compact figure rising in three horn-calls, but remaining stubbornly affixed to its root (A–C; A–D; A–E)”, of which many similar ones exist in the text. If B were correct, it would likely read that “Erebor became a place of greater wealth and greater power”, if the A–C; A–D; A–E pattern were installed. But the text does not say that. It says that Erebor is as it is in the film because of the A–C; A–D; A–E pattern used, a conclusion far better answered by option C.

child_mcqs.description: The theme accompanying Bilbo has
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage describes the changing nature of the themes (keys) as Bilbos journey progresses, and as his character develops 'an emerging thirst for excitement'. This accurately reflects the idea that the hobbit is represented by the key that best matches his demeanour at the time. Thus, the descriptions of the key changes surrounding the character of Bilbo indicate that Option C is likely the best answer.  This gives the composer the required flexibility.  Other options are rather more limiting. Option D is not really any kind of satisfactory answer when the necessity of musical key is considered.

child_mcqs.description: The choices of composer Howard Shore would be best described as
child_mcqs.explanation: C. as an answer is a redundancy.  D. is not supported by the passage.  A.  is too subjective and not really supported by any observations in the passage.  B. is the best answer.

answers.description: Coinciding with the associations of the narrative

child_mcqs.description: The phrase “a lonely French horn” likely expresses
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer B is a too-literal intepretation of the phrase, while Answer A does not successfully explain why the term “lonely” is used instead of “solo”.  Answers C and D are similar, however D recognizes the purposeful nature of the composition in leading to the horn having a lonely element, and is thus correct.

answers.description: That it is a solo horn and lonely in this context
That the overall composition lends a lonely element to the horn

child_mcqs.description:
On the road, Gandalf explains that he is not the only Wizard in Middle-earth. Radagast the Brown lives along the southern borders of Mirkwood where he cares for the flora and fauna as if they were his own. Radagast’s theme is a whir of perpetual motion — an oscillating flow of sawing half steps, rapid arpeggios, and swirling trills enrobed in disheveled fragments of diminished harmonies. Light percussion pecks away with accompanimental sextuplets on shakers, gourds, and woodblocks, while low strings and winds bubble upward. Above this dense collection of forest murmurs, boys chorus sings a text by Phillippa Boyens: “Meno, edveno / O galad vos ilais / Lim, meno lim / Na fuin, trí dhuaith … ” (“Away! Away! / From soft leaf-light / Hurry! Hurry! / Through dark of night … ”).Radagast’s perpetual motion serves a purpose: a Necromancer now haunts Middle-earth. Little is known of this sorcerer, but there is a disturbingly familiar ring to his themes. The Necromancer and his lair are first represented by two heavy motifs. The first is a pair of descending major thirds, and the second is a rising trellis of three ascending pitches that evades downbeats. Low winds announce these ominous figures while timpani, Japanese taiko, and the West African dunun drum thunder in the percussion section. But these wonderous figures are followed by a wailing line for two oboes and cor anglais that rises a strident half step, then descends through augmented intervals to form the theme of the Necromancer. The exotic tone of the Necromancer’s theme calls to mind the early days of Middle-earth, but there is a more treacherous connection as well: the same pitches that form this theme also form the string line that perches atop Smaug’s theme.

The composition style taken with the Necromancer offers
child_mcqs.explanation: Given that Smaug’s theme has already appeared and his evil nature is known, the commonality of the dragon’s theme with the Necromancer’s forms the basis of their connection, suggesting that Option B is a posibility. However, given that the nature of the Necormancer is currently an unknown, this commonality in themes could best be described as giving hints as to his nature, thus Option C is correct.  Other options misconstrue the relationship, or make inappropriate reference to Radagast.

answers.description: Clues as to the nature of the Necromancer
Clues as to the nature of Smaug

child_mcqs.description:
Smaug is yet uncommitted to any cause but his own, and remains a distant threat. A more immediate peril is the pack of Orcs that hunts the Dwarves. A theme for low brass stalks the forest alongside the barbaric horde. It is the second theme in the score to comprise a pair of descending thirds — though a fifth pitch falls an additional half step and clatters in aleatoric patterns (G–E –F–D–D ). The fatalistic line is sharp, vicious, and unrelentingly predatory.

Not all of the Dwarves’ enemies are so cunning, however. In the forest, Bilbo encounters a trio of Trolls: crude behemoths who have stolen a pair of the Dwarves’ ponies and plan to make a meal of their prize. Bilbo is assigned the responsibility of retrieving the ponies, but he is no more a hero than he is a burglar. While his triple-meter D minor theme protests, Bilbo does his best to enact a rescue, but he only manages to make the situation worse. The Trolls, too, are represented by a theme in triple meter — a grunting ‘waltz humoresque’ that becomes less amusing as it progresses from delicate pizzicato strings to low reeds and menacing brass. Even at its most threatening, the music of the Trolls is blunt and brutish. By contrast, the music of the Wargs is sleek, lean, and sharp as an arrow. Over repeated eighth notes, four-note patterns in E minor simultaneously rise and fall, snapping tight like the jaws of the wolf-like beasts.

A summary of composition in relation to the trolls would be
child_mcqs.explanation: The music of the trolls begins funny, then becomes threatening.  This would be most closely reflected in C.  Other options do not allow for the transition, or limit the possibilities that the time signature could in fact be amusing.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
The following is from the novel “The Great Gatsby”.

Gatsby walked over and stood beside her.

‘Daisy, that’s all over now,’ he said earnestly. ‘It doesn’t matter any more. Just tell him the truth—that you never loved him—and it’s all wiped out forever.’

She looked at him blindly. ‘Why,—how could I love him—possibly?’

‘You never loved him.’

She hesitated. Her eyes fell on Jordan and me with a sort of appeal, as though she realized at last what she was doing—and as though she had never, all along, intended doing anything at all. But it was done now. It was too late.

‘I never loved him,’ she said, with perceptible reluctance.

‘Not at Kapiolani?’ demanded Tom suddenly.

‘No.’

From the ballroom beneath, muffled and suffocating chords were drifting up on hot waves of air.

‘Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry?’ There was a husky tenderness in his tone. ‘… Daisy?’

‘Please don’t.’ Her voice was cold, but the rancour was gone from it. She looked at Gatsby. ‘There, Jay,’ she said—but her hand as she tried to light a cigarette was trembling. Suddenly she threw the cigarette and the burning match on the carpet.

‘Oh, you want too much!’ she cried to Gatsby. ‘I love you now—isn’t that enough? I can’t help what’s past.’ She began to sob helplessly. ‘I did love him once—but I loved you too.’

Gatsby’s eyes opened and closed.

‘You loved me TOO?’ he repeated.

‘Even that’s a lie,’ said Tom savagely. ‘She didn’t know you were alive. Why,—there’re things between Daisy and me that you’ll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.’

The words seemed to bite physically into Gatsby.

‘I want to speak to Daisy alone,’ he insisted. ‘She’s all excited now——‘

‘Even alone I can’t say I never loved Tom,’ she admitted in a pitiful voice. ‘It wouldn’t be true.’

‘Of course it wouldn’t,’ agreed Tom.

She turned to her husband.

‘As if it mattered to you,’ she said.

‘Of course it matters. I’m going to take better care of you from now on.’

‘You don’t understand,’ said Gatsby, with a touch of panic.

‘You’re not going to take care of her any more.’

‘I’m not?’ Tom opened his eyes wide and laughed. He could afford to control himself now. ‘Why’s that?’

‘Daisy’s leaving you.’

‘Nonsense.’

‘I am, though,’ she said with a visible effort.

‘She’s not leaving me!’ Tom’s words suddenly leaned down over Gatsby. ‘Certainly not for a common swindler who’d have to steal the ring he put on her finger.’

‘I won’t stand this!’ cried Daisy. ‘Oh, please let’s get out.’

child_mcqs.description: The crucial device this passage rests on is
child_mcqs.explanation: Gatsby believes Daisy does not love Tom and never did.  This is an incorrect assumption, so Option D is correct. Option A describes the scene and Options B and C are components of the scene without being the most crucial element of the scene’s success.

child_mcqs.description: The victim[s] in the scene are/is
child_mcqs.explanation: This is a difficult question to answer.  Technically all suffer pain and humiliation in the scene, yet for different reasons. Tom is faced with a situation where his wife loves another, while Jay's love is married to another and won't admit she didn't love him. Daisy is caught between the two. All are victims in their own way in the presented passage.

child_mcqs.description: The subtext of the scene is
child_mcqs.explanation: Both men are trying to influence Daisy.  This indicates Option B is correct.  Option A is a possible answer, but the reason for their competition is their need to control Daisy.  C. and D. are emotional components of the scene yet they spring from both men attempting to gain control of Daisy’s fate.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9

child_mcqs.description: Appreciating the humour of the cartoon relies on
child_mcqs.explanation: While a knowledge of Dick Cheney is helpful, the cartoon depends more on an knowledge of who Darth Vader is, and appreciation of the irony that it is actually Vader that is hurt by the comparison. That is, even if you don't know who Cheney is, it is possible to understand the humour of the cartoon, and know that Cheney is the target. Thus Answer D is correct.

child_mcqs.description: Who is the focus of criticism by the cartoonist?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A is correct. Once again, knowledge of who Cheney is is not required in order to know he is being ridiculed. It is implied that he is evil since Vader (the epitome of evil) is hurt by being compared with him, and thus Cheney is the focus of the cartoonists criticism.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon is a sly critique of:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D is correct. First, some definitions. Creationism is how God created the Earth and humans and the rest of it. Free will is supposedly not present in the world of creationism, because God has supreme power to act and make people act as he wishes. This angel is clearly in heaven (halo, gown, on a cloud) and thus must have believed in Gods laws – being against free will. God looks grumpy in the cartoon as he looks down onto the world. The little angel is merely stating; “ahh, don’t take your wrath out on me, I’m just a little angel that believes in what you preach; I’m not part of the world that you’re angry at.” In this way, the only purpose of the cartoon is to humour the situation in which God may be angry with the world. There is no critique present on any of the provided options. In short, creationism is referenced but not actively critiqued. Random chance is an element of the cartoon, but is not being held up for critique. Thus, the answer is D.

child_mcqs.description: Which two elements indicate the relationship of the two figures
child_mcqs.explanation: God has a larger halo, and is thus holier, and is clearly dressing down a subordinate.  The difference in body size would seemingly be natural given that they are differing entities, and does not speak to the relationship between them, however the body language, with God clenching fists and looming over the angel, show that he is in charge. Hence Option A is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11

child_mcqs.description: The humour of the cartoon relies on:
child_mcqs.explanation: The humour of the cartoon is derived from an unusual interpretation of "personal space". The term usually applies to the area surrounding a person, which they consider as their own. Here, it is used by one astronaut when talking to another when they are both in 'space'. Thus the humour relies upon a play on the word 'space', which here refers to their surroundings rather than just an area.

answers.description: The juxtaposition of friendly banter and an extreme environment

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is incorrect according to the chart?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answers A, B and D should be readily apparent from the chart. Some students may also think C true since the age group 30-39 represents the largest single group on the chart. However, since 30% of cotton candy is sold to this age group, 70% is sold to other age groups. Thus C is incorrect, because it is still more likely that cotton candy will NOT be bought by someone aged 30-39.

answers.description: More than a quarter of cotton candy is sold to those under 19 years of age
About half of cotton candy is sold to those aged 20-49
Cotton candy is most likely to be bought by someone aged 30-39
Cotton candy is less likely to be bought by those aged 50-59 than by those aged 40-49

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13

child_mcqs.description: If a black note without a horizontal line attaching to it, represents a quarter of a note, and those with a single line represent an eighth of a note, those with four lines represent:
child_mcqs.explanation: Each line halves the value of the note.  1 line is 1/8, hence 4 lines is 1/64.  D is the answer.

child_mcqs.description: If a dot beside a note represents adding to its existing value a further 50% of its value then a single black note (a black circle with a vertical line without any horizontal lines), with a dot would represent
child_mcqs.explanation: Each single black note is 25% of a whole note's value.  50% of 25% is 12.5%.  Added on this gives us A.

child_mcqs.description: The following notes comprise:
child_mcqs.explanation: According to the initial figure, notes with double horizontal lines are each 1/16th of a 'whole note' and 1/4 of a beat. So four of them  in a row would make one beat, or a quarter of a whole note, making option D correct.

answers.description: One beat or a quarter of a note

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
The following is a passage written by William James

 

Into the awareness of the thunder itself the awareness of the previous silence creeps and continues; for what we hear when the thunder crashes is not thunder pure, but thunder-breaking-upon-silence-and-contrasting-with-it. Our feeling of the same objective thunder, coming in this way, is quite different from what it would be were the thunder a continuation of previous thunder. The thunder itself we believe to abolish and exclude the silence; but the feeling of the thunder is also a feeling of the silence as just gone; and it would be difficult to find in the actual concrete consciousness of man a feeling so limited to the present as not to have an inkling of anything that went before. Here, again, language works against our perception of the truth. We name our thoughts simply, each after its thing, as if each knew its own thing and nothing else. What each really knows is clearly the thing it is named for, with dimly perhaps a thousand other things. It ought to be named after all of them, but it never is. Some of them are always things known a moment ago more clearly; others are things to be known more clearly a moment hence.

child_mcqs.description: In describing consciousness the example of thunder is apt in that
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A. is too broad and obvious.  Option B. is invalid because thunder is really only used a metaphor.  The suddenness of thunder might be correct, but the passage focuses on both silence and thunder. Hence D. is the key. The passage explains how our awareness of thunder is determined by the preceding silence, so that it is the change in awareness that is perceived.

answers.description: It is instantaneous in the effect it has
It is evocative of a change in awareness

child_mcqs.description: The passage presents a paradox in its
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is correct. This passage contains a metaphor of thunder and how this naming of 'thunder' does not align to the natural reality of what thunder actually is. In the second part, the author creates this paradox of language in which "we name our thoughts simply, each after its thing, as if each knew its own thing and nothing else", but this is not the reality. Thus language, that should be naming things specifically, is not specific at all. Logically, how seriously then can the passage itself be taken? Option B is incorrect because the paradox itself is not the thunder metaphor presented, whilst option D is equally wrong because the extended metaphor is not part of the paradoxical argument. Option C is indeed incorrect, because our consciousness is not touched upon in the passage.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage speculates on the Arts

To succeed thus in gaining recognition, the original painter, the original writer proceeds on the lines adopted by oculists. The course of treatment they give us by their painting or by their prose is not always agreeable to us. When it is at an end the operator says to us: "Now look!" And, lo and behold, the world around us (which was not created once and for all, but is created afresh as often as an original artist is born) appears to us entirely different from the old world, but perfectly clear. Women pass in the street, different from what they used to be, because they are Renoirs, those Renoir types which we persistently refused to see as women. The carriages, too, are Renoirs, and the water, and the sky: we feel tempted to go for a walk in the forest which reminds us of that other which when we first saw it looked like anything in the world except a forest, like for instance a tapestry of innumerable shades but lacking precisely the shades proper to forests. Such is the new and perishable universe which has just been created. It will last until the next geological catastrophe is precipitated by a new painter or writer of original talent.

child_mcqs.description: The writer defines the phrase “the world” as determined
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage discusses the world as created by art. Combined with the ongoing references in the passage to “originality”, C. is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: The primary discourse which the passage engages in is
child_mcqs.explanation: Aesthetics is a philoshopy regarding the appreciation of beauty. Metaphysics is a philosophy concered with explaining of the nature of reality. The passage only discusses how the world seems to change through an original artistic vision. This dispels A. and points to B.  Further, C. is too broad and D. fails to account for the degree to which aesthetic choices appeal to the author.

child_mcqs.description: The phrase “geological catastrophe” is
child_mcqs.explanation: Clearly the statement is not meant literally so cannot be taken as an oxymoron.  Likewise it does not use the word “like” in its formation so is not a simile.  There is no comparison to another comparable set of ideas so it is not an analogy.  This leaves A.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage explores the writer’s experience of déjà vu.

A deep azure intoxicated my eyes, a feeling of freshness, of dazzling light enveloped me and in my desire to capture the sensation, just as I had not dared to move when I tasted the madeleine because of trying to conjure back that of which it reminded me, I stood, doubtless an object of ridicule to the linkmen, repeating the movement of a moment since, one foot upon the higher flagstone, the other on the lower one. Merely repeating the movement was useless; but if, oblivious of the Guermantes' reception, I succeeded in recapturing the sensation which accompanied the movement, again the intoxicating and elusive vision softly pervaded me as though it said "Grasp me as I float by you, if you can, and try to solve the enigma of happiness I offer you." And then, all at once, I recognised that Venice which my descriptive efforts and pretended snapshots of memory had failed to recall (Proust 2006, 2: 1147);

child_mcqs.description: The passage suggests a link between
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D. refers to arguably similar notions.  There is no reference to the supernatural.  This cancels out A.  Paraphysical refers to physical phenomena without obvious cause, yet the passage describes the interaction with the flagstones.  This rules out B.  C. is the key.

child_mcqs.description: The narrator encounters his own memories
child_mcqs.explanation: The narrator describes the suddenness of his déjà vu as being like an external force in dialogue with his conscious mind.  Both of course exist within him.  The only option which successfully describes this is C.

answers.description: As a separate entity in dialogue with him
A seeming separate entity in dialogue with him
A seeming separate entity in dialogue with his consciousness
A separate entity in dialogue with his consciousness

child_mcqs.description: The narrator’s lesson from the passage is
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage explores how déjà vu occurs then passes.  Despite stimulus its involuntary nature means it is not easily recaptured.  A. describes this.  All other options describes things other than déjà vu.

answers.description: One cannot voluntary recapture the experience of involuntary memory.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
The following passages represent two versions of the same event in a single book.  One is the actual experience, the second is the narrator recounting the experience.

…when I caught sight of the twin steeples of Martinville, on which the setting sun was playing, while the movement of the carriage and the windings of the road seemed to keep them continually changing their position; and then of a third steeple, that of Vieuxvicq, which, although separated from them by a hill and a valley, and rising from rather higher ground in the distance, appeared none the less to be standing by their side.  In ascertaining and noting the shape of their spires, the changes of aspect, the sunny warmth of their surfaces, I felt that I was not penetrating to the full depth of my impression, that something more lay behind that mobility, that luminosity, something which they seemed at once to contain and to conceal.

The steeples appeared so distant, and we ourselves seemed to come so little nearer them, that I was astonished when, a few minutes later, we drew up outside the church of Martinville. I did not know the reason for the pleasure which I had found in seeing them upon the horizon, and the business of trying to find out what that reason was seemed to me irksome; I wished only to keep in reserve in my brain those converging lines, moving in the sunshine, and, for the time being, to think of them no more. And it is probable that, had I done so, those two steeples would have vanished forever, in us for a few seconds, had already disappeared, when, lingering alone on the horizon to watch our flight, its steeples and that of Vieuxvicq waved once again, in token of farewell, their sun-bathed pinnacles.

child_mcqs.description: Compared with the first passage, the second passage would best be described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. Passage 1 goes into the specifics of certain aspects: "shape of their spires, the changes of aspect, the sunny warmth of their surfaces”, and "something more lay behind that mobility, that luminosity, something which they seemed at once to contain and to conceal”. This deliberate attempt to uncover and describe is far more poetic than the mere factual recount in passage 2: "business of trying to find out what that reason was seemed to me irksome; I wished only to keep in reserve in my brain those converging lines, moving in the sunshine, and, for the time being, to think of them no more”. This makes passage 2 more prosaic; chunky, less beautiful and straightforward. Note that prosaic means, "using the style or diction of prose as opposed to poetry".

child_mcqs.description: The second passage would best be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage is not labouring the point over words or details, when taking into account the descrptive style of the piece, nor does the passage have a particularly sad tone, so it is neither pedantic or sombre. While it is clearly prose, making prosaic a potential answer, lines such as "I wished only to keep in reserve in my brain those converging lines, moving in the sunshine" and metaphorical descriptions of the steeples "waving farewell", make Answer B, lyrical, the best option since the writers emotions are expressed in beautiful and imaginative way.

child_mcqs.description: What might be the reason for the repetition of the two passages
child_mcqs.explanation: While the passages are repetitive of one another, their content differs.  As such they in fact represent divergent perspectives on the same event.  D. is the key.  There is nothing in the passages to support the notion that they are a metaphor.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage analyses the phenomena of bureaucracy.

Studies of bureaucracy have frequently included organization size as one of the most important variables in their investigations. Generally, it is believed that larger organizations are more bureaucratic. The studies claim that as the organization grows in size, there is less direct personal contact among members, and informal methods of communication and coordination become inappropriate. Instead, formal patterns of interaction, routine procedures, rules and regulations, and evaluative mechanisms of performance are developed in the organization. Furthermore, the size of an organization is related to decentralization because the larger the size, the more complex its goals and information become, hence precluding centralized decision making. In contrast to this, other studies have reported that the size of an organization is not related to the bureaucratic features of the organization. They argue that large organizations do not necessarily have to be impersonal and undemocratic, while smaller ones exhibit a more humanistic and democratic climate. They claim that organizations can use other modes of control besides rules and regulations. Another important variable that should be included in an explanation of bureaucratic inflexibility is the degree of professionalization in the organization. Human service organizations tend to rely on and employ professionals to implement their goals. Therefore, one way of reducing the number of written rules in bureaucratic organizations is to employ professionals who have internalized the relevant rules because of their formal education and training. These professionals, then, do not have to consult rules in many organizational situations. Hage and Aiken's study of health and welfare organizations provides support for this reasoning. The degree of professionalization is one indicator of "complexity" in their study, and it is negatively correlated with the degree of formalization

child_mcqs.description: The general belief surrounding bureaucracy is that it could best be described as
