child_mcqs.explanation: The article states by saying that 'generally, larger organisations are more bureaucratic', and goes on to explain that it is a natural evolution of large businesses as they grow in size. Therefore, the general view is that A and B are only correct when an organisation is of a specific size. D is not supported by the passage. C is therefore the answer, as bureaucracy becomes a logical necessity as an organisation increases in size.

child_mcqs.description: An organisation with a higher proportion of professionals in its ranks
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage provides that employing professionals is one indicator of complexity, which correlates negatively with the degree of formalisation. Hence, answer B is correct. Although employing professionals is an indicator of complexity, the article says nothing about moving from a simple organisation to a complex organisation, and says nothing on the criteria of these categories. A is incorrect, as although less formalisation is required, this does not necessarily give the organisation greater choice, as its professionals may be less willing to work under a formalised structure and the article includes it as an explanation of 'bureaucractic inflexibility'. D is not supported by the passage.

answers.description: Has a greater degree of choice regarding its level of bureaucracy
Is less reliant upon formal patterns of interaction
Moves from being a simple organization to a complex organization
Is more likely to be a small organisation

child_mcqs.description: Bureaucracy would likely favour an organizational hierarchy which is
child_mcqs.explanation: Bureaucracy promotes the notion of accountability. This is best supported by D, as in a tiered system an employee is accountable to another individual at a higher level.  B and C are too vague, whilst A is not supported by the passage.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage compares the writings of Heidegger and Penn Warren in their exploration of Time and Memory.

Now this "retrieve" of the past, as Heidegger calls it, is not a simple nostalgic return, but rather a presencing that uncovers lost possibilities, a going back to go forward. The "moment of vision" for Heidegger is characterized by "anticipatory resoluteness." That is, Dasein hands down to itself its own pastness in order to "throw" itself upon the world in an essentially futural manner. Its resoluteness about its own finite situation, its "heritage," is given purpose by anticipating or projecting itself, by attempting to understand and structure its own direction in history. Thus, ironically, "Its own past... is not something which follows along after Dasein, but something which goes already ahead of it". History and the future, inextricably bound, become the responsibility of Dasein; they do not constitute a passive field to be entered, but rather a structure always yet to be determined. In fact, the moment of vision, says Heidegger, simply cannot be clarified in terms of the simple "now," as a simple "making present," but rather temporalizes itself in terms of a future, the emerging structure of the moment that cannot be summed up in any single instant. The focus, for both Heidegger and Warren, is always upon potential, possibility; the moment is always futural, always a function of will and conscience.

child_mcqs.description: The word “presencing” is not actually an expression in Standard English.  The reason for this is likely
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage deals with metaphysical notions which do not easily translate to written expression.  The context is such that “inventing” a word is permissible given the complexity of the ideas being discussed. D.  accounts for this the best.

answers.description: The dialect format the article is written in makes allowances for such
The word is allowable in the context of its meaning
The word which expresses such an idea does not exist, thus must be invented

child_mcqs.description: The passage conceives of time as
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage contradicts B, which is clear from the first line when it states that retrieving the past is not a nostaligic return, but a presencing that uncovers lost opportunities going forward. This notion is repeated throughout the passage. C is a physics term that is irrelevant to metaphysical discussion. D is not supported by the passage. A is the key. The passage talks about the influence of the past on the future, which is best represented in the line '[history and future] do not constitute a passive field to be entered, but rather a structure always yet to be determined'.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
The following is an interview with the cinematographer Vittorio Storaro.

 

Q. You're working on Roma: Imago Urbis now ?

Vittorio Storaro: I just finished last night. Yesterday was the last day of shooting, which started six years ago. It is the longest project I've ever worked on. It' s a portrait of ancient Rome-a mosaic of the city. They're calling it the first attempt to create "a multi-media encyclopedia" in the modem sense. It's made for television, it will also be in theaters, but one of the primary forms of distribution will be a combination of book-with my own production photographs-and video. In about two years there will be a second release with laserdisc, and we're also considering interactive computer programs, CD-ROM, something like that.

Q. What attracted you to the project?

Vittorio Storaro:  Several things. ... One was the opportunity to work with the director, my good friend Luigi Bazzoni. Another was the challenge of the project itself, which was basically to discover ancient Rome through its monuments and artifacts, without any distractions or signs of modem life-in a sense, to create something that was timeless. But there was also something else. I told you a long time ago that the first part of my professional life, and the way that I was trying to come to a better understanding of myself, was based on my research and study of light and each of its of properties, such as shadow and penumbra, artificial and natural, and so on. Later on, I became more interested in qualities of light itself, the spectrum of light, in colors, "the children of light," as Leonardo put it. I spent a long time researching the meaning of color, what kind of response the human body has to it, how we can visualize sentiment and emotion with color, how this all relates to the physiology and psychology of the human being. Then, after The Last Emperor, I knew that I had to take another step in trying to find balance between all these different things. In the beginning, I was mainly trying to divide, to separate light from shadow, then red from blue, one color from another. It was not always conscious, but it was what I was trying to do. Now it was time to see if I could put them together, to find more harmony. The idea came to me to go back to ancient Greek philosophy, the pre-Socratics, who determined that life consists of four basic elements: water, earth, fire, and air. I wanted to understand how I could begin to visualize life itself through these four elements. And I began to think that maybe with these 15 hours of documentary I might be able to do a kind of resume of my professional life. I thought I should divide the series into three parts. One would mainly be the journey with light. One would be the journey within light, into color. And the third would be to try to find balance between these, but mainly the idea of balance between the four elements.

Q.  Do you feel that you succeeded?

Vittorio Storaro:  You will see the difference. It was an important journey into myself. But I'm telling you all of this because it's connected to Little Buddha. Because all along, with my sensibility, my cultural background, my own experience, I'm trying to express what I really am. I am trying to describe the story of the film through the visualization, the photography, so that the viewer can feel and understand, consciously and un-consciously, what the story is about. Of course, I'm always working very hard to complement the director's vision, but it is also my own story, because I'm using everything within myself to do that. From my first movie [Giovinezza, Giovinezza, 1969] up to Apocalypse Now, that was the first part, when I was mainly concerned about light. From then until The Last Emperor was the second part, where I was moving into light itself and this is the third part, where I am trying to find visualization through the balance of elements.

child_mcqs.description: Storaro’s attitude might be described best as
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D is correct. Options B and C are not supported by the passage, which leaves A and D. To be self-aware is to have an understanding of what one is doing while one is doing it, or being aware of their character or identity. To be self-conscious is essentially to be more contrived in one’s action or feeling of themselves. Self-consciousness is most of the time an innate feeling, however it is not always undue. For example, given the negative connotation of the word, if someone is being teased, they can feel self-conscious about their traits because of the teasing, which is a very due emotion in the circumstances. This kind of emotion is due to a heightened self-awareness, ie. A real inquisition into the self. This is what the explanation means by ‘contrived’; self-consciousness is considered and deliberate because of a given reason. Given that Storaro considers that their thinking is crucial; "It was an important journey into myself”, we start to realise that this fleeting awareness is not in fact awareness at all, but deliberate self-consciousness. Plus, the degree of abstraction Storaro brings to his work would likely best indicate D.

child_mcqs.description: A basic foundation of Storaro’s theory is that
child_mcqs.explanation: The use of colour by Storaro is literal not figurative. This would seem to dispel any notion of metaphorical similarities and rule out answer B. C and D are too narrow in how they relate to the question, which asks for the foundation of Storaro's theory. The key is A. The interview discusses Storaro's experiments with colour, and how colour can be used to visualise life's sentiment and emotion, which itself is described through the four basic elements.

answers.description: The elements and colour are compatible metaphors
A documentary series is the best medium for his current work

child_mcqs.description: This interview is dated by
child_mcqs.explanation: To date something usually means to determine the period from it comes - so for this question it's asking which piece of information gives the best clue as to the era of the interview. Given that the interview discusses a movie that is soon to be released on laserdisc, and from a general knowledge of the fact that laserdiscs were generally produced in the 90s, this helps us 'date' the piece. While the fact that the movies mentioned in the passage must have been made prior to the interview is relevant (i.e the interview must be after their production), it is the reference to laserdiscs that enables us to narrow this down - that is, it definitely wasn't conducted recently, and probably dates to the mid-late 90s.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21
stem_mcq.description:
The Black Heralds

 

There are blows in life, so powerful…I don't know!
Blows as from the hatred of God; as if, facing them,
the undertow of everything suffered
welled up in the soul…I don't know!

 

They are few; but they are….They open dark trenches
in the fiercest face and in the strongest back.
Perhaps they are the colts of barbaric Attilas;
or the black heralds sent to us by Death.

 

They are the deep falls of the Christs of the soul,
of some adored faith blasphemed by Destiny.
Those bloodstained blows are the crackling of
bread burning up at the oven door.

 

And man…. Poor…poor! He turns his eyes, as
when a slap on the shoulder summons us;
turns his crazed eyes, and everything lived
wells up, like a pool of guilt, in his look.

There are blows in life, so powerful…I don't know!

 

César Vallejo

child_mcqs.description: The “black heralds” are
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: C. The black heralds are a metaphor for the blows we all suffer in life: injustice, violence, suffering, grief, and so on. It is one of a series of metaphors for the “blows”–dark trenches, Attilas, burnt bread etc. A is incorrect because it gives the literal meaning of “black heralds sent to us by Death”. The poet isn’t talking about ghostly creatures that turn up at our doors delivering messages from Death. B is incorrect because the poem is about a living person contemplating the bad things that happen to people, not about the bad things that actually kill us (although a blow might be the grief caused by the death of someone else). Finally, D is obviously wrong because the poem is about the blows that befall us, not bad things that we worry will before us.

answers.description: Messengers sent out by Death to inform us of our fate
The bad things which happen to us in life
The morbid and depressing thoughts that we all think from time to time

child_mcqs.description: The use of ellipsis (the “…”)
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: A. The ellipsis indicates how to read the poem. There is supposed to be a pause, a pause in which the speaker is contemplating the blows in life, only to realise it’s beyond their understanding. In conjunction with the exclamation point this the ellipsis gives “I don’t know” a burst of force that it otherwise would not have. It becomes an expression of frustration rather than just a statement of fact. B and C are incorrect because “I don’t know” is the speakers response to an implied question. We all suffer terrible blows in life, but why? The speaker is at a loss. D is a distractor–if poets had a habit of putting ellipses in their poems whenever they paused to think poems would be mainly dots.

answers.description: accentuates the meaning of the phase that follows
shows that the speaker looses their train of thought
signals that the speaker is going to begin a different thought
reveals that the poet is struggling to complete the line

child_mcqs.description: The philosophical attitude of the speaker is
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: D. This is quite straightforward, for, as the speaker says, and says again, he doesn’t know. This rules out A and B. C is answer that is too technical, so a student should be suspicious of C. Moreover, it is wrong because there’s nothing in the passage to suggest the speaker is a nihilist.

answers.description: life is by necessity filled with suffering and disappointment
life is filled with suffering and disappointment owing to the influence of external forces be they Destiny or Death or God
a combination of realism, nihilism and theism

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
Resume

 

Razors pain you; 
Rivers are damp; 
Acids stain you; 
And drugs cause cramp; 
Guns aren't lawful; 
Nooses give; 
Gas smells awful; 
You might as well live.

 

Dorothy Parker

child_mcqs.description: The themes of this poem include
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: A. The poem is about suicide–it offers a list of ways to take your own life. Thus choice is also a theme. You can choose to live or to die, and if the latter, you have choices there too. Passivity comes in as the former option–choosing to live–is achieved by doing nothing. Part of the dark wit of the poem is that it seems the only reason the speaker is choosing to live is she finds the other option to tedious. B and C should both use an uncommon word, a word that GAMSAT markers would not normally expect candidates to know. So these answers should be regarded with suspicion for this reason alone. Moreover, concupiscence means “strong sexual desire, lust”, which is not a them of the poem. D is incorrect because this poems is about the choices we make, not the “choices” made for us, so fate is not a them.

child_mcqs.description:
From the poem we can infer that the speaker is

 

  1. Contemplating suicide
  2. Takes suicide seriously
  3. Thinks there is something comical about suicide
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: B. The speaker is thinking about suicide, but that’s not the same as contemplating suicide, so A is incorrect. Whilst the poem is piece of dark comedy, so the speaker appears to be talking about suicide in a comical way, this is not the same as thinking that suicide itself is comical. In fact, much of the dark humour stems from the grim reality of suicide. This leaves B. Whilst the poem is short and dripping with irony, but it has a serious purpose.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
Up-Hill

 

Does the road wind up-hill all the way?
 Yes, to the very end.
Will the day's journey take the whole long day?
 From morn to night, my friend.

 

But is there for the night a resting-place?
 A roof for when the slow dark hours begin.
May not the darkness hide it from my face?
 You cannot miss that inn.

 

Shall I meet other wayfarers at night?
 Those who have gone before.
Then must I knock, or call when just in sight?
 They will not keep you standing at that door.

 

Shall I find comfort, travel-sore and weak?
 Of labour you shall find the sum.
Will there be beds for me and all who seek?
 Yea, beds for all who come.

 

Christina Rossetti

child_mcqs.description:
The inn can be interpreted as a metaphor for

  1. Death
  2. Sleep
  3. Heaven
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: B. The central idea of the poem is that life is like a journey along a road that is forever up-hill. The end of the journey is death, which accorder to certain  religious beliefs means Heaven. The key point is that the metaphor is a journey to the very end, not just part of the way. This rules out II, leaving B as the only possible answer.

child_mcqs.description:
The poem has two voices (questioner and answerer). These voices could belong to

 

  1. the same person
  2. a priest and a child, respectively
  3. God and a man, respectively
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: A. This question tests whether you have read the question properly. All of I, II and III would be correct except that II and III get the order the wrong way round. Option I is correct because there is no reason why this couldn’t be a poems about a reverie in which someone is answering their own questions.

child_mcqs.description: The personality of the first voice could be described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D is correct. There are two aspects to the first voice's prose; the style and the content. The style is questioning, that is, they are indeed curious about the path ahead. The content contains questions like; "May not the darkness hide it from my face?", and "Then must I knock, or call when just in sight?". These questions have a tone of cautiousness about them; this person is not sure if what they're about to encounter is fully safe, or if everything is prepared. In short, they're being cautious. The reason that option A is incorrect is because the first voice may well be that of a warm and calm person, but there is no evidence from the poem itself. Moreover, the speaker is not a doubting person, as the s/he seems to accept the answers given by the second speaker (despite their vague character), thus B and C are wrong too.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 24
stem_mcq.description:
The following is an excerpt from an article in the journal Medical History: “Divine Stramonium”: The Rise and Fall of Smoking for Asthma"

The growing popularity of smoking for asthma was endorsed by two of the leading nineteenth-century writers on the condition, the English physician Henry Hyde Salter, who was himself asthmatic, and the French physician Armand Trousseau. Salter’s treatise on asthma, first published in 1860, was particularly successful. Considered a definitive text for many decades, it appeared in an American edition in 1864 and an expanded second British edition in 1868, establishing Salter’s international reputation as an expert in the field. Like Trousseau, who regarded asthma as a “diathetic neurosis” closely associated with eczema and hives, Salter subscribed to the nervous theory of asthma, arguing that asthmatic symptoms were caused primarily by “a spastic contraction of the fibre-cells of organic or unstriped muscle, which minute anatomy has demonstrated to exist in the bronchial tubes”, rather than by catarrh or bronchitis. Salter’s approach to treatment reflected this understanding of pathogenesis. In alleviating the paroxysms, he emphasized the importance of avoiding or removing any known “exciting cause”, as well as advocating the use of depressants such as ipecacuanha, tobacco and antimony to suppress nervous irritation, stimulants such as strong black coffee, tea, ammonia, and hot alcohol to divert “morbid activity” from the lungs, and a range of sedatives, including tobacco, chloroform, stramonium and belladonna, to allay irritability. Many of the substances discussed by Salter had dual actions: Indian hemp or Cannabis sativa, which was also becoming popular as a panacea in Britain following its introduction from India and which was regularly recommended in the form of a tincture for asthmatics, was both a stimulant and a sedative.
Salter’s discussion of the benefits of smoking stramonium was extensive. Although he recognized that stramonium did not always guarantee relief, partly on account of the “special caprice of asthma” and partly because of differences in the “mode of preparation and drying of the drug”, he nevertheless acknowledged that its efficacy in some cases always made it worth trying. Significantly, its action was amplified if the stramonium were not merely smoked in a pipe (leading to absorption “by the oral surface only”), but if the saliva was swallowed and the smoke inhaled “as much as possible into the lungs”, which had the “advantage of being applied to the very parts affected”. According to Salter, stramonium was more effective as a preventative than a cure. Indeed, he advocated smoking a pipe each night before bed in order to “keep the disease at bay”: “The stramonium seems to leave for some hours a state of nervous system in which the asthma is not likely to come on; and, since the attack is almost always at night, the use of stramonium at bedtime conducts and guards the patient through the critical time.”
 
The rising popularity of smoking stramonium for asthma during the middle decades of the nineteenth century can be traced to a variety of factors. In the first instance, it is evident that support for the therapeutic use of stramonium developed in tandem with medical accounts of asthma as the product of spasmodic bronchoconstriction. Articulated fully by William Cullen in the late eighteenth century, the spasmodic theory of asthma gained support during the early nineteenth century, not only from the clinical studies of Laennec but also from the work of the German physician Franz Daniel Reisseissen and others, who demonstrated the presence of circular muscle fibres around the bronchi. An emphasis on spasmodic constriction prioritized the application of anti-spasmodics, including stramonium and tobacco. Indeed, it is likely that both theory and practice were mutually reinforcing: while the spasmodic theory stipulated the use of anti-spasmodics, the apparent efficacy of stramonium legitimated theories that explained asthma in terms of nervous spasm rather than mucous obstruction.

child_mcqs.description: In Europe, the prescription of cannabis to patients with asthma was:
child_mcqs.explanation: We are only told that Indian cannabis was: "becoming popular as a panacea in Britain following its introduction from India and which was regularly recommended in the form of a tincture for asthmatics, was both a stimulant and a sedative". A is tempting given its seemingly contradictory function, however, given that its prescription was consistent with Salter's thesis, it is not necessarily incoherent (this is, of course, distinct from being 'wrong'). D is incorrect: while the cannabis was customary in India, it was relatively new to Europe. B is to be preferred over C as the latter term tends to connote metaphysical properties.

child_mcqs.description: What does the "special caprice of asthma" refer to?
child_mcqs.explanation: Caprice is a sudden and unaccountable change of mood. Clearly, the author is using the term metaphorically: the answer is thus B. While A and D may be true from the information we are provided in the text as a whole, the question specifically asks for an explanation of the given phrase. C is not supported bv the text: just because the degree to which asthma is capricious is 'special', it does not necessarily mean it is so special as to be unique.

answers.description: Asthma is strong enough to resist the effect of stramonium

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is the most valid conclusion to draw from the article:
child_mcqs.explanation: The article explains how scientists observed different reactions in patients taking certain substances and developed broad principles about the nature of asthma. Going from observed evidence to formulating a general principle is the process of inductive reasoning. The answer is C. D is nonsensical - science is, by definition, the study of nature. Nowhere in the text is the topic of the scientists' education discussed, thus precluding B. A is incorrect, too: the scientific method does not mean that all theories will be true. Rather, it regulates the manner in which knowledge should be aquired or improved.

answers.description: Inductive reasoning was important to nineteenth century scientists.
Nineteenth century science was more natural than it is today.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 25
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is taken from an editorial by Melissa S-L Kang in the Medical Journal of Australia

As the end of November approaches, tens of thousands of secondary school leavers around Australia prepare for the annual celebration known as “Schoolies” (“Leavers” in Western Australia). This rite of passage for many young people involves travelling to certain destinations around the country or overseas to participate in organised parties and recreational activities.

Each year, Schoolies brings into focus two important adolescent health issues: acute alcohol-related harm and unwanted consequences of sexual activity. In Australia and the United States, young people who attend a Schoolies-like event expect to get drunk, and these expectations are usually met. Further, the incidence of binge drinking during Schoolies has not changed over time, and there is increasing gender convergence on patterns of intoxication. Significant proportions of intoxicated young people at Schoolies require transport to hospital for further care, and hospital data are likely to underestimate the extent of this problem. Fewer expect to have sex, but these expectations, when present, are also usually met, often with casual partners. As Schoolies expands to include international destinations such as Bali and Fiji, the consequences of additional exposure to communicable diseases and pre-travel vaccinations need to be considered.

For most young Australians, the end of secondary school coincides with entering adulthood. Turning 18 years old has significant legal implications: the right to vote, enter into contracts, purchase tobacco and alcohol, and consent to one's own medical treatment without the need for a mature-minor assessment, to name a few. This emancipation from childhood, symbolised for many by Schoolies, brings a new wave of health risks. The epidemiology is stark: morbidity and mortality are higher in young adults (up to 24 years) compared with younger adolescents, in Australia and overseas. In Australia, the death rate for 20–24 year-olds is almost four times greater than that for 12–14-year-olds and 1.4 times greater than that for 15–19-year-olds. Mental health disorders, chronic conditions, and notification rates for sexually transmitted infections and bloodborne viruses are all higher for 18–24-year-olds than for 12–17-year-olds. Globally, health-related behaviour, such as tobacco use, binge drinking and unprotected sex, and overweight and obesity increase in prevalence from adolescence to young adulthood.

child_mcqs.description: The passage suggests that:
child_mcqs.explanation: This questions relies on accurate comprehension of two key phrases used within the passage. Firstly, the statement, "there is increasing gender convergence on patterns of intoxication" suggests that the difference in drinkig patterns between the sexes has decreased. Secondly, the statement, "Fewer expect to have sex, but these expectations, when present, are also usually met" suggests that the expectation of promiscous activity is less than the expectation of binge drinking. Combined, these two statements indicate that Option A is correct.

answers.description: The expectation of promiscuous activity during "Schoolies" is less common than binge drinking, and there is less of a difference recently between the intoxication levels experienced by males and females.
The expectation of promiscuous activity during "schoolies" is as common as binge drinking, and there is less of a difference recently between the intoxication levels experienced by males and females.
The expectation of promiscuous activity during "Schoolies" is as common as binge drinking, and there is a greater difference recently between the intoxication levels experienced by males and females.

The expectation of promiscuous activity during "schoolies" is less common than binge drinking, and there is a greater difference recently between the intoxication levels experienced by males and females.

child_mcqs.description: Which of these statements is not supported by the passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answers B, C and D are each strongly supported by the text. However, for Option A, the author actually states that the risks of obesity, tobacco use, and sexually transmitted infections increase over the age groups discussed, rather than in recent years (although that may also be true). Thus Option A is the statement that is not supported by the passage.

answers.description: The risk of obesity, tobacco use, and sexually transmitted infections in young people have increased in recent years
Hospitals may not accurately report the number of casualties of the "Schoolies" phenomenon.
The freedom of gaining adulthood coincides with increased risks of harm
The internationalisation of "Schoolies" has introduced new risk factors that should be considered

child_mcqs.description: From the tone of the passage, the author can best be described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The tone of the passage is expository, rather than critical, so Option A is not correct. For Option D, although sympatheitic is the other end of the spectrum from critical, the tone of the passage would best be described as neutral with regards to judging the actions of young people. Option B is not correct, since although the author is using "Schoolies" as an apt phenomenon to draw attention to these issues, she does not draw a causal link to suggest that "Schoolies" is responsible. Instead, she using the phrase, "each year, Schoolies brings into focus...", suggesting that this is just an appropriate time to raise concerns about the health risks associated with the behaviours of young adults in general.

answers.description: Critical of young people engaging in risky behaviour
Drawing attention to the fact that the phenomenon of "Schoolies" is resulting in an increase in adverse health risks for young Australians
Drawing attention to the unique health risks associated with being a young adult in Australia
Sympathetic with the challenges facing young Australians as they enter adulthood

stem_mcq.title: Unit 26
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is taken from an article by Casey et al (2013) in the Medical Journal of Australia, and adapted for use in this question.

Patients with depression, particularly those with chronic depression or difficult to treat depression (DTTD), often have coexisting medical and psychiatric conditions. In patients with comorbid depression and medical conditions (eg, thyroid disorders, infections, neurological conditions), the depression is often untreated or unrecognised because of shared symptoms. The United States National Comorbidity Survey found most lifetime cases of depression were secondary to another psychiatric disorder and that 75% of people with depression had another psychiatric disorder. Anxiety and depression often coexist, so that patients with a diagnosis of depression commonly experience an anxiety disorder, such as generalised anxiety disorder, obsessive–compulsive disorder or panic disorder. Alcohol and other substance dependencies and personality disorders also frequently coexist with depression, and recent studies have begun to identify “hidden” bipolarity features as significant factors for treatment resistance. Complexity and comorbidity should be considered the norm. These comorbidities complicate the clinical picture, worsen the depression, and make it difficult to treat.

Patients with a diagnosis of depression, and specifically DTTD, often experience a range of negative environmental or contextual factors, such as family conflict, financial distress, work stress or job loss, poor-quality interpersonal relationships and social support, poor social adjustment, and other serious life events. Adverse health behaviour such as obesity, sedentary lifestyle and smoking are also identified risks for people with major depressive disorder (MDD). A recent systematic review of 25 primary studies involving 5192 patients with chronic depression identified that negative social interaction and low levels of social integration coexist with chronic depression. There is consensus that late onset of depression, family history of DTTD, and severity or chronicity of depression are also risk factors for treatment resistance.

Depression in primary care appears in many guises. Two-thirds of patients with depression initially present with one or more physical symptoms, and comorbid anxiety, personality traits, addictive behaviour and bipolarity can all potentially alter the clinical presentation. Furthermore, although there are probably different types of depression, such as melancholic, hopeless or situational depression, these heterogeneous presentations are often treated as though they are the one condition.

If a patient has not responded fully to the first-line treatment, it is always necessary to review the diagnosis and the treatment. Antidepressant medication and psychotherapy are both recommended as first-line treatments, either alone or in combination, for patients with mild to moderate MDD. However, these treatments are not always equally efficacious. For example, there is evidence that depression characterised by severe hopelessness responds poorly to antidepressants. Coexisting psychiatric disorders and medical illnesses require treatment in their own right if the treatment for depression is to be successful. Similarly, persisting contextual factors need to be taken into account when making a comprehensive diagnosis of the situation. Continuing stressors, or poor resources and coping skills, have a ceiling effect on the level of improvement that can be expected from pharmacotherapy alone.

Patients with depression often do not take, forget to take, or cannot be bothered to take their medication. This non-adherence to antidepressants is explained partly by personality characteristics, the strength of the doctor–patient alliance, intolerable side effects, and health beliefs and stigma. Patients’ attitudes and beliefs are at least as important as side effects in predicting adherence to medication. Furthermore, the depression, anhedonia and secondary demoralisation (the “giving up”, “can’t be bothered”, “it won’t help” attitude) that so often accompany depressive illness reinforce the likelihood of non-compliance. Individuals with chronic depression that is difficult to treat tend to experience significant low self-esteem, anxiety, demoralisation, hopelessness, and lack of joy and drive (anhedonia). In some people, these may be lifelong traits; in others, they may be activated by the depression. Nevertheless, people with treatment-resistant depression have more negative affect and dysfunctional cognitions than those with non-resistant depression, and people who experience repetitive and unhelpful thinking about depression tend to have prolonged depressive symptoms.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not listed as a risk factor for difficult to treat depression
child_mcqs.explanation: Options A, B and C are all listed as risk factors for difficult to treat depression in either the first (B) or second (A and C) paragraphs of the passage. While option D, "poor social adjustment" is mentioned in the second paragraph, it is presented as an example of a factor that often co-presents in people with DTTD, however, it is not presented as a risk factor itself.

child_mcqs.description: The article suggests that:
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A is not correct since the passage actually states that "Coexisting psychiatric disorders and medical illnesses require treatment in their own right if the treatment for depression is to be successful". Answer B is not correct because the passage states that antidepressant medication and psychotherapy are used in combination or alone as a first-line treatment. Answer D is not correct because although the passage lists those factors as contextual factors often associated with depression, it doesn't say anything about how they may affect the clinical presentation of the disorder. Answer C is correct since it is strongly supported by the line of the passage that states, "Continuing stressors, or poor resources and coping skills, have a ceiling effect on the level of improvement that can be expected from pharmacotherapy alone."

answers.description: Efforts should be made to treat coexisting psychiatric disorders as a part of the overall depressive disorder
A combination of antidepressant medication and psychotherapy are reommended for first-line treament for patients with mild to moderate major depressive disorders
Pharmacological treatment of depressive illnesses can only accomplish so much if underlying factors aren't also addressed
The clinical presentation of someone with a major depressive disorder can be complicated by contextual factors such as financial distress, work stress or job loss.

child_mcqs.description: The fact that those experiencing demoralisation as part of their depressive condition are less likely to adhere to there treatment regimen can be best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The fact that demoralisation (that is, the feeling of giving up and that nothing can make things better) results in patients being less likely to take antidepressive medication can be best described as a vicious cycle. That is, by not taking their medication, they are more likely to feel demoralised, and thus less likely to take their medication. Thus, Answer B is correct. None of the other answers make sense in this context, since this effect in neither a paradox, oxymoron, nor does the phenomena represent a contextual factor.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 27
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is taken from an article by Barsky et al (2002) in the Journal of the American Medical Association

Patients taking active medications frequently experience adverse, nonspecific side effects that are not a direct result of the specific pharmacological action of the drug. Although this phenomenon is common, distressing, and costly, it is rarely studied and poorly understood. The nocebo phenomenon, in which placebos produce adverse side effects, offers some insight into nonspecific side effect reporting. We performed a focused review of the literature, which identified several factors that appear to be associated with the nocebo phenomenon and/or reporting of nonspecific side effects while taking active medication: the patient's expectations of adverse effects at the outset of treatment; a process of conditioning in which the patient learns from prior experiences to associate medication-taking with somatic symptoms; certain psychological characteristics such as anxiety, depression, and the tendency to somatize; and situational and contextual factors. Physicians and other health care personnel can attempt to ameliorate nonspecific side effects to active medications by identifying in advance those patients most at risk for developing them and by using a collaborative relationship with the patient to explain and help the patient to understand and tolerate these bothersome but nonharmful symptoms.

child_mcqs.description: The term "nonspecific side effects", as used in the passage, best refers to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Although the term "nonspecific side-effects" could mean all of these options in some situations, in this case the article is specifcally referring to the nocebo phenomenon, and discusses how these effects occur due to patient-specific factors such as their expectations. No specific drug is mentioned, and the "nonspecific side-effects" described are not attributed to a drug in any way. Option D is the only option that captures this meaning, since the other three options implicate the drug in some way.

answers.description: Side effects experienced by a patient that result from a combination of the drug's mechanism of action and the patients expectations
Side effects of a drug that occur as result of its pharmacalogical action, but are not intended
Side effects of a drug that are unexpected because they are not associated with its mechanism of action
Side effects experienced as a result of the expectations of the patient

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is NOT supported by the information in the passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage refers to a patients expectations and pre-conditioning as important factors that influence the nocebo effect. Basically, if a patient has felt sick while taking a drug to fight cancer, they will likely associate treatment with nausea and be more likely to feel sick on a future treatment due to the nocebo effect, whether or not this is a real side-effect attributed to the drug. Thus Options C and D are supported by the passage. We're also told that these sorts of side-effects can be partly ameliorated by interaction with healthcare professionals that can modify their expectations, and thus Option B is supported. Option A is not supported because, although it may be true in some cases, it states the opposite of the main theme of the passage.

answers.description: A cancer patient who has previously experienced nausea as a result of chemotherapy will be unlikely to feel sick after changing to a treatment that doesn't cause nausea
A cancer patient who has experienced nausea as a result of chemotherapy will be less likely to feel sick after being told by their doctor their treatment shouldn't cause nausea
A cancer patient who has previously experienced nausea as a result of chemotherapy could continue to feel sick after changing to a treatment that doesn't cause nausea

A cancer patient who has previously experienced nausea as a result of chemotherapy is more likely to feel sick when starting a new drug than they would have if they were first treated with that same drug

child_mcqs.description: According to the information in the passage, which the following statements is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is incorrect since although depression and anxiety are listed as two factors that are associated with the nocebo effect, it goes to far to assume that these are the patients where the effect is "usually seen". Option B is incorrect since the passage states that the phenomenon is not well studied. Option D could possibly be inferred from the information provided, but the passage doesn't state that effects can be avoided. Option C is the best answer since it refers to a patients past treatment having an effect on their current treatment. For example, if a patient previously experienced a symptom from an earlier treatment, they may be conditioned to expect (and thus experience) that same symptom on a new treatment.

answers.description: Detrimental side-effects that are unrelated to a drugs action are usually seen in patients also suffering depression or anxiety
Detrimental side-effects that are unrelated to a drugs action are a common and well studied phenomenon
Detrimental side-effects may be experienced by patients as a result of their medication history, rather than their current medication
Detrimental side-effects that are unrelated to a drugs action can be avoided by managing a patients expectations

stem_mcq.title: Unit 28
stem_mcq.description:
The following passages are taken from an article by CC Breuner in the journal Pediatric and Adolescent Healthcare

Passage 1

Homeopathy is a by Samuel Hahnemann, a German, who had been trained as a linguist, chemist, medical historian and physician. He had become disillusioned with the current state of medicine believing it to be more dangerous than the illness and had given up medical practice. In his new career as a translator, he found William Cullen's Materia Medica and its description of Peruvian bark, Cinchona (the source of quinine), as a treatment of malaria. Noting that the symptoms of Cinchona poisoning were similar to those of malaria, Hahnemann recalled that Hippocrates, Celsus and Paracelsus had written about the possibility of treating diseases with substances that cause similar symptoms. He began a series of experiments ingesting and later giving to willing colleagues medicinal dose of Cinchona. In each case, symptoms resembling malaria resulted and spontaneously resolved when the dosing was stopped. This observation led Hahnemann to further experimentation and the elucidation of his Law of Similars (similia similibus curentur)—“Let likes be cured by likes.” The development and refinement of this theory with all of its ramifications consumed the remaining 60 years of his life. Hahnemann conducted a series of “provings,” which were his observations of the symptoms produced by giving a specific substance to a group of healthy people. He did this to discover the potential medicinal value of a substance and learn what symptoms might, according to the Law of Similars, be treated by that substance. He named the new science homeopathy, from the Greek “similar suffering.” Hahnemann cited Jenner's use of the cowpox innoculum to vaccinate against small pox as an example of this principle. 

 

Passage 2

Acupuncture is embedded in naturalistic theories that are compatible with Confucianism and Taoism. Such ideas as yin yang, Qi, dampness, and wind represent East Asian conceptual frameworks that emphasize the reliability of ordinary human sensory awareness. The fundamental concepts of acupuncture revolve around the idea that a body's vital energy (Qi) flows through the blood (xue) along 12 defined channels (meridians). Illness and pain are manifestations of a body's energy imbalance. Therefore, the goal of acupuncture treatment is to restore the balance and flow of the Qi's negative and positive aspects (yin and yang). This is achieved by physical manipulation near or at the obstructed meridians. The twelve fundamental meridians correspond to the body's major functions and are divided between the yin and yang. The yin meridians include gallbladder, bowel, stomach and bladder. Although the meridians have the common names for body organs, the Western and Chinese concepts of such are only loosely associated. In the Daoist tradition, illness is caused by a number of both internal and external imbalances including: wind, cold, fire, damp, heat, dryness, joy, anger, anxiety, thought, sorrow, fear, fright, diet, excessive sexual activity, fatigue, and trauma. A practitioner makes a diagnosis of illness after extensive discussion and examination of the patient. This includes an examination of the shape, color, and coating of the tongue and the strength, rhythm, and character of the radial pulse. Once a diagnosis has been made, the specific treatment may take a number of forms including solid needle placement, moxibustion which is the practice of burning dried herbs over the acupuncture needles, acupressure or cupping. Chinese medicine is a coherent system of thought that does not require validation by the West as an intellectual construct. The way to approach Chinese concepts is to see whether they are internally logical or consistent, not to disguise them as Western concepts or dismiss them because they do not conform to Western notions.

child_mcqs.description: Considering the two passages, which of the following statements is most accurate?
child_mcqs.explanation: Despite differing opinions in the medical community, the passages shown here depict both homeopathy and acupuncture as legitimate therapies, making Option A correct. While in reality the processes behind homeopathy have no scientific basis, this does not come across in passage 1, which presents homeopathy in a positive light. Similarly, while the spiritual and religious origins of acupuncture are described, the overall theme of the passage is supportive of the method as a legitimate therapy, with the latter part of the passage defending it from criticism by suggesting it should be considered separately to western medicine.

answers.description: Both passages depict their respective treament methodology as legitimate therapies
Passage 1 depicts homeopathy as a legitimate therapy, while passage 2 depicts acupuncture as a quasi-spiritual experience
Passage 1 depicts homeopathy as having no scientific basis, while passage 2 depicts acupuncture as a quasi-spiritual experience
Passage 1 depicts homeopathy as having no scientific basis, while passage 2 depicts acupuncture as a legitimate therapy

child_mcqs.description: According to the passage, Samuel Hahnemann is best described as
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is not correct because his "advances" were not in the field of medicine, which he was disillusioned with, but were instead a move away from his originial field into what he considered a new discipline; homeopathy. Option B is incorrect because although the work he read described a treatment for malaria, it was Hahnemann himself that linked this to the symptoms produced at higher doses. Option D is incorrect for similar reasons. This leaves Option C, which is the correct answer since the passage depicts Hahnemann as basing his new discipline on observation and experiments.

answers.description: A pioneer in his field who was responsible for great advances in medicine
A translator who built on concepts he read describing the use of small doses of substances to treat diseases whose symptoms they mimic at larger doses
An educated medical professional that used careful observation and the scientific method to develop a new system for treating diseases
An educated medical professional that adapted and developed a treatment technique first described by William Cullen

child_mcqs.description: The author uses the sentence, "Chinese medicine is a coherent system of thought that does not require validation by the West as an intellectual construct", to suggest that
child_mcqs.explanation: The meaning of the author in this sentence is not that Chinese medicine doesn't need validation, despite the similarity of wording to Option A, but rather that there is no point in trying to measure it by western medicine standards, making Option D correct. The sentence following the one in question also clarifies this. Option B is not correct since Chinese medicine is described as having a clear theoretical framework, and Option C may be true, but is not the meaning of the sentence.

answers.description: Chinese medicine is a complete and proven system, and as such requires no further testing by the West
Chinese medicine is a practical system of thought that should not be considered as a theoretical framework
Chinese medicine follows its own internal logic, which is different to the internal logic of western medicine
Chinese medicine is logical within its own boundaries, and attempts to test it based on the expectations of modern medicine is pointless.

sections.title: Section III: Reasoning in Biological	and Physical Sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
b-lactamase is an enzyme produced by bacteria that has the capacity to bind penicillin and hydrolyse it, rendering it ineffective as an antibiotic. The bacteria is said to be resistant to penicillin.

To counter this, we can use clavulanic acid, which competitively inhibits penicillin from binding b-lactamase, thus preserving the function of penicillin when we administer it.

Enzyme kinetics are described by the Michaelis-Menton theory, which states that the Km of an enzyme is equal to the substrate concentration at V1/2, which is half the maximal velocity of the reaction. This is demonstrated pictorially in the diagram below.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following cannot be assumed regarding b-lactamase?
child_mcqs.explanation: The enzyme b-lactamase is able to function at human body temperature, and is therefore a problem when doctors give penicillin to a patient that is infected with a bacterium that can produce this enzyme.

answers.description: b-lactamase lowers the activation energy of the hydrolysis of b-lactam.
b-lactamase is unable to function within the human body because the temperature of the human body denatures the enzyme.
Penicillin binds the active site of b-lactamase

child_mcqs.description: As you administer more clavulanic acid to the b-lactamase-penicillin reaction described above, which of the following regarding this reaction is true?
child_mcqs.explanation: As stated in the stem of this question, Clavulanic acid competitively inhibits b-lactamase. Therefore, the Vmax will not change as the inhibition can be overcome by adding more of the substrate (i.e. penicillin)

answers.description: You cannot determine this from this information

child_mcqs.description: As you administer more clavulanic acid to the b-lactamase-penicillin reaction described above, which of the following regarding this reaction is true?
child_mcqs.explanation: Competitive inhibitors do not alter Vmax, but they decrease overall binding of the enzymes to their substrates, such that the Km increases.

answers.description: You cannot determine this from this information

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true regarding the addition of a non-competitive enzyme inhibitor to an enzymic reaction:
child_mcqs.explanation: If we add a non-competitive (allosteric) inhibitor to a reaction, the Vmax will decrease. This is because the inhibitor does not bind at the active site so no extra amount of substrate will be able to displace the inhibitor from the active site of the enzyme.

child_mcqs.description: If a change in temperature of the environment increased the ability of an enzyme to bind the substrate, the Km would:
child_mcqs.explanation: Any interaction that increases the ability of an enzyme to bind its substrate will cause a decrease in Km, which is the substrate concentration at ½Vmax

answers.description: You cannot determine what the Km will do based on this information.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true about enzymes?
child_mcqs.explanation: Enzymes do not alter Gibb’s free energy in a reaction. They merely decrease the activation energy required for a reaction to take place.

answers.description: They increase the change in Gibb’s free energy in a reaction
They decrease the change in Gibb’s free energy in a reaction
They decrease the activation energy of a reaction

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description: An insect starts to crawl from corner 1 of the room shown in the figure below to reach corner 2. Side a of the room is longer than side b, which is longer than side c.

child_mcqs.description: The net displacement of the insect is
child_mcqs.explanation:
The following images show the shortest path.

The first figure shows the net displacement, represented by the black diagonal line. The second figure demonstrates how to derive the length of the black diagonal line using the yellow line, the green line and Pythagoras's Theorom. The three lines represent the blue triangle in the diagram used for the question.

The length of the black line = displacement = `sqrt(("Length of yellow line")^2 + ("Length of green line")^2)`

Length of green line = c

Length of yellow line = `sqrt(a^2 + b^2)`

Displacement = `sqrt(a^2 + b^2 + c^2)`

The net displacement is given by the diagonal of the cuboid which is given by  √(a²+b²+c²)

child_mcqs.description: Find the angle θ shown in the figure above
child_mcqs.explanation:
Tangent of an angle is given by the ratio of the opposite side to the adjacent size. 

`tan(theta)=c/a  -> theta = tan^-1(c/a)`

child_mcqs.description: The distance travelled by the insect along the shortest path is
child_mcqs.explanation: Distance travelled by the insect along the shortest path is the diagonal and the shortest side of the cuboid. Therefore, the answer will be √(a²+b²)+c

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
A small sphere with mass, m has a radius, r. The spherical object rolls without slipping over the surface of a bigger hemisphere of radius R where. Radius R is a lot longer than radius r. The flat surface of the hemisphere is in full contact with a flat ground. The small sphere starts from rest on the top of the hemisphere.

Given that the Kinetic energy (translational) =1/2mv²; Kinetic energy (rotational) =1/2 Iω² (I is the moment of inertia and ω is the angular velocity). Also, I=2/5mr² for a solid sphere and v=rῳ.

Then find the following.

child_mcqs.description: The kinetic energy of the small sphere as it reaches the bottom of hemisphere
child_mcqs.explanation:
Draw diagram as per given instructions. Now from conservation of energy we have 

Total kinetic energy = Loss in gravitational energy

Gravitational energy = mgR

child_mcqs.description: What fraction is the rotational kinetic energy of the total kinetic energy?
child_mcqs.explanation:
KE (translational)=`1/2 mv^2`

KE(rotational)=`1/2 Iῳ^2`; 
Substituting `I=2/5mr^2` & `ῳ = v/r`;

KE(rotational) = `2/10 mv^2` 

TE=KE(rot)+KE(trans)=7/10mv².

Therefore fraction of rotational energy =K.E(rotational)/T.E= `((2/10 mv^2))/((7/10 mv^2)) = 2/7`

child_mcqs.description: What fraction is the translational kinetic energy of the total energy?
child_mcqs.explanation: Fraction of K.E(translational)=1-2/7 =5/7

child_mcqs.description: The normal force that the small sphere will exert on the hemisphere at its bottom is
child_mcqs.explanation:
Conservation of energy says    mg(R-r)=7/10(mv²);  (mv2)/(R-r)=4/3mg

Now   N - mg=  (mv2)/(R-r);    N=17/7 mg

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
Vision is a complex neural pathway, which involved light being detected at the retina and relayed to the brain to be interpreted. The pathway is as follows:

Light --> Photoreceptive cell --> Bipolar cells --> Ganglion cells --> Brain

When light enters the retina, there is a conformational change in a molecule called retinal (see diagram below). Retinal is contained inside a protein called rhodopsin, which also undergoes a confirmational change to accomodate this retinal's new shape. This change in rhodopsin results in an alteration in a G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR), which causes a fall in the level of cGMP by supressing levels of guanylate cyclase. This leads to closure of the cGMP-gated cation channels, and the cell releases less neurotransmitter onto the bipolar cell.

In darkness, rhodopsin is inactive, the cGMP-gated channels are open and the cell is depolarised. The cell subsequently releases high levels of the neurotransmitter.

child_mcqs.description: From the information provided above, it can be assumed that light causes the photoreceptive cell to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Because the photoreceptor is leads to less neurotransmitter being release, we can assume that light causes the cell to hyperpolarise. We are told that in darkness, the cell is depolarised.

child_mcqs.description: It can be inferred from the information above that:
child_mcqs.explanation: The release of neurotransmitters from photoreceptors is higher in darkness. It can be concluded that in darkness (where there is no visual information detected by the brain) that these neurotransmitters inhibit bipoplar cells from signalling.

answers.description: Light causes the release of neurotransmitters from photoreceptors, which stimulates bipolar cells from signalling to the brain
Darkness causes the release of neurotransmitters from photoreceptors, which inhibits bipolar cells from signalling to the brain
The neurotransmitter released by photoreceptors causes depolarisation of ganglion cells

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true regarding GPCRs?
child_mcqs.explanation: G-protein couple receptors contain G proteins, which are composed of an a, b and subunit. GPCRs exist on the surface of cells, act less rapidly than ion channel receptors and are stimulated by peptide hormones due to their location on the surface of cells.

answers.description: G proteins are composed of three subunits
GPCRs are present within the cytosol of cells
GPCRs act more rapidly than ion channel receptors

child_mcqs.description: cGMP is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Cyclic GMP is a nucleotide. It consists of a phosphate group, a nucleotide base and a sugar molecule.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information above, cGMP acts as a:
child_mcqs.explanation: cGMP is acting as a second messenger molecule. The receptor involved is the GPCR and the enzyme is guanylate cyclase.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
The first law of thermodynamics states that ΔQ=ΔU+ΔW. ΔW refers to work done and can be calculated using formula pdV. ΔQ refers to the heat exchanged between a system and its surrounding.  ΔQ and ΔW are path functions, meaning their value depends on the net change of their net change from start to end. ΔU refers to the internal energy in a system and it depends only on the initial and final temperature and hence is a point function.

Consider that the heat transfer per degree of temperature change and work for a system undergoing a non-flow processes are given by dQ/dt=1/10 Kcal/°C  and dW/dt =1/30 Kcal/°C respectively. The system undergoes a change in temperature from 125°C to 245°C. Then find the following:

child_mcqs.description: Internal energy of the system
child_mcqs.explanation:
dQ/dt=dU/dt +dW/dt ;   1/10=dU/dt +1/30   ;    dU/dt= 1/10-1/30 = 1/15 =+ve

Therefore, the internal energy increases because the change in temperature is also positive.

child_mcqs.description: Heat exchange will be
child_mcqs.explanation: Since Q is positive the heat transferred (exchange) is also positive

child_mcqs.description: Heat exchange between system and surrounding is
child_mcqs.explanation: dQ/dt=1/10  ;  dQ/(245-125)=1/10  ;    dQ = 12Kcal

child_mcqs.description: Change in internal energy is
child_mcqs.explanation: dQ/dt =dU/dt+dW/dt  ;     1/10 = dU/dt +1/30   ;    1/15=dU/(245-125)  ;    dU=8 Kcal

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Blood glucose levels need to be maintained within a specific range in the body. After a meal, dietary glucose enters the blood. Insulin is secreted by the b-cells of the pancreas in response to this glucose load. Insulin then acts to move glucose out of the bloodstream and into the cells of the body to prevent prolonged high glucose levels. In contrast, during starvation, when glucose levels are low, glucagon is released by a-cells of the pancreas to increase blood glucose levels.

The regulation of insulin release is complex, and demonstrated in the figure below:

child_mcqs.description: The GLUT2 is a protein channel embedded in the cell membrane. It allows glucose to enter the cell. The amino acids on the inner-most aspect of the channel, forming the passageway through which glucose passes are most likely:
child_mcqs.explanation: The amino acids on the inner-most aspect of the channel are away from the lipid component of the lipid bilayer, and in contact with the aqueous environment which contains the dissolved glucose. Therefore, the amino acids on the inside of the channel must be hydrophilic.

answers.description: Amino acids, which form covalent bonds with glucose

child_mcqs.description: The diagram shows that when ATP levels inside the cell increase, ATP-gated K+ channels are inhibited. The cell:
child_mcqs.explanation: As it shows in the diagram, as we decrease the efflux of K+ from the cell, the cell becomes depolarises, and therefore becomes more positive.

answers.description: Does not change its membrane potential because sodium has not moved into the cell
Does not change its membrane potential because sodium has not moved out of the cell

child_mcqs.description: The synthesis of insulin within the cell above involves:
child_mcqs.explanation: After proteins are translated, they pass through the golgi apparatus and undergo modifications.

answers.description: Splicing out the exons from the insulin pre-mRNA
Synthesis of insulin at the ribosomes on the smooth endoplasm reticulum

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description: A particle weighing 1kg is moving along x. The particle’s has a kinetic energy of 20 J when it is 5 meters along x.The graph below shows the relationship between potential energy that an object possesses and its position along x.

child_mcqs.description: The mechanical energy of the system is
child_mcqs.explanation:
See the figure in the question.

Potential energy at x=5.0m is 29J. At any similar point, Mechanical energy = Potential energy + Kinetic energy = 20+29 =49J.

child_mcqs.description: Make a plot of U(x) as a function of x for -10m≤x≤10m, and on the same graph draw the line that represents the mechanical energy of the system. Use this to find the least value of x
child_mcqs.explanation:
See the figure

The particle will move between the points where its kinetic energy becomes zero or its potential energy is equal to its mechanical energy of 49J.

Generating an equation for the parabolic graph based on the two points that are known, and including the intersection of where U = 49 J

 Thus,   49=20+(x-2) 2                                              

 (x-2)2 =29 ;  x-2=±√29 = 5.38m  ;  x = 7.38m   and -3.38m

So , the least value of x is -3.38m.

child_mcqs.description: The maximum kinetic energy of the particle
child_mcqs.explanation: Max kinetic energy is at x=2m, where the potential energy is minimum and maximum kinetic energy is, K(max)=E-U(min) = 49-20 =29J

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description:
The multiple bond of an unsaturated hydrocarbon consists of 1 or 2 pi bonds in addition to a sigma bond. Losing these pi bonds requires addition of hydrogen, otherwise known as saturation.

The index of hydrogen deficiency indicates the number of pairs of hydrogen a compound requires in order to become a saturated alkane. Since a saturated alkane contains 2n+2 hydrogens (n=number of carbons), in order to find the index of deficiency of a compound we subtract the compounds total number of hydrogens from the number of hydrogens on a corresponding saturated alkane and divide by 2. Halogens are counted as hydrogens while nitrogen atoms are counted as one half a hydrogen atom. Oxygen atoms are ignored.

Saturated alkanes usually have higher bond energies than alkenes and are thus harder to break apart, as a pi bond is weaker than a sigma bond

child_mcqs.description: The hydrogen deficiency of decane is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Decane is saturated with 22 hydrogens, thus its hydrogen deficiency is 0. ((20+2)-22)/2=0

child_mcqs.description: What is the hydrogen deficiency of guanosine, shown below?
child_mcqs.explanation: Guanosine has the empirical formula C10H13N5O5, ((20+2)-(13+2.5))/2= (22-15.5)/2 = 6.5/2 = 3.25 ~3 So B

child_mcqs.description: The correct IUPAC name for the following compound is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The longest carbon chain contains 8 carbons with a double bond, octene; the carbons are numbered with the lowest number being attributed to the double bond, 1-octene; side groups are labeled in alphabetical order including their numbered carbon and occurrence, 4-bromo and 3,6,7-trimethyl. Thus: 4-bromo-3,6,7-trimethyl-1-octene

child_mcqs.description: The table below shows the magnitude of the bond energies for several single bonds in kJ/mol. Of the four bonds listed below, the strongest bond is between:
child_mcqs.explanation: Bond energy is a measure of energy required to break apart covalent bonds. The more stable the bond the greater the bond energy required to break it. The bond between a hydrogen and a carbon has the highest bond energy and is thus the most stable.

child_mcqs.description: Given the information on bond energies, which of the following elements has the strongest bond of the elements occuring naturally as diatomic molecules?
child_mcqs.explanation: The bond energies are F 159, P 213, Br 192, I 151. P does not naturally occur as a diatomic molecule - the molecules that do are those ending in "-ine" and "-gen". Br has the highest bond energy of F, Br and I.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description:
Magnetic moment of a bar magnet placed in a magnetic field of 0.15T is m=0.32J/T. Bar magnets can rotate freely in a magnet field. For a bar magnet to be in stable equilibrium, the magnet should be aligned in the same direction as the magnetic field. When the magnet is be displaced from the stable position, it is said to be in unstable equilibrium.

The potential energy of a magnetic moment in an external magnetic field is defined by - mBcosθ, where θ corresponds with the alignment of the magnetic moment to the magnetic field.

Answer the following:

child_mcqs.description: The orientation it would correspond to in stable equilibrium is
child_mcqs.explanation:
Moment of the bar magnet, M=0.32 J/ T; External magnetic field, B = 0.15 T

 

The bar magnet is aligned along the magnetic field. This system is considered as being in stable equilibrium. Hence, the angle is 0°, by convention (as opposed to 180o, where the bar magnet is orientated in the opposite direction of the magnetic field)

child_mcqs.description: The orientation it would correspond to in unstable equilibrium resulting in the most rotational motion is
child_mcqs.explanation: The bar magnet is oriented 180° to the magnetic field. This is the orientation where it experiences the most rotational force to realign it with the magnetic field again. Hence, it is in unstable equilibrium at θ= 180°

child_mcqs.description: What is the potential energy of the magnet in case 1(stable equilibrium)?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Potential energy of the system=-MBcosθ

                                                              =-0.32 * 0.15 cos 0°

                                                              = -4.8*10⁻²

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description: In chemistry, resonance or mesomerism is a way of describing delocalized electrons within certain molecules or polyatomic ions where the bonding cannot be expressed by one single Lewis formula. A molecule or ion with such delocalized electrons is represented by several contributing structures. (called resonance structures). Electron delocalization lowers the potential energy of the substance and thus makes it more stable than any of the contributing structures. The difference between the potential energy of the actual structure and that of the contributing structure with the lowest potential energy is called the resonance energy or delocalization energy.

child_mcqs.description: A higher resonance energy indicates
child_mcqs.explanation: -High resonance energy indicates a more stable hybrid, and more stable contributing structures. Greater stability indicates higher bond energy (energy required to break the bond). Delocalised electrons can also increase intermolecular bonding.

child_mcqs.description: The molecule pyrrole is shown below. Which of the following is not a valid resonance structure for pyrrole?
child_mcqs.explanation: Only electrons are able to move in resonance structures - in the wrong answer, a N-H bond has been broken so that more than electrons have moved. Note also that B and D are identical.

child_mcqs.description: Benzene exibits resonance. The pi bonds are of a benzene molecule are
child_mcqs.explanation: -The hybrid or "average" of the two contributing structures of benzene has one sigma bond and one-half of a pi bond between each two carbon atoms. Thus each carbon is joined by a bond that is longer and weaker than the double bond of an alkene, which contains one sigma and one pi bond.

answers.description: Shorter and stronger than the double bond of an alkene
Longer and weaker than the double bond of an alkene
Shorter and weaker than the double bond of an alkane
Longer and stronger than the double bond of an alkane

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description: Starting from rest a truck accelerates uniformly with acceleration 2.0 ms⁻². A daredevil is standing on the hood of the truck who drops a stone at t = 10 s, (the stone is dropped from a height of 6m). Neglect air resistance. Find the following

child_mcqs.description: The velocity of the stone  at t=11s is
child_mcqs.explanation:
Given that, the initial velocity of the truck, u = 0; Acceleration, a = 2 m/s2; Time, t = 10 s

As per the first equation of motion, the final velocity is given as: v = u + at

                                                                                                                                     = 0 + 2 × 10 = 20 m.

 The final velocity of the truck and hence, of the stone is 20 m/s.

 At t = 11 s, the horizontal component v (x) of velocity, in the absence of air resistance, remains unchanged, i.e. v (x) = 20 m/s

child_mcqs.description: The acceleration of the stone at t=11s is
child_mcqs.explanation:
The vertical component v (y) of the velocity of the stone is  given by the first equation of

   v (y) = u + ayδt ;  Where, δt = 11 – 10 = 1 s and ay = g = 10 m/s2; Thus, v (y)  = 0 + 10 × 1 = 10 m/s. The       resultant velocity (v) of the stone is given as   v = √(v (x)² + v (y)²)

                                                                                    =     √(20 ²+10²)    =       22.36 ms⁻²

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description: Amino acids can be classified in a number of ways due to the chemical properties imparted by their R group. The amino acid lysine is shown below.
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Lysine acquires a positive charge at physiological pH due to the acquisition of an extra hydrogen ion on the NH2 group of its R chain to become NH3+.

The correct anwer can be also be achieved by discounting the other three. Lysine is a polar amino acid due to the NH2 groups it contains. The chemical structure of lysine is C6 H14N2O2. Lysine is not aromatic because it does not contain the aromatic ring present in phenylalanine, tryptophan or tyrosine.

answers.description: Lysine acquires a positive charge in a solution with a pH of 7.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description: Bats are good listeners. They are blind but they have such an elevated sense of hearing that they can identify sound waves emitted by them. The ultrasonic sound waves of frequency 1000 kHz are emitted by a bat. (Speed of sound in air and water is 340 ms⁻¹ and 1486 ms⁻¹). The sound waves meet water surface, now answer the following:

child_mcqs.description: The wavelength of the reflected sound wave is
child_mcqs.explanation:
Given that, Frequency of the ultrasonic sound, f = 1.0 x 106 Hz 

Speed of sound in air, v (air) = 340 m/s.

The wavelength λ (reflected) of the reflected sound is given by the relation  λ = v/f

  = 340/106 =340 × 10-6 m

child_mcqs.description: The wavelength of the transmitted sound wave is
child_mcqs.explanation:
Frequency of the ultrasonic sound, f = 1.0 x 106 Hz ;

Speed of sound in water, v (water) = 1486 m/s ;

The wavelength of the transmitted sound is given as  λ = v/f  = 1486/106 = 149 × 10-5 m

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
The following experiment shows the synthesis and abstraction of (+)-methamphetamines (enantiomeric forms of methamphetamine that rotate light in a clockwise (+) direction). Achiral reactants must give optically inactive products or an equimolar mixture of enantiomers (a racemic mixture) that is optically inactive. In an achiral environment, all physical properties of enantiomers are identical, except for direction of rotation of plane polarized light. This complicates synthesis of a single enantiomer of methamphetamine because the other enantiomer is produced in equal amounts and they are chemically inseparable.

Therefore a more complicated separation strategy is required. In the first step, the enantiomers are converted to diastereomers (which do have different physical properties) by adding at least one extra stereocentre to the molecule. In the second step the diastereomers are separated. In the final step the separated diastereomers are converted back to separated enantiomers, thus giving a pure sample of the enantiomer of interest.

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following statements about the racemic mix initially produced are true?

I The chiral character of (R)-(-)-methamphetamine dictates that the plane polarized light is rotated counterclockwise
II The components differ at two stereogenic carbons
III They have similar chemical properties
child_mcqs.explanation:
I The chiral character is what dictates that the plane polarized light will rotate counterclockwise; we are told in the preamble that the (+) isomer rotates light clockwise

II They differ in one stereogenic carbon only; they are enantiomers of one another

III As mentioned in the preamble, they only differ in optical activity

child_mcqs.description: Fractional crystalization is most likely to separate the two diasteriomers based on
child_mcqs.explanation: Fractional crystallization is a method of separating substances based on solubility.

child_mcqs.description: The IUPAC name of NH2CH3 added in the first reaction is
child_mcqs.explanation: The IUPAC name is methylamine, as the amine group is the highest priority functional group. Aminomethane is not wrong but is not the IUPAC name, in the same way that we wouldn't call ethanol 1-hydroxyethane, despite the second name also being accurate.

child_mcqs.description: In the first reaction, the addition of NH2CH3 can best be described as what sort of reaction on the main precursor molecule:
child_mcqs.explanation: There is no net change in oxidation state to the main molecule, as it loses two bonds to O but gains two bonds to N. This is a substitution reaction, as one group has replaced another. It is not an elimination as something has also been gained.

child_mcqs.description: The ammonium tartate salts produced in the second reaction would have a pH closest to:
child_mcqs.explanation: The ammonium tartrate salts can both lose and gain a hydrogen ion, creating neutral pH.

answers.description: Can’t be determined using the information given

child_mcqs.description: What is the IUPAC name of the first molecule?
