child_mcqs.explanation: This is really just 2-propanone with a phenyl attached to one end.

child_mcqs.description: All of the following compounds are optically active EXCEPT:
child_mcqs.explanation: The selected molecule does not contain any stereocentres - it is thus achiral and not optically active.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following properly named compounds could exist in enantiomeric forms
child_mcqs.explanation: This molecule contains a stereocentre at the carbon two away from the double bond with a bromo- side group.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
Breast tissue is composed or cells that normally express oestrogen receptors and HER-2 receptors. . When the ligands bind these receptors, they stimulate the breast cells to divide. These receptors may be found at higher or lower levels in breast cancers

Current immunohistochemical assays can be used to detect the presence of these receptors in a sample of tissue. Immunohistochemistry involves the use of a monoclonal antibody targeted to a specific protein.  The antibody is tagged with a fluorescent label and added to a section of tissue. The location of the antibody bound can be seen when the sample of tissue is looked at under the microscope.

When a fluorescently-labelled monoclonal antibody for oestrogen receptors is added to the tissue, the cytoplasm of cells stain positive. In contrast, when a fluorescently-labelled monoclonal antibody for HER-2 is added to the breast tissue, the staining appears around the edges of the cells.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: The Immunohistochemistry described above relies on:
child_mcqs.explanation: Immunohistochemistry relies on an antibody being specific for its antigen. If the antigen was not specific, it may bind other proteins and therefore give a false reading of oestrogen receptor or HER-2 receptor positivity, In addition, Immunohistochemistry relies on the visualisation of the antibody under the microscope after it has bound. This is often achieved using a fluorochrome.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information above, which of the following is true:
child_mcqs.explanation: The oestrogen receptor is located within the cell cytoplasm, so its ligand must be lipophilic or non-polar so it can cross the cell membrane to get to its receptor. In contrast, the HER-2 receptor is located on the cell membrane, as the stain appears surrounding the cell. This indicates that the ligand for the HER-2 receptor is likely to be polar or hydrophilic in nature.

answers.description: The ligand for the oestrogen receptor is likely to be polar, whereas the ligand for HER-2 receptor is likely to be non-polar.
The ligand for the oestrogen receptor is likely to be non-polar, whereas the ligand for HER-2 receptor is likely to be polar.
The ligands for both receptors are likely to be polar in nature.
The ligands for both receptors are likely to be non-polar in nature.

child_mcqs.description: If specimen of breast cancer tissue is determined to be oestrogen receptor negative, but demonstrates over-expression of the HER-2 receptor, which of the following is likely to be effective for treating this breast cancer?
child_mcqs.explanation: A HER-2 receptor antagonists is likely to be effective as it will bind the HER-2 receptor and prevent this receptor from being stimulated to divide

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
Gringard reagents are normally used to synthesise complicated alcohols. Metallic magnesium is reacted with an organic halide to produce a gringard reagent

However, this reagent is a very powerful base ad is impossible to prepare it from a hydrogen having a more powerful hydrogen than an aljkene. The gringard formula is RMgX, and the polarity of the magnesium carbon bond is what makes this reagent a strong nucleophile

child_mcqs.description: What would make the best solvent in a Gringard Synthesis with ethylbromide?
child_mcqs.explanation: -Grignard reagents are typically prepared using an ether solvent, e.g. diethylether (C2H5)2O. Organobromides react rapidly under these conditions.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following compounds could be reacted with the gringard reagent shown below to create a tertiary alcohol?
child_mcqs.explanation: -This compound is a ketone. Ketones react with Grignard reagents to create tertiary alcohols

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following alcohols would react the most strongly with a gringard reagent
child_mcqs.explanation: -Grignard reagents are very strong bases and act readily with any compound containing O-H via proton transfer. A primary alcohol with a small R group, ethanol, would react most strongly.

child_mcqs.description: In the reaction below, if the final alcoholic product were oxidized by H2CrO4, what would be the major product?
child_mcqs.explanation: -Tertiary alcohols are resistant to oxidation because the carbon bearing the –OH group is bonded to three carbon atoms and therefore cannot form a carbon-oxygen double bond

child_mcqs.description: If the final alcoholic product from a gringard reaction (2,3-diethyl-4-methylpentanol) was heated to boil. Compared to the following 3 compounds (4-pentene 2,4,diethyl-2-methylpentanoic acid 2,2dimethylpentanone), which would distillate last in a distillation process
child_mcqs.explanation: -In this case 2,4-diethyl-2-methylpentanoic acid contains a large R group and a carboxylic acid group, indicating the greatest intermolecular forces (H-bonding and Van Der Waals), and thus the least volatile substance.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
C10H10Fe is an unstable compound made by a chemist in 1951. The proposed structure of

this compound was called a sandwich complex and is shown below along with its

spectroscopy.

To confirm if the proposed structure of C10H10Fe was valid scientists conducted the

following reaction

A summary of the spectroscopy of the following product is given in the table.

child_mcqs.description: What is the name of the reactant added to C10H10Fe, and what is the name of this reaction
child_mcqs.explanation: -This substance is acetic anhydride. It undergoes electrophilic aromatic substitution, as it substitutes the H from the lower aromatic ring of C10H10Fe.

child_mcqs.description: If after the reaction is conducted, there is a new peak in a conducted IR spectrum, this would most likely be due to
child_mcqs.explanation: -The carbonyl group causes the new peak in the spectrum. This is the only option that wasn't present in the sandwich structure before the reaction.

child_mcqs.description: The NMR peak at 4.50 ppm in table 3 is from protons on
child_mcqs.explanation: -The carbon of the methyl group attached to the carbonyl carbon will account for the NMR peak at 2.30 ppm. The carbon of the upper cylopentadiene ring (not attached to the carbonyl) accounts for the NMR peak at 4.20 ppm. The cyclopentadiene does not have a methyl group directly attached. Thus, it is the carbon of the lower cyclopentadiene ring (attached to the carbonyl) that accounts for the NMR peak at 4.50 ppm.

answers.description: The carbon of the methyl group attached to the carbonyl carbon
The carbon of the upper cyclopentadiene ring (not attached the a carbonyl)
The carbon of the lower cyclopentadiene ring (attached to the carbonyl)
The carbon of the methyl group attached to the cyclopentadiene

child_mcqs.description: A lower chemical shift indicates
child_mcqs.explanation: -A lower chemical shift indicates more shielding due to higher electron density.

answers.description: More shielding due to a higher electron density
Less shielding due to a lower electron density

child_mcqs.description: The 5 membered ring in C10H10Fe is
child_mcqs.explanation: -Aromatic – due to the resonance structure created by multiple double bonds.

child_mcqs.description:
From table 1, 2, and 3 what confirms that the proposed structure of C10H10Fe is correct?

  1. The chemical shift in table 1 indicates that all the hydrogens are equivalent
  2. The coupling pattern in table 1 indicates that no splitting occured because all hydrogens are equivalent
  3. The IR peak at 2900 indicates a carbonyl stretch
child_mcqs.explanation: -Since all the hydrogens are equivalent in C10H10Fe, there is a chemical shift and coupling pattern in table 1. There should not be a carbonyl stretch, as there is no carbonyl group.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description: Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a genetic defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. It appears in infancy and tends to results in neurological problems due to accumulation of the substrate.  Phenylalanine metabolism is shown in the diagram below.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information above, the defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase will result in:
child_mcqs.explanation: If the enzyme PAH is not functioning, we will not be able to convert phenylalanine to tyrosine and phenylalanine will accumulate in the blood.

child_mcqs.description: The essential role of Dihydropteridine reductase (DHPR) in the normal metabolism of phenylalanine:
child_mcqs.explanation: The essential role of DHPR is to regenerate BH4, which is the cofactor consumed in the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.

child_mcqs.description: In the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, tetrahydrobopterin is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Dihydrobiopterin is a cofactor of the enzyme PAH.

child_mcqs.description: In the reaction described above, O2 is converted to water. Based on your knowledge of cellular metabolism, this implies that oxygen has:
child_mcqs.explanation: Like in oxidative phosphorylation, oxygen will gain two electrons during the reaction.

child_mcqs.description: The most important aspect of treatment of phenylketonuria would involve:
child_mcqs.explanation: As stated in the stem, the problem of PKU results due to accumulation of Phenylketonuria in the bloodstream. This could be treated through limitation of phenylalanine consumption. C is incorrect because the enzymes would reach the stomach and be denatured by the acidity of stomach acid meaning they would become denatured and unable to properly function (even after they leave the stomach).

child_mcqs.description: Different patients with phenylketonuria demonstrate different severities of disease. This implies that:
child_mcqs.explanation: If different patients with PKU demonstrate different severities, this indicates that some mutations in the PAH enzyme do not completely obliterate its function, so the levels of phenylalanine in the blood would not be as high.

answers.description: There is some residual enzymatic activity associated with some mutations that cause Phenylketonuria.
Some people with Phenylketonuria have another enzyme to make tyrosine.

child_mcqs.description: A baby is born with Phenylketonuria. The parents do not have Phenylketonuria. This implies:
child_mcqs.explanation: PKU is a recessive condition, so if parents without the disease have a child with the condition, this indicates that the parents are both carriers for the condition. This means that the disease is autosomal recessive and both parents must give their defected copy of the gene to their child. There is a 50% (or 0.5) chance of the mother giving the defected gene to the child and a 50% (or 0.5) chance that the father will give the defected gene to the child. To determine the chance of the child having the disease, you must multiply the odds of BOTH the parents giving the defected genes to their child (50% X 50% = 25% or 0.5 X 0.5 = 0.25).

answers.description: One of the parents is a carrier for the mutation, whereas the other is not.
If the parents have another child, there is a 50% chance that the next child will have Phenylketonuria.
Both of the parents are carriers for the mutation.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
During high intensity exercise the muscles get stressed and anaerobic conditions result. As a result, pyruvate produced from glycolysis is converted into lactate (instead of going into the Krebs cycle) via the following reaction

Although less ATP is produced in this process compared to the Krebs cycle, NAD+ is recycled in this step to re-enter glycolysis.The increase in the amount of lactic acid produced from lactate fermentation causes metabolic acidosis and muscle fatigue.
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: Compared to pyruvic acid, lactic acid is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The lone oxygen in the ketone group of pyruvate helps to pull the electron density from the carbon producing an increased polarity of the O-H bond. Thus making the carboxylate group of pyruvate a better proton donor than lactate

answers.description: Acidity cannot be determined based on structure only

child_mcqs.description: Pyruvic acid and lactic acid are considered
child_mcqs.explanation: Stereoisomers and constitutional isomers have the same chemical formula, so Answer A and Answer B are incorrect. The redox pair of this reaction is NADH and pyruvate, so C is incorrect. Both pyruvic acid and lactic acid are organic compounds with acidic functional groups, making Answer D correct.

child_mcqs.description: The transformation from pyruvate to lactate is a/an:
child_mcqs.explanation: The double bond becoming a single bond represents a decrease in the oxidation state of the carbon, so reduction.

child_mcqs.description: What is the product of this reaction
child_mcqs.explanation: -The reagent here substitutes the –OH group for chloride. It is an example of nucleophilic acyl substitution

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following statements are NOT true?

  1. Pyruvic acid has a smaller molecular mass than acetic acid
  2. Pyruvic acid has a higher boiling point than acetic acid
  3. Pyruvic acid is more acidic than acetic acid
child_mcqs.explanation:
Students would be expected to know the structure of a simple compound such as acetic acid, and to determine it's characteristics compared with pyruvate.

As a much (relatively) smaller compound, acetic acid has a lower boiling point than pyruvate, making statement ii true. 

Pyruvic acid has more electron withdrawing capacity than acetic acid, which will draw electrons aways from the carboyx group and increase it's propensity to 'donate' its proton, making pyruvic acid the stronger acid. Thus statement iii is true.

Since pyruvic acid is a larger compound than acetic acid, only statement i is untrue, so Answer A is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description: Aspartame, saccharine, and sodium cyclamate are all synthetic sweeteners used to replace glucose.

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following properties are shared by both glucose and the synthetic sweetners?

  1. All activate gustatory receptors at the tip of the tongue
  2. All are carbohydrates
  3. All can hydrogen bond
child_mcqs.explanation: -In order to cause a sweet taste, these substances must activate gustatory receptors at the tip of the tongue. They are not carbohydrates since they incorporate non-CHO elements, yet they all show hydrogen bonding (possessing O and H atoms).

child_mcqs.description: Bearing in mind the 'D' of D glucose refers to the orientation of functional groups on carbon 5, how many stereoisomers exist of D-Glucose?
child_mcqs.explanation: -There are 5 chiral carbons in the cyclic version of D-Glucose shown. However, all versions of D-glucose have the same arrangement around one of the carbons (C5) otherwise they would be considered to be L-glucose. Thus, there are 4 chiral centres to consider, and 16 stereoisomers of D-glucose in total (2 conformations per chiral carbon).

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following types of reaction describe the following process
child_mcqs.explanation: -Carbon 1 is bonded to both an O-R group and an alcohol group, forming a hemiacetal. It was derived from the aldehyde end group of the carbohydrate reagent by adding an alcohol group to the carbonyl group.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21
stem_mcq.description:
The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney. One of the processes that occur in the nephron is filtration of the plasma to produce urine. This occurs at the glomerulus (see the diagram below). The glomerular filtration barrier consists of:

  1. Fenestrated capillary endothelium
  2. A basement membrane that is negatively charged
  3. An epithelial layer consisting of podocyte foot processes.

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the volume of plasma filtered by the glomerulus per unit time. The renal plasma flow (RPF) is the volume of blood delivered to the entire kidney per unit time.

The filtration fraction (FF) is the proportion of plasma filtered by the glomerulus, i.e. FF = GFR/RFP.

The diagram below demonstrates the glomerulus, and the afferent and efferent blood vessels.

child_mcqs.description: Prostaglandins are known to dilate the afferent arteriole of the glomerulus. What would be the effect of increasing prostaglandin production in the kidneys?
child_mcqs.explanation: Dilating the afferent arteriole will increase blood flow to the kidney, and also increased glomerular filtration rate. Because both values will increase, according to the equation FF = GFR/RFP, the filtration fraction will not change.

answers.description: Increased RPF, increased GFR, increased filtration fraction
Increased RPF, increased GFR, no change in filtration fraction
Increased RPF, decreased GFR, increased filtration fraction
Increased RPF, decreased GFR, no change infiltration fraction

child_mcqs.description: Angiotensin II constricts the efferent arteriole of the glomerulus. What would be the effect of high levels of angiotensin II in the kidneys?
child_mcqs.explanation: Constricting the efferent arteriole will cause blood to bank up in the glomerulus and increased GFR. It will, however, also cause an overall decreased in renal plasma flow. Therefore, according to equation FF = GFR/RFP, the filtration fraction will increase.

answers.description: Decreased RPF, increased GFR, decreased filtration fraction
Decreased RPF, decreased GFR, increased filtration fraction
Decreased RPF, increased GFR, increased filtration fraction
Increased RPF, decreased GFR, decreased filtration fraction

child_mcqs.description: If the albumin content of plasma increased, GFR will:
child_mcqs.explanation: In filtration, blood protein provides the oncotic pressure drawing filtrate from the Bowman’s capsule back into the capillaries. Therefore if the albumin (protein) content of blood increased, the GFR would decrease.

answers.description: There is not enough information to determine the answer.

child_mcqs.description: If there is constriction of a ureter, GFR will:
child_mcqs.explanation: Constriction of the ureter of a kidney will cause increased pressure in Bowman’s capsule, which therefore causes a decreased GFR.

answers.description: There is not enough information to determine the answer.

child_mcqs.description: In some diseases, the charge barrier of the glomerulus is lost, allowing protein to pass into the urine. What will not be an associated consequence of this?
child_mcqs.explanation: A loss of the charge barrier should not allow larger red blood cells to pass into the urine. There will be loss of protein into the urine, which will lead to low protein content in the blood and generalised oedema due to a loss of oncotic pressure in the systemic capillaries.

child_mcqs.description: In relation to general renal physiology:
child_mcqs.explanation: To determine how much a substance is secreted, you must determine how much is excreted in total, and then minus how much has been filtered. This will tell us the amount that was passes from the peritubular capillaries into the blood.

child_mcqs.description: Clearance refers to the volume of plasma cleared of a substance per unit time. In relation to general renal physiology:
child_mcqs.explanation: The stem states "Clearance refers to the volume of plasma cleared of a substance per unit time". Thus the units for Clearance must be volume/time. This would be the same concentration of urine flow rate (volume/time). The concentration of both the urine and plasma of a substance would be g/L. Notice in answer A that urine concentration is being divided by plasma concentration. This means the units g/L is being divided by g/L (the exact same units). In math, whenever a unit is divided by itself, the units cancel out. This means the only unit remaining on the right hand of the equation is from urine flow rate which is volume/time and on the left hand of the equation the clearance unit is volume/time. Since the units match, this is the correct answer.

answers.description: Clearance of Y = (Urine concentration of Y x urine flow rate)/Plasma concentration of Y
Clearance of Y = (Urine concentration of Y x plasma concentration of Y)/Urine flow rate
Clearance of Y = (Urine flow rate x plasma concentration of Y)/Urine concentration of Y

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
The cell cycle is divided into four main phases: G1, S, G2 and M. G1 is the first gap phase during which a cell synthesizes proteins and undergoes growth. S is the synthesis phase in which the cell duplicates the DNA and centrioles. G2 is the second gap phase between DNA replication and cell division. Finally M is the mitotic phase in which the cell replicates into two identical daughter cells. Phases G1, S, G2 are collectively called Interphase.​

Meiosis is the form of cell division used to generate gametes with a haploid number of chromosomes.

child_mcqs.description: In a cell is undergoing meiosis, in which phase of the cell cycle is there the greatest content of DNA within the single cell:
child_mcqs.explanation: The cell has greatest content of DNA in the cell in G2. At this stage, DNA has been replicated and the cell is yet to divide for the first time.

child_mcqs.description: The primary underlying cause of trisomy 21 (3 copies of chromosome 21 within a cell) may be due to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Non-disjunction at either anaphase I or anaphase II can result in an extra 2 chromosome 21s in the one gamete. Therefore, during fertilisation, the offspring results in 2 chromosome 21s in the one zygote.

answers.description: Non-disjunction in anaphase 1 (non-disjunction = failure of the chromosomes to separate)

child_mcqs.description: Meiosis differs from mitosis in that:
child_mcqs.explanation: Variation occurs in meiosis due to crossing over and recombination during prophase I of meiosis.

answers.description: Meiosis only ever produces daughter cells that are diploid, whereas mitosis only ever produces daughter cells that are haploid
Meiosis results in variation in the daughter cells, whereas in mitosis the daughter cells are identical to one another.

child_mcqs.description: During fertilisation, when a sperm enters the egg, there is a cortical reaction that prevents any other sperm entering. This prevents:
child_mcqs.explanation: If more than one sperm entered an egg, the egg will have >2 sets of chromosomes. This is what we call polyploidy

answers.description: euploidy (correct number of chromosome sets for that species)

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not true regarding DNA replication?
child_mcqs.explanation: DNA ligase is required to join the okazaki fragments of the lagging strand.

answers.description: The template strand is replicated in a 3’ to 5’ direction
DNA helicase and topoisomerases are responsible for the unwinding and uncoiling of DNA respectively.
DNA ligase is required to join the okazaki fragments of the leading strand
DNA polymerase cannot synthesise the new strand of DNA from the single stranded template.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
A Fridel-Crafts acylation is a reaction where an acyl group is added to benzene in the presence of a Lewis acid. The acylium anion formed from this reaction is very stable due to resonance. Next, the acylium anion attacks the benzene ring to generate the final product.

Powerful electron withdrawing groups on the benzene, such as another acyl group, would make the ring less reactive and more acidic and thus slow this reaction. On the other hand powerful electron donating groups, such as an amine, would make the ring more reactive but less acidic.

The manufacturing of Naphthalene shown below is an example of a Fridel Crafts reaction:

child_mcqs.description: What is the IUPAC name of the compound created in step 2?
child_mcqs.explanation: -The carboxylic functional group is what determines the parent chain of the substance, butanoic acid., because the acid group always takes priority over the phenyl group.  It is then named with a phenyl side group on carbon 4. Hence, 4-phenylbutanoic acid

child_mcqs.description: What is X in the following reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: -One carboxyl group becomes Y, so the other carboxylic acid portion remains as X

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following would have the slowest rate of reaction with FeBr3?
child_mcqs.explanation: -Benzene is a very stable compound with no attached functional groups for a reaction with FeBr3. Thus it would have a slow reaction.

answers.description: All have the same rate of reaction

child_mcqs.description: What is the correct order of acid strength of these three benzene derivatives; ranked from strongest to weakest
child_mcqs.explanation: -The strength of the various carboxylic acid groups depends on the stability of the anions formed. The various R groups affect this stability. The electronegative oxygen in the first substance has an electron drawing effect on the benzene ring and the COO- formed, making the anion more stable. The alkyl group has the opposite effect, pushing the electron density towards the COO- and decreasing its stability. Having no branch of the benzene does not improve or worsen the stability of the anion formed.

child_mcqs.description: If placed on a silicon paper chromatography, which of the following would travel faster?
child_mcqs.explanation: Chromatography paper is made of cellulose, a polar substance, and the compounds within the mixture travel farther if they are non-polar. More polar substances bond with the cellulose paper more quickly, and therefore do not travel as far. The third substance is the least polar molecule - the first has two polar groups and is clearly most polar, where the second has the same number of polar groups but has less aliphatic (C-H groups) than the third

answers.description: Cannot be determined from the information given

stem_mcq.title: Unit 24
stem_mcq.description:
When red blood cells are broken down, a by-product is bilirubin. Bilirubin must be removed from the body due to its toxicity. If a person is unable to remove bilirubin, it accumulates and the person becomes jaundiced (yellowing of the skin).

Bilirubin is bound to the albumin in the blood and carried to the liver, where it undergoes a glucuronidation reaction to become more water-soluble so it can become part of bile. This conjugated bilirubin then passes out of the liver through the bile duct into the small intestine. The bilirubin is converted to urobilinogen and then to stercobilin by the action of gut bacteria. Stercobilin imparts the brown colour onto faeces. Urobilinogen can be reabsorbed back into the blood stream and be excreted by the kidneys.

Note that if the bile ducts are obstructed, conjugated bilirubin accumulates in the blood at a faster rate than it can be excreted by the kidneys. This results in a person’s urine becoming darker.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following cannot cause a person to become jaundiced?
child_mcqs.explanation: All of the answers given can cause a patient to become jaundice. Excessive liver damage will mean that the liver cells (hepatocytes) will not be able to conjugate the bilirubin, which will therefore not be able to be excreted and accumulate in the blood. Similarly, not having the enzymes to glucuronidate bilirubin will lead to the inefficient excretion, and gall stone obstruction of the bile duct will prevent the flow of bile and lead to high bilirubin in the blood. Finally, excessive break down of red blood cells will saturate the enzymes responsible for bilirubin metabolism and result in jaundice.

answers.description: Lack of the enzymes in the liver that lead to glucuronidation of bilirubin
A gall stone blocking the bile duct
All of the above answers could cause a person to become jaundice.

child_mcqs.description: If there is complete obstruction of the bile duct, such that bilirubin cannot get into the small intestine:
child_mcqs.explanation: If bilirubin cannot get into the small intestine, there will be no bilirubin for the gut bacteria to act upon, and therefore no formation of stercobilin. This means that the person’s stools will be pale. Instead of passing out via the gut, the bilirubin will be released into the bloodstream and excreted by the kidneys. This will make the person’s urine darker.

answers.description: The person will be jaundiced, with pale stools and dark urine
The person will be jaundiced, with normal stools and dark urine
The person will be jaundiced, with normal stools and normal urine
The person will not be jaundiced, but will have pale stools and dark urine.

child_mcqs.description: If red blood cell destruction in a person is excessive:
child_mcqs.explanation: Excess red blood cell destruction can result in high levels of bilirubin in the blood, and therefore lead to a jaundiced person. Since there is no problem with the liver or biliary system, bilirubin metabolism will occur as normal and the stools should be normal in colour. The kidneys will, however, be excreting a higher level of bilirubin when the liver enzymes are overwhelmed and urine will be darker.

answers.description: The person will be jaundiced, with pale stools and dark urine
The person will be jaundiced, with normal stools and dark urine
The person will be jaundiced, with normal stools and normal urine
The person will not be jaundiced, but will have pale stools and dark urine

stem_mcq.title: Unit 25
stem_mcq.description:
The pH of blood must be kept with narrow limits to prevent the denaturing of proteins and to ensure that enzymes are functioning at their optimum. The pH is calculated by the following equation:

pH = 6.1 + log{[HCO3-]/0.03 x PCO2}

Normally, PCO2 = 40mmHg, HCO3- = 24 mmol/L

The two main body systems involved in keeping pH within these normal limits include the respiratory system and the renal system. The lungs can alter pCO2 through changes in ventilation. For example, increasing the rate of respiration will remove carbon dioxide from the body and therefore increase the pH.

 The kidneys can alter HCO3- by changes in production and excretion. For example, the kidneys can resorb HCO3- and raised the pH.  

An abnormal pH may be due to respiratory causes or metabolic causes. When the pH is lower than normal, the person is said to be acidotic. When the pH is higher the normal, the person is said to be alkalotic. If the cause is respiratory in nature, the kidneys will attempt to compensate and return the pH to normal. In contrast, if the cause is metabolic in nature, the lungs will attempt to correct the pH.

child_mcqs.description: The normal pH of the blood is
child_mcqs.explanation: The normal pH of the blood is 7.4. If this was not known it could be calculated using the equation provided.

child_mcqs.description: During starvation, the body begins to make keto-acids (i.e. ketones) from fat. This lowers the pH. The initial response by the body to correct this involves:
child_mcqs.explanation: The generation of more acid in the body will lower the blood pH. This will result in the lungs attempting to remove carbon dioxide (an acidic compound) to raise the pH and maintain homeostasis.

answers.description: The kidneys excreting more HCO3- to raise the pH
The kidneys excreting less HCO3- to raise the pH
An increase in breathing rate to remove more CO2 from the blood
A decrease in breathing rate to remove less CO2 from the blood

child_mcqs.description:
The following two questions refer to the table below.

 

pH

PCO2

HCO3-

Case 1

7.30

60

27

Case 2

7.30

30

16

 

 

 

Case 1:
child_mcqs.explanation: Case 1 is an example of a respiratory acidosis. It is an acidosis because the pH is less than 7.4, and respiratory in nature because the CO2 is high, meaning the lungs are not getting rid of it from the body efficiently. In contrast, the HCO3- is relatively normal.

child_mcqs.description:
The following question refers to the table below.

 

pH

PCO2

HCO3-

Case 1

7.30

60

27

Case 2

7.30

30

16

 

Case 2:
child_mcqs.explanation: Case 2 is an example of a metabolic acidosis. It is an acidosis because the pH is less than 7.4. It is metabolic in nature because HCO3- (a basic compound) is less than normal, whereas CO2 (acidic) is normal (or slightly less than normal).

stem_mcq.title: Unit 26
stem_mcq.description: When heated at high temperatures, adipic acid reacts with acetic anhydride to form diacetoxy-terminated adipic acid as shown in the schematic below. When heated further in a vacuum, a reaction known as melt polycondensation occurs and a polymer of adipic acid is formed (polyadipic acid). During the reaction, care is exercised as overheating can cause thermal degradation of all reagents and products, which occurs around 180°C

child_mcqs.description: In the synthesis of diacetoxy-terminated adipic acid, what is the most likely by-product that is formed?
child_mcqs.explanation: -By analyzing the reaction scheme, the group that is being replaced by the acetic anhydride must be an acetic acid group.

child_mcqs.description: In order to purify the diacetoxy-terminated adipic acid in step 2, the by-product is typically removed via distillation to improve yield. This is because:
child_mcqs.explanation: -The entire reaction scheme is in equilibrium. It is uncertain whether the by-product, in this case acetic acid, will affect the reaction scheme so answer A cannot be correct. While B may be true to some extent, it doesn’t explain why yield will be improved, this also applies to D. The only answer that directly addresses and answers the question is C, according to Le Chetalier’s principle.

answers.description: The by-product is an impurity that will prevent the final polycondensation reaction
The by-product dilutes the concentration of the reagents, thus reducing the rate of the forward reaction.
Removing the by-product shifts the equilibrium in the forward direction.
The by-product cannot be removed at low temperatures

child_mcqs.description: How would one determine if the reaction has initiated during the reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since the byproduct is acetic acid, which students should be able to surmise has a boiling point lower than 170C, the correct answer is A. Bubbling will be observed when the reaction is initiated. Condensate will occur on the distillation apparatus in almost all situations, since the surface of the apparatus is lower than the termperature of the reaction. The reactants are also acidic, so litmus paper will not be useful in testing whether acetic acid formation has occured.

answers.description: Observe for the presence of bubbles that signifies the boiling of the by-product from the reaction
Observe for the appearance of condensate in the distillation apparatus, signifying the production and removal of the by-product from the reaction.
Use blue litmus paper to check for acidity of the by-product.
One cannot tell unless the reaction is stopped.

child_mcqs.description: It was found that at 175°C, distillation only removed 50% of the by-product. What could be done to improve the removal rate of the by-product?
child_mcqs.explanation: -Increasing the temperature further will cause degradation as indicated in the introduction to the question. B is obviously wrong as degradation of the by-product will most likely degrade everything else as well. C is the only correct answer as decreasing the pressure in the reaction vessel will decrease the boiling point of the by-product, facilitating its removal.

answers.description: Thermally degrade the by-product by heating above 180°C.
Reduce the pressure of the reaction vessel by applying a vacuum.
Increase the pressure of the reaction vessel by sealing the vessel

child_mcqs.description:
After using the improved distillation method described in question 3, the diacetoxy-terminated adipic acid was analysed using mass spectroscopy. Below is the mass spectrum:

What could explain the pattern observed in the mass spectrum?
child_mcqs.explanation: The mass spectrum indicates that there is a repeating unit of mass 128 amu, which coincides with the mass of a single unit of adipic acid. Since the reaction is a polymerization reaction, the mass spectrum is representing polymer strands with various number of adipic units. This means that the polymerization has already started during the distillation phase, thus C is the only correct answer.

answers.description: The reaction conditions created large amounts of impurities
The by-product was not removed completely, leading to multiple reactions.
The polycondensation reaction was accidentally initiated in the attempt to remove the by-product.
A reaction occurred within the within the mass spectrometer that resulted in the formation of adipic acid clusters.

title: Live Exam Results
instruction:
This GradReady Practice Exam is meant to test your ability to take the GAMSAT. The idea behind this exam is to help you assess what you have learned and where you may still be struggling. You will get the best results from this exam if you treat it as if it were the actual GAMSAT.

Upon completion of the exam you will be able to see your score. Your essay will be graded by a tutor, and feedback will be given.

Today’s Exam consists of 3 Sections:

Section 1: Reasoning in Humanities and Social Sciences (10 min reading time + 1 hr 40 min)

Section 2: Written Communication - Essay (5 min reading time + 1 hr)

Lunch Break (1 hr)

Section 3: Reasoning in Biological & Physical Sciences (10 minute reading time + 2 hr 50 min)

Good luck!

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
The follow passage explores natropathy

Like medical doctors, naturopaths must undergo considerable training before they are allowed to receive their Doctor of Naturopathy (N.D.).6 To pursue a career in naturopathic medicine, a baccalaureate degree or at least the minimum of 3 years (15 full courses), is required before applying for the four-year doctoral degree. In some institutions, entrance requirements also include an essay, two reference letters, an autobiographical sketch and a personal interview, much like the Ontario medical schools. While many institutions of  naturopathy are located in the United States, two institutions can be found in Canada: the Boucher Institute of Naturopathic Medicine in New Westminster, BC and the Canadian College of Naturopathic Medicine (CCNM) in North York, Ontario. However, the CCNM is the country’s only accredited four-year training program. At this institution, the first two years are spent studying anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, pathology, pharmacology, and natural therapies. The next two years focus on clinical training in diagnosis and natural treatment modalities. Tuition at the CCNM for the 2002-2003 academic year was $15,175 for first-year domestic students, only slightly less than medical school tuition for the University of Toronto.

 

Efficacy of Treatments

The NIH National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) has a website  (http://nccam.nih.gov) which provides evidence for and against a variety of alternative remedies. Despite the increased demand for CAM, there are few high quality studies that provide evidence  for their effectiveness. In this article, we will highlight the use of two popular herbal remedies: red clover and garlic.  With the early termination of one of the trial arms of the Women’s Health Initiative evaluating hormone replacement therapy, many women may now be  considering using alternatives to conventional medicine to manage menopausal symptoms. One  of the alternatives prescribed by naturopaths may include red clover (Trifolium pratense) which  has been shown to contain plant estrogens or phytoestrogens. The class of phytoestrogens in red  clover are the isoflavones, which are plant sterols also found in soybeans (albeit to a lesser  degree). Their effect is believed to be exerted by possessing structural similarities to human  estrogens and thus, when taken in large quantities, may show estrogenic activity. A study  conducted in the Netherlands showed that red clover may have some actual therapeutic benefit. 

In a randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled trial, van de Weijer and Burentsen demonstrated that the isoflavones from red clover significantly reduced menopausal hot flush  symptoms by 44%.10 However, the trial was rather small with only thirty participants and it  lasted for only 12 weeks. A more comprehensive study examining the ben- efits derived from red  clover in addition to its potential toxicity is currently being conducted by the NCCAM. Thus, for  the time being, the prescription of red clover by naturopaths for the treatment of hot flushes may be valid. The naturopath would most likely combine the herbal prescription  with dietary and lifestyle modification advice.

The use of garlic has gradually become more popular for the treatment of cardiovascular disease.  Of the nearly 100 chemicals in garlic, the most important appears to be allicin, an amino acid containing sulfur, which is formed when cloves are crushed.11 In rat hepatocytes, garlic was shown to inhibit the activity of the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, the primary enzyme responsible for synthesizing cholesterol. However, a report examining garlic use and its effects on the risk of cardiovascular disease concluded that “there are insufficient data to draw conclusions regarding garlic’s effects on clinical cardiovascular outcomes such as myocardial infarction.” Garlic preparations failed to show consistent reductions in blood pressure, had no effects on glucose or insulin sensitivity, and showed only small, positive effects on cholesterol levels. Thus, garlic pills do not appear to have the beneficial effects that many consumers believe. In addition, garlic has several side effects such as bad breath, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux.  It may reduce blood clotting so it should be taken with caution in patients who are on blood thinning agents.14 Thus, at the current time, garlic should only be used as a supplement to treatments of proven cardiac risk reduction benefit, such as regular exercise, weight control, tobacco avoidance, and a good diet.

child_mcqs.description: The early section of the passage compares natural medicine and more official medical training
child_mcqs.explanation: Both medical training and natropathy training are shown as involving hard work and a long period of study.  In this respect the two are seen in favorable juxtaposition.  The key is “A”.

child_mcqs.description: Red clover’s effectiveness is due to
child_mcqs.explanation: There is a specific reference to the fact that the clover has a similar chemistry to the hormone.  Its red colour is immaterial.  B. is too general.  D. is not supported by the passage.  C is the key.

answers.description: The fact that it is a herbal remedy

child_mcqs.description: A crucial issue with the blind, placebo-controlled study on red clover’s effectiveness is
child_mcqs.explanation: Specific reference is made to the relative smallness of the sample group used and how this can prejudice results.  “C” is the key.  “A” “B” and “D” are too general as responses.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

A less toxic therapy for older patients with AML would be of great benefit. Antibody-targeted chemotherapy is expected to be less toxic than conventional chemotherapy and has beendeveloped for the treatment of CD33-positive AML. The antibody-targeted chemotherapy Mylotarg (gemtuzumab ozogamicin, Wyeth Laboratories, Philadelphia, PA, USA) consists ofa humanized anti-CD33 monoclonal antibody conjugated to calicheamicin, a highly potent antitumor antibiotic that cleaves double-stranded DNA at specific sequences. Approximately 90% of AML patients have myeloid blast cells that express the CD33 surface antigen. This antigen is present on normal hematopoietic progenitor cells but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells or on nonhematopoietic cells. It also is present on the leukemic stem cells of at least some AML patients.26 Thus, Mylotarg is targeted treatment for patients with CD33-positive AML because the antibody component of the molecule targets calicheamicin, the cytotoxic component, to CD33-positive cells. In a phase I dose-escalation trial with relapsed or refractory CD33-positive AML patients, eight of 40 (20%) patients treated with Mylotarg had leukemic blast cells eliminated from the blood and marrow. In phase II efficacy and safety trials, a preliminary report indicated that 42 of 142 (30%) patients with AML in first relapse obtained remission after treatment with two doses of Mylotarg at 9 mg/m2. Although severe myelosuppression was common, mucositis and severe infections were not. Based on these data, Mylotarg was approved in the United States for the treatment of patients with CD33-positive AML in first relapse who are 60 years of age or older and who are not considered candidates for other cytotoxic chemotherapy. Here, we specifically report data from the phase II trials on the efficacy and safety of Mylotarg in patients  60 years of age for whom it was approved. These results show that Mylotarg, as a single agent, offers an effective, well-tolerated treatment option for older patients with AML in first relapse. These 101 older patients were included among the 188 adult patients of all ages who were enrolled on the phase II clinical trials. Limited data on 80 of these older patients were included in an earlier report on the first 142 patients who were treated.

child_mcqs.explanation: If 90% do express the antigen, as the passage states, then it follows that 10%.  The key is “B”.  The other options are not supported by the passage.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage explore the concept of economic geography

The study of economic geography - - of the location of factors of production in space - occupies a relatively small part of standard economic analysis. International trade theory, in particular, conventionally treats nations as dimensionless points (and frequently assumes zero transportation costs between countries as well). Admittedly, models descended from von Thünen play an important role in urban studies, while Hotelling-type models of locational competition get a reasonable degree of attention in industrial organization. On the whole, however, it seems fair to say that the study of economic geography plays at best a marginal role in economic theory. On the face of it, this neglect is surprising. The facts of economic geography are surely among the most striking features of real-world economies, at least to laymen. For example, one of the most remarkable things about the United States is that in a generally sparsely populated country, much of whose land is fertile, the bulk of the population resides in a few clusters of metropolitan areas; forty percent are crowded into a not especially inviting section of the East Coast. It has often been noted that nighttime satellite photos of Europe reveal little of political boundaries, but clearly suggest a center-periphery pattern whose hub is somewhere in or near Belgium. A laynian might have expected that these facts would play a key role in economic modelling.

Furthermore, there is a long if somewhat thin tradition in location theory, that one might have supposed would inspire the efforts of both theorists and econometricians. Indeed, several schools of thought may be identified. Best known, perhaps, is the German School, originating in the work of von Thünen (1826) but led in the twentieth century by Weber (1909), Christaller (1933), and Lösch (1940). Inspired by this German school, but less preoccupied with the geometry of location, was the American school of regional science, including Hoover (1948) and especially Isard (1956). Yet another tradition, drawing on Marshall's initial description of agglomeration due to external economies, stresses the role of externalities in producing divergent regional development; the most influential writings in this tradition are those of Myrdal (1957), Hirschmann (1958), and Perroux (1950), and this tradition has been carried on more recently by David (1984) and Arthur (1989).

child_mcqs.description: The passage opens with
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage begins with a broad range of facts, all of which fulfill options “A” “B” and “C”.  “D” is the option which therefore best addresses the question.

child_mcqs.description: The observations on center-periphery in the passage relate to
child_mcqs.explanation: The middle of the passage makes observations about where people live in America, with most areas sparsely populated and others densely populated.  This supports “A”.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
EXTERMINATOR!

During the war I worked for A. J. Cohen Exterminators ground floor office dead end street by the river. An old Jew with cold gray fish eyes and a cigar was the oldest of four brothers. Marv was the youngest wore wind breakers had three kids. There was a smooth well dressed college trained brother. The fourth brother burly and muscular looked like an old time hoofer could bellow a leather lunged "Mammy" and you hope he won't do it. Every night at closing time these two brothers would get in a heated argument from nowhere I could see the older brother would take the cigar out of his mouth and move across the floor with short sliding steps advancing on the vaudeville brother.

"You vant I should spit right in your face!? You vant!? You vant? You vant!?"

The vaudeville brother would retreat shadow boxing presences invisible to my Goyish eyes which I took to be potent Jewish Mammas conjured up by the elder brother. On many occasions I witnessed this ritual open mouthed hoping the old cigar would let fly one day but he never did. A few minutes later they would be talking quietly and checking the work slips as the exterminators fell in.

On the other hand the old brother never argued with his exterminators. "That's why I have a cigar" he said the cigar being for him a source of magical calm.

I used my own car a black Ford V8 and worked alone carrying my bedbug spray pyrithium powder bellows and bulbs of fluoride up and down stairs.

"Exterminator! You need the service?"

A fat smiling Chinese rationed out the pyrithium powder — it was hard to get during the war — and cautioned us to use fluoride whenever possible. Personally I prefer a pyrithium job to a fluoride. With the pyrithium you kill the roaches right there in front of God and the client whereas this starch and fluoride you leave it around and back a few days later a southern defense worker told me "They eat it and run around here fat as hawgs."

From a great distance I see a cool remote neighborhood blue windy day in April sun cold on your exterminator there climbing the gray wooden outside stairs.

"Exterminator lady. You need the service?"

"Well come in young man and have a cup of tea. That wind has a bite to it."

"It does that, mam, cuts me like a knife and I'm not well you know/cough/."

"You put me in mind of my brother Michael Fenny."

"He passed away?"

"It was a long time ago April day like this sun cold on a thin boy with freckles through that door like yourself. I made him a cup of hot tea. When I brought it to him he was gone." She gestured to the empty blue sky "cold tea sitting right where you are sitting now." I decide this old witch deserves a pyrithium job no matter what the fat Chinese allows. I lean forward discreetly.

"Is it roaches Mrs. Murphy?"

"It is that from those Jews downstairs."

"Or is it the Hunkys next door Mrs. Murphy?"

She shrugs "Sure and an Irish cockroach is as bad as another."

"You make a nice cup of tea Mrs. Murphy . . . Sure I'll be taking care of your roaches . . . Oh don't be telling me where they are . . . You see I know Mrs. Murphy . . . experienced along these lines . . . And I don't mind telling you Mrs. Murphy I like my work and take pride in it."

"Well the city exterminating people were around and left some white powder draws roaches the way whisky will draw a priest."

"They are a cheap outfit Mrs. Murphy. What they left was fluoride. The roaches build up a tolerance and become addicted. They can be dangerous if the fluoride is suddenly withdrawn . . . Ah just here it is . . ."

I have spotted a brown crack by the kitchen sink put my bellows in and blow a load of the precious yellow powder. As if they had heard the last trumpet the roaches stream out and flop in convulsions on the floor.

"Well I never!" says Mrs. Murphy and turns me back as I advance for the coup de grace . . . "Don't shoot them again. Just let them die."

When it is all over she sweeps up a dust pan full of roaches into the wood stove and makes me another cup of tea.

When it comes to bedbugs there is a board of health regulation against spraying beds and that of course is just where the bugs are in most cases now an old wood house with bedbugs back in the wood for generations only thing is to fumigate . . . So here is Mamma with a glass of sweet wine her beds back and ready . . .

I look at her over the syrupy red wine . . . "Lady we don't spray no beds. Board of health regulations you know."

"Ach so the wine is not enough?"

She comes back with a crumpled dollar. So I go to work . . . bedbugs great red clusters of them in the ticking of the mattresses. I mix a little formaldehyde with my kerosene in the spray its more sanitary that way and if you tangle with some pimp in one of the Negro whore houses we service a face full of formaldehyde keeps the boys in line. Now you'll often find these old Jewish grandmas in a back room like their bugs and we have to force the door with the younger generation smooth college trained Jew there could turn into a narcotics agent while you wait.

"All right grandma, open up! The exterminator is here."

child_mcqs.description: The persona which the author borrows is that of a(n)
child_mcqs.explanation: The character would not take on the persona of who he is.  This precludes “A”.  There is nothing in the passage to support “C” and “D”.   In contrast “B” is supported by his attempts to establish a rapport and promote his work.

child_mcqs.explanation: The character is clearly fascinated by the people he meets.  “D” is not supported by the passage, as it is a concern he would not be likely to have in his professional position.  He is not an ethnographer so “A” is unlikely.  He is not fabricating details so “A” is unlikely.  This leaves “C”.

child_mcqs.explanation: The writer hopes to show how people talk, what is the sound of their voices.  This is distinct from idiom.  This precludes all options but “C”.

child_mcqs.explanation: The writer’s work does not make him more insightful.  He already possesses that quality.  Access to chemicals will not improve his writing, and knowledge of it is only incidental.  In gaining access to homes he can see people in their element.  “D” is the key.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
Lee turned his attention to a Jewish boy named Carl Steinberg, whom he had known casually for about a year. The first time he saw Carl, Lee thought, "I could use that, if the family jewels weren't in pawn to Uncle Junk."

The boy was blond, his face thin and sharp with a few freckles, always a little pink around the ears and nose as though he had just washed. Lee had never known anyone to look as clean as Carl. With his small round brown eyes and fuzzy blond hair, he reminded Lee of a young bird.

Born in Munich, Carl had grown up in Baltimore. In manner and outlook he seemed European. He shook hands with traces of a heel-click. In general, Lee found European youths easier to talk to than Americans. The rudeness of many Americans depressed him, a rudeness based on a solid ignorance of the whole concept of manners, and on the proposition that for social purposes, all people are more or less equal and interchangeable.

What Lee looked for in any relationship was the feel of contact. He felt some contact with Carl. The boy listened politely and seemed to understand what Lee was saying. After some initial balking, he accepted the fact of Lee's sexual interest in his person. He told Lee, "Since I can't change my mind about you, I will have to change my mind about other things."

But Lee soon found out he could make no progress. "If I got this far with an American kid," he reasoned, "I could get the rest of the way. So he's not queer. People can be obliging. What is the obstacle?" Lee finally guessed the answer: "What makes it impossible is that his mother wouldn't like it." And Lee knew it was time to pack in. He recalled a homosexual Jewish friend who lived in Oklahoma City. Lee had asked, "Why do you live here? You have enough money to live anywhere you like." The reply was, "It would kill my mother if I moved away." Lee had been speechless.

One afternoon Lee was walking with Carl by the Amsterdam Avenue park. Suddenly Carl bowed slightly and shook Lee's hand. "Best of luck," he said, and ran for a streetcar. Lee stood looking after him, then walked over into the park and sat down on a concrete bench that was molded to resemble wood. Blue flowers from a blossoming tree had fallen on the bench and on the walk in front of it. Lee sat there watching the flowers move along the path in a warm spring wind. The sky was clouding up for an afternoon shower. Lee felt lonely and defeated. "I'll have to look for someone else," he thought. He covered his face with his hands. He was very tired.

He saw a shadowy line of boys. As each boy came to the front of the line, he said "Best of luck," and ran for a streetcar.

"Sorry . . . wrong number ... try again . . . somewhere else . . . someplace else . . . not here. . . not

me ... can't use it, don't need it, don't want it. Why pick on me?" The last face was so real and so

ugly, Lee said aloud, "Who asked you, you ugly son of a bitch?"

Lee opened his eyes and looked around. Two Mexican adolescents walked by, their arms around each other's necks. He looked after them, licking his dry, cracked lips. Lee continued to see Carl after that, until finally Carl said "Best of luck" for the last time, and walked away. Lee heard later he had gone with his family to Uruguay.

child_mcqs.description: The nature of the relationship between Lee and Carl is
child_mcqs.explanation: The relationship between the two is unresolved despite strong feelings/desires.  This precludes “B” and “C”.  Multifaceted is probably too strong an adjective for the relationship.  The key is “A”.

child_mcqs.description: Lee’s attitude towards Carl’s sexuality suggests
child_mcqs.explanation: Lee has sexual interest in the boy.  This precludes “A”.  He knows the boy is not gay.  This precludes “D”.  The boys receptiveness to Lee’s proposition precludes “C”.  “B” is the key.

child_mcqs.description: While Lee is arguably a predator he is ultimately depicted as
child_mcqs.explanation: Time and again the passage focuses on the loneliness of Lee.  The final part of the passage in fact makes this the primary focus.  “D” is the key.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
The name is Clem Williamson Snide.

               Another time I am working on a routine case of industrial sabotage when the factory burns down killing twenty-three people. These things happen. I am a man of the world. Going to and fro and walking up and down in it.

               Death smells. I mean it has a special smell, over and above the smell of cyanide, carrion, blood, cordite or burnt flesh. It's like opium. Once you smell it you never forget. I can walk down a street and get a whiff of opium smoke and I know someone is kicking the gong around.

               I got a whiff of death as soon as Mr. Green walked into my office. You can't always tell whose death it is. Could be Green, his wife, or the missing son he wants me to find. Last letter from the island of Spetsai two months ago. After a month with no word the family made inquiries by long-distance phone.

               "The embassy wasn't at all helpful," said Mr. Green.

               I nodded. I knew just how unhelpful they could be.

               "They referred us to the Greek police. Fortunately, we found a man there who speaks English."

"That would be Colonel Dimitri."

"Yes. You know him?"

I nodded, waiting for him to continue.

               "He checked and could find no record that Jerry had left the country, and no hotel records after Spetsai."

               "He could be visiting someone."

               "I'm sure he would write."

               "You feel then that this is not just an instance of neglect on his part, or perhaps a lost letter? ... That happens in the Greek islands...."

               "Both Mrs. Green and I are convinced that something is wrong."

               "Very well, Mr. Green, there is the question of my fee: a hundred dollars a day plus expenses and a thousand-dollar retainer. If I work on a case two days and spend two hundred dollars, I refund six hundred to the client. If I have to leave the country, the retainer is two thousand. Are these terms satisfactory?"

               "Yes."

               "Very good. I'll start right here in New York. Sometimes I have been able to provide the client with the missing person's address after a few hours' work. He may have written to a friend."

               "That's easy. He left his address book. Asked me to mail it to him care of American Express in Athens." He passed me the book.

               "Excellent."

               Now, on a missing-person case I want to know everything the client can tell me about the missing person, no matter how seemingly unimportant and irrelevant. I want to know preferences in food, clothing, colors, reading, entertainment, use of drugs and alcohol, what cigarette brand he smokes, medical history. I have a questionnaire printed with five pages of questions. I got it out of the filing cabinet and passed it to him.

               "Will you please fill out this questionnaire and bring it back here day after tomorrow. That will give me time to check out the local addresses."

               "I've called most of them," he said curtly, expecting me to take the next plane for Athens.

               "Of course. But friends of an M.P. —missing person—are not always honest with the family. Besides, I daresay some of them have moved or had their phones disconnected. Right?" He nodded. I put my hands on the questionnaire. "Some of these questions may seem irrelevant but they all add up. I found a missing person once from knowing that he could wriggle his ears. I've noticed that you are left-handed. Is your son also left-handed?"

               "Yes, he is."

               "You can skip that question. Do you have a picture of him with you?"

               He handed me a photo. Jerry was a beautiful kid. Slender, red hair, green eyes far apart, a wide mouth. Sexy and kinky-looking.

               "Mr. Green, I want all the photos of him you can find. If I use any I'll have copies made and return the originals. If he did any painting, sketching, or writing I'd like to see that too. If he sang or played an instrument, I want recordings. In fact, any recordings of his voice. And please bring if possible some article of clothing that hasn't been dry-cleaned since he wore it."

               "It's true then that you use uh psychic methods?"

               "I use any methods that help me to find the missing person. If I can locate him in my own mind that makes it easier to locate him outside it."

               "My wife is into psychic things. That's why I came to you. She has an intuition that something has happened to him and she says only a psychic can find him."

               That makes two of us, I thought. He wrote me a check for a thousand dollars. We shook hands.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description:
If the Ithaca episode begins at 2:00 A,M., as the Gilbert schema says, then Stephen and Bloom must part at 2:30~plus. Bloom, left alone, is aware of "the incipient intimations of proximate dawn" (17.1247-48 [704:30]). Sunrise in Dublin on 17 June 1904 was at 3:33 A,M., so, depending on the cloud cover, daylight would have begun to gray things as early as 2:00A.M. Would it help to move Circe, Eumaeus, and Ithaca back an hour, as the Linati schema does, relocating Ithaca at 1:00 A.M.? That would ease the timetable from the beginning of Ithaca to first light to sunrise and almost make it believable that Molly hears the chimes of "George's church" ring "2 o’clock" (18.1231-32[772:27-28]), but it would incredibly clog the hours from 11 :00 P.M. to 1 :00 A.M.

If elaborate efforts to establish accurate timetables tend to fairer, they also tend to mislead our attention as readers and distract us from the variety of ways Joyce imitates time. We are all aware, for example, that we can think and perceive far more in the course of a few minutes of multi-leveled consciousness than we could spell out in words in as many hours. Joyce variously explores that disparity. At 8.481 (164:23) Bloom reflects that it is "five minutes" since he fed the birds from O'Connell Bridge, and it is a five minute stroll from the bridge to the front of Trinity College where Bloom is, but he feeds the birds at 8.75-76 (153:7-8), a good   twenty minute read away. Twenty minutes of prose time is being manipulated to imitate five minutes of half-formed thought-perception time, thought-perception that could be verbalized  but usually is not.

There are even more radical experiments with the disparities between clock time, psychological time, and the imitation of time in the Circe and Penelope episodes. Because the Circe episode is cast in the form of a play with speeches and stage directions, we assume that reading time is approximately equal to playing time. But the reverse is the case: there is a radical disparity between reading time and playing time. For example, the hallucination at Introduction 3 15.1354-1956 (pp. 478-99), which we associate with Bloom, actually takes place between the two halves of Zoe's speech: "Go on. Make a stump speech out of it. . . . Talk away till you're black in the face," And again at 15.2750 (527: 10), Bella Cohen, the whore mistress, enters with the line, "My word! I'm all of a muck sweat," and continues at 15.3500 (555:2-3), "Which of you was playing the dead march from Saul?" The implication is that the hallucinations we associate with Bloom are acted out not for his witness but for ours; what are mere blips on the screen of his consciousness are dramatized and spelled out for us.

Psychoanalysts I have consulted about Bloom's hallucinations say that the ones we associate with him would unfold not in the course of one night's dreams, but over a period of about two years for the average patient undergoing analysis. In other words, the hallucinations last only a moment in dramatic time but are spelled out in a dramatic imitation of epic time, the two years or so of this phase-in-the-life.

In the Penelope episode the prose seems to imitate the way Molly might mutter to herself. Read aloud, the duration of the episode is three hours. Is that the order of time Joyce is imitating? Or is the muttering voice of the prose in turn imitating the foreshortened time and kaleidoscopic scatter of image we experience in brief spells of insomnia, an hour or less by the clock? I suspect that the Penelope episode's time is more like the time of hallucination and drama in Circe than it is like the time of a voice overheard and, therefore, that Molly's soliloquy belongs at once in the dramatic and the epic dimensions of time.

child_mcqs.explanation: Option “D” obviously is possible, so would not qualify as an assumption.  “C” also is obvious and wouldn’t qualify as an assumption.  This leaves “A” and “B”.  Of the two “B” is referenced specifically in the passage.  “B” is the key.

The depiction of private fantasy and private memory

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
Explaining to a child why a fairy tale is so captivating to him destroys, moreover, the story’s enchantment, which depends to a considerable degree on the child’s not quite knowing why he is delighted by it. And with the forfeiture of this power to enchant goes also a loss of the story’s potential for helping the child struggle on his own, and master all by himself the problem which has made the story meaningful to him in the first place. Adult interpretations, as correct as they may be, rob the child of the opportunity to feel that he, on his own, through repeated hearing and ruminating about the story, has coped successfully with a difficult situation. We grow, we find meaning in life, and security in ourselves by having understood and solved personal problems on our own, not by having them explained to us by others.

Fairy-tale motifs are not neurotic symptoms, something one is better off understanding rationally so that one can rid oneself of them. Such motifs are experienced as wondrous because the child feels understood and appreciated deep down in his feelings, hopes, and anxieties, without these all having to be dragged up and investigated in the harsh light of a rationality that is still beyond him. Fairy tales enrich the child’s life and give it an enchanted quality just because he does not quite know how the stories have worked their wonder on him.

This book has been written to help adults, and most especially those with children in their care, to become more fully aware of the importance of such tales. As has already been pointed out, innumerable interpretations besides those suggested in the text that follows may be pertinent; fairy tales, like all true works of art, possess a multifarious richness and depth that far transcend what even the most thorough discursive examination can extract from them. What is said in this book should be viewed as illustrative and suggestive merely. If the reader is stimulated to go beyond the surface in his own way, he will extract ever more varied personal meaning from these stories, which will then also become more meaningful to the children he may tell them to.

Here, however, one especially crucial limitation must be noted: The true meaning and impact of a fairy tale can be appreciated, its enchantment can be experienced, only from the story in its original form. Describing the significant features of a fairy tale gives as little feeling for what it  is all about as the listing of the events of a poem does for its appreciation. Such a description of main features, however, is all that a book like this one can provide, short of actually reprinting the stories. Since most of these fairy tales are readily available elsewhere, the hope is that this book will be read in conjunction with a re-reading of the tales discussed.* Whether it is “Little Red Riding Hood,” “Cinderella,” or any other fairy tale, only the story itself permits an appreciation of its poetic qualities, and with it an understanding of how it enriches a responsive mind.

child_mcqs.description: The author takes what specific attitude in his writing?
child_mcqs.explanation: The author clearly establishes the need to explain what motivates fairy tales.  As such his intention is not condescending or paternalistic.  The author is authoritative by default, but mainly interested in educating.  “C” is the key.

child_mcqs.description: A paradox the passage presents is that
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage explicitly states that its own interpretations of dreams are not definitive and hence can only be given as much credence as the reader might wish to grant them.  This fundamentally undermines the writers authority.  “B” is the key.

answers.description: It discusses fairy tales while being aimed at an adult audience
It disavows its own authority as a text
It analyses the importance of not engaging in analysis

child_mcqs.description: The function of this text as a(n)
child_mcqs.explanation: No one needs instructions on how to read fairy tales.  This precludes “C”.  The structure of the book is not as an annotation.  This precludes “A”.  “B” is too vague.  “D” is the key.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
EXT. ROAD - DAY

 

               The three of them... Carol chattering away.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  I don't know the last time I've

                                  been out of the city... Hey, my

                                  arms are tanning. I used to tan

                                  great. We gotta stop soon so'se

                                  I can check on Spencer.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                                 (during the above)

                                  I'm sorry... I can't hear you. I

                                  can't turn my head all the way

                                  yet... tell her we can't hear her.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  Doesn't matter. She's enjoying

                                  herself. Consider it part of the

                                  music.

 

               A short time later. Carol is now driving.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  I'm sure, Simon, they did

                                  something real off for you to feel

                                  this way... But when it comes to

                                  your partners -- or your kid --

                                  things will always be off for you

                                  unless you set it straight. Maybe

                                  this thing happened to you just to

                                  give you that chance.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  Nonsense!

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Anybody here who's interested in

                                  what Melvin has to say raise their

                                  hands.

 

               Simon does not raise his hand. Simon and Carol have thus

               declared their majority.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Do you want to know what happened

                                  with my parents?

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Yes. I really would.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Well...

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  No, let me pull over so I can pay

                                  full attention.

 

               Car pulling over toward parking spot.

               She takes the car curbside and parks.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Now go ahead.

 

               Simon looks back at Melvin as does Carol. He looks

               innocent. Several beats -- Melvin almost says something

               -- a hidden hand gesture from Carol stops him. Finally.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Well, I always painted. Always.

                                  And my mother always encouraged

                                  it. She was sort of fabulous

                                  about it actually... and she used

                                  to... I was too young to think

                                  there was anything at all wrong

                                  with it... and she was very

                                  natural. She used to pose nude

                                  for me... and I thought or assumed

                                  my father was aware of it.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  This stuff is pointless.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Hey -- you let him...

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  You like sad stories -- you want

                                  mine.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Go ahead, Simon. Really.

                                  Please. Don't let him stop you. Ignore him.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Okay. Well, one day my father

                                  came in on one of those painting

                                  sessions when I was nine -- and he

                                  just started screaming at her --

                                  at us -- at evil. And...

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                                 (very quickly)

                              ... my father didn't leave his

                              room for 11 years -- he hit my

                              hand with a yardstick if I made a

                              mistake on the piano.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Go ahead, Simon. Your father

                                  walked in on you and was yelling

                                  and... really, come on.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  I was trying to defend my mother

                                  and make peace, in the lamest way.

                                  I said, "she's not naked -- it's

                                  art." And then he started hitting

                                  me. And he beat me unconscious.

                                  After that he talked to me less

                                  and less -- he knew before I left

                                  for college, my dad came into my

                                  room. He held out his hand. It

                                  was filled with money. A big wad

                                  of sweaty money.

                                                 (gathers himself)

                                  And he said to me, "I don't want
