                                  you to ever come back." I grabbed

                                  him and I hugged him... He turns

                                  and walked out.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Well, you know -- I still say

                                  what I said. You've got to get

                                  past it all when it comes to your

                                  parents. We all have these horror

                                  stories to get over.

 

               Melvin shifts INTO the FRAME.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  That's not true. Some of us have

                                  great stories... pretty stories

                                  that take place at lakes with

                                  boats and friends and noodle

                                  salad. Just not anybody in this

                                  car. But lots of people -- that's

                                  their story -- good times and

                                  noodle salad... and that's what

                                  makes it hard. Not that you had

                                  it bad but being that pissed that

                                  so many had it good.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  No.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Not it at all, really.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                                 (a veteran's irony)

                                  Not at all, huh?!... Let's go to

                                  the hotel. And if you're lucky

                                  tomorrow Dad will give you another

                                  wad of sweaty money.

child_mcqs.description: What role does Melvin play in the scene?
child_mcqs.explanation: While elements of what Melvin says are represented in “A” “C” and “D”, each of these options suggests he is acting in direct opposition to the scene’s other characters.  In actual fact, as is made clear at the passage’s end, all the he is saying is representative of an essentially cynical philosophy.   “B” is the key.

child_mcqs.description: Carol’s role in the scene is that of
child_mcqs.explanation: Carol, in her opposition to Melvin, only occupies such a position because her personal philosophy is antithetical to his.  As such she would not qualify for any label other than that of optimist.  “A” is the key.

child_mcqs.description: What is Simon’s role in the scene
child_mcqs.explanation: Simon, unlike the other two characters, is only basing his responses off his emotional experiences, not of any preconceived notions.  He is purely emotional, and as such is “The Heart”.  “B” is the key.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
All furniture is scaled down to fit into this low-ceilinged

               space. A few other short men sit reading tiny magazines.

               Craig approaches Floris, the receptionist.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Welcome to LesterCorp. May we meet

                                  your filing needs?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No, uh, my name is Craig Schwartz.

                                  I have an interview with Mr. Lester.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Please have a seat, Mr. Juarez...

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Schwartz.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Pardon?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Schwartz.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  I'm sorry, I'm afraid I have no idea

                                  what you're saying right now.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  My name is Schwartz.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Money, Miss Warts?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Forget it.

 

               Craig takes a seat next to the other applicants.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                                 (calling across the room)

                                  Fork ah did?

 

               The intercom buzzes. Floris picks it up.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                                 (to Craig)

                                  Mr. Juarez?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Yes?

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Yex?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  I said "yes."

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  You suggest what? I have no time for

                                  piddling suggestions from mumbling job

                                  applicants, my good man. Besides, Dr.

                                  Lester will see you now. I think

                                  that's what he said.

 

               Craig stands, opens Lester's door, and enters

                                            

               Craig enters. Lester, a giant of an old man, sits hunched

               behind his tiny desk.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Come in, Mr. Juarez. I'd stand, but,

                                  well, you know.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                                 (extending his hand)

                                  Actually, my name is Craig Schwartz,

                                  Dr. Lester.

 

               Lester flips an intercom switch.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Security.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No, it's okay, sir. Just a mixup with

                                  your secretary.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  She's not my secretary. She's what

                                  they call an executive liaison, and

                                  I'm not banging her, if that's what

                                  you’re implying.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Not at all, Dr. Lester. I simply

                                  misspoke.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Tell me, Dr. Schwartz, what do you

                                  feel you can bring to LesterCorp?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Well, sir, I'm an excellent filer.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                                 (crafty)

                                  You think so, eh? Which comes first,

                                  L or... Glooph?

 

                                                             CRAIG  

                                  Glooph is not a letter, sir.           

 

                                                             LESTER 

                                  Damn, you are good. I tried to trick

                                  you. Okay, put these in order.

 

               Lester hands Craig a bunch of index cards. Craig orders

               them with amazing speed and dexterity. Lester watches,

               eyes wide.

 

                                                             LESTER (CONT'D)

                                                 (flips intercom switch)

                                  Floris, get Guinness on the phone.

 

                                                             FLORIS (O.S.)

                                  Gehginnis ondah foam?

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Forget it.

 

                                                             FLORIS (CONT'D)

                                  Fork ah did?

 

                                                             LESTER

                                                 (flips off switch)

                                  Fine woman, Floris. I don't know how

                                  she puts up with this damn speech

                                  impediment of mine.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  You don't have a speech impediment,

                                  Dr. Lester.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Flattery will get you everywhere,

                                  my boy. But I'm afraid I have to

                                  trust Floris on this one. You see,

                                  she has her doctorate in speech

                                  impedimentology from Case Western.

                                  Perhaps you've read her memoirs,

                                  "I can't understand a word any of

                                  you are saying."

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Pity, it tells it like it is.

                                  That's why the eastern, read Jewish,

                                  publishing establishment won't touch

                                  it. That's a quote from the book

                                  jacket. George Will, I think.

                                                 (beat)

                                  I apologize if you can't understand

                                  a word I'm saying, Dr. Schwartz.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No. I understand perfectly.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                                 (choking up)

                                  Thank you for being kind enough to

                                  lie. You see, I've been very lonely

                                  in my isolated tower of

                                  indecipherable speech. You're hired.

                                  Any questions?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Just one. Why is this floor so short?

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Low overhead, m'boy. We pass the

                                  savings on to you.

                                                 (laughs heartily)

                                  But seriously, that's all covered in

                                  orientation.

child_mcqs.description: By the scene’s end Lester
child_mcqs.explanation: The fact that he refers to Craig as Dr. Schwartz, even though Craig has not indicated that he is a doctor, indicates that the old man is still confused as to the identity of his new acquaintance.

answers.description: Is still confused as to who Craig is
Is unsure Craig is who he says he is

child_mcqs.description: It is clear in relation to her book that Floris
child_mcqs.explanation: While Lester refers to Floris being published he also says who she is not published by.  Given the overall absurd tone of the exchange, it is possible that she may not in fact be published.

answers.description: Is not published with a major publishing group

child_mcqs.description: The most absurd element of the conversation between Craig and Lester is
child_mcqs.explanation: Lester believes that he is having a wonderful conversation with Craig even though he believes the man does not understand what he is saying.  This is impossible, and the more remarkable given the clarity of what Lester generally says.

answers.description: Lester’s rapport with Craig given the general circumstances of their conversation

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
Aaron is seated behind a desk -- some old news copy in

               his hand.  An unmanned camera is pointing at him.  Tom

               is standing a few feet further back studying him.

 

                                                            AARON

                              This is uncomfortable for me --

                              because, well, I don't mean it as

                              a knock, but we approach this

                              differently.

 

                                                            TOM

                              We sure do.  I don't mean it as a

                              knock either.

                                             (he smiles)

                              Go ahead.  I'll just say what I think

                              and you can disregard it if you want.

 

                                                            AARON

                              It just might not work for me because

                              of our different approaches.

 

               Tom nods and gestures that he proceed.  Aaron begins reading

               the news.  Barely a sentence in, he is interrupted.

 

                                                            TOM

                              Wait.

 

                                                            AARON

                              What?

 

                                                            TOM

                              Your coat jacket is rising up in

                              back.

 

               Aaron ignores the tip.

 

                                                            TOM

                              When you sit down -- sit on your

                              jacket a little -- that gives you

                              a good line.  Look at yourself in

                              the monitor.

 

               Aaron looks but is unimpressed and resumes reading the news.

               Tom, not about to be ignored when he knows it's important, moves

               behind Aaron and begins to force his jacket down.

 

                                                            AARON

                                             (very uncomfortable)

                              I don't like being handled.

 

                                                            TOM

                              Sit on it!  Now look.

 

                                                            AARON

                              Just don't physically...

                                             (he sees himself in the

                                              monitor and is suddenly

                                              enthusiastic)

                              Fantastic tip -- fantastic.

 

               He starts to read again.

 

                                                            TOM

                              No.  That's not going to tell us

                              anything.  Let's get this prompter

                              going.

 

                                                            AARON

                              It's not loaded.

 

                                                            TOM

                              I'll find some copy.  Be right back.

 

               Tom exits -- Aaron looking after him, clearly taken with the

               genuine camaraderie... the unmistakable joy Tom derives from

               helping out.  Several beats and Tom comes back with a CAMERAMAN in

               tow.

 

                                                            TOM

                              I got copy, I got Ellen to heat up

                              the camera and I got Master Control

                              taping so you can study it later.

 

               He puts the roll of copy in the prompter.

 

                                                            AARON

                              Hey, Tom...

 

               Tom turns.

 

                                                            AARON

                              I'm very appreciative.

 

               SAME SCENE - LATER

 

               Tom totally focused on him down one knee checking him from

               various angles.  He interrupts.  Aaron reading from the prompter.

 

                                                            TOM

                              No.  No.

 

                                                            AARON

                              No?

 

                                                            TOM

                              Don't let your eyes go from the

                              beginning of the sentence to the end

                              like that.  You don't want to look

                              shifty, do you?

 

                                                            AARON

                              Oh, God, no!

 

                                                            TOM

                              And the left side of your face is the

                              good one.  Go again.  And try to punch

                              one word or phrase in every sentence --

                              punch one idea a story.  Punch -- come

                              on --

 

               Aaron does same with the story he is reading...

 

                                                            TOM

                              Good...very nice.

 

               Aaron acknowledges the compliment in news mode.  Punching the

               first words.

 

                                                            AARON

                              Thank you for the compliment, Tom.

 

               He draws a laugh from the Cameraman as he goes right into the

               next story.

 

                                                            TOM

                              Try not to move your head or wrinkle

                              your forehead...this is good, very

                              good...

child_mcqs.description: The subtext of the scene’s early section is
child_mcqs.explanation: Even though Aaron is looking for Tom’s tuition he still explicitly states that he believes their approaches are too different, and as such will not make for a very good match.  He does not really believe Tom will help him.  “C” is the key.

answers.description: Tom likes Aaron and wants to help him

child_mcqs.description: It can be assumed from the dialogue that
child_mcqs.explanation: The context for the tuition session is based on Tom having more experience than Aaron.  This would indicate “C”.  The other categories are more subjective, and as such less likely.

answers.description: Tom is better at presentation than Aaron
Tom has more experience with being a news anchor than Aaron
Tom is pretending to know more than Aaron

child_mcqs.description: A likely reason for Tom being in the position he is in is due to
child_mcqs.explanation: Once again the crucial factor is the presence of television and a television camera.  “A” and “B” suggest general notions of self-possession.  “D” is more vague than “C”.  “C” is the key.

answers.description: Thinking about the visual impression he makes
Thinking about how his presence and words translate on television
Thinking of how to present on television

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
Sidney comes up beside Hunsecker, falls

into step beside him.  As they cross towards a water cooler

at the back of the stage, they talk in rapid undertone.

 

                         HUNSECKER

            I got that boy coming over here.

                   (a glance at Sidney)

            What's so funny?

 

                         SIDNEY

                   (who is smiling faintly)

            With a pocket fulla firecrackers -

            good.

 

                         HUNSECKER

                   (narrowly)

            I think you loused this up but good.

            If I can trust my eyes, and I think

            I can, Susie knows all about your

            dirty work.

 

                         SIDNEY

                   (shrugging)

            Can't hurt...

 

                         HUNSECKER

                   (incredulously)

            Can't hurt?  I had to get him back

            his job.

 

                         SIDNEY

                   (smugly)

            I like that, too.

                   (closer, faster)

            Look, J.J., we can wrap this up in

            one neat bundle, addressed to the

            dumps - to oblivion.  We're going

            great, but please play it my way.

            I cased this kid.

            Know his ins and outs...He's fulla

            juice and vinegar, just begging for

            some big shot like you to give him

            a squeeze.  Do little Sidney a

            favor: squeeze! - You know, J.J. -

            the porcupine bit - needles.

 

                         HUNSECKER

            But it's too late.  I got him back

            the job...

 

                         SIDNEY

                   (impatiently)

            No, that's the point - he won't

            accept your favor!  The manager

            yes, but not the boy.

 

A pause.  Hunsecker renumerates.

 

                         HUNSECKER

            Well he's got her in a tizzy, I'll

            tell you that!

 

                         SIDNEY

            Sure, he steams her up - wants her

            to stand on her own two feet and

            all that jazz!

 

                         HUNSECKER

            And who's feet is she on now?

 

                         SIDNEY

            Presumably yours...

                   (a hasty addition)

            That's according to St. Dallas.

 

                         HUNSECKER

            What's this boy got that Susie likes?

 

                         SIDNEY

            Integrity - acute, like indigestion.

 

                         HUNSECKER

            What does that mean - integrity?

 

                         SIDNEY

                   (repeating as before)

            A pocket fulla firecrackers -

            looking for a match!

                   (grinning)

            It's a new wrinkle to tell the

            truth... I never thought I'd make a

            killing on some guy's "integrity".

 

Hunsecker gives him certain slow begrudging admiration:

 

                         HUNSECKER

            Full of beans, ain't you?  But you

            know that you'll stand or fall by

            what you're doing now...

 

                         SIDNEY

                   (grins; confidently)

            Calculated risk.  Only we happen to

            know, J.J., that you like me.  I'm

            your star pupil -- I reflect back

            to you your own talent.

 

Hunsecker permits himself a faint smile.  Burton is

approaching with script in hand.

 

                         HUNSECKER

            I wouldn't like to take a bite of

            you; you're a cookie full of arsenic.

 

Sidney smirks.  He turns away and goes off towards the

auditorium in the background.

child_mcqs.description: Hunsecker’s final remark represents
child_mcqs.explanation: The level of control Hunsecker demonstrates suggests he would not be shocked.  He is clearly attempting to insult Sidney, precluding amusement.  This leaves “C” and “D”.  He marvels in fact at the cynicism of his underling, even as a cynic himself.  “D” is the key.

answers.description: The surprise of one cynic at another cynicism

child_mcqs.description: Susie’s boyfriend produces what response in the two men?
child_mcqs.explanation: The jovial quality of Sidney’s remarks on the brother and Hunsecker’s queries would seem to indicate “A” to be the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
From Billy Budd by Herman Melville

The night, so luminous on the spar-deck, but otherwise on the cavernous ones below, levels so like the tiered galleries in a coal-mine—the luminous night passed away. But, like the prophet in the chariot disappearing in heaven and dropping his mantle to Elisha, the withdrawing night transferred its pale robe to the breaking day. A meek shy light appeared in the East, where stretched a diaphanous fleece of white furrowed vapor. That light slowly waxed. Suddenly eight bells was struck aft, responded to by one louder metallic stroke from forward. It was four o'clock in the morning. Instantly the silver whistles were heard summoning all hands to witness punishment. Up through the great hatchways rimmed with racks of heavy shot, the watch below came pouring, overspreading with the watch already on deck the space between the main-mast and fore-mast including that occupied by the capacious launch and the black booms tiered on either side of it, boat and booms making a summit of observation for the powder--boys and younger tars. A different group comprising one watch of topmen leaned over the rail of that sea-balcony, no small one in a seventy-four, looking down on the crowd below. Man or boy, none spake but in whisper, and few spake at all. Captain Vere--as before, the central figure among the assembled commissioned officers--stood nigh the break of the poop-deck facing forward. Just below him on the quarter-deck the marines in full equipment were drawn up much as at the scene of the promulgated sentence.

child_mcqs.description: The spar-deck is probably
child_mcqs.explanation: The night is luminous on this deck, suggesting it is open to the sky, i.e. the top deck

child_mcqs.description: ‘Diaphanous’ is closest to
child_mcqs.explanation: The meaning of diaphanous is most similar to translucent

child_mcqs.description: The tone of the piece is
child_mcqs.explanation: Signalling bells are struck and all hands come up on deck. Something is about to happen.

child_mcqs.description: Most likely, the next paragraph will describe
child_mcqs.explanation: The sailors have all come on deck to witness a punishment. This is not a pirate story, so it is unlikely anyone will be walking the plank

child_mcqs.description: The weather is
child_mcqs.explanation: A “diaphanous fleece of white furrowed vapor” is a translucent sheet of water droplets, i.e. mist.

child_mcqs.description: The author describes the dawn
child_mcqs.explanation: The imagery of a beautiful dawn contrasts and so emphasises with the image of the ship as a mine and the soldiers emerging to witness a whipping.

answers.description: to explain that the sailors can see

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
From Howards End by E M Forster

 

 Shortly before the move, our hero and heroine were married.  They have weathered the storm, and may reasonably expect peace.  To have no illusions and yet to love--what stronger surety can a woman find?  She had seen her husband's past as well as his heart.  She knew her own heart with a thoroughness that commonplace people believe impossible.  The heart of Mrs. Wilcox was alone hidden, and perhaps it is superstitious to speculate on the feelings of the dead.  They were married quietly--really quietly, for as the day approached she refused to go through another Oniton.  Her brother gave her away, her aunt, who was out of health, presided over a few colourless refreshments.  The Wilcoxes were represented by Charles, who witnessed the marriage settlement, and by Mr. Cahill.  Paul did send a cablegram.  In a few minutes, and without the aid of music, the clergyman made them man and wife, and soon the glass shade had fallen that cuts off married couples from the world.  She, a monogamist, regretted the cessation of some of life's innocent odours; he, whose instincts were polygamous, felt morally braced by the change, and less liable to the temptations that had assailed him in the past.
    They spent their honeymoon near Innsbruck.  Henry knew of a reliable hotel there, and Margaret hoped for a meeting with her sister.  In this she was disappointed.  As they came south, Helen retreated over the Brenner, and wrote an unsatisfactory postcard from the shores of the Lake of Garda, saying that her plans were uncertain and had better be ignored.  Evidently she disliked meeting Henry.  Two months are surely enough to accustom an outsider to a situation which a wife has accepted in two days, and Margaret had again to regret her sister's lack of self-control.  In a long letter she pointed out the need of charity in sexual matters: so little is known about them; it is hard enough for those who are personally touched to judge; then how futile must be the verdict of Society.  "I don't say there is no standard, for that would destroy morality; only that there can be no standard until our impulses are classified and better understood." Helen thanked her for her kind letter--rather a curious reply.  She moved south again, and spoke of wintering in Naples.

child_mcqs.description: The passage probably comes
child_mcqs.explanation: Since our the main characters of the novel have ‘weathered a storm’, we know that some ‘storm’ precedes the passage, so it is not at the beginning. Helen’s letter is ‘curious’, i.e. we don’t here understand it. This tells us that it will later be explained, so the passage does not come at the end of the novel.

child_mcqs.description: Margaret
child_mcqs.explanation: She loves with no illusions, and has accepted something regarding him. So she knows something discrediting about him but has forgiven him, i.e. she feels compassion.

child_mcqs.description: “Life’s innocent odours” refers to
child_mcqs.explanation: These ‘innocent odours’ are ceasing for the woman because she is monogamous and is getting married, so they must be flirtations, which a monogamous married person cannot engage in.

child_mcqs.description: We can infer that Henry
child_mcqs.explanation: We can assume that she has forgiven him for something sexual, but there is no indication specifically what it was.

child_mcqs.description: Margaret tells her sister
child_mcqs.explanation: She says there can be no standard for moral judgment until our impulses are classified and better understood.

answers.description: only those involved in a situation can judge its morality
understanding is needed before morality can be decided

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
From Orlando by Virginia Woolf

 

So, after a long silence, 'I am alone', he breathed at last, opening his lips for the first time in this record. He had walked very quickly uphill through ferns and hawthorn bushes, startling deer and wild birds, to a place crowned by a single oak tree. It was very high, so high indeed that nineteen English counties could be seen beneath; and on clear days thirty or perhaps forty, if the weather was very fine. Sometimes one could see the English Channel, wave reiterating upon wave. Rivers could be seen and pleasure boats gliding on them; and galleons setting out to sea; and armadas with puffs of smoke from which came the dull thud of cannon firing; and forts on the coast; and castles among the meadows; and here a watch tower; and there a fortress; and again some vast mansion like that of Orlando's father, massed like a town in the valley circled by walls. To the east there were the spires of London and the smoke of the city; and perhaps on the very sky line, when the wind was in the right quarter, the craggy top and serrated edges of Snowdon herself showed mountainous among the clouds. For a moment Orlando stood counting, gazing, recognizing. That was his father's house; that his uncle's. His aunt owned those three great turrets among the trees there. The heath was theirs and the forest; the pheasant and the deer, the fox, the badger, and the butterfly.

 

He sighed profoundly, and flung himself--there was a passion in his movements which deserves the word--on the earth at the foot of the oak tree. He loved, beneath all this summer transiency, to feel the earth's spine beneath him; for such he took the hard root of the oak tree to be; or, for image followed image, it was the back of a great horse that he was riding, or the deck of a tumbling ship--it was anything indeed, so long as it was hard, for he felt the need of something which he could attach his floating heart to; the heart that tugged at his side; the heart that seemed filled with spiced and amorous gales every evening about this time when he walked out. To the oak tree he tied it and as he lay there, gradually the flutter in and about him stilled itself; the little leaves hung, the deer stopped; the pale summer clouds stayed; his limbs grew heavy on the ground; and he lay so still that by degrees the deer stepped nearer and the rooks wheeled round him and the swallows dipped and circled and the dragonflies shot past, as if all the fertility and amorous activity of a summer's evening were woven web-like about his body.

child_mcqs.description: In the passage the main character
child_mcqs.explanation: The author says he ‘opens his lips for the first time in this record’, i.e. speaks for the first time in the novel.

answers.description: speaks for the first time in the novel

child_mcqs.description: The author uses
child_mcqs.explanation: The author says 19 counties can be seen from the hill, plus galleons, armadas, forts and castles. This is obviously an exaggeration.

child_mcqs.description: The passage is set
child_mcqs.explanation: The architecture discussed is all from the past and all plausibly existing at the one time in the past, so not some invented time.

child_mcqs.description: The tone of the passage is
child_mcqs.explanation: The hyperbolic imagery, particularly that pertaining to nature ands its fertility, all create a tone of abundance.

child_mcqs.description: Orlando is
child_mcqs.explanation: As he lies under the tree ‘image follows image’. He creates a series of poetic images.

child_mcqs.description: The imagery in the second paragraph is employed
child_mcqs.explanation: This imagery describes the images in Orlando’s imagination, so do not describe the scene or the time Orlando lives. There is no plot development. The answer is therefore C.

answers.description: to illustrate the time in which Orlando lived

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
From The Age of Innocence by Edith Wharton

 

No expense had been spared on the setting, which was acknowledged to be very beautiful even by people who shared his acquaintance with the Opera houses of Paris and Vienna. The foreground, to the footlights, was covered with emerald green cloth. In the middle distance symmetrical mounds of woolly green moss bounded by croquet hoops formed the base of shrubs shaped like orange-trees but studded with large pink and red roses. Gigantic pansies, considerably larger than the roses, and closely resembling the floral pen-wipers made by female parishioners for fashionable clergymen, sprang from the moss beneath the rose-trees; and here and there a daisy grafted on a rose-branch flowered with a luxuriance prophetic of Mr. Luther Burbank's far-off prodigies.

 

In the centre of this enchanted garden Madame Nilsson, in white cashmere slashed with pale blue satin, a reticule dangling from a blue girdle, and large yellow braids carefully disposed on each side of her muslin chemisette, listened with downcast eyes to M. Capoul's impassioned wooing, and affected a guileless incomprehension of his designs whenever, by word or glance, he persuasively indicated the ground floor window of the neat brick villa projecting obliquely from the right wing.

 

"The darling!" thought Newland Archer, his glance flitting back to the young girl with the lilies-of-the-valley. "She doesn't even guess what it's all about." And he contemplated her absorbed young face with a thrill of possessorship in which pride in his own masculine initiation was mingled with a tender reverence for her abysmal purity. "We'll read Faust together ... by the Italian lakes ..." he thought, somewhat hazily confusing the scene of his projected honey-moon with the masterpieces of literature which it would be his manly privilege to reveal to his bride. It was only that afternoon that May Welland had let him guess that she "cared" (New York's consecrated phrase of maiden avowal), and already his imagination, leaping ahead of the engagement ring, the betrothal kiss and the march from Lohengrin, pictured her at his side in some scene of old European witchery.

child_mcqs.description: Archer sees his fiancé as
child_mcqs.explanation: He tells us that she doesn’t understand what the amorous affair in the opera is about. She is still innocent.

child_mcqs.description: Archer envisages
child_mcqs.explanation: In his mind he brings together images of his honeymoon with the cultural works it will be his manly privilege to reveal to his bride. He is thinking about what he will reveal to her on their honeymoon, so the answer is C.

answers.description: bringing his wife from innocence to experience

child_mcqs.description: Regarding his fiancé, Archer is
child_mcqs.explanation: He looks at her with the thrill of possessorship.

child_mcqs.description: The window of the villa represents
child_mcqs.explanation: M Capoul is attempting to persuade Madame Nilsson to go into the room with him. By glancing at the window he is suggesting they commit adultery. (He is suggesting they go specifically into that room, so what is suggested is adultery not more generally an affair.)

child_mcqs.description: ‘Guileless’ is closest to
child_mcqs.explanation: ‘Guileless’ is closest in meaning to ‘candid’.

child_mcqs.description: In the passage, America is to Europe as
child_mcqs.explanation: The American bride to be is chaste and pure, and will come to experience in some scene of European witchery.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon uses
child_mcqs.explanation: The idea that Einstein made his big discovery by accidentally overhearing a remark and interpreting it in a way which was not intended is surprising, rather than ironic or paradoxical.

child_mcqs.description: The cartoonists suggests
child_mcqs.explanation: The serious message of the cartoon is not that this is really possibly how the theory of relativity was discovered (so it isn’t suggesting that this discovery involved luck or being in the right place at the right time). It is rather suggesting through a humorous metaphor that women’s contribution to society is often unacknowledged.

answers.description: the theory of relativity was discovered by luck
the contributions of women have been long unacknowledged
at the right point in history anyone could have discovered the theory of relativity

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
From A DISCOURSE OF A METHOD, For the well-guiding of Reason; AND The discovery of Truth in the SCIENCES by Descartes

 

Right understanding is the most equally divided thing in the World; for every one beleevs himself so well stor’d with it, that even those who in all other things are the hardest to be pleas’d, seldom desire more of it then they have; wherein it is not likely that all Men are deceived: But it rather witnesseth, That the faculty of right-judging and distinguishing truth from falshood (which is properly call’d, Understanding or Reason) is naturally equal in all Men. And as the diversity of our Opinions, is not, because some are more reasonable then others; but only that we direct our thoughts several ways, neither do we consider the same things. For ’tis not enough to have good faculties, but the principal is, to apply them well. The greatest Souls are as capable of the greatest Vices, as of the most eminent Vertues: And those who move but very slowly, may advance much farther, if they always follow the right way; then those who run and straggle from it.

 

For my part, I never presum’d that my Minde was more perfect in any thing then an ordinary Mans; nay, I have often wish’d to have had my thoughts as quick, my imagination as clear and distinct, and my memory as large and as ready as some other Men have had. And I know no Qualities which serve more then those to the perfection of the Minde; for as for Reason or Understanding, forasmuch as it is the only thing which makes us Men, and distinguisheth us from beasts, I will beleeve it to be entire in every One, and follow herein the common opinion of the Philosophers, who say, That there is only more or less among the Accidents, and not amongst the Forms or nature of the Individuals of one species.

child_mcqs.description: According to Descartes
child_mcqs.explanation: He says right understanding (reason) is equally divided among people (most people have it).

child_mcqs.description: Descartes argues disagreement stems from
child_mcqs.explanation: He says that it is not enough to have a good faculty of reason, we also need to be able to apply reason well, and this is why people hold different opinions (not because some have more reason than others).

child_mcqs.description: Descartes draws an analogy between
child_mcqs.explanation: The clue to this is to look at the preceding sentence. After saying that reason can be used well or badly, and so lead to good or bad opinion, he says that great souls are also capable of good or bad activity (virtue or vice). The analogy is thus between that which stems from the bad activity of reason and that which stems from the bad activity of the soul, bad opinion and vice.

child_mcqs.description: According to Descartes the perfection of the mind involves
child_mcqs.explanation: After saying his mind is not perfect he lists a series of things he has wished about his mind, one of which is a larger memory, so large memory must be part of the perfect mind.

child_mcqs.description: Descartes believes
child_mcqs.explanation: It is understanding which distinguishes us from animals

answers.description: understanding is part of the nature of people

child_mcqs.description: Descartes’ character appears as
child_mcqs.explanation: He argues that everyone has reason, not just himself, and that his mind is not perfect, listing things he would like to improve about it, so he appears to be humble.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
From Letter to a Hindu by Tolstoy

 

Thus it went on everywhere. The recognition that love represents the highest morality was nowhere denied or contradicted, but this truth was so interwoven everywhere with all kinds of falsehoods which distorted it, that finally nothing of it remained but words. It was taught that this highest morality was only applicable to private life—for home use, as it were—but that in public life all forms of violence—such as imprisonment, executions, and wars—might be used for the protection of the majority against a minority of evildoers, though such means were diametrically opposed to any vestige of love. And though common sense indicated that if some men claim to decide who is to be subjected to violence of all kinds for the benefit of others, these men to whom violence is applied may, in turn, arrive at a similar conclusion with regard to those who have employed violence to them, and though the great religious teachers of Brahmanism, Buddhism, and above all of Christianity, foreseeing such a perversion of the law of love, have constantly drawn attention to the one invariable condition of love (namely, the enduring of injuries, insults, and violence of all kinds without resisting evil by evil) people continued—regardless of all that leads man forward—to try to unite the incompatibles: the virtue of love, and what is opposed to love, namely, the restraining of evil by violence. And such a teaching, despite its inner contradiction, was so firmly established that the very people who recognize love as a virtue accept as lawful at the same time an order of life based on violence and allowing men not merely to torture but even to kill one another.

 

For a long time people lived in this obvious contradiction without noticing it. But a time arrived when this contradiction became more and more evident to thinkers of various nations. And the old and simple truth that it is natural for men to help and to love one another, but not to torture and to kill one another, became ever clearer, so that fewer and fewer people were able to believe the sophistries by which the distortion of the truth had been made so plausible.

 

In former times the chief method of justifying the use of violence and thereby infringing the law of love was by claiming a divine right for the rulers: the Tsars, Sultans, Rajahs, Shahs, and other heads of states. But the longer humanity lived the weaker grew the belief in this peculiar, God—given right of the ruler

child_mcqs.description: Tolstoy argues that popular attitude toward love was
child_mcqs.explanation: Tolstoy argues that love was recognised as the highest morality in words only, not deeds. This attitude is hypocritical.

child_mcqs.description: The one condition of love could best be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: This condition is described as “the enduring of injuries, insults, and violence of all kinds without resisting evil by evil” which is the principle a person is upholding when they offer their cheek to be struck again.

answers.description: love your neighbour as you love yourself
do unto others as you would have them do unto yours
if he strikes your cheek, offer him the other

child_mcqs.description: Common sense indicates that
child_mcqs.explanation: Common sense dictates that if some people claim to decide who can be violently oppressed for the benefit of others, the oppressed people will in turn come to the conclusion that they can decide who can be violently oppressed (i.e. they will attempt to oppress others).

answers.description: those who have been oppressed will attempt to oppress

child_mcqs.description: ‘Sophistries’ is closest to
child_mcqs.explanation: ‘Sophistries’ is closest in meaning to ‘specious’.

child_mcqs.description: The growing belief in the need for love was accompanied by
child_mcqs.explanation: The chief method of justifying the infringement of the law of law had been monarchies, but the longer humanity lived this belief came to be doubted, as the validity of the infringement of the law of love came to be doubted.

sections.title: Section III: Reasoning in Biological and Physical Sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
The boiling point of some molecules was recorded and plotted in the following graph:

The boiling point of a substance increase with the strength of its intermolecular bonds which range from strong hydrogen bonding to week Vander Waal’s bonding.

The table below shows the energies of interaction of intermolecular as well as intermolecular (covalent and ionic) bonds.

child_mcqs.description: Why does the trend of H2O and HF deviate from the trend in the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: When hydrogen is bonded to fluorine or oxygen the large difference in electronegativity causes an unequal distribution of electron density. The partial positive charge of the hydrogen attracts the partial negative charges of oxygens/fluorines on adjacent molecules leading to hydrogen bonding, and thus higher boiling points.

answers.description: They experience more Van Der Waal’s attractions

child_mcqs.description: What is the most probable explanation of why do noble gasses boiling points increase as the period increases?
child_mcqs.explanation: Temporary dipoles occur in all molecules including symmetrical atoms, such as noble gases. The larger the atom, the further the electrons are from the nucleus and the greater the amount of dispersion that can occur.

answers.description: The bonds are stronger because bigger atoms are more polarizable as the period increases
The bonds are weaker because bigger atoms are more less as the period increases
The bonds are stronger because electronegativity of atoms increase as the period increases
The bonds are weaker because electronegativity of atoms decrease as the period increases

child_mcqs.description: The atomic radius of Xe is
child_mcqs.explanation: Atomic radius increases with each period.

child_mcqs.description: From table 1 above, it could be concluded that:
child_mcqs.explanation: The higher the typical energy of the bond, the more stable it is, and the more energy is required to break it.

answers.description: The lower the typical energy of the bond the more stable it is
The higher the typical energy of the bond the more stable it is
Hydrogen Bonding with noble gasses is the strongest
Hydrogen Bonding with noble gasses is the weakest

child_mcqs.description: From graph 1 above it could be concluded-with the exception of HF and H20- that:
child_mcqs.explanation: -From the graph, the less electronegative the element, the higher the boiling point of its hydride. HI and HBr both have higher boiling points than HCl, and iodine and bromine are less electronegative than chlorine.

answers.description: The more electronegative a substance is, the higher the boiling point of its hydride
The less electronegative a substance is, the higher the boiling point of its hydride
the more electronegative a substance is, the lower the ionization energy
the less electronegative a substance is ,the higher the ionization energy

child_mcqs.description: all of the following have a net dipole moment EXCEPT
child_mcqs.explanation: The shape of SiH4 is tetrahedral with a silicon atom bonded to four hydrogen atoms, thus it does not have a net dipole moment.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description: Transcription is the process of generating an mRNA transcript from a DNA sequence. Translation is the production of polypeptide from an mRNA sequence.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: The transcription of DNA into mRNA requires:
child_mcqs.explanation: The transcription of DNA into RNA requires RNA polymerase to produce the mRNA sequence.

answers.description: The free nucleotides A, T, C and G

child_mcqs.description:
This table shows the mRNA codons, and the amino acids for which they code:

What is a possible DNA sequence that codes for the polypeptide: Tyr-Glu-Asp
child_mcqs.explanation: Tyr could be encoded by ATA (mRNA codon UAU), Glu by CTT (mRNA codon GAA) and Asp by CTA (mRNA codon GAU)

child_mcqs.description: Which is a possible anticodon for arginine?
child_mcqs.explanation: The mRNA codons for arginine are: CGU, CGC, CGA, CGG, AGA and AGG. The possible anticodons are therefore GCA, GCG, GCU, UCU, UCC. Of these, only GCA appears in the answers

child_mcqs.description:
What is the mRNA sequence that is generated from the following sequence of DNA:

5’ AGTCTAG 3’
child_mcqs.explanation: Be careful to check the orientation of your molecules in relation to 5’ and 3’.

child_mcqs.description: Elongation of a nucleic acid chain involves:
child_mcqs.explanation: Nucleotides are added onto the 3’ carbon atom of the previous nucleotide in the chain. We call this a phosphodiester bone.

answers.description: The addition of the next nucleotide on the 3’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a peptide bond
The addition of the next nucleotide on the 5’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a peptide bond
The addition of the next nucleotide on the 5’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a phosphodiester bond
The addition of the next nucleotide on the 3’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a phosphodiester bond

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not involved in mRNA processing before it leaves the nucleus?
child_mcqs.explanation: mRNA processing involves the addition of a 5’ G-methylated cap, a 3’ polyA tail, and the splicing out of introns by the spliceosome complex, which then splices the exons together to have a continuous coding sequence that is read by the ribosome to produce the protein molecule.

answers.description: Splicing out of introns by RNA polymerase

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
The behaviour of non-ideal gasses can be represented by Van der Waals Equation:

Where P is the absolute pressure, n is the number of moles, V is the volume, T is the absolute temperature and R is the gas constant (0.08206 L/atm mol K). a and b are constants determined experimentally for each gas studied.

child_mcqs.description: For an ideal gas what can be said about both “a” and “b?
child_mcqs.explanation: Mathematically, for the equation to equal the ideal gas equation, PV=nRT, ‘a’ and ‘b’ must be zero.

answers.description: A is positive while b is negative

child_mcqs.description: For a non-ideal gas, what can be said about both “a” and “b”?
child_mcqs.explanation: ‘A’ represents intermolecular attractions, not intramolecular attractions and ‘b’ represents the actual volume occupied by a gas.

answers.description: “a” reflects the strength of intra-molecular attractions, and “b” is the measure if the actual volume occupied by a gas
“b” reflects the strength of intermolecular attractions, and “a” is the measure if the actual volume occupied by a gas
“a” reflects the strength of intermolecular attractions, and “b” is the measure if the actual volume occupied by a gas
“b” reflects the strength of intra-molecular attractions, and “a” is the measure if the actual volume occupied by a gas

child_mcqs.description: From Van der Waals equation, it can be concluded that all of the following are true except
child_mcqs.explanation: For an ideal gas, ‘a’ would be zero however, for a real gas ‘a’ must be added onto the pressure in order to satisfy the ideal gas equation. Thus the pressure of the real gas is less than the ideal gas.

answers.description: Volume of the real gas is greater than the volume of the ideal gas
The pressure of the real gas is greater than the pressure of the ideal gas
Deviations from the ideal gas are due to intermolecular forces and molecular volume

child_mcqs.description: A compression factor Z has been defined. Z= PV/nRT. The graph below shows a plot of this z value against molarity at 3 different temperatures. This graph most likely represents:
child_mcqs.explanation: The compression factor is the ratio of the molar volume of a gas to the molar volume of an ideal gas at the same temperature and pressure. Thus the ratio of an ideal gas to another ideal gas would remain 1 for all temperatures.

answers.description: Both an Ideal and a real gas
This graph doesn’t not represent any gas since the compression factor Z is a function of temperature

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following molecules has the greatest dipole moment?
child_mcqs.explanation: Each are symmetrical molecules and thus do not have a dipole moment.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
When Ca(IO3) 2 dissolves in an acidic solvent the following reaction takes place 

Where HIO3 is a weak acid. The solubility constant (Ksp) can be determined from the solubility of Ca(IO3) 2 for solutions of varying concentrations of the acid solvent H+ using the following formula. 

To measure Ksp the solubility of 4 different solutions has been recorded in Table 1 below each with a different concentration of H+.
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: The Ksp for Ca(IO3) 2 is
child_mcqs.explanation: Ksp is equal to the product of the concentration of the ions produced to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients.

child_mcqs.description: The relationship between [H+] and solubility is
child_mcqs.explanation: As [H+] increases, solubility increases, thus it is directly proportional.

child_mcqs.description: As the solubility in mol/L increases from 5.4 x 10-3 to 2.0 x 10-2 ksp will
child_mcqs.explanation: The value of the Ksp is independent of the amount of solute and the solubility.

answers.description: Increase to a certain amount and then start decreasing again

child_mcqs.description: In a lab, if we want to increase the amount of un-dissociated HIO3
child_mcqs.explanation: Adding HCl will increase the concentration of H+ ions, thus pushing the equilibrium to the right to produce more un-dissociated HIO3.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
Cancer involves dysregulation of the cell cycle, such that the neoplastic (cancerous) cells are driven to divide above and beyond their surrounding normal cells. This dysregulation occurs through the acquisition of mutations in genes that control the cell cycle.

Tumour suppressor genes include genes that prevent the progression of the cell through the growth cycle when the cell is not fit to divide. In contrast, oncogenes are genes that signal the cell to undergo cell division. An example of these includes growth factors.

child_mcqs.description: The cells in lung cancer proliferate by:
child_mcqs.explanation: Cancer cells divide by mitosis, as they produce cells with the same number of chromosomes.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above information, for a cell to become cancerous it must:
child_mcqs.explanation: For a cell to become cancerous it must acquire gain of function mutations in the genes that drive cell proliferation so that they become constitutively activated (oncogenes). It must also acquire loss of function mutations in the tumour suppressor genes, which prevent the cell cycle from continuing when there are mistakes in DNA.

answers.description: Acquire mutations in tumour suppressor genes only
Acquire mutations in both tumour suppressor genes and oncogenes
Either acquire mutations in tumour suppressor genes or oncogenes

child_mcqs.description: Human papilloma virus can infect cells of the cervix and result in cervical cancer. As part of its invasion into the host cell, the viruses, induces the cell to produce proteins to drive the cervical cells to proliferate. These proteins inhibit p53 and Rb. From this information, we can conclude that p53 and Rb are:
child_mcqs.explanation: p53 and Rb normally prevent the cell from undergoing cell division.

child_mcqs.description: In some cancers, a chromosomal translocation takes place such that gene x is placed in front of the promoter region of another gene that is constantly being transcribed and translated. If this translocation causes the cell to divide, gene x must be a(n):
child_mcqs.explanation: If a gene is constantly being expressed causing a cell to divide, it must be an oncogene.

child_mcqs.description: The correct order of the phases of mitosis includes:
child_mcqs.explanation: The correct order is from prophase to metaphase to anaphase and finally to Telophase.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Hypophosphataemia rickets is a genetic disorder that causes short stature and bow leggedness. It is caused by a mutation in a gene that encodes the PHEX protein. The normal role of this protein is to inhibit phosphatonins, which promote phosphate excretion. This results in excess excretion of phosphate, which impairs bone mineralisation.

A pedigree of a family with this genetic disorder is shown below.  Affected individuals are shaded.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above pedigree, hypophosphataemia rickets cannot be:
child_mcqs.explanation: Hypophosphataemia rickets cannot be X-linked recessive because not all affected females have an affected father.

child_mcqs.description: What supports this trait being X-linked dominant?
child_mcqs.explanation: A father with the trait will pass on his X chromosome to all of his daughters. Because the trait is dominant, they too will have the trait.

answers.description: All females of an affected father are affected.
Both males and females of an affected mother are affected.
All males of an affected mother are affected
Both males and females of an affected father are affected.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not true about autosomal recessive inheritance?
child_mcqs.explanation: Because the trait is autosomal, the sex of the parents and children do not influence whether or not they will be affected by the trait.

answers.description: 25% of offspring from 2 carrier parents are affected
They are often due to deficiencies in enzymes
They may only be seen in one generation

child_mcqs.description: When a zygote is fertilised, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote originates from the egg. The mitochondrial DNA of the sperm is not found in the zygote. Based on this information, which of the following is true regarding defects due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since the mitochondrial DNA is inherited via the maternal line, all offspring of any couple will get their mitochondria from their mother. Therefore, if the mother is affected by a defect in mitochondrial DNA, all offspring will also inherit this gene.

answers.description: They are inherited from the mother or the father
All offspring of affected females tend to show the disease
All offspring of affected males tend to show the disease

child_mcqs.description: In X-linked recessive transmission?
child_mcqs.explanation: Sons inherit their X chromosome from their mothers. If the mother is a carrier, there is a 50% chance she will pass the X chromosome with the trait to the son. Because males only have one X chromosome, the son will demonstrate the trait.

answers.description: Daughters of affected fathers will have the condition
Sons of affected fathers will have the condition
Daughters of heterozygous mothers have a 50% chance of being affected
Sons of heterozygous mothers have a 50% chance of being affected

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description:
Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of a substance. Within gases, temperature can be related to the root mean square speed with the following equation.


R is the gas constant (8.31 J/molˑK); T is the absolute temperature (Kelvin = °C + 273), and M is the molar mass. Note: J = kgˑm2/s2

child_mcqs.description: What is the approximate root mean square speed of oxygen particles at room temperature (25°C)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Remember that oxygen is a diatomic gas, hence the molar mass is 0.032 kg/mol

child_mcqs.description: If the distribution of speeds of gas particle can be closely approximated to a normal (bell-shape curve, what is the relationship between the most probable speed and the root mean square speed?
child_mcqs.explanation: Higher speeds contribute non-linearly to the energy of the system, which governs the root-mean-square velocity of gas particles.

answers.description: The root mean square speed is larger.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description: The above diagram describes the phase changes of water.

child_mcqs.description: Which phases do A, B and C represent?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is apparent as A, B and C corresponds to the segments of the graph that connects to form the triple point.)

child_mcqs.description: What form does water take at 0.1°C and 0.5kPa?
Point D is the triple point, where all three phases of water exist simultaneously. If a slight increase in pressure occurs from this point, what phase would water take?
child_mcqs.explanation: slight increase in pressure will shift towards the positive y direction.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description: A motorist heads north for 30 min at 80 km/hr, screeches to a halt, looks over his map for 10 minutes, then heads east for 48 min at 100 km/hr and collides into a tree.

child_mcqs.description: What was his average speed?
What was his average velocity?

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description: For the frictionless and stationary pulley shown in the figure below, answer the following

child_mcqs.description: The mass of M1 is greater than M2, True or False?
child_mcqs.explanation: The question stated the pulley was stationary , thus the forces must balance

child_mcqs.description: If FA, FB and FC represent the tension for in the rope at points A,B and C respectively, which of the following is true?
child_mcqs.explanation: Tension force in the string is equal at all points throughout the string

child_mcqs.description: If the mass of M1 is 200g, what is the tension force at B?
child_mcqs.explanation: Tension force at B is simply equal to gravity. So Ft = mg = 0.2 * 10 kg m/s2 = 2N

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description: The following figure is of a 200g block been pushed against a vertical wall. The block is at rest 5m off the ground. Refer to the figure to answer the following questions
stem_mcq.tag: PHY03 Newton's Laws and Types of Forces

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following Force diagrams correctly depicts the forces acting on the block? Where FP is the push force, Ff is the force due to friction, FN is the normal force and Fg is the force due to gravity.
child_mcqs.explanation: Normal Force is always perpendicular to the surface and friction always acts against motion. Thus answer must be A.

child_mcqs.description: If the angle θ is equal to 30° find the magnitude of the normal force.
child_mcqs.explanation: The normal force must be equal to the horizontal component of the push force. Thus  FN = sin(θ) * FP = 0.5 * 12 = 6N

child_mcqs.description: How long would it take the block to reach the ground if the Force due to friction was only 7N?
child_mcqs.explanation:
1. First we need to find the net Force.

Fnet=Ff-(Fg+Fpx)

Fnet=7 - ( 2+ 6)= -1N

Find the Acceleration

a = Fnet/m =  -(1N/0.2) = -5m/s2

Now find Time to Travel down the Wall   

s = ut + 1/2 at2

s = 0t + 1/2 at2

√(2s/a) = t

t = √((2*5)/5) = 1.6s

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true for an isolated system?
child_mcqs.explanation: For an isolated system the change in internal energy must be zero.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
This diagram shows lung volumes during breathing

ERV = Expiratory reserve volume

TV = Tidal volume

IRV = Inspiratory reserve volume

VC = Vital capacity

FRC = Functional residual capacity

TLC = Total lung capacity

IC = inspiratory capacity

 

Note that a capacity is a sum of ≥2 volumes.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the graph, the residual volume:
child_mcqs.explanation: The residual volume refers to the volume left in the lung after complete expiration. It can be calculated by the total lung capacity minus the vital capacity of the lung.

answers.description: is the volume of air left in the lungs during tidal breathing

child_mcqs.description: Vital capacity is equal to:
child_mcqs.explanation: This question is testing whether you understand the diagram of lung volumes and capacities. Refer to the diagram for a visual representation of these equations.

answers.description: Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume + expiratory reserve volume

child_mcqs.description: The functional residual capacity  =
child_mcqs.explanation: This question is testing whether you understand the diagram of lung volumes and capacities. Refer to the diagram for a visual representation of these equations.

answers.description: The volume of air left in the lungs after the inspiration phase of tidal breathing

child_mcqs.description: A person may have a reduced vital capacity due to a decreased in compliance of the lung. In relation to lung compliance:
child_mcqs.explanation: Elastic forces within the lung cause an increase in the propensity of the lung to collapse on itself. Therefore, these elastic forces decrease lung compliance. Surfactant reduces the surface tension of water within the lung and therefore increases the compliance of the lung.

answers.description: It is decreased by the elastic forces within the lung

child_mcqs.description:
The physiologic dead space of the lung refers to the volume of inspired air that does not take part in gas exchange. It can be calculated by:

VD = physiologic dead space

VT = tidal volume

PaCO2 = arterial PCO2

PeCO2 = expired air PCO2

The physiologic dead space equals:
child_mcqs.explanation: The physiologic dead space refers to volume of gas in the lung that does not take part in gas exchange. Therefore, it refers to both the anatomical dead space in the conducting airways, the functional dead space in the alveoli.

answers.description: The anatomical dead space of conducting airways plus the functional dead space in alveoli
Just the anatomical dead space of conducting airways
Just the functional dead space in the alveoli

child_mcqs.description: If the tidal volume decreased, the physiologic dead space would:
child_mcqs.explanation: As you can see in the equation, the physiologic dead space is proportional to the tidal volume. Therefore, if the tidal volume decreases, so too does the physiologic dead space.

child_mcqs.description: Using a snorkel would:
child_mcqs.explanation: A snorkel essentially extends the conducting system, and therefore increases the physiological dead space.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
The pancreas is a comma-shaped accessory organ of the gastrointestinal system. It connects to the gastrointestinal system via the main pancreatic duct and empties into the duodenum. The pancreas serves as both an exocrine and an endocrine organ. Its exocrine function involves the secretion of bicarbonate and a suite of enzymes involved in digestion, including amylase, peptidases and lipase.

The peptidases of the pancreas are shown in the diagram below: 

The pancreas’ endocrine function involves the release of glucagon and insulin to control blood sugar level.  Insulin is released after the intake of a meal, whereas glucagon is released during period of starvation.

child_mcqs.description: Absorption of which of the following will be affected by pancreatic insufficiency (inability of the pancreas to perform its exocrine function)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Absorption of vitamin K will be affected. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin and is only absorbed if there is proper digestion of fat. The other vitamins are water-soluble and can be absorbed freely.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not true regarding pancreatic function?
child_mcqs.explanation: Insulin is an endocrine hormone. Therefore it is not released into the pancreatic duct but into the bloodstream.

answers.description: It depends on the Na+-K+-ATPase pump on the basolateral surface
It releases insulin into the pancreatic duct
Most of the pancreatic mass is involved in its exocrine function
Enzymes are released as inactive substances called zymogens

child_mcqs.description: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disease that results in dysfunction of the chloride transporter, CFTR, and Cl- cannot be transported into the lumen of the pancreatic duct. This results in:
child_mcqs.explanation: In cystic fibrosis, chloride ions cannot be transported into the pancreatic ducts. Therefore, sodium is not attracted into the lumen and water does not follow. This results in a thick mucus that blocks the ducts, and the enzymes of the pancreas start to digest the substance of the pancreas. This leads to pancreatic insufficiency.

answers.description: Decreased movement of Na+ and water into the pancreatic duct

child_mcqs.description: Regarding the pancreatic enzymes released during digestion, a lack of which will have the greatest effect on protein digestion:
child_mcqs.explanation: Refer to the diagram. Trypsin is the activated form of trypsinogen. It is the enzyme required for activation of the other zymogens. The conversion of trypsinogen to trypsin relies on enterokinase. For this reason the absence of trypsinogen and enterokinase will have the same and greatest effect on protein digestion.

child_mcqs.description: Insulin
child_mcqs.explanation: Insulin acts to decrease blood glucose. One of the ways it does this is by stimulating protein synthesis, which uses up ATP. Glucose is then used to replenish this ATP. Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, and gluconeogenesis is the formation of new glucose from other molecules. Both of these would raise blood glucose levels. Note that insulin does not cause excretion of glucose into the urine.

answers.description: Increases the level of glucose in the urine

child_mcqs.description: Steatorrhoea (fatty stools) can occur due to pancreatic insufficiency. This is most likely due to loss of:
child_mcqs.explanation: Lipase is the enzyme responsible for the digestion of fat, and therefore a lack of lipase will result in fat in the stools. Bile salts come from the liver and are used to emulsify fats.

child_mcqs.description: Glucagon has a similar action to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Glucagon has a similar action to cortisol and adrenaline. Both of these are stress hormones, and act to raise the level of blood glucose in times of need.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
A phase diagram is a plot of the changes in the phase of a material as a function of temperature and pressure.

The first figure represents the phase diagram of carbon dioxide, while the second represents that of water. A, B and E represent solid, liquid and gas respectively. D is called the triple point, where all phases exist in equilibrium. C is the critical temperature after which the gas cannot be liquefied regardless of the pressures applied.

child_mcqs.description: The positive slope XY in figure 1 is indicative that
child_mcqs.explanation: As pressure increases, (increasing the Y value) water changes from solid to liquid. Thus water in the liquid phase is denser than in the solid phase.

answers.description: Water in the solid phase is more dense than water in the liquid phase
Water in the liquid phase is more dense than water in the solid phase
Water is more resistant to change when in the solid phase than when in the liquid phase
Water is more resistant to change when in the liquid phase than when in the solid phase

child_mcqs.description: At temperatures and pressures beyond point C in figure 1
child_mcqs.explanation: No difference can be made between a gas and a liquid above the critical point; the supercritical state is homogeneous in terms of physical properties.

answers.description: carbon dioxide exists as a combination of solid liquid and gas
carbon dioxide exists as a combination between liquid and gas
The gas and liquid phase of carbon dioxide cannot be distinguished

child_mcqs.description: According to figure 1 as the pressure increases, the sublimation point of carbon dioxide
child_mcqs.explanation: As indicated by the graph, as pressure is increased, a higher temperature is required in order for CO2 to undergo sublimation – thus the sublimation point is increasing.

child_mcqs.description:
In the graph below, isotherms for water are plotted against pressure and volume. 

The area in the dashed lines on the graph represent what region in the phase diagram of water (Figure 2) above
child_mcqs.explanation: The line between D and C indicates the junction between liquid and vapour phases. At this two phase condition (below the dotted line on the isotherm graph) a small amount of additional pressure will result in a large reduction in volume since the gas phase is compressible.

child_mcqs.description:
The graph below compares the density of a material X in liquid phase with its vapour phase.

From this graph it could be concluded that 375 is
child_mcqs.explanation: At zero degrees, and at low and high pressure, material X is in the vapour and liquid phases, respectively. As temperature is increased 375oC, these phases become indistinguishable – representing the critical point.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description: The equilibrium reaction below shows Mond process of the purification of Nickel

child_mcqs.description: The purification of Nickel is considered
child_mcqs.explanation: . Using the equation for Gibbs free energy: ΔG = -160.8 kJ – (-122.03kJ) = -38.77 kJ. A negative Gibbs free energy indicates a spontaneous reaction, thus the forward reaction is favoured.

answers.description: A nonspontaneous reaction and the backward reaction is favoured
An equation in equilibrium where the forward and the backward reactions cancel each other
An endothermic reaction that needs very high temperatures to initiate
A spontaneous reaction and the forward reaction is the favoured reaction

child_mcqs.description: The ΔHf of Ni (s) is
child_mcqs.explanation: By definition, the standard enthalpy of formation of the most stable form of Nickel is zero because there is no formation reaction needed when Nickel is already in its standard state.

child_mcqs.description: What is the approximate change in Gibb’s free energy of reaction 1 at 100C ?
child_mcqs.explanation: Use the same initial equation, with 373K as the temperature.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following graphs best represents Nickel purification
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the negative enthalpy, the reaction is exothermic.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
The heart is a four-chambered pump that pumps blood throughout the body. There are two atria, two ventricles and the vessels that return blood to the heart (veins), and those that take it away from the heart (arteries).

Certain structural problems can occur in the heart in infancy resulting in problems. 

One such condition is the tetralogy of Fallot. Two features of this include pulmonary stenosis, which is narrowing  of the pulmonary artery and a ventricular septal defect, such that there is an abnormal connection between the two ventricles.

Another condition is transposition of the great vessels, in which the aorta leaves from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery leaves from the left ventricle.

A final condition is patent ductus arteriosus in which there is a persistent connection between the pulmonary artery and the aorta.

child_mcqs.description: The flow of blood in someone with transpition of the great vessels would be:
