child_mcqs.explanation: In transposition of the great vessels, blood will return to the heart via the vena cavae, which will then pass through the right atrium to the right ventricle and pumped out of the aorta to the systemic capillaries. This circuit will never pump blood to the heart.

answers.description: Vena cavae --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> pulmonary artery --> pulmonary vein --> left atrium --> left ventricle --> aorta
Vena cavae --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> aorta
Vena cavae --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> aorta --> pulmonary vein --> left atrium --> left ventricle --> aorta
Vena cavae --> left atrium --> left ventricle --> pulmonary artery --> pulmonary vein --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> aorta

child_mcqs.description: If somone suffered from transposition of the great vessels, it would be beneficial to also have:
child_mcqs.explanation: A patent ductus arteriosus would allow a connection between the systemic and the pulmonary circuits and thereby allow some oxygenation of the blood in the circuit described in section 1.

child_mcqs.description: The arterial oxygen content of a person with tetralogy of Fallot is likely to be what in relation to a person with a normally developed heart:
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the ventricular septal defect, blood from the left side of the heart will be shunted into the right side of the heart. This will cause a decrease in the oxygenation of the blood.

answers.description: There is not enough information to determine this.

child_mcqs.description: Pulmonary stenosis is likely to result in:
child_mcqs.explanation: To generate enough flow through the stenosed pulmonary artery, higher pressure must be generated in the right ventricle. This in turn will lead to high pressure in the atrium.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
The primary purpose of the circulation is to provide adequate blood flow to organs. For this to occur, blood pressure must be maintained at a certain level.

Mean arterial pressure = total peripheral resistance x cardiac output

child_mcqs.description: Blood pressure is predominantly maintained by the baroreflex. A fall in blood pressure:
child_mcqs.explanation: A fall in blood pressure will cause an activation of the sympathetic nervous system. One of the responses of this is an increase in noradrenaline release onto the b-receptors in the heart, which will cause an increase in heart rate. This will act to increase cardiac output and therefore increase mean arterial pressure.

answers.description: Causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in arterioles
Increases noradrenaline release on to beta-receptors in the heart

child_mcqs.description: Organs need more blood when they are metabolically active, and therefore arterials in metabolically active organs dilate. This does not occur is in response to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Arterioles dilate in response to high CO2, as this is a marker of cells being metabolically active, thereby requiring higher blood flow for oxygen and nutrients.

child_mcqs.description: In extreme exercise, the need to lose heat competes with the need to maintain blood pressure. This is because:
child_mcqs.explanation: All of the answers are true. Humans vasodilate arteriole skin to carry more blood to the skin so heat can be lost, and sweat to lose heat via evaporation. In addition, arterioles supplying muscles vasodilate. All of these will cause a decrease in blood pressure

answers.description: Humans lose heat by vasodilating the arteriolar supply to the skin
Humans lose heat by sweating, which can reduce intravascular volume
During exercise, muscle metabolites cause local arteriolar dilatation of blood vessels

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
A 300g ball sits on an inclined plane 2m off the ground. When the ball is released it collides and sticks with a 600g ball at the bottom of the slope. The friction along the ground is equal to 2N.

Now answer the following

child_mcqs.description: What is the velocity of the two balls after the collision?
child_mcqs.explanation:
1. The momentum before is simply

Pi=m1 v1+m2 v2=m1 v1+m2 0

Pi=0.3* v1

 

Need to find  v1 through conservation of energy.

mgh = 1/2 mv2

v = √2gh = √(2*10*2) = √40

Pi = 0.3 * √40

Now find momentum afterwards

Pf = Pi = (m1+m2 ) v2

 (0.3* √40) / (m1+m2 ) = v2

 (0.3* √40) / (0.3+0.6)  = v2

v = 1.5ms-2

child_mcqs.description: How far do the two balls continue to travel after the collision?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Need to find the acceleration of the two balls.

a = Ff / (m1+ m2) = -2 / 0.9 = 2.2ms-2

Now find the displacement

v2 = u2+2as

s = (v2-u2) / 2a =  (0-1.52) / (2* -2.2) = 0.5m

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description: Ricky Ponting hits an oncoming ball travelling at 20 m s-1 with his cricket bat, clearing the ball for 6 runs. If the closest distance to the edge of the pitch is 150 m, his initial trajectory is 30° above the horizontal, his contact time with the ball was 0.005 s, and the mass of the ball was 0.16 kg

child_mcqs.description: Do achieve this shot, what was the minimum forced needed?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Force, and the related acceleration, can be calculated from the impulse formula. We need to take into account the vector nature of velocity, so the initial velocity before the impact is negative as it's in the opposite direction to the final velocity.

To solve for the final velocity, we need to decompose the velocity into horizontal and vertical components, and then solve using the linear motion equations

Horizontal: This is the time that it will take the ball to cover the 150m from the pitch to the boundary.

Vertical: For the ball to land on the boundary, it will have a displacement of s = 0 at time t = 150/v_h 

Substituting this back into the Force equation gives

child_mcqs.description: Ricky Ponting will also feel the same amount of force on his hands. Which of Newton’s laws is being applied
child_mcqs.explanation:
A. 1st Law – that an objects velocity will not change until perturbed by a force, which doesn't apply to the force on Pontings hands

B. 2nd Law – Force = mass * acceleration – doesn't apply to this case

C. 3rd Law – Every force has an equal and opposite reaction, which is correct, as the reaction force on Pontings hands is a response to the force exerted on the bat, which in turn applied the force to the ball.

D. None of the above – No, C is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
There are receptors in muscle that sense muscle length and force. These receptors send information to the CNS via sensory neuron, which then either activate somatic motor neurons to muscle fibres (contraction) or activates inhibit neurons to inhibit the somatic motor neurons.

Muscle spindles are called stretch receptors, and exist as small elongated structures scattered among and arranged parallel to the contractile extrafusal muscle fibres. They are activated when the length of the muscle changes.

Golgi tendon organs are diffuse nerve endings scattered between the collagen fibres of the muscle tendon. They are arranged in series to the extrafusal muscle fibres, and act to regulate the force of the muscle contraction. Therefore when they are activated more, the contraction of the muscle will decrease to keep the force constant within the muscle.

child_mcqs.description: In regards to skeletal muscle reflexes:
child_mcqs.explanation: Excitation of somatic motor neurons always causes contraction in skeletal muscle. No neurons directly inhibit the contraction of muscles.

answers.description: Muscle spindles are the only receptors found in muscles
Golgi tendon organs sense the length of the muscle fibres.
Excitation of somatic motor neurons always causes contraction in skeletal muscle

child_mcqs.description: One consequence of muscle spindles being in parallel to the extrafusal muscle fibres are that, when the extrafusal muscle fibres contact:
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the parallel nature of spindle fibres and extrafusal muscle fibres, when the extrafusal muscle fibres contract, this would cause slackening of the spindle fibre. This means that the spindle fibre will no longer be able to sense the true length of the muscle. Therefore it must contract to maintain sensitivity to unexpected changes in length/stretch of the muscle.

answers.description: The length of the spindle does not change
The muscle spindle fibres must contract as well so that it maintains its sensitivity to changes in stretch
Spindle fibres will contract independently of extrafusal muscle fibres

child_mcqs.description: The knee jerk reflex involves tapping the quadriceps with a tendon hammer, causing the knee to extend. This reflex would be initiated by
child_mcqs.explanation: The knee jerk reflex causes stretching of the muscle fibres, which therefore cause spindle fibres to length. The response is to shorten the muscle fibre, which keeps the length of the muscle relatively constant.

child_mcqs.description: In the knee jerk reflex:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the knee jerk reflex, the knee extends. For this to occur, the quadriceps muscle in the anterior thigh must contract, and the hamstring muscles in the posterior thigh must relax.

child_mcqs.description: When a muscle fatigues, and the force it generates decreases:
child_mcqs.explanation: When a muscle fatigues, the force it generates will be decreasing. This will lead to decreased activation of the Golgi Tendon Organ. Therefore to keep the force constant, the Golgi Tendon Organ will be stimulated less, leading the muscle to contract more forcefully.

answers.description: Golgi tendon organs are more activated to increase muscle contraction
Golgi tendon organs are more activated to decrease muscle contraction
Golgi tendon organs are less activated to increase muscle contraction
Golgi tendon organs are less activated to decrease muscle contraction.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true regarding muscle contraction:
child_mcqs.explanation: In sarcomeric contraction, the movement of actin relatively to myosin occurs via the formation of cross-bridges between actin and myosin. Note that muscles are only innervated by activating neurons, and are dependent on calcium influx for muscle contraction.

answers.description: It depends on magnesium influx from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
It involves the formation of cross-bridges between actin and myosin
Muscles are innervated by activating and inhibitory neurons

child_mcqs.description: By definition, a reflex:
child_mcqs.explanation: The spinal cord is required for integrating sensory information and initiating the motor response. Therefore a reflex must involve the CNS.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21
stem_mcq.description:
The neuromuscular junction is the site where a motor neuron synapses with a muscle fibre. An action potential travels down the axon of the motor neuron, causing release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine then diffuses across the synaptic cleft, binds to its receptor and initiates depolarisation of the muscle fibre.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease of the neuromuscular junction. It leads to progressive muscular weakness due to the production of antibodies that target nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

child_mcqs.description: In myasthenia gravis, the antibodies must be binding receptors:
child_mcqs.explanation: In synaptic transmission, acetylcholine is released by synaptic vesicles into the synaptic cleft. The acetylcholine then diffuses across the cleft and binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on the post-synaptic membrane.

answers.description: In the vesicles of the pre-synaptic neuron

child_mcqs.description: In myasthenia gravis, the antibodies act as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Since the antibodies are causing muscle weakness, they must be acting as antagonists of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

child_mcqs.description: The symptoms of myasthenia gravis could be overcome by:
child_mcqs.explanation: Giving an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor will shut down the enzyme that degrades acetylcholine, so there would be a higher level of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft per action potential of the neuron. The result of this is that the ACh would then displace some of the antibodies by competitive inhibition, allowing some of the channels to open.

answers.description: Giving the person blood from patient without myasthenia gravis

child_mcqs.description: When an action potential is initiated in a motor neuron:
child_mcqs.explanation: As with any action potential, when a neuron is stimulated, voltage-gated sodium channels open at the nodes of Ranvier to cause depolarisation, which travels down the neuron.

answers.description: Calcium ions cause the action potential to propagate down the neuron
There is a change in the conductance of ions at the nodes of Ranvier
The conductance of ions does not change.

child_mcqs.description: If the antibodies of someone with myasthenia gravis were injected into someone without myasthenia gravis:
child_mcqs.explanation: In autoimmune conditions, the cell’s immune system generates immune responses that are targeted to self. Because the person that is receiving the antibodies would not be continuously making these antibodies, they would only experience a transient muscle weakness as the antibodies would eventually be degraded.

answers.description: The person would experience transient muscle weakness
The person would experience permanent muscle weakness
The person would not experience muscle weakness
The person’s muscle weakness would come and go.

child_mcqs.description: The development of myasthenia gravis is dependent on:
child_mcqs.explanation: The generation of pathogenic antibodies requires B cells to differentiate into plasma cells to produce the antibodies, and CD4+ T helper cells to provide the B cells with the ‘help’ to make the antibodies.

child_mcqs.description: Another autoimmune disease is multiple sclerosis, which causes ‘demyelination’ of neurons. The outcome of this disease would be:
child_mcqs.explanation: Myelin is predominantly a lipid substance that coats the axon of nerves, and prevents current leak across the neuron cell membrane. Its role is to speed up the transmission of the axon potential down the axon. Therefore, in multiple sclerosis, transmission of the action potential down the axon is essentially slowed without the effect of myelin.

answers.description: The inability to generate an action potential
The inability of a nerve to signal to a muscle cell to contract
The slowing of transmission down a nerve axon
The inability of the nerve to conduct potassium ions

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
The rate law for a chemical reaction is an equation that links the reaction rate with concentrations or pressures of reactants and constant parameters. To determine the rate equation for a particular system one combines the reaction rate with a mass balance for the system.

The reaction rate for a given reaction 2A + B --> C is: 

A reaction 2 NO2 + F2 --> 2NO2F was conducted 3 times with different initial concentration of reactants. 

The table below shows the 3 different initial rates of the overall reaction.

Where A is NO2 and B is F2

Molarity in mol/L and rate in M/sec

 

The Equilibrium constant on the other hand is the ratio of the equilibrium concentrations of the products raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients to the equilibrium concentrations of the reactants raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients.

child_mcqs.description: What is the rate constant K of this reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: By comparing the different initial reaction rates, the reaction appears to be first order. By rearranging the formula, the rate constant = 0.1 sec-1.

child_mcqs.description: The graph that best displays the above overall reaction would be:
child_mcqs.explanation: Graph III pictures a first order reaction.

child_mcqs.description: In the above reaction if the rate of step 1 is “X” and that of step 2 is “Y” where step 1 is much slower than step 2, then the rate of the overall reaction would be:
child_mcqs.explanation: The slower step is the rate limiting step in a two-step reaction, thus X determines the overall rate.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true concerning a reaction that starts from reactants only and commence to equilibrium?
child_mcqs.explanation: For the two reactions to reach equilibrium – occurring at equal rates, the forward reaction will have to decrease after its initial rate whilst the backward reaction increases.

answers.description: The rate of the forward reaction decreases while the rate of the backward reaction increases until equilibrium is reached
The rate of the forward reaction increases while the rate of the backward reaction decreases until equilibrium is reached
Both the forward and the backward reaction rates decrease until equilibrium is reached
The forward reaction keeps on increasing until no more reactants are present

child_mcqs.description: How many grams of sulphur trioxide are produced by the complete oxidation of 2 mols of Sulfur dioxide?
child_mcqs.explanation: The stoichiometry of the reaction indicates that 2 moles of sulphur dioxide oxidises to produce 2 moles of sulphur trioxide. SO3 weighs 80g/mol, so 2 moles weighs 2*80 = 160g

child_mcqs.description: What is the percent by mass of Sulfur in SO2?
child_mcqs.explanation: Sulphur dioxide is made up of 32g/mol of sulphur, and (16 x 2)g/mol sulphur. Thus, 50% is sulphur.

child_mcqs.description: What is the limiting reagent when 32g of sulphur dioxide form 20g of sulphur trioxide in a reaction that runs to completion.
child_mcqs.explanation: Since 32g SO2 can react with excess O2 to form 32g of SO3, if only 20g SO3 is formed, the oxygen must be the limiting reagent.

child_mcqs.explanation: H2SO4 is a polyprotic acid, meaning that it has two pKa values referring to the dissociation of each of its protons (H+). The smaller the value of the pKa, the larger the extent of dissociation – and the stronger the acid – thus the pKa values of -2 and 1.92 refer to H2SO­4 and HSO4-, respectively.

child_mcqs.description: A sample of rain water is tested with thymol blue and results in a yellow colour. And the addition of methyl orange to another sample of the same water results in a red colour. What is the PH of this water?
child_mcqs.explanation: The yellow region of thymol blue is >2.8, and the red region of methyl orange is <3.2, thus the pH must lie between 2.8 and 3.2.

child_mcqs.description: What is the oxidation state of Sulfur in H2SO4 and HSO3- respectively?
child_mcqs.explanation: H2SO4 is made up of +2 (2 x H) and -8 (4 x O), thus sulphur is +6. HSO3- is made up of +1 (1 x H) and -6 (3 x O), thus sulphur is +5.

child_mcqs.explanation: Since sulphuric acid is a diprotic acid, it’s reaction with sodium hydroxide takes place in two reactions leading to an equivalence point for the donation of each of the two protons. The pH of the solution should start near 1 prior to the addition of any base.

title: Exam 3
instruction:
This GradReady Practice Exam is meant to test your ability to take the GAMSAT. The idea behind this exam is to help you assess what you have learned and where you may still be struggling. You will get the best results from this exam if you treat it as if it were the actual GAMSAT.

Upon completion of the exam you will be able to see your score.

Today’s Exam consists of 3 Sections:

Section 1: Reasoning in Humanities and Social Sciences (10 min reading time + 1 hr 40 min)

Section 2: Written Communication - Essay (5 min reading time + 1 hr) - you may submit these essays through the Essays tab (if you had purchased essay marking), if you wish to have them marked. You may pick topics from the Essays tab or from our course book.

Lunch Break (1 hr)

Section 3: Reasoning in Biological & Physical Sciences (10 minute reading time + 2 hr 50 min)

Good luck!

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
The follow passage explores naturopathy; the study of natural medicine.

Like medical doctors, naturopaths must undergo considerable training before they are allowed to receive their Doctor of Naturopathy (N.D.). To pursue a career in naturopathic medicine, a baccalaureate degree or at least the minimum of 3 years (15 full courses), is required before applying for the four-year doctoral degree. In some institutions, entrance requirements also include an essay, two reference letters, an autobiographical sketch and a personal interview, much like the Ontario medical schools. While many institutions of naturopathy are located in the United States, two institutions can be found in Canada: the Boucher Institute of Naturopathic Medicine in New Westminster, BC and the Canadian College of Naturopathic Medicine (CCNM) in North York, Ontario. However, the CCNM is the country’s only accredited four-year training program. At this institution, the first two years are spent studying anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, pathology, pharmacology, and natural therapies. The next two years focus on clinical training in diagnosis and natural treatment modalities. Tuition at the CCNM for the 2002-2003 academic year was $15,175 for first-year domestic students, only slightly less than medical school tuition for the University of Toronto.

 

Efficacy of Treatments

The NIH National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) has a website  (http://nccam.nih.gov) which provides evidence for and against a variety of alternative remedies. Despite the increased demand for CAM, there are few high quality studies that provide evidence  for their effectiveness. In this article, we will highlight the use of two popular herbal remedies: red clover and garlic. With the early termination of one of the trial arms of the Women’s Health Initiative evaluating hormone replacement therapy, many women may now be  considering using alternatives to conventional medicine to manage menopausal symptoms. One of the alternatives prescribed by naturopaths may include red clover (Trifolium pratense) which has been shown to contain plant estrogens or phytoestrogens. The class of phytoestrogens in red clover are the isoflavones, which are plant sterols also found in soybeans (albeit to a lesser  degree). Their effect is believed to be exerted by possessing structural similarities to human estrogens and thus, when taken in large quantities, may show estrogenic activity. A study conducted in the Netherlands showed that red clover may have some actual therapeutic benefit. 

In a randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled trial, van de Weijer and Burentsen demonstrated that the isoflavones from red clover significantly reduced menopausal hot flush symptoms by 44%. However, the trial was rather small with only thirty participants and it lasted for only 12 weeks. A more comprehensive study examining the benefits derived from red clover in addition to its potential toxicity is currently being conducted by the NCCAM. Thus, for the time being, the prescription of red clover by naturopaths for the treatment of hot flushes may be valid. The naturopath would most likely combine the herbal prescription with dietary and lifestyle modification advice.

The use of garlic has gradually become more popular for the treatment of cardiovascular disease.  Of the nearly 100 chemicals in garlic, the most important appears to be allicin, an amino acid containing sulfur, which is formed when cloves are crushed. In rat hepatocytes, garlic was shown to inhibit the activity of the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, the primary enzyme responsible for synthesizing cholesterol. However, a report examining garlic use and its effects on the risk of cardiovascular disease concluded that “there are insufficient data to draw conclusions regarding garlic’s effects on clinical cardiovascular outcomes such as myocardial infarction.” Garlic preparations failed to show consistent reductions in blood pressure, had no effects on glucose or insulin sensitivity, and showed only small, positive effects on cholesterol levels. Thus, garlic pills do not appear to have the beneficial effects that many consumers believe. In addition, garlic has several side effects such as bad breath, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux. It may reduce blood clotting so it should be taken with caution in patients who are on blood thinning agents. Thus, at the current time, garlic should only be used as a supplement to treatments of proven cardiac risk reduction benefit, such as regular exercise, weight control, tobacco avoidance, and a good diet.

child_mcqs.description: The early section of the passage, the author:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is correct; the author spends the first paragraph demonstrating how many of the important characteristics of a medicine degree are also required to attain a natural medicine degree. Both medical training and natropathy training are shown as involving hard work and a long period of study. The long period of study for conventional medicine is similarly is required for natural medicine. Option B and D are incorrect because the text does not refer to practicing either type of medicine, only studying and the admissions process. Option C is incorrect because whilst the text does say that the admissions scheme for traditional medicine is similar to that of naturopathy, it does not outline the specific steps themselves.

answers.description: Elucidates the pedagogical agenda of natural medicine as opposed to traditional medicine.
Compares the checks and processes of practicing natural medicine to those of traditional medicine.
Clarifies the designated steps to becoming a practicing traditional doctor.
Sees the two as compatible when practiced in conjunction.

child_mcqs.description: Red clover’s effectiveness is due to
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that red clover's 'effect is believed to be exerted by possessing structural similarities to human estrogens and thus, when taken in large quantities, may show estrogenic activity'. This aligns with C. B is not mentioned, and A and D are too general

answers.description: The fact that it is a herbal remedy

child_mcqs.description: A crucial issue with the blind, placebo-controlled study on red clover’s effectiveness is
child_mcqs.explanation: Following its mention of the trial, the article states that 'the trial was rather small with only thirty participants and it lasted for only 12 weeks'. This is represented by answer C.  A, B and D are too general as responses and are not specifically mentioned

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

A less toxic therapy for older patients with AML would be of great benefit. Antibody-targeted chemotherapy is expected to be less toxic than conventional chemotherapy and has been developed for the treatment of CD33-positive AML. The antibody-targeted chemotherapy Mylotarg consists of a humanized anti-CD33 monoclonal antibody conjugated to calicheamicin, a highly potent antitumor antibiotic that cleaves double-stranded DNA at specific sequences. Approximately 90% of AML patients have myeloid blast cells that express the CD33 surface antigen. This antigen is present on normal hematopoietic progenitor cells but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells or on nonhematopoietic cells. It also is present on the leukemic stem cells of at least some AML patients. Thus, Mylotarg is targeted treatment for patients with CD33-positive AML because the antibody component of the molecule targets calicheamicin, the cytotoxic component, to CD33-positive cells. In a phase I dose-escalation trial with relapsed or refractory CD33-positive AML patients, eight of 40 (20%) patients treated with Mylotarg had leukemic blast cells eliminated from the blood and marrow. In phase II efficacy and safety trials, a preliminary report indicated that 42 of 142 (30%) patients with AML in first relapse obtained remission after treatment with two doses of Mylotarg at 9 mg/m2. Although severe myelosuppression was common, mucositis and severe infections were not. Based on these data, Mylotarg was approved in the United States for the treatment of patients with CD33-positive AML in first relapse who are 60 years of age or older and who are not considered candidates for other cytotoxic chemotherapy. Here, we specifically report data from the phase II trials on the efficacy and safety of Mylotarg in patients 60 years of age for whom it was approved. These results show that Mylotarg, as a single agent, offers an effective, well-tolerated treatment option for older patients with AML in first relapse. These 101 older patients were included among the 188 adult patients of all ages who were enrolled on the phase II clinical trials. Limited data on 80 of these older patients were included in an earlier report on the first 142 patients who were treated.

child_mcqs.description: What percentage of patients do not have the myloid blast cells which express antigens CD-33
child_mcqs.explanation: If 90% do express the antigen, as the passage states, then it follows that 10%.  The key is “B”.  The other options are not supported by the passage.

child_mcqs.description: The results of remission in phase II safety trials are
child_mcqs.explanation: Although the excerpt indicates that the remainder of the article will discuss the efficacy of the phase II trials, there is enough information to justify A. The results indicate that a positive interpretation is possible from the data, and the article implies that it is from this data that Mylotarg was approved. Hence A is the best option.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is NOT a potential reason that older aged persons were the targeted demographic for the new therapy?
child_mcqs.explanation: The question asks the reader to hypothesise a reason that the manufacturers of the drug will create a drug to target the older age market. If older persons are more likely to have the disease, or are more affected by the symptoms, they are more likely to require a cure. Similarly, if older persons have less ability to handle side effects, then they will require a drug with fewer side effects. Conversely, the fact that older persons have a shorter remaining lifespan is a reason not a reason to market a drug to them. Therefore, the answer is B

answers.description: Older persons are more likely to have AML
Older persons have fewer remaining life years
Older persons are more severely affected with the symptoms AML
Older persons are less equipped to handle drug side effects

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage explore the concept of economic geography

The study of economic geography - - of the location of factors of production in space - occupies a relatively small part of standard economic analysis. International trade theory, in particular, conventionally treats nations as dimensionless points (and frequently assumes zero transportation costs between countries as well). Admittedly, models descended from von Thünen play an important role in urban studies, while Hotelling-type models of locational competition get a reasonable degree of attention in industrial organization. On the whole, however, it seems fair to say that the study of economic geography plays at best a marginal role in economic theory. On the face of it, this neglect is surprising. The facts of economic geography are surely among the most striking features of real-world economies, at least to laymen. For example, one of the most remarkable things about the United States is that in a generally sparsely populated country, much of whose land is fertile, the bulk of the population resides in a few clusters of metropolitan areas; forty percent are crowded into a not especially inviting section of the East Coast. It has often been noted that nighttime satellite photos of Europe reveal little of political boundaries, but clearly suggest a center-periphery pattern whose hub is somewhere in or near Belgium. A laynian might have expected that these facts would play a key role in economic modelling.

Furthermore, there is a long if somewhat thin tradition in location theory, that one might have supposed would inspire the efforts of both theorists and econometricians. Indeed, several schools of thought may be identified. Best known, perhaps, is the German School, originating in the work of von Thünen (1826) but led in the twentieth century by Weber (1909), Christaller (1933), and Lösch (1940). Inspired by this German school, but less preoccupied with the geometry of location, was the American school of regional science, including Hoover (1948) and especially Isard (1956). Yet another tradition, drawing on Marshall's initial description of agglomeration due to external economies, stresses the role of externalities in producing divergent regional development; the most influential writings in this tradition are those of Myrdal (1957), Hirschmann (1958), and Perroux (1950), and this tradition has been carried on more recently by David (1984) and Arthur (1989).

child_mcqs.description: The passage opens with
child_mcqs.explanation: A is true as the passage discusses how contemporary economics fails to properly include economic geography, which the article suggests is an important factor. B is provided by the definition of economic geography as 'of the location of factors of production in space'. The contextual information is provided by discussing how economic geography first into the wider topic of economics.  Therefore, D is the option which therefore best addresses the question.

child_mcqs.description: The observations on center-periphery in the passage relate to
child_mcqs.explanation: The centre-periphery comment appears after discussion of where people live in America, with most areas sparsely populated and others densely populated. It also follows the mention of nighttime satellite photos, which are likely to relate to where people live. This supports “A”.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
Lee turned his attention to a Jewish boy named Carl Steinberg, whom he had known casually for about a year. The first time he saw Carl, Lee thought, "I could use that, if the family jewels weren't in pawn to Uncle Junk."

The boy was blond, his face thin and sharp with a few freckles, always a little pink around the ears and nose as though he had just washed. Lee had never known anyone to look as clean as Carl. With his small round brown eyes and fuzzy blond hair, he reminded Lee of a young bird.

Born in Munich, Carl had grown up in Baltimore. In manner and outlook he seemed European. He shook hands with traces of a heel-click. In general, Lee found European youths easier to talk to than Americans. The rudeness of many Americans depressed him, a rudeness based on a solid ignorance of the whole concept of manners, and on the proposition that for social purposes, all people are more or less equal and interchangeable.

What Lee looked for in any relationship was the feel of contact. He felt some contact with Carl. The boy listened politely and seemed to understand what Lee was saying. After some initial balking, he accepted the fact of Lee's sexual interest in his person. He told Lee, "Since I can't change my mind about you, I will have to change my mind about other things."

But Lee soon found out he could make no progress. "If I got this far with an American kid," he reasoned, "I could get the rest of the way. So he's not queer. People can be obliging. What is the obstacle?" Lee finally guessed the answer: "What makes it impossible is that his mother wouldn't like it." And Lee knew it was time to pack in. He recalled a homosexual Jewish friend who lived in Oklahoma City. Lee had asked, "Why do you live here? You have enough money to live anywhere you like." The reply was, "It would kill my mother if I moved away." Lee had been speechless.

One afternoon Lee was walking with Carl by the Amsterdam Avenue park. Suddenly Carl bowed slightly and shook Lee's hand. "Best of luck," he said, and ran for a streetcar. Lee stood looking after him, then walked over into the park and sat down on a concrete bench that was molded to resemble wood. Blue flowers from a blossoming tree had fallen on the bench and on the walk in front of it. Lee sat there watching the flowers move along the path in a warm spring wind. The sky was clouding up for an afternoon shower. Lee felt lonely and defeated. "I'll have to look for someone else," he thought. He covered his face with his hands. He was very tired.

He saw a shadowy line of boys. As each boy came to the front of the line, he said "Best of luck," and ran for a streetcar.

"Sorry . . . wrong number ... try again . . . somewhere else . . . someplace else . . . not here. . . not

me ... can't use it, don't need it, don't want it. Why pick on me?" The last face was so real and so

ugly, Lee said aloud, "Who asked you, you ugly son of a bitch?"

Lee opened his eyes and looked around. Two Mexican adolescents walked by, their arms around each other's necks. He looked after them, licking his dry, cracked lips. Lee continued to see Carl after that, until finally Carl said "Best of luck" for the last time, and walked away. Lee heard later he had gone with his family to Uruguay.

child_mcqs.description: The nature of the feelings Lee has for Carl is best described as
child_mcqs.explanation: The feelings Lee has for Carl are not vague or ambiguous since they are made quite obvious in the passage. Similarly, Carl makes his own feelings to Lee clear through his statement. Ambivalent would suggest that Lee is uncertain about his feelings, which is not the case. Lee is attracted to Carl but understands he cannot gain what he wishes from him. While Carl his hapy to speak to Lee, but is unflattered by his interest. The answer is therefore A, 'unrequited'.

child_mcqs.description: Lee’s attitude towards Carl’s sexuality suggests
child_mcqs.explanation: Lee's knowledge of Carl's sexuality is that they're incompatible based on Carl's heterosexual preference. Thus, D is incorrect as Lee knows that Carl is not gay. Carl's understanding reception to Lee’s proposition precludes C. Option B presents a case in which Lee would have to have an opportunity and seize it to be labeled as 'opportunistic'. As the passage suggests that Carl has no obvious, tangible shot with Lee, there is actually no opportunity to be seized. Thus, option A - indifferent is the best option. Furthermore, 'A' indicates that Lee lacks empathy/sympathy/is arrogantly pursuing Carl regardless of his heterosexuality. In this way, given the question explicitly questions Carl's ’sexuality’, this must be the correct choice.

child_mcqs.description: While Lee is arguably a predator he is ultimately depicted as
child_mcqs.explanation: Throughout the passage, the focus is on the loneliness of Lee. Lee clearly has difficulty speaking to Americans, who you would suspect are the majority of his peers. Lee also desires contact, which may be interpreted as suggesting he receives little affection from others. Although ‘licking the lips’ could indicate desperation, it is not sufficient to displace loneliness as the main characteristic, and may also further exemplify this characteristic The final part of the passage in fact makes this the primary focus.  “D” is the key.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
The name is Clem Williamson Snide.

               Another time I am working on a routine case of industrial sabotage when the factory burns down killing twenty-three people. These things happen. I am a man of the world. Going to and fro and walking up and down in it.

               Death smells. I mean it has a special smell, over and above the smell of cyanide, carrion, blood, cordite or burnt flesh. It's like opium. Once you smell it you never forget. I can walk down a street and get a whiff of opium smoke and I know someone is kicking the gong around.

               I got a whiff of death as soon as Mr. Green walked into my office. You can't always tell whose death it is. Could be Green, his wife, or the missing son he wants me to find. Last letter from the island of Spetsai two months ago. After a month with no word the family made inquiries by long-distance phone.

               "The embassy wasn't at all helpful," said Mr. Green.

               I nodded. I knew just how unhelpful they could be.

               "They referred us to the Greek police. Fortunately, we found a man there who speaks English."

"That would be Colonel Dimitri."

"Yes. You know him?"

I nodded, waiting for him to continue.

               "He checked and could find no record that Jerry had left the country, and no hotel records after Spetsai."

               "He could be visiting someone."

               "I'm sure he would write."

               "You feel then that this is not just an instance of neglect on his part, or perhaps a lost letter? ... That happens in the Greek islands...."

               "Both Mrs. Green and I are convinced that something is wrong."

               "Very well, Mr. Green, there is the question of my fee: a hundred dollars a day plus expenses and a thousand-dollar retainer. If I work on a case two days and spend two hundred dollars, I refund six hundred to the client. If I have to leave the country, the retainer is two thousand. Are these terms satisfactory?"

               "Yes."

               "Very good. I'll start right here in New York. Sometimes I have been able to provide the client with the missing person's address after a few hours' work. He may have written to a friend."

               "That's easy. He left his address book. Asked me to mail it to him care of American Express in Athens." He passed me the book.

               "Excellent."

               Now, on a missing-person case I want to know everything the client can tell me about the missing person, no matter how seemingly unimportant and irrelevant. I want to know preferences in food, clothing, colors, reading, entertainment, use of drugs and alcohol, what cigarette brand he smokes, medical history. I have a questionnaire printed with five pages of questions. I got it out of the filing cabinet and passed it to him.

               "Will you please fill out this questionnaire and bring it back here day after tomorrow. That will give me time to check out the local addresses."

               "I've called most of them," he said curtly, expecting me to take the next plane for Athens.

               "Of course. But friends of an M.P. —missing person—are not always honest with the family. Besides, I daresay some of them have moved or had their phones disconnected. Right?" He nodded. I put my hands on the questionnaire. "Some of these questions may seem irrelevant but they all add up. I found a missing person once from knowing that he could wriggle his ears. I've noticed that you are left-handed. Is your son also left-handed?"

               "Yes, he is."

               "You can skip that question. Do you have a picture of him with you?"

               He handed me a photo. Jerry was a beautiful kid. Slender, red hair, green eyes far apart, a wide mouth. Sexy and kinky-looking.

               "Mr. Green, I want all the photos of him you can find. If I use any I'll have copies made and return the originals. If he did any painting, sketching, or writing I'd like to see that too. If he sang or played an instrument, I want recordings. In fact, any recordings of his voice. And please bring if possible some article of clothing that hasn't been dry-cleaned since he wore it."

               "It's true then that you use uh psychic methods?"

               "I use any methods that help me to find the missing person. If I can locate him in my own mind that makes it easier to locate him outside it."

               "My wife is into psychic things. That's why I came to you. She has an intuition that something has happened to him and she says only a psychic can find him."

               That makes two of us, I thought. He wrote me a check for a thousand dollars. We shook hands.

child_mcqs.description: The tone of the passage would best be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: The tone of the passage is too wild to qualify as ironic.  Likewise it may be funny, but is structured to be more than amusing, instead revealing a lot about Clem's thoughts and methods. It might qualify as satirical, yet the situation it explores it absurd enough to seem distinct from any contemporary reality, such that it is not mocking an actual private detective interview. The passage deliberately undermines the seeming authority of the private eye, by suggesting that he operates on methods that the audience is unlikely to believe a private eye would use. There are many hints that the author does not believe in the methods of the PI - 'use uh psychic methods’, 'My wife is into psychic things. That's why I came to you.’ The fact that the author would go to someone other than his wife because she believes in psychic things suggests that he has a strong scepticism to this way of investigating. This means that the correct answer is D.

child_mcqs.description: From the passage, it can be subtly seen that Clem
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage features a private eye going to some efforts to appear prepared and professional.  He is specific in his questions, which precludes D.  B is possible but the passage does not conclusively prove it to be the case.  A is not illustrated by the passage, as although the questions are specific there is no indication that they will help other than by Clem's assertions. Noticing that someone is writing with their left hand is unlikely to indicate that Clem is particularly observant, as may instead be trying to appear as such. This leaves C. Clem's client is clearly expecting him to be more proactive in his work, yet he is instead going to stay in New York and operate on the basis of a questionnaire. Other statements similarly appear unprofessional, such as 'I found a missing person once from knowing that he could wriggle his ears'. It is unlikely that his client will believe this statement, and instead undermines his confidence in Clem.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description: Consider the follwoing chart:

child_mcqs.description: Why is the chart split into two sections?
child_mcqs.explanation: Sometimes the simplest explanation is the best. This chart is split in two because overlaying all the lines would make it difficult to read. Thus Answer D is correct. Often this sort of split is made for reasons such as those given in B or C, however this is not the case in this instance because there is no significant difference in growth rates, nor is the scall of the y-axis different on either side. Answer A is not correct because all the lines show the same data except the red "regional" line, so the two sides are not related to differences between houses and apartments.

answers.description: To distinguish between higher growth and lower growth regions
So that separate scales can be used for different cities or regions

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description: The following figure shows a schematic representation of the process of evolution and habitat variation over time.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is the best summary of the information shown in the figure:
child_mcqs.explanation: Answering this question requires some assumptions as to the meaning of the figure. Only Answer B, however, can actually describe the process shown. The information above the passage tells us that it shows an evolutionary schematic and habitat changes, so we can assume that the shapes indicate species and the territory they occupy. There are two shapes at the bottom of the figure with different shading. These overlap significantly, and each occupies much of the area that the first shape (at the top) occupied. This fits with the description in answer B. Answer A is incorrect since the shading clearly differentiates between species, and although some of the original animals may have been physically separated from the rest (second figure from top), they apparently rejoined the original group later. Answer C is not correct because the figure doesn't show that one species has been pushed out by the other, but that they overlap. Answer D is not correct as there is nothing to suggest that one species is "more distinct" than another, and it makes no sense.

answers.description: A single species evolves into three separate species. Two of the new species recombine while the third stays divergent. The territory of the two new species overlap.
A single species evolves into two separate species. The two new species each occupy much of the territory that was previously occupied by the 'parent' species, with significant overlap.
A single species evolves into two separate species. One of the new species occupies the majority of the habitat of the 'parent' species, while the other is pushed into a niche territory.
A single species evolves into two separate species, one of which evolves further into a more distinct species. The final products of this evolutionary process occupy overlapping habitats.

child_mcqs.explanation: The street is located to the north of the Liffey River (look at insert). It is not north of Dublin, but IN north Dublin

child_mcqs.description: The likely reason for Dublin being built where is was is due to
child_mcqs.explanation: The railway line was only build in recent times.  This precludes “D”.  “A” “B” and “C” are all possible answers, but the one faction which is most limiting are the tidal flats.  It is not possible to build on these flats.  Hence “C” is the key.

answers.description: The relative position of the Liffey River
The relative position of the tidal flats
The relative position of the railway lines

child_mcqs.description: What noted feature of the harbour would most aid ships in entering the harbour?
child_mcqs.explanation: Of the features described, the lighthouse is the only one which would be visible to ships entering the harbour.  Hence B is the correct answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
If the Ithaca episode begins at 2:00 A,M., as the Gilbert schema says, then Stephen and Bloom must part at 2:30~plus. Bloom, left alone, is aware of "the incipient intimations of proximate dawn" (17.1247-48 [704:30]). Sunrise in Dublin on 17 June 1904 was at 3:33 A,M., so, depending on the cloud cover, daylight would have begun to gray things as early as 2:00A.M. Would it help to move Circe, Eumaeus, and Ithaca back an hour, as the Linati schema does, relocating Ithaca at 1:00 A.M.? That would ease the timetable from the beginning of Ithaca to first light to sunrise and almost make it believable that Molly hears the chimes of "George's church" ring "2 o’clock" (18.1231-32[772:27-28]), but it would incredibly clog the hours from 11 :00 P.M. to 1 :00 A.M.

If elaborate efforts to establish accurate timetables tend to fairer, they also tend to mislead our attention as readers and distract us from the variety of ways Joyce imitates time. We are all aware, for example, that we can think and perceive far more in the course of a few minutes of multi-leveled consciousness than we could spell out in words in as many hours. Joyce variously explores that disparity. At 8.481 (164:23) Bloom reflects that it is "five minutes" since he fed the birds from O'Connell Bridge, and it is a five minute stroll from the bridge to the front of Trinity College where Bloom is, but he feeds the birds at 8.75-76 (153:7-8), a good twenty minute read away. Twenty minutes of prose time is being manipulated to imitate five minutes of half-formed thought-perception time, thought-perception that could be verbalized  but usually is not.

There are even more radical experiments with the disparities between clock time, psychological time, and the imitation of time in the Circe and Penelope episodes. Because the Circe episode is cast in the form of a play with speeches and stage directions, we assume that reading time is approximately equal to playing time. But the reverse is the case: there is a radical disparity between reading time and playing time. For example, the hallucination at Introduction 3 15.1354-1956 (pp. 478-99), which we associate with Bloom, actually takes place between the two halves of Zoe's speech: "Go on. Make a stump speech out of it. . . . Talk away till you're black in the face," And again at 15.2750 (527: 10), Bella Cohen, the whore mistress, enters with the line, "My word! I'm all of a muck sweat," and continues at 15.3500 (555:2-3), "Which of you was playing the dead march from Saul?" The implication is that the hallucinations we associate with Bloom are acted out not for his witness but for ours; what are mere blips on the screen of his consciousness are dramatized and spelled out for us.

Psychoanalysts I have consulted about Bloom's hallucinations say that the ones we associate with him would unfold not in the course of one night's dreams, but over a period of about two years for the average patient undergoing analysis. In other words, the hallucinations last only a moment in dramatic time but are spelled out in a dramatic imitation of epic time, the two years or so of this phase-in-the-life.

In the Penelope episode the prose seems to imitate the way Molly might mutter to herself. Read aloud, the duration of the episode is three hours. Is that the order of time Joyce is imitating? Or is the muttering voice of the prose in turn imitating the foreshortened time and kaleidoscopic scatter of image we experience in brief spells of insomnia, an hour or less by the clock? I suspect that the Penelope episode's time is more like the time of hallucination and drama in Circe than it is like the time of a voice overheard and, therefore, that Molly's soliloquy belongs at once in the dramatic and the epic dimensions of time.

child_mcqs.description: A crucial assumption which the passage makes is that
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D obviously is possible, so would not qualify as an assumption. C also is obvious and wouldn’t qualify as an assumption. This leaves A and B.  A is the opposite of what the passage is saying at points, while B is referenced specifically in the passage. The passage states that 'twenty minutes of prose time is being manipulated to imitate five minutes of half-formed thought-perception time', which is used to demonstrating the difference in time between developing thoughts in one's consciousness and putting those thoughts into words

answers.description: Perception of time and reading occur at about the same speed
Everyone would read the same amount in 20 minutes
There is some kind of equivalence between reading time and thinking time

child_mcqs.description: The passage suggest a possible intersection between
child_mcqs.explanation: Literature deals with the depiction of things.  This would indicate C or D.  A hallucination would qualify more as fantasy than memory.  This indicates D as the answer.

answers.description: The depiction of private memory and collective memory
The depiction of private fantasy and private memory

child_mcqs.description: Disciplines tied together in this passage include
child_mcqs.explanation: Neurology studies with the mechanics of the brain and the pathways and mechanisms involved. The passage mainly deals with the end point (i.e. perception), and how this differs between internal perceptions of time and the actual passage of time. This is the domain of psychology, making option C correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description:
Explaining to a child why a fairy tale is so captivating to him destroys, moreover, the story’s enchantment, which depends to a considerable degree on the child’s not quite knowing why he is delighted by it. And with the forfeiture of this power to enchant goes also a loss of the story’s potential for helping the child struggle on his own, and master all by himself the problem which has made the story meaningful to him in the first place. Adult interpretations, as correct as they may be, rob the child of the opportunity to feel that he, on his own, through repeated hearing and ruminating about the story, has coped successfully with a difficult situation. We grow, we find meaning in life, and security in ourselves by having understood and solved personal problems on our own, not by having them explained to us by others.

Fairy-tale motifs are not neurotic symptoms, something one is better off understanding rationally so that one can rid oneself of them. Such motifs are experienced as wondrous because the child feels understood and appreciated deep down in his feelings, hopes, and anxieties, without these all having to be dragged up and investigated in the harsh light of a rationality that is still beyond him. Fairy tales enrich the child’s life and give it an enchanted quality just because he does not quite know how the stories have worked their wonder on him.

This book has been written to help adults, and most especially those with children in their care, to become more fully aware of the importance of such tales. As has already been pointed out, innumerable interpretations besides those suggested in the text that follows may be pertinent; fairy tales, like all true works of art, possess a multifarious richness and depth that far transcend what even the most thorough discursive examination can extract from them. What is said in this book should be viewed as illustrative and suggestive merely. If the reader is stimulated to go beyond the surface in his own way, he will extract ever more varied personal meaning from these stories, which will then also become more meaningful to the children he may tell them to.

Here, however, one especially crucial limitation must be noted: The true meaning and impact of a fairy tale can be appreciated, its enchantment can be experienced, only from the story in its original form. Describing the significant features of a fairy tale gives as little feeling for what it  is all about as the listing of the events of a poem does for its appreciation. Such a description of main features, however, is all that a book like this one can provide, short of actually reprinting the stories. Since most of these fairy tales are readily available elsewhere, the hope is that this book will be read in conjunction with a re-reading of the tales discussed.* Whether it is “Little Red Riding Hood,” “Cinderella,” or any other fairy tale, only the story itself permits an appreciation of its poetic qualities, and with it an understanding of how it enriches a responsive mind.

child_mcqs.description: The author takes what specific attitude in his writing?
child_mcqs.explanation: The author clearly establishes the need to explain what motivates fairy tales.  As such his intention is not condescending or paternalistic.  The author is authoritative by default, but mainly interested in educating. As such, C is the preferable answer

child_mcqs.description: A paradox the passage presents is that
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage explicitly states that its own interpretations of fairy tales are not definitive and hence can only be given as much credence as the reader might wish to grant them.  This fundamentally undermines the writers authority. Usually, an author would write a text with the sight that their views are true/concrete. As the author makes a conceptual acknowledgement that their views are not in fact the be-all and end-all, the inherent authority/control/belief that we would assume of his writing, is taken away. “B” is thus the correct answer. Whilst it does analyse the importance of not engaging in analysis, this is only in regards to explaining fairy tales to children, when in this case the book is aimed at adults.

answers.description: It discusses fairy tales while being aimed at an adult audience
It disavows its own authority as a text
It analyses the importance of not engaging in analysis

child_mcqs.description: The function of this text is as a(n)
child_mcqs.explanation: The text provides advice not upon how to actually read fairy tales to children, but upon not thereafter destroying their meaning for children.  This precludes C.  The structure of the book is not as an annotation.  This precludes A. There is nothing in the passage that critiques the actual fairy tales. D is the correct answer, as the text is a supplementary tool by offering advice on a specific aspect of fairy tales, in this case not destroying their meaning for children.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
EXT. ROAD - DAY

 

               The three of them... Carol chattering away.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  I don't know the last time I've

                                  been out of the city... Hey, my

                                  arms are tanning. I used to tan

                                  great. We gotta stop soon so'se

                                  I can check on Spencer.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                                 (during the above)

                                  I'm sorry... I can't hear you. I

                                  can't turn my head all the way

                                  yet... tell her we can't hear her.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  Doesn't matter. She's enjoying

                                  herself. Consider it part of the

                                  music.

 

               A short time later. Carol is now driving.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  I'm sure, Simon, they did

                                  something real off for you to feel

                                  this way... But when it comes to

                                  your partners -- or your kid --

                                  things will always be off for you

                                  unless you set it straight. Maybe

                                  this thing happened to you just to

                                  give you that chance.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  Nonsense!

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Anybody here who's interested in

                                  what Melvin has to say raise their

                                  hands.

 

               Simon does not raise his hand. Simon and Carol have thus

               declared their majority.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Do you want to know what happened

                                  with my parents?

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Yes. I really would.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Well...

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  No, let me pull over so I can pay

                                  full attention.

 

               Car pulling over toward parking spot.

               She takes the car curbside and parks.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Now go ahead.

 

               Simon looks back at Melvin as does Carol. He looks

               innocent. Several beats -- Melvin almost says something

               -- a hidden hand gesture from Carol stops him. Finally.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Well, I always painted. Always.

                                  And my mother always encouraged

                                  it. She was sort of fabulous

                                  about it actually... and she used

                                  to... I was too young to think

                                  there was anything at all wrong

                                  with it... and she was very

                                  natural. She used to pose nude

                                  for me... and I thought or assumed

                                  my father was aware of it.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  This stuff is pointless.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Hey -- you let him...

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  You like sad stories -- you want

                                  mine.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Go ahead, Simon. Really.

                                  Please. Don't let him stop you. Ignore him.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Okay. Well, one day my father

                                  came in on one of those painting

                                  sessions when I was nine -- and he

                                  just started screaming at her --

                                  at us -- at evil. And...

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                                 (very quickly)

                              ... my father didn't leave his

                              room for 11 years -- he hit my

                              hand with a yardstick if I made a

                              mistake on the piano.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Go ahead, Simon. Your father

                                  walked in on you and was yelling

                                  and... really, come on.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  I was trying to defend my mother

                                  and make peace, in the lamest way.

                                  I said, "she's not naked -- it's

                                  art." And then he started hitting

                                  me. And he beat me unconscious.

                                  After that he talked to me less

                                  and less -- he knew before I left

                                  for college, my dad came into my

                                  room. He held out his hand. It

                                  was filled with money. A big wad

                                  of sweaty money.

                                                 (gathers himself)

                                  And he said to me, "I don't want

                                  you to ever come back." I grabbed

                                  him and I hugged him... He turns

                                  and walked out.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  Well, you know -- I still say

                                  what I said. You've got to get

                                  past it all when it comes to your

                                  parents. We all have these horror

                                  stories to get over.

 

               Melvin shifts INTO the FRAME.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                  That's not true. Some of us have

                                  great stories... pretty stories

                                  that take place at lakes with

                                  boats and friends and noodle

                                  salad. Just not anybody in this

                                  car. But lots of people -- that's

                                  their story -- good times and

                                  noodle salad... and that's what

                                  makes it hard. Not that you had

                                  it bad but being that pissed that

                                  so many had it good.

 

                                                              CAROL

                                  No.

 

                                                              SIMON

                                  Not it at all, really.

 

                                                              MELVIN

                                                 (a veteran's irony)

                                  Not at all, huh?!... Let's go to

                                  the hotel. And if you're lucky

                                  tomorrow Dad will give you another

                                  wad of sweaty money.

child_mcqs.description: What role does Melvin play in the scene?
child_mcqs.explanation: While elements of what Melvin says are represented in A, C and D, each of these options suggests he is acting in direct opposition to the scene’s other characters. D is incorrect as although Melvin continually interrupts Simon's story, it is not Melvin whom Simon is fighting against, but his past. C is not preferable, as it implies that he is interrupting the fun of the others, when in fact this is a serious discussion. Finally, A is not correct, as playing Devil's Advocate would be supporting the notion that Simon's father was correct to act the way that he did. In actual fact, as is made clear at the passage’s end, Melvin shows that he is cynical of meaning of Simon's story, by ironically referencing the sweaty money can look foward to

child_mcqs.description: Carol’s role in the scene is that of
child_mcqs.explanation: Carol, as displayed by her opposition to Melvin, is antithetical to Melvin's philosophy and serves as the optimist of the group. After hearing Simon's story, she responds by asserting that Simon can get past it all. As such, A is the key. She does not provide comic relief, nor is there enough to support that she is the protagonist

child_mcqs.description: What is Simon’s role in the scene
child_mcqs.explanation: Simon, unlike the other two characters, is only basing his responses off his emotional experiences, not of any preconceived notions. He is purely emotional, and as such is “The Heart”. B is the correct answer. The answer is not memory, as Simon is offering only his own experiences, as does not represent a collective memory for the group. Simon is a not a martyr, as he did not suffer for his beliefs, and in any case actually accepts the money rather than fighting for his father.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
From Billy Budd by Herman Melville

The night, so luminous on the spar-deck, but otherwise on the cavernous ones below, levels so like the tiered galleries in a coal-mine—the luminous night passed away. But, like the prophet in the chariot disappearing in heaven and dropping his mantle to Elisha, the withdrawing night transferred its pale robe to the breaking day. A meek shy light appeared in the East, where stretched a diaphanous fleece of white furrowed vapor. That light slowly waxed. Suddenly eight bells was struck aft, responded to by one louder metallic stroke from forward. It was four o'clock in the morning. Instantly the silver whistles were heard summoning all hands to witness punishment. Up through the great hatchways rimmed with racks of heavy shot, the watch below came pouring, overspreading with the watch already on deck the space between the main-mast and fore-mast including that occupied by the capacious launch and the black booms tiered on either side of it, boat and booms making a summit of observation for the powder--boys and younger tars. A different group comprising one watch of topmen leaned over the rail of that sea-balcony, no small one in a seventy-four, looking down on the crowd below. Man or boy, none spake but in whisper, and few spake at all. Captain Vere--as before, the central figure among the assembled commissioned officers--stood nigh the break of the poop-deck facing forward. Just below him on the quarter-deck the marines in full equipment were drawn up much as at the scene of the promulgated sentence.

child_mcqs.description: The spar-deck is probably
child_mcqs.explanation: The night is luminous on this deck, suggesting it is open to the sky, i.e. the top deck

child_mcqs.description: ‘Diaphanous’ is closest to
child_mcqs.explanation: The meaning of diaphanous is most similar to translucent

child_mcqs.description: The tone of the piece is
child_mcqs.explanation: Portentous referes to being of momentous significance. The passage states that signalling bells are struck and all hands come up on deck, which suggests that something is about to happen. Whilst this, combined with the following explanation that it signifies a punishment, could potentially precede A, C and D, there is insuffient information to suggest any of these. Instead, the passage is building up to an important event

child_mcqs.description: Most likely, the next paragraph will describe
child_mcqs.explanation: The sailors have all come on deck to witness a punishment. This is not a pirate story, so it is unlikely anyone will be walking the plank. It is possible that the next paragraph will further describe the captain, but given the prelude to the punishment, C is the most likely answer

child_mcqs.description: The weather is
child_mcqs.explanation: A “diaphanous fleece of white furrowed vapor” is a translucent sheet of water droplets, i.e. mist.

child_mcqs.description: The author describes the dawn
child_mcqs.explanation: The imagery of a beautiful dawn contrasts and so emphasises with the image of the ship as a mine and the soldiers emerging to witness a whipping.

answers.description: to explain that the sailors can see

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
From Howards End by E M Forster

 

Shortly before the move, our hero and heroine were married. They have weathered the storm, and may reasonably expect peace. To have no illusions and yet to love--what stronger surety can a woman find? She had seen her husband's past as well as his heart. She knew her own heart with a thoroughness that commonplace people believe impossible. The heart of Mrs. Wilcox was alone hidden, and perhaps it is superstitious to speculate on the feelings of the dead. They were married quietly--really quietly, for as the day approached she refused to go through another Oniton. Her brother gave her away, her aunt, who was out of health, presided over a few colourless refreshments. The Wilcoxes were represented by Charles, who witnessed the marriage settlement, and by Mr. Cahill. Paul did send a cablegram. In a few minutes, and without the aid of music, the clergyman made them man and wife, and soon the glass shade had fallen that cuts off married couples from the world. She, a monogamist, regretted the cessation of some of life's innocent odours; he, whose instincts were polygamous, felt morally braced by the change, and less liable to the temptations that had assailed him in the past.
    They spent their honeymoon near Innsbruck. Henry knew of a reliable hotel there, and Margaret hoped for a meeting with her sister.  In this she was disappointed. As they came south, Helen retreated over the Brenner, and wrote an unsatisfactory postcard from the shores of the Lake of Garda, saying that her plans were uncertain and had better be ignored. Evidently she disliked meeting Henry. Two months are surely enough to accustom an outsider to a situation which a wife has accepted in two days, and Margaret had again to regret her sister's lack of self-control. In a long letter she pointed out the need of charity in sexual matters: so little is known about them; it is hard enough for those who are personally touched to judge; then how futile must be the verdict of Society. "I don't say there is no standard, for that would destroy morality; only that there can be no standard until our impulses are classified and better understood."Helen thanked her for her kind letter--rather a curious reply. She moved south again, and spoke of wintering in Naples.

child_mcqs.description: The passage portrays the wedding as
child_mcqs.explanation: The wedding is clearly low key with few guests and a lack of extravagence. Although such an event may appear bleak to many observers, it is likely what the couple desired and therefore uneventful is a more appropriate answer. Although a clergyman is present, and the couple intend to stay monogamous following the wedding, the passage is not conveying that this was a particularly pious wedding

child_mcqs.description: Margaret
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that Margaret has no illusions about her husband, and that has seen his past and his heart. This implies that she knows something discrediting about him, but has forgiven him. It can therefore be argued that Margaret loves with compassion, rather than sentiment, and D is correct. Although Margaret has known Henry's past, this does not mean that she has known him her whole life. Similarly, although there is something discrediting about Henry, and the wedding and honeymoon is low key, this is not enough to suggest that he is dissolute.

child_mcqs.description: “Life’s innocent odours” refers to
child_mcqs.explanation: These ‘innocent odours’ are ceasing for the woman because she is monogamous and is getting married, so they must be flirtations, which a monogamous married person cannot engage in.

child_mcqs.description: We can infer that Henry
child_mcqs.explanation: When reflecting on how marriage affected him, the he is described as having "instincts [that] were polygamous... and less liable to the temptations that had assailed him in the past." This suggests he was previously promiscuous, making Answer B the best option.

child_mcqs.description: Margaret tells her sister
child_mcqs.explanation: In her letter Margaret states that there can be no standard for moral judgment until our impulses are classified and better understood, which is in line with Answer C. In the letter Margaret also states that 'so little is known about them; it is hard enough for those who are personally touched to judge; then how futile must be the verdict of Society'. Although this may align with Answer B by asserting that those who are not involved are not in a position to judge, it also precludes B by stating that even those involved are frequently unable to judge. Therefore, C is the better answer in the passage

answers.description: only those involved in a situation can judge its morality
understanding is needed before morality can be decided

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17

child_mcqs.description: The cartoon uses
child_mcqs.explanation: The idea that Einstein made his big discovery by accidentally overhearing a remark and interpreting it in a way which was not intended is surprising.
