Therefore, the answer is D. Paradoxical refers to a statement that appears contradictory or impossible but is possibly true. The idea of Einstein obtaining his equation in this way, whilst unlikely, does not fall within this definition. Irony refers to when what occurs is the opposite of what was intended. Whilst Einstein may not have planned upon solving his equation in this manner, there is nothing in his wife or companion's character that makes it ironic that she assisted in the discovery (such as may have been the case if he had made disparging remarks about her usefulness/presence)

child_mcqs.description: The cartoonists suggests
child_mcqs.explanation: The serious message of the cartoon is not that this is really possibly how the theory of relativity was discovered (so it isn’t suggesting that this discovery involved luck or being in the right place at the right time). It is rather suggesting through a humorous metaphor that women’s contribution to society is often unacknowledged. Interpreting the cartoon in this way requires recognising that Einstein's wife intended to assist Einstein through her statement, as otherwise it does little to advance the cause of females in science. This is highly possible given her emphasis upon the phrase 'squared away'.

answers.description: the theory of relativity was discovered by luck
the contributions of women have been long unacknowledged
at the right point in history anyone could have discovered the theory of relativity

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
From A DISCOURSE OF A METHOD, For the well-guiding of Reason; AND The discovery of Truth in the SCIENCES by Descartes

 

Right understanding is the most equally divided thing in the World; for every one beleevs himself so well stor’d with it, that even those who in all other things are the hardest to be pleas’d, seldom desire more of it then they have; wherein it is not likely that all Men are deceived: But it rather witnesseth, That the faculty of right-judging and distinguishing truth from falshood (which is properly call’d, Understanding or Reason) is naturally equal in all Men. And as the diversity of our Opinions, is not, because some are more reasonable then others; but only that we direct our thoughts several ways, neither do we consider the same things. For ’tis not enough to have good faculties, but the principal is, to apply them well. The greatest Souls are as capable of the greatest Vices, as of the most eminent Vertues: And those who move but very slowly, may advance much farther, if they always follow the right way; then those who run and straggle from it.

 

For my part, I never presum’d that my Minde was more perfect in any thing then an ordinary Mans; nay, I have often wish’d to have had my thoughts as quick, my imagination as clear and distinct, and my memory as large and as ready as some other Men have had. And I know no Qualities which serve more then those to the perfection of the Minde; for as for Reason or Understanding, forasmuch as it is the only thing which makes us Men, and distinguisheth us from beasts, I will beleeve it to be entire in every One, and follow herein the common opinion of the Philosophers, who say, That there is only more or less among the Accidents, and not amongst the Forms or nature of the Individuals of one species.

child_mcqs.description: According to Descartes
child_mcqs.explanation: He says right understanding and reason is equally divided among people, making Answer C the correct answer. Opinions are described as a product of the direction of thoughts, and are not equal as people may apply their reasoning poorly.

child_mcqs.description: Descartes argues disagreement stems from
child_mcqs.explanation: A is incorrect given that reason is shared equally. Descartes says that it is not enough to have a good faculty of reason, but we also need to be able to apply reason well. People therefore hold different opinions as they use their reasoning differently, making B the correct answer. Understanding is used as a synonym of reason in the passage, and therefore D is not correct. Vice can be a cause of poor reasoning, but is only one example and therefore B is preferable.

child_mcqs.description: Descartes draws an analogy between
child_mcqs.explanation: The clue to this is to look at the preceding sentence. After saying that reason can be used well or badly, and so lead to good or bad opinion, he says that great souls are also capable of good or bad activity (virtue or vice). The analogy is thus between that which stems from the bad activity of reason and that which stems from the bad activity of the soul, bad opinion and vice. As such, there is a link between vice and bad opinion and B is correct

child_mcqs.description: According to Descartes the perfection of the mind involves
child_mcqs.explanation: After saying his mind is not perfect he lists a series of things he has wished about his mind, one of which is a larger memory, so large memory must be part of the perfect mind. When the author then discusses reason, he is saying that despite reason and understanding separating us from the beasts, each person has their own complete reason and understanding, and it is not therefore this that provides us with the perfect mind

child_mcqs.description: Descartes believes
child_mcqs.explanation: Descartes states that is understanding which distinguishes us from animals, which is used to demonstrate that reason is part of what makes us human. It is not used to suggest that people should rule over animals or that humans are the perfect specimen, as the passage does not convey either of these two ideas

answers.description: understanding is part of the nature of people

child_mcqs.description: Descartes’ character appears as
child_mcqs.explanation: Descartes argues that everyone has reason, not just himself, and that his mind is not perfect, listing things he would like to improve about it, so he appears to be humble.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
From Letter to a Hindu by Tolstoy

 

Thus it went on everywhere. The recognition that love represents the highest morality was nowhere denied or contradicted, but this truth was so interwoven everywhere with all kinds of falsehoods which distorted it, that finally nothing of it remained but words. It was taught that this highest morality was only applicable to private life—for home use, as it were—but that in public life all forms of violence—such as imprisonment, executions, and wars—might be used for the protection of the majority against a minority of evildoers, though such means were diametrically opposed to any vestige of love. And though common sense indicated that if some men claim to decide who is to be subjected to violence of all kinds for the benefit of others, these men to whom violence is applied may, in turn, arrive at a similar conclusion with regard to those who have employed violence to them, and though the great religious teachers of Brahmanism, Buddhism, and above all of Christianity, foreseeing such a perversion of the law of love, have constantly drawn attention to the one invariable condition of love (namely, the enduring of injuries, insults, and violence of all kinds without resisting evil by evil) people continued—regardless of all that leads man forward—to try to unite the incompatibles: the virtue of love, and what is opposed to love, namely, the restraining of evil by violence. And such a teaching, despite its inner contradiction, was so firmly established that the very people who recognize love as a virtue accept as lawful at the same time an order of life based on violence and allowing men not merely to torture but even to kill one another.

For a long time people lived in this obvious contradiction without noticing it. But a time arrived when this contradiction became more and more evident to thinkers of various nations. And the old and simple truth that it is natural for men to help and to love one another, but not to torture and to kill one another, became ever clearer, so that fewer and fewer people were able to believe the sophistries by which the distortion of the truth had been made so plausible.

In former times the chief method of justifying the use of violence and thereby infringing the law of love was by claiming a divine right for the rulers: the Tsars, Sultans, Rajahs, Shahs, and other heads of states. But the longer humanity lived the weaker grew the belief in this peculiar, God—given right of the ruler

child_mcqs.description: Tolstoy argues that popular attitude toward love was
child_mcqs.explanation: Tolstoy argues that love was recognised as the highest morality in words only, not deeds. He prodives a number of examples of how people recognised love as the highest morality, but then nevertheless rationalised innumerable actions that opposed love. This attitude is hypocritical.

child_mcqs.description: The one condition of love could best be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: The one condition is described as “the enduring of injuries, insults, and violence of all kinds without resisting evil by evil”. Of the available answers, the condition is best exemplified by a person when, following the violence and insult of a strike, they offer their cheek to be struck again.

answers.description: love your neighbour as you love yourself
do unto others as you would have them do unto yours
if he strikes your cheek, offer him the other

child_mcqs.description: Common sense indicates that
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage indicates that 'common sense dictates that if some people claim to decide who can be violently oppressed for the benefit of others, the oppressed people will in turn come to the conclusion that they can decide who can be violently oppressed (i.e. they will attempt to oppress others)'.

answers.description: those who have been oppressed will attempt to oppress

child_mcqs.description: ‘Sophistries’ is closest to
child_mcqs.explanation: ‘Sophistries’ is closest in meaning to ‘specious’. Both refer to making an argument that appears true or correct but is actually false. This is a key theme in the passage, in which the author argues governments and leaders provide reasons to justify and prove correct that which can never be correct, namely the use of violence in the name of love.

child_mcqs.description: The growing belief in the need for love was accompanied by
child_mcqs.explanation: The final passage provides that the chief method of justifying the infringement of the law had been monarchies, but the longer humanity lived this belief came to be doubted, as the validity of the infringement of the law of love came to be doubted. This best corresponds with answer C

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
All furniture is scaled down to fit into this low-ceilinged

               space. A few other short men sit reading tiny magazines.

               Craig approaches Floris, the receptionist.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Welcome to LesterCorp. May we meet

                                  your filing needs?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No, uh, my name is Craig Schwartz.

                                  I have an interview with Mr. Lester.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Please have a seat, Mr. Juarez...

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Schwartz.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Pardon?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Schwartz.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  I'm sorry, I'm afraid I have no idea

                                  what you're saying right now.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  My name is Schwartz.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Money, Miss Warts?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Forget it.

 

               Craig takes a seat next to the other applicants.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                                 (calling across the room)

                                  Fork ah did?

 

               The intercom buzzes. Floris picks it up.

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                                 (to Craig)

                                  Mr. Juarez?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Yes?

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  Yex?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  I said "yes."

 

                                                             FLORIS

                                  You suggest what? I have no time for

                                  piddling suggestions from mumbling job

                                  applicants, my good man. Besides, Dr.

                                  Lester will see you now. I think

                                  that's what he said.

 

               Craig stands, opens Lester's door, and enters

                                            

               Craig enters. Lester, a giant of an old man, sits hunched

               behind his tiny desk.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Come in, Mr. Juarez. I'd stand, but,

                                  well, you know.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                                 (extending his hand)

                                  Actually, my name is Craig Schwartz,

                                  Dr. Lester.

 

               Lester flips an intercom switch.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Security.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No, it's okay, sir. Just a mixup with

                                  your secretary.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  She's not my secretary. She's what

                                  they call an executive liaison, and

                                  I'm not banging her, if that's what

                                  you’re implying.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Not at all, Dr. Lester. I simply

                                  misspoke.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Tell me, Dr. Schwartz, what do you

                                  feel you can bring to LesterCorp?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Well, sir, I'm an excellent filer.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                                 (crafty)

                                  You think so, eh? Which comes first,

                                  L or... Glooph?

 

                                                             CRAIG  

                                  Glooph is not a letter, sir.           

 

                                                             LESTER 

                                  Damn, you are good. I tried to trick

                                  you. Okay, put these in order.

 

               Lester hands Craig a bunch of index cards. Craig orders

               them with amazing speed and dexterity. Lester watches,

               eyes wide.

 

                                                             LESTER (CONT'D)

                                                 (flips intercom switch)

                                  Floris, get Guinness on the phone.

 

                                                             FLORIS (O.S.)

                                  Gehginnis ondah foam?

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Forget it.

 

                                                             FLORIS (CONT'D)

                                  Fork ah did?

 

                                                             LESTER

                                                 (flips off switch)

                                  Fine woman, Floris. I don't know how

                                  she puts up with this damn speech

                                  impediment of mine.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  You don't have a speech impediment,

                                  Dr. Lester.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Flattery will get you everywhere,

                                  my boy. But I'm afraid I have to

                                  trust Floris on this one. You see,

                                  she has her doctorate in speech

                                  impedimentology from Case Western.

                                  Perhaps you've read her memoirs,

                                  "I can't understand a word any of

                                  you are saying."

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Pity, it tells it like it is.

                                  That's why the eastern, read Jewish,

                                  publishing establishment won't touch

                                  it. That's a quote from the book

                                  jacket. George Will, I think.

                                                 (beat)

                                  I apologize if you can't understand

                                  a word I'm saying, Dr. Schwartz.

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  No. I understand perfectly.

 

                                                             LESTER

                                                 (choking up)

                                  Thank you for being kind enough to

                                  lie. You see, I've been very lonely

                                  in my isolated tower of

                                  indecipherable speech. You're hired.

                                  Any questions?

 

                                                             CRAIG

                                  Just one. Why is this floor so short?

 

                                                             LESTER

                                  Low overhead, m'boy. We pass the

                                  savings on to you.

                                                 (laughs heartily)

                                  But seriously, that's all covered in

                                  orientation.

child_mcqs.description: By the scene’s end Lester
child_mcqs.explanation: The fact that he refers to Craig as Dr. Schwartz, even though Craig has not indicated that he is a doctor, indicates that the old man is still confused as to the identity of his new acquaintance. It is clear that he is not mistaking Craig for a Mr Juarez, as he no longer refers to him as this. Whilst D is similar to B, D indicates that he believes Craig is being dishonest, which is not the case from reading the latter portion of the passage.

answers.description: Is still confused as to who Craig is
Is unsure Craig is who he says he is

child_mcqs.description: It is clear in relation to her book that Floris
child_mcqs.explanation: While Lester refers to the possibility of Floris being published by referencing the book jacket, he also says who she is not published by. However, given the overall absurd tone of the entire exchange, it is not possible to confirm A, B or C and instead all that can be stated is that she may not in fact be published.

answers.description: Is not published with a major publishing group

child_mcqs.description: The most absurd element of the conversation between Craig and Lester is
child_mcqs.explanation: Lester believes that he is having a wonderful conversation with Craig even though he believes the man does not understand what he is saying.  This is impossible, and the more remarkable given the clarity of what Lester generally says. B and D are quite possible (although unlikely) in this situation, and are therefore not the most absurd elements. A is slightly absurd, but given that C incorporates both this fact and the notion that Lester believes they are having a normal conversation, it is clearly the most absurd answer

answers.description: Lester’s rapport with Craig given the general circumstances of their conversation

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
Aaron is seated behind a desk -- some old news copy in

               his hand.  An unmanned camera is pointing at him.  Tom

               is standing a few feet further back studying him.

 

                                                            AARON

                              This is uncomfortable for me --

                              because, well, I don't mean it as

                              a knock, but we approach this

                              differently.

 

                                                            TOM

                              We sure do.  I don't mean it as a

                              knock either.

                                             (he smiles)

                              Go ahead.  I'll just say what I think

                              and you can disregard it if you want.

 

                                                            AARON

                              It just might not work for me because

                              of our different approaches.

 

               Tom nods and gestures that he proceed.  Aaron begins reading

               the news.  Barely a sentence in, he is interrupted.

 

                                                            TOM

                              Wait.

 

                                                            AARON

                              What?

 

                                                            TOM

                              Your coat jacket is rising up in

                              back.

 

               Aaron ignores the tip.

 

                                                            TOM

                              When you sit down -- sit on your

                              jacket a little -- that gives you

                              a good line.  Look at yourself in

                              the monitor.

 

               Aaron looks but is unimpressed and resumes reading the news.

               Tom, not about to be ignored when he knows it's important, moves

               behind Aaron and begins to force his jacket down.

 

                                                            AARON

                                             (very uncomfortable)

                              I don't like being handled.

 

                                                            TOM

                              Sit on it!  Now look.

 

                                                            AARON

                              Just don't physically...

                                             (he sees himself in the

                                              monitor and is suddenly

                                              enthusiastic)

                              Fantastic tip -- fantastic.

 

               He starts to read again.

 

                                                            TOM

                              No.  That's not going to tell us

                              anything.  Let's get this prompter

                              going.

 

                                                            AARON

                              It's not loaded.

 

                                                            TOM

                              I'll find some copy.  Be right back.

 

               Tom exits -- Aaron looking after him, clearly taken with the

               genuine camaraderie... the unmistakable joy Tom derives from

               helping out.  Several beats and Tom comes back with a CAMERAMAN in

               tow.

 

                                                            TOM

                              I got copy, I got Ellen to heat up

                              the camera and I got Master Control

                              taping so you can study it later.

 

               He puts the roll of copy in the prompter.

 

                                                            AARON

                              Hey, Tom...

 

               Tom turns.

 

                                                            AARON

                              I'm very appreciative.

 

               SAME SCENE - LATER

 

               Tom totally focused on him down one knee checking him from

               various angles.  He interrupts.  Aaron reading from the prompter.

 

                                                            TOM

                              No.  No.

 

                                                            AARON

                              No?

 

                                                            TOM

                              Don't let your eyes go from the

                              beginning of the sentence to the end

                              like that.  You don't want to look

                              shifty, do you?

 

                                                            AARON

                              Oh, God, no!

 

                                                            TOM

                              And the left side of your face is the

                              good one.  Go again.  And try to punch

                              one word or phrase in every sentence --

                              punch one idea a story.  Punch -- come

                              on --

 

               Aaron does same with the story he is reading...

 

                                                            TOM

                              Good...very nice.

 

               Aaron acknowledges the compliment in news mode.  Punching the

               first words.

 

                                                            AARON

                              Thank you for the compliment, Tom.

 

               He draws a laugh from the Cameraman as he goes right into the

               next story.

 

                                                            TOM

                              Try not to move your head or wrinkle

                              your forehead...this is good, very

                              good...

child_mcqs.description: The subtext of the scene’s early section is
child_mcqs.explanation: Even though Aaron is looking for Tom’s tuition he still explicitly states that he believes their approaches are too different, and as such will not make for a very good match.  He does not really believe Tom will help him.  “C” is the key.

answers.description: Tom likes Aaron and wants to help him

child_mcqs.description: It can be assumed from the dialogue that
child_mcqs.explanation: The context for the tuition session is based on Tom having more experience than Aaron.  This would indicate “C”.  A is not mentioned in the article. D is possible, but given Aaron's initial reluctance to accept the tips and his later gratitude, it is likely that Tom is not merely pretending to know more than Aaron but is genuinely helping him. B and C are quite similar, but C is correct as the nature of Tom's tips likely indicate they are learned more from experience than instinct.

answers.description: Tom is naturally better at presentation than Aaron
Tom has more experience with being a news anchor than Aaron
Tom is pretending to know more than Aaron

child_mcqs.description: A likely reason for Tom being in the position he is in is due to
child_mcqs.explanation: Once again the crucial factor is the presence of television and a television camera.  A and B suggest general notions of self-possession and appearing good in front of others, whereas Tom's position requires him to do this in the specific context of television. D is more vague than C, and as such C is the correct answer

answers.description: Thinking about the visual impression he makes
Thinking about how his presence and words translate on television
Thinking of how to present on television

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
in Just-

 

in Just-

spring          when the world is mud-

luscious the little

lame balloonman

 

whistles          far          and wee

 

and eddieandbill come

running from marbles and

piracies and it's

spring

 

when the world is puddle-wonderful

 

the queer

old balloonman whistles

far          and             wee

and bettyandisbel come dancing

 

from hop-scotch and jump-rope and

 

it's

spring

and

 

         the

 

                  goat-footed

 

balloonMan          whistles

far

and

wee

 

e e cummings

child_mcqs.description: The typographical irregularity of the poem (the lack of punctuation, capitals and the irregular spacing)
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: B. This poem is half a sound-play and half a painting. A is a ridiculous distractor, C involves a nonsense word “transliterality”, and D is incorrect because of course this poem should be read out loud. Just try it.

answers.description: shows that e e cummings had difficulty using a typewriter
serves to emphasise the continuity between the visual and the verbal
suggests that the poem should not be read aloud

child_mcqs.description: The “piracies” of eddie and bill refers to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is correct. Eddie and Bill are kids playing with marbles. They’re children, and children like to pretend to be pirates (or the modern equivalent). They are obviously not real pirates, so ‘pretence’ is the word used to describe them efforting to make something fake (being pirates) appear true – like 'pretend', from which the word was formed. Thus, their ‘piracies’ of stealing and looting are pretences. There’s nothing in the poem to suggest that they're actually stealing and looting though, so B, C and D are all incorrect options.

child_mcqs.description:
The phrase “puddle-wonderful” evokes

 

  1. the joy of splashing about in puddles
  2. the spring melt
  3. youthful exuberance
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: D.  Ever watch a child in gum boots confront a puddle? In the North when spring comes it means the snow melts creating lots of muddy puddles. The whole idea of finding puddles fun is something from our youth. When you’re old puddles are a pain in the ass.

child_mcqs.description: The title “In just-“ serves to
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: D. The trick to this question is to realise the title is an interrupted hyphenated word-phrase like “puddle-wonderful” and “mud-luscious”: just-spring. Just-spring is just at the moment when spring has sprung. Hence A and B and C, therefore D.

answers.description: emphasise the suddenness of the arrival of spring
emphasise the continuity between lines of poetry
serves a double purpose of being the title and a word-part

child_mcqs.description: In describing the balloonman as “goat-footed” the poet
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: C. A is incorrect, as goats are not lame, they’re famously sure footed. B is a distractor. It’s hard to see why being goat-footed would make a man selling balloons more humours rather than more creepy, discounting D. This leaves C. In fact, there is an allusion to Greek myth here. Satyrs are creatures with goats legs but human in appearance from the waist up. They were known for drinking, dancing and mischief. Also, the god Pan was a satyr and is associated with sexuality and desire. Creepy. Finally, the Devil is often depicted with goat legs.

answers.description: is making reference to the fact that he is lame
suggests the man is in a goat costume
amplifies the sinister undertones of the balloonman
amplifies the humours nature of the balloonman

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21
stem_mcq.description:
A Dream Within A Dream

 

A Dream Within a Dream

Take this kiss upon the brow!
And, in parting from you now,
Thus much let me avow—
You are not wrong, who deem
That my days have been a dream;
Yet if hope has flown away
In a night, or in a day,
In a vision, or in none,
Is it therefore the less gone?
All that we see or seem
Is but a dream within a dream.

 

I stand amid the roar
Of a surf-tormented shore,
And I hold within my hand
Grains of the golden sand—
How few! yet how they creep
Through my fingers to the deep,
While I weep- while I weep!
O God! can I not grasp
Them with a tighter clasp?
O God! can I not save
One from the pitiless wave?
Is all that we see or seem
But a dream within a dream?

 

                        Edgar Allan Poe

child_mcqs.description: The speaker is
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: C. The speaker is certainly contemplative, thoughtful and reflective–he is engaging in philosophical thought. He takes it seriously too. So the key to answering this question is considering the first word in each pair. The man could be erudite but there’s nothing in the poem to suggest this, ruling out A. The same with fatalism, ruling out B. A phlegmatic person is unemotional and stolidly calm. This person is not, ruling out D. Consider how emotional he becomes in the second stanza. This is a passionate person. Difficulty: medium

child_mcqs.description:
The themes of this poem include:

 

  1. Love
  2. Isolation
  3. Loneliness
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: B. The poem concerns isolation. In the first stanza the speaker departs and in the second finds himself alone on a beach. Moreover, the very question of whether what we see or hear is real is confronted alone, inside our own heads. Hence II. It may be argued that in the first stanza he is departing from a woman with whom he has had a love affair. However, this ignores the highly symbolic nature of the departure–it’s about loss and ending in general. Another way to approach this is to ask yourself: when I finished reading the poem was love on my mind? Probably not. Hence I is out. Finally, being isolated and alone does not imply that you are lonely. There is no evidence in the poem that the speaker is upset by his isolation. Hence III is out. (There is evidence that he is upset that he can’t quite get a grip on reality). Difficulty: medium

child_mcqs.description: In using the metaphor of grasping grands of sand the poet
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer: C. This poem is not about time, rather, it’s about reality and our grasp on it, discounting A. B is silly, and D is wrong for the same reasons as A. This leaves C. This is what is happening the second stanza.  The speaker is desperately trying to hold onto reality (grasping the sand in his hands trying to save it from the pitiless waves). However, nothing he can point to or appeal to can save him from the fact that for all he knows he’s experiencing a dream within a dream.

answers.description: is making an allusion to the ravages of time
is making an allusion uncertainty delivered by experience
is making reference to suffering in life

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
Delight in Disorder

By Robert Herrick

 

A sweet disorder in the dress

Kindles in clothes a wantonness;

A lawn about the shoulders thrown

Into a fine distraction;

An erring lace, which here and there

Enthrals the crimson stomacher;

A cuff neglectful, and thereby

Ribands to flow confusedly;

A winning wave, deserving note,

In the tempestuous petticoat;

A careless shoe-string, in whose tie

I see a wild civility:

Do more bewitch me, than when art

Is too precise in every part.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements best summarises the poem?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect as there is no link made between clothing and an individual’s personality. Answer 2 is also incorrect as there is no sense of art being personified within the poem for the statement “Art lives and breathes” to be applicable. Put simply, although the careless dress of the subject is artful, she herself is not art personified. Answer 3 is incorrect - although the speaker highlights his attraction to a disordered, slightly unkempt state of dress, it cannot be assumed that he advocates highlighting one’s inadequacies; rather he appears to view “careless” and unvolitional disarray charming. Thus, Answer 4 is the most appropriate summation of the poem as the speaker finds imperfection (“ a careless shoe-string” / “a cuff neglectful”) to be enticing ("Do more bewitch me"), and dislikes when art, in this case attire, is too precise and controlled.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is an example of personification?
child_mcqs.explanation: This question is straightforward. Personification refers to the attribution of elements of human nature or characteristics to animals, plants, inanimate objects etc. In this case, the only appropriate option would be one where the descriptor word refers to some aspect of human nature or characteristic. Therefore Answer 3, where a “petticoat” is described as “tempestuous”, meaning something that is tumultuous or like a tempest, is correct.

child_mcqs.description: The line “wild civility” is an example of a(n)
child_mcqs.explanation: An oxymoron is a figure of speech that features juxtaposes elements which appear to be contradictory. Therefore, Answer 2, “wild civility”, is correct as the words “wild[ness]” and “civility” have quite incongruent meanings.

child_mcqs.description:
Which component(s) best reinforce(s) the poem’s theme of disorder?

I.        An incomplete rhyme pattern

II.        The use of anastrophe, or inversion of word order

III.        The heavy focus on women’s clothing
child_mcqs.explanation:
Option I is correct. Robert Herrick has formatted “Delight in Disorder” such that it reflects the poem’s content—that is, he has deliberately inserted technical imperfections in order to create “sweet disorder”. For example, the lines 1 and 2, 9 and 10, 13 and 14 rhyme, however the rest are only approximate rhymes that create a sense of incompleteness, or disorder in formatting. Option II is also correct as the use of anastrophe, or the inversion of word order (e.g. a “cuff neglectful” rather than a neglectful cuff, or “lawn about the shoulders thrown” rather than lawn thrown about the shoulders”) is a stylistic choice where words are disordered, reflected the overall theme of the poem. Option III is incorrect as the focus on women’s clothing is arbitrary, and in of itself, it does not reflect the theme of disorder. Put simply, Herrick could have chosen any topic to write about to the same effect; therefore the focus on women’s clothing in particular does not reinforce the theme of disorder.

Hence, Answer 2 is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
The Applicant

By Sylvia Plath

 

First are you our sort of person?

Do you wear

A glass eye, false teeth or a crutch,

A brace or a hook

Rubber breasts or a rubber crotch,

 

Stitches to show something’s missing? No, no?

How can we give you a thing?

Stop crying.

Open your hand.

Empty? Empty. Here is a hand

 

To fill it and willing

To bring teacups and roll away headaches

And do whatever you tell it.

Will you marry it?

It is guaranteed

 

To thumb shut your eyes at the end

And dissolve your sorrow.

We make new stock from the salt.

I notice you are stark naked.

How about this suit –

 

Black and stiff, but not a bad fit.

Will you marry it?

It is waterproof, shatterproof, proof

Against fire and bombs through the roof

Believe me, they’ll bury you in it.

 

Now, your head, excuse me, is empty.

I have the ticket for that.

Come here, sweetie, out of the closet.

Well, what do you think of that?

Naked as paper to start

 

But in twenty-five years she’ll be silver,

In fifty, gold.

A living doll, everywhere you look.

It can sew, it can cook

It can talk, talk, talk.

 

It works, there is nothing wrong with it.

You have a hole, it’s a poultice.

You have an eye, it’s an image.

My boy, it’s your last resort.

Will you marry it, marry it, marry it.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following would the speaker most likely be?
child_mcqs.explanation: The marriage is not being held currently, so Answer 3 of marriage celebrant seems unlikely. Answer 1 seems quite unlikely; the speaker talks quite abruptly (“No, no?”), appears not to know the other personas (“First are you our sort of person?”), and appears unfazed by the other parties’ state of undress. The choice remains between Answer 2 and 4. Answer 4 is incorrect, as the speaker’s distinct disregard for any of the groom’s answers suggests that he or she is not an interviewer who is seeking information. The entire interaction between the speaker and groom resembles that of a salesperson and buyer, more so than interviewer and interviewee. This leaves Answer 2 – what is demonstrated within the poem is the speaker’s status of authority – he or she dominates the conversation, speaks discourteously, and completely disregards the autonomy of both the bride and groom. Therefore, the most evidenced assumption is that the speaker is an authority figure in some position of influence or power – Answer 2.

answers.description: A relative of the bride or groom

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following lines is a clear example of the use of enjambment?
child_mcqs.explanation: Enjambment is a poetic technique where, most often, a line ends abruptly in a manner that does not coincide with natural pause or punctuation breaks, and is continued on the next line or stanza. Answers 1 and 3 are not examples of enjambment, given that the first line of each ends in a question mark, and as such is a relatively natural position for a new line. Answer 2 could be considered an example of enjambment, although it could also coincide with a natural pause in speech. Answer 4, however, is a clear example of this poetic technique, given that the last line of a stanza ends with the words, "here is a hand", which while it could be a complete clause, is actually continued in the next stanza with the words, "to fill it". Thus, Answer 4 is correct.

answers.description: “First are you our sort of person? / Do you wear”
“To thumb shut your eyes at the end / And dissolve your sorrow”
“Will you marry it? / It is guaranteed”
“Empty? Empty. Here is a hand / To fill it and willing”

child_mcqs.description: The type of marriage expressed within the poem would most likely be:
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A does not seem to adequately describe the type of marriage scenario depicted within the poem. There is no evidence to suggest to the reader that this marriage will be lively - actually quite the contrary is depicted (“bring teacups”/ “roll away headaches”). Nor does it seem unmanageable, as the bride is described as quite docile (“do whatever you tell it”). Answer C is also incorrect as there is no evidence to suggest that this marriage is unprincipled, and considering that the groom is crying at the mere suggestion of marriage (“stop crying”), the tone also implies that this marriage may be unenjoyable. Answer D is also incorrect as the groom’s status as a distraught “applicant” who is being rigorously propositioned suggests that this marriage will be born of an unnatural process, one similar to that of a sale. Answer B is the most appropriate choice, as the poem alludes to the lifelong, contractual nature of this marriage (“thumb shut your eyes in the end”/ “they’ll bury you in it”). It also suggests that this marriage will be middling and mediocre, as both the groom and bride are portrayed as generic halves of an artificial and coerced union.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 24
stem_mcq.description: Consider the table and chart below when answering the following questions:

child_mcqs.description: Which activity had the greatest change in the proportion of total energy it consumed between 1970 and 1980
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D, 'farm family living' is correct. The question relates to changes in the proportion of the total energy used, so the differences between the first column (1970) and second column (1980) are the relevant data. 'Farm family living' decreased (i.e. changed) from 11.9% to 9.6%, a difference of 2.3%, and thus a greater change that any of the other activities.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is incorrect because it relies on the mistaken assumption that the columns of figures under 1970 and 1980 are absolute values, rather than proportions. If the total was 100 gigawatts in 1970, then 'farm production' used 22.5 gigawatts in 1970. A 4.2% change in this consumption gives a 0.945 gigawatt increase. The other three options are all correct statements.

answers.description: 'Processing of food and related products' was responsible for the greatest proportion of energy consumption in both 1970 and 1980, and it experienced the greatest absolute change between the two dates
The amount of energy consumed for 'farm family living' increased between 1970 and 1980, although by less than the average increase of other activities, while its share of energy consumption decreased
If a total of 100 gigawatts of electricity were consumed by the listed activities in 1970, then this means that 'farm production' used 1.4 gigawatts less energy in 1980 than in 1970

Activities experiencing a decrease in the share of total energy that they consumed between 1970 and 1980 experienced an increase in the absolute amount of energy that they consumed over the same period

child_mcqs.description: According to the energy production/consumption chart:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is incorrect because 40% of industrial energy comes from peteroleum (i.e. less than half). Option C is incorrect because while 100% of nuclear energy goes to electricity production, only 20% of electricity production is supplied from nuclear energy. Option D is incorrect because there are some examples where renewable sources provide more energy to sectors than other sources - e.g. 13% of electricity supply compared to 1% from petroleum. Option B is the correct answer because 75% of energy for residential and commercial use is supplied from gas, and that accounts for 32% (i.e. about a third) of all the natural gas supply.

answers.description: About a quarter of the total petroleum produced supplies more than half the energy for industrial use
Three quarters of energy for residential and commercial use is produced from about a third of the total natural gas supply
100% of electric power is supplied by nuclear energy
Renewable sources provide the lowest amount of energy to each sector

sections.title: Section III: Reasoning in Biological and Physical Sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
The boiling point of some molecules was recorded and plotted in the following graph:

The boiling point of a substance increase with the strength of its intermolecular bonds which range from strong hydrogen bonding to week Vander Waal’s bonding.

The table below shows the energies of interaction of intermolecular as well as intermolecular (covalent and ionic) bonds.

child_mcqs.description: Why does the trend of H2O and HF deviate from the trend in the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: When hydrogen is bonded to fluorine or oxygen the large difference in electronegativity causes an unequal distribution of electron density. The partial positive charge of the hydrogen attracts the partial negative charges of oxygens/fluorines on adjacent molecules leading to hydrogen bonding, and thus higher boiling points.

answers.description: They experience more Van Der Waal’s attractions

child_mcqs.description: What is the most probable explanation of why do noble gases boiling points increase as the period increases?
child_mcqs.explanation: Temporary dipoles occur in all molecules including symmetrical atoms, such as noble gases. The larger the atom, the further the electrons are from the nucleus and the greater the amount of dispersion that can occur.

answers.description: The bonds are stronger because bigger atoms are more polarizable as the period increases
The bonds are weaker because bigger atoms are less polarizable as the period increases
The bonds are stronger because electronegativity of atoms increase as the period increases
The bonds are weaker because electronegativity of atoms decrease as the period increases

child_mcqs.description: The atomic radius of Xe is
child_mcqs.explanation: Atomic radius increases down a group.

child_mcqs.description: From table 1 above, it could be concluded that:
child_mcqs.explanation: The higher the typical energy of the bond, the more stable it is, and the more energy is required to break it.

answers.description: The lower the typical energy of the bond the more stable it is
The higher the typical energy of the bond the more stable it is
Hydrogen Bonding with noble gasses is the strongest
Hydrogen Bonding with noble gasses is the weakest

child_mcqs.description: From graph 1 above it could be concluded-with the exception of HF and H2O that:
child_mcqs.explanation: From the graph, the less electronegative the element, the higher the boiling point of its hydride. HI and HBr both have higher boiling points than HCl, and iodine and bromine are less electronegative than chlorine. Note that this is not actually a true statement, but the question is askinng you to interpret the graph, not use your own knowledge.

answers.description: The more electronegative a substance is, the higher the boiling point of its hydride
The less electronegative a substance is, the higher the boiling point of its hydride
the more electronegative a substance is, the lower the ionization energy
the less electronegative a substance is ,the higher the ionization energy

child_mcqs.description: all of the following have a net dipole moment EXCEPT
child_mcqs.explanation: The shape of SiH4 is tetrahedral with a silicon atom bonded to four hydrogen atoms, thus it does not have a net dipole moment.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description: Transcription is the process of generating an mRNA transcript from a DNA sequence. Translation is the production of polypeptide from an mRNA sequence.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: The transcription of DNA into mRNA requires:
child_mcqs.explanation: The transcription of DNA into RNA requires RNA polymerase to produce the mRNA sequence.

answers.description: The free nucleotides A, T, C and G

child_mcqs.description:
This table shows the mRNA codons, and the amino acids for which they code:

What is a possible DNA sequence that codes for the polypeptide: Tyr-Glu-Asp
child_mcqs.explanation: Tyr could be encoded by ATA (mRNA codon UAU), Glu by CTT (mRNA codon GAA) and Asp by CTA (mRNA codon GAU)

child_mcqs.description:
An anticodon is a region of tRNA that is complementary to an mRNA codon

Which is a possible anticodon for arginine? note that the answers are written 3'-5'
child_mcqs.explanation: The mRNA codons for arginine are: CGU, CGC, CGA, CGG, AGA and AGG. The possible anticodons are therefore GCA, GCG, GCU, UCU, UCC. Of these, only GCU appears in the answers

child_mcqs.description:
What is the mRNA sequence that is generated from the following sequence of DNA:

5’ AGTCTAG 3’
child_mcqs.explanation: Be careful to check the orientation of your molecules in relation to 5’ and 3’.

child_mcqs.description: Elongation of a nucleic acid chain involves:
child_mcqs.explanation: Nucleotides are added onto the 3’ carbon atom of the previous nucleotide in the chain. We call this a phosphodiester bone.

answers.description: The addition of the next nucleotide on the 3’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a peptide bond
The addition of the next nucleotide on the 5’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a peptide bond
The addition of the next nucleotide on the 5’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a phosphodiester bond
The addition of the next nucleotide on the 3’ carbon of the previous nucleotide in the chain, forming a phosphodiester bond

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not involved in mRNA processing before it leaves the nucleus?
child_mcqs.explanation: mRNA processing involves the addition of a 5’ G-methylated cap, a 3’ polyA tail, and the splicing out of introns by the spliceosome complex, which then splices the exons together to have a continuous coding sequence that is read by the ribosome to produce the protein molecule.

answers.description: Splicing out of introns by RNA polymerase

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
The behaviour of non-ideal gases can be represented by Van der Waals Equation:

Where P is the absolute pressure, n is the number of moles, V is the volume, T is the absolute temperature and R is the gas constant (0.08206 L/atm mol K). a and b are constants determined experimentally for each gas studied.

child_mcqs.description: For an ideal gas what can be said about both “a” and “b?
child_mcqs.explanation: Mathematically, for the equation to equal the ideal gas equation, PV=nRT, ‘a’ and ‘b’ must be zero.

answers.description: A is positive while b is negative

child_mcqs.description: The value of the Van der Waals constant, a, of a given gaseous substance increases with the strength of attractions between its component molecules, where the constant b increases with the physical size of the component molecules. Predict which of the following substances would have the lowest "a" constant.
child_mcqs.explanation: The value of the Van der Waals constant, a, of a given gaseous substance increases with the strength of attractions between its component molecules. All of the molecules here have atoms with different electronegativities and so local dipoles, except for O2. O2 thus has the lowest a as the only forces between molecules are the very weak dispersion forces, where the others have much stronger dipole-dipole forces. Note that although some of these have a net zero dipole moment, they still have local dipoles and can interact through dipole-dipole forces.

child_mcqs.description: Predict which of the following substances would have the highest "b" constant.
child_mcqs.explanation: The constant b increases with the physical size of the component molecules. Clearly He is much smaller and so ruled out immediately. As for the other three, all three have the same number of electrons (10), and the size of a particle is defined by its electrons. However, Na+ and Mg2+ are actually smaller than neon because they have a more positive nucleus and so pull in their ten electrons more tightly. The actual sizes in terms of Van der Waals radius (one way to look at size) are Ne 154, Na+ 118 and Mg2+ 76; the same rough relationship is true for the other methods of looking at size.

child_mcqs.description: A compression factor Z has been defined as Z= PV/nRT. The graph below shows a plot of this Z value against molarity for a specific gas at 3 different temperatures. This graph most likely represents:
child_mcqs.explanation: The compression factor is the ratio PV/nRT, which is constant for an ideal gas. However, for a real gas this is not a constant as it does not take into account the van der Waals constants. For a real gas, what is constant is (P+an2/v2)(V-nb)/nRT.

answers.description: Both an ideal and a real gas
This graph doesn’t not represent any gas since the compression factor Z is a function of temperature

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following molecules has the greatest dipole moment?
child_mcqs.explanation: Each are symmetrical molecules and thus do not have a dipole moment.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
When Ca(IO3)2 dissolves in an acidic solvent the following reaction takes place 

Where HIO3 is a weak acid. The solubility constant (Ksp) can be determined from the solubility of Ca(IO3)2 for solutions of varying concentrations of the acid solvent H+ using the following formula. 

To measure Ksp the solubility of 4 different solutions has been recorded in Table 1 below each with a different concentration of H+.
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: The Ksp for Ca(IO3)2 is
child_mcqs.explanation: Ksp is equal to the product of the concentration of the ions produced to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients.

answers.description: [Ca2+]2[IO3-]2
[Ca2+][IO3-]2 / [Ca(IO3)2]
[Ca2+][IO3-]2 / [Ca(IO3)2][H+]

child_mcqs.description: The relationship between [H+] and solubility is
child_mcqs.explanation: As [H+] increases, solubility increases, so at the very least A should be ruled out. However, neither of the other two answers are correct, mostly because of the extra Ksp1/2 term on the left - if this wasnt present then H would be exponentially proportional to S. It is clearly not lineally proportional because we have S3/2 on the left and H on the right - if it was lineally proportional there would be no Ksp1/2 term and S and H would be to the same power.

child_mcqs.description: As the solubility in mol/L increases from 5.4x10-3 to 2.0x10-2, Ksp will
child_mcqs.explanation: The value of the Ksp is constant for a given solute and is independent of both the amount of solute and the solubility. The fact that solubility increases with acidity is due entirely to the [H+] term in the equation, and not due to a change in Ksp.

answers.description: increase to a certain amount and then start decreasing again

child_mcqs.description: If we wanted to increase the amount of un-dissociated HIO3 we should
child_mcqs.explanation: Adding HCl will increase the concentration of H+ ions, thus pushing the equilibrium to the right to produce more un-dissociated HIO3.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
Cancer involves dysregulation of the cell cycle, such that the neoplastic (cancerous) cells are driven to divide above and beyond their surrounding normal cells. This dysregulation occurs through the acquisition of mutations in genes that control the cell cycle.

Tumour suppressor genes include genes that prevent the progression of the cell through the growth cycle when the cell is not fit to divide. In contrast, oncogenes are genes that signal the cell to undergo cell division. An example of these include genes which stimulate growth factors.

child_mcqs.description: The cells in lung cancer proliferate by:
child_mcqs.explanation: Cancer cells divide by mitosis, as they produce cells with the same number of chromosomes.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above information, for a cell to become cancerous it must:
child_mcqs.explanation: For a cell to become cancerous it must acquire gain of function mutations in the genes that drive cell proliferation so that they become constitutively activated (oncogenes). It must also acquire loss of function mutations in the tumour suppressor genes, which prevent the cell cycle from continuing when there are mistakes in DNA.

answers.description: Acquire mutations in tumour suppressor genes only
Acquire mutations in both tumour suppressor genes and oncogenes
Either acquire mutations in tumour suppressor genes or oncogenes

child_mcqs.description: Human papilloma virus can infect cells of the cervix and result in cervical cancer. As part of its invasion into the host cell, the viruses, induces the cell to produce proteins to drive the cervical cells to proliferate. These proteins inhibit p53 and Rb. From this information, we can conclude that p53 and Rb are:
child_mcqs.explanation: p53 and Rb normally prevent the cell from undergoing cell division.

child_mcqs.description: In some cancers, a chromosomal translocation takes place such that gene x is placed after the promoter region of another gene that is constantly being transcribed and translated. If this translocation causes the cell to divide, gene x must be a(n):
child_mcqs.explanation: If a gene is constantly being expressed causing a cell to divide, it must be an oncogene.

child_mcqs.description: The correct order of the phases of mitosis includes:
child_mcqs.explanation: The correct order is from prophase to metaphase to anaphase and finally to Telophase.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Hypophosphataemia rickets is a genetic disorder that causes short stature and bow leggedness. It is caused by a mutation in a gene that encodes the PHEX protein. The normal role of this protein is to inhibit phosphatonins, which promote phosphate excretion. This results in excess excretion of phosphate, which impairs bone mineralisation.

A pedigree of a family with this genetic disorder is shown below.  Affected individuals are shaded.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above pedigree, hypophosphataemia rickets cannot be:
child_mcqs.explanation: Hypophosphataemia rickets cannot be X-linked recessive because not all affected females have an affected father.

child_mcqs.description: What supports this trait being X-linked dominant?
child_mcqs.explanation: A father with the trait will pass on his X chromosome to all of his daughters. Because the trait is dominant, they too will have the trait.

answers.description: All females of an affected father are affected.
Both males and females of an affected mother are affected.
All males of an affected mother are affected
Both males and females of an affected father are affected.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not true about autosomal recessive inheritance?
child_mcqs.explanation: Because the trait is autosomal, the sex of the parents and children do not influence whether or not they will be affected by the trait.

answers.description: 25% of offspring from 2 carrier parents are affected
They are often due to deficiencies in enzymes
They may only be seen in one generation

child_mcqs.description: When a zygote is fertilised, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote originates from the egg. The mitochondrial DNA of the sperm is not found in the zygote. Based on this information, which of the following is true regarding defects due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since the mitochondrial DNA is inherited via the maternal line, all offspring of any couple will get their mitochondria from their mother. Therefore, if the mother is affected by a defect in mitochondrial DNA, all offspring will also inherit this gene.

answers.description: They are inherited from the mother or the father
All offspring of affected females tend to show the disease
All offspring of affected males tend to show the disease

child_mcqs.description: In X-linked recessive transmission?
child_mcqs.explanation: Sons inherit their X chromosome from their mothers. If the mother is a carrier, there is a 50% chance she will pass the X chromosome with the trait to the son. Because males only have one X chromosome, the son will demonstrate the trait.

answers.description: Daughters of affected fathers will have the condition
Sons of affected fathers will have the condition
Daughters of heterozygous mothers have a 50% chance of being affected
Sons of heterozygous mothers have a 50% chance of being affected

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description:
Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of a substance. Within gases, temperature can be related to the root mean square speed with the following equation.


R is the gas constant (8.31 J/molˑK); T is the absolute temperature (Kelvin = °C + 273), and M is the molar mass. Note: J = kgˑm2/s2

child_mcqs.description: What is the approximate root mean square speed of oxygen particles at room temperature (25°C)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Remember that oxygen is a diatomic gas, hence the molar mass is 0.032 kg/mol. Sub this value in for M, and the given values for R and T (remember to convert to Kelvins). Evaluate from there to reach the answer C.

child_mcqs.description: If the distribution of speeds of gas particle can be closely approximated to a normal (bell-shape curve, what is the relationship between the most probable speed and the root mean square speed?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Higher speeds contribute non-linearly to the energy of the system, which governs the root-mean-square velocity of gas particles.

EDIT:

I personally find this to be quite a challenging question in terms of understanding it from the chemical theory. I instead have a mathematical solution which I will present to you here, which I hope that some of you who may be more mathematically oriented, or who enjoy physics over chemistry, will find helpful.

answers.description: The root mean square speed is larger.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description: The above diagram describes the phase changes of water.

child_mcqs.description: Which phases do A, B and C represent?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is apparent as A, B and C corresponds to the segments of the graph that connects to form the triple point.)

child_mcqs.description: What form does water take at 0.1°C and 0.5kPa?
Point D is the triple point, where all three phases of water exist simultaneously. If a slight increase in pressure occurs from this point, what phase would water take?
child_mcqs.explanation: slight increase in pressure will shift towards the positive y direction.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description: A motorist heads north for 30 min at 80 km/hr, screeches to a halt, looks over his map for 10 minutes, then heads east for 48 min at 100 km/hr and collides into a tree.

child_mcqs.description: What was his average speed?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Notice that the numerator of the above fraction represents the total distance (in km) that the motorist travelled:

`30/60 times 80 + 48/60 times 100 = 40 + 80 = 120"km"`

The denominator represents the total time spent travelling, including the 10min pause, with the units of hours:

`{:30 + 48 + 10:}/60 = 88/60 approx 90/60 approx 1.5"h:`

Hence the answer is `120/1.5 = 120/{:3/2:} = 240/3 = 80"km.h"^{:-1:}`. The closest answer is B.

child_mcqs.description: What was his average velocity?

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description: For the frictionless and stationary pulley shown in the figure below, answer the following

child_mcqs.description: The mass of M1 is greater than M2, True or False?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The question stated the pulley was stationary, thus the net torque acting on the pulley must be zero.

This implies that M1 and M2 exert equal and opposite torques on the pulley that cancel each other out.

For this to be the case, the mass of M1 and M2 must be identical.

child_mcqs.description: If FA, FB and FC represent the tension in the rope at points A,B and C respectively, which of the following is true?
child_mcqs.explanation: Tension force in the string is equal at all points throughout the string

child_mcqs.description: If the mass of M1 is 200g, what is the tension force at B?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Tension force at B is simply equal to the force of weight exerted by the mass under gravity (approximated as `10"m.s"^{:-2:}`):

`F_t = m times g = 0.2"kg" times 10 "m.s"^{:-2:} = 2"kg.m.s"^{:-2:} = 2"N"`

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description: The following figure is of a 200g block been pushed against a vertical wall. The block is at rest 5m off the ground. Refer to the figure to answer the following questions
stem_mcq.tag: PHY03 Newton's Laws and Types of Forces

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following Force diagrams correctly depicts the forces acting on the block? Where FP is the push force, Ff is the force due to friction, FN is the normal force and Fg is the force due to gravity.
child_mcqs.explanation:
Normal Force is always perpendicular to the surface so this eliminates answers B and D.

Static frictional force always acts to oppose motion and will exist if there is a force acting to cause motion. Note that a frictional force exists even when there is no motion. To correctly deduce the direction of this frictional force, you have to determine the net force on the block (that is, the vertical component of the push force minus the force due to gravity). However, notice that the resultant force must either be up or down and in answer C there is no frictional force component.

So by process of elimination, the answer must be A.

child_mcqs.description: If the angle θ is equal to 30° find the magnitude of the normal force.
child_mcqs.explanation:
The normal force must be equal to the horizontal component of the push force:

`Cos 30^"o" = {:F_N:}/12`

`F_N = 12 times {:{:sqrt3:}/2:} = 6sqrt3 = sqrt{:3 times 36:} = sqrt108 approx sqrt100 approx 10N`

So the correct answer is C

child_mcqs.description: How long would it take the block to reach the ground if the frictional force (acting to oppose motion) was 7N?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The first step is to determine the net force acting on the block. The forces involved are the vertical component of the push force, the force due to gravity, and the force due to friction. The direction that the frictional force acts in can only be determined after you know the direction of the force acting to cause motion so we will figure that out first. This will be the vertical component of the push force minus the force due to gravity:

`F_V = 12 times sin30^"o" = 12 times 1/2 = 6N "acting upward"`

`F_g = 10 times 0.2 = 2N "acting downward"`

Thus the resultant force is 4N upward.

Now, we incorporate the frictional force. Recalll, a friction force always acts to oppose motion hence the frictional force in this case will act downward. Also note that a frictional force of 7N exceeds the force acting to cause motion so the block will not move at all! Remember, a friction force can't generate movement, it can only inhibit it.

So the block will never hit the ground.

answers.description: The block will never reach the ground

child_mcqs.description: If the mass of the block increases from 200g to 2kg, now how long will the block take to reach the ground?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Using the same approach as the last question, we calculate the net force acting to cause motion on the block:

`F_V = 12 times sin30^"o" = 12 times 1/2 = 6N "acting upward"`

`F_g = 10 times 2 = 20N "acting downward"`

So the resultant force is 14N downward. The frictional force is 7N against motion so it acts upwards again.

Now the net force remaining is 7N downward.

With a known force and mass, we can determine the acceleration of the block:

`F_{:"net":} = m times a`

`a = F_{:"net":}/m = 7/2 = 3.5 "m.s"^{:-2:}`

Now we can use our equations of motion with acceleration and displacement to determine the time required for the block to hit the ground:

`s = ut + {:1/2:}at^2 = 0t + {:1/2:} times 3.5 times t^2`

`t^2 = {:5 times 2:}/3.5 = 10/3.5 approx 3`

`t approx sqrt3 approx 1.75s`

answers.description: The block will never reach the ground

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
This diagram shows lung volumes during breathing

ERV = Expiratory reserve volume

TV = Tidal volume

IRV = Inspiratory reserve volume

VC = Vital capacity

FRC = Functional residual capacity

TLC = Total lung capacity

IC = inspiratory capacity (= TV + IRV)

 

Note that a capacity is a sum of ≥2 volumes.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the graph, the residual volume:
child_mcqs.explanation: The residual volume refers to the volume left in the lung after complete expiration. It can be calculated by the total lung capacity minus the vital capacity of the lung.

answers.description: is the volume of air left in the lungs during tidal breathing

child_mcqs.description: Vital capacity is equal to:
child_mcqs.explanation: This question is testing whether you understand the diagram of lung volumes and capacities. Refer to the diagram for a visual representation of these equations.

answers.description: Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume + expiratory reserve volume

child_mcqs.description: The functional residual capacity  =
child_mcqs.explanation: This question is testing whether you understand the diagram of lung volumes and capacities. Refer to the diagram for a visual representation of these equations.

answers.description: The volume of air left in the lungs after the inspiration phase of tidal breathing

child_mcqs.description: A person may have a reduced vital capacity due to a decreased in compliance of the lung. In relation to lung compliance:
child_mcqs.explanation: Elastic forces within the lung cause an increase in the propensity of the lung to collapse on itself. Therefore, these elastic forces decrease lung compliance. Surfactant reduces the surface tension of water within the lung and therefore increases the compliance of the lung.

answers.description: It is decreased by the elastic forces within the lung

child_mcqs.description:
The physiologic dead space of the lung refers to the volume of inspired air that does not take part in gas exchange. It can be calculated by:

VD = physiologic dead space

VT = tidal volume

PaCO2 = arterial PCO2

PeCO2 = expired air PCO2

The physiologic dead space equals:
child_mcqs.explanation: The physiologic dead space refers to volume of gas in the lung that does not take part in gas exchange. Therefore, it refers to both the anatomical dead space in the conducting airways, the functional dead space in the alveoli.

answers.description: The anatomical dead space of conducting airways plus the functional dead space in alveoli
Just the anatomical dead space of conducting airways
Just the functional dead space in the alveoli

child_mcqs.description: If the tidal volume decreased, the physiologic dead space would:
child_mcqs.explanation: As you can see in the equation, the physiologic dead space is proportional to the tidal volume. Therefore, if the tidal volume decreases, so too does the physiologic dead space.

child_mcqs.description: Using a snorkel would:
child_mcqs.explanation:
Question 5 defines:

  • Physiologic dead space = volume of inspired air that does not take part in gas exchange = anatomical dead space + functional dead space
  • Anatomical dead space = conducting airways
  • Functional dead space = that within the alveoli

A snorkel essentially extends the conducting system and therefore increases the physiological dead space.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
Ingested food is mechanically digested in the stomach to break it down into smaller pieces. These are then chemically digested by pancreatic and gut enzymes in the duodenum to release nutrients and vitamins, including the fat-soluble A, K, D and E vitamins. These are then absorbed through the brush border of the duodenum and transported to tissues via the blood or lymphatic circulations. 

The pancreas is a comma-shaped accessory organ of the gastrointestinal system. It connects to the gastrointestinal system via the main pancreatic duct and empties into the duodenum. The pancreas serves as both an exocrine and an endocrine organ. Its exocrine function involves the secretion of bicarbonate and a suite of enzymes into the duodenum including amylase (digests carboydrates), peptidases (proteins) and lipase (fats).

The peptidases of the pancreas are shown in the diagram below: 

The pancreas’ endocrine function involves the release of glucagon and insulin into the blood to control blood sugar level.  Insulin is released after the intake of a meal, when blood glucose and amino acid levels are higher, whereas glucagon is released during period of starvation.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: Absorption of which of the following will be affected by pancreatic insufficiency (inability of the pancreas to perform its exocrine function)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Absorption of vitamin K will be affected. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin and is only absorbed if there is proper digestion of fat. The other vitamins are water-soluble and can be absorbed freely.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not true regarding pancreatic function?
child_mcqs.explanation: Insulin is an endocrine hormone. Therefore it is not released into the pancreatic duct but into the bloodstream.

answers.description: It depends on the Na+-K+-ATPase pump on the basolateral surface
It releases insulin into the pancreatic duct
Most of the pancreatic mass is involved in its exocrine function
Enzymes are released as inactive substances called zymogens

child_mcqs.description: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disease that results in dysfunction of the chloride transporter, CFTR, and Cl- cannot be transported into the lumen of the pancreatic duct. This results in:
child_mcqs.explanation: In cystic fibrosis, chloride ions cannot be transported into the pancreatic ducts. Therefore, sodium is not attracted into the lumen and water does not follow. This results in a thick mucus that blocks the ducts, and the enzymes of the pancreas start to digest the substance of the pancreas. This leads to pancreatic insufficiency.

answers.description: Decreased movement of Na+ and water into the pancreatic duct

child_mcqs.description: Regarding the pancreatic enzymes released during digestion, a lack of which will have the greatest effect on protein digestion:
child_mcqs.explanation: Refer to the diagram. Trypsin is the activated form of trypsinogen. It is the enzyme required for activation of the other zymogens. The conversion of trypsinogen to trypsin relies on enterokinase. For this reason the absence of trypsinogen and enterokinase will have the same and greatest effect on protein digestion.

child_mcqs.description: Insulin
child_mcqs.explanation: Insulin acts to decrease blood glucose. One of the ways it does this is by stimulating protein synthesis, which uses up ATP. Glucose is then used to replenish this ATP. Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, and gluconeogenesis is the formation of new glucose from other molecules. Both of these would raise blood glucose levels. Note that insulin does not cause excretion of glucose into the urine.

answers.description: Increases the level of glucose in the urine

child_mcqs.description: Steatorrhoea (fatty stools) can occur due to pancreatic insufficiency. This is most likely due to loss of:
