child_mcqs.explanation: Lipase is the enzyme responsible for the digestion of fat, and therefore a lack of lipase will result in fat in the stools. Bile salts come from the liver and are used to emulsify fats.

child_mcqs.description: Glucagon has a similar action to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Glucagon has a similar action to cortisol and adrenaline. Both of these are stress hormones, and act to raise the level of blood glucose in times of need.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
A phase diagram is a plot of the changes in the phase of a material as a function of temperature and pressure.

The first figure represents the phase diagram of carbon dioxide, while the second represents that of water. A, B and E represent solid, liquid and gas respectively. D is called the triple point, where all phases exist in equilibrium. C is the critical temperature after which the gas cannot be liquefied regardless of the pressures applied.

child_mcqs.description: The negative slope XY in figure 2 is indicative that
child_mcqs.explanation: As pressure increases for a given temperature, water changes from solid to liquid. Thus water in the liquid phase is denser than in the solid phase.

answers.description: water in the solid phase is more dense than water in the liquid phase
water in the liquid phase is more dense than water in the solid phase
water is more resistant to change when in the solid phase than when in the liquid phase
water is more resistant to change when in the liquid phase than when in the solid phase

child_mcqs.description: If carbon dioxide at its critical point is compressed and cooled, it will first transition into
child_mcqs.explanation: This involves finding C on Figure 1 and following the changes described. Move your pen to the left to follow the path it takes while cooled (decreasing temperature), and then move it up to find the effect of compressing (increasing pressure)

child_mcqs.description: According to Figure 1 as the pressure increases, the sublimation point of carbon dioxide
child_mcqs.explanation: As indicated by the graph, as pressure is increased, a higher temperature is required in order for CO2 to undergo sublimation – thus the sublimation point is increasing.

child_mcqs.description:
In the graph below, isotherms for water are plotted against pressure and volume. 

The area in the dashed lines on the graph represent what region in the phase diagram of water (Figure 2) above
child_mcqs.explanation: The line between D and C indicates the junction between liquid and vapour phases. At this two phase condition (below the dotted line on the isotherm graph) a small amount of additional pressure will result in a large reduction in volume since the gas phase is compressible.

child_mcqs.description:
The graph below compares the density of a material X in liquid phase with its vapour phase.

From this graph it could be concluded that 375 is
child_mcqs.explanation: At zero degrees, and at low and high pressure, material X is in the vapour and liquid phases, respectively. As temperature is increased 375oC, these phases become indistinguishable – representing the critical point.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
The equilibrium reaction below shows the Mond process for the carbonylation of nickel

The Gibbs free energy change ΔG for a reaction can be expressed in terms of the change in enthalpy ΔH and entropy ΔS, and the temperature T as below

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS

child_mcqs.description: At standard conditions, the carbonylation of nickel is considered to be
child_mcqs.explanation:
At standard conditions, temperature = 25C or 298K; it is easier to approximate this to 300K in practice. We thus need to work out the ΔG for the reaction. Note that ΔH is given in kJ but ΔS is only given in J/K; we need to change the units on one of them so they are matching. This gives ΔH = -160800 J and ΔS = -409.5 J/K. Putting this into the Gibbs equation we get:

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS
ΔG = -160800 - (300)(-409.5)
ΔG approximately = -160000 + 120000 = -40000J

Thus ΔG is negative and the reaction is spontaneous

answers.description: a nonspontaneous reaction and the backward reaction is favoured
an reaction in equilibrium where the forward and the backward reactions cancel each other
an endothermic reaction that needs very high temperatures to initiate
a spontaneous reaction and the forward reaction is the favoured reaction

child_mcqs.description: The enthalpy of formation ΔHf of Ni(s) is
child_mcqs.explanation: By definition, the standard enthalpy of formation of the most stable form of nickel is zero because there is no formation reaction needed when nickel is already in its standard state.

child_mcqs.description: What is the approximate change in Gibbs free energy ΔG of reaction 1 at 100C?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Use the same initial equation, with 373K (which is the same as 100C) as the temperature. 

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS
ΔG = -160800 - (373)(-409.5)
ΔG approximately = -160000 + 15000 = -10000J

The closest answer is -8 kJ; with the approximations we wouldn't expect to be bang on, just close enough to get the right answer.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following graphs best represents the carbonylation of nickel?
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the negative enthalpy, the reaction is exothermic. All reactions require activation energy to take place, and so the reaction profile should have a hump in it between the reagents and products.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
The heart is a four-chambered pump that pumps blood throughout the body. There are two atria, two ventricles and the vessels that return blood to the heart (veins), and those that take it away from the heart (arteries).

Certain structural problems can occur in the heart in infancy resulting in problems. 

One such condition is the tetralogy of Fallot. Two features of this include pulmonary stenosis, which is narrowing  of the pulmonary artery and a ventricular septal defect, such that there is an abnormal connection between the two ventricles.

Another condition is transposition of the great vessels, in which the aorta leaves from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery leaves from the left ventricle.

A final condition is patent ductus arteriosus in which there is a persistent connection between the pulmonary artery and the aorta.

child_mcqs.description: The flow of blood in someone with transpition of the great vessels would be:
child_mcqs.explanation: In transposition of the great vessels, blood will return to the heart via the vena cavae, which will then pass through the right atrium to the right ventricle and pumped out of the aorta to the systemic capillaries. This circuit will never pump blood to the heart.

answers.description: Vena cavae --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> pulmonary artery --> pulmonary vein --> left atrium --> left ventricle --> aorta
Vena cavae --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> aorta
Vena cavae --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> aorta --> pulmonary vein --> left atrium --> left ventricle --> aorta
Vena cavae --> left atrium --> left ventricle --> pulmonary artery --> pulmonary vein --> right atrium --> right ventricle --> aorta

child_mcqs.description: If somone suffered from transposition of the great vessels, it would be beneficial to also have:
child_mcqs.explanation: A patent ductus arteriosus would allow a connection between the systemic and the pulmonary circuits and thereby allow some oxygenation of the blood in the circuit described in section 1.

child_mcqs.description: The arterial oxygen content of a person with tetralogy of Fallot is likely to be what in relation to a person with a normally developed heart:
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the ventricular septal defect, blood from the left side of the heart will be shunted into the right side of the heart. This will cause a decrease in the oxygenation of the blood.

answers.description: There is not enough information to determine this.

child_mcqs.description: Pulmonary stenosis is likely to result in:
child_mcqs.explanation: To generate enough flow through the stenosed pulmonary artery, higher pressure must be generated in the right ventricle. This in turn will lead to high pressure in the atrium.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
The primary purpose of the circulation is to provide adequate blood flow to organs. For this to occur, blood pressure must be maintained at a certain level.

Mean arterial pressure = total peripheral resistance x cardiac output

child_mcqs.description: Blood pressure is predominantly maintained by the baroreflex. A fall in blood pressure:
child_mcqs.explanation: A fall in blood pressure will cause an activation of the sympathetic nervous system. One of the responses of this is an increase in noradrenaline release onto the b-receptors in the heart, which will cause an increase in heart rate. This will act to increase cardiac output and therefore increase mean arterial pressure.

answers.description: Causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in arterioles
Increases noradrenaline release on to beta-receptors in the heart

child_mcqs.description: Organs need more blood when they are metabolically active, and therefore arterials in metabolically active organs dilate. This does not occur is in response to:
child_mcqs.explanation: Arterioles dilate in response to high CO2, as this is a marker of cells being metabolically active, thereby requiring higher blood flow for oxygen and nutrients.

child_mcqs.description: In extreme exercise, the need to lose heat competes with the need to maintain blood pressure. This is because:
child_mcqs.explanation: All of the answers are true. Humans vasodilate arteriole skin to carry more blood to the skin so heat can be lost, and sweat to lose heat via evaporation. In addition, arterioles supplying muscles vasodilate. All of these will cause a decrease in blood pressure

answers.description: Humans lose heat by vasodilating the arteriolar supply to the skin
Humans lose heat by sweating, which can reduce intravascular volume
During exercise, muscle metabolites cause local arteriolar dilatation of blood vessels

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
A 300g ball (m1) sits on an inclined plane 2m off the ground. When the ball is released it collides and sticks with a 600g ball (m2) at the bottom of the slope. The friction along the ground is equal to 2N.

Now answer the following

child_mcqs.description: What is the velocity of the two balls after the collision?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The initial momentum of the system immediately prior to collision is:

`P_i = m_1 v_{:1,i:} + m_2 v_{:2,i:} = 0.3 v_{:1,i:} + m_2 times 0 = 0.3 v_{:1,i:}`

Now we need to find `v_{:1,i:}` through the conservation of energy. We achieve this by noting that the potential energy of ball 1 is entirely converted to kinetic energy prior to collision with ball 2:

`PE_1 = KE_1`

`m_1 times g times h = {:1/2:} m_1 times v_{:1,i:}^2`

`v_{:1,i:} = sqrt{:2 times g times h:} = sqrt{:2 times 10 times 2:} = sqrt40`

Therefore, `P_i = 0.3 times sqrt40`

Now that we have found the momentum of the system prior to collision, we use the conservation of momentum to find the final velocity of the paired balls after the collision:

`P_f = P_i = (m_1 + m_2) v_f`

`{:0.3 times sqrt40:}/{:0.3 + 0.6:} = v_f = {:sqrt40:}/3 = sqrt{:40/9:} approx sqrt{:40/10:} approx sqrt4 approx 2"m.s"^{:-1:}`

So the final velocity of the paired balls after collision is `2"m.s"^{:-1:}`.

child_mcqs.description: How far do the two balls continue to travel after the collision?
child_mcqs.explanation:
We know the velocity of the paired balls immediately after the collision so we now need to find their acceleration which incorporates the resistive frictional force:

`a = {:F_f:}/{:m_1 + m_2:} = -2/0.9 approx -2/1 approx -2"ms"^{:-2:}`

With the acceleration, now we can find the displacement:

`v^2 = u^2 + 2as`

`s = {:v^2 - u^2:}/{:2a:} = {:0 - 2^2:}/{:2 times -2:} = {:-4:}/{:-4:} = 1"m"`

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description: Ricky Ponting, an Australian cricketer, hits an oncoming ball travelling at `20 "m.s"^{:-1:}` with his cricket bat, clearing the ball over the nearest boundary. The trajectory of the ball is initially at `30^{:"o":}` above the horizontal. If the distance to this boundary is 150 m, his contact time with the ball is 0.005s, and the mass of the ball was 0.16kg, answer the following questions:

child_mcqs.description: To achieve this outcome (the ball clearing the boundary) what was the minimum forced needed?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Ricky ponting must exert a force on the cricket ball with his bat in order to alter its path. This force can be determined from the impulse formula:

`F = {:Delta p:}/{:Delta t:} = m times {:Delta v:}/{:Delta t:} = {:m/{:Delta t:}:} times (v_f - v_i)`

We know the mass of the ball (0.16kg), the contact time with the bat (`Delta t = 0.005s`), and the initial velocity vector of the ball (`20 "m.s"^{:-1:}` toward Ricky) so we can substitute these into the expression:

`F = {:m/{:Delta t:}:} times (v_f - v_i) = {:0.16/{:0.005:}:} times (v_f - {:-20:}) = 32 times (v_f + 20)`

So now we need to find `v_f` which is the horizontal component of the velocity vector of the ball immediately after it collides with the cricket bat. This requires the use of a vector triangle and the equations of motion. We will start with the vector triangle:

Here, `v_f` is the horizontal component of the ball's velocity vector (`v_b`) immediately after collision. `v_v` is the vertical component. Now we need to use this vector triangle to find an expression relating `v_f` and `v_v`:

`tan 30^{:"o":} = {:v_v:}/{:v_f:} = 1/sqrt3` therefore `v_v = {:v_f:}/sqrt3`

Note here that you can derive `tan 30^{:"o":}` from the fact that `tan 30^{:"o":} = {:sin 30^{:"o":}:}/{:cos 30^{:"o":}:} = {:1/2:}/{:{:sqrt3:}/2:} = 1/sqrt3`

With this relation between `v_f` and `v_v`, we can now use the equations of motion to find a second expression for `v_f` giving us two equations in two unknowns. Recall that we know the final horizontal displacement of the ball (`s=150"m"`). We can use this to find the flight time of the ball:

`s = ut + {:1/2:}at^2`

`150 = v_f times t + {:1/2:} times 0 times t^2`

`t = 150/{:v_f:}`

Now we know the flight time. Note that we also know the final vertical displacement of the ball (`s=0"m"`) and the time at which the ball lands (`t = 150/{:v_f:}`) so we can use this to figure out the vertical component of the ball's final velocity vector `v_v`:

`s = ut + {:1/2:}at^2`

`0 = v_v times {:150/{:v_f:}:} + {:1/2:} times -g times ({:150/{:v_f:}:})^2`

`0 = 150 times {:{:v_v:}/{:v_f:}:} - {:1/2:} times 10 times {:150^2/{:v_f:}^2:}`

`150 times {:{:v_v:}/{:v_f:}:} = 5 times {:22500/{:v_f:}^2:}`

`30 times {:v_v:} = 22500/{:v_f:}`

`v_v = 750/{:v_f:}`

Now substitute our first expression we found previously:

`{:v_f:}/sqrt3 = 750/{:v_f:}`

`{:v_f:}^2 = 750sqrt3`

I use `sqrt3 approx 1.75 = 7/4` to simplify. This gives:

`{:v_f:}^2 approx 750 times {:7/4:} = 5250/4 = 1312.5`

`v_f = sqrt{:1312.5:} approx 35"m.s"^{:-1:}`

Note here I used the approximation that `sqrt{:1312.5:}` is about halfway between `sqrt{:900:} = 30^2` and `sqrt{:1600:} = 40^2` hence the answer lies approximately halfway between 30 and 40 thus 35.

Now we can substitute this back into our original impulse equation to find force:

`F = 32 times (v_f + 20) = 32 times (35 + 20) = 32 times 55 = 1760N`

Thus no answers are sufficiently close enough to this one hence D is the correct answer.

Final note: don't be overwhelmed - this is a very difficult question. It is highly unlikely you will be asked a question like this on the GAMSAT. Rather, it would be asked in smaller parts that appear less panic-inducing.

child_mcqs.description: Ricky Ponting will also feel a force on his hands during the collision between the bat and ball. Which of Newton’s laws is being applied?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A. 1st Law – that an objects velocity will not change until perturbed by a force, which doesn't apply to the force on Pontings hands

B. 2nd Law – Force = mass * acceleration – doesn't apply to this case

C. 3rd Law – Every force has an equal and opposite reaction, which is correct, as the reaction force on Pontings hands is a response to the force exerted on the bat, which in turn applied the force to the ball.

D. Newton only has 3 laws!

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
There are receptors in muscle that sense muscle length and force. These receptors send information to the CNS via sensory neuron, which then activate somatic motor neurons to muscle fibres which stimulates contraction. Inhibitory signals also exist which inhibit muscle contraction. 

Muscle spindles are called stretch receptors, and exist as small elongated structures scattered among and arranged parallel to the contractile extrafusal muscle fibres. They are activated when the length of the muscle changes.

Golgi tendon organs are diffuse nerve endings scattered between the collagen fibres of the muscle tendon. They are arranged in series to the extrafusal muscle fibres, and act to regulate the force of the muscle contraction. Therefore when they are activated more, the contraction of the muscle will decrease to keep the force constant within the muscle.

child_mcqs.description: In regards to skeletal muscle reflexes:
child_mcqs.explanation: Excitation of somatic motor neurons always causes contraction in skeletal muscle. No neurons directly inhibit the contraction of muscles.

answers.description: Muscle spindles are the only receptors found in muscles
Golgi tendon organs sense the length of the muscle fibres.
Excitation of somatic motor neurons always causes contraction in skeletal muscle

child_mcqs.description: One consequence of muscle spindles being in parallel to the extrafusal muscle fibres are that, when the extrafusal muscle fibres contact:
child_mcqs.explanation: Due to the parallel nature of spindle fibres and extrafusal muscle fibres, when the extrafusal muscle fibres contract, this would cause slackening of the spindle fibre. This means that the spindle fibre will no longer be able to sense the true length of the muscle. Therefore it must contract to maintain sensitivity to unexpected changes in length/stretch of the muscle.

answers.description: The length of the spindle does not change
The muscle spindle fibres must contract as well so that it maintains its sensitivity to changes in stretch
Spindle fibres will contract independently of extrafusal muscle fibres

child_mcqs.description: The knee jerk reflex involves tapping the quadriceps with a tendon hammer, causing the knee to extend. This reflex would be initiated by
child_mcqs.explanation: The knee jerk reflex causes stretching of the muscle fibres, which therefore cause spindle fibres to length. The response is to shorten the muscle fibre, which keeps the length of the muscle relatively constant.

child_mcqs.description: In the knee jerk reflex:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the knee jerk reflex, the knee extends. For this to occur, the quadriceps muscle in the anterior thigh must contract, and the hamstring muscles in the posterior thigh must relax.

child_mcqs.description: When a muscle fatigues, and the force it generates decreases:
child_mcqs.explanation: When a muscle fatigues, the force it generates will be decreasing. This will lead to decreased activation of the Golgi Tendon Organ. Therefore to keep the force constant, the Golgi Tendon Organ will be stimulated less, leading the muscle to contract more forcefully as contractions are increased.

answers.description: Golgi tendon organs are more activated to increase muscle contraction
Golgi tendon organs are more activated to decrease muscle contraction
Golgi tendon organs are less activated to increase muscle contraction
Golgi tendon organs are less activated to decrease muscle contraction.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true regarding muscle contraction:
child_mcqs.explanation: In sarcomeric contraction, the movement of actin relatively to myosin occurs via the formation of cross-bridges between actin and myosin. Note that muscles are only innervated by activating neurons, and are dependent on calcium influx for muscle contraction.

answers.description: It depends on magnesium influx from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
It involves the formation of cross-bridges between actin and myosin
Muscles are innervated by activating and inhibitory neurons

child_mcqs.description: By definition, a reflex:
child_mcqs.explanation: The spinal cord is required for integrating sensory information and initiating the motor response. Therefore a reflex must involve the CNS.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21
stem_mcq.description:
The neuromuscular junction is the site where a motor neuron synapses with a muscle fibre. An action potential travels down the axon of the motor neuron, causing release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine then diffuses across the synaptic cleft, binds to its receptor and initiates depolarisation of the muscle fibre.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease of the neuromuscular junction. It leads to progressive muscular weakness due to the production of antibodies that target nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

child_mcqs.description: In myasthenia gravis, the antibodies must be binding receptors:
child_mcqs.explanation: In synaptic transmission, acetylcholine is released by synaptic vesicles into the synaptic cleft. The acetylcholine then diffuses across the cleft and binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on the post-synaptic membrane.

answers.description: In the vesicles of the pre-synaptic neuron

child_mcqs.description: In myasthenia gravis, the antibodies act as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Since the antibodies are causing muscle weakness, they must be acting as antagonists of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

child_mcqs.description: The symptoms of myasthenia gravis could be overcome by:
child_mcqs.explanation: Giving an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor will shut down the enzyme that degrades acetylcholine, so there would be a higher level of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft per action potential of the neuron. The result of this is that the ACh would then displace some of the antibodies by competitive inhibition, allowing some of the channels to open.

answers.description: Giving the person blood from patient without myasthenia gravis

child_mcqs.description: When an action potential is initiated in a motor neuron:
child_mcqs.explanation: As with any action potential, when a neuron is stimulated, voltage-gated sodium channels open at the nodes of Ranvier to cause depolarisation, which travels down the neuron.

answers.description: Calcium ions cause the action potential to propagate down the neuron
There is a change in the conductance of ions at the nodes of Ranvier
The conductance of ions does not change.

child_mcqs.description: If the antibodies of someone with myasthenia gravis were injected into someone without myasthenia gravis:
child_mcqs.explanation: In autoimmune conditions, the cell’s immune system generates immune responses that are targeted to self. Because the person that is receiving the antibodies would not be continuously making these antibodies, they would only experience a transient muscle weakness as the antibodies would eventually be degraded.

answers.description: The person would experience transient muscle weakness
The person would experience permanent muscle weakness
The person would not experience muscle weakness
The person’s muscle weakness would come and go.

child_mcqs.description: The development of myasthenia gravis is dependent on:
child_mcqs.explanation: The generation of pathogenic antibodies requires B cells to differentiate into plasma cells to produce the antibodies, and CD4+ T helper cells to provide the B cells with the ‘help’ to make the antibodies.

child_mcqs.description: Another autoimmune disease is multiple sclerosis, which causes ‘demyelination’ of neurons. The outcome of this disease would be:
child_mcqs.explanation: Myelin is predominantly a lipid substance that coats the axon of nerves, and prevents current leak across the neuron cell membrane. Its role is to speed up the transmission of the axon potential down the axon. Therefore, in multiple sclerosis, transmission of the action potential down the axon is essentially slowed without the effect of myelin.

answers.description: The inability to generate an action potential
The inability of a nerve to signal to a muscle cell to contract
The slowing of transmission down a nerve axon
The inability of the nerve to conduct potassium ions

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
The rate law for a chemical reaction is an equation that links the reaction rate with concentrations or pressures of reactants and constant parameters. To determine the rate equation for a particular system one combines the reaction rate with a mass balance for the system.

The reaction rate for a given reaction 2A + B --> C is: 

A reaction 2NO2 + F2 → 2NO2F was conducted three times with different initial concentration of reactants. This is a multi-step reaction as below.

Overall reaction: 2NO2 + F2 → 2NO2F + F
Step 1: NO2 + F2 → NO2F + F
Step 2: NO2 + F → NO2F

The table below shows the three different initial rates of the overall reaction.

Reaction

[A] (M)

[B] (M)

Initial rate (M/sec)

1

0.05

0.05

5x10-3

2

0.05

0.10

5x10-3

3

0.10

0.05

1x10-2

 

The equilibrium constant on the other hand is the ratio of the equilibrium concentrations of the products raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients to the equilibrium concentrations of the reactants raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients

child_mcqs.description: What is the rate constant K of this reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Looking at the initial reaction rates in 1 and 2, [B] has no effect on reaction rate. Comparing 1 and 3, [A] is lineally proportional to the reaction rate as doubling [A] doubled the rate. The rate law for this reaction is thus rate = k[A]. We then take the numbers from reaction 1:

rate = k[A]
0.005 M/s = k*0.05 M
k = [0.005 M/s]/[0.05 M]
k = 0.1 s-1

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following changes would increase the initial rate for the above reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: Increasing reaction temperature always increases the rate of a reaction, but may lower the yield in an exothermic reaction. Decreasing pressure tends to decrease rate because it means the molecules are less pushed together and are less likely to collide and react

child_mcqs.description: If the first step of the reaction is much slower than the second step, the overall rate of the reaction most depends on
child_mcqs.explanation: The slower step is the rate limiting step in a multi-step reaction, thus the first step most determines the overall rate.

answers.description: the difference in rate between the two steps

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is true concerning an equilibrium reaction that starts from reactants only?
child_mcqs.explanation: For the two reactions to reach equilibrium – occurring at equal rates, the forward reaction will have to decrease after its initial rate whilst the backward reaction increases in rate until the both are equal

answers.description: The rate of the forward reaction decreases while the rate of the backward reaction increases until equilibrium is reached
The rate of the forward reaction increases while the rate of the backward reaction decreases until equilibrium is reached
Both the forward and the backward reaction rates decrease until equilibrium is reached
The forward reaction keeps on increasing until no more reactants are present

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
Sulfur dioxide oxidises in the presence of oxygen gas as per the following reaction

(M O= 16g/mol ; M S= 32g/mol)

child_mcqs.description: How many grams of sulphur trioxide are produced by the complete oxidation of 2 mols of Sulfur dioxide?
child_mcqs.explanation: -The stoichiometry of the reaction indicates that 2 moles of sulphur dioxide oxidises to produce 2 moles of sulphur trioxide. Using n=m/M, the mass of SO3 = 160g.

child_mcqs.description: What is the percent by mass of Sulfur in SO2?
child_mcqs.explanation: Sulphur dioxide is made up of 32g/mol of sulphur, and (16 x 2)g/mol sulphur. Thus, 50% is sulphur.

child_mcqs.description: What is the limiting reagent when 32g of sulphur dioxide forms 20g of sulphur trioxide in a reaction that runs to completion?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since 32g SO2 can react with excess O2 to form 40g of SO3, if only 20g SO3 is formed, the oxygen must be the limiting reagent.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 24
stem_mcq.description:
As SO3(g) produced by industrial burning of fuel dissolves in the moist atmosphere, acid rain is produced in the following process: 

SO3 (g) + H2O (l) → H2SO4 (aq)

The table below gives the pH range over which the colour of different acid-base indicators used to test the pH of water changes, as well as the colours they change from and to.

The pKa value of this acid rain water ranges between -2.0 and 1.9 depending on the level of pollution
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: The pka value of -2.0 and 1.92 represent
child_mcqs.explanation: H2SO4 is a polyprotic acid, meaning that it has two pKa values referring to the dissociation of each of its protons (H+). The smaller the value of the pKa, the larger the extent of dissociation – and the stronger the acid – thus the pKa values of -2.0 and 1.9 refer to H2SO­4 and HSO4-, respectively.

answers.description: HSO4- and H2SO4 respectively

child_mcqs.description: A sample of rain water is tested with thymol blue and results in a yellow colour. And the addition of methyl orange to another sample of the same water results in a red colour. What is the pH of this water?
child_mcqs.explanation: The yellow region of thymol blue is >2.8, and the red region of methyl orange is <3.2, thus the pH must lie between 2.8 and 3.2.

child_mcqs.description: What is the oxidation state of sulfur in H2SO4 and HSO3- respectively?
child_mcqs.explanation: H2SO4 is made up of +2 (2 x H) and -8 (4 x O), thus sulphur is +6. HSO3- is made up of +1 (1 x H) and -6 (3 x O), thus sulphur is +4 due to the overall -1 charge.

child_mcqs.description: If a sample of water polluted by SO3 was titrated with a sample of NaOH which of the following represents the titration curve?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since sulfuric acid is a diprotic acid, its reaction with sodium hydroxide takes place in two steps leading to an equivalence point for the donation of each of the two protons. The pH of the solution should start near 1 prior to the addition of any base.

child_mcqs.description:
The reaction of the ionisation of water is as shown below

2H2O → H3O+ + OH-

Table 1 below lists the values of the ionisation constant Kw at several temperatures

From the information above it can be concluded that the pH of water
child_mcqs.explanation:
Kw= [H+][OH-] and since [hydronium] and [hydroxide] are equal, then:

Kw= [H+][H+] = [H+]2

Hence Kw and [H+] increase directly with each other, so a higher Kw means a higher [H+] and so a lower pH. From the table it is clear that at high temperatures, pH decreases. Note this does not mean that water is becoming more acidic - the OH increases by the same amount so the water is net neutral. pH 7 is neutral at standard conditions, but this changes with temperature. Note however that unless a question explicitly states so you should assume that pH 7 is neutral regardless of temperature as this refinement is often excluded for the sake of complexity.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 25
stem_mcq.description: The nickel-cadmium cell battery is an example of a rechargeable battery used in small electronic devices. The hald reactions that take place in this battery are:

child_mcqs.description: When the nickel cadmium battery is discharging the reaction taking place at the cathode is
child_mcqs.explanation: The cathode is an electrode where reduction (gain of electrons) takes place. Nickel oxidises cadmium, thus the reaction at the cathode involves nickel gaining electrons.

child_mcqs.description: When the nickel cadmium battery is recharging the reaction taking place at the cathode is
child_mcqs.explanation: During recharging, what was the cathode is now the anode, and what was the anode is now the cathode, because all the reactions are swapped. So cadmium, which was oxidised during discharge, is now reduced, and hence the reduction of cadmium will take place at the cathode, as the cathode always undergoes reduction, so C.

child_mcqs.description: When the battery is discharging the potential difference measured across its electrodes is
child_mcqs.explanation: Add the potentials of the nickel half reaction (0.5V) and the reverse of the cadmium half reaction (0.4V) = 0.9V

child_mcqs.description: What is the reducing agent in the nickel cadmium battery during discharge
child_mcqs.explanation: A reducing agent donates electrons to another chemical species. It itself gets oxidised - during discharge Cd gets oxidised.

child_mcqs.description: As the reaction is allowed to proceed:
child_mcqs.explanation: The forward reaction is discharge. From the equations given we know that Cd is oxidised and the formation of Cd(OH)2 occurs, so concentration of Cd(OH)2 must increase, and this will be accompanied by a decrease in the cell potential. A.

answers.description: The cell potential will decrease and the concentration of Cd(OH)2 will increase
The cell potential will increase and the concentration of Cd(OH)2 will increase
The cell potential will decrease and the concentration of Cd(OH)2 will decrease
The cell potential will increase and the concentration of Cd(OH)2 will decrease

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
First impressions?

Misleading, of course. As always. But unforgettable; the red glow of his face - a boozer's incandescent glow. The pitted, sun-coarsened skin - a cheap, ruined leather. And the eyes: an old man's moist, wobbling jellies.

But then the suit: white linen, freshly pressed. And - absurdly in that climate - the stiff collar and tie.

'Herr Keller?'

'Mrs Crabbe?'

I stood behind my mother outside his room at the Swan, perched on a wooden balcony overlooking the beer-garden. The hotel - a warren of crumbling weatherboard, overgrown with bougainvillea - was packed, the drinkers and their noise spilling out of the front bar into the garden. Up the stairs, second on the right, a barman had shouted - and every face in the bar had turned and followed us up. One or two drunken wolf whistles had also followed us up; whistles living far beyond their sexual means, my mother later reported to my father, contemptuously.

'This is Paul,' she said, pushing me forward, ignoring the noise below.

The figure in the white suit stood aside from his doorway, and motioned us inside.

'Of course. Your father has told.'

The accent was thick. Continental, my father had described it vaguely. A voice that reminded him of grilling sausages; a faint, constant spitting of sibilants in the background.

'Sit down,' that voice hissed. 'We will talk.'

A problem: how to capture that accent here? Ve Vill talk? It's tempting - too tempting - to slip into comic-book parody. Ve haf vays of makink. . .

If I were less the musician and more the dramatist perhaps I could capture it. No: if I were more the musician, if I had a better ear, I could surely capture it - invent some new notation to better pin those strange melodies to the page. But that looks too much like hard work. And might prove too distracting. What matters is content - what he said, not how.

So, a declaration: from this point in my memoir Keller - Herr Eduard Keller, the maestro - will speak English as well, or as badly, as me.

child_mcqs.description: What is the best description of the reason Paul records Herr Keller’s words in standard English?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is what Paul’s father says about Keller’s voice, rather than a reason for Paul recording Keller’s words in standard English. B, C and D are all possibilities but the question asks for the best description of the reason Paul records Keller in standard English. C is one of the reasons but it is not the main reason. B is the best answer. Paul concludes his musing on how to transcribe Keller’s voice with the words, “What matters is content - what he said, not how.”

answers.description: Her Keller’s voice is redolent of grilling sausages.
It is difficult for Paul to capture Herr Keller’s accent on the page, and what he said is more important than how it was said
It isn't easy to invent a notation system for transcribing Keller’s accent.
Paul enjoys slipping into comic book parody.

child_mcqs.description: Paul’s first impressions of Herr Keller characterise Keller as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The key word in the question is “first.” Paul’s first impressions of Herr Keller are contained in the descriptions of Keller at the very beginning of the passage: “the red glow of his face - a boozer's incandescent glow. The pitted, sun-coarsened skin - a cheap, ruined leather. And the eyes: an old man's moist, wobbling jellies. But then the suit: white linen, freshly pressed. And - absurdly in that climate - the stiff collar and tie.” The word “boozer” means someone who gets drunk frequently. Keller is also described as having “old man’s” eyes. His suit is “white linen, freshly pressed” suggesting that Keller is well dressed. Therefore a) is the best answer.

answers.description: A foreign, unfriendly man, with a voice impossible to capture.
A Continental man, living beyond his sexual means.

child_mcqs.description: From this passage, we can presume that Paul, telling this story:
child_mcqs.explanation: From the opening of the extract, it is established that Paul is looking back on his past experiences, his “first impressions” were misleading. His close relationship with his parents, with them introducing him to Keller and setting up the meeting, is evidence for this scene occurring during his childhood or adolescence. Paul states, “If I were less the musician and more the dramatist” he could better render Keller’s speech, suggesting that he is a musician and not a dramatist. He also talks about how he wishes he had a “better ear”, a musical term. Paul’s attitude to Keller’s German accent, remarking on it, wondering how to transcribe it, suggests that he is not from Germany. Therefore, D is the best answer.

answers.description: Is recalling memories from his childhood or adolescence.
Is a musician and not a dramatist.

child_mcqs.description: Throughout the passage, Paul:
child_mcqs.explanation:
There is no evidence in the passage for b) or c). And while his first impression regarding Keller is not very appealing, disgust is too strong a work, and it is definitely not something he focuses on 'throughout the passage'. Thus d) is incorrect.

Paul does encourage the reader to notice the distance between what actually happened and his description of it. He opens the extract with commenting about how “misleading” his first impressions were, and then telling the reader what these first impressions are. He also tells the reader that despite Keller’s accent, he will transcribe Keller’s words as though he spoke English in the same way that Paul spoke it. This encourages the reader to notice a distance between who Keller “really” was, and the Keller that Paul is describing.

answers.description: Encourages the reader to notice the distance between what actually happened and his description of what happened.
Establishes himself as an unfeeling, artificial character.
Provides the reader with hints that he has a fractured relationship with both his parents.

child_mcqs.description: “And the eyes: an old man's moist, wobbling jellies,” is an example of:
child_mcqs.explanation: Simile is a rhetorical device where something is said to be “like” something else. Here, the eyes are not described as being like jellies, they are described as being jellies. While many students would no doubt look for 'metaphor' as the correct answer, this is not an option, making B the best answer. The quote contains descriptive language, encouraging the reader to imagine what Keller’s eyes were like. There is no rhyming slang used in the quote. “Caricature” is a two-dimensional, exaggerated version of a person, something not suggested by this quote.

answers.description: Descriptive language
Rhyming slang
Caricature

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
Extract from Pham-Ledard et al, Diagnostic and Prognostic Value of BLC2 Rearrangement in 53 Patients With Follicular Lymphoma Presenting as Primary Skin Lesions

Primary cutaneous lymphomas (PCLs) of B-cell origin account for 25% of all PCLs. Three main types of primary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas are recognized: primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma (PCFCL), primary cutaneous marginal zone lymphoma (PCMZL), and primary cutaneous diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (PCLBCL), leg type. PCFCL, representing approximately 55% of all primary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas, is the most common B-cell lymphoma to occur as a primary tumor of skin. PCFCL usually involves the head and neck or trunk, with solitary or grouped plaques and tumors, while multifocal skin lesions are possible. Morphologically, PCFCL exhibits a proliferation of neoplastic follicle center cells, usually a mixture of small/medium and large centrocytes (sometimes spindle-shaped type) and a variable proportion of centroblasts. Architectural pattern is variable along a continuum from follicular, nodular, sometimes focally periadnexal to diffuse growth patterns. PCFCL, even with a predominance of large cells (large centrocytes or centroblasts), has an indolent behavior characterized by a 5-year survival rate of 95% as opposed to the 41% rate of PCLBCL, leg type. Multifocal lesions do not have a poorer outcome than solitary lesions. PCFCL on the leg displays a poorer prognosis, with 5-year disease-specific survival reported at 41%. Skin relapse is observed in 30% to 45% of patients. Recurrence does not affect prognosis and is usually confined to the skin. Secondary extracutaneous dissemination may occur in 5% to 10% of cases. Furthermore, secondary skin involvement by nodal follicular lymphoma (SSIFCL) may share clinicopathologic similarities with PCFCL, especially if skin lesions are the initial manifestation of a systemic disease. Therefore, a negative staging is required to assert PCFCL and to rule out SSIFCL since both diseases require a different treatment.

The hallmark of nodal follicular lymphoma is the t(14;18)(q32;q21) translocation, which consists of a reciprocal translocation between the BCL2 proto-oncogene and the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) gene, leading to the overexpression of BCL2 protein. Therefore, the t(14;18) should be detected either by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for BCL2-IgH breakpoint amplification or by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) for either BCL2-IgH fusion or BCL2 separation or split.

child_mcqs.description: Primary cutaneous follicle center lymphomas (PCFCL) account for approximately what percentage of primary cutaneous lymphomas (PCL)?
child_mcqs.explanation: PCFCLs account for 55% of all B-cell PCLs, whilst B-cell PCLs account for 25% of PCLs. Therefore, PCFCLs account for 55% x 25% of total PCLs. This gives 12.5%, which best corresponds with answer B.

child_mcqs.description: Which feature is associated with a poorer clinical prognosis?
child_mcqs.explanation: Prognostic differences between follicular and nodular PCFCLs are not mentioned, and hence A cannot be verified. Both leg type PCLBCL and leg type PCFCL are associated with a 41% 5-year survival, and hence B is not true. For C and D, it is important to note that multifocal lesions are not associated with poorer prognosis than singular lesions. Hence, the answer is dependent upon location. Leg type PCFCL is associated with a poorer prognosis, whereas the difference between head and trunk lesions are not mentioned. Therefore, the answer is D.

answers.description: Follicular PCFCL as opposed to nodular PCFCL
Leg type PCLBCL as opposed to leg type PCFCL
Multifocal head type PCFCL lesions as opposed to a singular trunk PCFCL lesion
Singular leg type PCFCL as opposed to multifocal head type PCFCL

child_mcqs.description: PCR detects the t(14;18)(q32;q21) translocation through
child_mcqs.explanation: The text states, "... PCR amplification of the BCL2-IgH breakpoint provided positive results". Thus, the test operates via amplification of the BCL2-IgH breakpoint, which is answer C. A and B are detected using FISH. BLC2 overexpression is a consequence of the translocation, but it is not clear whether either PCR or FISH can detect this directly

child_mcqs.description: Negative staging is necessary because?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is found from the last line of the first paragraph, where it states that 'negative staging is required to assert PCFCL and to rule out SSIFCL'. Staging is therefore differentiating PCFCL from SSIFCL. The need differentiation must be because these two conditions can be confused. Therefore, the answer is A

answers.description: It can help determine the prognosis of PCFCL

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
Read the paragraph below carefully, and answer the following questions.

The problem is that “quixotism,” “quixotic,” and their related terms are used so indiscriminately that they have come to stand in as synonyms for virtually all aspects of Cervantes’s prodigious literary influence. Ardila recognizes this problem and attempts at the outset of The Cervantean Heritage: Reception and Influence of Cervantes in Britain to differentiate between “quixotic” (“a narrative which relates the adventures of a Quixote”), “Cervantean” (“when form as been influenced by Cervantes’ novelistic techniques as employed in Don Quixote”), “Cervantic” (“the employment of a quixotic character obsessed with the adventures and stereotypes they have read in romances”), and “Cervantine” (seemingly of or related to Cervantes in general). We can observe, however, that even Ardila’s careful differentiations direct us back into the infinite loop of Cervantes-Don Quixote, the signifier “quixotic” pointing to something formally and stylistically of Cervantes, and the signifiers “Cervantean,” “Cervantic,” and “Cervantine” always referencing the influences of that dominant text in Cervantes’s oeuvre, Don Quixote (1605-15). In other words, so long as “quixotic” is predominantly used in literary studies as a taxonomic term to relate some allusive or structural aspect of a text back to Don Quixote as a source-text, “quixotic” will be conflated with an unwieldy array of allusions, authorial devices, and structural components that can be found not merely in that protean group of texts that has come to be known as “quixotic fictions,” but in countless other novels for which Don Quixote is perhaps a member of the same species (novel), but a different genus.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is the best summary of the main argument in the passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A is what Ardila, rather than the author of this passage argues. The author points out problems with Ardila's argument: "We can observe, however, that even Ardila’s careful differentiations direct us back into the infinite loop of Cervantes-Don Quixote." Answer D is affirmed by the author, but it is not something that the author is arguing - he takes it as given that Cervantes was of immense literary significance. This leaves C and B. While the author does note how "quixotism,” “quixotic,” and other terms are used indiscriminately to stand in for all Cervantes's literary influence, the main motivation behind the passage is to point out how the vagueness of these terms poses problems for literary studies. The key sentence is: "so long as “quixotic” is predominantly used in literary studies as a taxonomic term to relate some allusive or structural aspect of a text back to Don Quixote as a source-text, “quixotic” will be conflated with an unwieldy array of allusions, authorial devices, and structural components that can be found . . . in countless other novels." Therefore B is the best answer.

answers.description: We need to distinguish between the “quixotic,” the “Cervantean,” the “Cervantic” and the “Cervantine.”
As long as the “quixotic” and related terms are used to allude to Don Quixote, they remain unwieldy categories for literary criticism.
"Quixotism,” “quixotic,” and other terms are used indiscriminately to stand in for all Cervantes's literary influence.
Cervantes, and his novel Don Quixote, had a tremendous impact on literature.

child_mcqs.description: What could replace the word "protean" in this passage's last sentence?
child_mcqs.explanation: This is obscure vocabulary, and if you are familiar with the word that's very beneficial. The most likely meaning can also be determined from context, however. "Protean" is used as an adjective in the sentence, therefore A is incorrect. Given the emphasis the author places in the passage on the vastness of Cervantes's influence C is very unlikely. This leaves B and D. B fits best with what the author is saying about the problems with the term "quixotic". "Protean" means variable, changeable and unstable.

child_mcqs.description: When this author discusses the "quixotic" he is talking about:
child_mcqs.explanation: B is incorrect: the quixotic refers to a vast body of texts in literature that allude to or in some way echo Don Quixote, a text by Cervantes, not texts exclusively by Cervantes. Because B is incorrect D must be too. While the quixotic does refer to a complicated body of literary allusions, when the author discusses the quixotic he is talking about a problematic category. The author's main argument is that the "quixotic" is a category that is too imprecise to be a useful term in literary criticism. Since the question asks what the author means when he uses the term "quixotic", A is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
Waiting Room- Gwen Harwood

They hang in some crevice of light,

still wearing the masks they have chosen.

The world contracts to this room.

An old man sits and stares

at a drug house calender,

a view of a tropic beach,

as if it might solve existence.

A child with a comic frowns,

absorbed in fantasy

while his mother beside him hears

his illness grinding its teeth in the dark.

 

The Sister, brisk and white

as a segull, carries in flowers,

then turns her scavenging eye

on a fallen match, a wisp of thread.

 

A woman sighs for the pain

so fastened on to her body

that she cannot think but through it.

Some read, pursuing lost meanings

that fade in the gutters of print,

and some raise their eyes to the flowers’

pale pinks and thorny greens.

But all sit locked apart

assured of their secret possession

that will change them, or be changed,

as one by one they are called away.

It is dangerous to hope.

 

Stirred by a draught from the closing door

cut flowers shake their pitiless heads.

child_mcqs.description: The atmosphere of the waiting room can be best described as one of:
child_mcqs.explanation: The occupants of the waiting room are said to be wearing ‘masks’ and all ‘sit locked apart’ reflecting that each individual is occupied in their own world, with little concern for each other. Therefore, D is the best answer. It is ‘dangerous to hope’, hence C is incorrect. The patients are presented as being more apprehensive, rather than angry about their situation, therefore B is incorrect.

child_mcqs.description: The Sister is portrayed as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The Sister’s ‘scavenging eye’ falls upon the minor imperfection in the otherwise presumably neat and tidy waiting room, rather than on the ailments of its occupants. At no point is she shown to be concerned about the patients, hence A and D are incorrect.  Option B cannot be drawn from the description given in the poem. C is the best answer.

answers.description: Stern but attuned to the patients’ needs.
Attempting to minimise interaction with patients to avoid giving them hope.
More attentive to the site than its occupants.

child_mcqs.description: The flowers are used by the poet:
child_mcqs.explanation: The flowers are carried in by the Sister, who is not depicted as a particularly warm or caring individual. This itself gives a clue that it is not intended to be an optimistic presence in the waiting room.  So A is incorrect. Rather than being a source of connection, the flowers act as a distraction for the patients who can ‘raise their eyes to the flowers’ and further detach themselves from each other.  Hence option C is incorrect. The ‘cut flowers shake their pitiless heads’ just as the patients in their isolation show no pity to each other.  B is the best answer. Option D is not an analogy that is relevant to this poem.

answers.description: To symbolise optimism and hope in an otherwise desolate setting.
To reflect the lack of concern the patients have for one another.
As a means of connection for people who are otherwise strangers.
To show that every rose has its thorns.

child_mcqs.description: The greatest contrast in the poem is provided by:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the context of the poem, option A, B, and C all depict individuals who are lost in their own thoughts, presumably about their own health. Option D on the other is an interaction where the child is absorbed in his fantasy world, with the mother absorbed in her fears for his health. Hence D provides the greatest tonal contrast.

answers.description: Those who read and those who look at the flowers.
The old man and the drug house calendar.

child_mcqs.description: The ‘secret possession’ referred to in the poem is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The key is in the next line of the poem, ‘that will change them, or be changed’. It can be inferred from this that the ‘secret possession’ is the patients illness which can either be cured (be changed) or affect their way of life hereafter (change them). Hence A is the best answer.

answers.description: The illness each patient carries within them.
The hope that everything will be alright.
The confidence that they will receive the best care.
The fear about how their affliction will affect the future

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
Lindsay Foyle, 9 June 2015, New Matilda https://newmatilda.com/2015/06/09/human-rights-safety

Examine the cartoon above and answer the questions below.

child_mcqs.description: What word best describes the cartoon's humour?
child_mcqs.explanation: The best answer is B. The cartoon's humour is satirical: it has a political point behind it. If there is sarcasm in the cartoon (which is debatable) it is directed towards a political purpose, so B is a better answer than A. Option C is a description of a mood the cartoon might elicit, rather than a precise description of the type of humour the cartoon has. The cartoon is not a parody (it is not obviously appropriating or burlesquing another text) so D is incorrect.

child_mcqs.description: Of the following items, which is the least important for the purpose of the cartoon?
child_mcqs.explanation: While D is true, it does not answer the question, which asks which item is least important to the cartoon's message. The question does not aask whether the items are important or not. The bars on the window are necessary to establish that the man on the right is being imprisoned. The safe is important because it signals, in a visual pun, how human rights are being kept "safe" and locked away. The newspaper contributes to the humour, but it is less important than the other two items in the cartoon, and the cartoon's joke and message could function without it. Therefore C is the best answer to this question.

answers.description: All of the above are important in relation to the cartoon's message.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
- Biddle, Developing a Behavioural Model of School Attendance

A finding from the analysis that has implications for both a behavioural model and for Indigenous policy is that children who live in families on income support are only marginally less likely to attend school than those from families whose main source of income is wages and salaries; this difference is not statistically significant. For practical reasons, the Australian Government might focus on income support recipients—these  are the individuals over whom the government has  the greatest control. However, to make a significant reduction in non-attendance, policies need to focus on all Indigenous children.

With this broader focus in mind, it would appear that household stress, housing issues and family crises  are more important predictors of non-attendance than income support. There are practical limits to what governments can do to reduce this stress. However, it is important to keep the potential effect of such stress in mind when designing policies that may increase it—for example, the suspension of welfare payments, policies that encourage mobility, or policies that might affect inter- or intra-family violence.

A model of school attendance would recognise that  the school sector does not appear to have a significant association with attendance once other characteristics are controlled for. There may be other reasons to provide scholarships for students to attend non-government schools, but attendance does not appear to be one of them. What appears to be more important, based on the empirical evidence, is the experience of bullying or being treated unfairly. This highlights that Indigenous children have agency and autonomy. Consequently, any model  of school attendance and policies that flow from it need to be child centred, and take into account the fact that Indigenous children are likely to have their own views on the costs and benefits of attending school. Not only are there ethical reasons for taking these costs and benefits into account, the analysis presented in this paper would also suggest that there are practical reasons

child_mcqs.description: Why is the government focusing upon income support recipients as a means to improving school attendance?
child_mcqs.explanation: It is explained in the first paragraph that the Government targets income support recipients ‘for practical reasons’, as ‘these  are the individuals over whom the government has  the greatest control’. Hence, the answer is A. The government is likely to have some belief in its efficacy and efficiency, and may on some level desire to reprimand those whose children do not attend, but these are not described as the overriding factors.

answers.description: It is demonstrably the most efficacious method
The government considers it the most efficient method
The government desires to financially penalize non-attendance

child_mcqs.description: Which concern regarding suspending welfare payments is specifically raised in the article?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is arrived at in the second paragraph. The author discusses how many factors influence a child’s school attendance, including household stress and family crises. The article then raises the concern of implementing policies that increase these factors, and uses welfare payments as an example. Hence welfare payments may increase household stress and decrease a child’s school attendance. Hence, the answer is A. B and C are possible outcomes, although fairness is not specifically mentioned. D may be true, although the article acknowledges the difficulty of implementing policies that address the key factors surrounding school attendance and A represents a more specific answer.

answers.description: It may exacerbate the problem of school attendance
It is unfair as it creates unnecessary financial hardship for welfare recipients
It is unfair as recipients are not always responsible for their child’s school attendance
There are more effective means for addressing the problem of school attendance

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following does the article suggest may be an effective way of improving school attendance?
child_mcqs.explanation: A and B are both mentioned. However, in the third paragraph it is stated the providing scholarships to attend non-government schools do not improve attendance when taking account of other variables. As mentioned in the previous answers, the author has significant concerns with answer B. This leaves C and D. Whilst indigenous autonomy is also mentioned, the author is saying that the government should acknowledge that Indigenous children do have autonomy, rather than advocating to give them more. Answer C is therefore correct. The author states that school bullying and unfair treatment impacts upon school attendance, and hence improving this should improve indigenous attendance.

answers.description: Providing access for Indigenous children to non-government schools
Restricting welfare payments of caregivers whose children fail to attend school
Improving the school environment for Indigenous children

child_mcqs.description: What is the author’s main criticism of current government policy?
child_mcqs.explanation: The need of the government to consider the thoughts of Indigenous children is clear throughout the passage. At the end of the first paragraph, it is stated that Indigenous children should be the focus of policy. Specifically, the last paragraph provides that policy should be ‘child centred’, and acknowledge that children ‘are likely to have their own views on the costs and benefits of attending school’. Hence, A is correct

answers.description: It fails to consider the thoughts and desires of Indigenous children
It represents an unethical means by which to improve school attendance
It is unlikely to have any effect on school attendance
The government should invest more funding into Indigenous schooling

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description:
- An extract from Snelgrove et al, “Completely out-at-sea” with “two-gender medicine”

Systematic deficiencies in addressing trans peoples’ needs may contribute to social erasure of trans bodies, with the structuring of healthcare delivery playing a significant role in how governments recognise and accommodate trans patients. Additionally, the way in which medical and mental health professionals identify and acknowledge transgenderism might further propagate healthcare access barriers for trans people. These barriers arise when eligibility criteria for specific treatments are based on a specific diagnosis, and also when patients perceive discordance between their lived experiences and a nosological interpretation of these experiences as a medical or mental disorder. In Canada, the tool used predominantly by psychiatrists and other physicians to guide diagnosis of mental health conditions is the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), currently available as a text-revised fourth edition. Transgender patients generally receive the diagnosis of gender identity disorder (GID), which is defined as a strong, consistent cross-gender identification accompanied by persistent discomfort with the assigned sex that is not based solely on a perceived cultural advantage of adopting the opposite sex, and not better explained by other psychiatric diagnoses. Some researchers and members of the trans community have challenged the nosological premise that transgender identity represents psychiatric pathology. Lev (2005) describes how the DSM does not allow for a healthy, functioning variant of transgenderism, and only categorises transgender experience in the context of dysfunction. Additional concerns relate to the practice of establishing GID as a precondition for medical treatment. Dominant narratives of transgender experience are reinforced by the DSM criteria for GID, but these exclude other gender variant individuals for whom transitioning treatment may be of benefit. An ethical implication extending from this is the possibility that patients feel compelled to provide disingenuous histories of their transgender identity in order to ensure treatment, should their actual experiences not align with GID criteria. The GID diagnosis often forms a part of medical and surgical transition related care, and may also influence how physicians and healthcare professionals provide non-transition care to trans patients. A formal diagnosis of GID is not considered an absolute requirement to initiate sex transitioning therapy in clinical guidelines. Nonetheless, sex transitioning therapies are generally preceded by a GID diagnosis, and clinical guidelines do advise assessment of readiness to transition by a clinician with competency in mental health. For this reason, the interaction between psychiatrists and the mental health system and physicians in other medical fields becomes important when considering healthcare barriers for trans patients

child_mcqs.description: Lev (2005) describes which concern raised by the diagnosis of a gender identity disorder (GID)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Lev’s concern is that GID ‘only categorises transgender experience in the context of dysfunction’. This also follows from the article’s assertion that researchers challenge the view that ‘transgender identity represents psychiatric pathology’. Hence, the criticism is that diagnosing a person as having a gender identity disorder implies that there is something wrong with them. This is best aligned with answer B

answers.description: Its place as a precondition for medical treatment
Its categorisation of transgender as an abnormality
Its failure to capture all individuals with gender identity issues
The difficulty of obtaining a GID diagnosis

child_mcqs.description: Why might a transgender patient describe their identity to their doctor in a way that is not entirely true?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage provides that whilst a categorization of GID is not an absolute necessity for therapy, it is generally required. Hence, patients may wish to ensure that they fit within the GID criteria to receive the therapy. The article suggests the possibility of patient dishonesty to receive the diagnosis, stating that ‘patients feel compelled to provide disingenuous histories of their transgender identity in order to ensure treatment’.

answers.description: Because of their failure to understand their identity
To avoid facing discrimination from the doctor

child_mcqs.description: According to the article, how might the healthcare system impact upon transgender persons outside of the medical sphere?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is obtained from the first sentence. The first sentence discusses the social erasure of trans bodies, and states that ‘the structuring of healthcare delivery play[s] a significant role in how governments recognise and accommodate trans patients’.  The sentence is thus suggesting that factors in the healthcare system determine how society views transgender individuals. For instance, if the medical profession defines transgender as a pathology, it may be viewed in this way by society. This answer best aligns with B. Access to sex transitioning therapy is not ‘outside the medical sphere’. C and D are possibilities of healthcare’s interaction with transgender persons, but are not specifically mentioned

answers.description: The healthcare system prevents transgender persons from obtaining access to sex transitioning therapy
The healthcare system impacts upon societal validation of transgender persons
The healthcare system imposes significant stress and cost on transgender persons
Failures in the healthcare system decrease the quality of life for transgender persons

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the extract below, from Charlotte Lennox's eighteenth-century novel, The Female Quixote.

 

Your Ladyship would do well, said Miss Glanville, to persuade People, that Miss Groves, at fifteen, did not want to run away with her Writing-master.

As I am persuaded myself, said Arabella , that Writing-master was some noble Stranger in Disguise, who was passionately in Love with her, I shall not suffer any body, in my Hearing, to propagate such an unlikely Story; but since he was a Person worthy of her Affection, if she had run away with him, her Fault was not without Example, and even Excuse: You know what the fair Artemisa did for Alexander, Sir, pursued she, turning to Sir George: I would fain know your Sentiments upon the Action of that Princess, which some have not scrupled to condemn ---

Whoever they are, Madam, said Sir George, who condemn the fair Artemisa for what she did for Alexander, are Miscreants and Slanderers; and though that beautiful Princess has been dead more than two thousand Years, I would draw my Sword in Defence of her Character, against all who should presume, in my Presence, to cast any Censures upon it.

Since you are so courageous, said Miss Glanville, laughing excessively at this Sally, which, she thought, was to ridicule her Cousin; it is to be hoped, you will defend a living Lady's Character, who may thank you for it; and make the World believe, that her Correspondence with Mr. L------ was intirely innocent; and that she never had any Design to run away with her Writing-master.

Are you resolved, Cousin, said Lady Bella, to persist in that ridiculous Mistake, and take a Nobleman for a Writing-master only because his Love put him upon such a Stratagem to obtain his Mistress?

Indeed, Lady Bella, said Miss Glanville, smileing, you may as well persuade me, the Moon is made of a Cream Cheese, as that any Nobleman turned himself into a Writing-master, to obtain Miss Groves ---

Is it possible, Miss, said Arabella , that you can offer such an Affront to my Understanding, as to suppose, I would argue upon such a ridiculous System; and compare the second glorious Luminary of the Heavens to so unworthy a Resemblance? I have taken some Pains to contemplate the heavenly Bodies; and, by Reading and Observation, am able to comprehend some Part of their Excellence: Therefore it is not probable, I should descend to such trivial Comparisons; and liken a planet, which, haply, is not much less than our Earth, to a thing so inconsiderable, as that you name---

Pardon me, dear Cousin, interrupted Miss Glanville , laughing louder than before, if I divert myself a little with the Extravagance of your Notions. Really, I think, you have no Reason to be angry, if I supposed you might make a Comparison between the Moon and a Cream Cheese; since you say, that same Moon, which don't appear broader than your Gardener's Face, is not much less than the whole World: Why, certainly, I have more Reason to trust my own Eyes, than such whimsical Notions as these.

Arabella, unwilling to expose her Cousin's Ignorance, by a longer Dispute upon this Subject, begged her to let it drop for the present; and, turning to Sir George, I am very glad, said she, that having always had some Inclination to excuse, and even defend, the Flight of Artemisa with Alexander, my Opinion is warranted by that of a Person so generous as yourself: Indeed, when we consider, that this Princess forsook her Brother's Dominions, and fled away with a Lover whom she did not hate; questionless, her Enemies accuse her, with some Appearance of Reason, of too great Imbecility.

child_mcqs.description: What would be the best replacement for “Sentiments” in the phase, “I would fain know your Sentiments on the Action of that Princess”?
child_mcqs.explanation: From replacing “sentiments” with the words suggested we can see that D is grammatically incorrect. Arabella is asking Glanville’s opinion on the actions of the Princess, a way to work this out is to see that he responds to her question by telling her his opinion: “Whoever they are, Madam, said Sir George, who condemn the fair Artemisa for what she did for Alexander, are Miscreants and Slanderers.” A and C make much less sense than B in the context of Sir George’s answer.

answers.description: Thoughts, opinions, feelings
Sadness, melancholy, pain
Triteness, triviality, inconsequentiality

child_mcqs.description: In this passage, who believes that the moon is made of cheese?
child_mcqs.explanation: Arabella does not believe the moon is made of cheese. She assures Miss Glanville that she is shocked by the very idea that she could “compare the second glorious Luminary of the Heavens to so unworthy a Resemblance.” Miss Groves is discussed by the characters, but we are not given any clues as to whether Miss Groves thinks the moon is made of cheese or not. The key to answering this question is to realise that Miss Glanville does not introduce the moon/cheese comparison seriously. When she says “you may as well persuade me, the Moon is made of a Cream Cheese, as that any Nobleman turned himself into a Writing-master, to obtain Miss Groves”, she is saying that is just as ridiculous to claim the Writing-master is a nobleman as it is to claim the moon is cream cheese. When Arabella takes the comparison seriously, Miss Glanville pretends she does believe the moon is cheese in order to make fun of Arabella. Hence D is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: Miss Glanville’s attitude towards her cousin, Arabella, is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Miss Glanville shows no sign of being friendly and loving towards Arabella, disagreeing with her and hoping that Sir George is making fun of Arabella, so D is incorrect. “Amiable” is another word for friendly, so A is incorrect. She might be competitive but she is not despairing. Her response to Arabella’s claims about Miss Groves and her writing master are best described as “mocking and disbelieving”. She makes fun of, and disparages or criticises Arabella’s belief that the writing-master was a nobleman in disguise.

answers.description: Patronising and amiable
Friendly and loving

child_mcqs.description: Arabella’s view of life is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Arabella is romantic, being invested in the reputation of princesses and believing that noblemen frequently assume disguises. She is naïve, taking Miss Glanville’s comparison between the moon and cream cheese seriously. She is not shown to be small minded in the passage (she is interested in astronomy, for instance), nor is she shown to be cynical or sceptical since she has such romantic beliefs. A is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description:
The chart below is from the report "The Forgotten Children: National Inquiry into Children in Immigration Detention" (Australia, 2014). Eighty-five percent of children and parents interviewed for the report indicated that their emotional and mental health had been affected since being in detention. There were no positive responses to detention. Examine the chart carefully, and answer the questions below.

From https://www.humanrights.gov.au/sites/default/files/document/publication/forgotten_children_2014.pdf

child_mcqs.description: Which statement is supported by the chart above?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is incorrect because the information below the chart states that interviewees could provide multiple responses. It is therefore possible that some of the respondents who reported being always worried also reported being always sad/crying and we cannot know from the chart the percentage of children and parents inverviewed who reported being always sad/crying and/or worried. Option B is incorrect because parents as well as children were interviewed. Option D is not supported by the chart, which does not offer a comparison between parents' and childrens' responses. Option C is correct, this is evident from reading the chart and the information beside the chart carefully.

answers.description: 55% of the children and parents in detention who were inverviewed reported being always sad, crying or worried.
9% of the children in detention inverviewed reported having nightmares.
4% of the children and parents in detention interviewed reported self-harming.
Detention is equally distressing for parents as it is for children kept in detention.

child_mcqs.description: Which is the best summary of the information shown in the chart?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is the best answer, summarising what the chart demonstrates. Option B is true, but it does not summarise the chart like the question requires. Instead, it repeats information that accompanied the chart. Option C is shown by the chart, but it is not a summary of the chart's information like the question requires. Option D does not summarise the chart, but instead recommends a course of action.

answers.description: Detention has a negative impact on the metal and emotion well-being of children and parents in detention.
Eighty-five percent of children and parents indicated that their emotional and mental health had been affected since being in detention.
2% of the children and parents in detention interviewed reported 'going crazy'.
Parents and children should be removed from detention.

child_mcqs.description: If 200 parents and children were interviewed for the report, how many of them indicated that detention affected their mental and emotional well-being?
child_mcqs.explanation: The information beside the chart states that eighty-five percent of children and parents indicated that their emotional and mental health had been affected since being in detention. The question asks how many parents and children this would be if there were 200 interviewed. Eighty-five precent of 200 is 170.

answers.description: There is not enough information in the chart to answer this question.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the extract below, from bell hook's essay "Eating the Other: Desire and Resistance" on cultural appropriation:

Within current debates about race and difference, mass culture is the contemporary location that both publicly declares and perpetuates the idea that there is pleasure to be found in the acknowledgment and enjoyment of racial difference. The commodiﬁcation of Otherness has been so successful because it is offered as a new delight, more intense, more satisfying than normal ways of doing and feeling. Within commodity culture, ethnicity becomes spice, seasoning that can liven up the dull dish that is mainstream white culture. Cultural taboos around sexuality and desire are transgressed and made explicit as the media bombards folks with a message of difference no longer based on the white supremacist assumption that “blondes have more fun.” The “real fun” is to be had by bringing to the surface all those “nasty” unconscious fantasies and longings about contact with the Other embedded in the secret (not so secret) deep structure of white supremacy. In many ways it is a contemporary revival of interest in the “primitive,” with a distinctly postmodern slant. As Marianna Torgovnick argues in Gone Primitive: Savage Intellects, Modern Lives: "What is clear now is that the West’s fascination with the primitive has to do with its own crises in identity, with its own need to clearly demarcate subject and object even while ﬂirting with other ways of experiencing the universe."

Certainly from the standpoint of white supremacist capitalist patriarchy, the hope is that desires for the “primitive” or fantasies about the Other can be continually exploited, and that such exploitation will occur in a manner that reinscribes and maintains the status quo.
