Whether or not desire for contact with the Other, for connection rooted in the longing for pleasure, can act as a critical intervention challenging and subverting racist domination, inviting and enabling critical resistance, is an unrealized political possibility. Exploring how desire for the Other is expressed, manipulated, and transformed by encounters with difference and the different is a critical terrain that can indicate whether these potentially revolutionary longings are ever fulfilled.

child_mcqs.description: The best summary of bell hook's argument in this essay is:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the first paragraph, hooks talks about how an “enjoyment” of racial difference can result in a commodification of a non-white “Other,” eg. “Within commodity culture, ethnicity becomes spice, seasoning that can liven up the dull dish that is mainstream white culture.” In the second paragraph, she questions the extent that “desire for contact with the Other, or connection rooted in the longing for pleasure, can act as a critical intervention challenging and subverting racist domination” that is, the extent that white desire for a racialized otherness can subvert a racist society. Hence B is the best answer, it is the most comprehensive and most precise.

answers.description: We must examine the extent white desire for racialized otherness has the potential to subvert a racist society, and if it merely results in the "Other" being commodified and exploited by white culture.
White supremacist culture asserts that blondes have more fun.

child_mcqs.description: Torgovnick and hooks respond to white interest in the "primitive" or the Other with:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option B is correct. With comments such as, "longings about contact with the Other embedded in the secret (not so secret) deep structure of white supremacy”, "Whether or not desire for contact with the Other… can act as a critical intervention challenging and subverting racist domination… is an unrealized political possibility”, hook suggests quite a degree of scepticism. Similarly, Torgovnick quotes that "what is clear now is that the West’s fascination with the primitive has to do with its own crises in identity, with its own need to clearly demarcate subject and object even while ﬂirting with other ways of experiencing the universe". In hook's quote of Torgovnick, Torgovnick does not compare primitivism to food consumption, nor does she suggest that it can challenge a white supremacist capitalist patriarchy. It's usually wise not to strongly criticise the source text in your answer, unless the question is asking you to; so option C is incorrect.

answers.description: Scepticism about its capacity to challenge a white supremacist culture.
Interest in its capacity to challenge white supremacist capitalist patriarchy.

child_mcqs.description: hooks political and phlosophical position is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: B is a distractor, "dilettante" is someone who is a dabbler, rather than someone who has a serious interest in what they are engaged in. The vocabulary hooks deploys shows that she is writing as a cultural critic and an academic. C is wrong, hooks approvingly quotes Torgovnick, who critiques primitivism. It's not clear that hooks is naive. A is the best answer. hooks talks about challenging the patriarchy, suggesting she is a feminist, while she critiques capitalist, racist responses to racial differences.

answers.description: Primitivist, appropriationistic, pluralistic

child_mcqs.description: Of the following, which is bell hooks most concerned with criticising in her essay?
child_mcqs.explanation: The West’s fascination is more a concern of Marianna Torgovnick than hooks. Considering that hooks stance is strongly anti-racist and anti-capitalist and the question is asking what she is criticising, neither c) or d) makes sense. Therefore b) is the best answer.

answers.description: The celebration and commodification of racial difference in ways that do not challenge the white supremacist status quo
The dangers of white supremacist capitalist dominion
The revolutionary longing to resist white supremacist capitalist structures

child_mcqs.description: The best replacement for the word "reinscribes" that does not change the meaning of the first sentence of the second paragraph is:
child_mcqs.explanation: “Reinscribes” means “writes again” but in this sentence, hooks is talking about a “writing again” as a reinforcing, a reinscribing that “maintains the status quo.” Therefore, B is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description:
Examine the cartoon below and answer the following questions.

“Why do you have to be a nonconformist like everyone else?”

(Stan Hunt 1958)

child_mcqs.description: Which of following elements is LEAST relevant to the cartoon?
child_mcqs.explanation: The best answer is A. The cartoon works because of two elements, the scene and the caption. The scene is one of a try-hard bohemian artist (these days we’d call him a ‘hipster’) in an attic being challenged by a conservatively dressed woman. The conformity of the woman is suggested by her outfit, which includes her dress. If she was dressed as a hippie, the lack of contrast between the couple would detract from the scene. It would also make her comment strange, as hippies typically embrace nonconformism. That they are in an attic is suggested by the sloping roof and the dark lighting. The attic setting invokes the struggling-artist-in-a-garret motif. The man is trying to be a nonconformist, hence he sits on the chair backwards. What a rebel! In contrast to these elements, the drink is not as important to the depiction. One could imagine the cartoon without it, while still retaining its punch. Imagine, for instance, him holding a brush or clasping his hand together.

child_mcqs.description: The humour of the cartoon turns on:
child_mcqs.explanation: The best answer is B. The tension gives the cartoon some emotional oomph, which is important no doubt. Moreover, the cartoonist clearly enjoyed making fun of abstract expressionism. But the best answer must the paradox of caption: if everyone is being nonconformist then being a nonconformist is not nonconformist. If the reader misses this they have missed the joke. Answer D is a distractor. What connotation?

answers.description: Tension between the man and the woman

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
Extract from A System for Classifying Mechanical Injuries of the Eye, Pieramice et al

The classification system was based on four specific variables of ocular trauma anatomy or physiology that have been shown to be prognostic of final visual outcome: type of injury; grade of injury, based on visual acuity at initial examination; the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect in the involved eye; and the zone of injury, based on the location of the globe opening in open-globe injuries or the most posterior structure involved in closed-globe injuries

The type of injury refers to the mechanism of injury. In general, the injuries were categorized as those involving blunt force, resulting in globe rupture, vs those involving sharp forces, resulting in globe lacerations. We felt that additional categories should account for intraocular foreign bodies and perforating (through-and-through) injuries because these are specific types of open-globe injuries that differ in prognosis and management from simple rupture or penetrating injuries. Mixed injuries are those that involve multiple mechanisms. Classification of the type of injury should be based primarily on the circumstances of the injury as reported by the patient or witnesses to the incident. The injury mechanism should not be selected on the basis of other classification variables. However, in situations in which the patient is unconscious and there are no witnesses to the injury, the typing of the injury will be based on the overall findings from examination of the patient. In the case of a suspected intraocular foreign body that cannot be confirmed on clinical examination, ancillary testing such as x-ray, computed tomography, or high resolution B-scan ultrasonography should be used to rule out an intraocular foreign body. The ancillary test or tests chosen will depend on the circumstances of the injury and availability at a given center.

The grade of the injury is based on visual acuity of the injured eye at initial examination. Testing should occur at the time of initial examination and should be attempted on injured patients who are able to cooperate. The testing can be done at distance using the Snellen acuity chart or at near with the Rosenbaum card. When possible, all testing should be done with the patient's corrective lenses, with and without pinhole. If visual acuity improves with pinhole, then this is recorded as the visual acuity at initial examination. Visual acuity of no light perception is confirmed with a bright light source, such as the indirect ophthalmoscope, set at the highest intensity while the fellow eye is completely occluded. In rare instances, visual acuity at initial examination cannot be obtained because the patient is intoxicated, comatose, or too young. In such instances, classification of the injury on this variable is impossible. Visual acuity is a physiologic variable and is limited by its subjective nature. Nevertheless, it has proven to be the strongest predictor of visual outcome in globe injuries.

The second physiologic variable in this classification system is the assessment of a relative afferent pupillary defect. This variable grossly measures optic nerve and retinal function. The testing for a relative afferent pupillary defect should utilize the swinging flashlight test. If one pupil is mechanically or pharmacologically nonreactive or cannot be visualized because of media opacity, it can still be assessed by observing the consensual response in the fellow eye. This variable is positive when a relative afferent pupillary defect is present in the injured eye. This variable is negative when an afferent pupillary defect is absent in the injured eye. In monocular patients or patients with bilaterally fixed or unreactive pupils, the injury cannot be classified for this variable.

The zone of injury is defined by the location of the most posterior full-thickness aspect of the globe opening. Zone I injuries occur when the opening of the globe is isolated to the cornea or corneoscleral limbus. Zone II injuries are those that involve the anterior 5 mm of the sclera, so chosen because in most eyes, this location would not extend more posteriorly than the pars plana. Zone III injuries are those that extend the full thickness into the sclera more than 5 mm posterior to the corneoscleral limbus. In cases of multiple corneoscleral openings, the zone is defined as the most posterior opening. In cases of intraocular foreign bodies, the zone is defined at the entry site, whereas in perforating injuries, the zone is defined by the most posterior defect, generally the exit site. The zone of injury can often be determined at the time of initial examination. However, the exact extent of the injury may be more accurately determined, and identification of the zone of injury revised, during the initial surgical intervention

child_mcqs.description: The classification system for mechanical injuries of the eye was chosen on the basis of its?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer comes from the first line, where it is stated that the method was based on variables shown to be ‘prognostic of final visual outcome’. This best corresponds to answer C. A, B and D are also desirable attributes for a classification system, but were not the primary motivator mentioned in the article

child_mcqs.description: A patient suffers an eye injury in a car accident whereby a shard of glass slices through the eye, extending through the full thickness into the sclera. This injury would most likely be classified as a?
child_mcqs.explanation: A sharp force injury is one that lacerates the globe, a blunt force injury is one that ruptures the globe, and a mixed injury has components of both. A glass shard described as ‘slicing’ is likely to best align with a sharp force injury. A Zone III injury extends >5mm posterior to the cornea, such as piercing the full thickness of the sclera. Hence, the answer is D

child_mcqs.description: Assume that there is a consistent link between a positive relative afferent pupillary defect and perforating (through and through) injuries. A finding of a positive relative afferent pupillary defect is of relevance to classifying the type of injury?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage provides that the mechanism or type of injury should be based upon the reported circumstances of the injury, and not on other classification variables (such as a positive relative afferent pupillary defect). However, this information may be relied upon when both the patient is unconscious and no other witnesses are available to provide the circumstances. Hence, the answer is B. A does not exclude the possibility of a witness providing information

answers.description: Any time that the patient is unconscious
When no one can is capable of providing an account of the injury
When further examination provides definitive proof of the cause of the injury

child_mcqs.description: A patient suffers a perforating injury, in which multiple sharp forces enter the eye. On examination, the examiner finds that two sharp forces are isolated to the corneoscleral limbus, but a third enters 3mm posterior to the corneoscleral limbus. This injury would be categorised as in which zone?
child_mcqs.explanation: Of the three sharp forces, two are confined to Zone I, as they are isolated to the corneoscleral limbus. The third enters Zone II, as it is <5mm posterior to the corneoscleral limbus. It is then provided that in the case of multiple corneoscleral openings, the zone is defined as the most posterior opening. Hence, Zone II is posterior to Zone I, and is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: Which category best correlates with recovery?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage provides that the visual acuity ‘has proven to be the strongest predictor of visual outcome in globe injuries’. The grade of the injury 'is based on visual acuity'. Hence, the answer is B.

answers.description: The presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect

child_mcqs.description: For a patient who wears glasses and whose vision improves whilst looking through the pinhole, the visual acuity is recorded as the score obtained?
child_mcqs.explanation: In the grade of injury paragraph, it is provided that ‘[w]hen possible, all testing should be done with the patient's corrective lenses, with and without pinhole. If visual acuity improves with pinhole, then this is recorded as the visual acuity at initial examination.’ Hence, the patient should keep their glasses on and the recorded score is that when looking through the pinhole.

answers.description: With the glasses on and looking through the pinhole
With the glasses off and looking through the pinhole
With the glasses on and not looking through the pinhole
With the glasses off and not looking through the pinhole

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
The passage below is from The Spiritual Quixote (1773):

Mr. Wildgoose, being intent upon his adventurous undertaking, that of preaching for the first time to a mob of holiday clowns at a revel, moved on in profound silence. And though he did not think any premeditation necessary, as he depended upon some supernatural power to give him utterance---yet he could not forbear anticipating, in some measure, the incidents which he should probably meet with on this occasion---nor avoid recollecting how ingeniously Mr. Whitfield spiritualized every circumstance attending his ministration. Thus when he was to preach from the starting-post at Northampton, for instance, "He took occasion to speak home to their souls, concerning our spiritual race." And from the windmill at Bedford---"He exhorted them not to be carried about by every wind of doctrine;" and the like. So Wildgoose was devising with himself how to allegorize the different athletic exercises, which were usually practised on these occasions, and apply them to the best advantage.

To the wrestlers, he intended to preach up the necessity of struggling against flesh and blood; against the world and the Devil; and also frequently to wrestle with God in prayer; as Mr. Whitfield so often did.

The cudgel-players, he thought, he might aptly enough exhort to bruise and "break the head of that old red serpent" the Devil, as St. Austin calls him: and to guard themselves against every attack of their spiritual antagonists ---and the like. 

They proceeded therefore in silent meditation for some time; till at length Tugwell took the liberty to expostulate a little with his master upon the subject. "Please your Worship", says he, "I have been thinking about this same preachment of ours, which we are now going about---since we are almost got to the place, methinks my heart begins to fail me a little. To be sure, it does one's heart good to hear your Worship preach---and talk about justification ---and prestination and reperbation, and---and---generation, and sich like---in our chimney corner---in an evening: for then, as one may say, we have nothing else to do; and nobody to contradict us. But here, when folks are got together---to make merry; that is, to break heads---and to kick shins, and sich as that; methinks, they will hardly have time to hear us preach: and mayhap, they may only laugh at us, for talking about religion at sich a time as this---or belike may pelt us with dirt or horse-dung---and sich as that."

"Ah! Jerry," says Wildgoose, "have not I told thee, how Mr. Whitfield has preached to twenty thousand people at a time, upon Kennington Common---where (as he assures us himself) he was frequently attended by four-score coaches, and numbers of horses; and yet all was hushed, the moment he began to speak---their hearts were melted; they would have plucked out their eyes, and have given them to him; they crowded about him, hugged, and were even eager to salute him!"

child_mcqs.description: A notable literary feature about this passage is the way it contains many examples of:
child_mcqs.explanation: This passage uses several examples of wordplay, for example Wildgoose preaches from a windmill against being ‘carried about by every wind of doctrine’ and preaches to the wrestlers ‘the necessity of struggling against flesh and blood’. The wordplay is highlighted by the italics. Answer A does not work grammatically (you can say a passage is satirical, but not that it uses many examples of satire). The emotive language that Wildgoose might use is subordinate to the wordplay, and therefore not the most notable feature about the passage. D is a distractor, blasphemy is not a literary feature.

child_mcqs.description: From the passage above, it can be presumed that Mr Whitfield:
child_mcqs.explanation: Wildgoose states that ‘Mr Whitfield has preached to twenty thousand people at a time’ and seems to be modelling his preaching technique on Mr Whitfield, ‘recollecting how ingeniously Mr. Whitefield spiritualized’. Therefore A is correct. As for C, given the passage’s gentle mockery of Wildgoose’s preaching, it’s unlikely that as readers we are to take Wildgoose’s description of Whitfield’s amazing preaching seriously.

answers.description: Is a worker of miracles who Wildgoose admires.

child_mcqs.description:
The italics within the passage signal:

I Wordplay

II Idiosyncratic pronounciations

III Misspelt words
child_mcqs.explanation: Most of the words in italics indicated wordplays, but the word 'sich' is italicized to indicate it is a unique pronunciation of the word 'such'. Although the word is misspelt, it is done so on purpose, and the italics is not to draw attention to, or signal, this fact.

child_mcqs.description: How does the author of The Spiritual Quixote treat Wildgoose in the passage above?
child_mcqs.explanation: In the passage the author does not treat Wildgoose with ‘foolish fondness’. B is a distractor. It is unlikely that there will be a correct answer in the GAMSAT involving labelling the author of a text as ‘foolish’. There is no evidence of ‘melancholy’ in the passage either, with the bulk of the passage focused on the wordplay. This leaves A and C. C is the best answer because the passage is not ‘stern’ but rather playful in its treatment of Wildgoose. Wildgoose is not humiliated, for instance, and it’s his words, rather than himself that is the focus of the jokes. While the passage might satirise the rhetoric of ‘Mr. Whitfield’ it does not sternly condemn Wildgoose.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
Review the graph and information below and answer the following questions:

The graph above is based on a collection of 4,275 (mostly book-length) documents. For each year, the number of words in the documents that entered English before 1150 was counted, and then divided by the number of words that entered the language between 1150 and 1699. (We consider only the most common ten thousand words in the collection, and exclude function words: determiners, prepositions, conjunctions, and pronouns.)

Ted Underwood and Jordan Sellers, "The Emergence of Literary Diction" Journal of the Digital Humanities (2012) http://journalofdigitalhumanities.org/1-2/the-emergence-of-literary-diction-by-ted-underwood-and-jordan-sellers/

child_mcqs.description: In the year 1750, which genre used the largest absolute number of old English words?
child_mcqs.explanation: The graph plots the number of pre-1150 words words divided by the number of 1150-1699 words (for each genre and year). Therefore, the graph does not provide us with  information about which genre used the largest number of old words, only which genre had the greatest (or least) number of old words in proportion to new words. Therefore D is correct. It is also worth noting that the graph was based on a limited sample, a collection of only 4,275 book-length documents.

answers.description: There is not sufficient data to answer this question.

child_mcqs.description: What is the significance of the blue and purple line crossing?
child_mcqs.explanation: The graph is a scatterplot, and the lines of best fit - and where they cross - are significant because they indicate trends. Therefore D is incorrect. C makes an assumption, rather than answering the question. A does not recognise that the lines which cross are lines of best fit, so their crossing must be understood as significant in terms of trends. B recognises this, and is the best answer.

answers.description: Poetic and dramatic works had the same proportion of pre-1150 and 1150-1699 words in 1810.

Before the early 1800s, dramatic works, in comparison to poetry, typically contained a lower proportion of English words that emerged in 1150-1699 in comparison to words that emerged before 1150. After the early 1800s, poetic works, in comparison to drama, generally contained a higher proportion of English words that emerged in 1150-1699 in comparison to words that emerged before 1150.
In the early 1800s poetry became more innovative than drama.
As the graph is a scatterplot, there is no significance to the point where the two lines cross.

child_mcqs.description: According to the authors of the article accompanying the graph, in English, "etymology often has social implications . . . the boundary between words with pre- and post-12th-century origins tends to be a social distinction between relatively informal and learned/literate language." If this is the case, what can be deduced from examining what happens between 1750-1800 on the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: The authors statement identifies words pre-12th century with "relatively informal" and post-12th-century words with "learned/literate language". As the graph divides older words by newer words, the higher the plot on the y axis, more "informal" words are used in proportion to "learned/literate language". The graph between 1750-1800 shows the language of poetry began to be increasingly informal, while non-fiction vocabulary became increasingly formal. While poetry is becoming increasingly informal 1750-1800, the line of best fit shows it not to be more informal than drama during this period, so C is incorrect. D is also incorrect as poetry is becoming less, rather than more formal in this period.

answers.description: The language of poetry began to be increasingly informal, while non-fiction vocabulary became increasingly formal.
The language of poetry began to be increasingly formal, while non-fiction vocabulary became increasingly informal.
The language of poetry became more informal than drama.
The language of poetry became more formal than drama.

child_mcqs.description: What is the ratio of pre-1150/1150-1699 words, used in poetry, in the study's sample, in the year 1750?
child_mcqs.explanation: This question makes sure you can distinguish between a point in a scatterplot and the line of best fit. The graph shows that the ratio of old words / new words in poetry in 1750 is 1.8 (rather than 1.4 as suggested by the line of best fit).

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
- Is it conscionable to keep any animal as a pet? The Independent

'Dogs and cats are fine, fish maybe, and snakes and other more exotic animals probably not.'  That's about as close to a consensus as we have for the domestication of animals, but they are judgements largely based on history and tradition and imply that freedom and space are more important to some animals than others.

Wittgenstein famously said that 'If a lion could talk, we could not understand him'. He meant that animal's experience of consciousness is completely different to our own and will always be impenetrably alien to us. That even if they could speak and we could translate their Lionese, it would not mesh with our communications and understanding of the world. He might not have it totally right – various animals' ability to convey messages and experience apparently quite human feelings of excitement, enjoyment, pain and sorrow are clear to see – but this goes to show that exactly what it is animals feel and the quality of their being bothered by their situation is a matter neither philosophy nor science has as yet managed to settle.

If we strip away the factors that muddy the issue of domestication - cases of neglect, the way animals are removed from the wild, problems within breeding - we're left with the core question of whether animals can live as full a life in our homes as they would in the wild. Would dogs not be better off having the run of an entire forest and chasing prey than they are getting to stretch their legs when we can be bothered to take them out and feeding from a bowl?

Maybe the answer is no, but their subordination and any corresponding negative effects are worth it for the joy they bring us? I love dogs, I love their loyalty and affection (or at least what we perceive as loyalty and affection), I like their propensity to jump around like a maniac and I'm fond of their intelligence and their utter stupidity, but am I putting my enjoyment for having a furry companion above their well-being? We might be well beyond that now, with dogs being domesticated centuries ago, but I need to be able to look him in the eye, damn it!

The mystery of exactly what it is animals think and feel may forever elude us, as might our certainty that keeping pets is a justifiable practice.

child_mcqs.description: What point does the first paragraph make regarding an animal’s need for freedom and space?
child_mcqs.explanation: The paragraph states that human choices regarding which animals to domesticate ‘imply that freedom and space are more important to some animals than others’. Therefore, it is suggesting that humans decide which animals require more space and freedom, regardless of an animal’s actual need. Hence, B is correct. This answer is reinforced by the second paragraph, which again discusses the difficulty of interpreting animal needs from a human perspective. The first paragraph also suggests that humans have restricted the space and freedom of various animals. However, this is not the main point of the paragraph, as it is not as challenging to the reader as answer B and does not flow into the second paragraph. A is incorrect as it is assumes that humans are correct in their value judgements, which is the opposite of the main message. D is incorrect as the paragraph implies that humans may incorrectly judge an animal’s needs, but this is not the same as stating that they are actually incorrect.

answers.description: Cats and dogs are more suited to restricted freedom and space than undomesticated animals
Humans make value judgements regarding an animal’s need for space and freedom
Humans have historically restricted the space and freedom of a variety of animals
It is likely that all domesticated animals require more space and freedom than humans provide them with

child_mcqs.description: Why does the author mention removing animals from the wild and problems with animal breeding?
child_mcqs.explanation: It is clear that the author wishes for these arguments to be excluded from the current discussion of domestication. This is not because they are not important, but because they detract from ‘the core question of domestication’ – i.e. whether domestication is correct in any form. Hence A and D are not correct. It is also not because they undermine the author’s argument. The author would likely have chosen to respond to them or not mention them at all if they detracted from his or her argument, and in any case these are issues that likely weigh against animal domestication. Hence, the answer is B. The author is discussing the morality of pet domestication, and feels it necessary to acknowledge common arguments around the issue. He then suggests that even if these common arguments against pet domestication were resolved, the very nature of pet domestication is still a morally challenging issue

answers.description: They are important issues for addressing in answering his core question
They represent commonly discussed issues surrounding animal domestication
They undermine the author’s core argument
The author believes that these are not genuine problems

child_mcqs.description: What is presented as the most important reason for the inability of humans to understand animals?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer to this question comes from Wittgenstein's statement and the author's explanation of this statement. It is stated that we could not understand a lion because 'animal's experience of consciousness is completely different to our own and will always be impenetrably alien to us'. A is incorrect as the article states that even if we could communicate with a lion, we could not understand it. Science and philosophy is mentioned, but do not necessarily correlate with our inability to communicate. C is a common theme in the article, but again does not account for our inability to communicate.

answers.description: The primitive nature of science and philosophy
The failure of humans to consider an animal’s perspective
The insurmountable differences in human and animal consciousness

child_mcqs.description: Why was the parenthesised ‘(or at least what we perceive as loyalty and affection)’ inserted?
child_mcqs.explanation: The author is suggesting that he loves his dogs because ‘of their loyalty and affection’. However, given that a main message of the article is that humans cannot accurately judge an animal’s thought processes, the author actually cannot know whether his dogs are loyal and affectionate. Hence, the author is demonstrating a contradiction in his thoughts, and D is correct

answers.description: To expand upon the sentence’s central idea
To resolve an ambiguity in the sentence’s meaning
To highlight an inconsistency in the author’s thoughts

child_mcqs.description: What does the author suggest is the overriding reason that humans keep animals as pets?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A is correct. In the penultimate paragraph the author suggests (through using his or her own experience) that humans love animals and what they bring them. This feeling overrides everything, even doing what may be right by the animal. B and C may be true, but the author does not suggest that even if humans did understand their needs that they would be benevolent enough to release them. For instance, the author has considered this issue yet chooses to keep his or her dog

answers.description: They do not understand their needs
They do not consider their needs
They do not care for the animal’s freedom

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the poem below. It is from the prologue of a play, Polly Honeycombe (1760).

Hither, in days of yore, from Spain or France
Came a dread Sorceress; her name, Romance.
O'er Britain's Isle her wayward spells She cast.
And Common Sense in magick chain bound fast.
In mad Sublime did each fond Lover wooe,
And in Heroicks ran each Billet-Doux:
High deeds of Chivalry their sole Delight,
Each Fair a Maid Distrest, each Swain a Knight.
Then might Statira Orondates see,
At Tilts and Tournaments, arm'd Cap-a-pè.
She too, on Milk-white Palfrey, Lance in hand,
A Dwarf to guard her, pranc'd about the land.
   This Fiend to quell, his sword Cervantes drew.
A trusty Spanish Blade, Toledo true:
Her Talismans and Magick Wand He broke---
Knights, Genii, Castles---vanish'd into smoke.
   But now, the dear delight of later years,
The younger Sister of Romance appears:
Less solemn is her air, her drift the same,
And Novel her enchanting, charming, Name.
Romance might strike our grave Forefathers' pomp,
But Novel for our Buck and lovely Romp!
Cassandra's Folios now no longer read,
See, Two Neat Pocket Volumes in their stead!
And then so sentimental is the Stile,
So chaste, yet so bewitching all the while!
Plot, and elopement, passion, rape, and rapture,
The total sum of ev'ry dear---dear---Chapter. 

 'Tis not alone the Small-Talk and the Smart,
'Tis Novel most beguiles the Female Heart.
Miss reads---she melts---she sighs---Love steals upon her---
And then---Alas, poor Girl!---good night, poor Honour!

child_mcqs.description: According to the poem, Romance is:
child_mcqs.explanation: This question tests your ability to distinguish between the literal and the figurative. The poem describes ‘Romance’ as a genre that dominated ‘in days of yore’ that is now supplanted by ‘The younger Sister of Romance’, the Novel. While ‘Romance’ is described as a sorceress and a defeated enchantress in the poem, the personification of romance is used to describe aspects of the genre. The poem is not saying that Romance itself is a sorceress or enchantress. Therefore A and D are incorrect. While the author talks about the ‘spells’ Romance casts, it is the novel which is described in the poem as being particularly dangerous for young women. C is the best answer.

answers.description: A genre dangerous for young women to read.
A genre that has been supplanted by the novel.

child_mcqs.description: Which statement does the poem not support?
child_mcqs.explanation: Novels are certainly represented in the poem as telling stories of passion: the poem describes ‘passion’ as being part of ‘The total sum of ev’ry dear---dear----Chapter’. The poem also describes novels as rendering their female readers as vulnerable to seduction. Novel reading makes ‘Miss’ melt and sigh, ‘Love steals upon her’, to such an extent that her ‘Honour’ is possibly compromised ‘good night, poor Honour!’ This implies that female novel readers become softened and beguiled by their novel reading to such an extent that it has the potential to compromise their ‘Honour’. Novels are also represented as fashionable and popular. While romance is ‘no longer read’ or no longer popularly read, it is implied, people are reading ‘Two Neat Pocket Volumes’ (novels) ‘in their stead.’ This leaves C. In the poem, Cervantes is described as vanquishing the sorceress Romance, ‘his sword Cervantes drew. . . Her Talismans and Magick Wand He broke’. However Cervantes does not fight novels in this poem. Therefore C is the best answer.

answers.description: Novels make their female readers vulnerable to seduction through their descriptions of passionate love.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is a contrast between novels and romances that the author does not use in the poem above?
child_mcqs.explanation: This question requires you to understand that contrast involves a comparison that stresses difference. The poem certainly compares the size of novels and romances, the ‘Cassandra’s Folios’ of romance (‘Folios’ referring to a volume about 38cm tall) are compared to the more portable size of novels ‘Two Neat Pocket Volumes.’ Their seriousness is also contrasted in the poem, with Novel, the ‘younger sister of Romance’ described as being ‘Less solemn.’ Their drift is not contrasted, with the poet affirming that novel’s ‘drift [is] the same’ as that of romance. Therefore, since this comparison isn’t a contrast, B is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: 'Sentimental' in the line 'And then so sentimental is the Stile,' means:
child_mcqs.explanation: ‘Sentimental’ in the eighteenth-century meant emotionally moving. This question can be answered by replacing ‘sentimental’ in the poem with the suggested answers and seeing which works best. ‘And then so sentimental is the Stile, / So chaste, yet so bewitching all the while!’ is a description of novels’ power to emotionally effect their readers, therefore B is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
Extract from Sarah Mansfield, Generic drug prices and policy in Australia: room for improvement?

This article discusses supply-side factors that may impact upon the differences in reimbursement prices for generic drugs between Australia and England

Pricing policy

In both Australia and England, community pharmacies are reimbursed by government for drugs purchased based on agreed price schedules (less any patient co-payments), paid extra fees and mark-ups as part of government service agreements, and may retain at least some of the profits from margins between the reimbursement price and actual purchase price. Reducing this profit margin for pharmacies has been the target of pricing policy in both countries.

All PBS-subsidised generics (branded and unbranded) are listed on 'F2' of the PBS Schedule, which comprises off-patent originator drugs and their generic versions, and a small number of patented drugs (remaining patented originator drugs appear on F1). 'Price disclosure' is used to set the price for all F2 drugs (with a small number of exceptions). All NHS-subsidised generics are listed on the Drug Tariff (DT). There are several different groups within the DT - namely Categories M, A and C - each associated with different pricing mechanisms. Category M is the largest group and contains popular and readily available unbranded generics, and reimbursement prices are set using 'price disclosure'.

Both countries therefore use price disclosure to set reimbursement prices for most generic drugs. This method uses data obtained from all manufacturers of a particular drug molecule to determine the sale price to pharmacies (net of incentives) weighted by volume across all doses and forms. The aim is to achieve reimbursement prices that reflect actual market prices, reducing the profit margins for pharmacies on sale of government subsidised drugs. However there are some key differences in how price disclosure is applied in each country.

In Australia, the price disclosure formula includes all generics (branded and unbranded) and the originator for a specific drug molecule, and the reimbursement price is therefore the same for all versions of a drug. In contrast, in England price disclosure is only used for unbranded generics, with different methods used to set prices for branded generics and originators. In Australia, all drugs undergo a mandatory 16% price reduction when first listed on F2, and are not subject to further price reductions until the first price disclosure cycle to obtain price data is complete, which takes at least 18 months (there is a mandated 12-month period of data collection and 6 months of calculations). In England there are no mandatory price cuts on listing of a generic in Category M; however, adjustments to reimbursement prices based on price disclosure calculations occur immediately, often resulting in rapid price reductions. Subsequent price adjustments are made three times a year in Australia, while they are made quarterly in England.

Market size and share

There is limited publicly available information about the Australian and English generics industry, making it difficult to fully appreciate the market dynamics or terms of trade in the supply chain. Although the potential consumer market for generics is obviously much larger in England compared with Australia due to differences in population size, generics' share of the local pharmaceutical markets in the UK is also much larger than Australia by value and volume (10.2% v. 18.5% value, 30% v. 67.4% volume). Unlike Australia, the UK is considered to be a highly competitive market and attractive for generic suppliers. The number of suppliers is much greater in the UK (at least 22 manufacturers and around 34 wholesalers) compared with Australia (10 and at least 5). Analysis is complicated by the relationship between originator and generics manufacturers, with many engaging in the production of 'pseudo-generics' - repackaged versions of the originator sold under a generic name by a subsidiary of the originator company or cross-licenced to a generics supplier. Approximately 18% of Australian generics fall into this category, and it is uncertain how many do so in the UK.

child_mcqs.description: What is described as the main target of government pricing policy in both England and Australia?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option B is correct. The first paragraph provides that the main target of policy pricing is to reduce pharmacies profit margin from the difference in reimbursement price and actual purchase price. The governments therefore wish to ensure that pharmacies are only reimbursed what they actually pay drug manufacturers for the product. Hence, B is the correct answer. The government may indeed like A and D to eventuate, but this is not the target of government pricing policy. The reason that C is incorrect is because there’s a key difference between “profits obtained” and “profit margin”, for drugs that are on the listed pharmaceutical reimbursement schedules. The government does not wish to limit the success of community pharmacies in general and thus C is incorrect.

answers.description: Reducing the manufacturer’s sale price to pharmacies
Ensuring that the reimbursement price reflects the manufacturer’s sale price
Reducing the amount of profit obtained by community pharmacies

child_mcqs.description: According to the article, community pharmacies stand to gain if?
child_mcqs.explanation: Community pharmacies may retain extra profit when the reimbursement price is above the actual price paid. This is because the government is refunding the pharmacy more money than they have spent on the drug. In answer A, the actual price paid for the drug has fallen, but the pharmacy is still receiving the larger reimbursement fee from the government, and is hence making a profit. In B, the reverse is true and the pharmacist makes a loss (or lesser gain). In C and D, although the price paid for the drug has changed, the pharmacist will receive an adjusted amount from the government to match this change, and hence will neither benefit nor lose out.

answers.description: Drug manufacturers decrease the sale price of the generic drug and the government fails to adjust the reimbursement price
Drug manufacturers increase the sale price of the generic drug and the government fails to adjust the reimbursement price
Drug manufacturers decrease the sale price of the generic drug and the government accurately adjusts the reimbursement price
Drug manufacturers increase the sale price of the generic drug and the government accurately adjusts the reimbursement price

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following reasons mentioned in the article may allow Australian community pharmacists to obtain a larger profit margin than their English counterparts?
child_mcqs.explanation: The latter part of the ‘pricing policy’ section discusses differences between Australian and English pricing policy. For Australian pharmacists to obtain a larger profit margin than their English counterparts, Australian policy must cause a greater overestimation of reimbursement price relative to actual purchase price than in the UK. Of the answers, A and B do not reflect this. Answer C, whilst reflecting a difference in pricing, likely makes the Australian reimbursement price lower (by decreasing the recognised manufacturer’s sale price) and hence decreases the profit margin of Australian pharmacists. The answer is therefore D. The failure to make price changes in sufficient time creates the opportunity for the drug price to fall whilst the reimbursement price remains the same. Whilst it could be argued that manufacturer’s price could rise, the line ‘often resulting in rapid price reductions’ suggests that this is rarely the case.

answers.description: The complicated relationship between originator and generics manufacturers in Australia
Australian drugs are listed on the F2, whereas English drugs are listed on the DT
Australia imposes a mandatory 16% price reduction when first listing generic drugs
Australia is slower in making subsequent price adjustments

child_mcqs.description: It is clear from the market share section that
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is apparent from the line ‘unlike Australia, the UK is considered to be a highly competitive market’, which indicates that Australia’s market is not competitive. Answer A is incorrect according to the last sentence of the paragraph. Whilst England has a larger population size and a larger generic share of pharmaceutical sales, there is no indication that they are linked. D is incorrect given the author’s need to mention it in the discussion.

answers.description: Pseudo-generics are more common in Australia than in England
England’s larger population size is causative of the larger generic share of the pharmaceutical sales
Australia does not have a highly competitive generics market
The relationship between originator and generics manufacturers is insignificant

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the extract from 'The Outsiders' by S. E. Hinton.

"Johnny?" I called loudly, and that old wooden church echoed me, onny onny... I looked around wildly, almost panic-stricken, but then caught sight of some crooked lettering written in the dust of the floor. Went to get supplies. Be back soon. J.C. I sighed, and went to the pump to get a drink. The water from it was like liquid ice and it tasted funny, but it was water. I splashed some on my face and that woke me up pretty quick. I wiped my face off on Johnny's jacket and sat down on the back steps. The hill the church was on dropped off suddenly about twenty feet from the back door, and you could see for miles and miles. It was like sitting on the top of the world. When you haven't got anything to do, you remember things in spite of yourself. I could remember every detail of the whole night, but it had the unreal quality of a dream. 

It seemed much longer than twenty-four hours since Johnny and I had met Dally at the corner of Pickett and Sutton. Maybe it was. Maybe Johnny had been gone a whole week and I had just slept. Maybe he had already been worked over by the fuzz and was waiting to get the electric chair since he wouldn't tell where I was. Maybe Dally had been killed in a car wreck or something and no one would ever know where I was, and I'd just die up here, alone, and turn into a skeleton. My over-active imagination was running away with me again. Sweat ran down my face and back, and I was trembling. My head swam, and I leaned back and closed my eyes. I guess it was partly delayed shock. Finally my stomach calmed down and I relaxed a little, hoping that Johnny would remember cigarettes. I was scared, sitting there by myself.

child_mcqs.description: What is the best description of the tone of this passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: The narrator describes himself as feeling unsettled: ‘panic-stricken’, ‘[s]weat ran down my face and back, and I was trembling’. He is in ‘delayed shock’. While the narrator imagining himself as a skeleton could be argued as morbid, the overarching tone of the passage is one of fear and disorientation, ‘it had the unreal quality of a dream’ . ‘Unreal’ is not a tone (it is not an attitude), nor, for that matter is ‘over-active.’ A is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: J. C. is the initials of
child_mcqs.explanation: The narrator calls out ‘‘Johnny?’ . . . I looked around wildly, almost panic-stricken, but then caught sight of some crooked lettering written in the dust on the floor’. The qualifier ‘but then’ suggests that the letter answers the narrator’s call, and gives him a reason to stop looking for Johnny. The letter says ‘Went to get supplies’ and the narrator states that he hopes ‘Johnny would remember cigarettes’. While we don’t know for sure, it isn’t ‘impossible to know’ like D states. We have strong evidence that Johnny is J.C. (along with the fact that Johnny’s first initial is J). A is therefore the best answer.

answers.description: It is impossible to know from the passage above.

child_mcqs.description: The language in this passage is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Colloquial refers to everyday or slang language. There is colloquial language in the passage, ‘pretty quick’ and ‘fuzz’ (for police). This also shows that the language is not formal, or refined. ‘Infantile’ means childish or juvenile, and while the narrator is young the language is not strikingly immature. The language is also not ‘archaic’, that is, or ancient or old fashioned.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
New Class of 'Generic' Drugs could jeopardise patient safety

This week, the Federal Government changed legislation to allow chemists to dispense cheaper versions of biologic drugs (known as 'biosimilars'), despite warnings from consumer groups and pharmacy companies that patient safety could be compromised.

Biologics and biosimilars

Biologic medicines - which use living organisms to deliver therapeutic treatments - have become increasingly popular in the last decade to treat arthritis, diabetes and cancer. Biosimilar medicines are not exactly the same as the biologics they replace because it is not possible to make an exact copy of a medicine made from living organisms. While these cheaper medicines are safe, there are concerns switching from a biologic to a biosimilar may pose some risks to patients, and doctors say it should only be done under medical supervision. The government stands to save $880 million if it can shift patients onto the cheaper drugs, and this week changed legislation to allow a chemist to switch the medicine when a patient presents a script in the same way they can substitute cheaper generic drugs.

Arthritis & Osteoporosis NSW's stance

Our CEO Jannine Jackson recently wrote to the Health Minister about the need for more clinical evidence on the safety and effectiveness of patients switching between a biologic and a biosimilar, however a response is yet to be received.

“We don’t believe this move is in the best interest of our Members,” Jannine said. “It’s becoming increasingly obvious that for the sake of saving money the government is willing to bypass best practice when it comes to patient safety. Until we have more clinical evidence regarding the safety and efficacy of switching, people who are already receiving a biologic medication should not be switched at the pharmacy to the biosimilar version. We believe that patients and their prescribing doctor need to make an informed decision. We welcome new drugs with the potential to reduce health system costs but any new medication needs to be treated with caution.”

A Senate inquiry investigating the Government’s overhaul of drug pricing and latest community pharmacy agreement yesterday heard concerns from the pharmaceutical industry. Medicines Australia’s chief executive, Tim James, said more research was needed and told a Senate committee the move was “out of step” with the rest of the world. “Our concern is what is the evidence base, the decision making process, the mechanism by which that substitution is going to be assured to be safe and in the interests of patients,” he said.

Consumers Health Forum policy manager Josephine Root agreed the introduction of biosimilars to Australia is premature. “We’ve had a number of representations from people who’ve taken a long time to get onto an effective biologic and I’m worried they’ll have to switch to a biosimilar and they’re not sure of the effect,” she said.

Arthritis & Osteoperosis NSW, 19 June, 2015

child_mcqs.description:
What is an advantage of biosimilars over biologic drugs?

  1. They are used to treat arthritis, cancer and diabetes.
  2. They are cheaper.
  3. They are more effective.
  4. They are safe.
child_mcqs.explanation: Biosimilar drugs are used to treat arthritis, cancer and diabetes, but so are biologic drugs, so this is not an advantage of biosimilar drugs over biologics. The article affirms that the biosimilar drugs are cheaper (this is the reason they are being rolled out). The article expresses concerns that biosimilar drugs might be less effective than biologic drugs. The article also states that biosimilars are safe to use, but it does not suggest that they are safer than biologics, and the heading, for instance, suggests the opposite. Since the question asks for advantages of biosimilar over biologic drugs D is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: The tone of this article is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The article is cautious about the introduction of biosimilar drugs. The article’s title, for instance, is “New Class of 'Generic' Drugs could jeopardise patient safety”. The article treats the new biosimilar drugs with caution and is concerned about the patients who will be encouraged to switch to them from their biologic drugs. Caustic means sarcastic in a bitter, corrosive way. Melancholy means depressed. While this article is not happy about patients to switching to biosimilar drugs, it is not really caustic and melancholy. The article is arguably informed, but informed is not really a tone. Nor is it “jocular” which means joking, humorous or playful. While it is critical, it is not “hysterical,” or wild and emotive. Therefore A is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: The position expressed by the Arthritis Australia CEO in relation to the change from biosimilars to biologics is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The CEO is negative, rather than positive about the change from biosimilars to biologics. For example, she states, We don’t believe this move is in the best interest of our Members,” Jannine said. “It’s becoming increasingly obvious that for the sake of saving money the government is willing to bypass best practice when it comes to patient safety.” She is not “strident but despairing”, strident means harsh and shrill. This leaves A and C. The CEO does not greet the rolling out of biosimilar drugs with cautious expectancy: she does not seem to believe that the biosimilar drugs will help patients, only that they will reduce costs for the government. She is very critical about the switch to biosimilar drugs, but measured in her criticism: “We welcome new drugs with the potential to reduce health system costs but any new medication needs to be treated with caution.” Therefore C is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: What, according to this article, are some properties of biosimilar drugs?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article describes biosimilar drugs as a cheaper alternative to biologic drugs. Therefore, A is incorrect. The article also states that, “Biosimilar medicines are not exactly the same as the biologics they replace because it is not possible to make an exact copy of a medicine made from living organisms”. Therefore D is incorrect. The article also suggests that switching to them from biologic drugs without medical supervision is unsafe. The article states: “there are concerns switching from a biologic to a biosimilar may pose some risks to patients, and doctors say it should only be done under medical supervision”. Therefore, B is the best answer.

answers.description: They can treat arthritis, treat cancer and are expensive.
They can treat cancer, treat diabetes and can be unsafe.
Switching to them from biologic drugs without medical supervision is safe.
They are an exact copy of a medicine made from living organisms.

child_mcqs.description:
According to this article, who does not support the switch to biosimilar from biologic drugs?

I Sussan Ley

II The Australian Rheumatology Association

III The federal opposition

IV Tim James

V Josephine Root
child_mcqs.explanation: The article does not mention the federal opposition. Therefore III is incorrect. The article also does not mention the Australian Rheumatology association. According to the article, Sussan Ley is in favour of the switch, and Tim James and the Consumers Health forum are against it. Therefore D is the best answer.

sections.title: Section III - Reasoning in the Biological and Physical sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) belongs to the viral family Retroviridae. Like all enveloped viruses, the binding of viral glycoproteins to host cell proteins increases membrane proximity (thereby permitting the virus capsid to enter the host cytoplasm).

Unique to the Retroviridae is the presence of an enzyme called reverse transcriptase; essentially, this converts RNA to a form of DNA. When combined with HIV-encoded integrase (which facilitates the integration of the newly-formed 'viral' DNA into the host chromosome), HIV is able to stably exist within the host cell (and corresponding daughter cells) for more than fifty years.

After integration, the virus 'hijacks' the cellular machinery to produce multiple virions, which are released with the death of the cell (lytic cycle).
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: Which enzyme performs the opposite action of reverse transcriptase, as per the typical central dogma of genetics?
child_mcqs.explanation:
B is correct. RNA polymerase uses a DNA template (the template strand) to produce mRNA, thereby directly opposing the reverse transcriptase-mediated production of cDNA from an RNA template.

Note: after HIV vDNA is integrated, it uses RNA polymerase, as per the central dogma!

child_mcqs.description:
HIV is associated with an exceptionally high mutation rate (courtesy of its RNA nature), which has several implications in terms of the development of antiviral resistance, and the difficulty in producing an effective vaccine.

Why is RNA more susceptible to mutation?
child_mcqs.explanation:
B is correct. The absence of stable bonding between the two strands allows mutations to accumulate unrecognised in the single-stranded RNA.

A is incorrect, as phosphodiesterase bonds are of uniform strength, and C is incorrect as DNA replication mechanisms have little to do with RNA stability (this compares DNA replication with repair mechanisms to DNA replication without repair)

answers.description: Impaired interstrand hydrogen bonding (uridine poorly binds adenine)
The absence of DNA replication proof-reading mechanisms

child_mcqs.description:
HIV therapy takes the form of HAART (Highly Active Anti-Retroviral Treatment), which targets key enzymes used only by the virus (this reduces the effect on host cells and therefore decreases the burden of side effects).

Which is not a component of HAART?
child_mcqs.explanation:
C is correct. Ligase is one component of many normal DNA repair mechanisms, and thus would not feature in HAART (due to the excessive apoptosis resulting from incomplete DNA repair).

A and C are implied in the opening text, and D is another form (for those interested, it prevents the fusion of the lipid envelope with the lipid bilayer of the host, as mentioned in the opening text).

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
Enzymes can largely be thought of as biological catalysts. As with any catalyst, one of the principal functions of enzymes is to increase the rates of biochemical reactions. The activity of many enzymes can be generalised as follows:

S + E ↔ SE → E + P

The above equation describes an enzyme and its substrate reversibly associating, after which the substrate is converted into the product of the reaction and is released. This frees the enzyme to further convert other substrate molecules. Enzymes which follow this pattern obey what is termed Michaelis-Menten kinetics. The graph below is typical of an enzyme that follows these kinetics. Specifically, the graph shows the resultant reaction velocity (amount of product produced in a given time), for a fixed concentration of enzyme, across a range of substrate concentrations. Also shown is the equation which governs this relationship.

v – reaction velocity

Vmax – theoretical maximum velocity of the reaction (for a given enzyme concentration)

[S] – substrate concentration

Km – substrate concentration at which half of the enzyme’s catalytic sites are occupied (when v = Vmax/2)

 

By constructing graphs of Michaelis-Menten kinetics over a range of experimental conditions, it is possible to infer how those conditions impact upon enzymatic activity. Changing conditions can alter the conformation of enzymes resulting in changes to substrate binding (S + E ↔ SE), catalytic activity (SE → E + P) or both. This is dependent on the site and severity of the conformational change. Enzyme activity can also be altered by chemical modulators, as is the case with many pharmaceuticals. This modulation may occur through conformational change of the enzyme and/or otherwise altering the interaction between an enzyme and its substrate.

child_mcqs.description: Internal temperature is strictly controlled in humans. This is primarily because small variations in temperature can dramatically alter the conformation of enzymes. What would be true of a typical enzyme catalysed reaction in a human, above normal body temperature?
child_mcqs.explanation: As per the information in the question, we are interested in what changes occur to an enzyme catalysed reaction above normal temperature. Heat is said to dramatically change the conformation of enzymes. It is thus reasonable to assume that both substrate binding and catalytic activity will be impacted. Intuitively, this will lower Vmax. What is less intuitive is that the conformational change will actually increase Km. Recall that Km is the [S] where half of the binding sites are occupied. A disruption of those sites makes it more difficult for substrate to bind. This means that a higher [S] is required to get the binding sites to 50% occupancy and so Km is increased.

answers.description: Km is increased and Vmax is increased
Km is increased, but Vmax is decreased
Km is decreased, but Vmax is increased
Km is decreased and Vmax is decreased

child_mcqs.description: The following graph shows the same enzymatic reaction repeated in the presence of varying concentrations of an inhibitor (a negative modulator). What is the most likely mechanism by which the inhibitor operates? Assume that the maximum reaction velocity for each curve is gradually converging to the same value.
child_mcqs.explanation:
The curves depicted are sufficient to illustrate that the inhibitor increases the Km, but does not change the value of Vmax - all four curves are tending towards the same asymptote, albeit at different rates. Despite the lack of labels, the inhibitor must be serving to increase the Km (as opposed to increasing it) as it is an “inhibitor”. Recall that the definition of Km is the [S] where half of the catalytic sites are occupied. A larger Km thus represents a reduced capacity for the substrate to enter the substrate binding site and complex with the enzyme. This effect however can be overcome however with higher concentrations of substrate.

This question can alternatively be answered by eliminating the other possible answers. The fact that Vmax is the same for each curve means that the inhibitor is not compromising the catalytic activity of the enzyme. This immediately rules out B, C as possibilities. As there multiple curves are present, representing different inhibitor concentrations, it is reasonable to conclude that the inhibitor does not impact Vmax and increases the Km without needing a curve depicting the original reaction. This excludes D as a possibility.

answers.description: The inhibitor impedes the formation of the enzyme-substrate complex
The inhibitor impedes the catalytic activity of the enzyme
The inhibitor impedes both complex formation and catalytic activity
The curve depicting the uninhibited reaction needs to be present to allow comparison

child_mcqs.description: Fitting a curve of best fit to the Michaelis-Menten equation can be accomplished readily by computer programs. Before the development of this technology however, it was necessary to linearize the data to aid in analysis. A Lineweaver-Burk plot was one common linearization and was constructed by conducting a reciprocal transformation on each axis of the MM plot (y-axis transformed from v to v-1 and x-axis transformed from [S] to [S]-1). On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the value of the y-intercept is equivalent to what?
child_mcqs.explanation:
This question can be solved without having to manipulate the MM equation. Recall that the definition of the y-intercept is the value of y when x=0. According the transformation used to generate the Lineweaver-Burk plot, the x-axis is now in 1/[S]. Thus, x=0 when [S] is infinite. This happens to be the theoretical [S] at which Vmax is reached. Given that the y-axis is now 1/v, the y value of the y-intercept must be 1/ Vmax or equivalently Vmax-1.

Alternatively, you can rearrange the question as explained in the answer for question 4.

child_mcqs.description: The slope of a Lineweaver-Burk plot (see Question 3 for definition) is equivalent to what?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Unlike the last question, finding the answer in this instance requires manipulation of the MM equation. This question is heavily maths based and requires familiarity with algebraic manipulations. The starting point is to first consider the general equation for any line y=mx+b. x and y are provided by the axes of the graph and b (the y-intercept) was determined in the previous question. This leaves:

(1/v)=m(1/[S])+(1/Vmax)

In the introductory information, the relationship between v, Vmax and Km is provided in the MM equation and can be substituted in for v. Note that it is the inverse that is being substituted.

(Km+[S])/(Vmax[S])=(m/[S])+(1/Vmax)  {need a common denominator on the right side}
(Km+[S])/(Vmax[S])=(m/[S])=(mVmax+[S])/(Vmax[S])  {Vmax[S] common to both sides can be removed}
Km+[S]=mVmax+[S]  {[S] common to both sides can be removed}
Km=mVmax
m=Km/Vmax – equivalent expression to B

Alternatively, you can invert the M-M equation to get
1/v = (Km + [S])/Vmax[S]
1/v = Km/Vmax[S] + [S]/Vmax[S]
1/v = (Km/Vmax)*1/[S] + 1/Vmax
This an equation in y = mx+b form, where y = 1/v, x = 1/[S], gradient m = Km/Vmax and y-intercept b = 1/Vmax.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
A buffer solution contains an acid and its conjugate base in a dynamic equilibrium which shifts to resist a change in pH. They have an optimum capacity to resist pH change at the pKa value.

For example acetic acid/acetate buffer system is a common example with a pKa = 4.76

CH3COOH + OH- ⇋ CH3COO- + H2O

The pKa value is the pH at which the concentration of HA = A- (Here [CH3COOH] = [CH3COO-]). The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation allows the pH of buffer system to be calculated using the pKa.

pH = pKa +log([A-]/[HA])
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: A solution of acetic acid and acetate has a pH of 6.76. If the concentration of acetate is 0.1 molL-1, what is the concentration of acetic acid?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A general tip for buffer questions is to look at the pH conditions relative to the pKa. If they are more acidic than the pKa the protonated version will be favoured. If they are more basic the deprotonated molecule will be favoured.

Know:

pH = pKa + log([acetate]/[acetic acid])

6.76 = 4.76 + log([0.1molL-1]/[acetic acid])

2 = log([0.1molL-1]/[acetic acid])

102 = ([0.1molL-1]/[acetic acid])

100[acetic acid] = 0.1molL-1

[acetic acid] = 0.001molL-1

child_mcqs.description:
Table 1 shows the pKa values of a variety of buffer systems.

Table 1

If the concentration of A- in a solution is 0.1 molL-1 and the concentration of HA is 1 molL-1, and the resulting pH 9.25, what buffer system is being used?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Solve this question by substituting in the values into the HH equation.

Note only bicarbonate ion/carbonate make sense as its pKa values is about the given pH and the protonated form is favoured.

pH =pKa +log([A-]/[HA])

9.25 =pKa + log(0.1)

9.25 = pKa - 1

pKa = 10.25

child_mcqs.description:
In the human body the CO2/HCO3- buffer system helps regulate the pH of blood.

CO2 + H2O ⇋ H2CO3 ⇋ HCO3- + H+

because H2CO3 dissociates so quickly dissolved CO2 is effectively treated like an acid and the following expression may be derived:

pH = 6.1 + log([HCO3-]/(pCO2)(0.03))

Note pCO2 is the partial pressure of CO2 (in mmHg) and 0.03 is a solubility constant (mmHg-1)

Based on the information given which of the following processes is most likely help increase the pH of someone suffering from acidosis, an excess of protons in the blood?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A is correct because increasing respiration removes CO2 in the lungs, thereby decreasing it in the blood stream. This shifts the equilibrium to the left increasing the pH.

Answers C and D are not based off information in the question and if anything increase blood pH.

answers.description: Increasing the respiration rate to decrease the partial pressure of CO2 in the lungs
Decreasing the respiration rate to increase the partial pressure of CO2 in the lungs
Increasing the rate of H+ reabsorption at the kidneys

child_mcqs.description: A patient has a blood pH of 7.2. Assuming [HCO3-] = 30mmolL-1, which of the following is closest to the partial pressure of CO2 in their blood?
child_mcqs.explanation:
pH = 6.1 + log([HCO3-]/(pCO2)(0.03)) 

7.1 - 6.1 = log([0.03]/(pCO2)(0.03)) Note the 0.03 values cancel

1 = log(1/pCO2)

10 = 1/pCO2

pCO2 = 0.1 mmHg

Note the calculation did not need to be done if you looked at the potential answers and realized the value must be less than 1.

child_mcqs.description:
A diprotic acid has the following equilibrium:

H2A + 2H2O ⇋ HA- + H3O+ + H2O ⇋ A2- + 2H3O+

pKa of H2A = 3.1

pKa of HA- = 9.4

Under which conditions does the A2- ion primarily exist?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Remember at a pKa the concentration of the protonated and deprotonated acid forms are equal. Therefore at pH 9.4 [HA-] = [A2-]

Beyond pH 9.4 the deprotonated A2- form dominates. Alternatively, you can think of this in terms of the equilbria. Low pH increases [H+] and so shifts equilbria to the left, so a high pH would achieve the opposite effect.

answers.description: Cannot be determined from the given information.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
Greg and Jane sit on a see-saw as shown. The see-saw is perfectly horizontally balanced between the both of them. Greg is at a distance, a m from the fulcrum of the see-saw and Jane is at a distance, b m from the fulcrum. Given a = 2m, b = 3m.

The following formula may be used:

`tau = Fxxr`

where `tau` is torque, `F` is Force and `r` is the perpendicular distance from the line of action of the force to the pivot point being considered.

child_mcqs.description: What is the ratio of Gregs mass to Jane's mass?
child_mcqs.explanation:
As the see-saw is perfectly horizontal, and balanced, torque in the clockwise direction and torque in the counterclockwise direction are equal.

let `M` = Greg's weight and `N` = Jane's weight

The clockwise torques must equal the counterclockwise torques:

`2M = 3N`

`M/N = 3/2`

Therefore, the ratio of Greg's mass to Janes's mass = 3:2

child_mcqs.description: Greg and Jane remain seated at the same positions (a = 2m and b = 3m). What would happen if the fulcrum is moved from it's original position to 1m towards Greg? Which of the following diagrams show the likely outcome?
child_mcqs.explanation:
let M = Greg's weight and `N` = Jane's weight, and `M/N = 3/2` as before, making `M = 3/2 N`

as the fulcrum has moved 1m toward Greg, a =1m and b = 3m

Note: `asin(theta) "and" bsin(theta)` represent the distance to the fulcrum which is perpendicular to the force, where `theta` is of the same value and represents the angle between the direction of the force and a/b. 

`"Clockwise torque" = M(1sin(theta)) = 3/2Nsin(theta)`

`"Counterclockwise torque" = N(4sin(theta)) = 4Nsin(theta)`

Counterclockwise torque is of higher value. This means the see-saw will tilt towards Jane's side.

child_mcqs.description: What is Jane's weight if Greg's weight is 600N? Using any of the diagrams above may be helpful.
child_mcqs.explanation:
As found above, ratio of Greg's mass to Jane's mass = 3:2

Therefore, Jane's weight `= 2/3 (600) = 400` N

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
HLA-A refers to a subcategory of surface markers found on all nucleated cells in the human body. Functionally, they are responsible for presenting a sample of intracellular proteins; in the event of viral infection or malignancy, the expression of antigenic proteins indicates to specific 'tasting' immune cells that an abnormality is present.

The immune response to this antigenic presentation is complex, and following the involvement of multiple cell types and secretion of cytokines, cytotoxic cells are responsible for inducing apoptosis of the affected cell. The predominating cytotoxic cell type is the cytotoxic T-cell (TC cell).

However, some viral (particularly Herpes viruses) and some other old and successful intracellular pathogens evade this immune respose through the down-regulation of HLA-A molecules.

In response to this, Naural Killer cells recognise this down-regulation through many pathways, including an increased HLA-E:HLA-A ratio (HLA-E is constitutively stable acorss all nucleated cell types). Any cell with reduced HLA-A expression consequently undergoes cytotoxic apoptosis.

child_mcqs.description: Which cell type does not normally express HLA-A molecules?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is correct. Erythrocytes are not nucleated!

answers.description: All of the above express HLA-A molecules

child_mcqs.description: As a cytotoxic T cell brushes past a malignant cell, only one of the many HLA-A molecules is expressing an abnormal protein sample. What's the most likely outcome?
child_mcqs.explanation: B is correct. A could occur, but the phrase 'brushes past' strongly implies some degree of (even transient) binding. C is also possible, but we're looking at one of many (hence, lots of immune cells are needed to kick the immune response off). D highlights that NK cells are indeed immune cells, but 'one of the many' suggests there's a normal amount, and thus HLA-A is not down-regulated.

answers.description: The immune cell is unable to bind to the normal receptors, and nothing happens.
The immune cell transiently binds and 'tastes' the cell, but finding nothing wrong on the sampled HLA-A molecule, it continues onwards.
The immune cell transiently binds and 'tastes' the HLA molecule exhibiting the abnormal peptide, but due to specificity, binding is inadequate and the immune cell continues onwards.
The immune cell detects a relatively high proportion of HLA-E, and induces cellular apoptosis.

child_mcqs.description: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a functional deficiency of NK cells. What are the likely consequences?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is correct. According to the introduction, HLA-A allows detection of intracellular abnormalities, such as viruses, other intracellular pathogens (such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and malignancies. A is explicit in the information, C should also be considered as malignancies are reknowned for altering patterns of gene (and surface protein) expression, particularly in something as proliferative as a lymphoma. Furthermore, TB is arguably the definition of an 'old, successful intracellular pathogen'.

child_mcqs.description:
The cytotoxic response is again complex, with many pathways inducing apopotosis. One of these apoptotic pathways involves the binding of the cytotoxic T-cell's FasL to the affected cell's Fas surface protein (all nucleated cells express Fas).

Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) involves the production of defective Fas proteins. What is a likely consequence?
child_mcqs.explanation:
D is correct. A is unlikely, as other mechanisms will (less decisively) control the viral infection. B isn't really relevant, especially given platelets aren't nucleated. C is unlikely, as while Osteoclasts do use Fas-FasL binding, it's one of many functional pathways.

Hopefully this question shows that 'partial compensation' is usually a good option, and that even though the first answer's tempting, read them all.

answers.description: Clotting due to the gradual accumulation of platelets

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Redox reactions are chemical reactions which involve changes in the oxidation states on two or more atoms. The term redox is derived from the two complementary processes which occur in the reaction, reduction and oxidation. Reduction is defined as gain of electrons and oxidation refers to loss of electrons. A galvanic cell operates by splitting these two reactions into what are termed half-cells. Doing so forces the electrons which are normally transferred between the reduction and oxidation reactions to first traverse an electrical circuit. Thus galvanic cells are capable of providing electrical energy.

Half-cells are comprised of electrodes bathed in a solution. For example, a silver half-cell will have an electrode made of silver immersed in a solution containing silver ions. An electric potential is produced by connecting two half-cells with different reduction potentials. When connecting two half-cells, the half-cell with the largest reduction potential will undergo reduction, whereas the half-cell with the smallest reduction potential will undergo oxidation.

The total potential of any galvanic cell can be found by using the following equation:

Ecell = Elarger half-cell reduction potential – Esmaller half-cell reduction potential

For metal containing half-cells at 25 C, the Ehalf-cell can be found using this simplified equation, where [M] is the concentration of a metal in M and n is its charge in solution:

Ehalf-cell = E° - (0.05918/n)·log [Mn+]
