child_mcqs.description: How much time has elapsed in between the moment Handel loses his hold and the moment he comes to a complete halt at 9.6m above ground level? To facilitate calculations, use g = 10 m/s2 for this subquestion. Also assume that Handel free-falls from rest.
child_mcqs.explanation:
To obtain the time elapsed, consider the time Handel loses his hold until the time he reaches the rock as a separate event from the time Handel reaches the rock until the time he stops completely. 

The distance covered from the time Handel loses his hold until the time he reaches the rock = `11.25 - 10 = 1.25` m.

Using `s = ut + 1/2 at^2` (Note: u = 0m/s as he is falling from rest)

`1.25 = 1/2(10)t^2`

`t = sqrt(25/100) = 0.5 s`

Final velocity when Handel reached the rock, v

`v^2 = u^2 + 2as = 0 + 2xx10xx1.25 = 25`

`v = 5 "ms"^-1`

Distance covered from the time Handel reaches the rock until the time he stops completely `= 10 - 9.6 = 0.4` m

Using `s = 1/2 (u+v)t`

`0.4 = 1/2xx(5+0)xxt` (Note: v = 0m/s)

`t = 0.16` s 

Total time elapsed `= 0.5 + 0.16 = 0.66` s

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
Muscle fibers adapt to long-term changes that occur in the muscle fibers, enabling them to respond most efficiently to the types of demands placed on the muscle. Regular aerobic exercise, such as long-distance jogging or swimming promotes changes within the oxidative muscle fibers to enhance aerobic respiration. Muscles fibers adapt to use oxygen more efficiently to better endure prolonged activity without fatiguing without changing in size. The actual size of the muscles can be increased by short-duration, high intensity anaerobic exercise, such as weight lifting. The muscle enlargement comes primarily from an increase in diameter (hypertrophy) of the fast-glycolytic fibers. Most of the fiber thickening results from increased synthesis of myosin and actin filaments, allowing for more cross-bridge interaction which increases the muscle’s contractile strength. Testosterone promotes the synthesis and assembly of myosin and actin. Some athletes take advantage of this with the dangerous practice of taking testosterone or closely related steroids to increase muscle fiber size. 

 

Note: 100% represents theoretical maximum muscle cell size

child_mcqs.description: Why do men have naturally have larger muscles than females?
child_mcqs.explanation: As the passage states, testosterone is responsible for the increase in size of muscle fibers. Since men have substantially more testosterone, it is reasonable to conclude that this is the reason why men have naturally larger muscles than females. A is false (and it is not talked about in the passage). C is false and the effects of estrogen on muscle size is not discussed about in the passage. B is true since men’s muscle fibers are thicker, larger and stronger than those of women, even without weight training, because of the actions of testosterone, a steroid hormone secreted in greater quantities in males.

answers.description: Men can create actin and myosin quicker than females

child_mcqs.description:
What changes would be seen in a long distance runner?

1. Increased number of capillaries in muscles

2. Increased number of muscle fibers

3. Increased number of actin and myosin

4. Increased number of mitochondria in muscle cells
child_mcqs.explanation: D is the correct answer. According to the passage “Regular aerobic exercise, such as long-distance jogging or swimming promotes changes within the oxidative muscle fibers to enhance aerobic respiration”. Increasing the number capillaries will increase oxygen delivery to muscles so statement 1 is correct. Increased mitochondria will produce more ATP for muscles. Statement 2 is incorrect and as the passage states the number of muscle fibers does not change over time for aerobic exercise. Statement 3 is not true since increased numbers of actin and myosin will result in a larger muscle fiber (as the passage states) and we know that aerobic exercise does not increase muscle size.

child_mcqs.description: What best explains the Orange line?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is the correct answer since the passage states that testosterone levels increase muscle cell size. B is false since the passage states that cell size does not change with aerobic exercise. C is false since it is an example of aerobic exercise (which does not change muscle cell size). D is false but it takes reasoning. The passage states that increased activity of muscles such as weightlifting increases muscle cell size, so you can assume that decreased activity of muscles will decrease muscle cell size (this is a biological concept known as muscular atrophy).

child_mcqs.description: What best explains the blue line?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is true since the passage says that anaerobic exercise does not change the size of muscle cells. An example of anaerobic exercise is long distance running. A is false because decrease use of a muscle will decrease cell size. B is false because increase use of the muscle (such as weightlifting) would increase the size of the muscle. D is false because a decrease in testosterone would decrease muscle mass.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 24
stem_mcq.description:
Liquid-liquid phase extraction is a separation technique where the analyte in a liquid sample is extracted using a liquid solvent. It requires the analyte to be more soluble in an immiscible solvent thus allowing it to be extracted from a liquid sample. In other words, an organic solvent allows extraction of the analyte, in an aqueous phase, to be extracted into the organic phase, as the analyte is more soluble in the organic solvent than in the aqueous solution.

The fraction of the analyte extracted into the organic phase, p, is given by the equation:

D is the distribution ratio, which measures the relative concentrations of the analyte in the two phases. 

V(aq) is the volume of the aqueous solution 

V(org) is the volume of the organic solvent used for extraction

child_mcqs.description: A typical apparatus used to carry out a liquid-liquid phase extraction is a separating funnel where the bottom layer is removed after shaking, using a stopcock. If the organic layer has a higher density than the aqueous layer, which layer would appear at the bottom before shaking?
child_mcqs.explanation: As the organic layer has a higher density, it would appear at the bottom.

answers.description: Neither, as the organic and the aqueous layers are in equilibrium

child_mcqs.description: Chlorine has a distribution ratio of 3 between water and hexane. What fraction of chlorine is left in the aqueous phase if 10mL of aqueous solution was mixed with 5mL of hexane?
child_mcqs.explanation: Using the equation provided, the fraction of chlorine extracted into the organic phase is 0.6. Therefore, the fraction left in the aqueous phase is 1-0.6 = 0.4.

child_mcqs.description: If compound A has a distribution ratio of 2 between water and hexane, and compound B has a distribution ratio of 0.5 between water and hexane, and both were extracted using the same volume of aqueous solution and organic solvent. What could be inferred about their relative extractions into the organic phase?
child_mcqs.explanation: Substituting the values into the equation given, and knowing that V(aq)/V(org) must equal 1 as they are in equal amounts, we can calculate the value of p, the fraction of analyte being extracted into the organic phase, as 2/3 for compound A and 1/3 for compound B. Hence compound A is extracted more into the organic phase.

answers.description: Both compounds have the same amount being extracted into the organic phase
Compound A is extracted more into the organic phase than compound B
Compound B is extracted more into the organic phase than compound A
There is not enough information to tell

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is FALSE regarding liquid-liquid extractions?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Large amounts of solvent do improve extraction from the aqueous phase - they decrease the denominator in the fraction, giving a higher p. The solvent used must also be immiscible with water (an aqueous solution) as outlined in the introduction. A greater distribution ratio means greater extraction into the organic solvent by definition.

Emulsions cannot be formed as the aqueous and organic phase are immiscible to each other. If emulsions were to be formed, then the analyte cannot be extracted from the aqueous phase into the organic phase.

answers.description: A greater distribution ratio means greater extraction into the organic solvent.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following gives the general formula for the total amount of analyte extracted into the organic phase, if in each extraction, the leftover aqueous phase of the preceding extraction was used to further extract the analyte into the organic phase. Assume equal volumes of organic solvent in each extraction.
child_mcqs.explanation: This question is best tackled one extraction at a time. The first extraction has a fraction of p being extracted into the organic phase, thus the fraction left in the aqueous phase is 1-p. In the second extraction, the leftover aqueous phase in the first extraction is then extracted with an equal amount of organic solvent, where the total amount of the analyte extracted into the organic phase in the second extraction equals the amount extracted into the organic phase multiplied by the amount of aqueous phase leftover. Therefore, the total amount extracted into the organic phase after 2 extractions is p + p(1-p), hence C is the answer. Note that because we are extracting the leftover aqueous phase, and not adding additional aqueous solution, we do not need to know the volume of aqueous solution.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 25
stem_mcq.description:
Two common pieces of equipment used in laboratories are 'swinging bucket' and fixed-angle centrifuges. Both are used to subject fluid substances or substances in suspension to high accelerations. This is often done to seperate components of different density. For example, in a solution containing a homogeneous suspension of cells floating in a medium, the cells will be more dense than the surrounding fluid. Spinning this solution to give a particular acceleration will cause the cells to form a pellet at the bottom of their tube (furthest from the axis of rotation). 

 

For the following questions, consider two pieces of equipment:

 

 

1) A swinging bucket centrifuge with a radius of 30cm to the bucket hinge. The bucket is 10cm long, is hinged at the highest possible point, weighs 100g and it's density is homogenous. 

 

 

2) A fixed-angle centrifuge with a radius of 10cm from the axis of rotation to the furthest end of the tubes, which are at `130^o` to the radius.

 

The following equations may be useful:

 

`a = {:v^2:}/r`

`F = ma`

`v = (2pir)/T`

`"frequency" = 1/T`

`pi ~~ 3.1`

 

Where:

`a` is acceleration

`m` is mass

`v` is instantaneous velocity

`r` is radius

`f` is force

`T` is period of rotation.

 

Assume acceleration due to gravity is `10ms^-2`
stem_mcq.tag: PHY03 Newton's Laws and Types of Forces

child_mcqs.description: For any given centrifuge, keeping period of rotation as a constant, doubling the radius will result in what change in acceleration?
child_mcqs.explanation:
To answer this question correctly, the candidate must consider two formulas given above:

 

`a={:v^2:}/r`  and  `v = (2pir)/T`

 

These must be rearranged to present acceleration as a function of period:

 

`a= (2pir)^2/(rT^2) = (4pi^2r^2)/(rT^2) = (4rpi^2)/T^2`

 

Therefore:

`aproptor`

So as radius is doubled, acceleration is also doubled. The correct answer is 'C'.

child_mcqs.description:
The centripetal acceleration experienced in centrifuges is often expressed in terms of relative centrifugal force (RCF) which is the ratio of centripetal acceleration to graviational acceleration.

 

An undergraduate student is advised that some cells that they are centrifuging will lose their viability if exposed to acceleration greater than 400 RCF. However, if RCF is too low, the total cell yield will be diminished. The student is using the fixed-angle centrifuge described above. Of the following, which is the highest speed (in revolutions per second) that can be used without reducing cell viability?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The candidate must determine the maximum frequency with which the fixed-angle centrifuge may spin without exceeding 400 RCF. 

 

Firstly, convert from RCF to acceleration:

 

RCF`=a/g` so  `400=a/10`  therefore, 'a=4000ms^-2`

 

Now determine the maximum instantaneous velocity:

 

`a=v^2/r`

`4000=v^2/0.1`

`400=v^2`   Multiply both sides by 0.1

`v=sqrt(400)=20ms^-1`

 

Finally, determine the maximum frequency:

 

`v = (2pir)/T` rearranges to   `T = (2pir)/v`

 

frequency = `1/T`   `->`   frequency`= v/(2pir)`

 

 

frequency`=20/2pi0.1 = 100/pi ~~ 100/3 ~~ 33` revolutions per second. 

 

The highest answer that does not exceed this number is 'D'.

child_mcqs.description: The average human cell has a mass of approximately `1xx10^-12`kg. Approximately what force would be acting on a single human cell in the fixed-angle centrifuge spinning at 600 revolutions per minute (RPM)?
child_mcqs.explanation:
As mentioned in the introduction, cells are usually more dense than their media, so they will form a pellet at the furthest point from the axis of rotation. Therefore, the radius of this motion will be 0.1m.

 

Convert RPM to period:

`600 "RPM" = 10 "RPS"`  Divide by 60 seconds.

`T = 1/"frequency" = 1/10 = 0.1 "s"`

Determine instantaneous velocity:

`v = (2pir)/T = (2pixx0.1)/0.1 = 6.2ms^-1`

 

Determine acceleration:

`a=v^2/r=6.2^2/0.1 ~~ 400 "ms"^-2`        here, used `6^2 = 36`, so `6.2^2 ~~40`

 

Determine force:

`F = ma = 1xx10^-12xx4xx10^2 = 4xx10^-10N`

 

The correct answer is 'A'.

child_mcqs.description:
One of the great dangers that can be experienced in a laboratory is an exploding centrifuge. This can occur when the centrifuge is unbalanced. For example, samples may be loaded into a bucket on one side, but not the other. 

 

Consider the swinging bucket centrifuge described above to have a tolerance of 10N, so that it can safely operate as long as the force difference experienced between the two buckets is less than this. If an operator were uncertain about the exact mass of their samples, what would be the best way to reduce the force difference?
child_mcqs.explanation:
By combining the following two formulas:

 `a={:v^2:}/r`  AND  `F = ma`   we see that  `F = mv^2/r`

 

From this we can determine that:

`fproptov^2`

`fpropto1/r`

`fproptom`

 

From the explanation to question 1, we know that `aproptoT`.

As `"frequency"=1/T` AND `F= ma`

`fpropto1/"frequency"`

 

We can therefore determine that instantaneous velocity has a greater bearing on force than the other variables. 'C' is the correct answer.

answers.description: Decrease mass of all samples by a constant factor.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 26
stem_mcq.description: The figure below presents a systematic representation on a nephron, the functional filtration unit of the kidney. The main function of the kidneys relating to the filtering of the blood is to retain vital solutes, excrete superfluous or potentially harmful solutes, and to maintain water homeostasis. Section 1-7 represent different parts of the tubular system. Section 1 is where the majority of sodium is reabsorbed, through the action of Na/K-ATPase pumps. Angiotensin II can increase Na/K-ATPase function 3-fold. Because of this, Section 1 has the highest number of mitochondria. In Section 2, unnecessary organic compounds (e.g. penicillin) are removed from the blood by organic anion transporters (OAT), whereas essential organics (e.g. glucose) are reabsorbed. These transporters are non-specific and can become saturated. They can also only act on unbound solutes in serum. In Sections 3-5, urine is concentrated and water is retained. Section 3 is permeable to water and has no active sodium transport, whereas Sections 4 and 5 are impermeable to water and permeable to electrolytes. In Section 7, aldosterone acts to increase sodium reabsorption by increasing potassium excretion. From here the urine enters the ureter with a sodium concentration of approximately 25 mM.

child_mcqs.description: Which tubular section would be the most susceptible to damage if kidney blood flow were significantly decreased?
child_mcqs.explanation: Section 1 has the most mitochondria, therefore uses the most oxygen in aerobic respiration. Decreased perfusion would cause the most damage due to local hypoxia in the cells.

child_mcqs.description: What would be the effect of decreased systemic blood pressure? (Hint: Consider the effects of the RAAS system in regulating blood pressure)
child_mcqs.explanation: Decreased systemic blood pressure causes decreased perfusion systemically, despite peripheral vasoconstriction. It also causes Renin secretion which increases both Angiotensin II and Aldosterone in the bloodstream. Both act to increase sodium reabsorption, however aldosterone does so by increasing potassium excretion. Therefore C is the correct answer.

answers.description: Decreased blood to the kidney, net decrease in sodium reabsorption
Increased blood to the kidney, net increase in sodium reabsorption
Decreased blood to the kidney, net increase in potassium excretion
Increased blood to the kidney, net increase in potassium reabsorption

child_mcqs.description: Compound X is a nephrotoxic metabolite that is removed from the blood by OATs. It has an albumin association constant (KA) of 1.2 x 10-2. Which of the following compounds is most likely to reduce the removal of Compound X?
child_mcqs.explanation: The compound has to be an anion, so either B or C. C has the lowest association constant with albumin, therefore has the weakest binding and will have a higher free concentration in serum. Therefore C is the correct answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 27
stem_mcq.description:
Thyroid hormone (TH = T3 + T4) is a major metabolic hormone affecting most cells in the body. It increases metabolic rate and heat production. The hypothalamus produces thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) which acts on the anterior pituitary gland to cause secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH binds to receptors on the thyroid gland to promote the release of TH. TH is regulated by negative feedback with the anterior pituitary gland and hypothalamus. 

The sensitive response of TSH to changes in thyroid hormone levels provides a tool to assess whether levels of TH in the blood are sufficient, deficient or excessive. The patterns can also be used to locate any problems in the axis: if the thyroid is dysfunctional, it is referred to as a primary condition; if the problem is located in the pituitary gland, it is a secondary condition.

child_mcqs.description: If a person has secondary hyperthyroidism due to a pituitary adenoma, they have a hormone-secreting tumour in their pituitary gland which has escaped normal regulation to cause increased thyroid gland activity. Which of the following hormone patterns would you expect to see?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The pituitary tumour secretes hormones to cause overactivity of the thyroid gland, so it must be secreting TSH = high TSH. Answers A and D are incorrect. Overactivity of the thyroid gland means TH will be high, so answers C and D are incorrect. The tumour cells are not subject to negative feedback, so TSH will be high even though TH is also high, therefore we would expect to see the hormone pattern of answer B. 

Students are expected to be familiar with the concept of negative feedback.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following conditions best explains a high level of TSH with a low level of TH?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Students should be familiar with the terminology that hyper = increased, and hypo = decreased. Primary and secondary conditions were explained in the passage and secondary hyperthyroidism was explained in the previous question. 

Hyperthyroidism = increased activity of the thyroid gland = high TH, so answers A and B are incorrect. Primary hyperthyroidism would be increased thyroid gland activity due to a problem with the thyroid gland. Based on the information given about the axis and regulation, this high level of TH would feedback to the pituitary gland to cause low levels of TSH secretion. 

Hypothyroidism = decreased activity of the thyroid gland = low TH. Primary hypothyroidism occurs due to a problem in the thyroid gland. Secondary hypothyroidism results from a problem at the level of the pituitary gland. If the problem were at the pituitary gland, low levels of TH would occur because the gland was not being stimulated by TSH = low TSH, low TH. In primary hypothyroidism, the thyroid gland is being stimulated by TSH to release TH but is unable to do so = high TSH, low TH = answer C

child_mcqs.description: In Graves' disease, patients produce an antibody that binds to the same receptors on the thyroid gland as TSH does to the same effect. Based on the information you have been given, what change would you expect to see in TSH levels in a person with Graves' disease?
child_mcqs.explanation:
If the antibody produced in Graves' disease has the same effect as TSH, it stimulates the thyroid gland to release TH. High levels of TH cause negative feedback on the pituitary to suppress TSH = answer D. 

Students are expected to know what an antibody is.

child_mcqs.description:
In Graves' disease, patients produce an antibody that binds to the same receptors on the thyroid gland as TSH does to the same effect. 

Based on the information you have been given, what main side effect could you expect to see in a person with Graves' disease?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that thyroid hormone increases metabolic rate and heat production. Graves' disease results in increased thyroid hormone production which would result in an increased metabolic rate. Students should have a basic understanding that an increased metabolic rate is associated with weight loss rather than gain. They should be able to infer that this increased metabolic rate is more likely to be associated with increased appetite rather than decreased. As stated, TH promotes heat production so affected persons are unlikely to be sensitive to the cold.

sections.title: Section III - Reasoning in the biological and physical sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
Lewis structures are a simple means of predicting the structure of simple covalent-bonding molecules. The process of drawing a Lewis structure is as follows:

1. Each atom of the structure has its chemical symbol drawn

2. The number of valence electrons are drawn in for each. Note valence electrons are equal to the group of the periodic table the atom is in. For example, Al is in group III and so has 3 valence electrons.

3. Electrons from atoms are paired to form a bonds (1 electron each per bond). Up to 3 bonds may be formed between two atoms.

4. Check the final structure has the correct bonding framework and that each atom has 8 electrons in its valence shell (with the exception of hydrogen which only has 2 electrons associated).

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following molecules have their correct Lewis structure shown?

(i) NH3

 

(ii) NO2

(iii) CH3NCH2
child_mcqs.explanation:
i and iii are both reasonable Lewis structures because in each all electrons are accounted for and every atom has 8 electrons associated (except the hydrogens).

ii is incorrect because an electron is missing from the nitrogen. Although all atoms appear to have 8 electrons in their outer shells, the total number of electrons is incorrect.

child_mcqs.description:
Valence shell electron pair repulsion (VSEPR) theory states that repulsion between electron pairs primarily determines the shape of molecules. The geometry of a molecule can be determined by drawing a Lewis diagram and using VSEPR to determine where the bonds may minimize repulsion. Note lone pairs of electrons repel other electrons more than electrons in a covalent bond.

Electron Arrangement

Bonding pairs

Lone pairs

Shape

Bond angle

Linear

n/a

n/a

Linear

180°

Trigonal planar

 

3

0

Trigonal planar

120°

2

1

Bent

120°

Tetrahedral

 

 

 

4

0

Tetrahedral

109.5°

3

1

Trigonal pyramidal

107°

2

2

Bent

104°
 

Based on the information given, what are the geometries of

(i) H2O

(ii) NH3 

(iii) CO2
child_mcqs.explanation: Above are the Lewis structures of the molecules. By accounting for electron repulsion it can be seen that they are bent, trigonal planar and linear respectively. Oxygen has two lone pairs and two bonding pairs (one with each H), and nitrogen has one lone pair and 3 bonding pairs (one with each F). CO2, although it has four bonding pairs and no lone pairs, is clearly not tetrahedral - the only way to arrange the two pairs of double bonds such that they are as far apart from one another as possible is to have them lineally opposed.

child_mcqs.description: Chlorine pentafluoride (ClF5) and xenon tetrafluoride (XeF4) are molecules which have 6 electron pairs associated with the central atom (Cl and Xe respectively). Based on this information, what are the likely geometric structures of (i) ClF5 and (ii) XeF4?
child_mcqs.explanation: In both cases, if there were 6 bonding pairs instead of some bonding pairs and some lone pairs, the geometry would be octahedral. The basic geometry is still octahedral in both molecules, but with bonding pairs replaced by lone pairs and a resultant change in geometry. By examining the Lewis Diagrams it can be seen that in ClF5 the lone pair of electrons repels the remaining bonds, giving it a square pyramidal geometry. In XeF4 the lone pairs repel each other slightly more than the bonding pairs meaning that they are on opposite sides of Xe, leaving the remaining bonding pairs to form a square planar arrangement.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
Glycolysis, or the catabolism of glucose to two molecules of pyruvate, is a central pathway to human metabolism.

Hexokinase catalyses the endergonic phosphorylation of glucose (to glucose-6-phosphate), thereby trapping it within the cell in a high energy state. Following an isomerisation step, a second endergonic phosphorylation is catalysed by phosphofructokinase (PFK) to yield fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.

Following various glycolytic steps and the division into two molecules of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (and a few more steps to phosphoenolpyruvate), pyruvate kinase catalyses the first exergonic phase from PEP to pyruvate. The rate of this is regulated by the presence of products/substrates associated with high or low energy states.

Note: Every NADH formed is (ideally) later used to activate the Electron Transport Chain, and yields 2.5 ATP equivalents.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: A mutation in which of the following enzymes will exert no effect on glycolysis (according to this incomplete diagram)?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is correct. The conversion of GAP to DAP by phosphotriose isomerase is a side reaction (and while in reality products may assist regulation of the glycolytic pathway), and thus does not influence the catabolism of glucose to pyruvate. All others, including PFK (which is shown in pink to highlight its irreversible nature), are involved in the catabolic pathway.

child_mcqs.description: In the process of glycolysis as seen in the diagram above, what is the net gain of ATP equivalents (assuming aerobic respiration)?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is correct.

child_mcqs.description: A pyruvate kinase inhibitor is added to this system. Which options describes the likely outcome?
child_mcqs.explanation: B is correct. Pyruvate kinase is one of the highly-regulated irreversible steps; if the rate is limited, the gluconeogenic pathway will initially remain unchanged (thus decreasing the ratio) until feedback reduces the magnitude of the discrepancy.

child_mcqs.description:
Glycogen (a dense carbohydrate store found in skeletal muscle and liver) is formed following the isomerisation of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate (and polymerisation).

However, glucose-6-phosphatase is only found in the liver. Which of the following explanations for this observation is illogical?
child_mcqs.explanation:
C is (in)correct. Glucose cannot cross the membrane via simple diffusion (its facilitated diffusion, usually through GLUT transporters).

Note: questions can be this sneaky. Also, it's important to understand the concepts inherent in this subquestion (such as that liver oversees glucose release in response to glucagon, adrenaline and cortisol).

answers.description: The liver must be able to release glucose from stored glycogen in response to adrenaline, cortisol and glucagon.
Skeletal muscle stores glycogen for its own use during exercise; the catabolism of glycogen to pyruvate does not require the reformation of glucose.
Expression of glucose-6-phosphatase in other tissues would prevent the development of intracellular glucose concentrations; glucose would just seep out of the cell via simple diffusion.
All of the above are logical and true.

child_mcqs.description:
Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP) is formed by the non-glycolytic PFK2, and acts as a positive allosteric modulator of PFK1 (the form of PFK involved in glycolysis). When the external influences explained below are absent, the rate of production is proportional.

However, unlike the regulatory PFK2, PFK1 is activated by the insulin-dependent phosphoprotein phosphatase and inhibited by cAMP-dependent protein kinase (cAMP-DPK).

Furthermore, citrate is a negative allosteric modulator.

Which combination of factors will lead to maximal glycolysis?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is correct. Both PFK2 and insulin actvate PFK1, and an excess of the active enzyme will inherently increase the rate of reaction. B is incorrect because cAMP-PDK (and ATP) are incorrect, and C is incorrect because citrate is a negative allosteric modulator.

answers.description: High phosphoprotein kinase, low cAMP-PDK and high citrate

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
According to the partial pressures of the cardiorespiratory system shown in the table below, the diffusion gradient of pO2 is 60mmHg and pCO2 only 5mmHg. In normal pulmonary circulation with adequate ventilation and perfusion, it takes only 0.25 seconds out of the 0.8 normally available as blood transits through the alveoli.

Furthermore, the oxygen dissociation curve (the affinity of oxygen to erythrocyte haemoglobin at different partial pressures) can be shown below.

child_mcqs.description: An increase in which of the following will prolong the time taken for functional gas exchange?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is correct. Increasing the alveolar thickness decreases the gas exchange rate due to reduced perfusion (typically seen in fibrosis). A and B increase the alveolar pO2 (increasing gas exchange to expediate a functional oxygenation level), while D increases pulmonary blood flow (small positive effect on rate of gas exchange simply due to increased demand).

child_mcqs.description: Given the oxygen dissociation curve and the numbers shown in the table, how much of the available oxygen is released into tissues?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is correct. Following the graph across with the values of 100mmHg and 40mmHg (x-axis) should yield a change in the %saturation from 95 to 75, or thereabouts (y-axis).

child_mcqs.description: Given the oxygen dissociation curve and the numbers shown in the table, how much of the available carbon dioxide is removed from tissues?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is correct. We're dealing with the oxygen dissociation curve (completely separate from carbon dioxide).

child_mcqs.description:
Exercise leads to an increased temperature, acidosis (retention of carbon dioxide and the anaerobic formation of lactate) and the the production of 2,3-DPG (a byproduct of glycolysis). Together, they work synergistically to decrease oxygen binding.

What does this do to the oxygen dissociation curve?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is correct. Increased pO2 is required for the same %saturation, thus shifting the curve to the right.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
A homeowner has recently installed solar hot water system and would like to be able to convert the thermal energy stored in the hot water tank into electrical energy. One way to achieve this is to install a device called a stirling engine across the insulating wall of the hot water tank. Stirling engines are valveless, exhaustless external combustion engines that use the expansion and contraction of gas to drive pistons (Figure 1).

 

Figure 1: A diagram of a stirling engine connected to a generator. Pressure changes inside the cylinders drive the pistons as heat energy flows from the expansion cylinder to the compression cylinder.

 

 

Figure 2: A diagram of the hot water tank, showing the inclusion of the stirling generator. Heat energy escapes from the tank through the stirling generator, providing energy for its oepration.

 

The following equations may be used:

 

`C=E_t/{:MxxDeltaT:}`

`W=Fxxs`

`P=W/t`

`F=ma`

`T_{:"kelvin":}=T_{:"celcius":}+273.15`

 

Where C is heat capacity, `E_t` is thermal energy, M is mass, `DeltaT` is temperature change, W is work, F is force, s is displacement, P is power, t is time, `F` is force, `m` is mass, `a` is acceleration, `T_{:"kelvin":}` is temperature in kelvin and `T_{:"celcius":}` is temperature in celcius.

 

The volume of the hot water tank is `100 "L"` and the maximum internal temperature of the water is `70^oC`. Ambient temperature outside the tank is `20^oC`. 

 

The heat capacity (C) of water is `4 "kJkg"^-1"K"^-1`

child_mcqs.description:
The sun has set and the solar panels have stopped adding heat energy to the hot water tank. The stirling generator is able to provide `100` watts of power until the sun rises again in ten hours time. Which of the following is closest to the temperature of the water in the tank at sunrise?

 

Assume that the generator is operating at 100% efficiency and the tank does not leak any heat energy. Assume that the tank is at full capacity and the water in the tank starts at `70^oC`
child_mcqs.explanation:
The candidate should recognise that all of the energy generated by the stirling engine is converted from heat energy stored in the water tank. Because the volume (and therefore mass) of the tank is known, the temperature of the water in the tank can be used to describe the amount of energy it stores. As heat energy travels along its gradient out of the tank and through the stirling engine, the temeprature inside the hot water tank will drop. The temperature drop (in degrees celcius) will be equal to the energy that is generated by the stirling engine (in kilojoules). 

 

 

First, convert ten hours to seconds:

`10 "hours" = 60xx60xx10 = 36000 "seconds"`

 

Determine the total amount of work done by the stirling engine during the ten hour time period:

 

`P=W/t`   rearranges to   `W=Pt`

`W=Pt=100xx36000=3600000 "J" =3600 kJ`

 

Determine the temperature drop of water in the tank required to do this amount of work:

 

`C=E_t/{:MxxDeltaT:}`  rearranges to  `DeltaT=E_t/{:MxxC:}`

`DeltaT=3600/{:100xx4:}` Note that the definition of the energy capacity of water is given in terms of kJ, so kJ is used in this calculation.

`DeltaT=3600/400=9^oC`

 

The temperature drop is `9^oC` and the starting temperature is `70^oC`. As `70-9 = 61`, the temperature of the water in the tank will be `61^oC`. The answer that is closest to this is `D`.

child_mcqs.description:
Instead of being connected to a generator, the flywheel of the stirling engine is connected to a pulley, which is attached to a hanging `100 "kg"` mass. The mass is initially hanging `50 "m"` below the pulley. The force generated by the stirling engine causes the mass to rise at a constant velocity. How far up is the mass raised when the average temperature of the water in the tank reduces by `0.1^oC`?

 

Figure 3: The flywheel of the stirling engine (A) is now attached to a cable, which runs over a pully (B) to raise a 100kg mass (C). 

 

Assume that the stirling engine is operating at 100% efficiency. Assume that the pulley is frictionless. Acceleration due to gravity is `10ms^-1`.
child_mcqs.explanation:
This question tests the candidates' understanding of work and energy. Specifically, that for a certain amount of work to be done (force acting over a given distance), an equivalent amount of energy is needed. In this question, the amount of energy used is given in terms of heat, force can be determined and candidates are asked to determine the distance over which this force acts. 

First, determine the amount of energy available when the temperature of the water in the tank drops by `0.1^oC`:

`C=E_t/{:MxxDeltaT:}  "   rearranges to   "  E_t=CxxMxxDeltaT`

`E_t=4xx100xx0.1=40`

 

Next, determine the force exerted on the mass:

 

`F=ma=100xx10=1000N`  (Note that `a = 10` `"ms"^-2` as the object is moving with a constant velocity)

 

Finally, determine the distance over which this force acts:

 

`W=Fxxs "  rearranges to  " s=W/F`

`s=40000/1000=40m`

 

The energy provided by the hot water (via the stirling engine) will do enough work to raise a 100kg mass by 40m.

child_mcqs.description:
Carnot's theorem describes the maximum efficiency of a heat transfer engine (such as the stirling engine). This is descibed by the following formula:

 

`eta_{:"max":}=1-{:T_{:"cold":}/T_{:"hot":}`

 

Where `eta_{:"max":}` is proportion of input power that can be converted to output power by the stirling engine, `T_{:"cold":}` is ambient temperature and `T_{:"hot":}` is temperature inside the tank.

 

If the energy input to the stirling engine from the hot water tank is 1000 J every second, which of the following is closest to the maximum theoretical power output of the engine?
child_mcqs.explanation:
This question provides candidates with a potentially novel formula and asks them to use it within the framework of power and work. Essentially, for a given energy input from the hot water tank, a smaller amount of rotational kinetic energy is produced by the stirling engine. As suggested by the formula given, the greater the temperature difference across the engine, the greater its efficiency.

 

First, convert the temperatures given to kelvin:

 

`T_{:"kelvin":}=T_{:"celcius":}+273.15`

`T_{:"cold":}=20+273.15=293.15`

`T_{:"hot":}=70+273.15=343.15K`

 

Determine the maximum efficiency of the engine with the given parameters:

 

`eta_{:"max":}=1-{:T_{:"cold":}/T_{:"hot":}=1-{:293.15/343.15:}={:343.14-293.15:}/343.15=50/343.15 ~~ 50/350 ~~1/7`

 

Determine the power input from the hot water tank:

 

`P=W/t=1000/1=1000 "W"`

 

Determine the power output of the stirling engine:

 

`P_{:"output":}=eta_{:max:}xxP_{:"input":}=1/7xx1000= 1000/7 "W"`

 

So with the given parameters, the maximum power output of the stirling engine is`1000/7 "W"`. The correct answer is 'A'

child_mcqs.description:
If no heat energy is added, what is the total useable energy capacity of the hot water tank at its maximum temperature of `70^oC`?

 

Assume that the stirling generator is operating at its maximum efficiency as described by Carnot's theorem.
child_mcqs.explanation:
As explored in the previous question, Carnot's theorem dictates that the greater the temperature difference across the stirling engine, the greater its efficiency. This means that the efficiency of the described sytem will be greatest when the tank is at its maximum temperature. It also means that for every joule of energy that is used up, more power must be used to produce the same power output. 

 

As efficiency is given by a linear equation, the simplest way to work this out is to multiply the total thermal energy capacity of the tank by the average efficiency over the course of its discharge.

 

First, determine the total thermal energy capacity of the tank within its operational range:

 

`C=E_t/{:MxxDeltaT:}  "   rearranges to   "  E_t=CxxMxxDeltaT`

 

`E_t=CxxMxxDeltaT=4xx100xx(70-20)=20000 "kJ"`

 

Now determine the average efficiency of the engine:

 

`eta_{:"ave":}={:eta_{:"max":}+eta_{:"min":}:}/2={:{:1-T_{:"cold1":}/T_{:"hot1":}+1-{:T_{:"cold2":}/T_{:"hot2":}:}:}/2={:1-{:293.15/343.15:}+1-{:293.15/293.15:}:}/2=50/{:343.15xx2:}~~1/14`

 

Now determine the total useable energy stored in the tank:

 

`E_{:"useable":}=eta_{:"average":}xxE_{:"total":}=1/14xx20000= 20000/14 "kJ"`

 

The correct answer is 'D'.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description: An important reaction in the synthesis of organic molecules is known as Claisen condensation. It involves the reaction of two esters, in the presence of an appropriate deprotonated alcohol. The mixture is then acidified to complete the reaction, yielding a β-ketoester and an alcohol. The reaction is classified as a mixed Claisen condensation when the esters used are different from one another. The generalised form of this mixed reaction is shown below. Note that each R group must contain at least one carbon atom.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the generalised reaction for mixed Claisen condensations, determine which β-ketoester or pair of β-ketoesters would be produced in the following reaction.
child_mcqs.explanation: When a “none of the above” option exists in these types of questions, it is important to assess if what has been provided adheres to the general mechanism. In the general reaction you will note that Ester 1, Ester 2, the deprotonated alcohol (written above the reaction arrow) and the β-ketoester all contain the same R1 group. In this particular question, the R1 group is inconsistent between the esters. It is a propyl group on one and an ethyl group on the other. The necessary reactants for a mixed Claisen condensation are therefore not present, making D the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: A true Claisen condensation reaction involves the reaction of two identical esters. Following a true Claisen condensation, ethanol was one of the isolated products. Of the esters shown (I-IV), which could have been involved in the reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Based on the pattern of the reaction provided initially and the fact that ethanol was isolated, R1 must be an ethyl group. This is true of each ester however, so it is not a distinguishing factor.

The next consideration is that as this is a true Claisen condensation, the same ester is being used as both Ester 1 and Ester 2 (as shown in the mixed reaction). Comparing each of the possible esters to the general structure of Ester 1, again we find that none of the options can be excluded.

At last, comparing the structures to Ester 2 yields some information. Important to note in Ester 2 is that the R3 group is separated from the carbonyl carbon by a single carbon atom. This atom needs to be able to form additional bonds as it later binds the two carbonyl carbons together, along with R3 in the β-ketoester. The equivalent carbon in structure I is unable to form any additional bonds and thus is not a candidate for the true Claisen condensation. In the case of structure II, this carbon is available, but there is no R3 group (the question states they must contain at least one carbon atom). Thus, it too is not a candidate. This leaves structures III and IV, which could be used in a true Claisen condensation.

child_mcqs.description: In certain molecules which contain two esters, a Claisen condensation can occur within the molecule itself. This leads to the formation of a cyclic structure. Consider the following intramolecular Claisen condensation reaction. Which ring-containing structure will be produced?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The best place to start with this question is by noting that R1 is an ethyl group. This can be found by either looking at either side of the reactant or, more readily, by the deprotonated alcohol used in the first step of the reaction (written above the reaction arrow).  Looking at the general form of the β-ketoester produced, we know that it must contain a single R1 group bonded to an oxygen atom. This excludes structure II.

The next thing to notice from the β-ketoester is that the carbonyl carbons are separated by a single carbon atom. This is not the case in structure III and thus it can be excluded.

Structures I and IV differ only by the number of carbon atoms in the ring structure. By comparing the number or carbon atoms in the reactant to the number of carbon atoms in the products, structure I can be identified as missing a carbon. Thus, it is structure IV that will be produced by this intramolecular Claisen condensation reaction.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Bone fractures are disruptions in bone which vary according to both the nature, direction and magnitude of mechanical injury, and the strength of the bone (some diseases, such as osteoporosis, weaken the structural integrity of the bone and predispose individuals to bone fractures; usually transverse in nature, these are considered 'pathological fractures'). Consequently, most high-impact 'traumatic fractures' are spiral in nature.

As shown in the diagram below, haemorrhaging at the fracture site promotes the formation of a haematoma within the perisoteum, and the necrotic ends induce an inflammatory response (granulomatous type encases and protects the region). Mesenchymal stem cells then proliferate and differentiate to form the immature trabecular-like reparative tissue known as callus. Composed of immature cartilaginous and osseus matrix, the quantity of callus produced is proportional to both motion and distance between the ends, and the inadequacy of the blood supply. Furthermore, if an excessive gap is present (poor 'reduction' has occurred, a dense fibrous connective tissue bridge known as a fibrous union may result).

Finally, remodelling along physiological lines will eventually restore pre-fracture bone architecture, conferring structural and functional normality.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following factors will prolong fracture healing?
child_mcqs.explanation: B is correct. Infection is never good, and the other three options are explained in the introduction.

child_mcqs.description: An elderly lady presents with a spiral fracture. What does this suggest?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is correct. Regardless of the patient age (although it is an important consideration), a spiral fracture suggests good structural integrity; 'traumatic' fractures result from high-impact injuries.

answers.description: She suffered a traumatic fracture due to a high impact injury.
She suffered a pathological fracture due to a high impact injury.
She suffered a traumatic fracture due to a low impact injury.
She suffered a pathological fracture due to a low impact injury.

child_mcqs.description: By day 6, the elderly lady is continuing to make good progress with fracture healing. Which stage of healing would she be in?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is correct. 6 days, according to the diagram, is definitively within the third (Granulation) stage.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description:
The surface tension of a liquid, `gamma`, is defined as the force, `F` per unit length, `l` that acts perpendicular to any line/cut in a liquid surface acting to pull the surface closed. A water skater of mass, 2.72 x 10-5 kg, is perfectly balanced on 4 legs on the surface of 500cm3 of water at 10oC.

The radius of the base of the insect's leg, r assumed to be spherical is 2.5 x 10-5m. The volume of water displaced by each leg in this position is 5 x 10-10 m3. For surface tension, use l = 2`pi`r. Assume acceleration due to gravity, g = 10m/s2, `pi` = 3 and density of water, `rho` = 1 x 103 kg/m3.

The force diagram of one of the insect's legs is shown as below.

child_mcqs.description: What is the surface tension of the water at 10oC? (to the closest 2 decimal places)
child_mcqs.explanation:
Using the force diagram,

Downward force = Weight of one of the insect's leg = 1/4 (weight of insect) (Note: The insect is perfectly balanced)

Upward force = Buoyant force + Vertical component of force due to surface tension (`gamma`l cos 60o = `gamma` 2`pi`r cos 60o)

Upward force = downward force

`(1xx10^3)xx(5xx10^-10)xx10 + 2xx3xx(2.5xx10^-5)xx0.5xxgamma = 1/4xx2.72xx10^-5xx10`

`5xx10^-6 - 6.8xx10^-5 + 7.5xx10^-5gamma = 0`

`6.3xx10^-5 = 7.5xx10^-5gamma`

`gamma = 6.3/7.5 = 0.84 "N/m"`

The closest answer is 0.85 (B).

child_mcqs.description: Surface tension of water decreases as temperature increases. Assume that at a temperature of 90oC, the surface tension (and buoyant force) would not be enough to support the weight of the insect. How much heat energy should be supplied to the water such that the surface tension and buoyant force can no longer support the weight of the insect? (Specific heat capacity of water is 4.2 x 103 J kg-1 K-1)
child_mcqs.explanation:
Using `Q = mcDeltaT` and `m = rhoxxV`

Heat energy required

`Q = mcDeltaT`

`Q = 1xx10^3xx(500xx10^-6)xx4.2xx10^3xx(90-10)`              (Note: cm3 has to be converted to m3)

`Q = 168 000 J = 1.68xx10^5 J`

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description:
Generally, an acid dissociates in water to produce hydrogen ions.

HA + H2O → A- + H3O+

Where A- is the conjugate base of the acid HA.

Conversely, a base causes the dissociation of water to produce hydroxide ions.

B + H2O → HB+ + OH-

Where HB+ is the conjugate acid of the base B.

Strong acids and bases dissociate in a single irreversible step while the dissociation of weak acids and bases are reversible, as an equilbrium is present. The strength of an acid or base can be measured by its dissociation constant, Ka and Kb respectively.

The dissociation constant can also be expressed as an equilibrium constant, the concentration of products over reactants at equilibrium.

For example:
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following acids is the weakest?

  Acid

Ka value

  Formic acid

1.8 x 10-4

  Hydrocyanic acid

6.2 x 10-10

  Hypoiodous acid

2.3 x 10-11

  Propanoic acid

1.3 x 10-5
child_mcqs.explanation: Ka is a measure of an acid’s strength, thus its ability to dissociate in water to produce hydrogen ions; the higher the value of Ka, the stronger the acid. So the weakest acid has the smallest Ka.

child_mcqs.description: Acid-base indicators are often used in titrations between acids and bases as the change in concentration of hydrogen ions or hydroxide ions in a solution yields an observable colour change. What can be inferred about the relative strength of an acid-base indicator?
child_mcqs.explanation: We are told that an acid/base indicator changes colour as the concentration of hydrogen and hydroxide ions changes in a solution. This shows that an equilibrium must be involved as the reaction taking place is reversible, i.e. an acidic solution gives one colour while a more basic solution gives another colour. Hence, the indicator must be a weak acid/base. It cannot be a strong acid/base as strong acid/bases dissociate in a single step and is not reversible.

answers.description: It can be either a strong or weak acid/base
It can neither be a strong nor weak acid/base

child_mcqs.description:
Which of the following statement/s is TRUE regarding the dissociation of a weak base and its conjugate acid in water?

I – They combine to give the ionization of water

II – The level of dissociation of the conjugate acid in water can be measured using Ka
child_mcqs.explanation:
The dissociation of a weak base in water is as follows:

B + H2O ⇔ HB+ + OH-

The dissociation of its conjugate acid in water is:

HB+ + H2O ⇔ B + H3O+

They can be combined to give the ionization of water, hence I is true:

2H2O ⇔ OH- + H3O+

Ka is a measure of an acid’s strength, and its level of dissociation in water (i.e. whether it dissociates completely for a strong acid or partially for a weak acid), so by definition, II is also true.

child_mcqs.description:
Sulfuric acid, H2SO4 is a diprotic acid that dissociates in two steps, with the following acid dissociation constants, Ka1 and Ka2 for the first and second step respectively:

Ka1 = 1.0 x 107

Ka2 = 1.2 x 10-2         

Which of the following statements cannot be true?
child_mcqs.explanation:
We can observe that Ka1 is much larger than Ka2. We can conclude from the magnitude of these constants that H2SO4 is a much stronger acid than HSO4-, such that the first step must proceed via a single essentially irreversible step - the product concentration is roughly 3000 times higher than the reagent concentration. With such a high K, it is very hard to reverse the reaction, so C is incorrect.

As the first step has a much higher Ka1 value, thus indicating its high acid strength and subsequent high degree of dissociation in water to produce hydrogen ions, we can infer that the first hydrogen ion is more ionisable than the second. Similarly, the low Ka2 value indicates that since HSO4- is a weaker acid, the second step can be reversible.

answers.description: The first hydrogen ion is more ionisable than the second hydrogen ion
HSO4- is a weaker acid than H2SO4

child_mcqs.description: The starting concentration of a weak monoprotic acid and its dissociation constant are given. Which of the following values can be determined?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A weak monoprotic acid dissociates in a single step and exists in equilibrium, therefore we can treat Ka as an equilibrium constant. The initial concentration of the hydrogen ion and the conjugate base is zero as the acid is not dissociated. As the acid dissociates and approaches equilibrium, the change in concentration, x, shows how much the acid dissociates, thus at equilibrium, the concentration of the acid becomes [HA] – x. At equilibrium, the concentration of hydrogen ions is equal to x, as it shows how much the acid has dissociated to form hydrogen ions. As a monoprotic acid dissociates in a single step, the number of moles of hydrogen ions and the conjugate base are equal, hence the concentration of the conjugate base is also equal to x. This is best represented in the table below.

 

[HA]

[H3O+]

[A-]

Initial concentration

 [HA]

 0

 0

Change in concentration

 - x

 + x

 + x

Concentration at equilibrium

 [HA] - x

 x

 x

From this, we can express Ka as:

We can then rearrange the above expression to form a quadratic equation to solve for x, which equals the hydrogen ion concentration and the concentration of the conjugate base. The degree of ionization can also be calculated using the expression [H3O+]/[HA]. 

From a logical perspective however, if you can prove that either of A or B is correct, then you don't need to look at the other answers. A and B are intimately linked (the concentration of hydrogen ions = concentration of conjugate base) so if A or B is true, then so is the other. If they're both true, then the answer has to be D without even having to look at or understand what C is.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description:
Uranium-232 (mass = 232.04u), decays to thallium-228 (mass = 228.03u) with emission of one particle of radiation. 

Note: neutrinos do not contribute to mass balance. Mass of helium = 4.003u, mass of electron = 0.0006u and 1u = 931.5 MeV.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above information, what is the likely particle emitted during this decay process and which of the following decay equations are correct?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Given that the atomic mass number of uranium-232 = 232 and the atomic mass number of thallium-228 = 228

Atomic mass number is always conserved, meaning the particle emitted has to have an atomic mass number of `232-228 = 4`. Only helium (`alpha` decay) fits this description.

child_mcqs.description: Can the above decay process be spontaneous?
child_mcqs.explanation:
`"Change in mass during decay"`

`= "Mass after decay" ("daughter nucleus" + alpha  "particle") - "mass before decay" ("mass of uranium-232")`

` = 228.03u + 4.003u - 232.04u = 0.007u`

There is loss of mass. Decay can occur spontaneously.

If the parent had less mass than the daughter+alpha particle, then decay cannot occur spontaneously by the law of conservation of energy.

child_mcqs.description: Based on your answer above, what is energy released by the decay of uranium-232?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Using the conversion: 1u = 931.5 MeV

`"Energy released" = 0.007xx931.5 = 6.52 "MeV"`

Note: 

`0.007xx931.5 = 7xx10^-3xx931.5 = 7xx0.9315 ~~ 7xx0.9 ~~ 6.3 "MeV"`    `->` A is closest.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
Quantum numbers are a useful tool for describing the properties of electrons within an atom. Each set of four numbers is unique for each electron. However, if an electron is within an orbital alone, it is free to change its set of numbers as long as it remains within the same orbital. The numbers that comprise each set are as follows:

Principle Quantum Number (n): describes the energy level of the electron and determines the range of potential quantum numbers to follow. This is equivalent of the row number the element is found in, on the periodic table.

Angular Momentum Number (ℓ): can be any integer from 0 to n – 1, determines the shape of the electron orbital (0 = s, 1 = p, 2 = d and 3 = f)

Magnetic Number (mℓ): can be any integer from – ℓ to + ℓ, determines the number of different orientations an orbital can have simultaneously (ex. a p orbital can have an mℓ of -1, 0 or +1, so there are three p orbitals)

Spin Number (ms): can be either +½ or -½, having opposite spins allows a maximum of two electrons to occupy each orbital and they are said to be paired when this occurs

With increasing atomic number, electrons are added in a particular pattern, as determined by the principal quantum number and angular momentum number. This is illustrated on the diagram below. The pattern of addition to the orbitals can be found by following each successive arrow from top to bottom.

The electron configuration of an atom is a listing of the number of electrons in each orbital, according to the filling pattern. In the case of carbon this would be 1s22s22p2. Electron configurations can be quite lengthy for elements with high atomic numbers. As such, they are generally abbreviated by stating the preceding noble gas (according to atomic number) and then stating only the configuration of any additional electrons. For carbon, this would be [He]2s22p2

Ne (Z = 10): [He] 2s2 2p6
Ar (Z = 18): [Ne] 3s2 3p6 
Kr (Z = 36): [Ar] 3d10 4s2 4p6
Xe (Z = 54): [Kr] 4d10 5s2 5p6
Rn (Z = 86): [Xe] 4f14 5d10 6s2 6p6

child_mcqs.description: What are the quantum numbers of the outermost electron on a sodium atom?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Sodium is found at the beginning third row of the periodic table. As it comes relatively early, there are a couple of ways to approach this question. The fastest way to solve this question requires some background knowledge. Sodium is found in the s-block of the periodic table (the first two columns). These are the elements which have their outermost electrons in an s orbital. Already then, the first two quantum numbers are provided. n = 3 as sodium is in the third energy level and ℓ = 0 because that is the number which corresponds to an s-orbital. From the rules provided earlier, mℓ must be 0 and ms can be either +½ or -½. Only option A satisfies these requirements.

Without knowledge of the s-block, the other way to determine what type of orbital sodium’s outmost electron occupies is by looking at the electron filling diagram and accounting for all of the electrons of sodium (a viable option as there are only 11). The 1s orbital allows for two electrons, the 2s orbital allows for a further two and the 2p orbitals allow for six. This leaves a single electron, which will then occupy the 3s orbital. The rest of the quantum numbers can then be derived as explained above.

child_mcqs.description: In some elements, unpaired electrons in d orbitals can be induced to have the same spin number. This results in the magnetisation of the element. Which of the following elements could be magnetised according to this principle?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Again, this question can be answered very quickly knowing that only cobalt is in the d-block of the periodic table (all the transition metals). Thus, it will be the only element with the potential for unpaired electrons in d orbitals. Alternatively, you would have to check each atom individually for the configuration of its outermost electrons (starting at the preceding noble gas, which has been given in the preamble to speed up matters). Only the outermost electrons need to be checked, as they are the only ones which have the potential to be unpaired. Applying this method will show that both uranium and tin may have unpaired outer electrons, but these are in f and p orbitals respectively. The electron arrangements of each element are as below. Uranium is tricky because the arrow diagram stops at 7s, but you should be able to figure out from the pattern that the next orbital to be filled will be 5f, and then 6d, 7p, 8s etc.

U: [Rn] 5f4 7s2
Sn: [Kr] 4d10 5s2 5p2
Co: [Ar] 3d7 4s2
Sr: [Kr] 5s2

child_mcqs.description: In some instances, electrons do not fill the orbitals in the order predicted. This can occur when the energy levels of the orbitals are very close to one another. Which of the following is not an exception to the predicted filling order?
child_mcqs.explanation: In each instance but gold, one of the s orbital electrons has been moved to another orbital. Gold is thus the only one that fills in the correct order as predicted by the arrow diagrams.

child_mcqs.description: Consider any one electron in the outer shell of a neon atom. At any given moment, how many different sets of quantum numbers could describe that electron?
child_mcqs.explanation: The outermost electrons of neon are within the 2p orbital. There are 6 sets of quantum numbers that electrons in this orbital can have. At any given moment though, a single neon electron may only have one of them. As the 2p orbital of the neon atom is full, each electron may only have a single set of quantum numbers. This is in contrast, for example, to boron. It has a single electron in the 2p orbital. At any given moment its electron may be potentially described by 6 sets of quantum numbers.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory disease in which the insulating cover of nerve cells, known as myelin, in the brain and spinal cord is damaged. This damage disrupts the ability of parts of the nervous system to communicate. While the cause is not clear, the underlying mechanism is thought to be either destruction by the immune system or failure of the myelin-producing cells. There is no known cure for multiple sclerosis. Treatments attempt to improve function after an attack and prevent new attacks. There are several subtypes of MS. Relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis is characterized by clearly defined relapses with full recovery or with residual deficit upon recovery. There is no disease progression during the periods between disease relapses which have unpredictable lengths. This type of MS accounts for approximately 85 to 90 percent of cases at onset. Another subtype, known as primary progressive, occurs in approximately 10–20% of individuals, with no remission after the initial symptoms. It is characterized by progression of disability from onset.

child_mcqs.description: What is the purpose of myelin?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is the correct answer. The purpose of myelin is to decrease the loss of action potential by preventing ions form escaping the axon. Because of this, A is incorrect. B and C is not the role of myelin.

answers.description: Causes action potential loss
Protects neurons from toxic injury
Maintains resting potential

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following would theoretically help a patient with multiple sclerosis?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is the correct answer because it focuses on the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) and increases myelin. In the passage, it explains that MS is a disease of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), not the peripheral nervous system (everywhere except the brain and spinal cord). A and B are both wrong since they focus on the peripheral nervous system. C is incorrect because it implies that the immune system will damage myelin, which would cause more damage.

answers.description: A drug that increases myelin production in the peripheral nervous system
A drug that decreases the rate of myelin destruction in the peripheral nervous system
A drug that causes T-cells to attack myelin in the central nervous system
A drug that increases myelin production in the central nervous system

child_mcqs.description: Which is the worse type of MS and which is the correct reasoning?
child_mcqs.explanation: This question was two part, needing both the correct type and the reason behind it. The answer is progressive because damage is occurring at all times to myelin, slowly destroying it. A uses the point that the damage in a single remitting attack causes lots of damage but it is important to realize that most of the damage is repaired after the attack and between attacks is an invariable amount of time. This means it could be years between attacks and no damage is done during this time. B is false and the reasoning is illogical. Just because more people have a type of disease does not mean it will be more severe. D is false and is illogical. All forms of MS do not have a cure at the present time so this cannot be used as an explanation of which subtype is more severe.

answers.description: Relapsing-remitting because damage during a single attack is greater than a slow progression (seen in primary progressive)
Relapsing-remitting because a larger percentage of the population have it
Primary progressive because damage is occurring all the time
Primary progressive because this is not curable

child_mcqs.description:
Which one of the following makes myelin?

1. Oligodendrocytes

2. Schwann cells

3. Neuron

4. Fibroblast
child_mcqs.explanation: Oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells are the two types of cells that make myelin. It is also useful to know for the GAMSAT that oligodendrocytes make myelin in the central nervous system while Schwann cells make myelin in the peripheral nervous system.

child_mcqs.description: Axons that are myelinated contain small breaks in the myelin sheath at regular intervals along the axon membrane, are called nodes of Ranvier. What is the purpose of these in an action potential?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is the correct answer. At nodes of Ranvier, there are voltage-gated sodium AND voltage-gated potassium channels. The voltage-gated sodium channels allow sodium into the axon causing depolarization while voltage-gated potassium channels allow potassium out of the axon causing repolarization. C is a nonsense answer and nothing like this occurs during an action potential.

answers.description: Allow ions to move into the axon
Allow ions to move out of the axon
Allow ions to integrate into the axon
Two of the above

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
Infrared spectroscopy (IR) involves molecular vibrations, where a molecule absorbs infrared light from the electromagnetic spectrum and is excited to a higher vibrational energy level.  The frequency of infrared light used is usually expressed in cm-1, also known as the wavenumber of the radiation, and is the number of wavelengths of a particular radiation in 1 cm. The resultant IR spectrum shows a series of peaks over a range of wavenumbers, where such peaks can be attributed to particular functional groups as functional groups generally absorb similar frequencies, thus allowing qualitative analysis in IR spectroscopy.

Molecular vibrations occur in different modes, such as bending, rocking, stretching and scissoring. The number of fundamental modes of a molecule can be calculated using the formulae below, where N is the number of atoms:

            (3N – 6) vibrations for a non-linear molecule

            (3N – 5) vibrations for a linear molecule

However, only molecular vibrations where the absorption of radiation changes the dipole moment of the molecule are IR active, i.e. a molecule must contain a net molecular polarity in order for it to be IR active.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is FALSE?
child_mcqs.explanation: From the introduction, we are told that IR is a qualitative analysis that enables the detection of particular functional groups, hence A and C are possible. We are also told that a molecule absorbs infrared light and is excited to a higher vibrational energy level, so by theory, the energy of light must equal the difference in energy between the two vibrational energy levels. Hence B is false as IR does not provide quantitative analysis (i.e. how many functional groups are present).

answers.description: An IR spectrum can differentiate between but-2-enoic acid from butan-3-ol
An IR spectrum can determine the number of hydroxyl groups present
An IR spectrum can suggest that a hydroxyl group is present
The energy of light absorbed by a molecule equals the difference in energy of two vibrational energy levels

child_mcqs.description: A molecule absorbs light of 1000cm-1. What is the wavelength of light in nm?
child_mcqs.explanation: If the wavenumber is 1000 cm-1, then 1000 wavelengths fit within 1 cm. The wavelength must be 1/1000 of a cm, or 1*10-3 cm, which is 1*10-5 m. Converting this to nm gives the answer (1*10-5 * 109 = 1*104)

child_mcqs.description:
Carbon dioxide has 4 vibrational modes, 2 stretching and 2 bending, as depicted below. The arrow indicates the direction of movement for the atom:

How many modes are IR inactive?
child_mcqs.explanation: Only molecules that have a change in dipole moment, or a net molecular polarity are IR active.  We can see that only the first molecule has zero net polarity as the stretching of the two oxygen molecules in opposite directions, causes cancellation of polarity, which makes it a non-polar molecule, so it is IR inactive. This makes sense logically as it is a symmetric stretch, meaning that it must have zero net polarity. In the other 3 molecules, the movement of the carbon atom induces a change in dipole moment and a net polarity overall, thus only one mode is IR inactive. Alternatively, we know that CO2 is linear, and so should have 3N - 6 = 3 active modes, and are told in the preamble to this question that it has four total vibrational modes, so that one mode must be inactive.

child_mcqs.description:
Polarisability is the distortion of the electron cloud from its normal shape. In Raman spectroscopy, only vibrational modes with an asymmetric change in polarisability at both extremes are Raman active.

Using Question 3, how many modes in carbon dioxide are Raman active?
child_mcqs.explanation:
All 4 molecules have changes in polarisability as the electron cloud is distorted due to vibrations, but not all of them have an asymmetric change in polarisability.

For the first vibration, there is an asymmetric change during vibration as the change in polarisability is a linear function. This can be observed in a graph of polarisability vs vibrational co-ordinate, where the x-axis is the vibrational co-ordinate and the y-axis is polarisability. At one extreme of the mode, the cloud is spread widely, where at the other it is condensed tightly.

For the other three vibrations, the change in polarisability is symmetric as a quadratic function is observed:

 

So only one vibration is Raman active.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
Drug molecules can only exert their physiological effects after binding to a receptor. The study of this drug-receptor interaction is termed pharmacodynamics, and is a key component to the effective development and use of drugs. Shown below is a typical iteration of the Stephenson-Furchgott model of Occupation Theory, which describes the effect a particular drug-receptor combination can have on a given tissue.

E represents the observed response of the drug-receptor combination (and could be measured in methods as varied as a change in tissue length, ion concentration, tissue temperature, percentage of cells killed), and Em the maximum response attainable by the tissue. 

[A] represents the concentration of the drug in question, and [R]t the total population of the receptor in question. The ɛ represents drug A's intrinsic efficacy, a property specific to the drug-receptor combination.

S is commonly referred to as the stimulus, as it summarises the drug-receptor combination's effect on the tissue under particular conditions.

child_mcqs.description:
The fraction expression in the latter part of the equation shown above represents, altogether, the proportion of receptors occupied by (bound to) the drug in question. Here [AR] represents the amount of drug-bound receptors, and as before, [R]t the amount of receptors (bound or unbound) in total.

Given this information, what can be deduced about the term Kd?
child_mcqs.explanation:
If Kd is the concentration of drug at which 50% of receptors are bound, then when [A] = Kd, 50% of receptors are bound. By plugging [A] = Kd into the equation, the right hand side of the equation becomes 1/2. The left hand side has the total number of bound receptors divided by the total number of receptors, so when [A] = Kd, half the receptors are bound.

B is incorrect as although receptor occupancy is 50%, the stimulus function f(s) may be such that 50% occupancy does not yield a 50% response (imagine if f(s) were for example, a parabolic curve).

C is incorrect as Kd is dependent on affinity rather than efficacy - indeed, efficacy is a variable unto itself in the Stephenson-Furchgott equation in the question stem.

D is incorrect as although Kd is indeed dependent on the drug-receptor combination, this does not mean it is unreliable (it is, in fact defined by A).

answers.description: Kd represents the concentration of drug at which 50% of receptors are bound
Kd represents the of drug concentration at which 50% of the maximal effect is seen
Kd is dependent on the intrinsic efficacy, ɛ, of the drug
Kd is dependent on the combination of drug and receptor and therefore cannot consistently be true to any of the above

child_mcqs.description:
Constitutive agonism is a complicating factor in pharmacology, wherein receptors that are not occupied are active nevertheless. Essentially, receptors are able to adopt active conformations independent of drug, though the drug binding may stimulate adoption of active conformations far more readily. The following extension of the Stephenson-Furchgott model can partially account for the concept of constitutive agonism.

Given that [R] represents the amount of unoccupied receptor , which of the following statements is true?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Answer A is correct as β affects only [R], that is, unbound receptor only (as it appears only as β • [R]). It follows that β represents the stimulus derived from unbound receptor - how good the receptor is at being active independent of drug.

Answer B is incorrect as β represents the drug's ability to autonomously adopt the active conformation, without the drug (as above).

Answer C is incorrect as ɛ > β will mean the drug-bound receptor will activate the receptor moreso than the unbound. As such, the drug will be an agonist.

Answer D is incorrect as [R] will decrease as Kd decreases - if Kd decreases, then the concentration of drug required to achieve 50% occupancy is lower and thus its affinity is higher. Therefore, for the same [A], the drug will occupy more receptors, and [R] will decrease.

answers.description: β represents the receptor's ability to adopt the active conformation independent of drug
β represents the drug's ability to force receptor R into the active conformation
If ɛ > β then drug A is an inhibitor of receptor R

child_mcqs.description:
The two-state model is an alternative to account for the constitutive activity of receptors. Shown below is a graphical representation of this, wherein A represents the drug, AR the drug-occupied receptor, and an asterisk (*) denotes the active form of a receptor.

Which of the numbered processes is not accounted for by the extended Stephenson-Furchgott model?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The key here is that the extended Stephenson-Furchgott model does not treat R and R* differently from an affinity point of view. As such, the process unaccounted for is 3 - the binding of the drug to the active but unbound receptor.

1 represents the drug binding to the receptor (affinity) - this is accounted for by [R].

2 represents the activation of the receptor by the drug - that is, ɛ.

4 represents the receptor's activation independent of drug, β.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description: There are two types of glands in the human body: exocrine and endocrine glands. The former have ducts through which they secrete substances to a membrane surface; the latter are ductless glands, releasing their products into the blood. The pancreas is a mixed gland composed of both endocrine and exocrine gland cells. The exocrine acinar cells ('acinar' refers to a cluster of cells) produce bicarbonate and enzyme secretions which are ducted into the duodenum. The endocrine cells are clustered in the pancreatic tissue as islets. The islets are composed of alpha (α) cells, secreting glucagon, and beta (ß) cells, secreting insulin. The hormones insulin and glucagon regulate blood sugar levels over fed and fasting states (just eaten vs. between meals) and are antagonistic of one another. The pancreas can release hormones based on the sugar concentration in its own blood supply. Other cells in the body can release hormones in response to blood sugar concentrations to influence pancreatic secretion of insulin and glucagon. Insulin is an anabolic hormone, promoting cellular uptake of glucose from the blood for macromolecule synthesis. Glucagon is a catabolic hormone, causing liver cells to breakdown glycogen stores and synthesise glucose to increase blood sugar levels. This is important as the brain relies primarily on glucose for energy.

child_mcqs.description: In regards to blood sugar regulation, which of the following is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The definitions of anabolic and catabolic metabolism are assumed knowledge (build up vs. break down). Students should also be familiar with insulin and glucagon and basic physiology of blood glucose regulation i.e. blood glucose rises immediately after a meal as the gut absorbs glucose, and decreases while fasting. 

The diagram provides clarification for students about  the stimulus direction for hormone release in regards to blood sugar concentrations. Insulin is produced by ß-cells and acts to reduce blood sugar levels. It is secreted in greater amounts immediately after a meal (fed state) in response to high blood glucose. Glucagon is produced by α-cells and is secreted when blood glucose drops (fasting state).

In the fed state, ß-cells will increase and α-cells will decrease secretions. In the fasting state, α-cells will increase and ß-cells will decrease secretions

answers.description: Pancreatic α-cells increase secretions during the fed state
Pancreatic ß-cells increase secretions during the fed state
