This means that 2 x10-3 moles of NaOH (moles = concentration x volume) were required to reach equivalence, meaning the same number of moles of benzoic acid were present initially. By the equivalence point, all these moles of benzoic acid had been converted into the benzoate ion. The last step is to determine the volume of the solution when the titration is stopped. It is important to note that the titration in this question proceeds long after equivalence. At termination, 40 mL of NaOH had been added to the initial 40 mL of benzoic acid solution, yielding a final volume of 80 mL (0.08 L). 2 x10-3 moles of benzoate in 0.08 L of solution makes the concentration of the ion 2.5 x 10-2 M.

child_mcqs.description:
Titrations can also be based around redox reactions. KMnO4 is a particularly useful agent for such titrations as it is a strong oxidizer. It is also is deep purple in solution, but becomes clear when reduced in acidic conditions. Consider the titration of 100 mL of an acidified solution of butanal, with 0.01 M KMnO4. The purple colour of the titrant is lost rapidly when added to the titrate solution, but persists once 10 mL of the titrant has been added. What was the initial concentration of the butanal? The net chemical reaction is shown below.

5 C3H7COH + 2 MnO4- + 6 H+ → 5 C3H7COOH + 2 Mn2+ + 3 H2O
child_mcqs.explanation:
From the information provided, 10 mL is the point at which equivalence is reached. The number of moles of MnO4- added can be calculated using the formula n= C x V. This ends up being 1 x 10-4 moles.

In contrast to the monoprotic acid-base titrations described earlier in the question, it is important to notice that the permanganate and butanal do not react in a 1:1 ratio, but rather 2:5. That means that for every permanganate ion added to reach equivalence, there must be 2.5 butanal molecules. This means that to reach equivalence 2.5 x 10-4 moles of butanal must have been present.

The last step is to calculate the original concentration of butanal. Again this uses the n = C x V equation. With an original volume of 100 mL, the original concentration of butanal must have been 2.5 x 10-3 M.

sections.title: Section I - Reasoning in the Humanities

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
Read below the following extract from an academic article:

“Speculative realism” has lately emerged as one of the most provocative, and frequently misrepresented, currents in contemporary intellectual life. As articulated during the 2007 conference from which it takes its name, speculative realism encompasses an entire spectrum of philosophies “committed to upholding the autonomy of reality … against the depredations of anthropocentrism” (Brassier et al. 306). After a century of phenomenological and deconstructive investigations into consciousness and language, speculative realists take seriously the metaphysical claim that the world exists, independent of the mind and its perceptions. At the same time, in contesting all forms of relativism or anti-realism, they are joined in an appreciation of what Graham Harman calls “the strangeness of the real: a strangeness undetectable by the instruments of common sense” (Quentin viii). Speculative realists speak of reality in surprising, even uncanny, ways.

Skeptics have dismissed speculative realism as everything from the philosophical form of neoliberal economics to the dangerous renouncing of all political alignment. In this essay, I will argue not only for its philosophical importance, but also for its potential to reshape debate about “nature” in literary studies. My investigation therefore turns to romanticism, a literary and philosophical movement defined by its sustained reflection on the concept. Reading speculative realism through romanticism, and vice versa, suggests that much remains to be said about nature, even in its romantic instantiation – which turns out to be less familiar than we might have thought. It also shows how nearly our present theoretical moment hews to a certain romanticism.

For most speculative realists, the tradition of modern anti-realism begins with Kant’s epistemology. Responding to Hume’s skeptical attack on the uniformity of nature, Kant established the possibility of empirical realism by grounding it in a transcendental idealism. According to the familiar story, the Kantian revolution ensured the validity and coherence of our phenomenal experiences, but at the cost of transforming things in themselves into mere logical placeholders. After Kant, dogmatic speculation about the world in itself is supplanted by critical inquiry into the conditions under which experience of the world is possible.

The story is hardly new. More strikingly, though, the speculative realists insist that this transcendental procedure provides the basis for nearly all forms of modern thought. This poses major challenges for a renewed realism, since any contemporary thinking about the nature of reality begins with what Iain Hamilton Grant terms “the excision of the ‘in itself’ from metaphysics”. Grant draws on the work of F.W.J. Schelling, who declared in Kant’s immediate wake that nature does not exist for modern philosophy. Replacing ontology with the transcendental analytic and cosmology with the transcendental dialectic, Kant’s “anti-physics” forecloses on speculation about the in-itself or its origins. The transcendental method ultimately prevents us from engaging with nature other than as it is shaped by the conditions of human knowledge.

Greg Ellermann. "Speculative Romanticism." SubStance 44.1 (2015): 154-174

child_mcqs.description: The best replacements for "depredations" in this passage are:
child_mcqs.explanation: Substituting the words provided for "depredations" allows us to see which answers make grammatical sense. A and C are grammatically incorrect. This leaves B and D. The context of the quote, "upholding the autonomy of reality … against the depredations of anthropocentrism” suggests that "depredations" has connotations with damage. Speculative realism is described against upholding "the autonomy of reality" against what anthropocentrism does to reality. Therefore B is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: According to the author of this article, speculative realists:
child_mcqs.explanation: The phrase "speculative realism encompasses an entire spectrum of philosophies “committed to upholding the autonomy of reality … against the depredations of anthropocentrism”" places speculative realism against anthropocentrism. Therefore A is incorrect. B is cited by the author as an opinion of "skeptics" of speculative realism, but the author does not identify with the skeptics. It is Kant, not the speculative realists who is identified with establishing "the possibility of empirical realism by grounding it in a transcendental idealism". This leaves D, which the passage affirms: "speculative realists take seriously the metaphysical claim that the world exists, independent of the mind and its perceptions."

answers.description: Are committed to upholding the autonomy of anthropocentrism
Espouse the philosophical form of neoliberal economics
Establish the possibility of empirical realism by grounding it in a transcendental idealism
Take seriously the metaphysical claim that the world exists, independent of the human mind

child_mcqs.description: According to the author, why is it important to study romanticism alongside speculative realism?
child_mcqs.explanation: C and D are things that the article arguably affirms, but they do not answer the question, which is why it is important to study speculative realism alongside romanticism. This leaves A and B. A is the best answer because it encapsulates the author's motivation for writing the article, and there is little evidence that the author agrees with B. The author affirms A and contradicts B when writing, "Reading speculative realism through romanticism, and vice versa, suggests that much remains to be said about nature, even in its romantic instantiation – which turns out to be less familiar than we might have thought. It also shows how nearly our present theoretical moment hews to a certain romanticism."

answers.description: Doing so suggests that much remains to be said about nature, even in its romantic formulation.
Doing so shows how distant our present theoretical moment is from romanticism.
Because the tradition of modern anti-realism begins with Kant’s epistemology
Transcendental procedure provides the basis for nearly all forms of modern thought.

child_mcqs.description: The author notes that F.W.J. Schelling "declared in Kant’s immediate wake that nature does not exist for modern philosophy." Does nature exist for speculative realism, according to the author?
child_mcqs.explanation: The key sentence is, "After a century of phenomenological and deconstructive investigations into consciousness and language, speculative realists take seriously the metaphysical claim that the world exists, independent of the mind and its perceptions."  This sentence affirms that the world - and by extension nature - exists for speculative realists, hence the author's statement that speculative realism has the potential to "reshape debate about “nature” in literary studies". This shows that A and D are incorrect and B is the best answer. (C is a distractor).

answers.description: No, because speculative realism is the most modern of modern philosophies.
Yes, because speculative realists argue that the world exists beyond human perception of it.
Yes, because speculative realism replaces ontology with the transcendental analytic and cosmology with the transcendental dialectic
No, for reasons that are unclear in this article

child_mcqs.description: According to the author, why is speculative realism interesting?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is what skeptics apparently think of speculative realism, not the author and D is what transcendentalism apparently does, not speculative realism. This leaves B and C. C is a better answer, because it is a summary of the author's main purpose in writing the article. While there is a sense in the passage that speculative realism is sometimes misunderstood, this is not something the author finds as interesting as C.

answers.description: Because it involves a dangerous renouncing of all political alignment
Because it is a frequently misrepresented current in contemporary intellectual life
Because speculative realists' engagement with the metaphysical claim that the world exists, independent of the mind and its perceptions allows for a reevaluation of anthropocentric, romantic "nature"
Because speculative realism involves transforming things in themselves into mere logical placeholders

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
Melvin et al, Improving Medical Students' Written Communication Skills

Deficiencies in written and verbal communication within a healthcare team have been directly linked to increased incidence of patient-related errors. Despite the critical nature of these competencies in practice, the teaching of communication skills to medical students is often informal, either through an apprenticeship model without formal feedback or through the hidden curriculum. The literature addressing communication skills in medical education often focuses on verbal communication between the physician and the patient. Few studies address the important facets of communication that involve the synthesis of historical information into written admission notes, leading to a paucity of information on best practices. Written documentation of an initial patient encounter, referred to as a consultation notes, represents a complex, multifaceted task in which a student must collect, organise and synthesise a wealth of information from a patient interaction. The written case presentation is a fundamental skill across all disciplines in medicine and a necessary competency for students to achieve in medical training.

It has been previously reported that medical students largely learn communication skills through trial and error, and that they rely heavily on feedback from residents and staff physicians to refine their abilities. A key setting for developing these skills is during on-call shifts, where students communicate directly with residents and staff about specific patient encounters. The feedback and instruction that students receive on their written documentation during and immediately following a call shift are highly dependent on several factors, including the available time for supervising residents or staff to give directed instruction, the resident or staff comfort with delivering constructive feedback, as well as staff and resident preferences as to what written documentation should include. Such variables result in a heterogeneous mixture of medical student competency and comfort with oral and written communication at the end of rotations.

Many medical schools in Canada attempt to facilitate feedback on communication skills using encounter cards. Encounter cards are portable evaluation tools for a specific skill (eg, history taking, physical examination (PE), etc) and are used following the assessor observing the student in a clinical encounter. Encounter cards have permitted some assessment of communication abilities but their use has not been shown to result in improvement of medical student's oral presentation or written communication skills.

child_mcqs.description: Which aspect of training medical students in communication is of most concern to the author
child_mcqs.explanation: The article mostly addresses concerns regarding student competency arising from variables in clinical communication training. The article lists a number of practices that cause varied feedback between medical students. This best aligns with answer B. The skill may be difficult to acquire, although the article does not focus upon this. There is no suggestion that the skill is not recognized as important, rather than the methods for attaining it are ineffective. D is specifically mentioned, but is not the direct reason for students receiving inadequate training.

answers.description: The failure to recognize this skill as important
The lack of studies addressing written communication

child_mcqs.description: What is a listed problem regarding the setting in which students learn communication skills?
child_mcqs.explanation: Although it is not the only location in which students learn, the article specifically addresses the on-call clinical setting and the effects of this on student learning. It describes how this results in variability of teaching that depends upon several factors. One listed factor is that it is dependent upon available time, such that busy time periods may restrict the time in which students can receive feedback. This is answer D. A and B are specifically mentioned, but it is difficult to suggest that these negatively affect students learning. For instance, the concern is not that students are learning from more experienced colleagues, but rather the variable environment in which they learn or the fact that their particular supervisor may lack teaching competency. C is not mentioned.

answers.description: It requires direct communication with residents and staff
It forces medical students to learn through trial and error
It requires medical students to receive feedback when they are physically and emotionally tired
It may restrict the time in which students can obtain feedback

child_mcqs.description: Encounter cards
child_mcqs.explanation: Encounter cards represent an attempt to facilitate a more standardized feedback for medical students, by ensuring that assessors do observe students and that that this feedback has some structure (e.g. history taking, PE). This is answer A. However, the last line provides that they are not shown to have positive effect on outcomes, which causes answer B to be incorrect. Answer C is not correct as although encounter cards are unsuccessful, this does not mean that there is no solution to the problem. D is incorrect as the encounter cards are not an example of the author’s main concern (variable teaching), but a failed attempt to remedy it.

answers.description: Are an example of an attempt to implement a formalized evaluation of communication skills
Provide a sufficient remedy to the problem of teaching medical students adequate communication skills
Demonstrate the inefficacy of attempting to address issues with medical student communication abilities
Provide an example of the author’s main concern in teaching communication to medical students

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the text below, from Susan Sontag's On Photography (1977):

Humankind lingers unregenerately in Plato's cave, still reveling, its age-old habit, in mere images of the truth. But being educated by photographs is not like being educated by older, more artisanal images. For one thing, there are a great many more images around, claiming our attention. The inventory started in 1839 and since then just about everything has been photographed, or so it seems. This very insatiability of the photographing eye changes the terms of confinement in the cave, our world. In teaching us a new visual code, photographs alter and enlarge our notions of what is worth looking at and what we have a right to observe. They are a grammar and, even more importantly, an ethics of seeing. Finally, the most grandiose result of the photographic enterprise is to give us the sense that we can hold the whole world in our heads -- as an anthology of images.

To collect photographs is to collect the world. Movies and television programs light up walls, flicker, and go out; but with still photographs the image is also an object, lightweight, cheap to produce, easy to carry about, accumulate, store. In Godard's Les Carabiniers (1963), two sluggish lumpen-peasants are lured into joining the King's Army by the promise that they will be able to loot, rape, kill, or do whatever else they please to the enemy, and get rich. But the suitcase of booty that Michel-Ange and Ulysse triumphantly bring home, years later, to their wives turns out to contain only picture postcards, hundreds of them, of Monuments, Department Stores, Mammals, Wonders of Nature, Methods of Transport, Works of Art, and other classified treasures from around the globe. Godard's gag vividly parodies the equivocal magic of the photographic image. Photographs are perhaps the most mysterious of all the objects that make up, and thicken, the environment we recognize as modern. Photographs really are experience captured, and the camera is the ideal arm of consciousness in its acquisitive mood.

child_mcqs.description: The humour of the story of Michel-Ange and Ulysse hinges on:
child_mcqs.explanation: Sontag writes, "In Godard's Les Carabiniers (1963), two sluggish lumpen-peasants are lured into joining the King's Army by the promise that they will be able to loot, rape, kill, or do whatever else they please to the enemy, and get rich. But the suitcase of booty that Michel-Ange and Ulysse triumphantly bring home, years later, to their wives turns out to contain only picture postcards, hundreds of them, of Monuments, Department Stores, Mammals, Wonders of Nature, Methods of Transport, Works of Art, and other classified treasures from around the globe." The humour hinges upon the subversion of expectations: the peasants do not bring home loot but picture postcards. These picture postcards are still images, not moving images so A is the best answer and B is incorrect. A paradox is not used here, and D is a distractor - Sontag does not talk about Godard's use of the camera, just the peasant's collection of postcards.

answers.description: The equivocal power of the moving image.

child_mcqs.description: According to Sontag in the first paragraph, photographs are important primarily because:
child_mcqs.explanation: This question tests your ability to read the passage carefully. D is a distractor, there is no mention of the digital, and given the time Sontag is writing this is unlikely. A and C are attributes Sontag attributes to photography, but they are not the most important thing she attributes to photography. She suggests that photos are an important topic for an essay because they alter our experience of the world: In teaching us a new visual code, photographs alter and enlarge our notions of what is worth looking at and what we have a right to observe. They are a grammar and, even more importantly, an ethics of seeing."

answers.description: Photography alters our experience of the world

child_mcqs.description: The author's comment that photographs "are a grammar and, even more importantly, an ethics of seeing" shows that the author believes:
child_mcqs.explanation: D is a distractor. A shows the best understanding of the phrase that photographs "are a grammar and, even more importantly, an ethics of seeing." "Grammar" is what structures language, and Sontag is suggesting that photographs structure the way we see the world. By saying that photographs offer an "ethics" of seeing, Sontag sums up her previous statement: "photographs alter and enlarge our notions of what is worth looking at and what we have a right to observe." Thus, Sontag is writing of how photographs structure the way we see the word, and thus what we value in the world.

answers.description: Photographs structure the way we see the word, and thus what we value in the world.
When the photographer looks through the camera, he or she has to decide what is worth photographing.
Photography provides us only with images of what are real, but these images are valued like memories.
Photography tinctures the visual with the problems of late global capitalism.

child_mcqs.description: According to the author, movies and photographs are different because:
child_mcqs.explanation: Sontag does not suggest that cinema can be more collectible than photographs so D is incorrect. A does not answer the question, it is unclear what "they" is referring to. C is a distractor - Sontag is writing before the digital. B is the best answer. Sontag writes, "Movies and television programs light up walls, flicker, and go out; but with still photographs the image is also an object, lightweight, cheap to produce, easy to carry about, accumulate, store."

answers.description: Photographs can be kept and stored in ways that films cannot be.
The photograph is more transformed by the digital than the movie.
Cinema is both more, and less collectible.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
Read the following passage from the eighteenth-century novel, The History of Sir Charles Grandison. The passage is an extract from a letter from Harriet Grandison to her "grandmamma," Mrs Shirley.

 

St. James's-square, Sunday Morning.

Last night, blessed be God, we came hither in health and spirits. We are preparing for church. There shall we pray for the travellers, and be thankful for ourselves.

I expect Lord and Lady L., Lord and Lady G. and my cousin Reeves's, according to the following billet from the ever-lively Lady G.

"My Harriet, thank God, is arrived, and in health and spirits. Caroline and Mrs. Reeves, I know, will long to congratulate you. I have therefore sent to invite them to dinner with you. Their good men, and mine of course, must be admitted. I know my Brother will not be displeased. He is indulgent to all the whimsies of his Charlotte that carry in the face of them, as this does, affectionate freedom. Besides, it is stealing time for him: I know he will not long be in town, and must see us all before he leaves it. He will hasten to the Hall, in order to pursue the glorious schemes of benevolence which he has formed, and in which hundreds will find their account.

"But let the green damask bed-chamber be got in a little sort of order, for a kind of nursery: Where we dine, we sup. My marmouset must be with me, you know. I have bespoke Lady L's---Mrs. Reeves is to bring hers. They are to crow at one another; and we are to have a squalling concert. As it is Sunday, I will sing an anthem to them. My pug will not crow, if I don't sing. Yet I am afraid, the little pagans will be less alive to a Christian hymn, than to the sprightlier Phillida, Phillida, of Tom. Durfey. I long to see how my agreeable Italian, poor thing! bears the absence of his father and mother. Bid him rub himself up, and look chearful, or I shall take him into our Nursery, to complete the chorus, when our brats are in a squalling fit. Adieu till to-morrow, my dear, and ever-dear, Harriet!---"

Lady G. is a charming nurse. She must be extraordinary in whatever she does. Signor Jeronymo admires her of all women. But she sometimes makes him look about him. He rejoices that he is with us; and is in charming spirits. He is extremely fond of children; particularly so of Lady G's---It is indeed one of the finest infants I ever saw: And he calls it, after her, His Marmouset, hugging it twenty times a day to his good-natured bosom. It would delight you to hear her sing to it, and to see her toss it about. Such a Setting-out in matrimony; who would have expected Charlotte to make such a wife, mother, nurse! ---Her brother is charmed with her. He draws her into the pleasantry that she loves; lays himself open to it; and Lord G. fares the better for their vivacity. Sir Charles generally contrives to do him honour, by appealing to him, when Charlotte is, as he complains, over-lively with himself: But that is, in truth, when he himself takes her down, and compliments her as if she were an overmatch for him. She often, at these times, shakes her head at me, as if she were sensible of his superiority in her own way.

But how I trifle! ---I am ready, quite ready, my dear Sir Charles. Lead your ever-grateful Harriet to the house of the All-good, All-merciful, All-mighty. There shall I, as I always do, edify by your chearful piety!

child_mcqs.description: From this passage, it is likely that the "Marmouset" is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The key to answering this question is this part of the passage is: "He is extremely fond of children; particularly so of Lady G's---It is indeed one of the finest infants I ever saw: And he calls it, after her, His Marmouset." This phrase identifies Lady G's infant with the marmouset. Other clues in the passage abound, for instance, Harriet praises Lady G's ability as a mother and a nurse. Therefore A is the correct answer.

answers.description: Signor Jeronymo's dog.

child_mcqs.description: From this passage, it is likely that "Phillida, Phillida, of Tom. Durfey" refers to:
child_mcqs.explanation: "Yet I am afraid, the little pagans will be less alive to a Christian hymn, than to the sprightlier Phillida, Phillida, of Tom. Durfey" identifies Phillida Phillida as being the opposite to a Christian hymn, and the description of the infants as "little pagans" further suggests that Lady G. is characterising them as not enjoying Christian music. Therefore B, a lively secular song is the best answer. While the song is likely to be eighteenth-century music (this being an eighteenth-century novel), the question asks you to use the passage to work out what Phillida Phillida is and D does not answer the question as precisely as B.

child_mcqs.description: What is the best description of Lady G?
child_mcqs.explanation: This is best answered by using elimination. We are given no evidence that piety (or deeply felt religion) is one of Lady G's main traits, so B can be ruled out. Nor are we given any evidence that Lady G is cruel - Harriet praises her as a wife, a mother and a nurse, so we can rule out D. A is a better answer than C, Lady G. does not seem particularly (and certainly not conventionally polite), while she is certainly loving, impetuous (that is, impulsive) and eccentric - calling her baby "marmouset" is an example of the last two.

child_mcqs.description: Judging from this passage, the best description of Harriet is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Again, this question can be answered via elimination. B is more of a description of Lady G. than Harriet. There is no evidence that Harriet is nasty so D can be ruled out. Of A and C, A is the better answer, it is not clear whether Harriet is boring, but the passage certainly emphasises that she is pious (religious - she talks about church and prayer), dutiful (she writes to her grandmother) and polite (she writes about the characters in respectful terms).

child_mcqs.description: The relationship between Harriet and Lady G is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: There is no evidence that the friendship between Harriet and Lady G. is cold, coloured with rivalry or strained. They seem on good terms and Harriet writes about Lady G with affection and admiration, praising her qualities as a wife, mother and nurse. B is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
Review the cartoon below and answer the following questions.

www.cagle.com

child_mcqs.description: The humour of this cartoon hinges on:
child_mcqs.explanation: The cartoon does use dark humour but C does not answer the question (the cartoon's humour hinging on its use of dark humour does not make sense). The cartoon does not rely on caricature - there is no specific individual who is targeted in the cartoon (but general institutions - the media, the Ferguson police). This leaves A and D. The use of the pun (on shoot) is clearly more important to the cartoon's humour.

child_mcqs.description: The cartoonist's attitude is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: This question requires you to examine the cartoon very carefully. Through the pun on "don't shoot" the cartoon makes a comment on police antipathy towards being "shot" by the media. If it wasn't for the media there, there would be no joke. Therefore, the cartoon is not just about racialized police violence, but rather about the police not wanting to be filmed, and the important role the media can play in alerting people to police violence. Therefore A is the best answer.

answers.description: Critical towards the police, and supportive of the media.
Critical towards the police, and wary towards the media.
Sympathetic towards the victims of police violence, and critical towards the media.
Critical towards the police, and sympathetic towards victims of police violence.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Extract from 'Remind me again, how can companies patent breast cancer genes?', published in The Conversation

Myriad Genetics was granted a patent in 1995 for isolating hereditary mutations to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, which increase the carrier’s risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer.

Australia’s Federal Court last year rejected cancer survivor Yvonne D'Arcy’s appeal and ruled the patent was valid because the method of isolating the genes was an invention.

The High Court challenge is the last resort for Ms D'Arcy’s test case against companies patenting human genes and has implications for patients, clinicians and researchers' access to genetic information.

What are these three claims about?

D’Arcy argues the full Federal Court of Australia is wrong to uphold the validity of three of the 30 claims in Australian patent 686004. A “claim” defines the legal boundary of an “invention”, much like a certificate of title defines the legal boundary to a piece of land.

Each claim defines the “invention” to be human DNA in an “isolated” form. Isolated means that the human DNA has been removed from the human genome or has been made outside of it. Human DNA is further defined by reference to specific genetic sequences that correspond identically to the genetic sequences of mutations in the BRCA1 human gene.

The BRCA1 gene is a normal human gene that plays a critical role in controlling certain types of cancers, such as breast and ovarian cancers.

The mutations to the BRCA1 gene identified in the claims prevent this gene from performing that role effectively. The mutations specified in the “claims” are linked to much higher incidence of breast and ovarian cancers in women who have a family history of these cancers.

Why is this case before the High Court?

The High Court is the final court of appeal, but the right to an appeal is not automatic. Special leave is required. Its decision is binding on all courts in Australia, although the Australian Parliament can overrule any High Court decision by legislation.

Anyone can challenge an Australian patent in whole or in part. In the first instance, Justice John Nicholas upheld the validity of these claims in 2013. So did the full Federal Court in 2014. In February, Ms D’Arcy successfully applied for special leave to appeal to the High Court

Ms D’Arcy argues that the subject matter of the three claims are not “inventions” and therefore are not “patentable inventions” pursuant to Section 18(1)(a) of the Patents Act 1990.

Relying on a 1959 decision of the High Court in National Research Development Corporation v The Commissioner of Patents (NRDC) the full Federal Court held that the isolated DNA molecules are inventions because they are an “artificial state of affairs that has some discernible effect”.

The NRDC decision is the leading decision on the issue in Australia. The Federal Court is bound to follow it. The High Court is not; it can review any of its decisions by either overruling, qualifying or explaining them.

child_mcqs.description: In regards to Yvonne D'Arcy’s previous court cases, it can be ascertained that they
child_mcqs.explanation: The article is discussing Yvonne D’Arcy’s appeal that she will address to the High Court. Hence, her case has is yet to either to succeed or fail before the High Court, which eliminates C and D. The article provides that both Justice John Nicholas at first instance, and the full Federal Court on appeal, upheld the validity of the claim. As Yvonne D’Arcy was attempting to argue the invalidity of these claims, it can be inferred that she lost both cases. Hence, the answer is B.

answers.description: Succeeded at both first instance and before the full Federal Court
Failed at both first instance and before the full Federal Court
Failed at both first instance and before the full Federal Court, but succeeded before the High Court
Failed at first instance, before the full Federal Court and before the High Court

child_mcqs.description: In regards to the Australian court system, it can be determined from the article that?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is obtainable from the last sentence. The Federal Court is bound to follow the decision of NRDC, which was a decision made by the full Federal Court. Hence A is correct from the article. B and C are contradicted in the article. The High Court may overrule the full Federal Court, as discussed in the last line. Parliament is not bound by the decisions of the High Court, which is the most superior Court. It would thus be illogical that it would be bound by decisions of a lower Court. In any case, it is not stated that Parliament IS bound by decisions of the full Federal Court, in the same way that it is not discussed whether previous decisions of the High Court are binding upon later decisions.

answers.description: The previous decisions of the full Federal Court are binding on the Federal Court
The previous decisions of the full Federal Court are binding upon the High Court
The previous decisions of the full Federal Court are binding upon Parliament
The previous decisions of the High Court are binding upon the High Court

child_mcqs.description: A person who does not dispute that a patent is valid, but believes that it does not apply to his or her own product, is arguing about?
child_mcqs.explanation: The question states that the person does not dispute that the patent is valid. However, what is of concern is whether this patent actually applies to their own product. Hence, the person is arguing about the scope or boundaries of the patient. The passage provides that a claim defines the legal boundary of an “invention”, and hence D is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: That the human DNA is ‘isolated’ is important because?
child_mcqs.explanation: The NRDC decision provides that the invention must be an ‘artificial state of affairs that has some discernable effect’. Furthermore, ‘isolated’ is defined as ‘human DNA has been removed from the human genome or has been made outside of it’. By removing the DNA from the human genome, or making the DNA outside of it, the DNA becomes artificial as it is not naturally occurring. If the DNA was not isolated, it could not fulfil this condition, and hence A is correct. The human DNA may still have a discernable effect if it is not isolated, as it does in natural cancer patients with the mutation, so that B is incorrect. The Patents Act says nothing specific about DNA and there is nothing in the article to suggest that a gene must be isolated to reference specific sequences

answers.description: Under the NRDC decision, inventions must be artificial
Under the NRDC decision, inventions must have some discernable effect
Section 18(1)(a) of the Patents Act makes this a requirement
It allows referencing of specific genetic sequences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description: Review the graph below and answer the following questions:

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is true, according to the graph above?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since the graph only shows selected prime ministerial announcements, A is incorrect, because it states “all prime ministerial announcements”. B is not a something the graph strictly shows. D is also incorrect because it uses "always" and the graph only shows a selection of prime ministerial announcements (and therefore, it is likely that it shows only a selection of national security announcements). This leaves C as the best answer, and the graph does show an increase, with respect to time, in the maximum number of flags used, in the selected ministerial announcements that are graphed.

answers.description: The use of flags in all prime ministerial announcements has increased since October 2013.
The prime minister uses flags to compensate for policy deficiency.
There is an increase in the maximum number of flags used in certain policy announcements.
The prime minister always uses a large number of flags for national security announcements.

child_mcqs.description: What, of the following options, is the best critique of the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is not convincing, there is no evidence that the graph is biased against the coalition government. The difference in scale between the horizontal and vertical axis is not really a relevant critique, especially given that the axes represent different qualities. The graph does not show the use of flags in early 2013, but the graph is clear about the period that it starts and ends. The graph does not show announcements with 0 flags, and the way the graph is set up means there is no way of showing announcements with 0 flags. This means that the announcements graphed are those which use more flags, therefore B is the best answer.

answers.description: There is a large difference in scale between the horizontal and the vertical axis.
The graph does not plot announcements with “0” flags.
The graph does not show the transition between different prime ministers.
The graph is biased against the coalition government.

child_mcqs.description: What is the median number of flags used in a prime ministerial announcement in October 2013 – December 2013, excluding COAG?
child_mcqs.explanation: Since there is no way that the graph can plot ministerial announcements of 0 flags, and the graph only plots selected ministerial announcements, the graph cannot provide us with the median flag number of prime ministerial announcements between October 2013-December 2013. Therefore D is the best answer.

answers.description: There is not enough information in the graph to answer this question.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description:
THE FENCE -Lenrie Peters

There where the dim past and future mingle
their nebulous hopes and aspirations
there I lie.

There where truth and untruth struggle
in endless and bloody combat,
there I lie.

There where time moves forwards and backwards
with not one moment’s pause for sighing,
there I lie.

There where the body ages relentlessly
and only the feeble mind can wander back
there I lie in open-souled amazement

There where all the opposites arrive
to plague the inner senses, but do not fuse,
I hold my head; and then contrive
to stop the constant motion.
my head goes round and round,
but I have not been drinking;
I feel the buoyant waves; I stagger

It seems the world has changed her garment.
but it is I who have not crossed the fence,
So there I lie.

There where the need for good
and “the doing good” conflict,
there I lie.

child_mcqs.description: The poem addresses all of the following themes except:
child_mcqs.explanation: The entire poem is about uncertainty and sitting on ‘the fence’. The final stanza discusses moral conflict. ‘The world has changed her garment’ hence the poet acknowledges the changing world. Forgiveness is not a theme which arises in the poem, making C the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: From the poem it can be gleaned that one potential reason for the poet’s uncertainty is his:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the fifth stanza the poet says that ‘I have not been drinking’ so D is incorrect. In the 6th stanza it is acknowledged that the world has changed but the poet has not ‘crossed the fence’, indicating he has failed to adapt and it can be extrapolated that this is one reason he remains so uncertain. The poet does not express that sitting on the fence is the best choice; in fact the turmoil expressed in the fifth stanza implies that it may not be in ones best interest to be so irresolute. There is no mention of fear being the cause of the indecision, hence A is incorrect. Therefore, option B is the best answer.

answers.description: Fear of making the wrong choice
Failure to adapt to a changing world
Belief that it is best to sit on the fence

child_mcqs.description: In the fifth stanza, the poet’s mindset can be described as all of the following except:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the context of the stanza the ‘buoyant waves’ the poet feels, represents his sense of being overwhelmed, making him ‘stagger’. It is not intended to show a euphoric state of mind. Hence, C is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: The poet is someone who:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the first stanza the past and the future are said to ‘mingle’, hence A is incorrect. The truth and untruth are said to ‘struggle in endless and bloody combat’. In this statement the poet is acknowledging that it is in our nature to be deceitful. It cannot be concluded that humans strive for honesty, as then there would be no conflict. The changing world is mentioned in stanza 5. The final stanza shows the writer’s conflict about the need for good and ‘doing good’. The conflict exists because whilst there is moral justification to ‘do good’, it is not always the outcome. Hence D is the best answer.

answers.description: Sees the future and past as two separate entities
Feels the world is constant and consistent
Understands that humans strive for honesty, even if they do not always achieve it
Believes that the ‘need for good’ does not always result in ‘doing good’

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is from the World Health Organisation "Policy Brief: Transgender People and HIV" (July, 2015):

In general, health data, including HIV prevalence data, are less robust for transgender people than for the general population due to challenges in sampling, lack of population size estimates and issues of stigma and discrimination. Research and surveillance data that include transgender people frequently fail to disaggregate the data by gender identity and involve sample sizes too small to make reasonable inferences. Transgender people remain severely underserved in the response to HIV, with only 39% of countries reporting in the National Commitment and Policy Instrument 2014 that their national AIDS strategies address transgender people.

Transgender women

The existing data specific to transgender people demonstrate a heavy burden of HIV among transgender women, specifically transgender women who have sex with men. A systematic review and meta-analysis found a pooled HIV prevalence of 19% among transgender women in the 15 countries with available, laboratory-confirmed data. Transgender women had odds of HIV infection 49 times greater than the general population. A separate meta-analysis of HIV among transgender women sex workers found that these women had a pooled HIV prevalence of 27%, compared with 15% among transgender women who did not engage in sex work. Of note, no countries in Eastern Europe or the continent of Africa had published HIV prevalence data on transgender women at the time of these studies. Country reports in UNAIDS Gap Report 2014 suggest that HIV prevalence among transgender women sex workers is nine times higher than for non-transgender female sex workers and three times higher than for male sex workers. 

Many studies have demonstrated multiple co-occurring health problems among transgender women, including high rates of violence and victimization, substance use, sexual abuse and assault, and depression with suicidal ideation and attempts. This syndemic is associated with structural and social inequalities such as widespread stigma and discrimination, lack of access to identity documents that match gender expression, high prevalence of unemployment and underemployment, street-based sex work with low pay and no legal protections, homelessness and lack of access to health services, included gender-affirming care. Many transgender women have partners who are at high risk for HIV. Transgender women who seek psychological affirmation of their gender from partners may be more willing to have condomless sex, thereby increasing their vulnerability to HIV.

 

Transgender men

All published studies on HIV prevalence among transgender men are from North America, and they suggest a lesser burden of disease than among transgender women. The most recently published meta-analysis found only two studies with laboratory-confirmed HIV status among transgender men. One of the studies found no infections among participants, and the other found a prevalence of 2%, amounting to one HIV-positive study participant. Emerging data among transgender men who have sex with men raises the possibility that this subpopulation faces heightened vulnerability to HIV . Limited data suggest that mental health concerns are common among transgender men. It is unclear if and how mental health concerns among transgender men might affect their vulnerability to HIV.

child_mcqs.description:
According to the passage above, which of the following statements are true of transgender women?

I. Data on transgender women is less robust than data on the general population.

II. Transgender women have a higher risk of HIV infection than the general population.

III. HIV prevalence of non-transgender male sex workers is higher than that of non-transgender female sex workers.

IV. Limited data suggest that mental health concerns are common among transgender women.
child_mcqs.explanation: (I) is affirmed by the passage which states that data on transgender people is less robust than data on the general population. It follows that data on transgender women would be less robust than data on the general population. The "Transgender Woman" section affirms that transgender women are vulnerable to HIV infection than the general population so (II) is correct. (III) is also correct, according to the article, but it does not answer the question, which specifically asks about transgender women. (IV) is true of transgender men but not necessarily transgender women. The data suggesting transgender women have mental health problems is not (said to be) limited. The passage states, "Many studies have demonstrated multiple co-occurring health problems among transgender women, including high rates of violence and victimization, substance use, sexual abuse and assault, and depression with suicidal ideation and attempts." Therefore, C is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: How many countries, in 2014, do not address transgender people in their national AIDS strategies according to  the National Commitment and Policy Instrument?
child_mcqs.explanation: The extract states "with only 39% of countries reporting in the National Commitment and Policy Instrument 2014 that their national AIDS strategies address transgender people." Therefore 61% of countries according to the Instrument did not address transgender people in their national AIDS strategies.

answers.description: There is not sufficient data to answer this question.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is untrue, according to the article?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is not stated as true in the passage. Side effects aren't referred to at all, so it is not contradicted by the passage as the question asks. A is explicitly stated by the passage. C is also affirmed by the passage: "Many studies have demonstrated multiple co-occurring health problems among transgender women . . . This syndemic is associated with structural and social inequalities such as . . . lack of access to health services, included gender-affirming care." B is the best answer, it is contradicted by the passage, which states "Emerging data among transgender men who have sex with men raises the possibility that this subpopulation faces heightened vulnerability to HIV."

answers.description: There is less data on transgender men than on transgender women.
Transgender men are not vulnerable to HIV infection.
The limited access to gender-afirming health services contributes to the vulnerability of transgender women.
There are side effects from gender-affirming medications.

child_mcqs.description: Which group is most vulnerable to HIV?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article states "the existing data specific to transgender people demonstrate a heavy burden of HIV among transgender women, specifically transgender women who have sex with men." As for transgender men, "All published studies on HIV prevalence among transgender men . . . suggest a lesser burden of disease than among transgender women . . . Emerging data among transgender men who have sex with men raises the possibility that this subpopulation faces heightened vulnerability to HIV"

answers.description: Transgender women who have sex with men
Transgender men who have sex with men

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
- Political Ideologies of CEOs, Chin et al

To what extent do chief executive officers (CEOs) of publicly traded firms inject their personal values into their decisions? This question is of great practical significance, as it brings into focus—for corporate boards and overall society—the potential importance of executives’ preferences in shaping the actions and outcomes of our large economic enterprises. Additionally, this question helps to frame some incompatibilities, or at least tensions, between major theoretical frameworks. Under the logic of neoclassical economics, for example, firms act on the basis of contextual conditions (e.g., markets, competition, technologies), with managers playing little or no role. Similarly, according to new institutional theory and some renditions of population ecology theory, managers are so constrained by isomorphic and inertial forces as to have only a minor influence over organizational outcomes.

In contrast, agency theory is centered on a two-part premise: managers cansignificantly inject their personal preferences into corporate policies; the challenge for owners is to prevent this from occurring. According to the theory, managers are inclined toward some common, essentially universal tendencies—including empire-building, nest-feathering, risk-aversion, and shirking—which serve their own but not owners’ interests. Owners can ameliorate this “agency problem” by installing appropriate monitoring and incentive schemes. Any heterogeneity observed in company practices or performance can thus be traced to differences in governance arrangements.

Yet another perspective, often set forth under the rubric of upper echelons theory, similarly allows for substantial executive influence but proposes that executives vary in the personal orientations they bring to their decisions. According to the theory, strategic decision making is not so much a technical endeavor as an interpretive one, and executives perceive their situations and alternatives through highly personalized lenses, which are formed by their experiences, personalities, and values. In turn, these individualized construals shape executives’ choices. In contrast to agency theory, then, upper echelons theory posits that heterogeneity in companies’ actions or outcomes is due to differences among company leaders.

Values can be expected to enter into executives’ choices through two conduits. Even though we are not able to empirically observe these two mechanisms, it is useful to explicate them. First, an executive’s values may have a direct influence on his or her choices. After weighing available alternatives, facts, probabilities, and eventualities, the executive selects a course of action that suits his or her values. England (1967) referred to this direct influence of values on action as “behavior channeling.”

The second mechanism, which we envision as far more prevalent, occurs when values affect choices indirectly, through “perceptual filtering”. Under this process, the executive selectively searches for information that suits his or her values and then perceives and interprets information in a values-congruent way. Through the interpretive process that psychologists refer to as “motivated cognition”, executives see what they want to see and hear what they want to hear. Just as motivated cognition causes long-tenured executives to see great instrumental merit in the status quo, so too will CEOs’ values shape their assessments of the potential efficacy of various corporate actions, including CSR initiatives

child_mcqs.description: What is NOT a hypothesized mechanism by which CEO’s individual values affect their decision-making?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is found in the final two paragraphs, which outline the two conduits through which values enter CEOs decision. B is found in the line ‘the executive selectively searches for information’; whilst C is contained in the line ‘[the executive] perceives and interprets information in a values-congruent way’. D represents the ‘direct mechanism’, which is described as ‘select[ing] a course of action that suits his or her values’. A is therefore the correct answer. A is similar to B and D, although may be contrasted as A implies a conscious decision to exclude information, which is not supported by the passage.

answers.description: Deciding upon alternatives that align with their beliefs

child_mcqs.description: Agency theory suggests that
child_mcqs.explanation: The key element of agency theory is that managers possess ‘universal tendencies… which serve their own but not owner’s interests’. This is relevant to the passage as the theory presupposes that the manager is a separate entity from the company, and thus his or her individual values and beliefs will affect their decisions. Hence, answer C is correct. A is partially true, but it is not always necessary that owners require other people to make decisions for them, and in any case does not represent the main point of agency theory. B is untrue as, although the negative elements of managers are discussed, they must not have an overall negative impact or the owner would not hire them. D is incorrect as, whilst managers do possess their own characteristics, it is not evidenced that they differ significantly to other individuals.

answers.description: Owners require other individuals to make their decisions for them
Managers have an overall negative effect upon the operation of the company
Individuals will make decisions in their own and not the company’s interests
Managers have unique characteristics not shared by owners

child_mcqs.description: A major contrast between upper echelons theory and new institutional theory is that
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is found by observing that under new institutional theory, managers have only ‘minor influence over organizational outcomes’, which is also described as similar to neoliberal theory, in which managers also have little role to play in organizational decisions. Therefore, these theories suggest that managers’ values have little role in making organizational decisions. Conversely new institutional theory is discussed alongside agency theory as describing theories by which managers’ values do have a significant impact upon organizational decisions. In the case of upper echelons theory, this is because a decision requires interpreting available evidence, which must necessarily include the manager’s individual opinions and beliefs. Hence, the answer is B.

answers.description: Upper echelons theory asserts that managers have a diverse range of values and beliefs, whereas new institutional theory suggests that managers have mostly similar values and beliefs
Upper echelons theory asserts that managers' values do impact upon decisions to a significant extent, whereas new institutional theory does not
Upper echelons theory asserts that managers' values impact upon decisions directly, whereas new institutional theory suggests that they impact upon decisions indirectly
Upper echelons theory asserts that managers act in self-interest, whereas new institutional theory asserts that managers act in the owner’s interests

child_mcqs.description: CEOs who have held their position for a considerable time are more likely to be what in making their decisions?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article suggests that long-tenured executives are likely to see merit in the status quo. This suggests that such individuals are more reluctant to pursue decisions causing change, and are hence conservative. This is answer B. Although the article acknowledges that these CEOs will be biased, so too will newly employed CEOs, only that they may have other biases weighing upon their decision.

child_mcqs.description: What do the authors suggest about the two conduits by which values impact upon CEO’s decisions
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is found in the line ‘even though we are not able to empirically observe these two mechanisms’, which suggests that they are unable to provide evidence that these actually are the two mechanisms by which values impact upon decisions. B is incorrect as the passage specifically says values act through two conduits, rather than suggesting that they act through many with ‘direct’ and ‘indirect’ discussed as examples. C and D are likely to be true, but are not discussed by the author

answers.description: They are unable to provide definitive proof of their existence
They may represent only two of several potential mechanisms
They will have a variable impact upon specific managers and organisations
They are unlikely to hold true in in all circumstances

stem_mcq.title: Unit11
stem_mcq.description: -

child_mcqs.description: The primary aim of the cartoon is to illustrate that:
child_mcqs.explanation: The cartoon aims to highlight our over reliance on technology to answer all questions, even when it may not be appropriate to do so. It is insinuating that technology does not hold the answers to everything, hence D is incorrect. The cartoon is primarily making a point about technology rather than any comment about the meaning of life or religion. Hence, C is the best answer.

answers.description: The meaning of life is a process of self discovery
Religion does not have all the answers
Technology has the answers to everything

child_mcqs.description: The humour of the cartoon is based primarily on:
child_mcqs.explanation: As per the first question, the cartoon is primarily making a social commentary on technology. The fact that the second man feels that the computer will hold the answer to something as complex as the 'meaning of life' is what makes cartoon humorous, as it highlights our tendency to 'google' the answer to all of life's questions. B is the best answer.

answers.description: The belief that technology holds the answers to all of life’s questions
The alarmed expression on the face of the suited man
The irony of a wise religious looking individual not knowing the answer to the question posed

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is from Maria Edgeworth's novel, Belinda (1801). Lady Delacour is narrating to Belinda her past.

You see I had nothing at home, either in the shape of husband or children, to engage my affections. I believe it was this "aching void" in my heart which made me, after looking abroad some time for a bosom friend, take such a prodigious fancy to Mrs Freke. She was just then coming into fashion; she struck me, the first time I met her, as being downright ugly; but there was a wild oddity in her countenance which made one stare at her, and she was delighted to be stared at, especially by me; so we were mutually agreeable to each other – I as starer, and she as staree. Harriot Freke had, without comparison, more assurance than any man or woman I ever saw; she was downright brass, but of the finest kind – Corinthian brass. She was one of the first who brought what I call harum scarum manners into fashion. I told you that she had assurance – impudence I should have called it, for no other word is strong enough. Such things as I have heard Harriot Freke say! – You will not believe it – but her conversation at first absolutely made me, like an old-fashioned fool, wish I had a fan to play with. But, to my astonishment, all this took surprisingly with a set of fashionable young men. I found it necessary to reform my manners. If I had not taken heart of grace, and publicly abjured the heresies of false delicacy, I should have been excommunicated. Lady Delacour's sprightly elegance – allow me to speak of myself in the style in which the newspaper writers talk of me – Lady Delacour's sprightly elegance was but pale, not to say faded pink, compared with the scarlet of Mrs Freke's dashing audacity. As my rival, she would on certain ground have beat me hollow; it was therefore good policy to make her my friend: we joined forces, and nothing could stand against us. But I have no right to give myself credit for good policy in forming this intimacy; I really followed the dictates of my heart or my imagination. There was a frankness in Harriot's manner which I mistook for artlessness or character: she spoke with such unbounded freedom on certain subjects, that I gave her credit for unbounded sincerity on all subjects: she had the talent of making the world believe that virtue to be invulnerable by nature which disdained the common outworks of art for its defence. I, amongst others, took it for granted, that the woman who could make it her sport to "touch the brink of all we hate," must have a stronger head than other people. I have since been convinced, however, of my mistake. I am persuaded that few can touch the brink without tumbling headlong down the precipice. Don't apply this, my dear, literally, to the person of whom we were speaking; I am not base enough to betray her secrets, however I may have been provoked by her treachery. Of her character and history you shall hear nothing but what is necessary for my own justification. The league of amity between us was scarcely ratified before my Lord Delacour came, with his wise remonstrating face, to beg me "to consider what was due to my own honour and his." Like the cosmogony-man in the Vicar of Wakefield, he came out over and over with this cant phrase, which had once stood him in stead. "Do you think, my lord," said I, "that because I gave up poor Lawless to oblige you, I shall give up all common sense to suit myself to your taste? Harriot Freke is visited by every body but old dowagers and old maids: I am neither an old dowager nor an old maid – the consequence is obvious, my lord." Pertness in dialogue, my dear, often succeeds better with my lord than wit: I therefore saved the sterling gold, and bestowed upon him nothing but counters. I tell you this to save the credit of my taste and judgment.

child_mcqs.description: The word "pertness" in the second last sentence of this passage could be replaced by:
child_mcqs.explanation: D does not make grammatical sense when substituted into the passage in place of "pertness." C does not make sense in the context of the passage. Pay close attention to the context of the word:  "Pertness in dialogue, my dear, often succeeds better with my lord than wit: I therefore saved the sterling gold, and bestowed upon him nothing but counters." Pertness is described as something more valuable than "wit",  - counters to wit's sterling gold. Lady Delacour seems embarassed by what she said and has to justify it to save her "taste and judgement". Pertness is therefore unlikely to be "reason" or "logic". Indeed, pertness means cheekiness or brashness.

child_mcqs.description: According to Lady Delacour's account, Harriot Freke is:
child_mcqs.explanation: There is no evidence that Harriot is ugly, or that she is unfriendly - she becomes close friends with Lady Delacour after all, so D is incorrect. Lady Delacour becomes friends with Harriot so that she does not have a rival, so C is also incorrect. This leaves A and B. While Harriot is decidedly androgynous in the novel as a whole, there is not much evidence for this in the passage. There is, however, evidence in this passage that Harriot is shocking (Lady Delacour stares at her), fashionable (Lady Delacour feels faded and less fashionable next to her) and dangerous (Lady Delacour states, "few can touch the brink" that Harriot touches, "without tumbling headlong down the precipice" implying that Harriot's lifestyle is full of risks to her reputation.)

child_mcqs.description: Lady Delacour's friendship with Harriot:
child_mcqs.explanation: Lady Delacour talks about her friendship with Harriot in past tense. The key sentence here is, "I am not base enough to betray her secrets, however I may have been provoked by her treachery." This implies that Lady Delacour is no longer friends with Harriot, and has been betrayed by her. Therefore B is incorrect. C and D are also incorrect, as Lady Delacour makes it clear how intimate their friendship was, enough for them to share intimate secrets.

answers.description: Involved shared secrets and a lasting, fond connection

child_mcqs.description: When Lady Delcour describes Harriot as being "Corinthian Brass" she is describing Harriet's:
child_mcqs.explanation: Lady Delacour states, "Harriot Freke had, without comparison, more assurance than any man or woman I ever saw; she was downright brass, but of the finest kind – Corinthian brass. She was one of the first who brought what I call harum scarum manners into fashion. I told you that she had assurance – impudence I should have called it, for no other word is strong enough." Lady Delacour's words link "Corinthian brass" to "assurance", "impudence" and "harum scarum manners". Assurance or impudence means boldness or audaciousness. C is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: Why does Lady Delacour believe she became friends with Harriot?
child_mcqs.explanation: Lady Delacour states, "You see I had nothing at home, either in the shape of husband or children, to engage my affections. I believe it was this "aching void" in my heart which made me, after looking abroad some time for a bosom friend, take such a prodigious fancy to Mrs Freke." It is, according to Lady Delacour, a lack of anything at home (husband or children) capable of engaging her "affections" or provoking her love that is what leads to her becoming friends with Harriot. Therefore D is the best answer.

answers.description: She had nothing and no one at home she could love.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
"GPs So Overworked They Risk Causing Harm" (from The Guardian 29 July, 2015)

Britain’s GPs are so tired and overloaded that they are at risk of harming patients’ health by misdiagnosing illness or giving them the wrong drugs, the head of the profession has warned.

In a stark description of the potential consequences to patients’ safety of “GP fatigue”, Dr Maureen Baker says that “persistent and excessive workload” faced by family doctors puts them at the same risk of inadvertently causing harm or even death as overtired pilots or lorry drivers.

In a paper for the Royal College of GPs (RCGP), which she chairs, Baker, an acknowledged expert in patient safety, demands urgent action to prevent “devastating” impact on care.

In a stark description of the potential consequences to patients’ safety of “GP fatigue”, Dr Maureen Baker says that “persistent and excessive workload” faced by family doctors puts them at the same risk of inadvertently causing harm or even death as overtired pilots or lorry drivers.

NHS England and the Department of Health in England, while recognising pressures on GPs, chose to stress the thousands of extra staff promised in primary care by 2020, rather than to tackle head-on Baker’s warnings on more immediate risks to patients.

Baker’s paper says: “GPs will always work in the best interests of their patients – even when they are putting their own health at risk – but, ironically, this can actually have an adverse effect on patient safety.

“Few of us would voluntarily board a plane flown by a visibly tired pilot or get on a train where we knew the driver had spent too much time at the controls – yet there are no methods or systems for addressing doctor and staff fatigue in general practice.

“Even in other areas of the NHS, ‘distress signals’ – such as red and black alerts in hospitals – exist so that other clinicians can simply declare that they cannot take on further work safely.

“But unless we disrupt patient services – which is the last thing that GPs want to do – we currently have no strategies in place to prevent and reduce the risk of patient harm that might arise from having tired, overworked doctors and practice staff.”

child_mcqs.description: The article's tone is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The article's use of the phrase "risk causing harm" in the headline establishes a tone of concern, and the article stresses the danger that overworked GPs can cause. However, the article is not "despairing" (at a loss), simply reporting what Baker's paper states. Nor is the article shrill or hysterical - the article expresses alarm and perhaps fear, but there are no exclamation marks or highly emotive language. Therefore C is the best answer. D is a distractor, "jovial" means jolly or merry and "belligerent" means aggressive, neither of which this article is.

child_mcqs.description: According to this article, Dr Maureen Baker believes
child_mcqs.explanation: To answer this question it is necessarily to read all the possible options carefully. A reflects the position of NHS England and the Department of Health, rather than Baker, so A is incorrect. She is not concerned about lorry drivers, but just using them as a point of comparison so C is not the best answer either. D places the responsibility on doctors, whereas Baker is arguing that there needs to be more support for doctors so they are less overworked. B is the best answer.

answers.description: that pressure on GPs should be recognised, but this should be eased by the thousands of extra staff promised in primary care by 2020.
That overworked GPs are dangerous for patient safety.
That overtired doctors and overtired lorry drivers are hazardous for the community.
Doctors need to be careful about how long they work.

child_mcqs.description:
Baker is:

I. An expert on patient safety.

II. Unnecessarily alarmed

III. The chair of the Royal College of Medical Surgeons

IV. Supportive of the existing workplace conditions of GPs
child_mcqs.explanation: Baker is said in the article to be an expert in patient safety. She is not described in the article as unnecessarily alarmed, and the article supports her concern by quoting her at length and reflecting her opinion in the headline. She is not said in the article to be the Chair of the Royal College of Surgeons, and she is not supportive of the existing working conditions of GPs, in fact she is asking for them to be changed.

child_mcqs.description: According to this article, ‘distress signals’ exist for overworked doctors:
child_mcqs.explanation: A is the correct answer. The article states that distress signals for overworked doctors do not exist for GPs, but do exist in other areas of the British health service, such as hospitals. Therefore, A is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is an extract from John Dryden's poem, "Mac Flecknoe"

All human things are subject to decay, 
And, when Fate summons, monarchs must obey:
This Flecknoe found, who, like Augustus, young
Was call'd to empire, and had govern'd long:
In prose and verse, was own'd, without dispute
Through all the realms of Non-sense, absolute.
This aged prince now flourishing in peace,
And blest with issue of a large increase,
Worn out with business, did at length debate
To settle the succession of the State:
And pond'ring which of all his sons was fit
To reign, and wage immortal war with wit;
Cry'd, 'tis resolv'd; for nature pleads that he
Should only rule, who most resembles me:
Shadwell alone my perfect image bears,
Mature in dullness from his tender years.
Shadwell alone, of all my sons, is he
Who stands confirm'd in full stupidity.
The rest to some faint meaning make pretence,
But Shadwell never deviates into sense.
Some beams of wit on other souls may fall,
Strike through and make a lucid interval;
But Shadwell's genuine night admits no ray,
His rising fogs prevail upon the day:
Besides his goodly fabric fills the eye,
And seems design'd for thoughtless majesty:
Thoughtless as monarch oaks, that shade the plain,
And, spread in solemn state, supinely reign.

child_mcqs.description: The poet's attitude towards old Flecknoe is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The poem is satirical, and Flecknoe is represented as being incredibly stupid. The poet writes of how Flecknoe wages "immortal war with wit" or cleverness and is determined that his son that rules should be he who "most resembles me." Since Shadwell is "confirm'd in full stupidity" Flecknoe chooses Shadwell. The poet therefore, is scornful towards Flecknoe, using almost every line to drive home the stupidity of both Flecknoe and Shadwell.

child_mcqs.description: Why, according to Flecknoe, should Shadwell be king?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is a distractor, there is no evidence at all in this poem that Shadwell is brave. However, there is evidence for A, B and C. However, the best answer is B. Flecknoe chooses Shadwell because Shadwell most resembles himself. While Shadwell's stupidity when it comes to Flecknoe choosing an heir, it is only important because it means that Shadwell is more like Flecknoe.

answers.description: Because he is the most idiotic of all his sons.
Because he is like a magesterial oak.

child_mcqs.description: The humour of this poem is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The poem is satirical. It is not delighting in nonsense for its own sake, but concerned with painting a picture of Shadwell's stupidity.  The humour comes from the barbed descriptions of Shadwell's stupidity, suggesting to us that this poem is written to satirise and target particular people.The humour is not bawdy (rude/sexual), and "impoverished" does not make sense in the context of the question. B is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: What does "blest with issue of a large increase" refer to?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The mention of the old prince's "large increase" comes directly before his discussion of who should succeed him as ruler:

"And blest with issue of a large increase,

Worn out with business, did at length debate

To settle the succession of the State."

The poem also mentions that Flecknoe has several sons. This all suggests that D is the best answer. The other options do not relate as closely to the main thing happening in the poem, Flecknoe choosing a successor.

answers.description: The strength of the economy of Flecknoe's kingdom.
The extent of the peace in Flecknoe's kingdom.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
Review the two figures below and answer the following questions. "Associate Professor" is a lower academic rank than "Full Professor".

Figure 1

 

Figure 2

child_mcqs.description: What does figure 1 show?
child_mcqs.explanation: While there are more Asian men than the other gender/race groups shown in figure 1, the graph does not show that Asian men are overrepresented: the graph does not provide us with a race/gender breakdown of the US population, for instance. Answer B is incorrect because it compares figure 1 and 2, and the question asks about figure 1 only. Answer C is incorrect because it mentions “absolute numbers” but the graph only provides us with percentages. Answer D is correct: the graph does show that black women have increased their representation at the rank of associate professor at the time shown by the graph.

answers.description: Asian men are over-represented at the rank of associate professor.
The advances Hispanic women have made at the lower rank of associate professor have not translated into their promotion at higher accademic ranks.
The absolute number of black male associate professors has slowly decreased.
Black women have increased their representation at the rank of associate professor between 1995 and 2011.

child_mcqs.description: According to the graphs above, what is the percentage of full professors, who are black, in 1995?
child_mcqs.explanation: This question requires you to add the percentage of black male full professors to the percentage of black female full professors. The answer is approximately 3% (1.9+1.1).

child_mcqs.description: What is the significance of the grey-blue line crossing the blue-green line in figure 2?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A is incorrect because the question is in reference to figure 2 (full professors, not associate professors). Answer C is a better option than answer B because, from looking at the shape of the lines on the graph, it is apparent that the graph plots the percentages every 5-6 years (the years labelled on the horizontal axis), and therefore the graph does not show us the exact percentages in the year 2006.

answers.description: The proportion of Asian female associate professors overtook the proportion of black female associate professors.
In 2006 there was an equal proportion of female black and female Asian professors.
Between 2005 and 2011 the proportion of Asian female professors overtook the proportion of black female professors in the US.
There is no significance to the lines crossing.

child_mcqs.description: What, according to the graph, is the percentage of white academics at the level of full Professor in 2001?
child_mcqs.explanation: The graph does not give us the percentage of white full professors.
