However, because the graph shows the breakdown of the representation of certain races, we know that the total white professors will be less than 100 minus the total of the percentages shown in the graph. It is unlikely that the graph shows the entire percentage of non-white professors (for instance, what about Middle Eastern professors)? Therefore, the best answer is A.

answers.description: There is not enough information in the graph to answer this question.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
The history of British slave ownership has been buried, the Guardian

The past has a disconcerting habit of bursting, uninvited and unwelcome, into the present. This year history gate-crashed modern America in the form of a 150-year-old document: a few sheets of paper that compelled Hollywood actor Ben Affleck to issue a public apology and forced the highly regarded US public service broadcaster PBS to launch an internal investigation.

It was precisely because slaves were reduced to property that they appear so regularly in historic documents, both in the US and in Britain. As property, slaves were listed in plantation accounts and itemised in inventories. They were recorded for tax reasons and detailed alongside other transferable goods on the pages of thousands of wills. Few historical documents cut to the reality of slavery more than lists of names written alongside monetary values. It is now almost two decades since I had my first encounter with British plantation records, and I still feel a surge of emotion when I come across entries for slave children who, at only a few months old, have been ascribed a value in sterling; the sale of children and the separation of families was among the most bitterly resented aspects of an inhuman system.

Slavery resurfaces in America regularly. The disadvantage and discrimination that disfigures the lives and limits the life chances of so many African-Americans is the bitter legacy of the slave system and the racism that underwrote and outlasted it. Britain, by contrast, has been far more successful at covering up its slave-owning and slave-trading past. Whereas the cotton plantations of the American south were established on the soil of the continental United States, British slavery took place 3,000 miles away in the Caribbean.

That geographic distance made it possible for slavery to be largely airbrushed out of British history, following the Slavery Abolition Act in 1833. Many of us today have a more vivid image of American slavery than we have of life as it was for British-owned slaves on the plantations of the Caribbean. The word slavery is more likely to conjure up images of Alabama cotton fields and whitewashed plantation houses, of Roots, Gone With The Wind and 12 Years A Slave, than images of Jamaica or Barbados in the 18th century. This is not an accident.

The history of British slavery has been buried. The thousands of British families who grew rich on the slave trade, or from the sale of slave-produced sugar, in the 17th and 18th centuries, brushed those uncomfortable chapters of their dynastic stories under the carpet. Today, across the country, heritage plaques on Georgian townhouses describe former slave traders as “West India merchants”, while slave owners are hidden behind the equally euphemistic term “West India planter”. Thousands of biographies written in celebration of notable 17th and 18th-century Britons have reduced their ownership of human beings to the footnotes, or else expunged such unpleasant details altogether. The Dictionary of National Biography has been especially culpable in this respect. Few acts of collective forgetting have been as thorough and as successful as the erasing of slavery from the Britain’s “island story”. If it was geography that made this great forgetting possible, what completed the disappearing act was our collective fixation with the one redemptive chapter in the whole story. William Wilberforce and the abolitionist crusade, first against the slave trade and then slavery itself, has become a figleaf behind which the larger, longer and darker history of slavery has been concealed.

child_mcqs.description: Unlike America, Britain
child_mcqs.explanation: The article discusses how Britain has been more successful than America in hiding the details of its historical role in slavery. The reason provided in the third paragraph is that whilst American slavery took place on its own soil, Britain’s slave trade operated a significant distance from its shores. Hence, Britain is not faced with a constant reminder of its past, unlike America. This corresponds with answer B. A is unlikely to be correct as America may also wish to hide their history. The article does not support the notion that the British slave trade did not make records of slavery or not involve British nationals

answers.description: Has a strong desire to remove the slave trade from its history
Has a fortunate ability to remove the slave trade from its history
Developed a slave trade that did not record the details of slaves
Developed a slave trade that did not require the involvement of its nationals

child_mcqs.description: The author suggests that the inclusion of the term ‘West-Indian” is used primarily as a means of
child_mcqs.explanation: The term is used in the context of brushing British slavery out of their history, and is hence likely used for this purpose. By describing ‘West-Indian’ slave holders and slave traders, it is not immediately apparent that these were also English nationals. This is a means of lessening their association with Britain, and hence lessening the association between Britain and slavery. D is incorrect as it is in fact highly likely that the British are truly aware of their role in slavery, and hence feel the need to hide their past from themselves in such a manner.

answers.description: Accurately representing the nationality of the slave holder or slave trader
Accentuating the differences between American and non-American slave holders and slave traders
Lessening the slave holder or slave trader’s association with Britain
Demonstrating that the British are unaware of their role in slavery

child_mcqs.description: From the context of the article, it is likely that Roots, Gone With The Wind and 12 Years A Slave represent
child_mcqs.explanation: Roots, Gone With The Wind and 12 Years A Slave are discussed in the paragraph that explains how British people associate slavery with America, as it brings up images of ‘Alabama cotton fields and whitewashed plantation houses’. Hence, it is likely these too are images of American slavery, so that answer C is correct. They may also be theatrical depictions of slavery, but this is not clear only from the article (they may, for instance, be poems or stories)

child_mcqs.description: Which element of the British slave trade has enabled our awareness of its existence?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is clear in the second paragraph, when it is provided that slavery so often appears in historical documents due to the nature of its treating slaves as property. The slave trade involved recording slaves for ownership and tax purposes and these documents exist today to give us our understanding. This only corresponds with answer A. The location of the British slave trade is described as lessening our awareness. Whilst the British slave trade was undoubtedly severe and extensive, there is no mention that these helped assist in our awareness

child_mcqs.description: Which aspect of Britain’s role in slavery is remembered most by the current British population?
child_mcqs.explanation: As consistently mentioned, a key feature of the article is the British people’s airbrushing of slavery from their past. Whilst the location of the British slave trade assisted in this regard, the article also mentions that the redemptive nature of British involvement the abolishment of slavery provides another means to forget the immoralities of generations past. Hence, it is suggested that the British people will remember the abolishment of the slave trade most vividly, rather than those features that portray the harsh realities of their history.

answers.description: The reduction of children and families to property
The offshoring of slavery to the Caribbean

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
From "Powdered Poo, Anyone" by Richard Sugg, The Guardian 6 April 2015.

 

Earlier this week, we learned that researchers at Nottingham University, having "recreated a ninth-century Anglo-Saxon remedy using onion, garlic and part of a cow's stomach" were then astonished to find it almost completely wiped out the superbug, MRSA.

The news was certainly music to my ears. Over several years of discussing corpse medicine with different people, I had found that one of the most common questions was: “Did it work?”

“Bald’s eyesalve” is remarkable for the fact that it worked without being disgusting. And yet for those who could overcome their revulsion, historically some corpse medicines may have been effective. In the days of Shakespeare, numerous surgeons or physicians would press or sprinkle powdered Egyptian mummy, powdered blood or powdered moss of the skull onto a bleeding wound. This probably did work – but only because powder stimulates coagulation. The forensic pathologist who explained this to me added that, when his little brother suffered a bad head cut in childhood, their mother simply put powdered coffee on the wound.

Meanwhile, when various genteel patients with nosebleeds thrust powdered skull-moss up their nostrils, any benefits were probably no different from those who used chalk or mint, or the “noble German, cured of a desperate bleeding at the nose” by the insertion of warm hog’s dung.

By contrast, when Robert Boyle, the “father of chemistry”, stopped his own severe nosebleed one summer by merely holding skull-moss in his hand, he may have been experiencing a psychosomatic, rather than strictly physical effect.

Then we have human fat. Often sold and applied by public executioners, this was used extensively on wounds and sores, and remained popular as part of an ointment for gout or rheumatism well into the Georgian era. Although we probably don’t need clinical trials to convince us that many fats can produce the warming friction helpful against gout and rheumatism, there might well be more to learn about the action of fat against wounds and sores. Kathy Stuart, a historian, has suggested that it may have been used to save the wounded from amputations in early modern Germany. Come 1889, the German settlers of Pennsylvania were still using dog fat, skunk fat and bacon fat on wounds, while in the 1950s a Peruvian anthropologist, Efraín Morote Best, found that “the fatty tissues of human bodies are still valued in the region for their therapeutic effect on wounds, rheumatism” and smallpox scars.

child_mcqs.description: "Corpse medicine" involves:
child_mcqs.explanation: While the author opens with a description of an ancient remedy that did not involve a human corpse, he later writes, that this remedy "is remarkable for the fact that it worked without being disgusting. And yet for those who could overcome their revulsion, historically some corpse medicines may have been effective." Corpse medicine therefore potentially works, and is put in a different category to medicine involving just animal parts. The author writes about people using ancient (Egyptian) corpses in a later period, therefore human sacrifice doesn't seem to be involved. A is the best answer.

answers.description: The practice of using materials from human corpses as part of medical remedies.
Ancient, old-fashioned remedies, that have long been disapproved.
Medicine that involves dead human or animal tissue.

child_mcqs.description:
According to this article, skull-moss was used:

I for eye infections

II for nosebleeds

III for cuts and wounds

IV for rheumatism
child_mcqs.explanation: There is no discussion of skull-moss being used for eye infections in the article, nor for rheumatism. The article does talk about how "numerous surgeons or physicians would press or sprinkle powdered Egyptian mummy, powdered blood or powdered moss of the skull onto a bleeding wound" and how "various genteel patients with nosebleeds thrust powdered skull-moss up their nostrils". Therefore C is correct.

child_mcqs.description: The attitude of the author towards past health practices is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: While the author does talk about corpse medicine being repulsive and disgusting, he stresses its possibilities and is interested in the way it has been widely used. He is not dismissive about the past, nor is he wistful or nostalgic about using pieces of human corpse in medicine. C is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the passage below, from the first chapter of Mary Charlton's novel, Phedora.

On the eastern border of a fine lake, which communicates by the river Embeck with the lakes Peipus and Worfero, was situated a Livonian village, whole peasantry, in the latter end of the laft century, subsisted by the cultivation of flax and hemp, which their women and children assisted in dressing.

Amidst the small cottages, which marked the poverty and simplicity of the inhabitants that of the widow Eudocia Rubenski was the most humble, and exhibited the strongest appearance of indigence. Her son and only child, who had been torn from her by the desolating hand of war, had fallen in the field, and left his wife and mother a prey to the bitterest affliction, aggravated by all the horrors of absolute want.

In this scene of misery the little fatherless Phedora first saw the light. Her mother laboured with unremitiing industry to support her child and the aged parent of her lost husband; but his returning image ever mixed with her toil, and embittered every moment that should have been given to repose : her soul, divided between unabating tenderness for his memory, and affection for all that remained of him below, his infant daughter, lingered out ten years of existence after the stroke which for ever separated them in this world; she then breathed her last in the arms of the widow Rubenski, amidst the tears and lamentations of Phedora. This fatal event almost levelled the aged matron with the dust; and but for the assistance and support of her neighbours, she must have perished with united grief and famine.

The little Phedora had been associated in her mother's labours about a year; and upon the industry and gains of this infant, who had scarceley seen ten winter's snows, now depended the principal support of the ill-fated Eudocia Rubenski. For some time the attention of the surrounding cottagers supplied those wants the mother of Phedora had been used to administer to : but, alas! the first effusions of pity and compassion soon abate of their fervor; and a steady continuance of disinterested good offices and generous commiseration, are not the result of a casual though irresistible feeling, which accident may suddenly create, but a genuine branch of that liberal and extensive charity so divinely taught.

child_mcqs.description: The author in this passage stresses Phedora's:
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage stresses Phedora's vulnerability and unluckiness. Phrases like "little fatherless Phedora" and "little Phedora" and the stress the passage places on Phedora's youth, emphasise her vulnerability. The passage also stresses her unluckiness, describing how she becomes an orphan and how she is born into a "scene of misery". The passage does not refer to her sadness, we don't know how Phedora feels so B is incorrect. C is not the best answer, because though the passage stresses Phedora's youth, she is not represented as immature. D is a distractor, Phedora is not abandoned, and the word "commiseration" does not make sense in the context of the question.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is true about Eudocia Rubenski?
child_mcqs.explanation: This is a difficult questions and requires a careful reading of the section: "The little Phedora had been associated in her mother's labours about a year; and upon the industry and gains of this infant, who had scarceley seen ten winter's snows, now depended the principal support of the ill-fated Eudocia Rubenski." This sentence explains that Phedora had been helping her mother work (associated in her mother's labours) before her mother died. The passage then states that "upon the industry and gains of this infant" - that is the work of Phedora - "now depended the principal support of the ill-fated Eudocia Rubenski." This makes it clear that Eudocia is dependent on Phedora's labour to survive. Hence, C is correct.

answers.description: She decides to adopt Phedora because she is moved by her plight.
She supported Phedora through labouring in the cultivation of flax and hemp
She dies shortly after the death of her son.

child_mcqs.description:
The last sentence of the extract:

I. Moves from realism to idealism

II. Moves from the specific to the general

III. Provides a shift in tone

IV. Provides a shift in perspective
child_mcqs.explanation: The last sentence is: "For some time the attention of the surrounding cottagers supplied those wants the mother of Phedora had been used to administer to : but, alas! the first effusions of pity and compassion soon abate of their fervor; and a steady continuance of disinterested good offices and generous commiseration, are not the result of a casual though irresistible feeling, which accident may suddenly create, but a genuine branch of that liberal and extensive charity so divinely taught." This sentence moves from the specific (the situation of Phedora and her family) to the general (what can motivate steady, continuing charity). II is correct. It provides a shift in perspective (IV) because it makes this shift, encouraging the reader to no longer think of Phedora and her circumstances in isolation. The first option (I) does not make sense, because the last sentence, while very religious, is not idealistic, and suggests that acts of genuinely helpful charity can be rare. III is not correct, the last sentence contains the same lamenting tone as the rest of the passage.

child_mcqs.description: "Indigence" can be replaced in this passage by:
child_mcqs.explanation: Pay close attention to the context of the word: "Amidst the small cottages, which marked the poverty and simplicity of the inhabitants that of the widow Eudocia Rubenski was the most humble, and exhibited the strongest appearance of indigence. Her son and only child, who had been torn from her by the desolating hand of war, had fallen in the field, and left his wife and mother a prey to the bitterest affliction, aggravated by all the horrors of absolute want." The word "indigence" is used here as synonym for extreme poverty, this is signalled by the way the word is used to discriminate the Rubenski house from other poor households, and how the following sentence describes how the family was left, after the death of Phedora's father, in "absolute want". A is the best answer. While the passage does talk about the tragedies and the sadnesses of the Rubenski family, these cannot be "exhibited" by a cottage in the same way that extreme poverty can be.

child_mcqs.description: Why, according to the passage, did Phedora's mother die?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that Phedora's mother had a soul "divided between unabating tenderness for his memory, and affection for all that remained of him below, his infant daughter." She did have something to live for, her daughter, and did not hate the world so B and D are incorrect. Though the passage suggests and she was overworked, that she "laboured with unremitiing industry" this is not what killed her. Instead, the passage emphasises her grief over her  "lost husband. . . his returning image ever mixed with her toil, and embittered every moment that should have been given to repose." Hence, C not A is the best answer.

answers.description: She could not recover from her husband's death.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
- Does organ donation legislation affect individuals' willingness to donate their own or their relative's organs?, Mossialos et al.

Governments put forward a variety of policy approaches to improve organ transplant waitlists. European countries are classified according to two types of institutional settings for confronting organ transplant needs: informed consent (opt-in) or presumed consent (opt-out). In countries with informed consent or 'opt-in' legislation, such as the UK, Germany, and Sweden, an individual or his/her family must give explicit permission for organ removal. Presumed consent countries such as Spain, Portugal, and Austria, assume universal consent without explicit registration otherwise. The latter is more prominent in the EU although countries with presumed consent legislation can differ in enforcement levels. Enforced presumed consent policy means that individuals who have not opted out of organ donation will automatically donate their organs upon time of death if organs are in a suitable clinical condition. Otherwise, unenforced presumed consent policies have caveats such as allowing relatives to refuse their relative's organ donation even though the relative has not explicitly opted-out. 

In practice, most families are consulted with regard to a deceased relative's organ donation even if this relative has already expressed willingness to be a donor. Approximately half of families in the US and 42 percent of families in the UK refuse requests for the donation of a relative's organ in comparison to 20 percent objecting to donation in Spain. Compared to an individual's decision to donate their own organs, there are limited studies examining the determinants of willingness to consent to the donation of a deceased family member's organs. Just as Bowles finds that institutional setting prompts individuals to display certain preferences, we expect that organ donation policy will have an impact on individuals' propensities to donate their own organs and those of others.

While organ donation policies might impact donor rates, individual attitudes regarding donations are not always aligned with donation behavior. Though European surveys show widespread public support for organ donation, donor card signing (opt-in) does not reflect this opinion. In Germany, only 7–10 percent of individuals who are in favor of organ donation carry a donor card. Only 19 percent of all adults in the UK have registered on the national donor registry.

However, an individual's willingness to donate (WTD) is an expression of the intention to pursue a behavior; therefore WTD provides a better indication of donation rates in a country than simply support of organ donation. Individuals can express favor towards organ donation as an abstract concept for society to encourage but they may not be reflecting how they feel about donation for themselves or a family member.

child_mcqs.description: According to the wording of the policies, an individual who (whether in their own capacity or through their family) makes no declaration regarding the permissibility of donating their organs
child_mcqs.explanation: For an opt-in system, the individual or his or her family must give explicit consent for the organs to be donated. Conversely, under an opt-out system, in the absence of an explicit refusal, consent to donation is presumed. Hence, answers A and C are eliminated. Answer D is preferable as answer B fails to take into account that the presumed consent is 'unenforced', allowing relatives to refuse their relative's organ donation even though the relative has not explicitly opted-out.

answers.description: Will always have their organs donated under an opt-in system
Will always have their organs donated under an opt-out system
May have their organs donated under an opt-in system, but not under an opt-out system
May have their organs donated under an opt-out system, but not under an opt-in system

child_mcqs.description: The first line of the second paragraph ("In practice...") suggests that
child_mcqs.explanation: The line provides that a donor’s family members are usually consulted to determine whether the organs are to be donated, and hence are likely to play a key role in the final decision. This is so regardless of the policy implemented (as highlighted by the fact that family members are consulted in both Spain, the UK and America). Therefore, even though the final decision in an enforced presumed consent system should not (under the policy) be the same as that of an informed consent system, it is usually the case that it is. This best aligns with answer B. Answer A is true, but is discussed in the preceding paragraph and is not supported by the specific line in question. Options C and D are ultimately obtainable from the entirety of the paragraph, but neither is supported by the first line.

answers.description: The opt-in and opt-out systems differ in the extent to which they permit family members to allow or refuse the organ donation
The implementation of opt-in and opt-out systems may not actually determine the mechanism by which the final decision is made
The expressed willingness of the donor is impacted upon by the implementation of the opt-in or opt-out system
The expressed willingness of the donor is impacted upon by their country of origin

child_mcqs.description: The heading of the article shows that the authors are interested in determining whether institutional policy on organ donation affects an individual’s willingness to donate their own or their family’s organs. The comparison between Spain, the United Kingdom and the United States in paragraphs two and three
child_mcqs.explanation: Although it would require more evidence to be scientifically valid, the comparison of Spain, the UK and the US does provide anecdotal support to the notion that institutional policy does affect an individual’s own willingness to donate. This is demonstrated by Spain implementing an opt-out policy that is more favourable to organ donation, whilst the UK and US operate under an opt-in model. The potential effect of this on an individual’s decisions is demonstrated by the relatively low rejection rates of organ donation in Spain, compared to the higher rejection rates of organ donation in the UK and US. Hence, it is possible that a policy favouring organ donation also creates an attitude in individuals that favours donation.

answers.description: Provides no support either way to this assertion

child_mcqs.description: As specifically mentioned by the article, willingness to donate represents a more valid assessment of donation behaviour than public support for organ donation because
child_mcqs.explanation: The question asks for the reason specifically mentioned in the article. This is found in the last line, where it asserts that individuals can support organ donation as an abstract concept, but may come to realise that they do not wish for their organs or their family’s organs to be donated. This is answer B. Answer A is very similar to answer B, although an individual may be willing to donate but still nevertheless fail to register (such as through inadvertence). C is incorrect as, regardless of an individual’s willingness to donate, their family could potentially still deny the decision. No statistics are mentioned to support D

answers.description: Willingness to donate accounts for the fact that an individual may support organ donation but fail to register under an opt-in to the system
Willingness to donate accounts for the fact that an individual may support organ donation but may not wish for their own organs to be donated
Willingness to donate accounts for the fact that, whilst the individual may support organ donation, their family may nevertheless deny their donation
Donation rates are very low compared to a high level of public support for donation, but are closely aligned to levels of willing donors

title: Exam 4
instruction:
This GradReady Practice Exam is meant to test your ability to take the GAMSAT. The idea behind this exam is to help you assess what you have learned and where you may still be struggling. You will get the best results from this exam if you treat it as if it were the actual GAMSAT.

Upon completion of the exam you will be able to see your score.

Today’s Exam consists of 3 Sections:

Section 1: Reasoning in Humanities and Social Sciences (10 min reading time + 1 hr 40 min)

Section 2: Written Communication - Essay (5 min reading time + 1 hr) - you may submit these essays through the Essays tab (if you had purchased essay marking), if you wish to have them marked. You may pick topics from the Essays tab or from our course book.

Lunch Break (1 hr)

Section 3: Reasoning in Biological & Physical Sciences (10 minute reading time + 2 hr 50 min)

Good luck!

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
Break, Break, Break

By Alfred, Lord Tennyson

 

Break, break, break,

On thy cold gray stones, O Sea!

And I would that my tongue could utter

The thoughts that arise in me.

 

O, well for the fisherman's boy,

That he shouts with his sister at play!

O, well for the sailor lad,

That he sings in his boat on the bay!

 

And the stately ships go on

To their haven under the hill;

But O for the touch of a vanish'd hand,

And the sound of a voice that is still!

 

Break, break, break

At the foot of thy crags, O Sea!

But the tender grace of a day that is dead

Will never come back to me.

child_mcqs.description: The speaker is most likely
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 4 is incorrect, as while it is possible that the speaker is a grieving father, this is not implied within the text. The speaker does express envy toward the “[children] at play”, but this is no different to the tone and rhyme pattern used to refer to a “sailor” and “his boat on the bay”. For this same reason, Answer 3 is also incorrect. Despite the sea being an element of focus, it cannot be inferred that the speaker looks upon the ocean with any specific devotion. Therefore Answer 1 is incorrect. Overall, it is suggested within the text that the speaker has lost someone close, thus gazing enviously at those unaffected by bereavement ("O, well for the fisherman's boy" / "sailor lad"). Answer 2 is correct.

answers.description: One who looks upon the ocean with devotion

child_mcqs.description:
Consider the following statements.

  1. The repetition of “break, break, break” is a litany, which gives the piece its despondent tone and signals the passage of time.
  2. Like the “stately ships”, so too is the speaker caught in time.
child_mcqs.explanation: Option I is correct as the repetition of “break, break, break” serves to highlight the speaker's tone of despondency and disheartenment. Similarly, this litany also marks the passage of time; the speaker beseeches the sea to break first “on thy cold gray stones”, and during low tide, at “foot of thy crags”.  Option II is incorrect as the mention of “stately ships go[ing] to their haven” highlights how unlike the ships retiring for the night, the speaker remains near the ocean, caught in remembrance. Therefore, Answer 2 is correct.

answers.description: Both Option I and II are correct.
Both Option I and II are incorrect.

child_mcqs.description: The use of exclamation marks
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 3 is an incorrect assumption; there is no evidence to suggest that the sea is characterised as immovable and taciturn. Answer 4 is incorrect as although the speaker is envious of the happiness and contentment others display, this is not tantamount to hatred. Answer 2 is also incorrect; given that exclamation marks feature in every stanza, it cannot be accurately stated that they are used only to express the speaker’s envy. Within the poem, the use of exclamation marks emphasizes the speaker's various outward displays of emotionality. This not only includes feelings of envy and resentment, but also the fervent imploration of “break, break, break”. Therefore, such punctuation exemplifies the strength and conviction behind the speaker’s various emotions. Answer 1 is correct.

answers.description: Expresses the envy felt by the speaker
Characterises the sea as immovable and taciturn

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
The following is an excerpt of "The School" from Sixty Stories by Ronald Barthelme.

Well, we had all these children out planting trees, see, because we figured that ... that was part of their education, to see how, you know, the root systems ... and also the sense of responsibility, taking care of things, being individually responsible. You know what I mean. And the trees all died. They were orange trees. I don’t know why they died, they just died. Something wrong with the soil possibly or maybe the stuff we got from the nursery wasn’t the best. We complained about it. So we’ve got thirty kids there, each kid had his or her own little tree to plant and we’ve got these thirty dead trees. All these kids looking at these little brown sticks, it was depressing.

It wouldn’t have been so bad except that just a couple of weeks before the thing with the trees, the snakes all died. But I think that the snakes – well, the reason that the snakes kicked off was that ... you remember, the boiler was shut off for four days because of the strike, and that was explicable. It was something you could explain to the kids because of the strike. I mean, none of their parents would let them cross the picket line and they knew there was a strike going on and what it meant. So when things got started up again and we found the snakes they weren’t too disturbed.

With the herb gardens it was probably a case of overwatering, and at least now they know not to overwater. The children were very conscientious with the herb gardens and some of them probably ... you know, slipped them a little extra water when we weren’t looking. Or maybe ... well, I don’t like to think about sabotage, although it did occur to us. I mean, it was something that crossed our minds. We were thinking that way probably because before that the gerbils had died, and the white mice had died, and the salamander ... well, now they know not to carry them around in plastic bags.

Of course we expected the tropical fish to die, that was no surprise. Those numbers, you look at them crooked and they’re belly-up on the surface. But the lesson plan called for a tropical fish input at that point, there was nothing we could do, it happens every year, you just have to hurry past it.

We weren’t even supposed to have a puppy.

We weren’t even supposed to have one, it was just a puppy the Murdoch girl found under a Gristede’s truck one day and she was afraid the truck would run over it when the driver had finished making his delivery, so she stuck it in her knapsack and brought it to the school with her. So we had this puppy. As soon as I saw the puppy I thought, Oh Christ, I bet it will live for about two weeks and then... And that’s what it did. It wasn’t supposed to be in the classroom at all, there’s some kind of regulation about it, but you can’t tell them they can’t have a puppy when the puppy is already there, right in front of them, running around on the floor and yap yap yapping. They named it Edgar – that is, they named it after me. They had a lot of fun running after it and yelling, “Here, Edgar! Nice Edgar!” Then they’d laugh like hell. They enjoyed the ambiguity. I enjoyed it myself. I don’t mind being kidded. They made a little house for it in the supply closet and all that. I don’t know what it died of. Distemper, I guess. It probably hadn’t had any shots. I got it out of there before the kids got to school. I checked the supply closet each morning, routinely, because I knew what was going to happen. I gave it to the custodian.

child_mcqs.description: The character's voice is best described as
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. This is made evident thorough the use of colloquial, uncertain language including elipses (these are three full stops in a row to cause pause in reading) "...", frequent use of the word "well", and pervasive use of passive language. The character seems most unsure, particularly in the in first few paragraphs. Being unsure, or expressing uncertainty, can be described as being ambivalent, since it is a synonym for 'uncertain'.

child_mcqs.description: What overall themes are most strongly communicated in this piece?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option A is correct. The character attempts to communicate, with great uncertainty, the events of the year. It is made aware that, at times, the character is unsure of why particular things have occurred. The character does not seem particularly anxious about any of the events, rather the opposite (Option D is incorrect). Whilst the prose describes a lot within the environment, the passage is not about nature (Option C is incorrect). Option B may describe the antithesis of this passage (hence is incorrect).

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
- This passage is from Jane Eyre, written by Charlotte Bronte

"Then I should love Mrs. Reed, which I cannot do; I should bless her son John, which is impossible."

In her turn, Helen Burns asked me to explain, and I proceeded forthwith to pour out, in my own way, the tale of my sufferings and resentments. Bitter and truculent when excited, I spoke as I felt, without reserve or softening.

Helen heard me patiently to the end: I expected she would then make a remark, but she said nothing.

"Well," I asked impatiently, "is not Mrs. Reed a hard-hearted, bad woman?"

"She has been unkind to you, no doubt; because you see, she dislikes your cast of character, as Miss Scatcherd does mine; but how minutely you remember all she has done and said to you! What a singularly deep impression her injustice seems to have made on your heart! No ill-usage so brands its record on my feelings. Would you not be happier if you tried to forget her severity, together with the passionate emotions it excited? Life appears to me too short to be spent in nursing animosity or registering wrongs. We are, and must be, one and all, burdened with faults in this world: but the time will soon come when, I trust, we shall put them off in putting off our corruptible bodies; when debasement and sin will fall from us with this cumbrous frame of flesh, and only the spark of the spirit will remain, --the impalpable principle of light and thought, pure as when it left the Creator to inspire the creature: whence it came it will return; perhaps again to be communicated to some being higher than man--perhaps to pass through gradations of glory, from the pale human soul to brighten to the seraph! Surely it will never, on the contrary, be suffered to degenerate from man to fiend? No; I cannot believe that: I hold another creed: which no one ever taught me, and which I seldom mention; but in which I delight, and to which I cling: for it extends hope to all: it makes Eternity a rest--a mighty home, not a terror and an abyss. Besides, with this creed, I can so clearly distinguish between the criminal and his crime; I can so sincerely forgive the first while I abhor the last: with this creed revenge never worries my heart, degradation never too deeply disgusts me, injustice never crushes me too low: I live in calm, looking to the end."

Helen's head, always drooping, sank a little lower as she finished this sentence. I saw by her look she wished no longer to talk to me, but rather to converse with her own thoughts. She was not allowed much time for meditation: a monitor, a great rough girl, presently came up, exclaiming in a strong Cumberland accent - "Helen Burns, if you don't go and put your drawer in order, and fold up your work this minute, I'll tell Miss Scatcherd to come and look at it!"

Helen sighed as her reverie fled, and getting up, obeyed the monitor without reply as without delay.

child_mcqs.description: What emotion does Helen Burns show to the author following her assertion of suffering and mistreatment?
child_mcqs.explanation: Rather than demonstrating sorrow or outrage in response to the author’s claims, Helen shows disapproval of the author’s feelings towards her transgressor, and questions the utility of the anger that she holds towards Mrs. Reed. She is not indifferent, as she takes the time to explain her feelings to the author. Therefore, C is the correct answer.

child_mcqs.description: What advice does Helen Burns attempt to convey to the author following her assertion of Mrs. Reed’s transgressions?
child_mcqs.explanation: In response to the author’s tale of my sufferings and resentments, Helen attempts to dissuade the author from adopting feelings of anger and hatred. In revealing her philosophy, she asserts that ‘I can so clearly distinguish between the criminal and his crime; I can so sincerely forgive the first while I abhor the last.’ From this statement, it is clear that Helen is advising the author to separate the act from the actor, or to separate her anger towards Mrs. Reed from her anger towards Mrs Reed's actions. It is also clear from this passage that D cannot be correct, as Helen allows herself to abhor the crime, if not the criminal. Whilst Helen suggests that all are burdened with faults, this is not the same as suggesting that a person is not responsible for the actions that they do take. Therefore, the answer is B

answers.description: Mrs. Reed is not responsible for her actions towards the author
The author should attempt to separate her feelings towards Mrs. Reed from her feelings toward Mrs. Reed’s actions
The author should ensure that she does not act in a way that enlivens Mrs. Reed’s anger
The author should attempt to remain non-judgmental in the face of the adversity presented by Mrs. Reed

child_mcqs.description: Why does Helen Burns describe human bodies as ‘corruptible'
child_mcqs.explanation: From the surrounding phrase, Helen states that ‘all humans are burdened with faults’, and that ‘debasement and sin will fall from us with this cumbrous frame of flesh’. Human bodies are therefore corruptible as the sins resulting from human imperfections attach themselves to the body, which are only removed upon death. Therefore, B is the correct answer

answers.description: Humans endure much abuse and hardship from others
Humans are imperfect and debase themselves with immorality
Human bodies are fragile and vulnerable to outside harms
Humans are weak-minded and easily swayed by deceitful minds

child_mcqs.description: According to Helen Burns, what is the benefit of learning to control one’s anger towards others?
child_mcqs.explanation: As Helen says in her final two sentences, ‘with this creed revenge never worries my heart, degradation never too deeply disgusts me, injustice never crushes me too low: I live in calm, looking to the end.’ This evinces her ability to endure much mistreatment without allowing it to affect her, so that A is the correct answer. B and D may also be true, but they are not mentioned in the passage

answers.description: It provides the ability to endure much hardship
It may prevent a continuation or repeat of the original wrongdoing
It allows entry into the Creator’s heaven
It provides a means for building self-respect

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description: Examine the cartoon above carefully, and answer the following questions.

child_mcqs.description: Which feature is least important to the cartoon's message?
child_mcqs.explanation: The cartoon is about children being held in detention and the prime minister's response to a report, "The Forgotten Children". Since the plight of the children being held in detention is the focus of the cartoon, the children are necessary for the cartoon. The fence is also necessary as it establishes that they are being held in captivity. The report the man holds is necessary to both establish what the cartoon is responding to and give meaning to the man's words. This leaves the tents in the backgroud. While they are important, because they establishes that the children are being kept in poor conditions, the cartoon would make sense without them. Therefore A is the best answer.

answers.description: The fence in front of the children

child_mcqs.description:
This cartoon uses:

I. Satire

II. Caricature

III. Metaphor

IV. Anaphora
child_mcqs.explanation: Satire is humour being used with a political purpose. The cartoon uses humour to comment on children being held in detention and the grandstanding of politicians. Therefore I is correct. The cartoon also uses caricature. The red underwear on the outside of the suit and the exaggerated facial details suggest that the man in the suit is an exaggerated version of a specific politician. Therefore II is correct. Metaphor is when something is described as being something else for rhetorical and descriptive effect. There is no metaphor in this cartoon. Anaphora is a rhetorical device, involving the repetition of a particular phrase or word at the beginning of a series of lines or phrases. There is no anaphora in this cartoon. Therefore B is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
The following is an excerpt from Untruth by Robert J. Samuelson. Consider this excerpt and answer questions 1 - 3.

Every so often an item bounces across the Associated Press wire that reminds you how steadfast the American national character is. Here's one (sutaby abbreviated) that arrived a few weeks ago:

ROCHESTER, N.H. - An 88-year-old woman made good on her pledge not to pay "one red cent" of a court judgment against her for taking a neighbor boy's kickball away.

Rochester District Court Judge Franklin Jones accepted a check for $30.20 from someone who sympathized with Reba Martineau rather than pressing Martineau herself to pay. Jones could have jailed her for contempt.

Now, a lot of folks think the American national character is going to pot. Time magazine recently complained in a cover story that we have become a nation of "crybabies." We sue too often. We see ourselves as the "victims" of someone or something else. The editors at Time ought to brush up on their history. What they (and many others) deplore is simply the good old American character adapting to modern times. We may not like what we see, but-as the kickball saga will show-it's the way we've always been.

Americans have long lived by two propositions.

Proposition Number One: You're no better than I am.

Equality is our religion, as Alexis de Tocqueville noted. We may not be equal in income, wealth, or talent. But we categorically reject the idea that people are automatically better or worse merely because they belong to some class or group. Tocqueville found that, unlike Europe, there was no natural aristocracy in America. Everyone is supposed to have the same opportunity. This was our national ideal (and mythology) in the 1830s. It remains so today.

Proposition Number Two: You can't do that to me.

Since at least the Boston Tea Party, Americans have resented arbitrary authority. We have the Bill of Rights to define the limits of outside control over individual conduct. We react strongly against what we regard as intrusions into our lives, whether by government, bureaucracy (private and public), or other groups and individuals. Liberals defend "rights." Conservatives exalt "freedom." They're really talking about the same thing.

Let it be said that these have been-and are-sources of American greatness. They nurture love of liberty, a respect for the individual, and a healthy sensitivity to the abuse of power. But these same impulses can get out of hand. Unless somehow tempered, they can lead to absurd and wasteful conflict.

In a more traditional society, Reba Martineau would have received some deference merely because she is 88. Not in America. The old aren't superior simply because they're old. We won't have an aristocracy of age or anything else. After "Mama" and "dog," American children first learn to say: "It's not fair." They think they're as good as anyone else, and they're encouraged to believe it...

...What Time describes as "victimology" - the idea that your problems are always someone else's fault-derives from the same values. They are a wellspring for economic, social, racial, sexual, and personal resentment. They provide a ready-made escape from individual responsibility. We're all equal, right? Well, if we're not, then why not? Who's to blame? Every group of individuals that's dissatisfied with life looks for the villain who stole the American dream.

These questions are often fair and legitimate. Social conditions constantly change. Our society is and always will be imperfect. It can't improve itself if no one challenges the status quo. Nor is every lawsuit frivolous. But the trouble is that virtuous American values are increasingly unrestrained by custom, tradition, or common sense. In a bureaucratic and legalized society, there are many points for complaint and pressure. Television and print media provide ample opportunity for publicity and self-expression. Almost everyone can go somewhere to pout about something.

What has gotten us into trouble is the boundless belief in our own national rhetoric. Our virtues, when taken to excess, become vices. They breed self-pity, self-delusion, and pointless conflict. The old American character hasn't died. It's just grown a bit silly.

child_mcqs.description: From the author's perspective, the "American national character" is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option B is correct. The author repeatedly makes reference ot the ways in which the American national character is one who stands for equality, freedoms and rights and opposes any class-based hierarchical society. Option A is incorrect; the author does not believe the American character truly holds these values but rather may express them if deluded enough by the national rhetoric. Option C may be true but is most certainly not the most correct answer. Option D is incorrect because the author attempts to persuade the reader to view the American character is a positive light; rather than intending to breed conflict they uphold fair and just values.

answers.description: Best typified by an individual holding entrenched and self-interested beliefs but expresses kind and giving attitudes
A stern character who supports equality but opposes aristocracy in principle
An individual who fights for their individual freedoms
Any American persons who have lost their sense of equality and freedoms to breed self-delusion and conflict within the national interest

child_mcqs.description: What does the author conclude about societies in general?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option D is correct. The passage makes no particular reference to society in general - it is not possible to extend the author's comments regarding the American character to other societies. The author makes explicit reference multiple times to the values of an American society. For this reason, Options A, B and C are all in correct.

answers.description: Societies are and always will be imperfect
A just society can only truly achieve equality if established on the principle of freedom, free from hierarchy
Citizens of a society often become too persuaded and believe their own national rhetoric to an extent it prohibits social productivity
The author does not comment on societies in general and only remarks on the American society.

child_mcqs.description: In the last paragraph, what does the author mean by the "national rhetoric"?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. By the "national rhetoric", the author means the story (and values) that established the modern and independent American society. Option A is incorrect; students may become confused in the defition of rhetoric and may conclude it means rhetorical question (which is a  figure of speech in the form of a question that is asked in order to make a point, rather than to elicit an answer). Option B is partly correct however the rhetoric means much more than just the history. Whilst a rhetoric intends to partly persuade, Option D is not correct as it is not a national persuasion (nor does the author intend the use of the term rhetoric in this way).

answers.description: The questions American citizens pose themselves to conclude particular values such as freedom and equality
Values reflected in the American story and subsequent historic Bill of Human Rights

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
Beat! Beat! Drums!

By Walt Whitman

 

Beat! beat! drums!—blow! bugles! blow!

Through the windows—through doors—burst like a ruthless force,

Into the solemn church, and scatter the congregation,

Into the school where the scholar is studying,

Leave not the bridegroom quiet—no happiness must he have now with his bride,

Nor the peaceful farmer any peace, ploughing his field or gathering his grain,

So fierce you whirr and pound you drums—so shrill you bugles blow.

 

Beat! beat! drums!—blow! bugles! blow!

Over the traffic of cities—over the rumble of wheels in the streets;

Are beds prepared for sleepers at night in the houses? no sleepers must sleep in those beds,

No bargainers’ bargains by day—no brokers or speculators—would they continue?

Would the talkers be talking? would the singer attempt to sing?

Would the lawyer rise in the court to state his case before the judge?

Then rattle quicker, heavier drums—you bugles wilder blow.

 

Beat! beat! drums!—blow! bugles! blow!

Make no parley—stop for no expostulation,

Mind not the timid—mind not the weeper or prayer,

Mind not the old man beseeching the young man,

Let not the child’s voice be heard, nor the mother’s entreaties,

Make even the trestles to shake the dead where they lie awaiting the hearses,

So strong you thump O terrible drums—so loud you bugles blow.

child_mcqs.description: The overarching theme of this poem is
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect, as peace does not feature as a dominant theme within the poem. Answer 3 is also incorrect, as although the modern scenery of a “city” is depicted, the poem does not focus on illustrating a “contemporary battlefield”.  Answer 4 is not the best option as music (“bugles” and “drums”) operates as a vehicle through which the expansive and disruptive force of war can be illustrated to the reader. This is evidenced by the poet’s use of onomatopoeic imagery (“blow!” / “burst” / “pound”), which more accurately describes the sounds of war, rather than music. Therefore, the most appropriate option is Answer 2 – the magnitude of war. Sweeping across “cities” and “streets”, the sound of drums and bugles throws an entire populace into disarray (“scholar[s]” / “sleepers” / “lawyer[s]” / “mother[s]”). Across the three stanzas, the magnitude of war is shown to be so great that even the “dead” shake in their “hearses”.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements best summarises the attitude of the speaker?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as although the speaker makes mention of various groups and individuals, he or she is not suggesting that all citizens need fight. Answer 3 is incorrect, as although the “bugles” sound to attract focus to the war effort, the assumption that ordinary citizens live mediocre lives remains unfounded.  Similarly, Answer 4 is incorrect -  although a valid point, this statement does not adequately summarise the attitude of the speaker and the force with which the bugles and drums sound.  Therefore, Answer 1 provides the best summary of the speaker’s attitude. Considering the speaker’s words, it is evident war takes precedence over the sanctity of life (“shake the dead where they lie”/ “let not the child’s voice be heard”) and societal order (“no sleepers must sleep” / “leave not the bridegroom quiet”).

answers.description: War takes precedence over the sanctity of life and societal order.
War requires all citizens to fight for their country.
War drags the citizens' focus away from their mediocre lives.
War involves a certain degree of pageantry and parade.

child_mcqs.description: The speaker is most likely
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect as the speaker demonstrates great interest in the proceedings of war – highlighted by the exclamatory imperatives he gives to the instruments (“Beat! beat! drums!”). Answer 2 is incorrect, as perpendicular is not an accurate descriptor of the speaker’s stance. Similarly, Answer 3 of “perturbed by war” is incorrect as the speaker exhibits no emotionality within the poem - he or she simply states the way everything must be during war. Answer 4 is correct. The speaker exhibits deference to the war – even though the music of war throws the most venerable places into disarray (“churches” / “school[s]” / “court[s]”), he or she continues to implore the instruments to continue. It can therefore be assumed that the speaker deems warfare worthy of great respect and attention from the people.

child_mcqs.description: “So shrill you bugles blow” is an example of
child_mcqs.explanation: This is a straightforward question. This line is an example of word order inversion, where the verb appears at the end of a phrase. Order inversion, as a literary device, allows the poet to create an iambic heptameter (seven iambs, or metrical feet, in one line) that mimics the manner of a beating drum.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7

child_mcqs.description: Based on the graph, which of these statements is correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect as the percentages are inaccurate; approximately 38% of the Indigenous population is under 15 years of age, compared with 19% of the non-Indigenous population. Answer 2 is incorrect as these figures are not included in the graph. Answer 4 is a prediction that cannot be made accurately based on the information provided – the graph merely illustrates the ages of Indigenous and non-Indigenous populations for 2006. Therefore, Answer 3 is correct.  As seen within the graph, the percentages of both populations between ages 30 and 34 are approximately the same, about 3.5%.

answers.description: Approximately 23% of the Indigenous population is under the age of 15, compared with 9% of the general population.
There were approximately twice as many Indigenous females than non-Indigenous females, estimated at 60,000 and 30,000 respectively.
Proportionally, approximately the same percentage of both populations are between ages 30 and 34.
Approximately the same percentage of both populations will reach the age 30.

child_mcqs.description: Which of these statements best describes the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as an inference about the influence of chronic disease cannot accurately be made. Similarly, Answer 3 is incorrect, as inferences about the aging Australian population cannot accurately be made based on this graph. Answer 4 is incorrect as there is no bimodal peak in the data of the Indigenous population. Therefore, Answer 1 is correct as it is clearly seen within the graph that the age structure differs between the Indigenous and non-Indigenous populations.

answers.description: The Indigenous population has a different age structure to the general population.
The burden of mortality from chronic disease presents earlier in the Indigenous population.
Indigenous populations will not contribute greatly to the aging Australian population.
Indigenous populations experience a bimodal peak in mortality.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description:
This article is entitled, 'Addressing the burden of cancer in the Gulf', obtained from The Lancet Oncology

On Oct 21—23, 2014, a meeting to discuss how to tackle the growing burden of cancer in the Gulf region was held in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Although currently lower than in Europe and the USA, the burden of cancer in the Middle East is increasing, and is predicted to almost double by 2030. This increase is due, in part, to longer lifespans and adoption of western lifestyle habits (eg, greater use of tobacco; consumption of high-fat, low-fibre diets; and greater physical inactivity). The countries that form the Gulf Corporation Council (GCC)—Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, and Kuwait—are expected to be at the higher end of these predictions for the region, while also being faced with a high burden of infectious diseases. The meeting culminated in a declaration to be submitted for endorsement by the Executive Board of the Health Ministers Council for the GCC States, which listed areas in need of attention and called on member states to reduce cancer mortality by 25% between 2015 and 2025. But can this ambitious target be achieved?

Although GCC countries cannot be described as being of low-to-middle income—they are perhaps more accurately described as industrialising—they share many of the same barriers to universal health care that face developing countries. At a systems level, inadequate registration of cancer incidence and death prevents an accurate measure of the burden of the disease, thus hindering proper planning of national and regional cancer-control programmes. Efforts to improve disease registration are underway in the region, but there is still some way to go. Region-specific research is clearly needed to better understand the differences in underlying tumour biology that, for instance, result in about half of cancers in the region presenting at an early age, and to investigate why the pattern of malignancies diagnosed in the Gulf differs from that elsewhere (eg, haematological malignancies, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphomas, are very common in the GCC, possibly as a result of the high prevalence of consanguineous marriages in the region).

Further, distinct national cancer plans do not exist for all countries in the region. Some countries, such as Qatar, have taken useful steps forward with the launch of a National Cancer Strategy and a National Cancer Research Strategy, but such action is not universal. Additionally, primary care is generally geared towards acute care rather than chronic diseases, whereas in terms of secondary care, cancer treatment facilities are limited in number and of variable quality. To address the low number of facilities would need investment and detailed consideration of the geographical and personal financial barriers that exist for large proportions of the population. There is a growing interest in improving health infrastructure in the region—eg, medical centres of excellence such as King Abdulaziz Medical City in Saudi Arabia are being developed. However, where funding exists, it must be used wisely—eg, is there really a need to build four proton therapy facilities in Saudi Arabia when the country has only half the required number of linear accelerators for its population?

At the population and patient level, cultural barriers and educational issues, which together contribute to poor awareness of the disease and of health care in general, must be addressed. Primary prevention measures to successfully reduce exposure to risk factors (eg, tobacco use, poor diet, and little physical activity) are needed. Breaking down social taboos about cancer is also a priority for both primary and secondary prevention—region-specific research into methods to overcome these barriers is vital. Access to essential palliative drugs is restricted in the region, a situation that is unjustifiable, particularly given that most cancers present late and in non-curable stages. Lastly, the provision of universal health care in all Gulf countries should be mandatory: health is a human right, and the rights of all patients to both treatment and psychosocial support are paramount. The disproportionate distribution of wealth in the region is a substantial hurdle to accessing care for a large part of the population, which hinders efforts towards universal care.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is NOT listed as a barrier to universal health care in the Middle East
child_mcqs.explanation: Whilst all four answers are mentioned in the passage, only three are listed as barriers to universal health care. Instead the adoption of Western lifestyle habits is described as a cause of the increased burden of disease. Whilst Western lifestyle habits also feature in the fourth paragraph, it is the poor patient recognition of these risk factors that represent the barrier to health care. Therefore, the answer is B

answers.description: The adoption of Western lifestyle habits
The limited health research specific to the Middle East
The lack of national cancer plans

child_mcqs.description: The article portrays the Saudi Arabian purchase of four proton therapy facilities as?
child_mcqs.explanation: Profligate refers to the recklessly extravagant or wasteful use of resources. The purchase of the proton therapy facilities is used as an example of where funding is not used wisely. It suggests that the purchase of the facilities was reckless when resources are required elsewhere (such as for linear accelerators). Therefore, the answer is A

child_mcqs.description: Why does the article describe the issue of palliative drugs as being particularly important in cancer?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article immediately follows its request for palliative drugs with the fact that most cancers present late and in non-curable stages. This suggests that cancer patients have a greater need for palliative drugs than patients with other disease, as it is unlikely that curative drugs can work. Although the article says that palliative drugs are restricted in the region, this does not say anything about the difference between their role in cancer and other diseases. Therefore, D is the correct answer

answers.description: Palliative drugs possess greater efficacy in cancer patients
Palliative drugs are restricted in the Middle East
Palliative drugs are more affordable that other drugs used in cancer
Cancer patients are more likely to require palliative drugs

child_mcqs.description: Applying a similar analysis to road trauma injuries, which of the following may represent a systems level problem?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage includes system levels problems as inadequate recording of cancer risk and inadequate planning, as they affect the entire cancer treatment regime. In this example, D is the only answer that may represent a system risk, as it too affects the entire burden of road trauma. Conversely, answers A, B and C all represent individual driver risks associated with road trauma.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9

child_mcqs.description: Within the cartoon, the doctor is best described as
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 3 of highbrow is incorrect; the doctor speaks in uncomplicated terms, and as such there is no evidence to suggest he is pretentious or pompous. Similarly, Answer 4 is incorrect, as although the doctor’s words are friendly, (“I like that about you”), describing the doctor as congenial is not the best option. Although not explicitly stated, the predominant interpretation of this comic is that the doctor states his liking of the patient because being “sick a lot” results in more visits, hence more financial gain. However, Answer 2 is incorrect - describing the doctor as avaricious, or money-focused, is an assumption that, although suggested, cannot be accurately made based only on the interaction depicted within the cartoon. Therefore, Answer 1 is correct. From the short, sharp and straightforward dialogue, it can be most accurately surmised that the doctor is frank and candid. Both of his blunt statements (“you’re sick a lot”/ “I like that about you”) reinforce this description.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
Erl- Kring

English adaptation of a German poem y J W Van Goethe

Who rides there so late through the night dark and drear?
The father it is, with his infant so dear;
He holdeth the boy tightly clasp'd in his arm,
He holdeth him safely, he keepeth him warm.

"My son, wherefore seek'st thou thy face thus to hide?"
"Look, father, the Erl-King is close by our side!
Dost see not the Erl-King, with crown and with train?"
"My son, 'tis the mist rising over the plain."

"Oh, come, thou dear infant! oh come thou with me!
For many a game I will play there with thee;
On my strand, lovely flowers their blossoms unfold,
My mother shall grace thee with garments of gold."

"My father, my father, and dost thou not hear
The words that the Erl-King now breathes in mine ear?"
"Be calm, dearest child, 'tis thy fancy deceives;
'Tis the sad wind that sighs through the withering leaves."

"Wilt go, then, dear infant, wilt go with me there?
My daughters shall tend thee with sisterly care;
My daughters by night their glad festival keep,
They'll dance thee, and rock thee, and sing thee to sleep."

"My father, my father, and dost thou not see,
How the Erl-King his daughters has brought here for me?"
"My darling, my darling, I see it aright,
'Tis the aged grey willows deceiving thy sight."

"I love thee, I'm charm'd by thy beauty, dear boy!
And if thou'rt unwilling, then force I'll employ."
"My father, my father, he seizes me fast,
For sorely the Erl-King has hurt me at last."

The father now gallops, with terror half wild,
He grasps in his arms the poor shuddering child;
He reaches his courtyard with toil and with dread, –
The child in his arms finds he motionless, dead.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following words best describe the theme of this poem?
child_mcqs.explanation: While the boy is ill at the beginning of the poem and dead by the end, it's not correct to say that illness is a major theme of the poem so answers A and C can be ruled out. Similarly while reference is made to natural elements, the thematic focus of this poem is on a mythical creature (fantasy), the death of a child and the difference in perception between father and son. Therefore answer D is the best option.

child_mcqs.description: In the fifth stanza, who will tend to the infant with sisterly care?
child_mcqs.explanation: The sixth stanza explains that the infant hears the Erl-KIng has brought his daughter to call him. A careful reading of the poem will reveal that each alternate stanza is written in the words of the Erl-King who refers to his own daughters in the fifth stanza.

answers.description: The daughters of the man who is carrying him safely

child_mcqs.description: The poet's intention in writing this poem is most likely to:
child_mcqs.explanation: A ballad is a narrative written as a poem often with rhythm and rhyme. Students who understand the definition of a ballad will realise that this poem is a balllad that tells the story of a child being taken by a mythical creature. For this reason answer B is correct. There is not enough evidence in the poem to support any of the other answers.

answers.description: create a metaphor of a child being taken by an illness
write a ballad about a mythical creature that takes the life of a child
write about how a father is trying to rush his dieing son to safety, but the son dies before they reach their destination.
to warn other childrean about the Erl-King through poetry

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description:
- This passage is extracted from 'Eating Animals', by Jonathan Saffran Foer

No reader of this book would tolerate someone swinging a pickax at a dog’s face. Nothing could be more obvious or less in need of explanation. Is such concern morally out of place when applied to fish, or are we silly to have such unquestioning concern about dogs? Is the suffering of a drawn-out death something that is cruel to inflict on any animal that can experience it, or just some animals?

Can the familiarity of the animals we have come to know as companions be a guide to us as we think about the animals we eat? Just how distant are fish (or cows, pigs, or chickens) from us in the scheme of life? Is it a chasm or a tree that defines the distance? Are nearness and distance even relevant? If we were to one day encounter a form of life more powerful and intelligent than our own, and it regarded us as we regard fish, what would be our argument against being eaten?

The lives of billions of animals a year and the health of the largest ecosystems on our planet hang on the thinly reasoned answers we give to these questions. Such global concerns can themselves feel distant, though. We care most about what’s close to us, and have a remarkably easy time forgetting everything else. We also have a strong impulse to do what others around us are doing, especially when it comes to food. Food ethics are so complex because food is bound to both taste buds and taste, to individual biographies and social histories. The choice-obsessed modern West is probably more accommodating to individuals who choose to eat differently than any culture has ever been, but ironically, the utterly unselective omnivore — “I’m easy; I’ll eat anything” — can appear more socially sensitive than the individual who tries to eat in a way that is good for society. Food choices are determined by many factors, but reason (even consciousness) is not generally high on the list.

There is something about eating animals that tends to polarize: never eat them or never sincerely question eating them; become an activist or disdain activists. These opposing positions — and the closely related unwillingness to take a position — converge in suggesting that eating animals matters. If and how we eat animals cuts to something deep. Meat is bound up with the story of who we are and who we want to be, from the book of Genesis to the latest farm bill. It raises significant philosophical questions and is a $140 billion–plus a year industry that occupies nearly a third of the land on the planet, shapes ocean ecosystems, and may well determine the future of earth’s climate. And yet we seem able to think only about the edges of the arguments — the logical extremes rather than the practical realities. My grandmother said she wouldn’t eat pork to save her life, and though the context of her story is as extreme as it gets, many people seem to fall back on this all-or-nothing framework when discussing their everyday food choices. It’s a way of thinking that we would never apply to other ethical realms. (Imagine always or never lying.) I can’t count the times that upon telling someone I am vegetarian, he or she responded by pointing out an inconsistency in my lifestyle or trying to find a flaw in an argument I never made. (I have often felt that my vegetarianism matters more to such people than it does to me.)

We need a better way to talk about eating animals. We need a way that brings meat to the center of public discussion in the same way it is often at the center of our plates. This doesn’t require that we pretend we are going to have collective agreement. However strong our intuitions are about what’s right for us personally and even about what’s right for others, we all know in advance that our positions will clash with those of our neighbors. What do we do with that most inevitable reality? Drop the conversation, or find a way to reframe it?

child_mcqs.description: According to the first three paragraphs, what does the author argue is the principal point of separation between companion animals and fish?
child_mcqs.explanation: Although the author does talk about the differing levels of intelligence and evolution that may exist between fish and other animals, he also equates fish with potentially higher beings such as chickens, pigs and cows, some of which may be as intelligent as companion animals. Instead, the passage suggests that value placed upon animal life stems from our ‘familiarity’ to animals, as he argues that ‘we care about what is close to us and forget about everything else’. As companion animals occupy a place close to human life, it is more likely that we should feel empathy for their suffering. Thus, Answer C is correct

answers.description: Their level of intelligence
Their degree of evolution
Their proximity to human life
Their taste and cultural importance

child_mcqs.description: What does the author consider ironic about the ‘utterly unselective omnivore’?
child_mcqs.explanation: The author is indicating his belief that the decision of a person to eat according to their social beliefs causes inconvenience to others, and as such causes them to be viewed as socially insensitive. This is apparent as the sentence compares the utterly unselective omnivore to an individual who attempts to eat in a way that is ‘good for society’. The utterly unselective omnivore is thus socially sensitive in the sense of not inconveniencing others, but the author suggests that this is ironic as by failing to assert or act on views regarding the larger problem of meat consumption, they may not be socially sensitive at all. Therefore, B is the correct answer

answers.description: Despite the ‘choice-obsessed’ nature of society, it is the unselective individual that fits in best
It is the failure of the utterly unselective omnivore to confront social problems that allows them to be viewed as being socially conscious
In being ‘utterly unselective’, the omnivore has still made a decision that eating meat is OK
In stating that they will ‘eat anything’, it is unlikely that the utterly unselective omnivore will consume companion animals

child_mcqs.description: In comparison to the position of meat-consumers, the author suggests that the position of vegetarians?
child_mcqs.explanation: The author suggests throughout the passage that human reasoning surrounding meat is confined to the ‘logical extremes rather than the practical realities’. In asserting that eating meat is always bad, the author is implying that this argument suffers from the same problem as that of person who will never eat companion animals, or his grandma who will never eat pork. Each merely asserts a position on the spectrum that is incapable of flexibility, and therefore incapable of providing an avenue for discussing the problems of meat. Therefore, B is the correct answer.

answers.description: Is morally preferable
Is difficult to defend
Enhances the prospects of achieving agreement

child_mcqs.description: The author’s tone in the passage is
child_mcqs.explanation: Although the author is asking the reader to confront the issue of meat consumption, there is a concerted effort in the passage to appear disarming rather than accusatory. The author acknowledges the polarizing nature of the issue, and is attempting to enliven consideration of the issue rather than criticize those who decide differently to himself. The author recognizes that an overly didactic or confrontational tone would be inadequate to reach his goal of achieving discussion around the issue, and therefore a conciliatory and understanding tone is necessary. Therefore, D is the correct answer

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
- the following is an extract from 'Osteroarthritis: an update with relevance for clinical practice', published in the Lancet

The prevalence of osteoarthritis is dependent on the precise definition used and on the site of interest. The knee, hip, and hand are most affected by the disease. Osteoarthritis becomes more common with age, and after age 50 years more women than men are affected. For example, the Rotterdam study of a population-based cohort of 3906 people 55 years or older reported that 67% of women and 55% of men had radiographic osteoarthritis of the hand. In people older than 80 years, 53% of women and 33% of men had radiographic osteoarthritis of the knee.
