The age-standardised and sex-standardised incidence of osteoarthritis of the hand is 100 per 100,000 person-years, for the hip is 88 per 100 000 person-years, and for the knee is 240 per 100 000 person-years.

Osteoarthritis in general develops progressively over several years, although symptoms might remain stable for long periods within this period. The diagnosis of the disease relies on clinical and radiological features. Nearly half of patients with radiological features of osteoarthritis have no symptoms and vice versa. Risk factors for occurrence and progression of osteoarthritis have been identified, and differ on the basis of the joints involved.

The main characteristics of osteoarthritis are changes in the subchondral bone. Osteophyte formation, bone remodelling, subchondral sclerosis, and attrition are crucial for radiological diagnosis. Several of these bone changes take place not only during the final stage of the disease, but also at the onset of the disease —possibly before cartilage degradation. This finding led to the suggestion that subchondral bone could initiate cartilage damage.

Pain is the first and predominant symptom of osteoarthritis that causes patients to visit their family doctor. The pain experienced is intermittent, typically worst during and after weight-bearing activities. Inflammatory flares can happen during the course of the disease. Patients with osteoarthritis also experience stiffness: in the morning, after a period of inactivity, or particularly in the evening. This stiffness generally resolves in minutes, unlike the prolonged (usually >30 min) stiffness caused by rheumatoid arthritis.

child_mcqs.description: According to the passage, a patient with radiological features of osteoarthritis
child_mcqs.explanation: A is not correct, as the article states that the diagnosis of the disease relies on clinical and radiological features, so that a person with radiological features will not necessarily be diagnosed with osteoarthritis. The article also states ‘nearly half of patients with radiological features of osteoarthritis have no symptoms and vice versa’, so that B is not correct. The article does not state that radiological features represent a risk factor of osteoarthritis, so that C is not correct. The article does state that ‘osteophyte formation, bone remodelling, subchondral sclerosis, and attrition are crucial for radiological diagnosis’, which the article states are all bone changes. Therefore, a person with radiological diagnosis must have subchondral bone changes and D is the correct answer

answers.description: Will not possess the symptoms of osteoarthritis
Possesses significant risk factors for osteoarthritis

child_mcqs.description: In comparing osteroarthritis of the knee to osteoarthritis of the hand, the former
child_mcqs.explanation: Although the study of knee osteoarthritis is taken from an older cohort of patients, this does not conclude that knee osteoarthritis occurs later in life. The answer arises from the age-standardised and sex-standardised population statistics, which show that hand osteroarthritis is 100 per 100,000 person-years, whereas knee osteoarthritis is 240 per 100 000 person-years. Therefore, C is the correct answer

answers.description: Has a lower age-standardised and sex-standardised prevalence in both males and females
Has a higher age-standardised and sex-standardised population incidence
Has a greater degree of change in subchondral bone

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following does the article NOT state about the pain and stiffness associated with osteoarthritis
child_mcqs.explanation: The final paragraph states that the pain is worse following weight-bearing, that the stiffness resolves after several minutes, and that pain is the predominant reason for visiting the family doctor. The article states that the stiffness occurs ‘in the morning, after a period of inactivity, or particularly in the evening’ and does not mention exercise. Therefore, D is correct

answers.description: The stiffness resolves after several minutes
Pain is the predominant reason for first visiting the doctor

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description: -

child_mcqs.description: Within this comic, the doctor is suggesting that
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect, as there is no suggestion that the patient is diligent. Answer 3 is incorrect, as there is no evidence to suggest that the patient aims to receive praise. Answer 4 is incorrect, as it cannot be assumed that the doctor has other patients he praises to induce classical symptoms.  Therefore, Answer 2 is correct. By saying “nice work”, the doctor is implying that the patient has, of his own volition, exhibited symptoms that are “classical”, for which he should receive some sort of recognition or praise.

answers.description: Suggests that the patient is diligent even when presenting an illness
The patient exhibits symptoms of his own volition
The patient purposely displays all the symptoms in order to receive praise
He should praise patients so that their symptoms align classically more often

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
- This is an extract from Oscar Wilde's novel, The Picture of Dorian Gray

“Let us go and sit in the shade,” said Lord Henry. “Parker has brought out the drinks, and if you stay any longer in this glare you will be quite spoiled, and Basil will never paint you again. You really must not allow yourself to become sunburnt. It would be unbecoming.”

“What can it matter?” cried Dorian Gray, laughing, as he sat down on the seat at the end of the garden.

“It should matter everything to you, Mr. Gray.”

“Why?”

“Because you have the most marvellous youth, and youth is the one thing worth having.”

“I don’t feel that, Lord Henry.”

“No, you don’t feel it now. Some day, when you are old and wrinkled and ugly, when thought has seared your forehead with its lines, and passion branded your lips with its hideous fires, you will feel it, you will feel it terribly. Now, wherever you go, you charm the world. Will it always be so? . . . You have a wonderfully beautiful face, Mr. Gray. Don’t frown. You have. And Beauty is a form of Genius — is higher, indeed, than Genius, as it needs no explanation. It is of the great facts of the world, like sunlight, or spring-time, or the reflection in dark waters of that silver shell we call the moon. It cannot be questioned. It has its divine right of sovereignty. It makes princes of those who have it. You smile? Ah! when you have lost it you won’t smile. . . . People say sometimes that Beauty is only superficial. That may be so. But at least it is not so superficial as Thought is. To me, Beauty is the wonder of wonders. It is only shallow people who do not judge by appearances. The true mystery of the world is the visible, not the invisible. . . . Yes, Mr. Gray, the gods have been good to you. But what the gods give they quickly take away. You have only a few years in which to live really, perfectly, and fully. When your youth goes, your beauty will go with it, and then you will suddenly discover that there are no triumphs left for you, or have to content yourself with those mean triumphs that the memory of your past will make more bitter than defeats. Every month as it wanes brings you nearer to something dreadful. Time is jealous of you, and wars against your lilies and your roses. You will become sallow, and hollow-cheeked, and dull-eyed. You will suffer horribly. . . . Ah! realise your youth while you have it. Don’t squander the gold of your days, listening to the tedious, trying to improve the hopeless failure, or giving away your life to the ignorant, the common, and the vulgar. These are the sickly aims, the false ideals, of our age. Live! Live the wonderful life that is in you! Let nothing be lost upon you. Be always searching for new sensations. Be afraid of nothing. . . . A new Hedonism — that is what our century wants. You might be its visible symbol. With your personality there is nothing you could not do. The world belongs to you for a season. . . . The moment I met you I saw that you were quite unconscious of what you really are, of what you really might be. There was so much in you that charmed me that I felt I must tell you something about yourself. I thought how tragic it would be if you were wasted. For there is such a little time that your youth will last — such a little time. The common hill-flowers wither, but they blossom again. The laburnum will be as yellow next June as it is now. In a month there will be purple stars on the clematis, and year after year the green night of its leaves will hold its purple stars. But we never get back our youth. The pulse of joy that beats in us at twenty, becomes sluggish. Our limbs fail, our senses rot. We degenerate into hideous puppets, haunted by the memory of the passions of which we were too much afraid, and the exquisite temptations that we had not the courage to yield to. Youth! Youth! There is absolutely nothing in the world but youth!”

child_mcqs.description: Why does Lord Henry argue that Beauty is higher than Genius?
child_mcqs.explanation: Lord Henry says that Beauty is higher than Genius ‘it needs no explanation. It is of the great facts of the world, like sunlight, or spring-time, or the reflection in dark waters of that silver shell we call the moon. It cannot be questioned.’ Therefore, Beauty is unlike Genius as it is self-evident, whereas Genius may require proof. As such, C is the correct answer

answers.description: It grants freedom from moral servitude

child_mcqs.description: Exclaiming that ‘it is only shallow people who do not judge by appearances’ is an example of?
child_mcqs.explanation: Social norms generally dictate that it is shallow to judge a person on their appearances. Lord Henry reverses this by declaring that it is the failure to do so that makes them shallow. Therefore, A is the correct answer. There is no suggestion that Lord Henry does not believe the statement, so it is not a falsehood. Whilst some may believe that it is immoral to judge by appearances, this is not the purpose of his statement.

answers.description: A loss of contact with the modern world

child_mcqs.description: What does Lord Henry seek to provoke from Dorian Gray through his speech?
child_mcqs.explanation: Lord Henry explains to Dorian Gray both the beauty of his youth, and that this beauty will not last forever. This is evident through the statement ‘Ah! realise your youth while you have it’. Although Lord Henry mentions that he believes beauty is not superficial, it is not the main point of the passage. Similarly, although the passage demonstrates Lord Henry’s admiration of Dorian’s beauty, the passage is not intended to convey his personal feelings to Dorian. Finally, rather than acting to preserve his beauty, Lord Henry implores Dorian to act Hedonistically and make the most of his beauty, rather than taking all care to ensure that it does not fade. Therefore, answer B is the correct answer

answers.description: The recognition that Lord Henry admires him
An understanding that his beauty is fleeting
A belief that his beauty is not superficial
The establishment of measures to preserve his beauty

child_mcqs.description: What does the laburnum represent in the passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: Lord Henry explains that ‘the laburnum will be as yellow next June as it is now’. However, ‘we never get back our youth’. The laburnum is therefore used as a contrast to youth, which unlike the laburnum will not return. Therefore, A is the correct answer

answers.description: A continuation of the theme of beauty

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following would be a valid research question, based on the data provided within the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect as the graph illustrates the percentage of individuals that believe cocaine use acceptable, grouped by age. It does not illustrate at what age cocaine use is acceptable. Answer 3 and 4 are incorrect for similar reasons - the graph does not identify cocaine users.  Therefore, Answer 2 is most correct. The graph does contain information regarding the percentage of recent cocaine uses in each age group.

answers.description: At what age is it most acceptable to use cocaine occasionally?
In what age group is the percentage of recent cocaine users the highest?
At what age do cocaine users believe it to be most acceptable to take cocaine frequently/occasionally?
In what age group do cocaine users most greatly believe the occasional consumption of cocaine to be acceptable?

child_mcqs.description: How many respondents were there altogether?
child_mcqs.explanation: The numbers contained in the graph area represents the percentage of individuals who believe it is acceptable to take cocaine frequently/occasionally (light purple) and have taken cocaine in the past year (dark purple). As this graph only lists the percentages of respondents in each category, the total number of respondents cannot be ascertained. Answer 4 is correct.

answers.description: Cannot be ascertained based on the information provided.

child_mcqs.description: Within the graph, 11%
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 and 4 are incorrect – 11% does not represent the number of cocaine users as the answers of this group have not been illustrated. Answer 3 is incorrect, as 11% does not represent 11% of the total respondents from every age group. Therefore Answer 2 is correct – 11% represents the percentage of 25-29 year old respondents who believe it is acceptable to use cocaine frequently or occasionally.

answers.description: Represents the percentage of 25-29 year old cocaine users who also believe it is acceptable to use cocaine frequently or occasionally.
Represents the percentage of 25-29 year old respondents who believe it is acceptable to use cocaine frequently or occasionally.
Represents the percentage of total respondents who believe it is acceptable to use cocaine frequently or occasionally.
Represents the percentage of all of cocaine users who believe it is acceptable to use cocaine frequently or occasionally.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
Excerpt taken from Louise Keogh’s article “Abortions don’t cause cancer any more than parties do”. 

The purported link between abortion and breast cancer is based on research that’s no longer accepted as valid because its methods are so flawed. But that hasn’t stopped politicians such as Fred Nile and groups such as the World Congress of Families, a global conservative Christian group that claims to be a defender of the so-called “natural family”, from repeating it.


The association stems from research from the 1950s and has been used to publicise and bolster the conservative, anti-choice position on abortion. Numerous articles published since the 1950s that fail to confirm any such association between abortion and breast cancer seem not to have dented the enthusiasm of those repeating it. Nor have they reduced the newsworthiness of this early work.


These less than-perfect studies have led to improvements in how epidemiology is conducted because science is not static. New research about breast cancer is published every day and research methods are constantly adjusted and improved to take account of the latest findings.


The public needs to be able trust the scientific process, but when politicians and groups like the World Congress of Families selectively choose research that supports their position and promote these at the expense of the best and most current evidence, they damage science, people’s trust in politicians and in this case, women’s access to correct information about their bodies and risks to their health. The question for us now is not whether there’s a link between breast cancer and abortion but when will women’s health cease to be a political football, and their right to correct information be prioritised ahead of the conservative agenda.

child_mcqs.description: Which of these statements gives the best summary of the text?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect as while it was insinuated that the general public is not well versed in analysis of scientific journals, there was no mention of excluding them from engaging with future research. If anything, the text aims to promote greater future scientific literacy among the general public. Answer 2 is incorrect as while this sentiment is present in the passage, it is not the best summary of the piece. Answer 3 is incorrect as there was no suggestion of creating a division between politics and science. The passage merely suggests that it is ethically wrong for politicians use selective scientific data to support a social agenda when the best and most current evidence reaches a different consensus. The author is not averse to the use of science as evidence for public policy, only to its misuse in this way. Thus Answer 4 is correct.

answers.description: The general public cannot identify flawed scientific studies and therefore should be unable to play a role in the future directions of scientific research especially where it pertains to health conditions such as breast cancer.
The selective use of scientific data to further an agenda, particularly a conservative one, is exceedingly prevalent amongst politicians.
Politics and science should maintain a mutual exclusivity so as to preserve the objectivity of the scientific process for the good of the wider community.
The unethical manipulation of scientific information is to the detriment of the public, the greater scientific community as well as the relationship between the two.

child_mcqs.description: Which of these is NOT supported by the text?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect as this assertion is supported by the text. The author warns consumers of science against propaganda, which misinterprets scientific research to further an agenda. Answer 3 is also incorrect as it is supported by the text. “Science is not static” and where the public is not discerning about their consumption of scientific theory, the author suggests, “politicians…selectively choose research which supports their position.”  Answer 4 is also supported by the extract. The author states that when science is misused in the political arena it “damage[s] science”. Therefore, Answer 1 is correct, as it is never suggested by the extract that the scientific process is open to interpretation. In fact, it is clear that the author remains convinced of the fitness of the scientific process as he/she asserts that it was through further scientific testing that the inaccuracy of the abortion-cancer link was discovered.

answers.description: The scientific process, despite being decidedly objective, is open to interpretation.
The ever-evolving nature of science requires its consumers to be attentive.
Contemporary politics too oft sees the deliberate appropriation of scientific findings so as to monopolise on the public’s apathy.
Public perception and reliance in scientific practice may suffer if the political sphere does not cease its selective and misrepresentative use of discredited medical theory.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description: Consider the following cartoon and answer questions 1 and 2.

child_mcqs.description: The cartoonist's use of pigs in the illustration is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: Option B is correct. The use of pigs in the cartoon is two-fold. The pigs are first used in a gluttonous, fat and freedy sense to depict/symbolise the self-absorbed capacity of corporate entities, media and the military. Secondly, and contrastingly, they are shown to be crying in sorrow at having to slash the budget of social entities such as libraries and medicare. Option A is partly correct but does not fully describe the cartoonist's use of pigs as a symbol in the illustration. Option C describes the correct definition of the techqniue anthropmorphism but inaccurately describes the intention and effect. Option D is incorrect as this answer details a poor description of anaology and inaccurate description of the cartoonist's intent.

answers.description: Symbolic; overweight pigs are used to symbolise the greed and insatiable nature of corporate entities

Dichotomous; the gluttonous notoriety of pigs is used to depict corporation, media and the military budget whilst the vulnerable view of pigs is used to depict their apparent sorrow at slashing the budget
Anthropomorphic; depicting pig with human-like characteristics and capacilities (e.g. emotion and speech) creates a sense of authenticity and builds rapport between the reader and character(s)
Analogical; a comparison between pigs, corporate greed and society, for the purpose of clarifying the tone of injustice and empathy

child_mcqs.description: The overall tone of the cartoon with regard to social spending cuts is
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. The cartoonist intends to depict the corporate "pigs" as making fun of social spending cuts in a cruel and inhumane way; mocking such cuts. Whilst this may be a realistic depiction of social spending in any one country, the depiction of corporations does not tend to this conclusion (thus Option A is incorrect). Option B is incorrect - the cartoonist does not seek the worst opinion of social spending. Also, the cartoonist does not view social spending cuts as odd or strange or whimsical (thus Option D is incorrect).

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
- Lien and Schultz, Interpreting Signs of Female Genital Mutilation Within a Risky Legal Framework

In Norway, all forms of genital mutilation of girls and women are punishable pursuant to section 1 of the Act of 1996 relating to female genital mutilation. The penal provisions encompass all those who perform genital mutilation, including health personnel. However, the girl or the woman involved (the victim) will not be liable to punishment, as it is not illegal to be circumcised. In 2004 the FGM law was strengthened with a duty to avert. By establishing a punishment of up to one year in prison or a fine, the duty to avert is meant to motivate professionals to act on their suspicions of an imminent FGM procedure. The law thereby provides additional pressure by instigating fear in the minds of the personnel if they do not try to avert FGM, thereby making them accountable.

The background documents proposing the implementation of a duty to avert FGM make references to national security and its military secrets. In that context people can be punished if they are aware of dangers and do nothing to avert them. The duty to avert FGM seeks to predict a crime that has not yet taken place and to prevent it from happening. It is forward-looking and relies on a person’s subjective guesses about an incident that may occur in the future. The duty to avert is activated whenever someone believes that it is more likely that a girl will be genitally mutilated than that she will not. This applies irrespective of the type of FGM and the scope of the operation. There is no requirement for positive evidence of a planned act of genital mutilation. The knowledge requirement for the duty to avert (‘more likely’) indicates a higher threshold than the knowledge requirement for an existing duty to report child abuse (‘reason to believe’, ‘justified concern’). As stated in the government’s information circular, ‘[t]he threshold for the duty to avert should, however, not be placed so high as to undermine the intention of the Act, which is to prevent FGM from taking place.’

To satisfy the duty to avert, a report of concern should be given either to the Child Welfare Services or to the Police who would then examine the case. It is not recommended that professionals try to avert FGM by investigating and acting on their own accord; rather, they are advised to refer the case to the Child Welfare Services. It is not regarded a crime to be genitally mutilated if the procedure is done before moving to Norway. If a girl has younger sisters at risk of FGM, her case could be reported in order to prevent them from being mutilated, otherwise the duty of confidentiality will apply. If a girl suffers from health consequences due to FGM and is not given proper help and care by her parents, her case could be reported to the Child Welfare Services as child abuse. While the intention behind the duty to avert is commendable, it has introduced something new in the operation of the welfare services: threats of punishments for employees for not acting on their subjective guesses about the risk of a potential future crime. This law has not been openly discussed in the media or among experts, and was passed without much public discussion.

child_mcqs.description: The aim of the 2004 change to the FGM law was to
child_mcqs.explanation: Health practitioners were punishable for performing FGM before the 2004 law, so that B is incorrect. The addition of the duty to avert was intended to ‘motivate professionals to act on their suspicions of an imminent FGM procedure’. Hence, it was aimed at having health professionals act on their suspicions, rather than increasing suspicion in health professionals. There is a possibility that the law could impact on doctor’s views of FGM, but given that lawmakers had already made it illegal it is likely that they assumed most practitioners already had negative opinions of FGM.

answers.description: Influence health practitioners’ views on the morality of FGM

child_mcqs.description: If a girl presents to a General Practitioner having already undergone FGM, he or she should report the FGM
child_mcqs.explanation: The primary purpose of the legislative change is to impose a ‘duty to avert’. Hence, from this alone D is the most likely answer. A is incorrect as a girl who has undergone FGM outside of Norway should not be reported unless an exception arises. B is incorrect as there are situations when a girl who has undergone FGM outside Norway could still be reported, such as if she has younger sisters. C is incorrect as patient confidentiality can be broken in situations where there is a risk of harm to younger sisters. Hence, D is the correct answer.

answers.description: Only if the FGM occurred inside Norway
Provided that he or she can maintain patient confidentiality
Where there is a risk to others of FGM

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is a component of the health practitioner’s duty to report?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer A is a component of the duty as it is explained that 'the duty to avert is activated whenever someone believes that it is more likely that a girl will be genitally mutilated than that she will not'. Answer B is not a component as, although patient confidentiality should be maintained where possible, it is a factor that may be overriden to report FGM. Answer C is not a component, as the law is about professional's acting on their suspicions, not on requiring them to investigate each patient. Answer D is incorrect as the article provides that there is 'no requirement for positive evidence of a planned act of genital mutilation'.

answers.description: A belief that FGM is more likely than not
Questioning patients to uncover the likelihood of FGM
Providing positive evidence of the future FGM

child_mcqs.description: The major concern that the author has with the 2004 change to the law is the?
child_mcqs.explanation: The line beginning ‘while the intention behind the duty to avert...’ demonstrates that the author does have concerns with the law. This line reveals that this is due to the placing of threats of punishment for failure to reporting their ‘subjective guesses’. Clearly, the author is concerned that health practitioners will be placed in a position where they are unsure whether to report, but will face legal ramifications should they make the incorrect decision. Hence, the most likely answer is D. The article says nothing of the capabilities of the police or CWS. It is also does not discuss the capabilities of health practitioners to prevent FGM, instread talking only of their responsibilities. Similarly, the effects of the law on present victims of FGM is not discussed.

answers.description: Potential stress to victims of FGM caused by having their experiences recorded
Inability of health practitioners to sufficiently prevent the occurrence of FGM
Inability of the Police and Child Welfare Services (CWS) to prevent FGM following health practitioner reporting
Potential stress to health practitioners caused by the legal ramifications of reporting

child_mcqs.description: If a health practitioner has a suspicion that one child is being abused, and has the same level of suspicion that a second child is at risk of FGM:
child_mcqs.explanation: The second paragraph provides that the knowledge requirement for FGM is higher than the knowledge requirement for child abuse. This means that if a level of suspicion is high enough to warrant reporting FGM, it must also be high enough to warrant reporting of child abuse. The reverse is not necessarily the case. Hence, B is the correct answer. The article says nothing about a health practitioner escaping liability for misinterpreting the law.

answers.description: The health practitioner should report both the child abuse and the risk of FGM
If the level of suspicion is such to justify reporting the FGM, the doctor must also report the child abuse
If the level of suspicion is such to justify reporting the child abuse, the doctor must also report the FGM
The duty to report is dependent upon the health practitioner’s interpretation of the law

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
- The following is an extract from the article 'The path to Australia's tobacco warnings', by Ron Borland and David Hill

To be effective, health warnings need to be noticed, persuasive and provide guidance for appropriate action. To be noticed, health warnings need to stand out from the surrounding pack design and they need to be large enough to be read easily. To be persuasive, the warnings need to be understood, believed and judged to be personally relevant by the reader. It follows that having warnings about a broad range of the ill-effects of smoking increases the chance that people reading those warnings will find at least one ill-effect to which they relate. Finally, the effectiveness of any call to action is enhanced by specific instructions about the first step to take.

Given that tobacco smoking is habitual and addictive, it was considered most improbable that smoking behaviour could easily be "switched off' by manipulations of package warnings or contents information. However, it is plausible that behavioural effects on smoking attributable to tobacco pack manipulations might be found among smokers contemplating quitting. Australian research suggests that approximately 9% of smokers are taking action to quit at any time, and over a year more than 40% make quit attempts.

The second and even more important group who could be influenced by manipulations of health warning information and contents labelling on packages are those people who are tempted to try smoking, are experimenting with it, or are contemplating taking it up. Early adolescence is the developmental stage at which most experimental smoking begins and later adolescence and early adulthood is when most of the shift to daily consumption takes place.

The research programme that resulted in the CBRC (1992) report was designed to show that the existing health warnings and product labelling requirements were inadequate, and to explore some alternatives that might increase their salience and potential effectiveness. The aim was to achieve maximal effectiveness within the bounds of what was likely to be acceptable to the community at that time.

child_mcqs.description: Having a respected health professional endorse a health warning is predominantly an example of an advertisement’s?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article explains that persuasiveness refers to the ability of advertising to be ‘understood, believed and judged to be personally relevant by the reader'. If the health warning is presented by a health professional, it is more likely that the consumer will believe the warning. Therefore, B is the correct answer. This could subsequently affect the effectiveness, but it is not the most correct answer

child_mcqs.description: What is a limitation on the effectiveness of anti-tobacco advertising that is mentioned in the passage?
child_mcqs.explanation: The final line states that ‘the aim was to achieve maximal effectiveness within the bounds of what was likely to be acceptable to the community at that time’. This implies that a limitation on effective advertising is what the community believes to be socially acceptable. High cost and pro-tobacco advertising are not mentioned. Undoing the habitual nature of smoking is a desired outcome of the advertising, and not a limitation on its effectiveness. Therefore, the answer is D

child_mcqs.description: A campaign attempting to stop infrequent smokers becoming habitual smokers is likely to primarily target which group?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article states that ‘later adolescence and early adulthood is when most of the shift to daily consumption takes place’. Campaigns aimed at stopping infrequent smokers becoming habitual smokers are therefore likely to target this age group, and C is correct

answers.description: Adult smokers with at least one quit attempt in the past year
Adult smokers susceptible to behavioural modification

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
July Man
By Margaret Avison

Old, rain-wrinkled, time-soiled, city-wise, morning man
whose weeping is for the dust of the elm-flowers
and the hurting motes of time,
rotted with rotting grape,
sweet with the fumes,
puzzled for good by fermented potato peel out of the vat of the times,
turned out and left
in this grass-patch, this city-gardener’s place
under the buzzing populace’s
square shadows, and the green shadows
of elm and ginkgo and lime
(planted for Sunday strollers and summer evening
families, and for those
bird-cranks with bread-crumbs
and crumpled umbrellas who come
while the dew is wet on the park, and beauty
is fan-tailed, grey and dove grey, aslant, folding in
from the white fury of day).

In the sound of the fountain
you rest, at the cinder-rim, on your bench.

The rushing river of cars
makes you a stillness, a pivot, a heart-stopping
blurt, in the sorrow
of the last rubbydub swig, the searing, and
stone-jar solitude lost, and yet,
and still – wonder (for good now) and
trembling:

    The too much none of us knows
    is weight, sudden sunlight, falling
    on your hands and arms, in your lap,
    all, all, in time.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is best supported by the poem?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect – although the focal persona, an “old man”, does not interact directly with any other people within the poem, it cannot be accurately assumed that he actively recoils from interacting socially with others. As the narrator explicitly refers to the old man persona as “you” (“you rest, at the cinder-rim”), a separate entity, Answer 3 is precluded. Answer 4 is incorrect – the narrator states the striking descriptions of nature seen within the first stanza (“grass-patch”/ “green shadows”/ “white fury of day”) are stated by the narrator, and as such the unique interpretation of nature displayed cannot be attributed to the focal persona. Indeed, throughout the poem, the reader remains unaware of the old man’s thoughts, as this perspective is not provided. Therefore, Answer 1 is most correct. Within the poem, the persona’s “stillness” is juxtaposed against the “rushing” of a “buzzing populace”. More so, the focal persona is shown grieving for the “dust of elm-flowers”, and “motes of time” – such attention to miniscule elements suggests a warped perspective. Most markedly, sunlight “falls” onto the persona’s “hands and feet” – the use of such a verb to describe the usually undetectable speed of light most likely implies that time passes slower for the focal persona.

answers.description: To the focal persona, time seems to pass slower.
The focal persona recoils from social interaction.
The focal persona views nature in a unique way.

child_mcqs.description: Within the poem, the focal persona depicted can best be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as although the main persona could be described as a destitute geriatric (“old, time-soiled man”) it cannot be accurately stated that the scenery depicted somehow fragments his existence. The statement of enrichment is not supported (“weeping”/ “hurting”), nor is it suggested that the scenery around him has developed. Answer 3 is also incorrect – although allusions are made to homelessness (“rain-wrinkled, time-soiled”), the persona does not embody parsimony, or frugality, in any sense. Answer 4 is incorrect – although the focal persona is depicted only within a park (“you rest…on your bench” /”city-gardener’s place”), this does not suggest a predilection for natural environments. Therefore, Answer 1 is correct. The inebriated persona (“potato peel…vat”/ “rubbydub swig”) is shown to observe mundane and superfluous aspects of the park landscape around him (“weeping is for the dust of the elm-flowers”/ “rotted with rotting grape”). However, as the old man “rests” in front of the park “fountain”, he is suddenly overcome by the axiomatic “too much none of us knows”. “Trembling” under the “weight” of this newfound cognizance and worldly understanding, the narrator remarks how the focal persona now resembles a “pivot”, around which the “river” of movement and people “rush” by.

answers.description: An inebriated observer of the mundane who is beset by the growing awareness of his worldly significance.
An aged wanderer whose simplistic existence is both fragmented and complicated by the developing scenery around him.
The physical embodiment of desolation and parsimony within an increasingly modernized society.
A destitute geriatric who exhibits a strange predilection for natural environments in a city surrounded by manmade construction.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following quotes aligns best with the poem?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 3 is incorrect, as although the focal persona is an “old, rain-wrinkled man”, this does not mean that the central message is one about age and youthfulness. Answer 2 is incorrect - the central persona remains quite inconspicuous throughout the poem, (“you rest, at the cinder-rim”/ “The rushing river of cars makes you a stillness”), therefore as conspicuousness revealing wonder is not demonstrated, this quote is not applicable. Answer 1, although pertinent, is not the best option. It is clear that a natural environment is the primary backdrop within this poem (“city-gardener’s place”/ “elm and ginkgo and lime”). However, the statement that nature is only silent to the inattentive is an assumption that is not supported by the text. The “Sunday strollers” are shown to appreciate the nature surrounding them (“for those bird-cranks with bread-crumbs”/ “beauty is fan-tailed, grey”), although not to the microscopic extent the “old man” demonstrates. As both parties are attentive to nature, the poem does not demonstrate the quote stated in Answer 1. Therefore, Answer 4 is most correct, as this quote aligns best with the contents of the poem. The focal persona finds himself being the “pivot” around which the “river” of people rushes. He finds himself empathising with those aspects of nature that are “turned out and left”; in doing so, he finds significance in his prosaic, or existence.

answers.description: “Nature is only silent to an inattentive ear; listen closely and you will hear its grandeur.”
“Only when you adopt a veil of conspicuousness, do you see the wonder.”
“Age is but a number; you are as young as you feel.”
“In the rush of life, pausing for a moment can reveal your prosaic significance.”

stem_mcq.title: Unit 21
stem_mcq.description: The different behaviours of 25 whales were observed and classified by age and sex. The graph below (Figure 1) shows the relationship between gender and age with whale behaviour.

child_mcqs.description: On average, which age group dives for the longest period of time?
child_mcqs.explanation: The graph illustrates that within the sample, the average dive time for old female whales is the greatest, at approximately 46 seconds. Although the error bars show a comparatively large range of dive times for old female whales, on average, their dive time is the greatest.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 1 is incorrect, as although there is a male majority within this sample of 25 whales, it cannot be assumed that this proportion accurately represents the general whale population. Answer 2 is incorrect, as this assumption is not supported by the graph - the error bars for young male and female whales indicate that their respective dives times range from approximately 38 to 42 seconds. Answer 4 is incorrect as any correlation between age and speed cannot be made solely based on the information contained within the figure. Therefore, Answer 3 is most correct. Within the sample, for both genders, the average dive time is greater for older whales.

answers.description: Within the general whale population, there are more males than females.
All young male whales dive for longer than young female whales.
Within the sample, the older whales dive for longer than their younger counterparts.
Within the sample, the older whales are, the slower their speed.

child_mcqs.description: What is the difference between the average speed of all male and all female killer whales?
child_mcqs.explanation: Within the graph, the average speed of all male whales is approximately 6.2 km/h. The average speed of all female whales is approximately 4.8 km/h. Therefore the difference between these average speeds is approximately 1.5km/h. Answer 1 is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 22
stem_mcq.description:
Excerpt from Disgrace by J.M. Coetzee (Chapter 7, pg. 64-65)

Supper is simple: soup and bread, then sweet potatoes. Usually he does not like sweet potatoes, but Lucy does something with lemon peel and butter and allspice that makes them palatable, more than palatable. 
    “Will you be staying a while?”
    “A week? Shall we say a week? Will you be able to bear me that long?”
    “You can stay as long as you like. I’m just afraid you’ll get bored.”
    “I won’t be bored.”
    “And after the week where will you go?”
    “I don’t know yet. Perhaps I’ll just go on a ramble, a long ramble.”
    “Well, you’re welcome to stay.”
    “It’s nice of you to say so, my dear, but I’d like to keep your friendship. Long visits don’t make for good friends.”
    “What is we don’t call it a visit? What if we call it refuge? Would you accept refuge on an indefinite basis?”
    “You mean asylum? I’m not as bad as that, Lucy. I’m not a fugitive.”
    “Roz said the atmosphere was nasty.”
    “I brought it on myself. I was offered a compromise, which I wouldn’t accept.”
    “What kind of compromise?”
    “Re-education. Reformation of character. The code-word was counselling.”
    “And are you so perfect that you can’t do with a little counselling?”
    “It reminded me too much of Mao’s China. Recantation, self-criticism, public apology. I’m old-fashioned. I would prefer simply to be put against a wall and shot. Have done with it.”
    “Shot? For having an affair with a student? A bit extreme, don’t you think David? It must go on all the time. It certainly went on when I was a student. If they prosecuted every case the profession would be decimated.”
He shrugs. “These are puritanical times. Private life is public business. Prurience is respectable, prurience and sentiment. They wanted a spectacle: breast-beating, remorse, tears if possible. A TV show in fact. I wouldn’t oblige.” He was going to add, the truth is they wanted me castrated, but he cannot say the words, not to his daughter. In fact now he hears it through another’s ears, his whole tirade sounds melodramatic, excessive. 
    “So you stood your ground and they stood theirs. Is that how it was?”
    “More or less.”
    “You shouldn’t be so unbending, David. It isn’t heroic to be unbending. Is there still time to reconsider?”
    “No, the sentence is final.”
    “No appeal?”
    “No appeal. I am not complaining. One can’t plead guilty to charges of turpitude and expect a flood of sympathy in return. Not after a certain age. After a certain age one is simply no longer appealing, and that’s that. One just has to buckle down and live out the rest of one’s life. Serve one’s time. 
    “Well that’s a pity. Stay here as long as you like. On whatever grounds.”

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is most accurate?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as within the extract, it is clear David does not accept counselling as a “slightly unfair compromise”, given that he explicitly states he would rather be “put against a wall and shot”. Answer 3 is also incorrect, as although David identifies his age as a factor contributing to his sentence, the assumption that this is the most important factor is erroneous given he also mentions his “prurience” and refusal to “public[ly] apolog[ise]” in a similar manner.  Answer 4 is also incorrect. Although David states that he believes “long visits don’t make for good friends”, there is no information within the extract to suggest that after discussing his sentencing, his relationship with Lucy has somehow changed. Therefore, Answer 1 is correct. Throughout the extract, it is evident that David does not acknowledge the severity of his crime (“having an affair with a student”). He insinuates that his sentence does not reflect the need for punishment, but the tribunals need for a public spectacle (“they wanted a spectacle: breast-beating”/ “I wouldn’t oblige”).

answers.description: David does not acknowledge the severity of his crime.
David feels that accepting counselling constitutes a slightly unfair compromise.
David believes that age is the most important factor contributing to his sentence.
David believes that his relationship with Lucy has changed after discussing his sentence and crime.

child_mcqs.description: David could best be described as
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 of remorseful is incorrect, as David displays no semblance of remorse during his interaction with Lucy. Answer 3 of audacious is not the best descriptor of David, given he displays no reckless or bold behaviour within the extract. Similarly, despite his sentencing and surrounding circumstance, David does not outwardly show any melancholic sentiments (“One just has to buckle down”). Therefore, the most appropriate option is Answer 1 – as described by Lucy, the actions of David can best be described as obstinate, or “unbending”. He chooses to “stand his ground” by opting out of making a “public apology” and refusing to  “reform [his] character”.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 23
stem_mcq.description:
- the following is an extract from Spring Break, an article written by David Kennedy

In a way, edging towards Punta Rieles, we were just actors playing parts in a tale made familiar by hundreds of childhood fantasies. Like knights-errant setting forth from their domain in search of adventure, we were grounded in fealty to out sponsoring institutions and bounded by the oaths of our professional service. We hope that, like knights abroad, we would band together warmly in a foreign territory, our friendships tested and forged. But, in another way, we were more than just actors in a familiar cultural drama. Whether in remaking our institutional sponsorship, redefining our professional roles, or developing our team spirit, we were also narrators and directors, creating our roles and casting others as we wished in a production staged against the backdrop of Ana’s imprisonment.

There seem few human rights activists without sponsors. Activism is, in this sense, a representational activity. But not every potential institutional patrol is anxious to send would-be activists charging into battle. The scramble for the credentials of patronage and the processes by which institutions come to sponsor activists mean that action, even when guided by the activist’s intuition or inspired by his faith, refers back to the institution’s motive and forward to its goal. In this sense, the activist merely implements.

Transforming Pat, Richard, and me from Writer in Washington, Doctor in New York, and Lawyer in Boston to writer-doctor-lawyer in Montevideo required imagination on the part of our sponsoring institutions, which initially regarded sending missions to Montevideo as somewhat outside their normal portfolio. Their long standing concern for the plight of foreign colleagues needed to be translated into an ‘interest’ in four specific Uruguayan medical students and a willingness to send three activists on their trail. Our institutions were somewhat uncomfortable becoming involved in human rights work for several reasons. Scientific institutions often resist engaging in human rights work because they fear it would diminish their scientific neutrality – ironically the very neutrality which might enable and legitimise their human rights work. Often they resist this work because they fear they have little to offer – it seems counterintuitive, if not a little perverse, to think of political surveillance and imprisonment as threats to the confidentiality of the doctor-patient relationship, of systematic torture as a deterioration in the public health system. Moreover, in my experience, scientists and professionals in institutions normally removed from politics sometimes seem to fear that they will appear naïve and out of place in the hurly-burly of human rights work.

Overcoming these doubts was not simply the triumph of action over the passive habits of professional fuddy-duddies, however attractive that image might be. These doubts were overcome primarily by relying on the well-worn norms of professional responsibility and human rights ideology. As a result, we moved to action by thinking about Ana and her compatriots as fellow professionals and objects for our moral outrage. My own employer, the Harvard Law School, has moved over the past few years toward a public commitment to ‘international human rights’ which facilitated my own involvement in the Uruguayan mission considerably. This commitment is a bit difficult to explain, particularly given our widespread sense that any institutional participation in advocacy threatens the academic freedom, which gives the faculty faith in its prerogatives. In part, I suppose, foreign advocacy seems a neutral defence of the ‘rule of law’ rather than a partisan choosing of sides. As a result, we tend, oddly enough, to use the rubric of ‘human rights’ to refer to everything from foreign investment to cultural revolution. Partly, international human rights work seems to promise safety distanced contact with the certifiably barbaric. Partly, this work seems the modern extension of an institutional commitment to civil rights responsibility.

child_mcqs.description: How does the author differentiate the quest of human rights activists from those of actors in childhood fantasies and cultural dramas?
child_mcqs.explanation: In the first paragraph, the author draws similarities between activists and actors in childhood fantasies. However, the author then explains the author explains that activists are 'more than this'. He continues by stating that they are also ‘narrators and directors, creating our roles and casting others as we wished’. Therefore, B is the correct answer, as activists have control over their character's journey, unlike actors

answers.description: Actors in childhood fantasies do not arise from sponsoring institutions
Actors in childhood fantasies have no control over their character’s story
Human rights activists are incapable of uniting under a common banner
Human rights activists undertake quests more complex and intellectually challenging

child_mcqs.description: Why does the author argue that activism is a representational activity?
child_mcqs.explanation: The second paragraph discusses the link between activists and their sponsors. The activists are representatives of their sponsors, as the author states that their work ‘refers back to the institution’s motive and forward to its goal. In this sense, the activist merely implements’. Therefore, A is the correct answer

answers.description: The activist acts on behalf of their sponsoring institution
The activist embodies a wider community desire for change
The activist is a symbol of justice and virtue
The activist may undertake missions outside of their field of expertise

child_mcqs.description: What is NOT an observation made by the author regarding the involvement of scientific institutions in human rights work?
child_mcqs.explanation: The third paragraph states that ‘scientific institutions often resist engaging in human rights work because they fear it would diminish their scientific neutrality’. Therefore, B is true. It also states that scientific institutions ‘fear they have little to offer’, explaining the lack of relationship to the patient-doctor relationship and public health system. Therefore, A is true. Finally, the paragraph states that ‘scientists and professionals in institutions normally removed from politics sometimes seem to fear that they will appear naïve and out of place in the hurly-burly of human rights work’. Therefore, D is true. As such, C is the correct answer.

answers.description: Human rights work may fall outside of the characteristic realm of scientific study
Scientific involvement in human rights may provoke accusations of bias
Scientific institutions do not have sufficient resources to undertake human rights work
Representatives of scientific institutions are inexperienced in the human rights setting

child_mcqs.description: How does the author suggest that the Harvard Law School overcame the potential threat to its academic freedom caused by its participation in advocacy?
child_mcqs.explanation: The threat to academic freedom likely arises by the partisan taking of sides that may be associated with advocating for the Montevideo medical students, the idea being that if they support the medical students then the academia will not present an unbiased view nor allow their authors to provide articles disparaging the students. The author resolves this dilemma by arguing that ‘foreign advocacy seems a neutral defence of the ‘rule of law’ rather than a partisan choosing of sides’. As such, they are characterising their advocacy as supporting the law, rather than supporting the medical students, preventing the potential loss of academic freedom. Therefore, B is correct

answers.description: Realigning its prerogatives to fit within its new mission
Characterising its involvement as merely upholding the rule of law, rather than protecting a particular group
Making public its commitment to ‘international human rights'
Maintaining the distance of its employees from the ‘certifiably barbaric’

stem_mcq.title: Unit 24
stem_mcq.description:
Read the extract below, and answer the following questions.

Joanna Bourke says that the notion of pain as correctional punishment, or penance, only really began to change with advances in science and insight in the 19th century. Pain, in that age, she argues, became less about spiritual purification and began to be seen in adversarial terms.

‘In those circumstances, pain is not something that you accept passively or submit to, or even actually embrace,’ says Bourke. ‘Pain becomes something very different; it becomes something you have to fight. You don the armour and fight with all your might.’

By the mid 19th century, physicians began to acknowledge pain as an evolutionary mechanism. It was a sign that something was wrong in the body. Diagnosis suddenly involved asking questions of the patient about their suffering and trying to get them to personally pinpoint the areas of their body experiencing discomfort.

That sense of the necessity of a patient’s involvement in diagnosis was short lived, however. Chemical and neurological testing in the 20th century once again revolutionised the diagnostic technique.

The language of pain then became less important, argues Bourke: ‘What was important for the doctor was simply to get the tests done and they were the tests that showed what was wrong with the person. As opposed to stories of pain; as opposed to hearing the patient tell the story of her suffering.’

We all feel pain. Yet in society as a whole, pain is not a sensation that many of us like to discuss. Writers can venture forth freely about love, but pain is not a subject for polite discussion, and unless it’s bound in ropes and leather, it’s rarely a subject of literary interest.

As the novelist Virginia Woolf once wrote: 'To hinder the description of illness in literature, there is the poverty of the language. English, which can express the thoughts of Hamlet and the tragedy of Lear, has no words for the shiver and the headache. It has all grown one way. The merest schoolgirl, when she falls in love, has Shakespeare or Keats to speak her mind for her; but let a sufferer try to describe a pain in his head to a doctor and language at once runs dry.'

‘It’s difficult to talk about any powerful sensation,’ says Bourke, suggesting that our reluctance to discuss pain is in part an unwillingness to cause further discomfort.

‘Pain is particularly difficult. Talking about pain does have a risk of inflicting pain,’ she says. ‘A lot of people who suffer extreme pain, even chronic pain, tell me that in talking about it to their friends and loved ones, they actually end up inflicting pain on those loved ones. So they prefer to remain silent.’

In researching the history of pain over the past 300 years, Bourke says what perhaps struck her most was the willingness of many in the medical profession to diminish the suffering of people based on sex and race. Many doctors, she suggests, continued to believe until relatively recently that certain groups within society had diminished capacity for pain; in some cases, that they were incapable of feeling suffering at all.

‘There were all these arguments that African Americans, that ethnic minorities, that native Australians did not truly feel pain. Of course this is very convenient because it enabled others to treat these people in really appalling ways, but these arguments were really deeply entrenched within British, American, Australian and New Zealand society. Of course they were arguments that meant that you didn’t need to treat certain peoples with respect and you also didn’t need to give them sufficient analgesics.’

‘One of the really shocking things I discovered was that well into the 20th century, African Americans in American hospitals were not given anaesthetics even when they had major operations—limb amputations, for example—on the understanding, on the belief, that they didn’t truly suffer.’

‘I think one of the other really interesting things is that if a minority group or a woman—because women were also one of these categories—complained of pain, then they were simply being “hysterical” and therefore they didn’t need to be given analgesics or anaesthetics. If they did not complain, then they were simply insensitive to pain and therefore they didn’t need to be given analgesics or anaesthetics either.’

‘So it really was a catch-22 situation for these groups.’

From "The History of Pain", Antony Funnell, 22 July, 2014 http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/sundayextra/the-history-of-pain/5614136

child_mcqs.description:
According to Joanna Bourke, which of the following statements is true about pain prior to 1800?

  1. Pain was thought of as correctional punishment.
  2. Pain was seen in adversarial terms.
  3. Pain was acknowledged as an evolutionary mechanism.
  4. Those in the medical profession were willing to diminish the suffering of people based on their sex and race.
child_mcqs.explanation: At the beginning of the passage, Bourke distinguishes between 19th century (1800-1900) society, which viewed pain as something “to be seen in adversarial terms” (that is, something to combat), and before then, where pain was more about “spiritual purification.” The second sentence states that pain, “in that age” (the 19th century) “began to be seen in adversarial terms. Therefore I is correct and II is incorrect. III is incorrect because the acknowledgement of pain as an evolutionary mechanism is described as occurring in the mid 19th century. IV is correct because the passage states, “In researching the history of pain over the past 300 years, Bourke says what perhaps struck her most was the willingness of many in the medical profession to diminish the suffering of people based on sex and race. Many doctors, she suggests, continued to believe until relatively recently that certain groups within society had diminished capacity for pain” suggesting that there was a longstanding belief that certain groups did not feel pain “until relatively recently.” This suggests that prior to the 19th century (and probably later), those in the medical profession were willing to diminish the suffering of people based on their sex and race.

child_mcqs.description: What is the best summary of the quote by Virginia Woolf?
child_mcqs.explanation: A) is true, according to Bourke, but it is not stated in the Woolf quote. B) is not the best summary, because Woolf is concerned with the linguistic expression of pain, in general, rather than schoolgirls’ understanding of it. As for D), Woolf is remarking on the shortage of descriptions of pain in literature, but the focus of her quote is on the reason for it: that there is a “poverty of the language” when it comes to the “shiver and the headache” even though English lends itself to describing the feelings of love. Therefore C) is the best answer.

answers.description: Society is willing to diminish the suffering of people based on their sex and race.
Schoolgirls can understand Hamlet and Lear, but not the shiver or the headache.
It is difficult for English speakers to use language to describe physical pain.
There is not much description of pain in literature.

child_mcqs.description:
According to this article, why were certain groups of people denied treatment for their pain into the twentieth century?

  1. They did not complain of pain.
  2. There were different cultures.
  3. There are barriers in the English language to expressing and describing pain.
  4. It was believed that people in certain categories did not feel pain.
  5. When women complained about their pain, their complaints were dismissed as “hysterical”.
child_mcqs.explanation: Option I is incorrect, as Bourke describes how women, when they complained of pain, were dismissed as hysterical. II does not adequately answer the question, and the extract does not discuss cultural differences. III is discussed in the passage but, it is not used as a reason for why certain groups of people were denied treatment of their pain. IV is true, see for instance, “Many doctors, she suggests, continued to believe until relatively recently that certain groups within society had diminished capacity for pain; in some cases, that they were incapable of feeling suffering at all.” V is also true, but it doesn’t quite answer the question, women being only one of several groups of people who were denied adequate treatment for their pain. Therefore D is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 25
stem_mcq.description:
Excerpt from Fathers and Sons by Ivan Turgenev (Chapter 5, pg. 22-23)

    “Well, Arkady?”, said he. “Where is your new friend?”
    “Out somewhere. He seldom misses going for an early morning walk. But the great thing is to take no notice of him, for he deters all ceremony. “
    “So I have perceived.” And with his usual deliberateness Paul Petrovitch began to butter a piece of bread. “Will he be staying here very long?”
    “Well, as long as he may care to stay. As a matter of fact, he is going on to his father’s place.”
    “And where does his father live?”
    “Some eighty versts from here, in the same province as ourselves. I believe he has a small property, and used to be an army doctor.”
    “H’m! Ever since last night I have been asking myself where I can have heard the name before. Nikolai, do you remember whether there was a doctor of that name in our father’s division?”
    “Yes, there used to be.”
    “Then that doctor will be this fellow’s father. H’m!” And Paul Petrovitch twitched his moustache. “What exactly is your Bazarov?” he inquired of Arkady. 
    “What is he?” Arkady repeated smiling. “Do you really want me to tell you what he is, Uncle?”
    “If you please, my nephew.”
    “He is a Nihilist.”
    “A what?”” exclaimed Nikolai, while even Paul Petrovitch paused in the act of raising a knife to the edge of which there was a morsel of butter adhering. 
    “A Nihilist,” repeated Arkady. 
    “A Nihilist?” queried Nikolai. “I imagine that must be a term derived from the Latin nihil or “nothing”. It denotes, I presume, a man who – a man who – well, a man who declines to accept anything.”
    “Or a man who declines to respect anything,” hazarded Paul Petrovitch as he re-applied himself to the butter. 
    “No, a man who treats things solely from the critical point of view,” corrected Arkady. 
    “But the two things are one and the same, are they not?” queried Nikolai. 
    “Oh no. A Nihilist is a man who declines to bow to authority, or accept any principles on trust, however sanctified it may be.”
    “And to what can that lead?” asked Paul Petrovitch. 
    “It depends on the individual. In one man’s case, it may lead to good; in that of another, to evil.”
    “I see. But we elders view things differently. We folk of the older generation believe that without principles – without principles, it is impossible to take a single step in life, or to draw a single breath. Mais vous avez change tout cela.^ God send you health and a General’s rank,  Messieurs Nihil – how do you pronounce it?”
    “Ni-hil-ists,” said Arkady distinctly.
    “Quite so - God send you health and a General’s rank, but also let us see how you will contrive to exist in an absolute void, an airless vacuum. Pray ring the bell, brother Nikolai, for it is time for me to take my cocoa.”

-
Silence reigned on the terrace. For a while Paul Petrovitch drank his cocoa. Then he suddenly raised his head and muttered:
    “Monsieur Nihilist is about to give us the pleasure of his company.”
True enough, Bazarov could be seen stepping across the flowerbeds. On his linen jacket and trousers was a thick coating of mud, to the crown of his ancient circular hat clung a piece of sticky marshweed, and in his hand he was holding a small bag. Also, something in the bag was stirring as though it were alive. Approaching the terrace with rapid strides, he nodded to the company and said:
    “Good morning, gentlemen! Pardon me for being so late. I shall be back presently, but first my captures must be stowed away.”
    “What are those captures?” Paul Petrovitch enquired. “Leeches?”
    “No, frogs.”
    “Do you eat them? Or do you breed them?”
    “I catch them for the purpose of experiment,” was Bazarov’s only reply as he carelessly entered the house.
    “In other words, he vivisects them,” was Paul Petrovitch’s comment.     “In other words, he believes in frogs more than principles.”
Arkady threw his uncle a reproachful look, and even Nikolai shrugged his shoulders, so that Paul Petrovitch himself felt his bon mot* to be out of place, and hastened to divert the subject to the estate and the new steward. 

^But you have changed all that. 
*Witty reply

child_mcqs.description: “We folk of the older generation” refers to
child_mcqs.explanation: Given the pronoun “we”, it can be assumed that Paul Petrovitch considers himself part of the “older generation”. Similarly, after Arkady declares Bazarov a Nihilist, Nikolai’s exclamation of “A what?” suggests that he is part of “the older generation”. Nikolai’s opposition to Arkady’s definition of Nihilism also evidences this (““But the two things are one and the same, are they not?” queried Nikolai.”). As there is little information about Bazarov’s father within the excerpt, it cannot be assumed that he is part of the “older generation” still that believes in “principles”. Therefore, Answer 2 is correct.

child_mcqs.description: Why does Paul Petrovitch refer to Arkady and Bazarov as “Messieurs Nihil”?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as although Paul believes Nihilism to be an absurd doctrine, by stating this line he is not suggesting that Arkady and Bazarov are of lesser intellect. Within his earlier debate with Arkady, Paul’s tone and language does not belittle his conversation partner (“Mais vous avez change tout cela.”) – this makes Answer 2 unlikely. Answer 3 is incorrect as there is no evidence implying that Paul uses this French title out of necessity. Similarly, Answer 4 is unlikely given that the line (“Messieurs Nihil”) requires only rudimentary French. Therefore, Answer 1 is the most correct option. Paul perceives Bazarov’s and Arkady’s outright rejection of “principles” and the “old” way of thinking as a sign of supposed superiority, haughtiness and self-righteousness. Pauls condescending tone when he quips also evidence this - “ Monsieur Nihilist is about to give us the pleasure of his company”.

answers.description: He perceives them as haughty and self-righteous.
He is implying that compared to him they are of lesser intellect.
There is no comparative phrase in his native language.
He wishes to highlight his expert command of French.

child_mcqs.description: Within this excerpt, the dominant themes are
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as although the some of the main characters are related by blood, the central conflict that dominates the plot within this excerpt does not involve this relation. Answer 3 is incorrect, as although Nihilism features within the excerpt, Fascism does not. Answer 4 is too vague. Therefore Answer 1 is correct. The debate involving Paul, Nikolai and Arkady centres on doctrine and the definition of the emerging Nihilism. It is also evident that generation change has fuelled this argument, where Paul and Nikolai belong to an older generation that believes in “principles” and “authority”.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 26
stem_mcq.description: Based on a study by Hoffman, Vohs and Baumeister (2012), this multi-dimensional graph shows the degree to which participants’ desires conflicted with their goals as a function of the strength of the desire. The horizontal and vertical axes indicate the grand means for conflict and strength within the sample. The sizes of the pie graphs indicate the relative frequency of the labelled desire; overall fourteen different desire domains were assessed, ranging from alcoholic drinks to leisure. The lighter portion of the pie graphs represents the frequency of successfully controlling a desire over the course of a week, whilst the darker portion represents self-control failure.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer 2 is incorrect, as relative to the other desires, eating did not cause “great” conflict. Answer 3 is incorrect as tobacco and alcohol were two of the weakest desires, as indicated by their low desire strengths, approximately 3.3 and 3.5 respectively. Answer 4 is incorrect. Although desire frequency, as indicated by pie graph size, was relatively similar for both coffee and work, participants desired the latter greater than the former. Their respective desire strengths, approximately 3.8 for coffee and 4.0 for work, evidence this. Therefore, Answer 1 is most correct. There is evidence to support all statements included within this option. Participants desired sleep frequently, evidenced by the comparatively large pie graph. Sleep also conflicted greatly with goals, as it possessed the second greatest conflict score of approximately 1.7. The majority of participants, over the course of the week, controlled this desire, as evidenced by the large lighter portion of the pie graph, approximately 80%.

answers.description: Participants desired sleep frequently, however as it greatly conflicted with goals, this desire was frequently controlled by participants.
Eating was a desire participants felt most frequently, however as it caused great conflict relative to other desires, it was controlled approximately 75% of the time.
Despite alcohol and tobacco being desired by many participants, the comparative rate of self-control failure is surprisingly infrequent.
Over the course of the week, despite displaying relatively similar frequencies, participants desired coffee more strongly than they wanted to work.

child_mcqs.description: In comparing media use and leisure
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer B is correct. Leisure had a greater level of desire, as it is further right on the horizontal axis. It was also much easier to control, given that the darker portion takes up a considerably smaller portion of the total pie graph. Answer A is incorrect as leisure had a greater level of desire. Answer C is incorrect as the size of both the leisure and media pies are relatively similar, and so it cannot be said that lesiure was encountered more frequently. D is incorrect as the diagram does not weigh media's higher failure to control with leisure's higher desire and level of conflict.

answers.description: Leisure had a greater level of conflict, but a smaller level of desire
Leisure had a greater level of desire, but this desire was easier to control
Leisure had a greater level of conflict and was encountered more frequently
Lesiure had a greater level of conflict, but overall had a less significant effect upon individuals reaching their goals

sections.title: Section III - Reasoning in the Biological and Physical Sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
Hydrohalogenation is the process where a hydrohalogen such as HCl, HBr etc may react electrophilically across a carbon to carbon π-bond (typically an alkene). The general process is shown below in Figure 1.

Figure 1: General process of hydrohalogenation.

 

In these reactions, the major product is the one where the halogen ends up on the most substituted carbon. This is because a carbocation intermediate forms during the reaction at the most substituted carbon. See Figure 2 for an example.

Figure 2: Regiochemistry of hydrohalogenation.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following structure pairs provided correctly identifies both the major and minor product of the below reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: B is the correct answer because the chlorine (halogen) ends up on the most substituted carbon and the hydrogen on the least substituted carbon of the alkene pair. In A the major and minor products are reversed. Options C and D are unreasonable because they involve atoms other than the alkene carbons and the HCl.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following reactions do not correctly show the major product?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer D shows the minor product because the Br group has attached to the least substituted carbon. See below for the TRUE major product, with the bromine adding at the more substituted carbon.

child_mcqs.description: If the below molecules X and Y were each treated with 1 mole eqivalent of HBr how many possible products are there? Do not consider stereochemistry in your answer.
child_mcqs.explanation:
1 mole equivalent means only 1 bond can react on each molecule. Both have 4 possible products - note that Y doesn't have 6 because it has an internal plane of symmetry, so reactions at the left and right double bonds actually generate the same product. 

Products for molecules X and Y:

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following reactions i, ii and iii correctly identify both the major and minor products?
child_mcqs.explanation: iii is the only reaction which correctly identifies the major and minor products (note the molecules are rotated). In i the major and minor products are the other way around. In ii the OH group of the minor product has moved relative to the carbon branch on the ring. Therefore iii is the only correct answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description: When fertilization occurs in humans, the cytoplasm and organelles are supplied by the ovum.  The sperm contributes only DNA.  In other phylogenetic groups different patterns of fertilisation occur.  For example, in some groups of fungi, fertilisation occurs after fungal hyphae fuse.  This allows the cytoplasm to mix and haploid nuclei to meet and fuse, producing a diploid nuclei.  This diploid nuclei can then undergo meiosis and cytokinesis to produce spores.  Due to the processes of independent assortment, random segregation and crossing over, these spores all contain different combinations of gene variations.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements concerning fertilisation in humans is false?
child_mcqs.explanation: D is correct.  A is true, as both the ovum and sperm contribute DNA to the zygote (pre-existing knowledge).  B is correct, as described in the stem.  C is correct as mitochondrial DNA is found in the mitochondria, a type of organelle (pre-existing knowledge) and organelles are supplied by the ovum (from the passage).  D is incorrect as the sperm only contributes DNA.  No organelles (including mitochondria) from the sperm enter the zygote.  So there can be no mitochondrial DNA from the sperm in the zygote.

answers.description: The mother contributes genomic DNA to the zygote.
DNA from the sperm is found in the zygote.
The mother contributes mitochondrial DNA to the zygote.
The mitochondrial DNA from the sperm are found in the zygote.

child_mcqs.description: Which of these statements is the most correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is correct.  The stem describes the cytoplasm mixing in the fusing hyphae (assumed knowledge: cytoplasm is made up of cytosol + organelles, including mitochondria).  The mitochondrial DNA is found in the mitochondria, and so mitochondrial DNA from both parents in found in the cytoplasm of the cell that produces spores.

answers.description: In fungi the mitochondria DNA may be passed down the maternal line.
In fungi the mitochondrial DNA may be passed down the paternal line.
In fungi the mitochondrial DNA may be inherited from both parents.
In fungi the mitochondrial DNA may be inherited via the haploid nuclei.

child_mcqs.description: Crossing over is part of which cellular process?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is correct.  Crossing over is the process of exchanging DNA between chromosomes in a homologous pair in order to increase genetic variation between the daughter cells.  Crossing over occurs when chromosomes line up along the equator of the cell in homologous pairs.  This occurs during Meiosis I.  During Meiosis II, there are no homologous pairs and crossing over has already occured.  In mitosis, the chromosomes do not line up in homologus pairs, as crossing over is not required.  The point of mitosis is to produce daughter cells that are identical to the parent cell.  Cytokinesis in the process of cell division.

child_mcqs.description: Which option best represents the number of chromosomes you would expect in a fungal spore?
