child_mcqs.explanation: B is correct.  The fungal spores are described as being produced by meiosis.  To answer this question correctly you must know that meiosis produces 4 haploid daughter cells from 1 diploid parent cell.  Haploid refers to cells with half the number of chromosomes (by convention represented as n) and diploid refers to cells with the full number of chromosomes, two of each (by convention represented as 2n).

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not a benefit of combining two haploid nuclei to produce a diploid nucleus prior to the production of spores in fungi?
child_mcqs.explanation: A is correct.  Haploid nuclei are produced via meiosis.  Meiosis is a process that allows increases in genetic variation in the daughter cells while halving the chromosome number.  Doubling the chromosome number every generation is not sustainable, and so this halving is an important step.

answers.description: Allows chromosome number to increase in subsequent generations, increasing genetic variation.
Allows offspring to inherit genes from two individuals, increasing genetic variation within subsequent generations.
Maintains chromosome number in offspring in subsequent generations.
Production of haploid nuclei allows crossing over to occur, increasing genetic variation between offspring in subsequent generations.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description:
The rate of a reaction is the rate of the disappearance of a reactant or appearance of a product. It is most often expressed as a function of reactant concentration. However, the rate is not always proportional to the concentrations of all reactants.

If the rate is proportional to the change in concentration of only one reactant (A) the reaction is called a first-order reaction. The rate law for such a reaction is

rate = k [A]

where k is a rate constant for the reaction. The change in concentration of A with time is given by

In([A]0/[A]t) = kt

where [A]t is the concentration of A at some time t and [A]o is the concentration of A at the beginning of the reaction.

Similarly, the rate of a second-order reaction is proportional to the product of the concentration of both reactants A and B or proportional to the square of the concentration of one. This means that for two reactants A and B, the rate law could be any of

rate = k [A] [B] or rate = k [A]2 or rate = k [B]2

If the reaction is second-order in A only (i.e. rate = k[A]2) then the change in concentration of A with time is 

1/[A]t = 1/[A]0 + kt

child_mcqs.description:
The following data were collected for the reaction A + B → C

    Experiment    

[A]0

   [B]0   

    Initial rate (M/s)    

1

    0.200   

   0.100   

1.2

2

0.200

0.200

1.2

3

0.600

0.200

3.6
 
What is the rate law for the reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Comparing experiments 1 and 2, we can see that doubling [B]0 had no effect on the initial rate of reaction. The rate law thus cannot include a term for B; if it did we would expect a rate change with increasing B.

Conversely, comparing experiments 2 and 3, we can see that tripling A tripled the rate; the rate is thus lineally dependent on A and so the rate law for the reaction is 

rate = k[A]

child_mcqs.description: A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a given reaction without actually reacting itself. If D catalyzes the reaction E + F → G, what is a likely rate law for the reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: If the catalyst increases the rate of reaction, we would expect an increase in catalyst concentration [D] to increase the rate of reaction. In the first three answers, increasing [D] decreases the rate, so none of these rate laws could reasonably describe the situation. In contrast, in answer D rate is lineally proportional to [D], so that adding catalyst increases reaction rate as required.

child_mcqs.description: Which one of the following graphs represents a reaction that is second-order in reactant A?
child_mcqs.explanation:
If the reaction is second-order in A only (i.e. rate = k[A]2) then the change in concentration of A with time is 

1/[A]t = 1/[A]0 + kt

This is a line of form y = mx + b, where y = 1/[A]t, m = k, x = t and b = 1/[A]0. A plot of 1/[A]t against t should thus be linear for a second-order reaction. Note that the slope is positive - firstly, a rate constant can only be positive and so the gradient is positive, and also as the reaction proceeds [A] decreases, so that we expect 1/[A] to increase over time.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
The adaptive immune system matures in humans between the ages of 6-12 months of age. Immunoglobulins, or antibodies, are the major immunological proteins of the adaptive immune response. When the body is first exposed to a foreign antigen, it mounts a primary immune response. IgM is the first class of antibody produced by activated B-cells and mediates the initial component of this primary response. It circulates in the blood as a pentamer (5 units joined together). During this response, B-cells undergo a process called class-switching, in which they change the type of antibody they produce and the specificity of the antibodies for the antigen increases. Each B-cell undergoes class-switching once only. 

After the adaptive immune system has cleared the infection, a small population of class-switched plasma cells remain and provide what is known as immunological memory. These cells are able to respond quickly to a second exposure to the same antigen, producing a greater amount of specific antibodies in a shorter period of time. IgG is the major antibody of the secondary immune response and is the only type that can cross the placenta as it is monomeric. IgA is found in its monomeric form in blood and its dimeric form in secretions. It is primarily responsible for mucosal immunity and is secreted in milk with IgG. IgE binds to innate immune cells in a monomeric form to mediate allergic reactions and fight parasitic infections. 

Please answer the following questions based on this information.

child_mcqs.description: Which antibody class is primarily responsible for the efficacy of vaccination?
child_mcqs.explanation:
It is assumed knowledge that students know or can infer what an antigen is, what B and plasma cells are, and the basic principle of vaccination. 

The basic principle of vaccination is the exposure of the adaptive immune system to a "safe" version of a foreign antigen to induce a response resulting in immunological memory. This memory enables a highly specific, rapid secondary response in the event of a second exposure (i.e. contact with the disease-causing antigen) to prevent the establishment of infection/disease. The efficacy of vaccination is dependent upon the secondary response of which IgG is the major class, as stated in the passage.

child_mcqs.description: A toddler is eating peanuts for the first time. Would you expect them to have an allergic reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that IgE is the main antibody of allergic reactions. The information given indicates that the production of IgE occurs as a result of class-switching, which first requires a primary immune response to the antigen. Based on this information, regardless of age, if the toddler is eating peanuts for the first time they have not had a primary immune response to peanuts and therefore cannot have an allergic reaction.

answers.description: Yes - they are old enough to produce antibodies
No - they are too young to have an allergic reaction
No - they have not had a primary response before

child_mcqs.description: A healthy adult eats some cold pizza that has been left out overnight. Somehow they do not fall ill. Which of the following molecules would you expect to see if you were to isolate the antibodies responsible for this protection?
child_mcqs.explanation: The intestine is lined by mucosa and large amounts of secretions are produced here - this is assumed knowledge. The passage states that IgA is found in secretions and responsible for mucosal immunity. Ingested pathogens (i.e. bacteria on cold pizza) must overcome mucosal immunity to cause disease. From the passage, IgA is the only class of antibody that forms dimers and is only found in this form in secretions.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
Two cars with masses `m_{1}` and `m_{2}` respectively, approach each other perpendicularly at a T-intersection. Both drivers are distracted, so their cars collide in the intersection. Following the collision the vechicles stick together, and move with some final wreckage velocity, `v_{f}` at some angle `\theta` to the horizontal.

The following approximations may be useful for the following questions:

`\sqrt 2 \approx 1.41`

`\sqrt 3 \approx 1.73`

child_mcqs.description: The first car is travelling in the positive x-direction with velocity `v_{1,x}`, while the second travels in the positive y-direction with velocity `v_{2,y}`. Find expressions for the inital momentum of the each vehicle in terms of the velocity of the wreckage, `v_{f}`.
child_mcqs.explanation:
This is an inelastic collision, as the vehicles move as one object following the collision.

The expressions for the initial momentum of each vehicle are obtained by applying the law of conservation of momentum:

`\Sigma p_{i} = \Sigma p_{f}`

Applying conservation of momentum in the x-direction:

`m_{1}v_{1,x} = (m_{1} + m_{2}) v_{f,x}`

`\therefore m_{1}v_{1,x} = (m_{1} + m_{2}) v_{f} cos \theta`

Applying conservation of momentum in the y-direction:

`m_{2}v_{2,y} = (m_{1} + m_{2}) v_{f,y}`

`\therefore m_{2}v_{2,y} = (m_{1} + m_{2}) v_{f} sin \theta`

child_mcqs.description:
Given that `v_{1,x} = 10 \sqrt {3}` `"m" "s"^{-1}`, determine a value for the final wreckage velocity, if the wreckage travels at an angle of `30 ^\circ` to the horizontal. The following information may be useful:

`m_{1} = 2500` `"kg"`

`m_{2} = 1500` `"kg"`
child_mcqs.explanation:
The conservation of momentum equation derived for vehicle 2 can be rearranged to form an expression for the wreckage velocity, `v_{f}`:

`v_{f} = \frac{m_{1} v_{1,x}}{(m_{1} + m_{2}) cos \theta}`

The fact that `cos 30 = \frac{\sqrt 3}{2}`, gives the following expression,

`v_{f} = \frac{(2500)(10 \sqrt 3)}{(1500 + 2500) (\frac{\sqrt 3}{2})}`

`\therefore v_{f} = \frac{(2500)(10 \sqrt 3)}{(1500 + 2500) (\frac{\sqrt 3}{2})}`

`v_{f} = \frac{50}{4}`

`v_{f} = 12.5 "m" "s"^{-1}`

child_mcqs.description: Using the value determined for the final wreckage velocity, determine the initial velocity of car 2 in the y-direction.
child_mcqs.explanation:
`v_{2,y}` can be determined using the equation for the momentum in the x-direction. Rearranging gives:

`v_{2,y} = \frac{(m_1+m_2) v_f cos \theta }{m_2}`

`v_{2,y} = \frac{(1500 + 2500) (12.5) (0.5)}{1500}`

`v_{2,y} = \frac{50}{3}`

`v_{2,y} = 16 \frac{2}{3}` `"m" "s"^{-1}`

child_mcqs.description: The police investigating the accident wish to determine if either vehicle was exceeding the speed limit prior to the crash. If the speed limit on both roads was `60` `"km" "h"^{-1}`, which of the vehicles were exceeding this?
child_mcqs.explanation:
It is useful to convert the speed limit into units of metres per second:

`60` `"km" "h"^{-1}` `= \frac{(60)(1000)}{3600} = 16 \frac{2}{3}` `"m" "s"^-1`

We know the velocities of each of the cars initially:

`v_{1,x} = 10 \sqrt {3} = 17.3` `"m" "s"^{-1}`

`v_{2,y} = 16 \frac{2}{3}` `"m" "s"^{-1}`

Hence, the only vehicle exceeding the speed limit was vehicle 1.

answers.description: Neither car was exceeding the speed limit prior to the crash

stem_mcq.title: Unit 6
stem_mcq.description:
The definition of acids and bases have changed over time – from Arrhenius’ definition of acids containing a hydrogen ion and bases containing a hydroxide ion, to the now commonly accepted definition of acids being proton donors and bases being proton acceptors, a definition proposed by chemists Johannes Brønsted and Thomas Lowry. It then follows that in an acid-base reaction, the acid would donate a proton to a base, where the base accepts the proton. An example of an acid-base reaction is hydrochloric acid reacting with water, where HCl is the acid as it donates a proton and H2O is the base as it accepts this proton.

HCl(aq) + H2O(l) → H3O+(aq) + Cl-(aq)

Observations of the above reaction show that the reverse of the reaction is also an acid-base reaction, thus both the forward and reverse reactions are acid-base reactions. This means that there are two sets of species that differ only by one proton, which are called conjugate acid-base pairs: where a conjugate acid is the species acting as an acid, and the conjugate base is a proton-less acid. Using the above reaction, HCl is the conjugate acid of Cl- and Cl- is the conjugate base of HCl.

Both acids and bases can be classified as monoprotic (where one proton can be donated/accepted), diprotic (two protons can be donated/accepted), triprotic (three protons can be donated/accepted) and so on.
stem_mcq.tag: CHE06 Acids, Bases, Buffers and Redox reactions

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following equations is not an acid-base reaction?
child_mcqs.explanation: As stated in the introduction, one way to identify an acid-base reaction is to see if there are 2 sets of species that differ only by one proton, as either a proton is being donated or accepted. We can see this relationship in both A, B and D, but not in C.

answers.description: HSO4- (aq) + PO43-(aq) ⇔ SO42-(aq) + HPO42-(aq)
NH4+(aq) + OH-(aq) ⇔ NH3(aq) + H2O(l)
NH3(aq) + H2O(l) ⇔ NH4+(aq) + OH-(aq)

child_mcqs.description:
Two molecules of water react with each other as shown:

 

H2O(l) + H2O(l) → H3O+(aq) + OH-(aq)

 

Which of the following statement(s) is/are true?

I           The reaction is not an acid-base reaction

II         The reaction is an acid-base reaction

III        H2O is the conjugate base of OH-

IV        H2O is the conjugate base of H3O+
child_mcqs.explanation: The reaction is an acid-base reaction because we can observe two sets of pairs where there is only a difference of a proton in each pair: H2O and OH-, H2O and H3O+. Since a conjugate acid is the species which acts as an acid in a reaction, therefore a conjugate base is the proton-less species within the pair. Hence H2O is the conjugate base of H3O+ as it has one less proton.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following acids is a triprotic acid?
child_mcqs.explanation: A triprotic acid has 3 protons that can be donated. A is acetic acid, and it is monoprotic as it forms the acetate ion (CH3COO-) once a proton is donated. D is ethane - although it has six hydrogens, alkanes are not inherently acidic and would donate one proton, let alone three. C is ammonia and is a base. Therefore, the answer is B as phosphoric acid can donate 3 protons in succession forming H2PO4-, HPO42- and PO43- respectively.

child_mcqs.description:
Sodium carbonate has the following structural representation:

 

What could be inferred about the number of protons it can accept/donate?
child_mcqs.explanation: Upon first inspection, there are no protons to donate, therefore sodium carbonate must be a base, thus B and D are clearly wrong. We can then see that there are two sites where a proton can be accepted or added (at the O- which becomes OH), thus making it a diprotic base.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 7
stem_mcq.description:
Knowledge of the differing biochemical properties of DNA, RNA and protein has been essential for understanding how these molecular species interact within cells. These properties have also been exploited for laboratory use and have permitted the generation of tools for analysis and manipulation of these molecules. A selection of the biochemical properties of each species is listed below.

 

DNA

A strand of DNA is comprised of repeating sugar (deoxyribose) and negatively charged phosphate groups. One of the four nitrogenous bases (adenine, cytosine, guanine and thymine) is attached to each sugar. The familiar double helix structure is created when two complementary strands bind. They are made complementary by the pairing of bases (A with T and C with G), as determined by the number of hydrogen bonds they share. A-T pairs share two hydrogen bonds and C-G pairs share 3 hydrogen bonds. Each base has a neutral charge at physiological pH.

 

RNA

RNA is very similar to DNA. It principally differs in three ways: it contains ribose as its sugar instead of deoxyribose, uracil replaces thymine one of the bases and it typically exists as a single strand.

 

Proteins

Proteins are markedly different from DNA and RNA and are comprised of chains of covalently linked amino acids. These chains can be of dramatically varying lengths. Amino acids all have the same basic structure, but differ in their side groups. The 20 amino acids that exist in the human body are often categorized by the chemical properties of their side groups and are listed below. The interaction of these amino acids side groups determines the three dimensional conformation of a protein, which is a key determinant of its function.
Ionic – containing a charged group (+ or -) at physiological pH
Polar – able to form hydrogen bonds
Non-polar – generally hydrocarbon chains or aromatic rings
Disulphide bridge forming – able to form disulphide bridges (R-S-S-R) with similar amino acids within the protein

child_mcqs.description: When in the nucleus, DNA is associated with proteins called histones. Specifically, DNA is attracted to charged residues on the surface of the histones. This interaction serves as one regulatory mechanism of DNA transcription. When DNA is tightly bound to histones, transcription does not occur. The charge on the surface of histones is controlled by histone acetylases and deacetylases, which add and remove acetyl groups (-COCH3) respectively. Which of the following is true in regards to histone acetylases and deacetylases?
child_mcqs.explanation:
This question contains a great deal of jargon, meant to disguise two important pieces of information. Firstly, the question states that DNA is attracted to charged residues on the histones. DNA was described earlier as being partly comprised of negatively charged phosphate groups. Thus, the charged groups on histones must be positive for it to be attracted. The second piece of necessary information is that the acetyl group that is being added and removed from histones does not have a charge. These acetyl groups control the positive charge on histones by neutralizing it. They cannot however impart further negative charge.

When the potential answers are evaluated, only C adheres to these rules. Deacetylases remove acetyl groups from the histones, which returns their positive charge. This attracts the negative charge of DNA and binds it tightly, inhibiting transcription.

answers.description: Histone acetylases increase transcription by imparting negative charge on histones
Histone acetylases decrease transcription by removing positive charge on histones
Histone deacetylases decrease transcription by imparting positive charge on histones
Histone deacetylases increase transcription by removing positive charge on histones

child_mcqs.description: Spectrophotometry is a quick method to assess the purity of isolated DNA. The absorbance of the solution is tested using two ultraviolet wavelengths: 260 nm and 280 nm. These wavelengths are absorbed due to the presence of aromatic rings within the bases of DNA and RNA. A sample of DNA is considered pure if the 260nm/280nm ratio is 2.0. Due to its slightly different structure, pure RNA has an absorbance ratio of 1.8. Several amino acids also contain aromatic rings. The absorbance spectra of these amino acids are shown below. How would the presence of proteins containing these amino acids alter the 260nm/280nm ratio of a sample of DNA? Assume the amino acids are in roughly equal proportion.
child_mcqs.explanation: From the graph available, protein containing these amino acids would absorb more at 280 nm than 260 nm, but what is important to consider is the ratio of absorbances - note also that the graph is on a logarithmic scale. Though phenylalanine absorbs no light at 280 nm, both tryptophan and tyrosine significantly more at 280 nm than 260 nm. It is important to note that the absorbance scale is logarithmic. When in roughly equal proportion, these amino acids absorb much less at 260 than 280. Furthermore, the ratio is much lower than 1.8. This means that for any amount of RNA contamination (even 100%), the 260nm/280nm ratio will still be lowered. The best way to see this is to add the absorbances at 260 and 280 together and take the ratio - the absorbances at 260 are 100, 500 and 3500 and at 280 are 0, 1000 and 5000, giving a ratio of ~1.5.

answers.description: The presence of protein would increase the ratio
The presence of protein would decrease the ratio
The presence of protein would not change the ratio
The effect of protein on the ratio cannot be determined without knowing if the sample was contaminated with RNA

child_mcqs.description: DNA isolates frequently need to be amplified to ensure there is sufficient material for analysis. This is generally accomplished by a process called polymerase chain reaction. In brief, this process involves the heating of DNA until the hydrogen bonds between complementary strands break. A complex of proteins, termed DNA polymerase, is then able to replicate each strand. Though polymerases are found in all cells, most cannot tolerate the high temperatures of the laboratory reaction. The heat disrupts the interactions between the side groups of the amino acids and the protein loses its necessary three dimensional shape. A polymerase isolated from bacteria that live in extremely hot environments can be used in the reaction however. Which of the following would best explain the heat resistance of this polymerase?
child_mcqs.explanation: All of these options will increase the stability of a protein. The key here is to identify the option that would “best explain” the heat resistance. Only disulphide bridges represent a true chemical bond between amino acids. As such, they are much stronger that the other types of interactions between amino acids (ionic, hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic) and are best able to resist the effects of heat.

answers.description: Greater number of amino acids with charged side groups
Greater number of amino acids with hydrogen bond forming side groups
Greater number of amino acids with hydrophobic side groups
Greater number of amino acids with disulphide bridge forming side groups

child_mcqs.description: A common method of DNA analysis is gel electrophoresis. The DNA strand is first broken into fragments based on its sequence. The DNA fragments are then loaded into a gel block, which is immersed in a conductive buffer solution. Electrodes are located at either end of the gel and connected to a direct current power supply. The pH of the buffer solution is generally maintained around near physiological pH. When current is flowing, DNA migrates towards the positive electrode. Smaller DNA fragments migrate further in a given time than larger fragments. By comparing the distances travelled, the size of DNA fragments can be estimated. In regards to the difference in migration distance, smaller fragments travel further than larger fragments:
child_mcqs.explanation: In DNA, there is one phosphate group for each base (two for every base pair). Therefore, for any fragment size, there will always be an equal ratio of phosphates, bases and sugars. This means that the ratio of charge to mass is uniform for all fragment sizes. Answer C can be ruled out as it is nonsensical. If the ratio is common between fragment sizes, it cannot be responsible for causing them to move at different rates. In fact, it is the gel itself that causes larger fragments to move more slowly, but that knowledge is not required to answer the question.

answers.description: Because they have a higher charge/mass ratio
Because they have the same charge/mass ratio

child_mcqs.description: Proteins can also be analysed using gel electrophoresis (process described in Question 4). It is termed a native electrophoresis if no processing is done to the protein beforehand. In contrast to DNA electrophoresis, proteins may migrate in either direction. In a native electrophoresis, the proteins which do not migrate far in either direction:
child_mcqs.explanation:
As stated in the preliminary information, proteins vary widely in the number of amino acids they contain. Also, not all groups are charged. This leads to substantial variability in the charge/mass ratio of proteins whereas in DNA, it is uniform.

Proteins could contain almost exclusively charged amino acids and still not migrate very far. This would come about if the negative and positive charges were in roughly equal proportion. Thus, A is incorrect.

A large number of amino acids can decrease the charge to mass ratio, but not if they are all charged amino acids. Thus, B is incorrect.

Small proteins could have a high proportion of hydrophobic amino acids, but a small population of identically charged ones would still result in a high charge to mass ratio. Thus, C is incorrect.

Native electrophoresis is therefore unable to distinguish between all these features and that is why its use in a laboratory setting is quite restricted. D is the correct answer.

answers.description: Must contain a small proportion of charged amino acids
Must have a higher total number of amino acids
Must have a high proportion of hydrophobic amino acids
These features cannot be distinguished in native electrophoresis

stem_mcq.title: Unit 8
stem_mcq.description:
When light from a stellar object is split into its spectrum, it will contain Fraunhofer lines, which correspond to the wavelengths of light absorbed by the elements that make up the cooler external layers of the object. Strong Fraunhofer lines, designated A through K, represent elements that are common in the universe. 

Due to the Doppler effect, light from an object travelling away from an observer becomes stretched, resulting in a shift towards the red end of the spectrum. The degree of redshift, z, is given by:

 

`1+Z=lambda_{:"observed":}/lambda_{:"emitted":}`   AND   `Z=v/c`

 

Where:

`lambda_{:"observed":}` = wavelength apparent to the observer

`lambda_{:"emitted":}` = wavelength emitted by the object

`v` = the velocity of the object relative to the observer

`c` = `3xx10^8ms^-1`

 

An astronaut on board the international space station points her spectroscope towards a distant galaxy (Galaxy A) and records the absorption spectrum. She then compares this with the absorption spectrum of the sun.

child_mcqs.description: Assuming Galaxy A is travelling directly away from the astronaut, its velocity with respect to the astronaut is closest to:
child_mcqs.explanation:
Firstly, the redshift value must be determined by comparing the wavelengths of any two corresponding Fraunhofer lines from the spectra provided. It must be understood that the most common elements in the universe are present in both the sun and the distant galaxy. As the sun is essentially a constant distance from the ISS, the solar absorption spectrum provides the emitted wavelength values.

It may be recognised that as the magnitude of redshift is proportional to the emitted wavelength. Therefore, comparing lines of higher wavelengths (ie. line 'A') on this scale will return a more precise answer.

 

 

The emitted wavelength value for line A is approximately 760nm, while the observed wavelength is approximately 800nm.

 

First, determine the redshift value (z):

 

`1+Z=lambda_{:"observed":}/lambda_{:"emitted":}`

`1+Z=20/19`

`1+Z=1/19`

`Z~~0.05`

 

Now determine the velocity of Galaxy A:

 

 

`Z=v/c`

`0.05=v/{:3xx10^8:}`

`v=5xx10^-2xx3xx10^8`

`v=1.5xx10^7ms^-1`

child_mcqs.description:
Hubble's law states that in general, distant objects recede from an observer at a greater velocity than near objects. This relationship is represented by the following graph:

 

 

Given this information, a galaxy with a redshift of `z=3.3xx10^-2` is likely to approximately how far from the observer?
child_mcqs.explanation:
This question is essentially an extension of the first, as it requires candidates to determine the velocity of an object based on its redshift factor. 

 

`Z=v/c`

 

`3.3xx10^-2=v/{:3xx10^8:}`

 

`v=3.3xx10^-2xx3xx10^8`

 

`v=1xx10^7ms^-1`   

 

Now convert this to `kms^-1`:

 

`v=1xx10^4kms^-1`

 

The candidate must then find the point in the relationship provided where velocity is `10^4kms^-1`. The `x` value at this point is approximately 156 Mpc.

child_mcqs.description:
The astronaut turns her spectrometer to another object, Galaxy B, which is known to be 2.5 x 106 light years away. She finds that Galaxy B exhibits a slight blueshift of z = -0.0005.

 

1 lightyear `= 9.5xx10^12` km

 

Assuming Galaxy B is travelling within the line of sight of the astronaut and that its velocity remains constant, how long until Galaxy B collides with the galaxy of the observer?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The candidate must understand the nature of waves influenced by the doppler effect. While light wavelengths from from an object moving away from an observer will be 'stretched' and therefore shifted to the red end of the spectrum, light waves from an object travelling towards an observer will be 'compressed' and therefore appear shifted to the blue end of the spectrum. A negative z value corresponds to a situation where the observed wavelength is shorter than the emmitted wavelength, which occurs in blueshift.  

Firstly, the velocity of the galaxy must be determined:

`Z=v/c`

 

`-5xx10^-4=v/{:3xx10^8:}`


`v=-5xx10^-4xx3xx10^8`


`v=-1.5xx10^5ms^-1`

As the sign is negative, the direction of this velocity it towards the observer.


Next, the present distance of Galaxy B must be converted to meters:

 

`s=2.375xx10^19km=2.375xx10^22m`


The time taken for Galaxy B to travel this distance at its current velocity is then calculated:

`t=s/v`      Where t is time, s is displacement and v is velocity.
`t={:-2.375xx10^22:}/{:-1.5xx10^5:}`      Note that as displacement (`s`) is in the direction of the observer, it has a negative value.


`t={:2.375xx10^17:}/{:1.5:}`

 

The candidate should now recognise that only answer 'A' is in the same order of magnitude as this, so the solution needn't be continued beyond this point.

`t~~1.6xx10^17`seconds

child_mcqs.description: Astronomers discover a very large mirror at a considerable distance from the earth, travelling directly away from it. In order to determine the relative velocity of this object, a laser beam with a wavelength of 500nm is directed at the mirror and the wavelength of the returning beam is measured using a spectroscope. Compared with a light-emitting source of an equivalent recessional velocity, the light returning to the astronomers from the mirror will be:
child_mcqs.explanation:
By this stage, the candidate has explored the doppler effect as it occurs when observing light emitted from a moving object. In this question, the moving object is not emitting light, but reflecting light that has the same relative velocity as the observer.

 

To answer this, first consider the effect on the laser light as observed from the mirror. The mirror is moving away from the light source at some velocity, so to an observer on the mirror, the light would appear redshifted. As a result, the light indicent upon the mirror is redshifted by the same amount as the light from a light-emitting source at the same velocity.

 

Next, consider the effect on light from the reference frame of an observer from earth. The mirror is acting as a light source, and it is moving away at some velocity. Again, this means that the light will be redshifted. However, we know that the light incident on the mirror has already been redshifted. The light from the laser has therefore been redshifted twice, and so will appear more redshifted than a light-emitting source of an equivalent recessional velocity.

 

The correct answer is 'B'.

 

Answer 'A' describes what would occur if the mirror were travelling towards the observer.

Answer 'C' describes what would occur if the mirror were instead a light-emitting source.

Answer 'D' is an incorrect statement. It is not necessary to know the absolute velocity of an object to determine redshift. Only the relative velocity between two objects needs to be known.

answers.description: Impossible to determine as we do not know the absolute velocity of the observer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 9
stem_mcq.description: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common type of abnormal heart rhythm.  During AF electrical impulses are triggered from multiple areas in the atria in stead of just the sino atrial (SA) node resulting in 300-500 contractions per minute.  Not all of the electrical impulses produced are conducted to the ventricles causing rapid and irregular hearbeats.  As a result, blood tends to pool in the atria and the heart may not be able to pump enough through the body.

child_mcqs.description: Choose the correct sequence of current flow through the heart.
child_mcqs.explanation: The SA node generates a rhythm that is conducted though the AV node and His bundle towards the Purkinje fibers that distribute action potential to the ventricles.

answers.description: SA node, left and right bundle branches, His bundle, AV node, Purkinje fibers.
AV node, His bundle, SA node, Purkinje fibers, left and right bundle branches.
SA node, AV node, His bundle, left and right bundle branches, Purkinje fibers.
Purkinje fibers, SA node, AV node, His bundle, left and right bundle branches.

child_mcqs.description: ​An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart over time and can be used to confirm AF.  The diagram below represents a schematic of an ECG and the major events that take place during one cardiac cycle.  Depolarization starts and spreads out in the atrium and causes the atrium to contract (P wave).  The depolarization spreads rapidly towards the ventricles which causes them to contract subsequently.  What do you expect to see on the ECG of a patient with AF?
child_mcqs.explanation: The P wave represents atrial depolarization which initiates atria contraction.  R-R intervals are irregular because ventrical activation is irregular.

answers.description: Disorganised activity where the QRS complex should be and irregular T-T intervals.
Disorganised activity where the T wave should be.
A longer than normal P-Q interval and irregular Q-Q intervals.
Disorganised electrical activity where the P waves should be and irregular R-R intervals.

child_mcqs.description: Blood collected in the heart can potentially form a cloth which can travel to a patients brain and potentially cause a stroke.  Therefore, AF patients are often treated with an anticoagulant such as warfarin.  Warfarin works by suppressing the synthesis of the active forms of clotting factors II (prothrombin) and VII, IX and X.  In the last steps of coagulation, prothrombin is converted into thrombin which acts as a fibrinogenase converting soluble fibrinogen into insoluble strands of fibrin that become part of the clot.  Thus, thrombin acts as:
child_mcqs.explanation:
Thrombin acts as an enzyme because it catalysis the formation of fibrin out of fibrinogen.  

A subtrate is a substance that is converted (fibrinogen in this case).

An inhibitor inhibits a certain reaction.

A cofactor is a non-protein compound required for a protein's activity.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
Inspiration of air into the lungs is an active process; contraction of the diaphragm stretches the elastic tissue in the lungs to increase volume and draw air in. Expiration is a passive process, dependent upong to the elastic tissue in the lungs recoiling to reduce volume and force air out of the lungs. Normal quiet respiration is measured as tidal volume (VT). Accessory muscles can be recruited to utilise reserve inspiratory and expiratory volumes (IRV and ERV respectively) during times of increased oxygen demand, such as in exercise. 

Firefighters wear breathing apparatus' when entering a fire to avoid suffering smoke inhalation. The heat and chemicals in the smoke can cause and inflammatory reaction in the lung, resulting in the expansile elastic tissue being replaced by fibrous scar tissue. This is known as restrictive lung disease. In contrast, one condition commonly found in long-term cigarette smokers is emphysema. This is a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in which the elastic walls of the alveoli are gradually destroyed, causing air to become trapped in the lungs.

Lung volumes and capacities can be measured by spirometry. The term "capacity" refers to a combination of volumes, which are the minimum measurable units. Vital capacity (VC) refers to the total amount of exchangeable air in the lungs. Residual volume (RV) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs that cannot be expired - it keeps the alveoli open, preventing lung collapse.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following descriptions best fits the definition of functional residual capacity (FRC)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Spirometry and lung volumes are covered in most first year physiology classes, so students should be familiar with the concept and able to use the graph to work out the answer if they don't already know it. A = expiratory reserve volume, B = tidal volume, D = total lung capacity

answers.description: Air remaining in the lungs after tidal expiration

child_mcqs.description:
A patient is having a spirometry performed and is given the following instructions:

"breathe out normally, then breathe in as much as you can". 

What volume or capacity is being directly measured when the patient follows the instructions?
child_mcqs.explanation: Using the graph provided, students should be able to work out what is being measured based on the question description. The key point is that the person exhaled normally (within tidal volume) and then inhaled maximally. Both FRC and VC require maximal exhalation, so B and C are incorrect. IRC is measured after tidal inhalation whereas IC is measured after tidal exhalation, therefore D is correct. The measurement of IRV from these instructions would be indirect.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above information, what is the most significant change you would expect to see on spirometry of a person with obstructive lung disease?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that the destruction of alveolar walls in COPD results in air becoming trapped in the lungs, and defines RV as the amount of air in the lungs that cannot be expired. C is therefore correct. Total lung and functional residual capacities increase in obstructive disease due to gas trapping. Tidal volume does not change significantly, although requires more effort.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the above information, what is the most significant change you would expect to see on spirometry of a person with restrictive lung disease?
child_mcqs.explanation: Inspiration requires stretching of the elastic tissue of the lungs - this is replaced by fibrous scar tissue in restrictive lung disease. Thus a person with RLD will not be able to expand their lungs as much as a health person = reduced total capacity (B). Residual volume and FRC are both reduced in RLD for the same reason. Tidal volume does not change significantly in RLD, although work of breathing does.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 11
stem_mcq.description:
Vitamin A (retinol), like all vitamins, is an essential organic cofactor used in a variety of metabolic pathways. Derived from dietary carotenoids such as trans-β-carotene, these are transiently stored in fat (thereby giving the yellowish hue of fat) prior to hepatic bioactivation.

The 'typical' function of Vitamin A is in vision. When photons energise photoreceptor cells of the retina, the consequent conformational change in 11-cis-retinal leads to the release of bound opsin, the closure of associated cation channels and hyperpolarisation of the cell. This hyperpolarisation inhibits the vesicular release of glutamate, and consequently impairs nervous transmission back to the brain.

child_mcqs.description: Competitive antagonists of 11-cis-retinal and glutamate can be used to modulate photoreceptor cells in vitro. Which of the following combinations would allow nervous transmissions?
child_mcqs.explanation:
D is correct. If the hyperpolarisation of the photoreceptor cell inhibits glutamate release and ultimately reduces nervous transmission, we know that glutamate is excitatory in this situation. Thus, glutamate cannot be inhibited, and B or D remain options.

If opsin release leads to photoreceptor hyperpolarisation, we know that 11-cis-retinal binding is required to inhibit opsin activity, and thus functional 11-cis-retinal must be present. Therefore, D is the correct answer, as neither inhibitor can be present.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is least likely to be associated with Vitamin A deficiency?
child_mcqs.explanation: B is correct. Whilst lipophilic distribution is an important consideration in pharmacology, it should be understood that the rate of distribution is proportional to circulating levels, and that in (Western) countries where obesity is rife, dietary Vitamin A is inherently abundant in the diet (lipophilic distribution effects would be transient and minimal).

answers.description: Enzyme defects; inadequate bioactivation leads to functional deficiency
Functional blindness; an absence of 11-cis-retinal prevents light sensitivity
Diet; an absence of dietary carotenoids leads to absolute deficiency

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description:
The electrode potential of a cell, E, measures the potential difference between two half-cells of an electrochemical cell, which consists of a reduction half-cell (at the cathode) and an oxidation half-cell (at the anode). Under standard conditions, where temperature is at 298K, solutes have a concentration of 1 mol/L and a gas pressure of 1 bar, the electrode potential is known as the standard electrode potential, E°.

The Nernst equation measures the electrode potential under non-standard conditions, relating cell potential to the reaction quotient:

where R = Ideal gas constant

           n = Number of electrons transferred in the reaction

           F = Faraday’s constant (in C mol-1)

           T = Temperature (in K)

           Q = Reaction Quotient           

The reaction quotient, Q, is a measure of the activities, a, or effective concentrations of products and reactants in a reaction; it is a fraction of products over reactants. For dilute solutions, we can assume that their activities are approximately equal to their concentrations.  

For example:

The following reaction has taken place:

aA + bB ⇔ cC + dD

Where a, b, c and d equals the number of moles of A, B, C and D respectively.

The reaction quotient is thus:

child_mcqs.description: If the electrode potential is expressed in volts, and one volt equals one joule per coulomb (i.e. V=J/C), what are the units for the ideal gas constant, R?
child_mcqs.explanation: As electrode potential is expressed in volts, then  must be in volts, as ln Q is unit-less. As V = J/C, R must include the unit Joule, which rules out answers A and B. Since F (mol-1) and T (K) need to be cancelled out to give J, the answer must be C. n, the number of electrons transferred in the balanced reaction, is unitless - this is suggested by the fact that the other values are specifically given units in the question.

child_mcqs.description: Using the reaction quotient given in the introduction, and assuming dilute conditions, what would happen to the magnitude of Q if the number of moles of reactant A is doubled?
child_mcqs.explanation: From simple observation, if we increase the number of moles of A, the denominator would increase, thus decreasing the value of Q, so C is the answer.

child_mcqs.description: Using the Nernst equation, under what condition would the electrode potential equal the standard electrode potential?
child_mcqs.explanation:
In order for the electrode potential to equal the standard potential, , must equal zero.
A - Although the standard electrode potential is measured at 298K, the electrode potential can equal the standard electrode potential at other temperatures by changing the reagent concentrations. Similarly, even if the temperature is 298 K, unless the concentration of reagents is 1 M and the pressure is 1 atm, the electrode potential won't be the same as the standard electrode potential
B - If no electrons are transferred, then n = 0 and the denominator of  is zero - this involves dividing by zero, which is not possible

C - It is true to say that if Q = 1, then ln Q = 0 and the term becomes equal to zero as required. However, Q is not necessarily equal to 1 if the concentrations of reagents and products are equal. Consider for example the reaction

Al(s) + 3Cu+  ⇔ Al3+ + 3Cu(s)

This has reaction quotient Q = [Al3+][Cu]3/[Al][Cu+]3. However, the terms [Al] and [Cu] are meaningless as they refer to solids, which have constant concentration. Thus the reaction quotient is really Q = [Al3+]/[Cu+]3. Clearly even if the concentrations of reactants and products here are equal, we won't necessarily have Q = 1 and so this answer is also incorrect.

answers.description: When no electrons are transferred in the reaction
When the concentrations of both reactants and products are the same

child_mcqs.description:
The following reaction has taken place:

Ox1 + Red1 ⇔ Red2 + Ox2

Assuming dilute conditions, which of these depicts the Nernst equation?
child_mcqs.explanation: The reaction quotient is a fraction of products over reactants. This immediately rules out answer B. Applying the formula given in the introduction, we expect to see , but this is not one of the options. However, we can recognise that –ln(x) is the same as +ln(1/x), thus  is the same as .

child_mcqs.description:
I is the ionic strength of a solution and is the sum of the charges of the ions in a solution multiplied by their concentrations.

where c = concentration of the ion
            z = charge on the ion

How would the ionic strength of 1 mol/L of CaCl2 compare to 1 mol/L of CuSO4?
child_mcqs.explanation: CaCl2 dissociates to form Ca2+ and 2 x Cl- ions. Thus I = ½ [(1 x 22) + (2 x 12)] = 3. Note that because 2 chloride ions are formed, its concentration is doubled. CuSO4 dissociates to form Cu2+ and SO42- ions. Thus I = ½ [(1 x 22) + (1 x 22)] = 4. Hence the ionic strength of CaCl2 is lower than SO42-.

answers.description: The ionic strength is equal for both CaCl2 and CuSO4
CaCl2 has a higher ionic strength than CuSO4
CaCl2 has a lower ionic strength than CuSO4

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
Chemical reactions between molecules involve breaking and forming new bonds. All reactions require an initial input of energy to destabilise the reactants and break their existing chemical bonds. This energy is referred to as activation energy (EA) and the amount of EA required to overcome this kinetic barrier determines the speed of the reaction. Once in the transitional state, the atoms of the reactants will form new, more stable bonds to form the final product(s). The difference in free energy (ΔG) between the reactants and products determines whether a reaction can occur spontaneously or not. 

While exergonic reactions are theoretically spontaneous in living cells, in reality the amount of EA required to initiate reactions is large enough to prevent most from happening unassisted. Enzymes catalyse reactions by lowering the EA required for reactants to reach a transitional state; they do not remove the requirement for EA and they can only speed up reactions that would happen eventually anyway. The enzyme-substrate reaction is in an equilibrium situation: if product builds up, the reaction slows. 

Each enzyme has an optimal temperature and pH range for maximal functioning. Inhibitors reduce or prevent enzyme function: a competitive inhibitor binds to the active (catalytic) site while a non-competitive inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme. 

Cells depend on ATP (energy) to function. Ingested organic molecules are processed through metabolic pathways within cells to harvest the chemical energy stored in bonds of those molecules to generate ATP. These pathways depend on enzymes to lower the EA of the intermediary reactions so that they occur under physiological conditions. Endergonic reactions are coupled to exergonic reactions which generate enough ΔG to overcome the unfavourable EA of the endergonic reactions. Uncoupled exergonic reactions release free energy as heat. 

In many metabolic pathways, the first enzyme is often the major control enzyme = rate-limiting. Its activity is determined by the concentration of the starting material; it may also be affected by the amount of final product.
stem_mcq.tag: BIO02 Enzymes, cellular metabolism & the central dogma

child_mcqs.description: What would happen if an enzyme is added to a solution that contains equal relative concentrations of its product and substrate?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that the enzyme-substrate reaction is equilibrium dependent. If products and substrates of an enzyme are in equal relative concentrations (equilibrium), there will be no net reaction catalysed by the enzyme nor any change in free energy of the system.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information given, what is the best explanation for why controlled hypothermia may minimise brain damage in surgery?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that enzymes have an optimal temperature and pH range for maximal functioning. If a body is hypothermic, it is at a temperature below normal and thus the cellular enzymes are required to catalyse reactions at a temperature outside of their optimal range. If enzymes are functioning maximally within their optimal temperature range, the rate of enzymatic reactions can only be slowed by lowering the temperature. Slower enzyme reactions = slower metabolic rate which reduces the oxygen requirement of the brain.

answers.description: Lower temperatures convert exergonic reactions to endergonic reactions
Lower temperatures slow the rate of enzyme-catalysed reactions
Lower temperatures increase the free energy produced from reactions
Lower temperatures increae the rate of enzyme-catalysed reactions

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following would promote progression of a metabolic pathway through its enzymatic rate-limiting step, assuming this is the first reaction in the pathway?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that the enzyme-substrate reaction is equilibrium-dependent. It also states that the activity of the rate-limiting enzyme is determined by the concentration of starting material and may be affected by the amount of final product. Based on this, if the amount of product(s) were to increase, the reaction rate would slow down, making answers A and B incorrect. Reducing the concentration of substrate for the enzyme to act upon (answer C) would have the same effect, thus answer D is correct.

child_mcqs.description: A solution contains substance X that binds an enzyme at its active site, inhibiting the enzyme. If the concentration of enzyme product increases when additional substrate is added to the solution, what is substance X?
child_mcqs.explanation:
An irreversible inhibitor binds to an enzyme, usually by covalent bonds, and can only be overcome by replacing inactivated enzymes with functioning ones (which did not occur in this case), thus answers A and C are incorrect. A reversible inhibitor can dissociate from the enzyme. A non-competitive inhibitor binds to the enzyme at a site other than the active site, causing the enzyme to change conformation and preventing it from binding substrate at the active site, so answers C and D are incorrect. 

Substance X binds at the active site of an enzyme, so it is competing with that enzyme's substrate. Increasing the concentration of substrate results in substrate binding in the active site more often than the inhibitor (competes), allowing increased product formation, therefore answer B is correct.

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information in the passage, what change in free energy (ΔG) is typically seen in a reaction that does not occur spontaneously?
child_mcqs.explanation: A reaction that does not occur spontaneously is endergonic - the free energy of the products is greater than that of the reactants and therefore requires the addition of energy to proceed (+ΔG). This is shown in the diagram. The presence of an enzyme does not change the type of reaction.

answers.description: Depends on whether an enzyme is present or not

child_mcqs.description: From the information in the passage, what is the best explanation for how a bear maintains its body temperature during winter hibernation?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that uncoupled exergonic reactions results in energy being released as heat. This is the best explanation for the maintenance of body temperature in a warm-blooded mammal.

answers.description: Metabolism of fat stores via coupled exergonic reactions
Metabolism of fat stores via coupled exergonic and endergonic reactions
Metabolism of fat stores via uncoupled exergonic reactions
Metabolism of fat stores via uncoupled endergonic reactions

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
​The rapid movement of insect wings is powered by the indirect flight muscles (IFMs, figure 1).  Contraction of the IFMs results in depression of the tergite (dorsal part of the insect) and thus upstroke of the wings.  Insect wings can beat faster than action potentials reach the muscle cells and the IFMs are capable of contracting at up to 1,000 Hz.  Researchers have characterized the wing thrust (top trace in figure 2) and muscle action potential (bottom trace in figure 2) in flying beetles and found that one action potential can cause multiple muscle contractions.  This is called asynchronous muscle activation.  To explore this oscillatory activation further, the researchers also measured the capactity of the muscle to produce force by inducing a tetanic contraction followed by two stretch-hold-release cycles (figure 3A).  Figure 3B shows the boxed portion of figure 3A on an expanded time base.   

Figure 1.  Schematic of insect IFMs (blue) represented as an transverse section.  Contraction of the IFMs causes the wings to move upwards.

Figure 2.  Wing thrust (red top trace) and muscle action potentials (black bottom trace) of a flying beetle. 

Figure 3. A)  Muscle stimulation with shocks at 100 Hz caused a tetanic contraction followed by two stretch-hold-release cycles.  The thick line beneath the Force trace represents the duration of the stimulation.  B)  The boxed portion of figure A on an expanded time base and as strain and resulting stress.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is NOT correct?
child_mcqs.explanation: Answer C is incorrect since ATP is hydrolyzed by myosin.

answers.description: How fast a muscle can contract is limited by the pumping of Ca2+ in and out of the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Type I fibers (slow twitch fibers) are red due to the presence of large volumes of myoglobin and high numbers of mitochondria.
ATP is hydrolyzed by the troponin complex which causes formation of a cross-bridge between actin and myosin.
ATP is necessary for both muscle contraction and relaxation.

child_mcqs.description: Gathering from figures 3A and B, how can the sustained oscillary activation in insect wings be explained?
child_mcqs.explanation: The correct answer is answer A.  In figure 3A, note that the force rises as the muscle is stretched (hence stretch activation) and continous to rise when the lenght of the muscle remains constant.  When the length of the muscle decreases the force decreases (hence shortening deactivation) but remains to decrease even after the length of the muscle is back to starting point.  The same is shown in figure 3B but expressed in stress and strain on the muscle. The force/stress rises during stretch (a) and continous to rise during the interval at constant length (b).  This is the delayed stretch activation.  Force/stress declines during shortening (c) and continous to decline following the shortening (d).  This is the delayed shortening deactivation.

answers.description: Oscillatory activity is activated mechanically by stretching.  More specifically, there is delayed shortening deactivation (d) and delayed stretch activation (b).
Oscillatory activity is activated mechanically by stretching.  More specifically, there is delayed shortening deactivation (c) and delayed stretch activation (f).
Oscillatory activity is activated mechanically by stretching.  More specifically, there is delayed shortening deactivation (e) and delayed stretch activation (c).
Oscillatory activity is activated mechanically by stretching.  More specifically, there is delayed shortening deactivation (b) and delayed stretch activation (d).

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following statements is correct?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Answer A is correct (answer B is thus incorrect).  Compare stress and force in section c and e.  The force generated by the muscle during shortening is greater because the muscle has been activated by the preceding lengthening.  During lengthening, the muscle is partially deactivated by the preceded shortening. 

Answer C is incorrect because more work is done by the muscle during shortening than is required to restretch the muscled after shortening.  This can be seen in the prolonged decrease in force and stress after the strain and length have stopped decreasing (d).

Answer D is incorrect because the force at any length is greater during the shortening half-cycle than during the lengthening half-cycle, more work is done by the muscle druing shortening than is required to restretch the muscle after shortening and there is net work output over a full shortening-lengthening cycle.

answers.description: The force generated during shortening is greater than the force generated during lengthening.
The force generated during shortening is smaller than the force generated during lengthening.
During shortening, the muscle does not work harder than necessary to restretch.
There is no net work output over a full shortening-lenghtening cycle.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description:
Consider the following circuit, in which different combinations of switch positions will cause current to flow through three different groups of light bulbs.

 

 

The following equations may be used:

`I=V/R`    Where V is voltage, I is current and R is resistance. 

 

`R_{:"series":}=R_1+R_2+R_3`     (total resistance in a series circuit)

 

`1/{:R_{:"parallel":}:}={:1/R_1:}+{:1/R_2:}+{:1/R_3:}`      (total resistance in a parallel circuit)

 

Assume that all of the light bulbs in this circuit are identical and the battery supplies a constant voltage.

child_mcqs.description: Assuming that all of the light bulbs in this circuit are identical and the battery supplies a constant voltage, which combination of switch positions will result in the greatest total resistance?
child_mcqs.explanation:
From the equation `I=V/R` we can see that power and resistance are inversely proportional. The candidate should recognise that a series circuit will have a greater total resistance than a parallel circuit composed of the same elements. From this alone, it should be clear that the circuit labelled 'Group 2' produces the greatest resistance, however the full solution follows:

 

Group 1: (Three elements in parallel)

 

`1/{:R_{:"total":}:}={:1/R_1:}+{:1/R_2:}+{:1/R_3:}` 

 

`1/{:R_{:"total":}:}={:1/10:}+{:1/10:}+{:1/10:}=3/10`

 

`10=3R_{:"total":}`

`R_{:"total":}=0.33Omega`

 

 

Group 2: (Three elements in series)

 

`R_{:"total":}=R_1+R_2+R_3`

`R_{:"total":}=10+10+10`

`R_{:"total":}=30Omega`

 

Group 3: (A two-element series circuit composed of one element and two elements in parallel)

 

`R_{:"total":}=R_1+R_2`

 

Where:

 

`1/{:R_2:}={:1/R_{:" p1":}+{:1/R_{:"p2:}:}` 

`1/{:R_2:}={:1/10:}+{:1/R_10:} = 2/10`

`R_2=5Omega`

 

Therefore:

 

`R_{:"total":}=10+5`

`R_{:"total":}=15Omega`

 

There are two switches organised in a semi-hierarchical relationship. By following the circuit, the candidate should determine that 'Group 2' will recieve power when the switches are in the position '2a'.

child_mcqs.description: What is the maximum total resistance for any combination of switch states?
child_mcqs.explanation: By following the possible paths on the circuit, the candidate should realise that only one 'group' of bulbs can be lit at any given time. From the previous question, the greatest total resistance is achieved when the switches are in position '2a'.  The resistance for this circuit is `30Omega`. The solution for this is provided in the explanation for question 1.

child_mcqs.description: If one of the light globes in the above circuit were connected directly to a 24 volt power supply, what current would it draw?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The power being supplied is at a constant voltage.

 

Using Ohm's law:

 

`I=V/R`

 

`I=24/10`

 

`I=2.4A`

child_mcqs.description: The switches are in state '2b' and the bulb at the top of 'group 3' is removed from its socket. What happens to the total resistance of the circuit?
child_mcqs.explanation:
The solution to this question may seem a little counter-intuitive, as one may think that removing a resistive component from a circuit would reduce total resistance. However, this is not the case because the component being removed is part of a paralell assembly.

 

 As explained in question 1, the total resistance of 'Group 3' is `15Omega`. 

 

When the bulb at the top of 'Group 3' is removed, the total resistance becomes:

 

 `R_{:"total":}=R_1+R_2`

 `R_{:"total":}=10+10=20Omega`

 

Therefore, the removal of the indicated light bulb increases the total resistance of the circuit.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
A key feature of the periodic table is that it organizes elements into groups, which comprise elements of similar properties, and periods, each of which contains elements that can be paired with respect to properties with others from other periods. Elements in the same group (barring those of the f-block) share the same number of valence shell electrons – for example, all Group 1 elements contain a single electron in their outer shell, and all Group 2 elements contain two electrons in their outer shell.

The organization of the periodic table stems from the manner in which electrons are configured. Electron configuration can be best summarised using quantum numbers – each electron in an atom can be assigned a unique set of four quantum numbers:

  • The principal quantum number n describes the energy level of an electron, that is, the electron shell in which it resides. The value for n is restricted to whole numbers 1 or greater
  • The azimuthal quantum number l gives the angular momentum of an electron. This describes the shape of the orbital the electron resides in, progressing from s subshells to p, to d and f. The value for l is restricted to integers from 0 to n-1
  • The magnetic quantum number ml describes the orientation of an orbital in space. Values can range from –l to l
  • The spin projection quantum number ms describes the spin of an electron, and has a value of either +½ or -½

Orbitals are filled in order of ascending n+l, such that, as an example, the 4s orbital, for which n= 4 and l= 0 will fill before the 3d, for which n= 3 and l= 2. 

Orbitals can also possess nodes, places wherein electrons cannot be found. These are divided into radial and angular nodes. Radial nodes are hollow spheres of radius r centred at the nucleus, numbering n - l - 1, whereas angular nodes are flat planes numbering l.

child_mcqs.description: What is the minimum number of nodes an orbital can possess?
child_mcqs.explanation: The correct answer is A - the 1s orbital has n = 1 and l = 0, thereby having 1 - 0 - 1 = 0 nodes. This is most easily seen when working backwards from the two equations for each type of node: radial nodes = n - l - 1, and angular nodes = l. Thus, total nodes = n - l - 1 + l = n - 1. It can thus be seen that for n = 1, there will be zero nodes. This question is a great example of how prior chemistry knowledge is not necessary, but speeds up the process markedly, as students aware of orbital shapes would answer this question without needing the preamble.

child_mcqs.description: Shown below is the 95% inclusion surface (that is, the space in which a given electron can be found 95% of the time) of the 3s orbital, with the nodes (if there are any) not shown. Which of the following statements is true?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Answer B is incorrect, as the 3s orbital has no angular nodes (l = 0).

Answer C is incorrect as there is no 2d orbital (l cannot equal 2 if n = 2).

Answer D is incorrect as there are only 10 possible electrons for which n = 1 or 2.

Answer A is correct as the 3s orbital has 2 radial nodes (3 - 0 - 1 = 2), and thus two spheres centred on the nucleus in which electrons cannot be found.

answers.description: There exists two values of r for which electrons cannot be found at a distance r from the nucleus
There exists one flat plane of space wherein an electron cannot be found
The 3s orbital will be filled before the 2d orbital
12 electrons will fill lower energy orbitals before the 3s is filled

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
Dinitrogen pentoxide is a white solid formed by the dehydration of nitric acid by phosphoric (V) acids:

P4O10(s) + 4HNO3(l) → 4HPO3(s) + 2N2O5(s)

Above room temperature, it is unstable and readily decomposes to form oxygen and nitrogen dioxide gas:

2N2O5(g) → 4NO2(g) + O2(g)

child_mcqs.description: If 8 moles of nitric acid were used, how many moles of oxygen gas would be produced upon decomposition?
child_mcqs.explanation: We can observe from the reaction stoichiometry, that for every mole of nitric acid used, half a mole of dinitrogen pentoxide is produced, which also equals twice the amount of oxygen gas produced. Therefore, the ratio of nitric acid:oxygen gas is 4:1, hence 8 moles of nitric acid would form 2 moles of oxygen gas.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following graphs accurately depicts the amount of consumption and formation over time, for the decomposition of dinitrogen pentoxide?
child_mcqs.explanation: We know from the reaction stoichiometry, that one mole of N2O5 produces half a mole of O2 and two moles of NO2. The graph should thus have the concentration of N2O5 decaying to zero, with O2 approaching half the initial level of N2O5 and NO2 approaching twice the initial level of N2O5.

child_mcqs.description: The decomposition of dinitrogen pentoxide was observed in a reaction vessel and the total pressure was recorded over time. Which of the following equations derives a relationship between the initial pressure of nitrogen pentoxide (p0), the total pressure (ptot) and the current partial pressure of nitrogen pentoxide (pN2O5)?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Dalton’s Law states that the total pressure is equal to the partial pressures of each individual gas.

Application of Dalton’s law of partial pressure gives:

ptot = pN2O5 + pO2 + pNO2

The question asks us for the relationship involving N2O5; therefore, we must use the reaction stoichiometry involving N2 and O2 so that they can be substituted for the final equation.

From the reaction stoichiometry, pNO2 = 4pO2, thus ptot can now be expressed as equalling pN2O5 + 5pO2.

The pN2O5 reacted (i.e. the difference between the initial amount of pressure and pN2O5) is also equal to ½ pO2, so p0 – pN2O5 = ½ pO2.

Now combining all the equations, we have:

ptot = pN2O5 + 5/2(p0 – pN2O5) = 5/2p0 – 3/2pN2O5

answers.description: ptot = p0 - pN2O5
ptot = 5/2 p0 + 7/2 pN2O5
ptot = 5/2 p0 – 3/2 pN2O5

child_mcqs.description: Why might the equation in Q3 be needed for a student observing the rate of decomposition of dinitrogen pentoxide?
child_mcqs.explanation: Observing the rate of a reaction requires concentrations of individual species. Since the reaction vessel recorded the total pressure, an equation involving the partial pressures of individual gases with respect to the total and initial pressure is thus necessary so that the amount of individual gases can be monitored.

answers.description: Because O2 and NO2 do not play a role in the decomposition reaction
To monitor the amount of individual gases since only the total pressure was recorded
To monitor the presence of an equilibrium reaction.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description: GABA (γ-amino butyric acid) is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS. Receptors are generally divided into two classes, metabotropic and ionotropic. Ionotropic receptors function by allowing or preventing the flow of ions across the cell membrane. The binding of two GABA molecules to the ligand-gated ionotropic GABAA receptors at the synapse leads to Cl- influx and hyperpolarisation, thereby reducing the likelihood of nervous transmission.

child_mcqs.description: If Ethanol sensitises GABAA receptors, which of the following options is a likely consequence of ethanol ingestion?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A is correct. If GABAA receptors are sensitised, we're looking for a general relaxation response associated with impaired nervous transmission. Sedation is thus the only reasonable option.

Many people will have first hand experience with these effects.

child_mcqs.description: Ethanol specifically binds to a site other than the active site where GABA itself binds, and acts to increase the function of GABAA receptors. Thus, Ethanol is a...?
child_mcqs.explanation:
C is correct. Essentially, it's a definition that needs to be known and understood well.

More specifically, Ethanol is deemed a positive allosteric modulator, although this is outside the scope of the question.

child_mcqs.description:
When an individual is too-frequently exposed to ethanol, to the extent where decreased expression of the receptors and impaired functionality of the receptor (and/or secondary pathways) exists, pharmacological alcoholism occurs.

One pharmaceutical option to assist 'quitting' is the use of acamprosate, which blocks GABAA receptors. Which is not a desirable effect of its use?
child_mcqs.explanation:
A is correct. Addiction therapy is a challenging field, which requires both pharmacological and psychological interventions (with the former affecting the latter). Unfortunately, part of the challenge is encouraging individuals to continue, which is not assisted by the development of deleterious symptoms (A is not unlike going 'cold turkey').

Thankfully, A tends not to occur, and acamprosate (along with many other pharmaceuticals such as naltrexone, baclofen and disulfiram) is generally well tolerated (and increases abstinence rates).

answers.description: Blocking GABAA receptors prevents hyperpolarisation, inducing unpleasant withdrawal symptoms and facilitating psychological deassociation.
Blocking GABAA receptors prevents hyperpolarisation, reducing the pleasant inhibitory effects of alcohol and facilitating psychological deassociation.
Blocking GABAA receptors promotes, through feedback mechanisms, a return to normal GABAA receptor expression and functionality.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
The glomerulus is a high-pressure capillary bed in the kidneys, fed and drained by arterioles. The diameter of the supplying afferent arteriole is normally larger than the draining efferent arteriole, creating the high hydrostatic (blood) pressure within the glomerulus. This pressure forces fluid and small blood components through a membrane into the Bowman's capsule of the renal nephron to form primary filtrate, which will eventually become urine. A correctly functioning renal filtration membrane should not allow proteins into the primary filtrate. 

The pressure in the glomerulus and thus glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is regulated by the diameter of the arterioles. Constriction of the afferent arteriole reduces pressure in the glomerulus; constriction of the efferent arteriole increases it. Relaxation and constriction of these vessels occurs in response to systemic blood pressure changes. 

Net filtration pressure (NFP) is determined by the hydrostatic and osmotic pressures of the two compartments, the glomerulus and the Bowman's capsule. A major determinant of osmotic pressure is protein. If the filtration membrane is functioning correctly, the osmotic pressure in the Bowman's capsule (BOP) can be considered negligible. The capillary hydrostatic pressure (CHP) favours filtration; the hydrostatic (filtrate) pressure in the Bowman's capsule (BHP) and the capillary osmotic pressure (COP) oppose filtration.

This is summarised as: NFP = CHP + BOP - BHP - COP

child_mcqs.description: What is the NFP in a healthy kidney if the blood pressure within the glomerulus is 60 mmHg with a 31 mmHg osmotic pressure in the capillaries and the fluid pressure from filtrate is 20 mmHg?
child_mcqs.explanation:
According to the passage, BOP is negligible in a healthy kidney = 0 mmHg. The pressures were defined in the passage and thus CHP = 60, BHP = 20, COP = 31

NFP = 60 + 0 - 20 - 31 = 9 mmHg

The other answers occur if the values given are assigned to the wrong pressures in the equation.

child_mcqs.description: What would the BOP be in a person with a net filtration pressure of 31 mmHg, a glomerular blood pressure of 60 mmHg, a 19 mmHg blood osmotic pressure and a fluid filtrate pressure of 20 mmHg?
child_mcqs.explanation:
NFP = CHP + BOP - BHP - COP
31 = 60 + BOP - 20 - 19

BOP = 31 - 60 + 20 + 19 = 10 mmHg

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information in the passage, what is the most likely explanation for an increased BOP?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that proteins are the main determinant of osmotic pressure and that the renal filtration membrane prevents proteins from entering the filtrate. Based on this information, the most likely explanation for protein in the urine is damage to the filtration membrane.

answers.description: High blood pressure causing constriction of the afferent and efferent arterioles

child_mcqs.description: What would happen to the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) if the efferent arteriole were to constrict, assuming that systemic blood pressure and afferent arteriole diameter remained unchanged?
child_mcqs.explanation: This was essentially explained in the passage. Glomerular pressure determines GFR. Constriction of the efferent arteriole increases glomerular pressure and thus GFR. As stated in the passage, the efferent arteriole drains the capillary bed and thus this pressure increase is a result of reduced drainage.

answers.description: Increase due to increased blood supply to capillaries
Increase due to decreased blood drainage from capillaries
Decrease due to increased blood supply to capillaries
Decrease due to decreased blood drainage from the capillaries

child_mcqs.description: Based on the information in the passage, which of the following will be most affected in a person suffering from protein malnutrition (but otherwise healthy)?
child_mcqs.explanation: Protein malnutrition results in less plasma proteins. The passage states that the major determinant of osmotic pressure is protein, making answers A and C incorrect. D is incorrect as it is determined by the integrity of the filtration membrane and is already considered to be 0 mm Hg - less plasma protein cannot make this more negative. Less protein in the blood would reduce capillary osmotic pressure = answer B

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
A polymer consists of a series of repeating units called monomers. A binary copolymer is built up of 2 different types of monomers.

It is important for a polymer chemist, when synthesizing polymers to understand the reactivity ratios of both monomers, in order to predict the overall structure of the polymer. The reactivity ratio, r, allows the chemist to predict which of the two monomers is likely to add onto the polymer chain, thus the ratio of each monomer that exists in a copolymer.

For example, a binary copolymer contains monomers 1 and 2. The reactivity ratio for monomer 1 is how likely monomer 1 adds onto another monomer 1 instead of monomer 2:

Therefore, the reactivity ratio for monomer 2 is:

Using these reactivity ratios, a graph of F1 vs f1 can be drawn, where F1 is the mole fraction of monomer 1 in the copolymer (i.e. the amount of monomer 1 present in the overall copolymer) and f1 is the mole fraction of monomer 1 in the co-monomer feed (i.e. the amount of monomer 1 used in the synthesis).

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following can be TRUE for a binary copolymer consisting of monomers 1 and 2?
child_mcqs.explanation: As r measures the reactivity ratio of a given monomer and its tendency to add onto the same or different monomer, any number is possible. For example, r = 0 would mean that the monomer can only add to a different monomer and r = 2 would mean that the monomer has a high tendency to add to another same monomer.

child_mcqs.description: Which experimental method should be used to calculate the reactivity ratios for a binary copolymer?
child_mcqs.explanation: The reactivity ratio depicts the likelihood of a monomer to add to another same monomer, thus if we use different amounts of one monomer and observe how much of that monomer is present in the polymer chain, we can then work out its reactivity ratio. Answers A, B and D do not explain how a reactivity ratio can be measured.

answers.description: Observe the time it takes to synthesise a polymer
Observe the polymer chain at different time intervals
Use different feed ratios of one monomer and observe its composition in the copolymer
Use different temperatures to activate the monomers

child_mcqs.description: For Questions 3-6, choose the correct reactivity ratios that match the F1 vs f1 graph for a binary copolymer consisting of monomers 1 and 2.
child_mcqs.explanation:
It is important for this question and the following questions to consider what the reactivity ratio means carefully - the answer is expanded more for this one than the others as an example.
r1 > 1, r2 <1: In this case, if we have monomer 1 at the end of the chain, it is more likely that  monomer 1 will add than monomer 2. If we have monomer 2 at the end of the chain, it is more likely that monomer 1 will add next than monomer 2. This will give a predominance of monomer 1, such that we would expect F1 to be greater than f1 i.e. an over-representation of monomer 1 in the chain. 
r1 = 0, r2 >1: In this case, if we have monomer 1 at the end of the chain, only monomer 2 will add next. If we have monomer 2 at the end of the chain, it is more likely that monomer 2 will add next than monomer 1. This will give a predominance of monomer 2, such that we would expect F1 to be less than f1 i.e. an under-representation of monomer 1 in the chain. 
r1 = r2 = 1: In this case, if we have monomer 1 or 2 at the end of the chain, it is equally likely that monomer 1 will add as monomer 2. This will give a linear relationship between F1 and f1 as seen in the graph
r1 > 1, r2 = 0: This is the extreme case of answer A, or the reverse of B - it is wrong for the same reasons.
