child_mcqs.description: What is the major point of difference between treating diabetes mellitus in older and younger patients?
child_mcqs.explanation: The first paragraph provides that ‘the care of older adults with DM is complicated by their clinical and functional heterogeneity’. This is contrasted to the similarities in treating younger and older patients mentioned in the preceding sentences. Hence, the answer is A. B is directly contradicted by the first sentence. Quality of life is mentioned in regards to older patients, but this does not imply that it is not important for younger patients. The lack of efficacy for treating older patients only holds true for certain treatments.

answers.description: The greater variability in treating older patients
The main objectives of the treatment regime
The greater need to ensure a quality of life in older patients
The lack of efficacy of available treatments for older patients

child_mcqs.description: What is the main reason for the focus upon blood pressure, aspirin therapy and lipid management in older patients?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is B. The three therapies are discussed in the third paragraph, which opens and discusses the role that the shorter life expectancy has on the treatment of older patients. It states that the shorter life span means that the benefits of glycaemic control are not realized for a substantial period of time, whereas the benefits of blood pressure, aspirin therapy and lipid management are achieved earlier. Hence, they are focused upon in older patients as they require a benefit in their limited remaining life. A and C are similar but are not proven by the article. A is untrue as the concern is not in achieving adequate glycaemic control, but the lack of benefits that achieving such control will have on patient outcomes. C is incorrect as these therapies are not necessarily ineffective or less effective in younger patients, it is just that they also have the option of glycaemic control open to them. D is not discussed.

answers.description: The difficulties of achieving adequate glycaemic control in older patients
The shorter life expectancy of older patients
The greater effectiveness of these therapies in older patients
The cost effectiveness of employing these therapies in older patients

child_mcqs.description: Which feature of older patients necessitates regular reassessment of treatment goals and management skills?
child_mcqs.explanation: All of the options are discussed in some form in the second paragraph relating to developing self-care and management skills. However, the best answer is the one that specifically addresses the requirement for regular reassessment. At the end of the second paragraph, it is provided that regular reassessment is particularly important for older patients, as their ‘functional and cognitive status may change over short periods of time’. Hence, the answer is A.

answers.description: The greater potential for a rapid change in physical or mental health
The difficulties of relying upon family members and caregivers
The lack of time available to diabetes mellitus educators on initial consultation
The greater cultural, religious and language diversity present in older patients

child_mcqs.description: According to the final paragraph, many treatments for older patients with diabetes mellitus are?
child_mcqs.explanation: The question specifically requires the reader to address the final paragraph, so that statements that, for instance, mention an ineffectiveness of glycaemic control treatment in earlier paragraphs are excluded. The final paragraph discusses quality of life, and the potential negative effects that treatments have on the patient’s quality of life. The passage also states that interventions are available that significantly reduce morbidity and mortality. Taken together, these lines exclude A and B and provide support for answer C. D is less preferable as the treatments are not deleterious as such, given that they improve certain outcomes, but rather they must be balanced against competing factors.

child_mcqs.description: The second paragraph provides support to the notion that?
child_mcqs.explanation: A key aspect of the paragraph, which flows through the entire article, is the heterogeneous nature of older patients with diabetes mellitus. This is clear from the range of options available depending upon the specific circumstances of the individual. Hence, the second paragraph may be taken to suggest that an individualized approach to patient treatment, rather than a standardized regime, is necessary. A is incorrect as there is clearly a role for doctors and traditional medicine notwithstanding the abilities of the DM educator, given treatments discussed elsewhere in the passage. B is incorrect, as the variability in treatment does not stem from the lack of knowledge, but the differences in patient circumstances. C may be required for some patients, but again given the heterogeneity that is a key point of the passage, is unlikely to be necessary for all patients.

answers.description: The role of doctors in managing diabetes mellitus is limited given the extensive abilities of the diabetes mellitus educator
The best mechanism of managing diabetes mellitus is ill-defined, requiring variability in its management
A regimented management regime should be imposed upon older patients with diabetes mellitus to ensure adequate compliance
Diabetes mellitus management should be tailored to the individual patient

stem_mcq.title: Unit 10
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the extract from the 'Xenofeminism: A Politics for Alienation'. In this passage XF is short for Xenofeminism.
 
Why is there so little explicit, organized effort to repurpose technologies for progressive gender political ends? XF seeks to strategically deploy existing technologies to re-engineer the world.  Serious risks are built into these tools; they are prone to imbalance, abuse, and exploitation of the weak.  Rather than pretending to risk nothing, XF advocates the necessary assembly of techno-political interfaces responsive to these risks.  Technology isn't inherently progressive.  Its uses are fused with culture in a positive feedback loop that makes linear sequencing, prediction, and absolute caution impossible.  Technoscientific innovation must be linked to a collective theoretical and political thinking in which women, queers, and the gender non-conforming play an unparalleled role. 
 
The real emancipatory potential of technology remains unrealized.  Fed by the market, its rapid growth is offset by bloat, and elegant innovation is surrendered to the buyer, whose stagnant world it decorates.  Beyond the noisy clutter of commodified cruft, the ultimate task lies in engineering technologies to combat unequal access to reproductive and pharmacological tools, environmental cataclysm, economic instability, as well as dangerous forms of unpaid/underpaid labour.  Gender inequality still characterizes the fields in which our technologies are conceived, built, and legislated for, while female workers in electronics (to name just one industry) perform some of the worst paid, monotonous and debilitating labour.  Such injustice demands structural, machinic and ideological correction. 
 
Xenofeminism is a rationalism.  To claim that reason or rationality is 'by nature' a patriarchal enterprise is to concede defeat.  It is true that the canonical 'history of thought' is dominated by men, and it is male hands we see throttling existing institutions of science and technology.  But this is precisely why feminism must be a rationalism -- because of this miserable imbalance, and not despite it.  There is no 'feminine' rationality, nor is there a 'masculine' one.  Science is not an expression but a suspension of gender.  If today it is dominated by masculine egos, then it is at odds with itself -- and this contradiction can be leveraged.  Reason, like information, wants to be free, and patriarchy cannot give it freedom.  Rationalism must itself be a feminism.  XF marks the point where these claims intersect in a two-way dependency.  It names reason as an engine of feminist emancipation, and declares the right of everyone to speak as no one in particular.
http://www.laboriacuboniks.net/

child_mcqs.description: According to this passage, technology:
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage suggests that technology poses risks, but it does not say technology should be used rarely. The key sentences are: “Serious risks are built into these tools; they are prone to imbalance, abuse, and exploitation of the weak.  Rather than pretending to risk nothing, XF advocates the necessary assembly of techno-political interfaces responsive to these risks.” The use of the phrase “necessary assembly” shows that the authors believe that the use of technology is necessary. As the authors acknowledge the risk posed by technology and the way it is prone to abuse and exploitation C is incorrect. Technology (at least at the moment) does not provide a safe space for women, queers and the gender nonconforming. B is incorrect, there are no statements in the passage implying that technology is inherently conservative. Instead, the passage opens by talking about repurposing “technologies for progressive gender political ends,” talks about a possibility for “technoscientific innovation” where “women, queers, and the gender non-conforming play an unparalleled role” and that the “real emancipatory potential of technology remains unrealized.” Emancipatory means freeing or liberating. Therefore D is correct.

answers.description: Should be used carefully and rarely, because it is prone to imbalance, abuse, and exploitation of the weak.
Provides a safe space for women, queers and the gender nonconforming.
Can potentially provide emancipation for women, queers and the gender nonconforming.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is not one of Xenofeminism's aims?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states that the “ultimate task” is engineering technologies to “combat unequal access to reproductive and pharmacological tools” (evidence for A) and to avert “environmental cataclysm” (evidence for B). The passage asks “why is there so little explicit, organized effort to repurpose technologies for progressive gender political ends?” and stresses the emancipatory capacity of technology (evidence for D). There is evidence for all the options except C, so C is the correct answer. The nation state is not mentioned in the extract.

answers.description: To end unequal access to reproductive and pharmacological tools
To avert environmental cataclysm
To develop a rational, scientific nation state.

child_mcqs.description: A possible replacement for 'cruft' is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The section “cruft” appears in is: “elegant innovation is surrendered to the buyer, whose stagnant world it decorates.  Beyond the noisy clutter of commodified cruft, the ultimate task lies in engineering technologies. . .” Cruft is therefore used to describe the kinds of technology that the authors are not interested in. Therefore A is the best answer. B does not fit the dismissive tone of the sentence, C does not make grammatical sense. D does not make sense in the context of the sentence (money is used to buy commodified objects, it is not a commodity in itself).

child_mcqs.description: According to the passage, how can science, at this current moment, be characterised?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. The passage writes, “Science is not an expression but a suspension of gender.  If today it is dominated by masculine egos, then it is at odds with itself -- and this contradiction can be leveraged.” “At odds with itself” refers to something that is uneasy, unbalanced, or in conflict with itself. Equality is portrayed as a process in which “there [should be] no 'feminine' rationality, nor [should] there [be] a 'masculine’ one”, but there should be simple equality between both genders. Thus, we can infer that there is not currently equality (C is looking pretty good), but the overall interpretation of science is best described here: "Gender inequality still characterizes the fields in which our technologies are conceived”, ie. The field of science. The passage arguably suggests that women are exploited by science, and thus C is the best option.

answers.description: Having the potential to deal with some of the most pressing issues.

stem_mcq.title: Uni 11
stem_mcq.description:
- Prostaglandins, NSAIDs, and Gastric Mucosal Protection, John Wallace

“Mucosal defense” is a term used to describe the various factors and components that permit the mucosa to remain intact despite its frequent exposure to substances with a wide range of temperature, pH, and osmolarity, as well as to substances with detergent or cytotoxic actions, and bacterial products capable of causing local and systemic inflammatory reactions. It is important to realize that the gastric mucosa is not impervious to damage by these agents. The use of the term gastric mucosal barrier has often been misconstrued to suggest that this tissue is impenetrable. It was coined by Charles Code (36) to explain the relatively small amount of hydrochloric acid that “back-diffuses” into the mucosa. In fact, mucosal injury occurs regularly, but does not lead to clinically significant disruption of the function or even the “barrier” properties of the tissue. The reasons for this include the fact that there are several “layers” to mucosal defense, with secondary components becoming more important when more superficial components are breached, and because of a very rapid process of repair when damage to the epithelium occurs (191). Moreover, the various components of mucosal defense can be modulated by a number of endogenous substances, including prostaglandins. The net result is that the systemic circulation is protected from invasion by microbes, microbial products, and other toxins. On the other hand, there are certain circumstances in which mucosal defense is impaired, such as after administration of NSAIDs, thereby rendering the mucosa more susceptible to injury.

As alluded to above, mucosal defense is a dynamic process. In a healthy organism, the resistance of the gastric mucosa to injury is enhanced when irritants are present in the stomach, such as through an augmentation of mucosal blood flow and an efflux of mucus from surface epithelial cells. There are some conditions in which there is an impairment of these adaptive responses, rendering the gastric mucosa more susceptible to injury induced by luminal irritants.

The various levels of mucosal defense can be viewed in a structural sense, starting at the lumen and moving into deeper levels of the tissue. Which of these components will participate in a defensive response depends on the intensity of the challenge and the extent to which any toxin is able to diffuse into the mucosa.

child_mcqs.description: The administration of NSAIDs
child_mcqs.explanation: It is provided that NSAIDs impair the mucosal defence, rendering it more susceptible to injury. Hence, NSAIDs do not cause the mucosal injury, but increase the chances of a toxic substance being able to cause injury

answers.description: Is used to decrease the chances of mucosal injury

child_mcqs.description: In a healthy organism, luminal irritants?
child_mcqs.explanation: In the second paragraph, it is provided that resistance of the gastric mucosa to injury is enhanced when irritants are present in the stomach, indicating that they stimulate an increase in the defensive response. A is clearly incorrect given the following sentence. The article does not state that luminal irritants are necessarily endogenous, and it is highly likely that they are frequently ingested substances. Luminal irritants are not described as impairing the mucosal defence, but rather they are capable of injuring a mucosa that is an already impaired.

answers.description: Are incapable of damaging the gastric mucosa

child_mcqs.description: Why does mucosal injury not always result in clinically detectable mucosal injury?
child_mcqs.explanation: It is provided that ‘mucosal injury’ occurs regularly, but does not lead to clinically significant disruption of the properties of the tissue. The following sentence explains that this is because other components of the mucosal defence prevent the development of a clinically significant response. This is answer A. B is untrue, as it is not stated that only NSAIDs can cause clinically significant injury. C may be correct, but does not answer the question. D is not supported by the passage

answers.description: Mucosal injury can often refer to damage to the superficial components of the mucosa only
A clinically detectable injury appears only after the administration of NSAIDs, whereas a number of substances may cause mucosal injury
A clinically detectable injury includes only instances in which the mucosa has been damaged by cytotoxins or inflammatory reactions
Mucosal injury quickly resolves, such that it may be difficult to link a clinically detectable mucosal injury to the initial mucosal injury

child_mcqs.description: Prostaglandins
child_mcqs.explanation: Prostaglandins are an endogenous substance that modifies the various components of the mucosal defence. This is stated explicitly in the sentenct, "the various components of mucosal defense can be modulated by a number of endogenous substances, including prostaglandins". Hence, the answer is C.

answers.description: Form the primary layer of the mucosal defence
Appear following mucosal invasion by microbes, microbial products and other toxins
Alter the elements of the mucosal defence

stem_mcq.title: Unit 12
stem_mcq.description: -

child_mcqs.description: The tone of this cartoon is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The angel in the cartoon responds to the headlines at the top of the cartoon. By doing so, the angel establishes the cartoon's tone and suggests to the readers a way they can respond to the headlines. The angel looks sad and shocked so D is the best answer. The seriousness of the cartoon's subject matter means it is not lightly humorous, nor is it witty. At the same time the cartoon is not bitterly cynical; it does not respond to the headlines with a bitter joke (for instance) but with an angel looking shocked and sad.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following is the least plausible reason for the flowers being in the cartoon?
child_mcqs.explanation: A and B are both plausible. The flowers contribute to the cartoon's uneasy humour by contrasting with the headlines, and in the context of headlines about bombs and death, they suggest the flowers at funerals. This leaves C and D. C is more plausible than D: the flowers provide the only real colour in the cartoon, with the image of the angel in grey. As for D, it is the one answer that does not suggest how the flowers contribute to the overall meaning or appearance of the cartoon. There is no evidence that the cartoonist is trying to appeal specifically to feminine readers through using flowers. D is therefore the answer.

answers.description: To suggest a whimsy and a lightness which provides a contrast to the grimness of the headline
To add colour to the cartoon

stem_mcq.title: Unit 13
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is from Kate Chopin's 'The Story of an Hour'. Mrs Mallard has just learned of her husband's death.

There stood, facing the open window, a comfortable, roomy armchair. Into this she sank, pressed down by a physical exhaustion that haunted her body and seemed to reach into her soul.

She could see in the open square before her house the tops of trees that were all aquiver with the new spring life. The delicious breath of rain was in the air. In the street below a peddler was crying his wares. The notes of a distant song which some one was singing reached her faintly, and countless sparrows were twittering in the eaves.

There were patches of blue sky showing here and there through the clouds that had met and piled one above the other in the west facing her window.

She sat with her head thrown back upon the cushion of the chair, quite motionless, except when a sob came up into her throat and shook her, as a child who has cried itself to sleep continues to sob in its dreams.

She was young, with a fair, calm face, whose lines bespoke repression and even a certain strength. But now there was a dull stare in her eyes, whose gaze was fixed away off yonder on one of those patches of blue sky. It was not a glance of reflection, but rather indicated a suspension of intelligent thought.

There was something coming to her and she was waiting for it, fearfully. What was it? She did not know; it was too subtle and elusive to name. But she felt it, creeping out of the sky, reaching toward her through the sounds, the scents, the color that filled the air.

Now her bosom rose and fell tumultuously. She was beginning to recognize this thing that was approaching to possess her, and she was striving to beat it back with her will--as powerless as her two white slender hands would have been. When she abandoned herself a little whispered word escaped her slightly parted lips. She said it over and over under her breath: "free, free, free!" The vacant stare and the look of terror that had followed it went from her eyes. They stayed keen and bright. Her pulses beat fast, and the coursing blood warmed and relaxed every inch of her body.

She did not stop to ask if it were or were not a monstrous joy that held her. A clear and exalted perception enabled her to dismiss the suggestion as trivial. She knew that she would weep again when she saw the kind, tender hands folded in death; the face that had never looked save with love upon her, fixed and gray and dead. But she saw beyond that bitter moment a long procession of years to come that would belong to her absolutely. And she opened and spread her arms out to them in welcome.

child_mcqs.description: Throughout this story, Mrs Mallard's reaction to her husband's death is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: In the story Mrs Mallard changes from being weighed down with grief and crying (at the beginning), to feeling free (at the end). Therefore B is the best answer. A, C and D all are incorrect because they suggest that she has a single reaction to his death, rather than moving from one mood to another.

answers.description: Moving from one mood to another.

child_mcqs.description: Which sense is not used in the description of Mrs Mallard's experience when she feels something reaching at her from the window?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states: “There was something coming to her and she was waiting for it, fearfully. What was it? She did not know; it was too subtle and elusive to name. But she felt it, creeping out of the sky, reaching toward her through the sounds, the scents, the color that filled the air.” She “felt it” so this suggests touch, she notices it in the “sounds, the scents, the colour” that filled the air, so hearing and smelling are used. Taste is not used here, so A is the best answer. Though she tastes the delicious air, this is not at the point when she is feeling something reaching out at her from outside the window.

child_mcqs.description: At the end of the story Mrs Mallard's state of mind is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The key word in the question is “end of the story”. At the end of the story, though Mrs Mallard anticipates she will grieve for her husband again, “she saw beyond that bitter moment a long procession of years to come that would belong to her absolutely. And she opened and spread her arms out to them in welcome.” The best description of her state of mind at the end of the story is therefore A, eager.

child_mcqs.description: What is the significance of the repeated words "free, free, free"?
child_mcqs.explanation: Option C is correct. There is no evidence for A or D. While Mrs Mallard feels free of her husband after his death, there is no suggestion in this passage that he was a tyrant. Option B is unsuitable because the implication of her husband running a “tyranny”, is a bit too harsh for the description of “never looked… with love upon her, fixed and grey and dead”. Therefore C is the best answer, and this is supported by the story, where Mrs Mallard welcomes the “years to come that would belong to her absolutely”.

answers.description: They were the last words of Mrs Mallard's dead husband.
Mrs Mallard is finally free of her husband's tyranny.
Mrs Mallard is finally free to have an independent life.
Mrs Mallard is able to join her husband in death.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 14
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefuly the extract below from Edmund Burke's Reflections on the Revolution in France (1790), written during the revolution in France.

In the present disappearance of coin, no person could think it the same country in which the present minister of the finances has been able to discover fourscore millions sterling in specie. From its general aspect one would conclude that it had been for some time past under the special direction of the learned academicians of Laputa and Balnibarbi. Already the population of Paris has so declined, that M. Necker stated to the National Assembly the provision to be made for its subsistence at a fifth less than what had formerly been found requisite. It is said (and I have never heard it contradicted) that a hundred thousand people are out of employment in that city, though it is become the seat of the imprisoned court and National Assembly. Nothing, I am credibly informed, can exceed the shocking and disgusting spectacle of mendicancy displayed in that capital. Indeed, the votes of the National Assembly leave no doubt of the fact. They have lately appointed a standing committee of mendicancy. They are contriving at once a vigorous police on this subject, and, for the first time, the imposition of a tax to maintain the poor, for whose present relief great sums appear on the face of the public accounts of the year. In the mean time the leaders of the legislative clubs and coffee-houses are intoxicated with admiration at their own wisdom and ability. They speak with the most sovereign contempt of the rest of the world. They tell the people, to comfort them in the rags with which they have clothed them, that they are a nation of philosophers; and sometimes, by all the arts of quackish parade, by show, tumult, and bustle, sometimes by the alarms of plots and invasions, they attempt to drown the cries of indigence, and to divert the eyes of the observer from the ruin and wretchedness of the state. A brave people will certainly prefer liberty accompanied with a virtuous poverty to a depraved and wealthy servitude. But before the price of comfort and opulence is paid, one ought to be pretty sure it is real liberty which is purchased, and that she is to be purchased at no other price. I shall always, however, consider that liberty as very equivocal in her appearance, which has not wisdom and justice for her companions, and does not lead prosperity and plenty in her train.

child_mcqs.description: From this passage, it can be concluded that Burke's attitude towards the French Revolution is:
child_mcqs.explanation: Burke talks about the revolution as resulting in a "wretchedness of the state" and not being accompanied with wisdom or prosperity, so he is certainly not neutral (D) or positive about it (A) and (C). Therefore (B) is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description:
According to this extract, revolutionary Paris:

I. Is full of beggars

II. Is a site of massacres

III. Has a declining population

IV. Is governed by wise and scholarly people.
child_mcqs.explanation: I is true. Burke writes, "Nothing, I am credibly informed, can exceed the shocking and disgusting spectacle of mendicancy displayed in that capital." "Mendicancy" here refers to a large number of beggars. You can guess this is the case from Burke mentioning widespread unemployment and then going on to talk about "a tax to maintain the poor," and how the leaders have "clothed" the people in "rags". While II is arguably true of revolutionary France, it is not something Burke talks about in this passage. III is true, Burke writes "Already the population of Paris has so declined." IV is untrue, Burke is being sarcastic when he talks about the leaders in this passage. His last sentence suggests that the equivocal "liberty" that the revolution has bought does not have "wisdom and justice for her companions" so Burke definitely does not think that the revolutionary leaders are wise. B is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: In this passage, what is the best substitute for "indigence"?
child_mcqs.explanation: "Indigence" means extreme poverty. Burke writes: "They tell the people, to comfort them in the rags with which they have clothed them, that they are a nation of philosophers; and sometimes, by all the arts of quackish parade, by show, tumult, and bustle, sometimes by the alarms of plots and invasions, they attempt to drown the cries of indigence, and to divert the eyes of the observer from the ruin and wretchedness of the state." The use of words like "rags" and "ruin and wretchedness" suggest he is talking about poverty, as does his stress on the unemployment and widespread poverty of the people throughout the passage. (A) does not make as much sense in the context of the passage. The "they" Burke is talking about here is talking about the leaders of the revolution (leading the political unrest), so it's unlikely that they would be trying to drown out political unrest. There is no evidence for (C) or (D) in the passage.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following qualities does Burke not associate with the French revolution?
child_mcqs.explanation: Burke's mention of "rags" "indigence", beggars and widespread poverty, discussed in the questions above shows that he definitely associates the revolution with poverty (A). His second last sentence: "one ought to be pretty sure it is real liberty which is purchased" points to how Burke does not believe that the French Revolution brings with it a "real liberty," suggesting that Burke does associate the French Revolution with limited liberty - if he associates it with liberty at all (D). There are suggestive connections between the French Revolution and theatrics (C) when Burke writes, how its leaders practice "all the arts of quackish parade, by show." Burke never associates the French Revolution with wisdom, in the passage he argues that it is the opposite to wisdom, saying that the liberty the revolution does not have "wisdom and justice for her companions." Therefore (B) is the best answer.

child_mcqs.description: The last sentence contains an:
child_mcqs.explanation: The last sentence is: "I shall always, however, consider that liberty as very equivocal in her appearance, which has not wisdom and justice for her companions, and does not lead prosperity and plenty in her train." (C) does not make grammatical sense (the sentence does not contain an satire). There is not a pun (or a play on words) in this sentence, so (D) is not the best answer. There is not a simile here either. Burke is using figurative language, speaking about liberty as a "her" but this is personification rather than a simile. A simile involves describing something by saying it is like something else (A). The last sentence does contain an aphorism or a pithy/witty observation that (apparently) contains a general truth. Therefore (B) is the best answer.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 15
stem_mcq.description: Review the chart below carefully and answer the following questions:

child_mcqs.description: Of the following, which thinker or thinkers had only a "probable" influence on Charles Darwin's theory and was at large before 1800?
child_mcqs.explanation: Of the scientists/thinkers listed, the only two that are connected to Darwin via broken, or "probable" arrows are de Maillet and Matthew. Since Matthew was at large after 1800, de Maillet (D) is correct. Note that de Maillet had a "probable" influence on Darwin indirectly, through his influence on  Buffon, who was also indirectly connected to Darwin by others.

child_mcqs.description: Judging by this diagram, which of the following philosophers or scientists was the most influential on Charles Darwin's thought?
child_mcqs.explanation: This is a tricky question. First eliminate Kant, who is only connected to Charles Darwin via a broken line. Then you are left with three thinkers/scientists who are connected to Charles Darwin via a black, unbroken line. Lamarck, however, not only influences Darwin directly, but influences two scientists who have a personal influence on Darwin (Grant and Lyell). Therefore Lamarck is the most logical answer (B).

child_mcqs.description: According to this diagram how many scientist/philosophers had a direct, evidenced influence on Charles Darwin and advocated a more internal idea of evolution than the one he put forward?
child_mcqs.explanation: To answer this question, count the number of names to the left of Charles Darwin (using the internal/external axis), that are directly connected to him with a black arrow (since the question asks for direct influence). This gives us four names so B is correct.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 16
stem_mcq.description:
Review the cartoon below and answer the following questions:

Leunig

child_mcqs.description: The tone of this cartoon is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The question in the text of this cartoon is a variation on the "half full or half empty?" question (usually asked about a glass of a drink that has been half consumed and used to distinguish between the optimist who says it is half full, and the pessimist, who characterises it as half empty). The text asks if the glass is half broken or half fixed, but the potential optimism (optimism meaning looking on the bright side) of the question is humorously undermined by the cartoon showing a glass on the ground, completely smashed. Therefore A is not the best answer. The man gazes at the glass sadly. The cartoon implies that the text above asks a stupid question, the cartoon is therefore not speculative, or questioning (option D). The glass is not just half broken, but completely broken. Therefore B is the best answer. The cartoon's tone can be described as  pessimistic (the cartoonist suggests that the world is in a very bad state), There is no evidence for C.

child_mcqs.description: The woman in purple is best described as:
child_mcqs.explanation: The woman's expression, and her mouth open, suggests that she is speaking the words in the text above.  The cartoon, through the smashed glass, suggests that her question is a stupid question: the glass isn't half broken it is completely smashed, and therefore a completely pessimistic view is the only rational way of approaching the world (as discussed in Q1). The woman is not suggested in the cartoon to be insane or distressed.  While she is probably happy (A) and possibly drunk (D), these options do not show an understanding of the cartoon's joke. The cartoon suggests she is approaching the world from the wrong perspective (but not to the extent that she is insane, as option B offers). Therefore, C is the best answer. The woman, expecting the glass to be 'half fixed' is unrealistically optimistic.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 17
stem_mcq.description:
The following passage is from Jane Austen's unfinished novel, Sanditon. Mr Parker, who has sprained his ankle on the road near the Heywood's house, is being looked after by the Heywood family.

The acquaintance, thus oddly begun, was neither short nor unimportant. For a whole fortnight the travellers were fixed at Willingden, Mr. Parker's sprain proving too serious for him to move sooner. He had fallen into very good hands. The Heywoods were a thoroughly respectable family and every possible attention was paid, in the kindest and most unpretending manner, to both husband and wife. He was waited on and nursed, and she cheered and comforted with unremitting kindness; and as every office of hospitality and friendliness was received as it ought, as there was not more good will on one side than gratitude on the other, nor any deficiency of generally pleasant manners in either, they grew to like each other, in the course of that fortnight, exceedingly well.

Mr. Parker's character and history were soon unfolded. All that he understood of himself, he readily told, for he was very open-hearted; and where he might be himself in the dark, his conversation was still giving information, to such of the Heywoods as could observe. By such he was perceived to be an enthusiast on the subject of Sanditon, a complete enthusiast. Sanditon—the success of Sanditon as a small, fashionable bathing place, was the object for which he seemed to live. A very few years ago, it had been a quiet village of no pretensions, but some natural advantages in its position and some accidental circumstances having suggested to himself, and the other principal landholder, the probability of its becoming a profitable speculation, they had engaged in it, and planned and built, and praised and puffed, and raised it to something of young renown; and Mr. Parker could now think of very little besides.

The facts which, in more direct communication, he laid before them were that he was about five and thirty, had been married—very happily married—seven years, and had four sweet children at home; that he was of a respectable family and easy, though not large, fortune; no profession—succeeding as eldest son to the property which two or three generations had been holding and accumulating before him—that he had two brothers and two sisters, all single and all independent—the eldest of the two former indeed, by collateral inheritance, quite as well provided for as himself.

child_mcqs.description: When the passage states "where he might be himself in the dark, his conversation was still giving information" the author implies that:
child_mcqs.explanation: The key word here is "implies" telling you that this question is asking you to read between the lines. This question requires you to notice how the quote, "All that he understood of himself, he readily told, for he was very open-hearted; and where he might be himself in the dark, his conversation was still giving information," laughs at Mr Parker's expense. The narrator implies that Mr Parker is in the "dark" about a great deal of his own character, traits that can be easily observed after having a conversation with him. Therefore C is the best answer.

answers.description: Mr Parker does not have any secrets.
Mr Parker's knowledge about himself is limited.

child_mcqs.description: From this passage it can be assumed that Sanditon is:
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage states: "Sanditon—the success of Sanditon as a small, fashionable bathing place, was the object for which he [Mr Parker] seemed to live. A very few years ago, it had been a quiet village of no pretensions, but some natural advantages in its position and some accidental circumstances having suggested to himself, and the other principal landholder, the probability of its becoming a profitable speculation." Since there is another principal landholder, Mr Parker is not the only owner of Sanditon. Therefore A is incorrect. The passage states that Mr Parker wants Sanditon to become a fashionable seaside holiday resort, not that it actually is one yet, which implies that B is incorrect. Sanditon was "a quiet village of no pretensions" a "few years ago" - implying it has become more than a quiet village now now. This suggests that C might not be the best answer. D is correct: the passage states that Mr Parker and the other landholder speculate on Sanditon, seeing it as potentially "profitable".

answers.description: A seaside town owned entirely by Mr Parker.

child_mcqs.description: When Mr Parker is described as an "enthusiast" on the subject of Sanditon, what does this mean?
child_mcqs.explanation: All these answers are to some degree true. The question requires you to carefully work out what the passage means by "enthusiast." After describing him as an enthusiast, the passage states: "Sanditon—the success of Sanditon as a small, fashionable bathing place, was the object for which he seemed to live." This suggests that Mr Parker's enthusiasm for Sanditon extends beyond talking eagerly about it (A and D) and that B is the best answer. There is no evidence in the passage that Mr Parker is deluded (C).

answers.description: He is obsessed with turning Sanditon into a fashionable seaside resort.

child_mcqs.description: What is the best description of the narrator of the passage's relationship to Mr Parker?
child_mcqs.explanation: The passage gently mocks Mr Parker's "enthusiasm" for Sanditon. He is presented as being open, warm but not particularly self-aware, being in the "dark" about his own character. This suggests that A is the best answer. The third person narrator is distanced from Mr Parker, knowing more about who he is than he knows himself, and also amused at his enthusiasm for developing Sanditon. While the author talks about how warm and open Mr Parker, is, suggesting affection, B is not as good an answer as A because it does not encompass the way the author laughs at Mr Parker. C is incorrect, there is no evidence that the narrator is puzzled or repulsed by Mr Parker. The narrator suggests that they understand Mr Parker better than he does himself. The narrator is also not angry and despairing at Mr Parker (or indeed at anyone).

stem_mcq.title: Unit 18
stem_mcq.description:
- New Spring, James McAuley

The slender willow lashes

Are faintly touched with green;

A moorhen calls, and splashes

Among the reeds unseen.

 

In time past unembittered

We walked along this bank;

I threw flat stones that skittered

And bounced before they sank.

 

Still full of clouds and willows

The water spreads its gleam;

A dabchick dives; the swallows

Circle above the stream.

 

If now our thoughts move sadly,

It’s not that we grow old,

But that we grow old badly,

Shamed at the heart, and cold.

 

Undimmed the fount of being

With freshness overflows;

Beasts drink their life unseeing;

The wise heart drinks and knows.

child_mcqs.description: The author describes childhood as?
child_mcqs.explanation: The poem is discussing life, both in terms of an individual’s lifespan and the collective notion of life on earth. It considers the concept of ageing, and also an individual’s self-awareness of their own ageing and the changes that they have undergone through their life. The second stanza discusses aspects of childhood, in which the author’s character is launching stones into the water, suggesting that they are carefree. This is demonstrated more clearly by comparing it to the fourth and fifth stanza, where the author is saddened with age and is aware of the finality of life. As such, the best answer is that childhood is carefree, and unaffected by the thoughts that come later in life.

child_mcqs.description: What is the author suggesting with the line ‘undimmed the fount of being with freshness overflows’?
child_mcqs.explanation: In the context of the article, the ‘fount of being’ is referring to life on Earth, and ‘with freshness overflows’ suggesting that life continues to persist. Whilst this could refer to A or C, it is likely that the sentence is referring to the notion that collective life on Earth persists, rather than that an individual's life continues forever. This is because the rest of the poem discusses that individuals do age, contrasted with the idea that life remains ‘fresh’. Hence, the fount of being remains fresh as new generations replace old generations, giving the answer A.

answers.description: New life on Earth is continually emerging
Water is the basis of life on Earth
An individual’s life never truly ends but persists in other forms
The lake remembers the author’s experiences as a child

child_mcqs.description: A point of difference between animals and humans is that
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is found in the last two lines, where it is stated that ‘[B]easts drink their life unseeing; The wise heart drinks and know’. In the context of the poem’s discussion of life and ageing, the author is suggesting that humans acutely feel their limited lifespan on Earth, whereas animals drink from the fountain of life without really questioning their place there. Whilst it could also be argued that this makes humans superior to animals, this is not really the author’s main message, as it is not substantiated elsewhere and does not serve to further the main idea theme of the feelings associated with ageing.

answers.description: Animals have a closer relationship with the land and water
Spring has a greater meaning to animals

stem_mcq.title: Unit 19
stem_mcq.description:
- The Policing of Dissent, Jackie Esmonde

Political expression and political protest are essential to a healthy democracy. The capacity to express disagreement with policies and social institutions is vital not only for keeping a check on power, but also for encouraging democratic reform and social equity. Emerging discontent, when expressed through organized social movements, has an effect on those in power and can lead to positive social and legal changes: "Presidents, when pushed by social movements, may enforce good laws. Judges, observing a changing temper in the society, may come forth with humane decisions." For those without direct access to political and economic power, protest is one of the few ways by which they can attempt to influence government. Protests show that there are large numbers of people who support a particular position and are willing to take to the streets in order to achieve their demands. Thus political protest-including workplace actions, mass mobilizations of people, and civil disobedience-is a key method for participating in the democratic process. From the abolition of slavery and the establishment of social welfare programs, to the creation of protections for trade unions and the dismantling of legislated segregation in the American South, pressure from below has often led to positive social change. The importance of protecting public space for political participation is reflected by the rights to freedom of expression, association, and peaceful assembly enshrined in the Canadian Charterof Rights and Freedoms.' Indeed, the Supreme Court of Canada has recognized that political expression is at the very heart of freedom of expression.

However, where political movements pose a challenge to the distribution of political and economic power, social movements can test the "innermost integrity of the government, as well as the limits of its boundaries." A state's response to such a challenge is a measure of its commitment to democratic principles, for the state possesses powerful tools with which to suppress dissent. It is important to remember that, while many of the movements mentioned above are now lauded for their role in creating a more just and equitable world, they were more commonly viewed as chaotic and criminal at the time that their struggles were waged. Today, a wave of protest activity in Canada has focused largely on the global justice movement. As in the past, protesters are more often met by police than by government representatives willing to hear their views. Indeed, there appears to be an inherent conflict between the right of protesters to publicly support a cause through demonstrations and the role of the police in maintaining public order.

child_mcqs.description: Why is 'a state's response to [social movements] a measure of its commitment to democratic principles'?
child_mcqs.explanation: The preceding sentence provides that social movements test the innermost integrity of government, as they challenge the distribution of political and economic power. Therefore, those in power are likely to wish to ensure that the desires of the social justice movement do not come to fruition. As such, only through a clear commitment to democratic principles will those in power of the state allow a movement opposing its own interests to proceed. This is answer C. B is mentioned, but this is not the author’s key message, given that the article states that these were ‘viewed as criminal’ without referencing actual harm, and that her article is in favour of allowing demonstrations to occur and hence is unlikely to provide strong reasons for denying the right to protest. D is also possible, but the state would likely have no concern with allowing people to voice views that are inconsistent if they did not threaten there own interests. A is incorrect as the right to social movements is fundamental to state democracy.

answers.description: The tenets of state democracy are inherently inconsistent with the right to social movements
Social movements may be chaotic and endanger society
Social movements are likely to counter the interests of those in power
Social movements espouse views inconsistent with those of the general population

child_mcqs.description: Which characteristic of judges does the article suggest?
child_mcqs.explanation: The article suggests that judges may make their decisions by taking into account discontent expressed through social movements, and hence are impacted upon by factors outside of the confines of the case. C is possible given this statement, although it requires a larger jump to suggest that the judges is 'biased' by taking account of public sentiment and hence B is preferable. A and D are possibly true, but are not expressed by the article.

answers.description: They support the interests of the state

child_mcqs.description: For what reason is the Supreme Court of Canada mentioned?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer must be gleaned from the context of the article as a whole and the surrounding circumstances. For instance, although the Supreme Court of Canada serves to notify us that the article probably relates to the Canada, it is also probable that the audience of the article was Canadian and hence this is not the main purpose of the Court’s inclusion. Similarly, the role of the justice system in potentially punishing protestors and in being a means to social change is mentioned throughout the article, yet the section in which the ‘Supreme Court of Canada’ is discussed is actually talking about the importance of public protest. The article is entrenching the importance of political protest by using the statement of a foremost institution (the Supreme Court of Canada) to support this view

answers.description: To entrench the importance of political protest
To notify the reader that the article relates to the Canadian justice system
To represent the punitive measures available to counter political protesters
To demonstrate the role of the judicial system in furthering social change

stem_mcq.title: Unit 20
stem_mcq.description:
Read carefully the following extract from Erasmus Darwin's poem on botany, 'The Loves of the Plants'.

 

        Descend, ye hovering Sylphs! aerial Quires,
        And sweep with little hands your silver lyres;
        With fairy footsteps print your grassy rings,
        Ye Gnomes! accordant to the tinkling strings;


5      While in soft notes I tune to oaten reed
        Gay hopes, and amorous sorrows of the mead.--
        From giant Oaks, that wave their branches dark,
        To the dwarf Moss, that clings upon their bark,


        What Beaux and Beauties crowd the gaudy groves,
10    And woo and win their vegetable Loves.
        How Snowdrops cold, and blue-eyed Harebels blend
        Their tender tears, as o'er the stream they bend;

        The lovesick Violet, and the Primrose pale
        Bow their sweet heads, and whisper to the gale;
15    With secret sighs the Virgin Lily droops,
        And jealous Cowslips hang their tawny cups.

        How the young Rose in beauty's damask pride
        Drinks the warm blushes of his bashful bride;
        With honey'd lips enamour'd Woodbines meet,
20    Clasp with fond arms, and mix their kisses sweet.--

        Stay thy soft-murmuring waters, gentle Rill;
        Hush, whispering Winds, ye ruflling Leaves, be still;
        Rest, silver Butterflies, your quivering wings;
        Alight, ye Beetles, from your airy rings;

Vegetable Loves l. 10. Linnaeus, the celebrated Swedish naturalist, has demonstrated, that all flowers contain families of males or females, or both; and on their marriages has constructed his invaluable system of Botany. [Erasmus Darwin's note].

child_mcqs.description: Judging from this extract, and the accompanying note, Darwin's poem is about:
child_mcqs.explanation: The question mentions the note, which is a big clue. In the note Darwin talks about how “Linnaeus, the celebrated Swedish naturalist, has demonstrated, that all flowers contain families of males or females, or both; and on their marriages has constructed his invaluable system of Botany.” Darwin’s celebration of “vegetable Loves,” or plant “marriages” is about botanical classification and plant reproduction. C is therefore the best answer.

answers.description: The way insects need flowers in order to live.

child_mcqs.description: What poetic device is the most important for the meaning of Darwin's poem?
child_mcqs.explanation: B is the best answer. As we talked about in A, Darwin’s poem is about Linnaeus' classification of plant reproduction. In this poem he writes about plant reproduction by talking about the "loves" or "marriages" of flowers. Therefore, he is metaphorically describing the reproduction of flowers in terms of human romance. Even if you didn't manage to work this out, you can deduce from the answers that the poetic devices listed in A, C and D are less likely to be important to the overall "meaning" of Darwin's poem.

answers.description: An extended metaphor comparing plant reproduction with human romance.

child_mcqs.description: Linnaeus' system of plant classification was based on:
child_mcqs.explanation: C is contradicted by the note which praises Linnaeus’ system of botany, based on plant “marriages”.  There is no evidence for D. This leaves A and B. This question tests your ability to distinguish between the figurative and the literal. Plants don’t actually get married and it doesn’t make sense to talk literally about a plant’s marital status. This leaves B, which is the correct answer.

answers.description: He did not have a system of plant classification.

child_mcqs.description: In this poem 'beaux' means:
child_mcqs.explanation: Darwin writes, “What Beaux and Beauties crowd the gaudy groves” and proceeds to talk about snowdrops and harebells (flowers). Therefore, he is most likely talking about flowers or plants. This leaves B and C. B makes more sense than C, especially since he is talking about these plants charming and “winning” their “vegetable loves” and proceeds to talk poetically about flowers in ways that suggest they are beautiful. Therefore B is the best answer. While “beaux” can mean male lovers, in this poem, Darwin is using the word to refer to male flowers.

stem_mcq.title: Uni 21
stem_mcq.description:
Examine the graph below and answer the following questions:

-

child_mcqs.description: According to the graph, which of the following theories are in the "Trough of Distinction Critiques" and take more than 10 years to reach the "Plateau."
child_mcqs.explanation: "Trough of Distinction Critiques" is on the horizontal axis. The theories that take more than 10 years to reach the "Planteau" are marked by triangles. Actor-network theory is the only theory that fits this category.

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following theories causes the highest expectations, according to the graph?
child_mcqs.explanation: The vertical axis marks the height of expectations. "Drone epistemology" is the highest on the vertical axis of all the theories listed.

sections.title: Section III - Reasoning in the physical and biological sciences

stem_mcq.title: Unit 1
stem_mcq.description:
Activity, a, is a measure of the chemical potential of a substance to do work. In a solution of given concentration, the activity is defined as the effective concentration. The relationship between the activity and concentration of ions in solution can be shown as follows:

where a = activity, γ = activity co-efficient, m = concentration (mol/L).

For an ideal solution, the activity is equal to the concentration. However, for non-ideal solutions, the activity is not equal to the concentration due to the effects of intermolecular forces present in solution. Therefore, the activity co-efficient is dependent on the ionic strength of ions in solution, in order to correct for these interactions.

I is the ionic strength (mol/L) and is the sum of all ions in a chemical species multiplied by their respective concentrations:

where c = concentration of the ion and z = charge on the ion.

For example, the ionic strength of a 0.1 M solution of NaCl would be 0.1 M. This is because the concentration of both ions is 0.1M, and the charge of each ion is 1, so that I = 1/2*[0.1*12 + 0.1*12].

child_mcqs.description: What concentration (in mol/L) must a solution of calcium chloride be in if its ionic strength is 0.3 mol L-1?
child_mcqs.explanation:
CaCl2 dissociates to form Ca2+ and 2Cl- ions. Therefore if the concentration of CaCl2 is x, then the concentration of Ca2+ ions is x and the concentration of Cl- ions is 2x. Ca2+ has a charge of 2 and Cl- has a charge of 1 (note that the positive and negative signs are not necessarily as the charge is squared in the equation). The ionic strength is 0.3 mol/L

Substituting this into the equation given:

0.3 = ½ [(22 * x) + (12 * 2x)]
0.3 = ½(6x)
0.3 = 3x
0.1 = x

Therefore, x = 0.1.

child_mcqs.description: The concentration of a solution of calcium sulfate is double that of a solution of aluminium (III) oxide. What can be said about the ionic strength of the calcium sulfate solution compared to the aluminium (III) oxide solution?
child_mcqs.explanation:
First, we need to calculate the ionic strength of the aluminium (III) oxide (Al2O3) solution. We aren't given its concentration, so we just call its concentration x. The concentration of Al3+ ions is thus 2x, and of O2- ions is 3x:

I = ½ (32 * 2x + 22 * 3x) = 15x

If the concentration of calcium sulfate is double that of aluminium (III) oxide, then its concentration is 2*x = 2x. The concentration of both SO42- and Ca2+ ions is 2x. Therefore, its ionic strength is:

I = ½ (22 * 2x + 22 * 2x) = 8x

Therefore, the ionic strength of calcium sulfate is about half that of aluminium (III) oxide.

answers.description: The ionic strength of the calcium sulfate solution is approximately double that of the aluminium (III) oxide solution
The ionic strength of the calcium sulfate solution is approximately quadruple that of the aluminium (III) oxide solution
The ionic strength of the calcium sulfate solution is approximately half that of the aluminium (III) oxide solution
The ionic strength of the calcium sulfate solution is approximately a quarter that of the aluminium (III) oxide solution

child_mcqs.description: An aqueous solution of potassium bromide exhibits non-ideal characteristics. Which intermolecular force would be least important in explaining the deviation from ideal characteristics?
child_mcqs.explanation:
In a solution of potassium bromide, we know that there are water molecules, potassium and bromine ions present. The possible interactions in solution are:

- Water molecules and water molecules which gives hydrogen bonding

- Water and ion which gives ion-dipole bonding (as water is polar, it exhibits permanent dipoles as opposed to induced dipoles)

- Ion and ion which gives electrostatic attraction

It is somewhat debatable to what extent ion-induced dipole forces exist within this solution. Certainly, the presence of ions and water molecules would give random fluctuations in the permanent dipole moment of any given water molecule, but this may not strictly be considered an induced dipole moment. In any case, even if you consider all four of the forces given as answers to be present, ion-induced dipole would be the weakest, and so the least important in explaining deviation from ideal characteristics, which arises from intermolecular forces.

child_mcqs.description: The graph above shows that a solution of lithium iodide (LiI) is non-ideal, where activity > concentration at high concentrations. Which of the following explains why lithium iodide has a higher activity than an ideal solution under high concentration conditions?
child_mcqs.explanation: From the introduction, we are told that any deviation from an ideal solution is due to the effects of intermolecular forces, so we can infer that intermolecular forces are non-existent only in ideal solutions, hence C is untrue, as clearly LiI is not acting as an ideal solution. Attractive intermolecular forces means a decrease in the effective concentration of ions in solution as they participate in various interactions with the water molecules. As the effective concentration of ions in solution is increased, the ion-ion forces dominate and become net repulsive. This is hinted at in the previous question.

answers.description: The intermolecular forces in lithium iodide become strongly attractive
The intermolecular forces in lithium iodide become strongly repulsive
The intermolecular forces in lithium iodide become non-existent

stem_mcq.title: Unit 2
stem_mcq.description:
The process of breathing is entirely dependent on two principles:

1. The fluid layer between and produced by the pleural layers allows them to move relative to each other very easily, but resists them being pulled apart (adhesion force) e.g. wet glad wrap
If they were not held open by the pleural membrane attachment to the thoracic cavity walls, the lungs would collapse in response to recoil forces, due to

  • Elastic tissue force
  • Surface tension forces in alveoli

2. An increase in the volume of a container, all other things being equal, will result automatically in reduced pressure = Boyle's law: P1V1 = P2V2

Lung compliance is the distensibility of the lungs (stretchability) - the ease with which the lungs can expand. Specifically, lung compliance is a measure of the change in lung volume that occurs with a given change in transpulmonary pressure (the pressure difference between inside the alveoli and that in the pleural space). Compliance describes how much lung inflation can be achieved by a unit pressure increase. For a given change in pressure, the resultant change in volume depends on how "stretchy" the lungs are. Compliance is reduced by factors that produce resistance to distension. 

Elasticity is the tendency of the lungs to return to initial size after distension = recoil ability. The high content of elastin protein in the lungs means that lungs are very elastic and resist distension.

The characteristics of lung compliance are determined by the elastic forces of the lungs:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue
    • elastin and collagen content in lung tissue
    • accounts for 1/3 of total lung elasticity
  • Elastic forces caused by surface tension of the fluid lining the inside walls of alveoli
    • air-surface (fluid) interface
    • accounts for 2/3 of total lung elasticity
      • surface tension elastic forces of the lungs increase significantly when surfactant is not present in the alveolar fluid (surfactant = a group of certain proteins)

The diaphram produces volume changes of the lungs that lead to normal quiet inspiration. Deep inspiration or heavy breathing recruits accessory muscles of inspiration, including the sternocleidomastoid and external intercostal muscles. When these contract, the size of the thoracic cavity increases further. Inspiration requires energy; chronic lung disease results in the recruitment of accessory muscles for basic breathing, leading to constant fatigue. 

  • Inspiration: increased lung volume = reduced alveolar pressure → air moves into lungs

Expiration is a passive process reliant on lung elasticity - the recoil of elastic tissue and the tendency for alveoli to collapse. Forced expiration (active) recruits abdominal and internal intercostal muscles.

  • Expiration: reduced lung volume = increased alveolar pressure → air moves out of lungs

child_mcqs.description: Babies born before 30 weeks gestation (40 = full term) often develop respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). This is a condition in which the babies' lungs have an extreme tendency to collapse as they have not yet developed the ability to produce surfactant. Based on the information given, what is the best explanation for why their lungs tend to collapse?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Compliance = ability of the lungs to expand (stretch). Elasticity = tendency of the lungs to collapse (recoil). RDS is a tendency for the lungs to collapse, which would suggest that there is high elasticity and/or low compliance of the lung → answers B and C are incorrect. 

Elastin content and surface tension are both determinants of lung elasticity (recoil ability) and thus resist distension of the lungs (lower compliance). If elastin content were low, recoil ability would be reduced and lung compliance would be increased → answer D is incorrect. It is not expected that students know the composition of lung tissue, but they should be aware of what collagen and elastin are and that elastin is elastic. The passage states that elastin content is high in the lungs. 

2/3 of the lung's elastic properties are determined by surface tension, of which surfactant is the primary determinant (stated in passage). An inability to produce surfactant would significantly increase surface tension and thus lung elasticity, promoting collapse = answer A.

answers.description: High elastic forces in the lungs due to high surface tension
High lung compliance due to high surface tension
Low elastic forces in the lungs due to low elastin content of lung tissue
Low lung compliance due to low elastin content of lung tissue

child_mcqs.description: Emphysema is a common consequence of long-term smoking. The chemicals in smoke cause an inflammatory reaction in the lungs that results in the destruction of alveolar walls. Based on the information given, what is the best explanation for why patients with emphysema have trouble breathing?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Students are expected to know what alveoli are and that destruction of their walls would create larger air spaces within the lungs. 

Less surface = less surface tension = less elasticity. Further to this, destruction of lung tissue = less elastin/collagen = less elasticity → answers A and B are therefore incorrect. 

Reduced elasticity = reduced resistance to distension = easier expansion of lungs = increased lung compliance → answer C is correct. Patients with emphysema have trouble breathing as they are able to get air into their lungs but it becomes trapped there as they cannot force it out through recoil of lung tissue. This will eventually cause problems getting air in as the lungs become full of air, but this is not due to the compliance of the lungs.

answers.description: Increased lung compliance due to increased elasticity of the lung tissue
Decreased lung compliance due to increased elasticity of the lung tissue
Increased lung compliance due to decreased elasticity of the lung tissue
Decreased lung compliance due to decreased elasticity of the lung tissue

child_mcqs.description: How do patients with severe emphysema (i.e. high lung compliance and low elasticity) get enough air out of their lungs to inhale more air?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Although an awareness of these muscles is first year anatomy knowledge, it is not essential to answer this question as they are all stated in the passage. 

Moving air out of the lungs = expiration. Answers A and B are muscles of inspiration and thus are incorrect.

Passive expiration is dependent upon the elastic properties of the lungs as stated in the passage. A person with severe emphysema does not have enough elastic force to passively recoil their lungs. They use their accessory muscles of expiration = answer C

answers.description: Use their sternocleidomastoid and external intercostal muscles
Use their abdominal and internal intercostal muscles

child_mcqs.description: A person with restrictive lung disease has low lung compliance. According to Boyle's law, why does a person with restrictive lung disease have trouble breathing?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Low lung compliance = reduced ability to stretch the lungs = reduced ability to increase lung volume. 
Increasing lung volume is a requirement of inspiration initiation. Expanding the lungs reduces alveolar pressure (Boyle's law) so that it becomes lower than that of atmospheric pressure. Air follows its pressure gradient into the lungs = inspiration. Based on this, answers A and D are incorrect.

A person with restrictive lung disease and low lung compliance has difficulty with expanding their lungs to reduce alveolar pressure to initiate inspiration, so answer B is correct. 

Reducing the volume of their lungs would increase alveolar pressure (→expiration), but a person with low lung compliance would have high lung elasticity (inversely proportional) and thus this would not be the cause of their breathing difficulties.

answers.description: Reducing the volume of their lungs to reduce alveolar pressure is difficult
Increasing the volume of their lungs to reduce alveolar pressure is difficult
Reducing the volume of their lungs to increase alveolar pressure is difficult
Increasing the volume of their lungs to increase alveolar pressure is difficult

child_mcqs.description: Which of the following best explains why a person with restrictive lung disease has low lung compliance?
child_mcqs.explanation:
Collagen, elastin and surfactant are determinants of lung elasticity (recoil ability). Surfactant reduces the tendency for the lungs to recoil, so an increase in production would not reduce lung compliance (answer D). A reduction in elastin content would also reduce the elasticity of the lungs, increasing compliance (answer C). Alveolar wall destruction (answer B) was addressed in question 2 - it increases lung compliance.

Answer A is therefore correct - collagen content is stated in the passage as a determinant of lung elasticity and thus an increase in elasticity would reduce lung compliance. Further to this and beyond the knowledge expected of students at this level, collagen has a relatively high tensile strength and resists distension.

stem_mcq.title: Unit 3
stem_mcq.description: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an extensive interconnected network of membranous channels within a eukaryotic cell. ER comes in two forms: rough ER and smooth ER. The rough ER receives it name due to the fact that it is covered by ribosomes and conversely the smooth ER is so called because its membranes have no ribosomes attached to their surfaces. The smooth ER has various functions in the cytoplasm including the synthesis of lipids that become part of the cell membranes. In some cells, such as those of the liver, smooth ER membranes contain enzymes that convert drugs, poisons and toxic by-products of cellular metabolism into that substances that are not toxic. The rough and smooth ER membranes are connected, making the entire ER system a continuous network for interconnected channels in the cytoplasm. The relative proportions of rough and smooth ER reflect cellular activities in protein and lipid synthesis.

child_mcqs.description: What is the function of the rough endoplasmic reticulum?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is C. The passage states that rough ER contain ribosomes. Ribosomes are responsible for the creation of proteins. Ribosomes join together individual amino acids into a large chain which is called a protein.

child_mcqs.description: During an experiment, a scientist isolates a cellular membrane that is found to not contain ribosomes. What can be concluded?
child_mcqs.explanation: The answer is D. The only membrane that was mentioned that has ribosomes is rough ER. Since the membrane does not have ribosomes it could be smooth ER, the cell membrane, mitochondrial membrane, lysosome membrane, or any other membrane of a cell organelle (not including rough ER).

answers.description: The cell membrane is rough endoplasmic reticulum
The cell membrane is smooth endoplasmic reticulum
The cell membrane may be rough endoplasmic reticulum
The cell membrane may be smooth endoplasmic reticulum

child_mcqs.description: In humans, amino acid breakdown creates ammonia, which is toxic to cells. Ammonia is quickly converted urea by specialized cells in the liver. What is the most correct statement about these specialized cells?
child_mcqs.explanation: C is the correct answer. From the passage it explains that cells have their smooth and rough endoplasmic reticulum connected, so this implies that a cell will contain both smooth and rough ER. This makes A and B incorrect. The passage also states that the relative proportion of rough and smooth endoplasmic reticulum is dictated by cell function and since the stem states the specialized cells convert toxic ammonia the cells must have a high amount of smooth endoplasmic reticulum. Additionally, it would be worth understanding that rough ER makes internal proteins. All cells must have proteins so any cell, regardless of their specialization would have some amount of rough ER, so A must not be correct.

answers.description: They contain a large proportion of smooth endoplasmic reticulum
They contain a large proportion of rough endoplasmic reticulum

stem_mcq.title: Unit 4
stem_mcq.description:
Pairs of molecules can exhibit many different types of isomerism. The details of some of these types of isomers are described below:

Structural isomers are molecules with the same atoms, but different bonding arrangements. Pairs of structural isomers can differ greatly in regards to their physical and chemical properties.

Diastereomers have the same atoms and bonding pattern, but differ in their three-dimensional configuration. This may or may not be due to the presence of chiral carbons. Importantly, these differences in configuration between pairs of diastereomers cannot be rectified by the normal rotations along single bonds that take place within molecules. They have similar, but distinct, physical and chemical properties.

Enantiomers are similar to diastereomers, but are specifically defined as being non-superimposable mirror images of each other. Enantiomers, being mirror images, have identical physical properties as well as chemical (outside of biological systems). Most pairs of enantiomers also have the ability to differentially rotate plane polarized light. In solution, the chiral centre(s) of one enantiomer will rotate light in one direction, whereas the inverted chiral centre(s) of the other enantiomer will rotate light the same amount in the opposing direction. Where a chiral centre and its inverse are present in the same solution equally, the solution will not rotate light.

The geometry of chiral centres is denoted using the R/S system. Assigning a designation involves visualising the molecule such that the lowest priority attachment of the chiral carbon points directly away from the viewer. Doing so leaves the other three attachments pointed towards the viewer. These three attachments are then connected in an arc from highest priority to lowest priority. If the arc forms in a clockwise manner, the spatial arrangement around the chiral carbon is denoted R. If the arc forms in a counter-clockwise manner, the spatial arrangement is denoted S. Priority increases with the atomic number. Where the attachments to the chiral carbon have the same atomic number, the priority is determined by the highest atomic number of their attachments. In molecules with multiple chiral centres, the number of each chiral carbon is listed along with its configuration.

child_mcqs.description: Which type of isomer are the following pair of structures an example of?
child_mcqs.explanation: These two structures are in fact the same compound. In regards to the shifting of the double bonds within the ring, note that this is an example of an aromatic ring. Electrons are shared around the ring and all the bonds have the same character, midway between true single and double bonds. The drawing of single and double bonds in such structures is arbitrary, so long as they alternate.

child_mcqs.description: Though single enantiomers are produced in most biological reactions, most artificial reactions produce mixtures of enantiomers. Separating those enantiomers involves a process called chiral resolution. In chiral resolution, the enantiomeric mixture is allowed to react with an appropriate reagent. The products are then separated based on their physical properties, and finally the reaction is reversed to return relatively pure enantiomers. For chiral resolution to occur, what must the reagent be?
child_mcqs.explanation:
In the resolution process, the enantiomeric compounds are separated based on differing physical properties. This means that the compounds initially produced from the reaction of the two enantiomers with the reagent must be diastereomers of one another - if reaction of the enantiomeric mix with the reagent produced more enantiomers, we would again not be able to separate them as they would have the same physical properties. Structural isomers would not be produced as the two enantiomers undergo the same chemical reaction, and so form the same product with different chirality.

To generate a pair of diastereomers, the reagent itself can be an enantiomer or diastereomer. In either case, the resulting compounds will have different arrangements of their chiral centres that are not mirror images of each other (the definition of diastereomers). For example, if we have a mix of the R and S enantiomers of molecule A, and react them with the R enantiomer of molecule B, we will get an RR diastereomer of molecule C and an SR diastereomer of molecule C, and as these are diastereomers and not enantiomers they will be separable.

answers.description: One of a pair of enantiomers only
One of a pair of diastereomers only
One of a pair of either enantiomers or diastereomers

child_mcqs.description: An equal mixture of (2R,3S)-2,3,dibromo-2,3,dichlorobutane and (2S,3R)-2,3,dibromo-2,3,dichlorobutane is found to not rotate plane polarized light. After a chiral resolution reaction was performed (detailed in Question 2), the supposedly separated compounds also failed to rotate light. What is the most likely explanation for this observation?
child_mcqs.explanation: Drawing out both of the structures listed will reveal that there is a plane of symmetry in the middle of the molecule. This presence of a plane of symmetry within the molecule means that the inverse of each chiral carbon is always present in equal proportion. As such, no light rotation will ever be observed regardless of the purity of the enantiomers. Note also that these are in fact the same molecule.

answers.description: The resolution failed, leaving an equal proportion of each enantiomer in the “separated” solutions
The compounds are diastereomers, which do not rotate light
These particular enantiomers do not rotate light

stem_mcq.title: Unit 5
stem_mcq.description:
